Description: KDFWR WILL UTILIZE THIS GRANT TO MONITOR, RESEARCH, AND PROMOTE RUFFED GROUSE AND WILD TURKEY POPULATION AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT ACROSS THE STATE.
MANAGEMENT OF PUBLIC WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS AND WILDLIFE PROGRAMS INCLUDING TECHNICAL GUIDANCE, DEER, ELK, BEAR, GROUSE, TURKEY, SMALL GAME, MIGRATORY BIRDS, AND FURBEARERS.

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO ACQUIRE LAND IN ORDER TO PROTECT AND PERPETUATE ECOSYSTEMS THAT CONTAIN SIGNIFICANT FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES AND TO CONSERVE THE BIOLOGICAL DIVERSITY OF THE STATE OF MASSACHUSETTS. ONCE ACQUIRED LAND WILL PROVIDE PREMIUM OPPORTUNITIES FOR HUNTING, FISHING, TRAPPING, AND OTHER COMPATIBLE WILDLIFE RELATED RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES. ACTIVITIES TO BE CONDUCTED UNDER THIS GRANT INCLUDE PROJECT ADMINISTRATION, LAND SURVEYS AND APPRAISALS, LEGAL SERVICES, AND ACQUISITION OF REAL PROPERTY. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE THE PERMANENT PROTECTION OF OPEN SPACE IN MASSACHUSETTS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PUBLIC WHO USE AND APPRECIATE THESE NATURAL PLACES. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO COLLECT THE NECESSARY DATA RELATED TO FISHER POPULATION DYNAMICS IN NEW HAMPSHIRE TO AID IN SCIENCE-BASED DECISION MAKING FOR THIS SPECIES INTO THE FUTURE. FISHER POPULATIONS HAVE FLUCTUATED BETWEEN PERIODS OF DECLINE AND STABILITY OVER THE PAST 30 YEARS AND ABUNDANCE IS NOTABLE LOWER COMPARED TO DENSITIES OBSERVE DURING THE 1990S. FISHER HARVEST VIA REGULATED TRAPPING AND HUNTING HAVE BEEN GREATLY REDUCED DUE TO REDUCTIONS IN BAG LIMITS, SHORTENING OF THE HARVEST PERIOD, AND A DECLINE IN TRAPPER PARTICIPATION. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE CAPTURE, GLOBAL POSITION SYSTEM-MARKING, MONITORING, CARCASS COLLECTION, NECROPSY, AND TISSUE ANALYSIS OF FISHERS, AS WELL AS ANALYSIS OF DATA AND MODELING OF FISHER HABITAT USE AND SELECTION. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE EXPANDING THE DEPARTMENT S KNOWLEDGE OF FISHER POPULATION DYNAMICS AND MORTALITY FACTORS. THIS INFORMATION WILL INFORM FISHER MANAGEMENT TO ENSURE THAT THIS FURBEARER SPECIES IS MANAGED IN A HEALTHY AND SUSTAINABLE MANNER WAY CONSISTENT WITH BOTH PUBLIC EXPECTATION AND THE DEPARTMENT S MISSION. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PUBLIC WHO USE AND APPRECIATE FISHERS, INCLUDING TRAPPERS, WILDLIFE WATCHERS AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC, ALL OF WHOM BENEFIT FROM A HEALTHY ECOSYSTEM CAPABLE OF SUPPORTING BOTH PREY AND PREDATOR SPECIES. THIS PROJECT WILL BE COMPLETED THROUGH A SUBAWARD TO THE UNIVERSITY OF NEW HAMPSHIRE.

THIS GRANT WILL PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR HABITAT RESTORATION AND REHABILITATION PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION ACROSS THE STATE OF NEVADA. OVER THE LAST 30 YEARS NEVADA S HABITATS CHARACTERIZED AS MODERATE-TO-GOOD SHRUB AND GRASSLANDS HAVE DECREASED BY HALF WHILE AREAS CLASSIFIED AS BEING IN POOR CONDITION HAVE INCREASED FOUR-FOLD. DUE TO THESE NEGATIVE LANDSCAPE CHANGES, THERE IS A NEED TO ASSESS, PLAN, COORDINATE, AND IMPLEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND REHABILITATION PROJECTS DESIGNED TO RESTORE HEALTHY, FUNCTIONING SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEMS THAT ARE SPECIES-DIVERSE AND ECOLOGICALLY RESILIENT. NDOW BIOLOGISTS PLAN, CONSULT, AND IMPLEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND REHABILITATION PROJECTS ACROSS ALL LAND OWNERSHIPS THROUGHOUT NEVADA TO IMPROVE WILDLIFE HABITAT VALUES. SUBSEQUENTLY, WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND WILDLIFE DEPENDENT RECREATION AND VALUES BENEFIT.

SALMONELLA IS A BACTERIA THAT MAKES BOTH PEOPLE AND WILD BIRDS SICK. BIRDS TYPICALLY GET SICK AND DIE OF SALMONELLOSIS IN THE WINTER MONTHS, WHEN THEY COME TOGETHER IN GROUPS TO FEED ON BIRD FEEDERS, ESPECIALLY WHEN OTHER FOOD SOURCES ARE UNAVAILABLE. IN THE PAST TWO DECADES, THE FREQUENCY OF OUTBREAKS AND THE NUMBER OF BIRDS THAT DIE DUE TO SALMONELLA INFECTION HAVE INCREASED DRAMATICALLY. WE KNOW THAT SALMONELLA OUTBREAKS OCCUR IN THE WINTER AND WITH HIGHER FREQUENCY IN SOME BIRD SPECIES, BUT WE DO NOT KNOW WHY. NOR DO WE KNOW IF THERE ARE ANIMALS (BIRDS, RODENTS OR OTHER MAMMALS) THAT ARE CARRIERS AND CONTAMINATE THE FEEDERS. ONE OF THE BIRDS OF CONCERN ARE MOURNING DOVES WHICH FREQUENT FEEDERS AND ARE SUSCEPTIBLE TO CO-INFECTIONS OF SALMONELLA AND A PARASITE OF MAJOR CONCERN FOR THIS SPECIES. TO HELP CONSERVE BIRDS AND PROTECT PEOPLE FROM INFECTION, WE NEED TO PROVIDE THE PUBLIC WITH PRACTICAL RECOMMENDATIONS THAT THEY ARE WILLING TO ADOPT TO KEEP BOTH BIRDS AND THEMSELVES HEALTHY. PERSUADING THE PEOPLE TO CHANGE THEIR BEHAVIOR, ESPECIALLY IF THEY ARE PASSIONATE ABOUT HELPING AND FEEDING BIRDS, IS CHALLENGING. PART OF OUR STUDY WILL BE TO IDENTIFY WHAT MESSAGING OR COMMUNICATION WOULD PERSUADE THEM TO ALTER THEIR BIRD FEEDING BEHAVIORS. IN SUMMARY, WE WILL 1) IDENTIFY WHICH SPECIES ARE TRANSMITTING SALMONELLA AT BIRD FEEDERS, 2) LEARN MORE ABOUT HOW AND WHY SALMONELLA OUTBREAKS OCCUR, 3) UNDERSTAND WHY PEOPLE FEED BIRDS AND HOW THEY MANAGE BIRD FEEDERS TO PREVENT THE SPREAD OF SALMONELLA, AND 4) IDENTIFY POTENTIAL MESSAGING AND COMMUNICATION STRATEGIES THAT WILL PERSUADE PEOPLE WHO FEED BIRDS TO TAKE THE APPROPRIATE ACTIONS TO PROTECT BIRDS, OTHER ANIMALS AND THEIR FAMILY AGAINST SALMONELLA.

THIS GRANT FUNDS RESEARCH ON WILDLIFE SPECIES IN ORDER TO IMPROVE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AND ADD TO THE SCIENTIFIC UNDERSTANDING OF WILDLIFE SPECIES. STUDIES GATHER INFORMATION ABOUT CONDITION, DISTRIBUTION, HABITAT AND HABITAT USES OF WILDLIFE SPECIES. THEY ALSO TEST NEW CONCEPTS, EVALUATE NEW METHODOLOGIES, AND PROVIDE STRATEGIC INFORMATION TO INFORM MANAGEMENT. STUDIES SEEK TO DETERMINE WHAT IS NECESSARY FOR SPECIES TO THRIVE THROUGHOUT THEIR LIFE CYCLE, AND TO IDENTIFY BARRIERS THAT PREVENT SPECIES FROM EXPANDING TO NEW AREAS OR RETURNING TO RESTORED AREAS.

UNDER THIS GRANT, MINNESOTA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (DNR) WILDLIFE STAFF PROVIDE TECHNICAL INFORMATION ABOUT HOW TO BEST MANAGE LAND FOR WILD BIRDS AND MAMMALS (HEREAFTER  WILDLIFE ). WILDLIFE STAFF WORK WITH STAFF FROM OTHER GOVERNMENT AGENCIES AND CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS, OTHER STAFF FROM THE DNR, AND PRIVATE LANDOWNERS TO ENSURE THAT THE BEST INFORMATION IS USED, AND THAT WILDLIFE POPULATIONS ARE PROTECTED, RESTORED, OR ENHANCED. THIS WORK INCLUDES IDENTIFICATION AND DESIGNATION OF SHALLOW LAKES THAT SHOULD BEST BE MANAGED FOR WILDLIFE INSTEAD OF FISHERIES RESOURCES. IT ALSO INCLUDES WORKING WITH LANDOWNERS WHERE WILDLIFE ARE CONSIDERED A NUISANCE, OR CAUSING DAMAGE.

THIS GRANT GATHERS INFORMATION FROM HUNTERS AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS ABOUT THE HUMAN DIMENSIONS OF WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT. THIS INCLUDES HUNTING BEHAVIOR AND INTENTIONS, IMPACTS PERCEIVED FROM INTERACTIONS WITH WILDLIFE, PERCEPTIONS OF DNR WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT, USE OF STATE WILDLIFE AREAS, AND EFFECTIVE WILDLIFE-RELATED COMMUNICATION METHODS IN MINNESOTA. THESE DATA WILL HELP INFORM THE LARGER DECISION-MAKING PROCESS WITH RESPECT TO HABITAT, CONSERVATION, STRATEGIC COMMUNICATION, VISITOR USE, AND GAME SPECIES MANAGEMENT.

URBAN WILDLIFE BIOLOGISTS ARE STATIONED IN MAJOR METROPOLITAN AREAS TO PROVIDE EXPERT ASSISTANCE THAT ADDRESSES HABITAT FRAGMENTATION, URBAN SPRAWL, WILDLIFE CONFLICT, LAND PLANNING ISSUES, AND DEGRADATION OF ECOLOGICAL SERVICES AND TO ADDRESS NEEDS OUTLINED IN THE SECTIONS ABOVE.

THIS EFFORT WILL PRODUCE ACCURATE AND CONTEMPORARY POPULATION ESTIMATES FOR THE SOUTH GEORGIA BEAR POPULATION. SUCH AN ESTIMATE WILL ALLOW FOR AN EVALUATION OF HOW CURRENT AND FUTURE PROPOSED HARVEST RATES WILL IMPACT THE SGP. DATA COLLECTION WILL INCLUDE GENETIC HAIR-SNARE SAMPLING, CAMERA-TRAPPING EFFORTS, AND GPS COLLARING ACTIVITIES. TOGETHER, THIS WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION ON BLACK BEAR SURVIVAL, REPRODUCTION, RECRUITMENT.

THE KY DEPT. OF FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES UTILIZES THIS PROGRAM TO MANAGE AND MONITOR AVIAN LANDBIRD SPECIES. KDFWR WILL REVISE EXISTING PROGRAMS AND INITIATE SEVERAL NEW MONITORING PROJECTS TO EVALUATE HABITAT IMPROVEMENT PRACTICES AND THEIR IMPACTS TO SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED LISTED IN THE STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN. SEVERAL OTHER PROJECTS REQUIRE ADDITIONAL SURVEYS MANAGEMENT BEFORE RESULTS ON BIRD RESPONSE OR POPULATION STABILITY CAN BE ASSESSED.

MULE DEER POPULATIONS CONTINUE TO DECLINE IN OREGON AND THROUGHOUT THEIR RANGE. THERE IS A NEED TO IMPROVEHABITAT FOR MULE DEER IN OREGON TO REVERSE POPULATION DECLINES AND PROVIDE OUTDOOR RECREATION OPPORTUNITIES.HABITAT DEGRADATION IS LIKELY THE PRIMARY CONTRIBUTOR TO THESE DECLINES. THE PR FUNDS REQUESTED IN THIS PROPOSALWOULD HELP ADDRESS HABITAT IMPROVEMENT IN THE MALHEUR RIVER WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT UNIT BY REMOVING 2,000 ACRES OFWESTERN JUNIPER THAT ARE NEGATIVELY IMPACTING PLANT SPECIES MULE DEER RELY ON FOR FAWNING AND BROWSE.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO IMPROVE MULE DEER HABITAT IN THE HEPPNER WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT UNIT BY CONTROLLINGINVASIVE ANNUAL GRASS AND BY REPLACING WOVEN WIRE FENCES WITH SMOOTH BARBED WIRE FENCES. PR FUNDS REQUESTED INTHIS PROPOSAL WOULD HELP ADDRESS HABITAT IMPROVEMENT FOR MULE DEER IN THE HEPPNER WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT UNIT.THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (ODFW) HAS IDENTIFIED QUALITY AND QUANTITY OF FORAGE AS A CRITICALHABITAT COMPONENT FOR MULE DEER AND MULE DEER WINTER RANGE ACROSS EASTERN OREGON HAS BEEN NEGATIVELY IMPACTED BY THE COLONIZATION OF NON-NATIVE INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASSES. INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASSES SUCH AS MEDUSAHEAD RYE(TAENIATHERUM CANPUT-MEDUSAE), VENTENATA (VENTENATA DUBIA), AND CHEATGRASS (BROMUS TECTORUM) PROVIDE POOR FORAGEFOR WILDLIFE AND OUTCOMPETE NATIVE GRASSES AND FORBS. CHEMICAL APPLICATIONS USING ANNUAL GRASS SELECTIVEHERBICIDES IMAZAPIC AND INDAZIFLAM HAVE BEEN THE MOST COMMON AND SUCCESSFUL APPROACH USED TO CONTROL ANNUALGRASSES AND RESTORE RANGELAND HABITAT (SEBASTIAN ET AL., 2016, MONACO ET AL. 2017). IN ADDITION TO FORAGEQUALITY, HABITAT IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS WITHIN THE HEPPNER WMU HAVE INCLUDED WOVEN WIRE FENCE REMOVAL. THE HEPPNER WMU WAS HISTORICALLY GRAZED BY SHEEP AND MANY OF THE FENCES ARE OF A WOVEN WIRE CONSTRUCTION THAT ACT AS BARRIERS TO MULE DEER MOVEMENTS, PARTICULARLY FAWNS. REPLACING THESE FENCES WITH A TRADITIONAL SMOOTH BARBED WIRE FENCE WILL REDUCE THE FRAGMENTATION OF HABITAT AS WELL AS REDUCE THE MORTALITY ASSOCIATED WITH FENCE ENTANGLEMENT. THE EXPANSION OF NON-NATIVE INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASS CONTINUES TO DEGRADE THE QUALITY OF MULE DEER WINTER RANGE. ACTIVELY ADDRESSING ANNUAL GRASS WILL HELP TO PRESERVE AND ENHANCE THE QUALITY OF FORAGE AVAILABLE IN THESE CRITICAL HABITAT AREAS BENEFITING MULE DEER AND OTHER WILDLIFE SPECIES. ADDITIONALLY, WOVEN WIRE FENCING ACTS ASA BARRIER TO MOVEMENT FOR MULE DEER AND OTHER WILDLIFE SPECIES, REMOVAL OF THIS TYPE OF FENCING SHOULD IMPROVECONNECTIVITY AND REDUCE ENTANGLEMENT RELATED MORTALITY OF MULE DEER IN THE REGION. THE HEPPNER WMU PROVIDESVALUABLE OPPORTUNITIES FOR BIG GAME HUNTERS AND OTHER WILDLIFE RELATED RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES. PROVIDING QUALITYHABITAT WILL HELP SUSTAIN AND ENHANCE HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES OFFERED IN THE REGION.

CALIFORNIA BIGHORN SHEEP HAVE THRIVED IN THE JOHN DAY RIVER CANYON SINCE THE POPULATION WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1989.THIS HERD IS CURRENTLY THE LARGEST METAPOPULATION IN OREGON AND HAS CONSISTENTLY BEEN SHOWN FREE OF DISEASE.HOWEVER, THIS AREA IS SUBJECT TO INCREASINGLY FREQUENT THREATS FROM WILDFIRES, DROUGHT, AND CLIMATE CHANGE. ADETAILED UNDERSTANDING OF THE DEMOGRAPHICS, RESOURCE SELECTION PATTERNS, FORAGE AVAILABILITY, AND DIET QUALITY ISIMPORTANT FOR GUIDING FUTURE POPULATION AND LANDSCAPE MANAGEMENT IN THE AREA, AND HAS IMPLICATIONS FOR MANAGEMENT OF OTHER BIGHORN POPULATIONS THAT ARE STRUGGLING TO DEAL WITH SIMILAR THREATS. WE WILL STUDY THIS HEALTHY HERD TO INFORM FUTURE MANAGEMENT OF THIS POPULATION AND OTHERS AROUND THE STATE. SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES WILL FOCUS ONUNDERSTANDING HABITAT USE PATTERNS BY DEVELOPING RESOURCE SELECTION FUNCTIONS, UNDERSTANDING NUTRITIONAL ECOLOGYBY SAMPLING VEGETATION AND FECAL PELLETS FOR AVAILABLE QUALITY AND DIET SELECTION, QUANTIFYING DETAILEDPOPULATION DEMOGRAPHIC PARAMETERS AND FACTORS AFFECTING THOSE PARAMETERS. WE CONDUCT THIS STUDY WITH A PAIR OFGRADUATE STUDENTS (M.S.) THROUGH UNIVERSITY OF IDAHO WORKING WITH DR. RYAN LONG. ONE MASTERS STUDENT WILLCONDUCT THE HABITAT AND NUTRITIONAL RESEARCH COMPONENTS, THE OTHER STUDENT WILL CONDUCT THE DEMOGRAPHICS WORK.ODFW WILL BE ACTIVELY ENGAGED THROUGHOUT THE PROCESS VIA PARTICIPATING ON EACH OF THE GRADUATE COMMITTEES. ODFW REPRESENTATIVES ON COMMITTEES WILL BE ANDREW MEYERS AND DR. DON WHITTAKER, ONE PER COMMITTEE.

OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (ODFW) IS RESPONSIBLE FOR MANAGEMENT OF THE STATES BIG GAME POPULATIONS. IN ORDER TO MANAGE BIG GAME POPULATIONS, ODFW NEEDS HIGH-QUALITY INFORMATION TO UNDERSTAND HOW THOSE POPULATIONS ARE FLUCTUATING FROM YEAR TO YEAR. THIS GRANT COVERS AERIAL INVENTORY FOR DEER, ELK, PRONGHORN, BIGHORN SHEEP, MOUNTAIN GOAT, AND MOOSE IN OREGON. MOST SURVEYS OCCUR IN THE FALL, WINTER, AND SPRING PRIMARILY ON BIOLOGICAL WINTER RANGES WITHIN EACH WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT UNIT. GIVEN THE LARGE SIZE OF WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT UNITS (WMU) IN OREGON AND DISPERSED NATURE OF BIG GAME, GROUND-BASED SAMPLING IS IMPRACTICAL. MONITORING OF BIG GAMEPOPULATIONS USING HELICOPTERS OR FIXED WING AIRCRAFT IS MORE EFFECTIVE AND CAN BE COMPLETED FROM WITHIN A FEWHOURS TO MULTIPLE DAYS PER UNIT. ODFW STRIVES TO ESTIMATE POPULATION STATUS USING ROBUST, STATISTICALLY DESIGNEDMETHODS. AERIAL SURVEYS ALLOW ODFW TO EFFECTIVELY DETERMINE THE STATUS AND TRENDS OF SEVERAL BIG GAME MAMMALSPECIES AND THEREFORE MORE EFFECTIVELY MANAGE THEIR POPULATIONS AND THE HUNTING OPPORTUNITY THEY PROVIDE. THESEDATA WILL BE USED TO MAKE MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS FOR GAME MAMMALS THAT ARE CONSISTENT WITH OREGONS WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT POLICIES TO MAINTAIN AND INCREASE BIG GAME POPULATIONS AND INCREASE HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES.

GRANT FUNDS WILL BE USED TO FURTHER THE FOLLOWING WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES:  PROTECT, SUSTAIN, AND MANAGE HUNTED WILDLIFE.  PROVIDE STABLE, REGULATED RECREATIONAL HUNTING OPPORTUNITY TO ALL CITIZENS.  PROTECT AND ENHANCE WILDLIFE HABITAT.  MINIMIZE ADVERSE IMPACTS TO RESIDENTS, OTHER WILDLIFE, AND THE ENVIRONMENT.  ACHIEVE CONSERVATION OF SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) AND HABITATS OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (HGCN) ON PRIVATE LANDS, SPECIFICALLY THROUGH PARTICIPATION IN WORKING GROUPS, AND DELIVERY OF CONSERVATION PROGRAMS TO LANDOWNERS THROUGH TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE.  FACILITATE HUNTER ACCESS ON PRIVATE LANDS, WHILE MANAGING ISSUES AND COSTS.  EDUCATE THE PUBLIC TO FOSTER APPROPRIATE USE AND RESPECTFUL BEHAVIOR TOWARD PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND THEIR LANDS.THE IMPLEMENTATION OF STRATEGIES EMPLOYED TO IMPLEMENT THESE OBJECTIVES WILL BE CONDITIONED FIRST ON MEETING GAME POPULATION OBJECTIVES.MUCH OF THE WORK CONDUCTED IN WASHINGTON STATE IS COORDINATED WITH, OR BASED ON COLLABORATIVE PRACTICES DEVELOPED WITH OTHER STATES, ORGANIZATIONS, AND NATIONS.

THE GRANT (NEVADA SAGE-GROUSE CONSERVATION PROGRAM) ALLOWS THE NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE TO MONITOR GREATER SAGE-GROUSE POPULATIONS, CONDUCT HABITAT CONSERVATION PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION OF PROJECTS AND MANAGEMENT ACTIONS, CONDUCT RESEARCH PROJECTS, COORDINATE WITH FEDERAL LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES AND CARRY OUT ADMINISTRATIVE ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THE GRANT (E.G. GRANT DEVELOPMENT, REPORTING, CONTRACTING AND SUB-GRANT DEVELOPMENT).

THE WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE MANAGES EIGHTEEN PR-FUNDED WILDLIFE AREAS ACROSS THE STATE TO PRESERVE, PROTECT AND PERPETUATE WILDLIFE AND THE HABITATS THAT WILDLIFE DEPEND ON, WHILE PROVIDING COMPATIBLE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. GRANT DOLLARS PROVIDE A LARGE PORTION OF OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE FUNDS AND A LIMITED AMOUNT OF ENHANCEMENT FUNDS ON THESE LANDS. GRANT DOLLARS ALSO CONTRIBUTE TO WINTER-FEEDING COSTS FOR BIG GAME AND UPLAND BIRDS, EQUIPMENT, WLA PLANNING AND OUTREACH EFFORTS, DEVELOPMENT OF A FACILITIES INVENTORY AND RECREATION STRATEGY, AND PAYMENT OF STATEWIDE LEASES AND ASSESSMENTS.

THE DIVISION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE S GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEM (GIS) SERVES AS A DATA MANAGEMENT PROGRAM FOR PROCESSING, ORGANIZING, ANALYZING, AND LONG-TERM ARCHIVING OF BIOLOGICAL DATA FOR WILDLIFE CONSERVATION PROJECTS. DFW BIOLOGISTS COLLECT AND ANALYZE DATA FROM PERMIT REVIEWS, RARE SPECIES SURVEYS, AND MONITORING PROJECTS IN ORDER TO ASSESS AND MANAGE SPECIES  POPULATIONS, MITIGATE HABITAT LOSS, AND GUIDE LAND DEVELOPMENT. IN TANDEM, TEH GIS STAFF PROVIDE TECHNICAL SUPPORT FOR SUCH PROJECTS BY ENTERING DATA, DESIGNING SPATIAL COMPONENTS OF SURVEYS, MAPPING EFFORTS AND PERFORMING SPATIAL ANALYSIS TO BETTER INFORM DECISIONS. AS A RESULT, IT IS ESSENTIAL TO PROVIDE CONTINUED MAINTENANCE OF GIS INFRASTRUCTURE AND TECHNICAL SUPPORT IN ORDER TO CONTINUE THE PROGARM S CAPACITY AND PROVIDE THE BEST MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS FOR SPECIES FOUND WIHTIN THE COMMONWEALTH OF THE NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS.

THE MARIANA FRUIT BAT (PTEROPUS MARIANNUS  FANIHI) IS THE ONLY TERRESTRIAL MAMMAL NATIVE TO THE COMMONWEALTH OF THE NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS (CNMI). FANIHI PROVIDE ESSENTIAL ECOLOGICAL SERVICES AND HOLD GREAT CULTURAL SIGNIFICANCE FOR THE INDIGENOUS PEOPLE OF THE MARIANAS. IN ADDITION TO HABITAT LOSS, FANIHI POPULATIONS ARE THREATENED BY POACHING AND BY SEVERE WEATHER EVENTS SUCH AS TYPHOONS THAT DISRUPT COLONIES AND REDUCE THE AVAILABILITY OF FOOD RESOURCES. FANIHI ARE LISTED AS A THREATENED SPECIES UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT, AND PROGRESS HAS BEEN MADE TOWARD RECOVERY SINCE LISTING. THE CNMI DIVISION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (DFW) SUPPORTS FANIHI RECOVERY THROUGH MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT ACTIONS IN THE SOUTHERN ISLANDS OF ROTA, AGUIGUAN, TINIAN, AND SAIPAN  THROUGH ENGAGEMENT WITH THE HUNTING COMMUNITY AND BROADER PUBLIC TO IMPROVE AWARENESS OF FANIHI CONSERVATION EFFORTS AND ENCOURAGE THE REDUCTION OF ILLEGAL HUNTING  AND BY REHABILITATING INJURED AND ORPHANED FANIHI SURRENDERED TO DFW, WITH THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF RELEASING THESE BATS INTO THE WILD.

THERE IS A NEED TO DEVELOP SAFE AND RESPONSIBLE HUNTERS IN TEXAS BY:1. DECREASING THE HUNTING INCIDENT RATE -- KEEPING IT BELOW NATIONAL AVERAGE OF 6.1 INCIDENTS PER 100,000 PARTICIPANTS (INTERNATIONAL HUNTER EDUCATION ASSOCIATION - USA 2015).2. INCREASING UNDERSTANDING OF AND COMPLIANCE WITH TEXAS HUNTING REGULATIONS.3. PROMOTING RESPONSIBLE OUTDOOR ACTIONS AND BEHAVIORS BY HUNTERS AND TARGET SHOOTERS (E.G. REDUCED WOUNDING RATES, ENHANCED PUBLIC IMAGE AND ETHICAL BEHAVIORS).
REAL ESTATE SERVICES PROVIDES PROPERTY MANAGEMENT SERVICES FOR OWNED AND MANAGED LANDS OF THE DEPARTMENT FOR THE PURPOSES OF RECREATION AND CONSERVATION.

THE CNMI DIVISION OF FISH   WILDLIFES COORDINATION SECTION IS DEDICATED TO SUPPORTING ALL WILDLIFE RESTORATIONAND SPORT FISH RESTORATION (WSFR) FUNDED PROJECTS. WE WILL PROCESS ALL ADMINISTRATIVE TASKS SUCH AS EMPLOYEECONTRACTS, OFF-ISLAND RECRUITMENTS, PROCUREMENT ACTIONS, AND PROCESS MONTHLY PAYMENTS FOR GOODS AND SERVICESRECEIVED, AND ENSURE EQUAL DISTRIBUTION OF COSTS ACROSS ALL PROGRAMS AND PROJECTS BENEFITING FROM THESE GOODS ANDSERVICES. ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL PERFORM QUALITY CONTROL CHECKS ON ALL GRANT DOCUMENTS AND RECONCILE EXPENDITURESTO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH LOCAL AND FEDERAL REQUIREMENTS AND GRANT AWARD CONDITIONS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO SUPPORT THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION (ODWC) IN THE CONSERVATION OF WILDLIFE SPECIES AND THEIR ASSOCIATED HABITATS ON 89 WMAS IN OKLAHOMA. DOING SO WILL FACILITATE THE MAINTENANCE OF VIABLE POPULATIONS AND PUBLIC ENJOYMENT AND USE. ODWC WILL ALSO OCCASIONALLY ASSIST OTHER PARTNER LAND AGENCIES WITH WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT (I.E. OKLAHOMA STATE PARKS, NON-LICENSED U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS, U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, THE NATURE CONSERVANCY, BUREAU OF RECLAMATION, NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, ETC). THE ADMINISTRATIVE REGIONS OF OKLAHOMA ENCOMPASSING 89 WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS TOTALING 1,129,661 ACRES: NW: 17 WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS TOTALING 107,273 ACRES: BEAVER RIVER WMA, CANTON WMA, CIMARRON BLUFF WMA, CIMARRON HILLS WMA, CIMARRON PLAYA, COOPER WMA, DEWEY COUNTY WMA, DRUMMOND FLATS WMA, FORT SUPPLY WMA, LUNCEFORD PLAYA, MAJOR COUNTY WMA, OPTIMA WMA, RITA BLANCA NG, SANDHILLS WMA, SHORB WMA, SCHULTZ WMA, AND VANOSDOL WMA. CONTROLLED HUNT ADMINISTRATION ONLY ON SALT PLAINS STATE PARK AND GREAT SALT PLAINS NWR. SW: 12 WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS TOTALING 121,728 ACRES: ALTUS LUGERT WMA, BLACK KETTLE NG, ELLIS COUNTY WMA, ELLSWORTH WMA, FORT COBB WMA, GIST WMA, HACKBERRY FLAT WMA, MOUNTAIN PARK WMA,PACKSADDLE WMA, SANDY SANDERS WMA, WASHITA COUNTY WMA, AND WAURIKA WMA. CONTROLLED HUNT ADMINISTRATION ONLY ON FOSS LAKE WASHITA NWR, FOUR CANYON, WICHITA MOUNTAIN NWR. CENTRAL: 19 WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS TOTALING 129,659 ACRES: ARBUCKLE SPRINGS WMA, ARCADIA CEA, BLUE RIVER PFHA, CANDY CREEK WMA, CROSS TIMBERS WMA, DEEP FORK WMA, FOBB BOTTOM WMA, GRADY COUNTY WMA, HEYBURN WMA, HICKORY CREEK WMA, JOHN DAHL WMA, KAW WMA, KEYSTONE WMA, LEXINGTON WMA, LOVE VALLEY WMA, OKMULGEE WMA, SKIATOOK WMA, TISHOMINGO WMA, AND WASHITA ARM WMA. COORDINATION WITH CHICKASAW NRA. NE: 18 WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS TOTALING 199,959 ACRES: BAMBERGER WMA, BARREN FORK WMA, CHEROKEE WMA, COOKSON WMA, COPAN WMA, EUFAULA WMA, FORT GIBSON WMA, HULAH WMA, LOWER ILLINOIS PFHA, MCCLELLAN KERR WMA, NEOSHO WMA, OOLOGAH WMA, OSAGE WMA, OZARK PLATEAU WMA, SANS BOIS WMA, SPARROWHAWK WMA, SPAVINAW WMA, AND TENKILLER WMA. SE: 23 WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS TOTALING 571,042 ACRES: ATOKA PHA, ATOKA WMA, BROKEN BOW WMA, FMHA PROPERTY, GAINES CREEK WMA, GARY SHERRER WMA, GRASSY SLOUGH WMA, HUGO WMA, HUGO WMA HAMDEN UNIT, HUGO WMA SAWYER UNIT, JAMES COLLINS WMA, MCALESTER AAP, MCCURTAIN COUNTY WILDERNESS AREA, OUACHITA WMA LEFLORE UNIT, OUACHITA WMA MCCURTAIN UNIT, PINE CREEK WMA, PUSHMATAHA WMA, RED SLOUGH WMA, ROBBERS CAVE WMA, STRINGTOWN WMA, WHITEGRASS FLATS WMA, WISTER WMA, AND YOURMAN WMA. UNDER THIS AWARD ODWC WILL MEET EIGHT OBJECTIVES: 1) OPERATE AND MAINTAIN WMAS, 2) OPERATE AND MAINTAIN PROGRAM SUPPORT FACILITIES AND SHOOTING RANGES, 3) DIRECTLY RESTORE, ENHANCE,CREATE OR MANAGE ACRES FOR WILDLIFE, 4) DIRECTLY MANAGE TERRESTRIAL WILDLIFE HABITAT STRUCTURES, 5) DIRECTLY MANAGE INVASIVE ANIMAL SPECIES, 6) COLLECT DATA REGARDING AREA UTILIZATION AND FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES, 7)WMA PLANNING AND DATA STORAGE WITH GIS, AND 8)RED-COCKADED WOODPECKER MANAGEMENT ON MCCURTAIN COUNTY WILDERNESS AREA AND ADJACENT OUACHITA NATIONAL FOREST.

TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT IS CHARGED WITH THE STEWARDSHIP AND MANAGEMENT OF GAME BIRDS AND THEIR HABITATS IN TEXAS. THIS MISSION REQUIRES THE AGENCY TO SERVE AS THE LEAD FOR GAME BIRDS AND FACILITATE THE COLLECTION OF POPULATION AND HARVEST DATA TO HELP GUIDE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AND ENHANCE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. POPULATION AND HARVEST TRENDS OF GAME BIRDS ARE MONITORED TO ASSESS THE IMPACT OF CHANGES IN HABITAT AND LAND USE OVER TIME, AS WELL AS TO UNDERSTAND THE POTENTIAL EFFECTS OF TAKE ON SURVIVAL, REPRODUCTION, AND RECRUITMENT. THESE DATA ARE NEEDED TO ASSIST IN SETTING HUNTING REGULATIONS AND, WHEN APPLICABLE, IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW REGULATORY PROPOSALS. LONG-TERM SMALL GAME HARVEST SURVEYS ARE NEEDED TO PROVIDE DATA ON HUNTERS, HARVEST, AND EFFORT ACROSS ECOREGIONS. COLLECTIVELY, THESE PRODUCTS ARE SHARED WITH THE PUBLIC TO CONVEY RELEVANT INFORMATION ABOUT THE STATUS AND TRAJECTORY OF POPULATIONS, HUNTERS, AND HARVEST OF GAME BIRDS IN TEXAS. IN ADDITION, EXTENSIVE COORDINATION WITH OTHER STATE AND PROVINCIAL WILDLIFE AGENCIES, U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, AND CANADIAN WILDLIFE SERVICE AREREQUIRED DURING THESE EFFORTS.

A WELL-DEFINED AND FOCUSED BIG GAME PROGRAM IS NEEDED TO EFFECTIVELY MANAGE UPLAND TERRESTRIAL WILDLIFE IN ORDER TO MAXIMIZE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITY OF GAME ANIMALS AND TO CONSERVE THE DIVERSITY OF ECOLOGICAL RESOURCES THAT AFFECT BIG GAME SPECIES. THIS GRANT WILL PROVIDE FOR THE CONSERVATION OF BIG-GAME SPECIES  TO ENCOURAGE PUBLIC AND PRIVATE MANAGEMENT AND ENHANCEMENT OF HABITATS  TO ENSURE POPULATION PERPETUATION  TO PROMOTE PROTECTION AND UTILIZATION THROUGH HARVEST RECOMMENDATIONS  AND TO PROVIDE FOR THE CONSUMPTIVE AND NON-CONSUMPTIVE USE OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES.
MONITORING WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND HEALTH

THE WEST VIRGINIA DIVISION OF NATURAL RESOURCES, WILDLIFE RESOURCES SECTION IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THEMANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF THE STATES WILDLIFE RESOURCES AND FOR PROVIDING WILDLIFE-ASSOCIATEDRECREATION. TO ACHIEVE THIS GOAL THE WILDLIFE RESOURCES SECTION CONDUCTS MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES ON THE STATES WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA SYSTEM AND STATE FORESTS, AS WELL AS DIRECTING DISTRICT-WIDE WILDLIFE OPERATIONSINCLUDING MANAGEMENT OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES ON PRIVATE LANDS.

THERE IS A NEED TO CONDUCT RESEARCH ON BLACK-TAILED DEER POPULATION DYNAMICS AND THEIR HABITAT USE IN OREGON TOBETTER MANAGE THIS IMPORTANT STATE RESOURCE.THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL OBTAIN DATA ON SEVERAL CRITICAL POPULATION PARAMETERS: DENSITY ESTIMATES, HABITAT USEPATTERNS, SURVIVAL RATES, CAUSES OF MORTALITY, AND HERD HEALTH. THIS STUDY WILL ESTIMATE BLACK-TAILED DEERDENSITY BY HABITAT TYPE USING FECAL DNA AND SPATIALLY EXPLICIT CAPTURE-RECAPTURE MODELS, DOCUMENT BLACK-TAILEDDEER SURVIVAL RATES AND CAUSES OF MORTALITY FROM RADIO-MARKED INDIVIDUALS, AND COLLECT AND INTEGRATE DATA ONWESTERN OREGON BLACK-TAILED DOE BODY CONDITION, HABITAT SELECTION, AVAILABLE FORAGE RESOURCES, AND FAWN SURVIVAL.OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE NEED THESE DATA TO MAKE SOUND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS THAT FULFILL STATUTORYGOALS AND OBLIGATIONS.

RESEARCH ON BLACK-TAILED DEER MIGRATION PATTERNS AND USE OF DESIGNATED WINTER RANGE IS NEEDED TO BETTER MANAGETHIS IMPORTANT STATE RESOURCE. DEER HUNTING AND WILDLIFE-RELATED ACTIVITIES ARE AN IMPORTANT PART OF OREGONCULTURE AND THE ECONOMY. THERE ARE APPROXIMATELY 200,000 DEER HUNTERS THAT ANNUALLY PARTAKE OF THIS EXPERIENCEAND COMBINED WITH OTHER RECREATIONISTS ANNUALLY CONTRIBUTE BILLIONS( )TO THE STATES ECONOMY. THIS GRANT WILLEVALUATE COMPONENTS OF DEER POPULATIONS THAT USE DESIGNATED WINTER RANGE IN SOUTHERN OREGON. WILDLIFE HABITATQUALITY IN OREGON HAS BEEN DEGRADED AND FRAGMENTED BECAUSE OF DEVELOPMENT, AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES, TIMBERMANAGEMENT, AND ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH INCREASES IN THE HUMAN POPULATION. FOR SOME DEER POPULATIONS, THE MOST IMPORTANT CONCERN IS THE CONTINUED EXPANSION OF URBAN GROWTH BOUNDARIES INTO DESIGNATED WINTER RANGE. SPECIFIC COMPONENTS BEING INVESTIGATED ARE DEER MOVEMENTS AND USE OF MIGRATION CORRIDORS, WINTER RANGE (HABITAT) USE, POPULATION DENSITY, SURVIVAL RATES, AND CAUSES OF MORTALITY COMPARED BETWEEN 3 WINTER RANGE DESIGNATED TYPES.LACK OF IMMEDIATE ACTION IN OBTAINING THESE DATA ON BLACK-TAILED DEER WOULD AFFECT THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISHAND WILDLIFE S ABILITY TO MAKE SOUND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS, WHICH COULD LEAD TO LOSS OF HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES,LOSS OF REVENUE TO THE STATE, DECLINES IN GAME POPULATIONS, AND A REDUCED ABILITY OF THE ODFW TO MEET STATUTORYGOALS AND OBLIGATIONS.

RESEARCH ON FISHER POPULATION DENSITY, SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION, HABITAT USE, SURVIVAL RATES, AND COMPETITION WITHOTHER CARNIVORE SPECIES IS CRITICAL TO BETTER MANAGE AND CONSERVE THIS OREGON STRATEGY SPECIES.THE ODFW WILL USE NON-INVASIVE SAMPLING AT 95 SITES TO ESTIMATE FISHER POPULATION DENSITY. SAMPLING WILL CONSISTOF HAIR SNARE DEVICES (TO COLLECT DNA) AND TRACK PLATES. COLLECTED SAMPLES WILL BE SENT TO THE NATIONAL GENOMICSCENTER FOR WILDLIFE AND FISH CONSERVATION AT THE U.S. FOREST SERVICE ROCKY MOUNTAIN RESEARCH STATION FOR DNAEXTRACTION AND INDIVIDUAL FISHER IDENTIFICATION. IN ADDITION, 15 FISHERS AND 15 GRAY FOXES WILL BE CAPTURED ANDRADIO-MARKED TO MONITOR HABITAT USE, ESTIMATE SURVIVAL RATES AND EVALUATE POTENTIAL COMPETITION BETWEEN THESPECIES. LASTLY, 100 TRAIL CAMERAS WILL BE DEPLOYED IN THE STUDY AREA. CAMERA IMAGES WILL BE USED TO CALCULATEMESOCARNIVORE DENSITY USING TIME-TO-EVENT MODELING. FISHER DENSITY ESTIMATED VIA DNA WILL BE COMPARED TO DENSITYESTIMATES VIA TIME-TO-EVENT MODELING.KNOWING FISHER DENSITY, HABITAT USE, SURVIVAL RATES, AND DOCUMENTING LIMITING FACTORS (COMPETITION WITH GRAYFOXES, HABITAT QUALITY, CONNECTIVITY BARRIERS) WILL INCREASE THE UNDERSTANDING OF FISHER POPULATION DYNAMICS ATTHE NORTHERN EXTENT OF THEIR NATIVE RANGE. THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE NEED THESE DATA TO MAKESOUND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS THAT FULFILL STATUTORY GOALS AND OBLIGATIONS.

THE OVERALL PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO MAINTAIN AND DEVELOP 13 WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS (WMAS) AND ASSIST WITH STAFFING OF 18 FULL-TIME EMPLOYEES ALONG WITH 5 SEASONAL EMPLOYEES. THE WMAS PROVIDE VALUABLE HABITAT FOR MANY WETLAND AND UPLAND SPECIES ACROSS THE STATE. IN ADDITION TO THE WILDLIFE VALUES, THE PUBLIC BENEFITS FROM OPPORTUNITIES FOR HUNTING, FISHING, TRAPPING, CAMPING, NATURE STUDY AND WILDLIFE VIEWING ON THESE AREAS. THEREFORE, THE USE OF WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION (WSFR) FUNDS TO IMPLEMENT WILDLIFE RESTORATION PROJECTS FOR THE CONSERVATION, MANAGEMENT, AND ENHANCEMENT OF WILD BIRDS, FISHES AND MAMMALS AND TO PROVIDE FOR PUBLIC USE AND BENEFIT FROM THESE RESOURCES IS FULLY JUSTIFIED.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ESTABLISH AND IMPLEMENT MANAGEMENT CONTROL SYSTEMS ADEQUATE TOMEET THE REQUIREMENTS FOR PARTICIPATION IN AND ADMINISTRATION OF MASSWILDLIFES FEDERAL AID IN SPORT FISHAND WILDLIFE RESTORATION AND STATE WILDLIFE GRANT PROGRAMS. ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE OVERALL GRANT(S)ADMINISTRATION, PREPARATION AND REVIEW OF GRANT APPLICATIONS AND REQUIRED REPORTING AND FINANCIALMANAGEMENT. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE CONTINUED ELIGIBILITY TO RECEIVE WSFR GRANT FUNDS FOR THE GRANTPROGRAMS MENTIONED ABOVE. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE CITIZENS OF THE COMMONWEALTH OFMASSACHUSETTS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT AWARD REQUEST IS TO ACQUIRE, IN FEE TITLE, 160 ACRES ADJACENT TO THE EXISTING NANIH WAIYA WMA IN NESHOBA COUNTY, MISSISSIPPI. THE ACQUISITION WILL ALLOW IMPROVEMENT OF EXISTING HABITAT CONDITIONS WHICH WILL COMPLEMENT THE CURRENT MANAGEMENT PRACTICES ON NANIH WAIYA WMA FOR BOTTOMLAND HARDWOOD MANAGEMENT. THIS WILL PROTECT THE PROPERTIES FROM POTENTIAL CONVERSION OF WILDLIFE HABITAT TO ALTERNATIVE LAND USES. THE TRACT IS LOCATED WITHIN THE EXISTING WMA BOUNDARY AND INCORPORATES A PORTION OF THE PEARL RIVER, SO ACQUIRING IT FOR THE WMA WILL ALSO SUPPORT PUBLIC ACCESS FOR WILDLIFE-ASSOCIATED RECREATIONAL PURPOSES.

THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE FOR THE COORDINATED AND CONTINUED DEVELOPMENT, OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF NEARLY 185,520 ACRES OF LAND AND WATER MANAGED FOR FISHING, HUNTING, AND TRAPPING ACTIVITIES ON APPROXIMATELY 281 STATE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS (WMAS) IN NEBRASKA.  ACTIVITIES WILL ALSO EXTEND TO COMPARABLE WMAS THAT MAY BE GAINED THROUGH ACQUISITION OF AGREEMENTS WITHIN THE GRANT PERIOD. IMPROVED MIGRATORY WATERFOWL HABITAT CONDITIONS AND PUBLIC USE FACILITATION WILL RESULT IN THE ONGOING PUMPING ACTIVITIES SUPPORTED ON USFWS WATERFOWL PRODUCTION AREAS WITHIN THE RAINWATER BASIN AREA OF THE STATE. THE PROPOSED WORK ITEMS WILL ASSIST IN KEEPING THE NUMBER AND QUALITY OF NEBRASKAS PUBLIC FISHING, HUNTING AND TRAPPING OPPORTUNITIES AT A HIGH LEVEL.  THE OVERALL OBJECTIVE OF THE PROJECT INCLUDES PROVIDING, PROTECTING, AND ENHANCING WILDLIFE AND FISH HABITATS ON STATE WMAS AND PROVIDING PUBLIC USE OPPORTUNITIES ON THESE APPROXIMATELY 281 AREAS.
IOWA FY24 HUNTER EDUCATION

THE OVERARCHING OBJECTIVE OF THIS RESEARCH PROJECT IS TO ASSESS COMPETITIVE INTERACTIONS AMONG CARNIVORES, THEIRABUNDANCE AND POPULATION DYNAMICS, AND THEIR ASSOCIATED EFFECTS ON PREY POPULATIONS. IT IS OFTEN IMPLIED THATCARNIVORES ARE IMPORTANT DETERMINANTS OF UNGULATE POPULATION DYNAMICS, BUT EMPIRICAL DATA SUPPORTING THIS CLAIMIS LIMITED. FURTHERMORE, THE COMPETITIVE INTERACTIONS BETWEEN CARNIVORES MAY INFLUENCE UNGULATE POPULATIONS ANDTHIS TOPIC IS NOT WELL STUDIED. THIS LACK OF KNOWLEDGE WAS THE IMPETUS FOR THIS RESEARCH AND WILL HELP IMPROVEMANAGEMENT OF BOTH PREDATORS AND THEIR PREY IN OREGON AND ELSEWHERE.WE WILL USE INFORMATION GAINED FROM THIS STUDY IN CONJUNCTION WITH OTHER ONGOING RESEARCH TO IDENTIFY FACTORSINFLUENCING DECLINING MULE DEER POPULATIONS. OUR PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO DETERMINE CARNIVOREDENSITIES, DIETS, AND COMPETITIVE INTERACTIONS AT THE STARKEY EXPERIMENTAL FOREST AND RANGE AND TO ESTIMATECARNIVORE DENSITIES AND ABUNDANCE AT TWO STUDY AREAS IN CENTRAL AND SOUTHERN OREGON. THROUGH THIS AND OTHERCOMPLEMENTARY RESEARCH, WE WILL DETERMINE THE ROLE OF PREDATION IN INFLUENCING POPULATION DYNAMICS AND HABITATUSE OF MULE DEER. WE WILL CONDUCT FIELDWORK DURING THE CURRENT PROJECT PERIOD TO DEVELOP AN EMPIRICAL DATA SETTO MEET PROJECT OBJECTIVES. INFORMATION GAINED FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE USEFUL IN IMPROVING MANAGEMENT OFCARNIVORES AND THEIR PREY IN OREGON AND OTHER PORTIONS OF WESTERN NORTH AMERICA. THIS RESEARCH WILL ALSO ASSESSTHE RESPONSE OF CARNIVORES TO A SUBSTANTIAL DECLINE IN AVAILABLE PREY BIOMASS (PRIMARILY ELK) AT THE STARKEYEXPERIMENTAL FOREST AND RANGE AS PART OF A CONTROLLED EXPERIMENT. CHANGES IN DIET, SPACE AND HABITAT USE, ANDDENSITY WILL BE MONITORED AS PART OF THE EXPERIMENTAL REDUCTION OF THE ELK HERD. DOCUMENTING CHANGES IN PREDATORRESPONSES TO PREY REDUCTIONS ARE IMPORTANT TO UNDERSTANDING HOW PREDATORS ARE LIKELY TO AFFECT THEIR PREYPOPULATIONS.WE ARE ALSO CONDUCTING WORK IN OTHER PORTIONS OF EASTERN OREGON IN THE BLUE MOUNTAINS AND SOUTHERN OREGON CASCADE RANGE TO DOCUMENT ABUNDANCE AND DIET OF COUGARS, BLACK BEARS, AND COYOTES. THIS WORK WILL BE USED TO DETERMINE SPATIAL DIFFERENCES IN ABUNDANCE AND HOW HABITAT MAY INFLUENCE DENSITY. THIS KNOWLEDGE WILL THEN BE USED TO IDENTIFY PRIMARY PREDATORS OF MULE DEER VIA PRESENCE IN SCAT AND ALSO PROVIDE ACCURATE INFORMATION ON DENSITIES THAT COULD BE USED TO ALTER HARVEST RATES OF THE SPECIES. ADDITIONALLY, DATA COLLECTED AS PART OF THIS PROJECTWILL BE USED TO DETERMINE IF VARIATION IN PREDATOR ABUNDANCE EFFECTS MULE DEER SURVIVAL.

THIS GRANT FUNDS THE ANNUAL OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF THE ELKHORN WILDLIFE AREA (EWA). ESTABLISHED IN 1971 TOMITIGATE THE LOSS OF TRADITIONAL BIG GAME WINTER RANGE IN BAKER AND UNION COUNTIES THROUGH HABITAT MANAGEMENT ANDSUPPLEMENTAL FEEDING, THE WILDLIFE AREA PROVIDES SUPPLEMENTAL OR SUBSISTENCE FEED FOR WINTERING ELK AND DEER TOREDUCE DAMAGE TO ADJACENT PRIVATE LANDS AND AGRICULTURAL CROPS.THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE ELKHORN WILDLIFE AREA BEGAN WITH THE ACQUISITION OF THE NORTH POWDER AND AUBURN SITES.THESE SITES WERE IDENTIFIED AS CRITICAL WINTER RANGE WHERE SUPPLEMENTAL FEEDING COULD POTENTIALLY STOP AND HOLDMIGRATING ELK AND DEER. THE EWA HAS SINCE GROWN TO 8,836 ACRES, OF WHICH 6,723 ACRES ARE UNDER ODFW OWNERSHIP,1,728 ACRES MANAGED BY COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WITH THE U.S. FOREST SERVICE (USFS) AND BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT (BLM), AND 5 ACRES OF PRIVATE LANDS ARE LEASED BY ODFW. THE WILDLIFE AREA HAS RECEIVED ANNUAL FUNDING UNDER THE FEDERAL AID IN WILDLIFE RESTORATION ACT SINCE 1971.THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO FUND CONTINUED OPERATION OF ELKHORN WILDLIFE AREA TO ALLEVIATE DAMAGE CONFLICTSBETWEEN AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION AND UNGULATE POPULATIONS IN THE BAKER VALLEY.OPERATION OF ELKHORN WILDLIFE AREA PROVIDES HABITATS FOR BIG GAME SPECIES AND OTHER INDIGENOUS WILDLIFE. THEDAMAGE CONFLICTS HAVE BEEN ALLEVIATED THROUGH FENCE REPAIRS, FORAGE IMPROVEMENTS AND SUPPLEMENTAL WINTER FEEDINGOF 2000 ELK AND 350 DEER ON THE WILDLIFE AREA. WITHOUT THE OPERATIONS OF ELKHORN WILDLIFE AREA WILDLIFE INFLICTEDHARDSHIPS WOULD CONTINUE FOR AREA LAND OWNERS AND ULTIMATELY ELK AND DEER POPULATIONS WOULD BE REDUCED TOSOCIALLY TOLERANT LEVELS

CONSTRUCTION OF INTERNATIONAL (OLYMPIC) TRAP AND SKEET FIELDS ANDAMERICAN TRAP AND SKEET FIELDS - ALONG WITH SUPPORTING FACILITIES AND EQUIPMENT- INJACKSONVILLE AND PANAMA CITY BEACH.TO MEET THE GROWING DEMAND FROM THE INCREASING POPULATION IN THE STATE, AND TOACCOMMODATE HIGH SCHOOL AND COLLEGE SHOOTING SPORTS TEAMS IN NORTH FLORIDA THAT AREINTERESTED IN PRACTICING NEW DISCIPLINES OF COMPETITIVE SHOTGUN SHOOTING, THE FLORIDA FISHAND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION COMMISSION IS CONSTRUCTING A SERIES OF TRAP AND SKEET FIELDS.THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY CONSTRUCTION OF INTERNATIONAL (OLYMPIC) TRAP AND SKEETFIELDS AND AMERICAN TRAP AND SKEET FIELDS - ALONG WITH SUPPORTING FACILITIES -IN PANAMACITY BEACH AND JACKSONVILLE.PROVIDING INFRASTRUCTURE FOR THE PUBIC AND HIGH SCHOOL AND COLLEGE SHOOTING SPORTS TEAMSTO TRAIN AT AN INTERNATIONAL (OLYMPIC) TRAP AND SKEET AND AMERICAN TRAP AND SKEET FIELDBUILDS INTEREST IN THE SHOOTING SPORTS AND PROVIDES OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE REGIONAL TEAMS TOCOMPETE IN STATE AND NATIONAL TOURNAMENTS. PROVIDING THESE REGIONAL TRAININGINFRASTRUCTURES IN NORTH FLORIDA WILL INCREASE PARTICIPATION IN THESE SHOOTING DISCIPLINES ATSTATE, REGIONAL, NATIONAL, AND INTERNATIONAL SHOOTS.

UTAH HAS ALSO EXPERIENCED A LONG-TERM DECLINE IN THE NUMBER OF UPLAND GAME HUNTERS IN GENERAL. THERE WERE OVER100,000 UPLAND GAME HUNTERS IN UTAH IN THE LATE 1970S. LAST YEAR, LESS THAN 33,000 UPLAND GAME HUNTERS. THERE ISGROWING CONCERN NATIONWIDE, AS WELL AS IN UTAH, OVER THE LOSS OF HUNTERS.THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF PARTICIPANTS IN PHEASANT AND CHUKAR HUNTING BY FIVEPERCENT (22,062 TO 23,165 FOR PHEASANTS, AND 6,884 TO 7,228 FOR CHUKARS) BY THE END OF THE 2020-2021 HUNTINGSEASON. THIS OBJECTIVE WAS CREATED DUE TO THE DRASTIC DECLINE IN UPLAND GAME HUNTERS SINCE THE 1970S.THE APPROACH IS TO PURCHASE HEALTHY, DISEASE-FREE RING-NECKED PHEASANTS AND CHUKAR PARTRIDGE FROM CERTIFIEDGROWERS, AND RELEASE PEN-RAISED PHEASANTS AND CHUKARS IN APPROPRIATE AREAS STATEWIDE TO MAXIMIZE THE LIKELIHOODOF HUNTER HARVEST, PRIOR TO AND DURING THE HUNTING SEASONS. WE WILL ALSO RAISE AWARENESS FOR PARTICIPATION ANDFOR THE PROJECT, AND EVALUATE THE PROJECT. THE EXPECTED BENEFIT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE TO INCREASERECRUITMENT, RETENTION, AND REACTIVATION THROUGH PROVIDING AN ADDITIONAL HUNTING OPPORTUNITY TO THE PUBLIC.

OVER 600 NATIVE BIRD SPECIES ARE KNOWN TO OCCUR IN TEXAS. ONLY 9  OF THESE SPECIES (DOVE, QUAIL, WATERFOWL, AND TURKEY AMONG OTHERS) ARE CURRENTLY CONSIDERED GAME SPECIES. THE REMAINING MAJORITY OF TEXAS  BIRD SPECIES, COMPRISED OF SUMMER, WINTER, AND PERMANENT RESIDENTS AS WELL AS MIGRANTS, FORM THE NONGAME BIRDS COVERED BY THIS GRANT.NONGAME BIRD PROJECTS INVOLVE ADMINISTRATION, PLANNING, COORDINATION, AND IMPLEMENTATION OF NONGAME BIRD RESEARCH, CONSERVATION, PUBLIC OUTREACH, AND MANAGEMENT. PROJECTS INVOLVE EXTENSIVE COORDINATION WITH STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES, NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS, AND STAKEHOLDER GROUPS TO DEVELOP CONSERVATION PLANS AND AGREEMENTS.
PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS DEVELOPMENT W-53-D-02
THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO DEVELOP CONTROL TECHNIQUES, MONITORING TECHNIQUES AND INFORMATION TO ENHANCE MANAGEMENT OF WILD PIGS IN THE UNITED STATES.

TO INSTALL REPLACE A NEW WATER PRODUCTION WELL SYSTEM, WATER DISTRIBUTION PIPING, AND ASSOCIATED APPURTENANCES TO ENHANCE APPROXIMATELY 62-ACRES OF SEASONAL WETLANDS ON THE DUNCAN TRACT OF SLOUGHS WMA, IMPROVING WATERFOWL HABITAT AND PROVIDING QUALITY HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES.

THE WILDLIFE DIVISION OF TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT (TPWD) HAS A NEED TO PROVIDE ITS STAFF AND CUSTOMERS (LANDOWNERS AND LAND MANAGERS) WITH USER FRIENDLY ONLINE TOOLS THAT SECURELY STORE AND MANAGE RELEVANT DATA IN ORDER TO FOSTER PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING OF NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, ASSIST WITH DECISION MAKING, AND IMPLEMENT EFFICIENT BUSINESS PROCESSES. TO THAT END, TPWD DEVELOPED AND LAUNCHED THE LAND MANAGEMENT ASSISTANCE (LMA) ONLINE APPLICATION, AND THIS GRANT INTENDS TO FUND MANAGEMENT AND UPDATES TO THAT SYSTEM.

THERE IS A NEED FOR THE WILDLIFE HABITAT ASSESSMENT PROGRAM AT TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE (TPWD) TO REVIEW PROPOSED DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS THAT AFFECT THE STATE S WILDLIFE RESOURCES AND ASSOCIATED ECOSYSTEMS, AND FOR PROVIDING COMMENTS AND RECOMMENDATIONS TO PROTECT THESE RESOURCES AS DIRECTED BY 12.0011 OF THE PARKS AND WILDLIFE CODE.

OVER 94 PERCENT OF TEXAS LAND IS PRIVATELY-OWNED OR MANAGED. THE ABILITY OF TPWD TO MANAGE AND CONSERVE THE STATE S NATURAL AND CULTURAL HERITAGE IS TIED DIRECTLY TO THE STRENGTH OF OUR PARTNERSHIP WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS. INCREASING DEMAND FOR LANDOWNER ASSISTANCE RESULTING FROM A GROWING INTEREST IN WILDLIFE AND THE PURCHASE AND MANAGEMENT OF LAND FOR RECREATIONAL PURPOSES HAS INCREASED THE WORKLOAD OF FIELD STAFF. FINANCIAL AND REGULATORY INCENTIVES FOR PRIVATE LANDOWNERS HAVE BEEN VERY SUCCESSFUL IN ACCOMPLISHING ON-THE-GROUND CONSERVATION OF NATURAL RESOURCES. TPWD WILL CONTINUE TO WORK WITH OTHER GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES AND ORGANIZATIONS TO PROVIDE ADDITIONAL INCENTIVES FOR CONSERVATION OF WILDLIFE AND HABITATS. STAFF ALSO PROVIDE EDUCATION AND TRAINING TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF PRESCRIBED FIRE AS A WILDLIFE HABITAT MANAGEMENT AND WILDFIRE PREVENTION TOOL. THERE IS A SIGNIFICANT NEED FOR THIS TECHNICAL GUIDANCE SO THAT LANDOWNERS CAN HAVE THE KNOWLEDGE AND COMFORT TO UTILIZE THIS IMPORTANT MANAGEMENT TOOL ON THEIR PROPERTY.
THIS GRANT PROJECT ANNUALLY FUNDS GENERAL OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE, AS WELL AS SMALL-SCALE WEED CONTROL AT ALL STATE WILDLIFE AREAS IN COLORADO.

THERE IS A NEED TO IMPROVE HABITAT FOR MULE DEER IN THE DESCHUTES WATERSHED. LOSS OF QUALITY AND QUANTITY OF MULEDEER HABITAT IS THE PRIMARY CAUSE OF DECLINING MULE DEER POPULATIONS IN THE DESCHUTES WATERSHED. IMPROVINGFORAGE QUALITY AND QUANTITY IN WINTER, TRANSITION, AND SUMMER RANGE HABITATS BY REDUCING ENCROACHING JUNIPER, ANDPROVIDING FORAGE AND WATER WILL IMPROVE CONDITIONS FOR MULE DEER POPULATIONS.THESE ACTIVITIES WILL BE CONTINUED ON THIS GRANT BY PRIMARILY FOCUSING ON:1. TREATMENT OF WESTERN JUNIPER TO ALLOW THE RELEASE OF SHRUB COMPONENTS AND OTHER FORAGE.2. MULE DEER FORAGE ENHANCEMENT WITH CREATION OF FORAGE PLOTS ON A WORKING LANDSCAPE.3. PROVIDING ADDITIONAL WATER SOURCES BY REPLACING PREVIOUS TROUGHS AND PONDS WITH WILDLIFE GUZZLERS.4. COLLECTION AND GROW OUT OF NATIVE SEED.5. DECOMMISSION OF ROADS AND INSTALLATION OF GATES6. FENCE REMOVAL

THE DYNAMIC NATURE OF THE LANDSCAPE IN TEXAS REQUIRES CONSIDERABLE EFFORT TO MAP AND TRACK THESE CHANGES IN THE VEGETATION COMMUNITIES AND OTHER LAND USES. TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT, THROUGH THE LANDSCAPE ECOLOGY PROGRAM, USES THE TEXAS ECOLOGICAL MAPPING SYSTEMS SPATIAL DATABASE DATA TO SUPPORT HABITAT MAPPING FOR ALL NATIVE SPECIES. THIS GRANT SUPPORTS THE MAINTENANCE OF AND DATA ENTERED IN THIS DATABASE.

GENERAL ADMINISTRATIVE FUNCTIONS ARE NEEDED TO COORDINATE TEXAS PARKS   WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT (TPWD) WILDLIFE GRANT PROJECTS SUPPORTED BY APPROXIMATELY  30M IN ANNUAL FUNDS APPORTIONED FROM PITTMAN-ROBERTSON, AS WELL AS OTHER WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH ADMINISTERED GRANT PROGRAMS. THESE GRANT-FUNDED PROJECTS ARE NECESSARY TO FOSTER ON-THE-GROUND CONSERVATION OF DIVERSE NATIVE WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS THROUGH SOUND SCIENCE AND LAND STEWARDSHIP FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE RESOURCE AND OUR HUNTING AND OUTDOOR HERITAGE.

HUNTING IS A LONG STANDING TRADITION IN THE STATE OF UTAH AND AN IMPORTANT PART OF OUR HERITAGE. THE DIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES (UDWR) IS COMMITTED TO PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR INDIVIDUALS TO BE INTRODUCED TO SHOOTING AND HUNTING, AS WELL AS PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR THOSE ALREADY INVOLVED IN THE SPORT TO IMPROVE THEIR SKILLS AND FOSTER CONTINUED INTEREST IN PARTICIPATION OR TO REACTIVATE PAST PARTICIPANTS. THE UDWR PUBLIC SHOOTING RANGE FACILITIES (LEE KAY PUBLIC SHOOTING RANGE AND CACHE VALLEY PUBLIC SHOOTING RANGE) PROVIDE SAFE AND STRUCTURED LOCATIONS FOR PUBLIC TARGET SHOOTERS, EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS, A VARIETY OF HUNTING OUTREACH AND SHOOTING SPORTS PROGRAMS, AND INFORMATIONAL CLINICS AND SEMINARS TO BE CONDUCTED FOR OUR CITIZENS.THIS GRANT WILL HELP UDWR TO CONTINUE TO PROVIDE SAFE AND EDUCATIONAL PUBLIC ACCESS SHOOTING RANGE FACILITIES, PROGRAMS, AND SHOOTING SPORT ACTIVITIES IN THE STATE OF UTAH, THROUGH THE OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF BOTH THE LEE KAY PUBLIC SHOOTING RANGE AND THE CACHE VALLEY PUBLIC SHOOTING RANGE.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO FUND OREGONS GAME MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, WHICH INCLUDES THE BIG GAME AND FURBEARER PROGRAMS, TO PROMOTE HEALTHY GAME POPULATIONS AND PUBLIC USE.AS STATED IN OREGON REVISED STATUTE 496.012, IT IS THE POLICY OF THE STATE OF OREGON TO MANAGE WILDLIFE TOPREVENT SERIOUS DEPLETION OF ANY INDIGENOUS SPECIES AND TO PROVIDE THE OPTIMUM RECREATIONAL AND AESTHETICBENEFITS FOR PRESENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS OF THE CITIZENS OF THIS STATE. THE GAME PROGRAM IS THE PRIMARYPROGRAM FOR MANAGING POPULATIONS OF ANIMALS THAT ARE HUNTED AND TRAPPED TO MEET THE GOALS OF THE POLICY WHICHINCLUDE:  TO MAINTAIN ALL SPECIES OF WILDLIFE AT OPTIMUM LEVELS.  TO PERMIT AN ORDERLY AND EQUITABLE UTILIZATION OF AVAILABLE WILDLIFE.  TO REGULATE WILDLIFE POPULATIONS IN A MANNER THAT IS COMPATIBLE WITH PRIMARY USES OF THE LAND AND WATERS OF THESTATE.  TO PROVIDE OPTIMUM RECREATIONAL BENEFITS.THERE IS A NEED TO MANAGE GAME SPECIES IN OREGON TO MAINTAIN HEALTHY POPULATIONS WHILE PROVIDING OPTIMUMRECREATIONAL AND AESTHETIC BENEFITS FOR PRESENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS. THROUGH THIS GRANT, OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE WILL:  COORDINATE AND ADMINISTER THE GAME MANAGEMENT PROGRAM.  PROVIDE TECHNICAL GUIDANCE FOR BIG GAME AND FURBEARER MANAGEMENT TO 24 ORGANIZATIONS (FEDERAL, STATE, ANDTRIBAL LANDOWNERS, ORGANIZATIONS, STAFF BIOLOGISTS AND PERSONNEL).  PARTICIPATE IN 13 TECHNICAL COMMITTEES.  COLLECT AND ANALYZE HARVEST (29 INVESTIGATIONS) AND SURVEY DATA (44 INVESTIGATIONS) TO HELP MANAGEMENTRECOMMENDATIONS.

SUMMER LAKE WILDLIFE AREA WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1944, WITH PRIMARY OBJECTIVES OF PROTECTING AND IMPROVING WATERFOWLHABITAT AND PROVIDING A PUBLIC HUNTING AREA. THE WILDLIFE AREA IS LOCATED IN CENTRAL LAKE COUNTY ALONG STATEHIGHWAY 31, 100 MILES SOUTHEAST OF BEND AND 75 MILES NORTHWEST OF LAKEVIEW. THE WILDLIFE AREA IS 18,941 ACRES INSIZE AT PRESENT.SUMMER LAKE WILDLIFE AREA IS LOCATED IN THE NORTHERN GREAT BASIN AND HAS A SIGNIFICANT LAND BASE WELL SUITED TOSUPPORT INDIGENOUS FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES AND MIGRATORY WATERBIRDS. WETLANDS AND ASSOCIATED UPLANDS PROVIDEHABITAT FOR A DIVERSE ARRAY OF WILDLIFE SPECIES. HABITAT TYPES FOUND ON SLWA ARE OF QUALITY AND QUANTITY TO MAKEA SIGNIFICANT CONTRIBUTION TO WILDLIFE AND MIGRATORY WATERFOWL IN THIS PORTION OF THE STATE.SLWA IS A POPULAR DESTINATION FOR HUNTING, WILDLIFE VIEWING AND ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION DUE TO ITS GEOGRAPHICSETTING, THE ABUNDANCE OF WILDLIFE PRESENT AND SPECIES DIVERSITY.HABITAT MANAGEMENT AND PUBLIC USE PROGRAMS ON THE WILDLIFE AREA ARE ADMINISTERED BY ODFW STAFF.THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO PROTECT, MAINTAIN, ENHANCE, AND RESTORE WILDLIFE HABITAT TO SUPPORT OPTIMUMPOPULATION LEVELS OF ALL SPECIES FOR THE ENJOYMENT OF PRESENT AND FUTURE CITIZENS. ALL MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES ONSLWA ARE UNDERTAKEN WITHIN THE CONTEXT OF THIS PRIMARY PURPOSE.

SAUVIE ISLAND WILDLIFE AREA IS ONE OF SEVERAL WETLAND-FOCUSED WILDLIFE AREAS MANAGED BY THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OFFISH AND WILDLIFE (ODFW). THE WILDLIFE AREA IS LOCATED IN COLUMBIA AND MULTNOMAH COUNTIES, SOUTH OF THECONFLUENCE OF THE COLUMBIA RIVER AND MULTNOMAH CHANNEL, APPROXIMATELY 12 MILES FROM DOWNTOWN PORTLAND.SAUVIE ISLAND WILDLIFE AREA (11,643 ACRES) IS MANAGED PRIMARILY TO PRESERVE AND ENHANCE WETLANDS AND ASSOCIATEDUPLAND HABITATS IN THE COLUMBIA RIVER BOTTOMLANDS TO SUPPORT A DIVERSE ARRAY OF FISH, WILDLIFE AND PLANT SPECIES,FOR USE AND ENJOYMENT BY PRESENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS.1. PROVIDE WETLAND HABITAT FOR WATERFOWL AND OTHER WATER BIRDS.2. PROVIDE FORAGE HABITAT FOR WINTERING CANADA GEESE.3. MEET OREGON CONSERVATION STRATEGY OBJECTIVES FOR SPECIES AND HABITATS.PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR HUNTERS, ANGLERS, WILDLIFE VIEWERS AND OTHER WILDLIFE-ORIENTED RECREATIONAL USERS.

THERE IS A NEED TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTS OF WILDFIRE ON SAGE-GROUSE ECOLOGY FOR A MINIMUM OF 10 YEARS TO MAKEEFFECTIVE AND IMPACTFUL MANAGEMENT AND RESTORATION DECISIONS IN THE FUTURE GIVEN THE UNPRECEDENTED RATE AND SCALEOF WILDFIRES ACROSS THE GREAT BASIN, COUPLED WITH THE SLOW RECOVERY OF SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEMS, AND THAT SAGE-GROUSEARE CONSIDERED A LONGER-LIVING GALLIFORM,THIS PROJECT WILL TARGET HIGH DENSITY SAGE-GROUSE POPULATIONS WITHIN THE PERIMETER OF THE HOLLOWAY FIRE, BUT ITIS EXPECTED THAT SOME OF THESE BIRDS MAY ALSO USE PORTIONS OF THE LONG DRAW FIRE.THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO (1) COMPLETE THE COLLECTION BIOLOGICAL DATA ON SAGE-GROUSE FOR POPULATION MODELS,(2) DETERMINE THE EFFECTS OF LEGAL HARVEST, (3) DETERMINE SOURCE-SINK HABITATS FOR NESTING AND BROOD-REARING, AND(4) IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF SAGE-GROUSE RESPONSE TO RESTORATION AND RECOVERY OPTIONS.

THE NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE (NDOW) GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEM (GIS) PROGRAM PROVIDES CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURE SUPPORT BY SUPPLYING EXPERTISE AND CAPACITY TO COLLECT, STORE, MANAGE, AND ANALYZE THE WILDLIFE RESOURCE, HABITAT, AND PROJECT RELATED DATA PRODUCED AND UTILIZED THROUGHOUT NDOW S WILDLIFE RESTORATION EFFORTS. THE GIS PROGRAM REQUIRES DEDICATED PERSONNEL, HARDWARE AND SOFTWARE INFRASTRUCTURE, AND TIME TO DEVELOP AND MAINTAIN NDOW S ROBUST AND SOPHISTICATED DATA MANAGEMENT SYSTEM. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE THE ESSENTIAL FUNDING BASIS TO MEET THESE NEEDS AND ENSURE NDOW REMAINS TECHNICALLY CAPABLE OF MAKING EFFECTIVE WILDLIFE AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT DECISIONS GROUNDED IN DATA-DRIVEN SCIENCE.

TO REPAIR AND OR REPLACE IRRIGATION INFRASTRUCTURE ON IDFG PROPERTIES ACROSS THE STATE. IRRIGATION IS USED TO MANAGE THE VOLUME, FREQUENCY, AND APPLICATION OF WATER ON PROPERTIES MANAGED BY THE IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME. GROUND DISTURBANCE WILL BE DEPENDENT UPON THE TYPE OF INFRASTRUCTURE BEING IMPLEMENTED AND WHERE IT IS BEING INSTALLED.

TO REPAIR AND OR REPLACE FENCING ON IDFG PROPERTIES ACROSS THE STATE. FENCING IS INSTALLED IN AREAS WITH THE INTENTION OF CONTROLLING THE MOVEMENT OF PEOPLE, ANIMALS, AND VEHICLES. FENCING COMPLETED UNDER THIS AGREEMENT IS INTENDED TO BE INSTALLED WITHIN THE EXISTING FOOTPRINT OF CURRENT FENCE INFRASTRUCTURE.

FOLLOWING DROUGHTS IN THE 1930S THAT AFFECTED MOST OF NORTH AMERICA, MAJOR CONSERVATION EFFORTS, BOTH PRIVATE ANDGOVERNMENTAL WERE ENACTED TO REVERSE TRENDS OF DEGRADED AND DISAPPEARING WETLANDS THROUGHOUT THE CONTINENT.DURING THIS TIME PERIOD THERE WAS A MAJOR CREATION AND EXPANSION OF FEDERAL REFUGES AND STATE WILDLIFE AREAS.THE KLAMATH WILDLIFE AREA WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1958, WITH PRIMARY OBJECTIVES OF PROTECTING AND ENHANCING WATERFOWLHABITATS AND PROVIDING A VARIETY OF WILDLIFE ORIENTED RECREATIONAL AND EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. KLAMATHWILDLIFE AREA WAS ONE OF SEVERAL WETLAND FOCUSED WILDLIFE AREAS ESTABLISHED IN OREGON AND MANAGED BY THE OREGONDEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE. CURRENTLY KLAMATH WILDLIFE AREA IS COMPRISED OF FOUR MAIN GEOGRAPHICALLYSEPARATED UNITS TOTALING 3,628 ACRES. THE MILLER ISLAND UNIT IS THE LARGEST AT 2,680 ACRES, THE MAJORITY OFMANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES OCCUR ON THIS UNIT. DUE TO ITS GEOGRAPHIC SETTING, SPECIES DIVERSITY AND ABUNDANCE OFWILDLIFE PRESENT, KLAMATH WILDLIFE AREA IS A POPULAR DESTINATION FOR HUNTING, WILDLIFE VIEWING AND ENVIRONMENTALEDUCATION.THE PURPOSE OF KLAMATH WILDLIFE AREA IS FOR THE PROTECTION AND ENHANCEMENT OF HABITAT FOR ALL ENDEMIC WILDLIFEUSING SOUND STEWARDSHIP MEASURES, PROVIDING WILDLIFE RESOURCES FOR USE AND ENJOYMENT BY PRESENT AND FUTUREGENERATIONS WHILE REDUCING WATERFOWL DEPREDATION ON ADJACENT PRIVATE LANDS.THE FEDERAL AID TO WILDLIFE RESTORATION ACT OF 1937 (PITTMAN-ROBERTSON ACT OR PR) WAS THE MAJOR FUNDING SOURCEUSED FOR ACQUISITION OF LANDS. THIS FUNDING PROVIDED FOR INITIAL DEVELOPMENT OF KWAS INFRASTRUCTURE ANDCONTINUES AS THE SOLE SOURCE FOR OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE ACTIVITIES.

THE WHITE RIVER WILDLIFE AREA IS MANAGED PRIMARILY TO MINIMIZE OR ALLEVIATE CONFLICTS CAUSED BY ELK AND DEER TOPRIVATELY OWNED LANDS AND AGRICULTURAL CROPS. ALL MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES ON THE WRWA ARE UNDERTAKEN WITHIN THECONTEXT OF THIS PRIMARY GOAL.THE NATURAL RESOURCES IN THE WRWA NEED TO BE MANAGED IN SUCH A MANNER AS TO PROTECT, MAINTAIN, ENHANCE, ANDRESTORE FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT TO SUPPORT OPTIMUM POPULATION LEVELS OF ALL SPECIES FOR THE ENJOYMENT OFPRESENT AND FUTURE CITIZENS.TO PROTECT THESE NATURAL RESOURCES, MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS AND STRATEGIES UTILIZED ON THE WRWA WILL MEET OR EXCEEDHABITAT PROTECTION POLICIES AND STANDARDS SET BY THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE.OVERALL PROJECT GOAL: DEVELOP ADDITIONAL WILDLIFE HABITAT, CONTINUE MAINTENANCE AND MANAGEMENT OF EXISTINGHABITAT DEVELOPMENTS, MAINTENANCE, AND IMPROVEMENTS TO EQUIPMENT, FACILITIES AND INFRASTRUCTURE, WILDLIFE HABITATAND POPULATION MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT, AND PUBLIC USE PROGRAMS AS LISTED.TASK 1: TO MINIMIZE OR ALLEVIATE CONFLICTS CAUSED BY DEER AND ELK TO PRIVATELY OWNED LANDS AND AGRICULTURAL CROPSTHROUGH SUPPLEMENTAL FEEDING AND HABITAT ENHANCEMENT PRACTICES.TASK 2: CONDUCT PROJECT ADMINISTRATION ON 1 WILDLIFE AREA TO SUPPORT AND IMPLEMENT ACTIVITIES. MAINTAININFRASTRUCTURE AND EQUIPMENT. PROVIDE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR WILDLIFE-ORIENTED RECREATION ON WHITE RIVERWILDLIFE AREA.

CURRENTLY, FLORIDA S WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA (WMA) SYSTEM CONSISTS OF OVER 150 TRACTS AND 6 MILLION ACRES. THERE ARE 82 WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS AND 4.55 MILLION ACRES ON THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION GRANT. FLORIDA S WMAS PROVIDE A VARIETY OF RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES, SUCH AS HUNTING, FISHING, AND WILDLIFE VIEWING. THESE NATURAL AREAS ALSO PROVIDE VALUE BY MAINTAINING ENDANGERED SPECIES, PRESERVING WETLANDS, AND PROVIDING A STABLE ECOSYSTEM. AS FLORIDA S LANDSCAPE BECOME SUBJECT TO MORE GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT, THE FUTURE OF MANY WILDLIFE SPECIES WILL REST WITH HOW GOOD WE ARE AS LAND MANAGERS AND STEWARDS OF THE RESOURCES. IT IS IMPERATIVE THAT SOUND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES ARE IMPLEMENTED ON THESE CONSERVATION LANDS TO PROTECT THE NATURAL RESOURCES AND BALANCE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE THE DEVELOPMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF WMAS IN FLORIDA. THIS GRANT WILL RESTORE, MAINTAIN, AND ENHANCE THE HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE AND ASSIST IN PROVIDING PUBLIC ACCESS TO THE WMAS OF FLORIDA.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH   WILDLIFE S (CDFW) NORTH CENTRAL REGION (NCR) WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM(WMP) IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE GEOGRAPHIC REGION WHICH INCLUDES THE NORTHERN SACRAMENTO VALLEY AND THE CENTRALSIERRA. THIS AREA SPANS SEVENTEEN COUNTIES AND CONTAINS A NETWORK OF OVER 82,000 ACRES OF DEPARTMENT OWNED LAND.THE BREAKDOWN OF THESE LANDS IS AS FOLLOWS:  TYPE C  OR UNSTAFFED WILDLIFE AREAS (WA  61,403 ACRES), ECOLOGICALRESERVES (ER  10,725 ACRES), AND NON-DESIGNATED LANDS (10,000 ACRES). THESE PROPERTIES ARE HEREAFTER COLLECTIVELYREFERRED TO AS  CONSERVED LANDS. THESE LANDS WERE ORIGINALLY PURCHASED BY OR TRANSFERRED TO CDFW BY THE WILDLIFE CONSERVATION BOARD (WCB) ANDOTHER AGENCIES. THOUGH THE PRECISE PURPOSE OF THE ACQUISITIONS HAS VARIED THROUGH THE YEARS, THE MANAGEMENTOBJECTIVES REMAIN THE SAME: CONSERVATION AND PRESERVATION OF WILDLIFE HABITATS AND SUPPORTING COMPATIBLE PUBLICUSE. IN ACCORDANCE WITH THIS MISSION, THE CDFW MANAGES COMPATIBLE PUBLIC USE ACTIVITIES, WHICH MAY VARY FROMPROPERTY TO PROPERTY AND INCLUDE: HUNTING, FISHING, HIKING, WILDLIFE WATCHING, BICYCLING, HORSEBACK RIDING,NATURE STUDY, RESEARCH, AND OTHER SUITABLE FORMS OF OUTDOOR RECREATION.

THE UTAH DIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES (UDWR) HAS AN OPPORTUNITY TO ACQUIRE APPROXIMATELY 701.45 ACRES OF CONTIGUOUS, PRIVATELY OWNED, UNDEVELOPED LAND, AND 138.22 WATER SHARES IN BOX ELDER COUNTY, UTAH. ACQUISITION OF THIS PROPERTY WILL PROTECT IMPORTANT HABITAT FOR WATERFOWL, SHOREBIRDS, WILDLIFE AND PROVIDE PUBLIC OPPORTUNITY FOR WILDLIFE-RELATED RECREATION ACCESS. THIS PROPERTY ENCOMPASSES THE NORTHERN 1 3 OF THE SALT CREEK WMA REST AREA POND AND PROVIDES CRUCIAL YEAR-ROUND HABITAT FOR A VARIETY OF AVIAN SPECIES, BUT PARTICULARLY FOR WATERFOWL, SHOREBIRDS AND PHEASANTS. DUE TO THE CRUCIAL HABITATS, WILDLIFE, GEOGRAPHIC LOCATION, AND LARGE AMOUNT OF WATER SHARES, UDWR IDENTIFIED THIS AS CRITICAL PROPERTY. IT IS THE THE INTENT OF THE UDWR TO COMPLETE THIS TRANSACTION BY DECEMBER 2023.THIS ACQUISITION WILL INCREASE THE ACREAGE OF THE SALT CREEK WATERFOWL MANAGEMENT AREA FOR THE PROTECTION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES, PROPAGATION OF WILDLIFE, AND WILL ENHANCE THE WETLANDS AND ASSOCIATED UPLANDS. THE ACQUISITION WILL ALSO PROVIDE ADDITIONAL RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR WATERFOWL HUNTING, WILDLIFE-RELATED RECREATION AND PHEASANT HUNTING. THE ASSOCIATED WATER SHARES WILL SECURE CRITICAL WATER AND ALLOW FOR INCREASED MANAGEMENT OF OPEN WATER. UNDER UDWR OWNERSHIP AND MANAGEMENT, THE PROPERTY WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO THE EXISTING SALT CREEK WMA, AND THE ESTABLISHED SALT CREEK WATERFOWL HABITAT MANAGEMENT PLAN WILL GOVERN THE MANAGEMENT OF THE NEWLY ACQUIRED PROPERTY. MANAGEMENT OF THIS AREA IS DIRECTED TO MAINTAIN A DIVERSIFIED PLANT COMMUNITY WITH A DIVERSIFIED STRUCTURAL COMPONENT.ACQUISITION OF THIS PROPERTY WILL PROTECT CRITICAL WATER AND IMPORTANT HABITAT FOR WATERFOWL, SHOREBIRDS, WILDLIFE AND PROVIDE PUBLIC OPPORTUNITIES FOR WILDLIFE RECREATION ACCESS.

THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION (ODWC) WILL CONDUCT THE PLANNING ACTIVITIES NEEDED TO CONSTRUCT A PUBLIC-USE ARCHERY PARK AT ARCADIA CONSERVATION EDUCATION AREA, LOCATED EAST OF EDMOND. THIS PARK WILL INCREASE TARGET SHOOTING AND HUNTER SKILLS-BUILDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR ODWC S CONSTITUENTS, ESPECIALLY THOSE IN THE OKLAHOMA CITY METROPOLITAN AREA. FUNDS WILL BE USED TO COMPLETE ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLIANCE WORK, AS WELL AS ENGINEERING CONSULTATION TO DETERMINE THE FEASIBILITY OF THE PROJECT. ENGINEERING PLANS WILL INCLUDE SITE DESIGN, CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS AND CONSTRUCTION BUDGET ESTIMATES.

THE NATIONAL BOBWHITE   GRASSLAND INITIATIVE WILL CONTRACTUALLY ASSIST KDFWR WITH CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION PLANNING, ASSESSMENT, AND RESTORATION ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH BOBWHITE AND GRASSLAND HABITAT MANAGEMENT.
COLORADO PARKS AND WILDLIFE (CPW) WILL CONSTRUCT A NEW 66  X 40  METAL SHOP BUILDING AT TETER-MICHIGAN CREEK STATE WILDLIFE AREA IN PARK COUNTY, COLORADO.

THE CDFW NORTHERN REGION (NR) IS RESPONSIBLE FOR MANAGING ALL CDFW LANDS IN THE NORTHERN NINE COUNTIES OFCALIFORNIA (DEL NORTE, HUMBOLDT, LASSEN, MENDOCINO, MODOC, SHASTA, SISKIYOU, TEHAMA AND TRINITY COUNTIES). THE NR HAS SEVEN STAFFED WILDLIFE AREAS (AREAS)  ASH CREEK WILDLIFE AREA (ACWA), BUTTE VALLEY WILDLIFE AREA (BVWA),HONEY LAKE WILDLIFE AREA (HLWA), HORSESHOE RANCH WILDLIFE AREA (HRWA), LAKE EARL WILDLIFE AREA (LEWA), SHASTAVALLEY WILDLIFE AREA (SVWA), AND WILLOW CREEK WILDLIFE AREA (WCWA) COMPRISING OVER 58,280 ACRES OF MANAGEDWILDLIFE HABITAT.MOST OF THESE LANDS WERE ORIGINALLY PURCHASED BY THE WCB BETWEEN 1941 AND 1991. FUNDING FROM WR WAS ALSO USED SPECIFICALLY TO ACQUIRE HLWA. WHILE THE PURPOSE OF THE ACQUISITIONS HAS VARIED THROUGH THE YEARS, THE GOALS HAVE REMAINED THE SAME: CONSERVATION, RESTORATION, AND ENHANCEMENT OF HABITATS FOR WILDLIFE, WHILE PROVIDING FORCOMPATIBLE PUBLIC RECREATION SUCH AS HUNTING, FISHING, WILDLIFE VIEWING, NATURE STUDY, ETC.SUBSEQUENT ADDITIONS TO THE AREAS HAVE FOCUSED ON IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PACIFIC COAST AND INTERMOUNTAIN WESTJOINT VENTURES AND PROTECTION OF SENSITIVE SPECIES AND THE HABITATS THEY DEPEND ON. WCB, ON BEHALF OF THE STATE,HAS ASSIGNED OVERALL MANAGEMENT OF THESE LANDS TO THE CDFW.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO FUND THE RESEARCH AND OUTREACH WORK FOR THE DEPARTMENTS FURBEARER MANAGEMENT PROGRAM. IN DOING SO, THE GRANT HAS THREE OBJECTIVES: 1)TO MONITOR AND MANAGE THE POPULATIONS OF HARVESTED FURBEARER SPECIES IN THE STATE OF VERMONT  2)TO DO HABITAT MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION FOR FURBEARER SPECIES, AND  3)TO DISSEMINATE INFORMATION RELATED TO THE FURBEARER MANAGEMENT PROGRAM TO THE PUBLIC.THE APPROACHES FOR ACHIEVING THESE GOALS ARE THROUGH POPULATION INVENTORY, MONITORING, AND MANAGEMENT, HABITAT MONITORING AND CONSERVATION, AND HUMAN DIMENSIONS AND DISSEMINATION OF RESULTS.

THE PHEASANT PROPAGATION PROGRAM IS USED BY DEC TO PROMOTE HUNTER RECRUITMENT, RETENTION, AND REACTIVATION THROUGH THE TARGETED RELEASE OF PEN-REARED PHEASANTS TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITY, ACCESS, INCREASED ODDS OF SUCCESS, AND ULTIMATELY STABILIZE OR INCREASE THE NUMBER OF PHEASANT HUNTERS IN NEW YORK STATE. THIS GRANT WOULD BE USED TO MODERNIZE AND IMPROVE THE DEC PROPAGATION PROGRAM TO BETTER MEET THE PREFERENCES AND NEEDS OF NEW YORK HUNTERS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS THE COORDINATION OF DELAWARE S WILDLIFE RESTORATION GRANT MANAGEMENT PROCESSES AND MAINTENANCE OF DELAWARE S PROGRAM ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE COORDINATION AND ADMINISTRATION OF PROGRAMMATIC AND FINANCIAL ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH WILDLIFE RESTORATION GRANT APPLICATIONS AND AGREEMENTS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE DELAWARE S ELIGIBILITY FOR PARTICIPATION IN THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION PROGRAM, TIMELY SUBMISSION OF GRANT APPLICATION PACKAGES AND PERFORMANCE REPORTS, EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATION AND COORDINATION OF ALL ASPECTS OF THE PROGRAM AND GRANT ACTIVITIES WITH THE WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM, AND EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATION, COORDINATION AND TRAINING FOR DELAWARE LEADERSHIP, MANAGEMENT, PROJECT LEADERS AND STAFF. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE CONSERVATION MANAGERS AND SCIENTISTS IMPLEMENTING GRANT-FUNDED PROJECTS AIMED AT IMPROVING WILDLIFE AND WILDLIFE HABITAT IN DELAWARE FOR THE BENEFIT OF HUNTERS AND THOSE WHO ENJOY VIEWING OR PHOTOGRAPHING WILDLIFE. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THIS PROJECT.

THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS GRANT IS TO EXPAND THE AGENCYS EXISTING WMA SYSTEM TO HELP ACHIEVE THE WVDNRSMISSION OF PROVIDING AND ADMINISTERING A LONG-RANGE COMPREHENSIVE PROGRAM FOR THE EXPLORATION, CONSERVATION,DEVELOPMENT, PROTECTION, ENJOYMENT AND USE OF THE NATURAL RESOURCES OF THE STATE OF WEST VIRGINIA. WVDNRS WMAPROGRAM IS DESIGNED TO PROTECT, CONSERVE AND OR MANAGE HIGH QUALITY WILDLIFE HABITAT FOR A VARIETY OF WILDLIFESPECIES (MANY OF WHICH ARE IDENTIFIED IN THE STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN) AND TO INCREASE PUBLIC ACCESS ANDRECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THESE RESOURCES.THE WVDNR, WILDLIFE RESOURCES SECTION ANTICIPATES ACQUIRING 15,000 TO 25,000 ACRES OF ADDITIONAL WMAS DURING THE5-YEAR GRANT PERIOD.

THE DEER HABITAT PROJECT IN LEXINGTON TOWNSHIP, MAINE, WILL PROTECT 1,452 ACRES WITHIN A 30-MILE RADIUS OF SEVERAL SMALL TOWNS WHERE 22,477 PEOPLE LIVE. APPROXIMATELY 846 ACRES (58 ) OF THE PROPERTY HAS BEEN DESIGNATED BY DEPARTMENT BIOLOGISTS AS BIOLOGICAL DEER WINTERING AREA, AND AREAS OUTSIDE OF THE BIOLOGICAL DWA ACRES OFFER GREAT FUTURE POTENTIAL FOR DEER YARD MANAGEMENT BASED ON TOPOGRAPHY, SLOPE, ASPECT, AND VEGETATION SPECIES COMPOSITION. THE MIX OF FOREST, RIPARIAN HABITAT, AND WETLANDS ALSO PROVIDE HABITAT FOR A WIDE VARIETY OF BIRDS, MAMMALS, FISH AND OTHER WILDLIFE.CONSERVATION OF THIS AREA WILL ESTABLISH A SECURE HAVEN FOR DEER AT THE NORTHERN BOUNDARY OF THEIR RANGE, EVEN AS THAT BOUNDARY MOVES NORTH OVER TIME DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE, AND GUARANTEE PUBLIC ACCESS FOR HUNTERS, TRAPPERS, AND OTHER OUTDOOR RECREATIONISTS.

RECOVERING, CONSERVING, AND MANAGING A SPECIES REQUIRES ESTIMATES OF THEIR ABUNDANCE AND DENSITIES ACROSS THE LANDSCAPE OVER TIME (BOITANI AND POWELL 2012). THIS INFORMATION IS NECESSARY TO TRACK TRENDS IN POPULATION GROWTH AND ASSESS SPECIES STATUS, TO MAKE SCIENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT DECISIONS, AND DETERMINE WHEN RECOVERY GOALS HAVE BEEN MET. RECOLONIZING POPULATIONS OF THREATENED LARGE CARNIVORES MAY BE ESPECIALLY VULNERABLE TO STOCHASTIC EVENTS IN THE ENVIRONMENT (HELLGREN ET AL. 2005) AND LOSS OF INDIVIDUALS FROM HUMAN-CAUSED MORTALITIES (LOGAN 2019, LAMB ET AL. 2020). THEREFORE, REGULAR POPULATION MONITORING OF SUCH SPECIES WITH SOUND MONITORING PROTOCOLS IS ESSENTIAL TO UNDERSTAND HOW THESE EVENTS IMPACT THE POPULATION AND TO DEVELOP EFFECTIVE CONSERVATION STRATEGIES.BLACK BEARS (URSUS AMERICANUS) ARE A RECOVERING SPECIES IN TEXAS. THROUGH NATURAL RECOLONIZATION, BEARS RETURNED TO THE STATE FROM THE MOUNTAINS OF MEXICO (ONORATO AND HELLGREN 2001). HOWEVER, A MIGRATION AND DISPERSAL EVENT IN 2000 REDUCED THE POPULATION IN TEXAS FROM 29 INDIVIDUALS DOWN TO 5-7 INDIVIDUALS (HELLGREN ET AL. 2005). SINCE THAT EVENT, BEAR POPULATIONS HAVE REBOUNDED BUT LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT THE POPULATION TRENDS FOR BEARS IN TEXAS IN THE LAST TWO DECADES, WHICH COMPLICATES RECOVERY EFFORTS. EFFECTIVE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF BLACK BEARS IN TEXAS WILL RELY ON AN IN-DEPTH KNOWLEDGE OF POPULATION DYNAMICS AS WELL AS EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES TO ASSIST WITH NATURAL RECOLONIZATION.NON-INVASIVE GENETIC SAMPLING FROM HAIR SNARES CONFIGURED APPROPRIATELY ON THE LANDSCAPE TOGETHER WITH GPS COLLAR MOVEMENT INFORMATION CAN PROVIDE DATA FOR ESTIMATING BEAR DENSITY AND ABUNDANCE (HUMM ET AL. 2017  GOULD ET AL. 2018  HOOKER ET AL. 2020), EVEN IN LOW-DENSITY RECOLONIZING POPULATIONS (MURPHY ET AL. 2016, SOLLMANN ET AL 2016, SUN ET AL 2017, TUMENDEMBEREL ET AL 2021), AND FOR MODELING HOW DENSITY MAY CHANGE OVER TIME RELATED TO CHANGES IN BEAR SPACE-USE. USING THESE METHODS, OUR PROJECT WILL PROVIDE THE FIRST DENSITY ESTIMATES FOR BLACK BEARS IN THE REGION OUTSIDE OF BIG BEND NATIONAL PARK, A COMPREHENSIVE FRAMEWORK FOR FUTURE MONITORING OF BLACK BEAR POPULATIONS IN THE STATE, PREDICT AREAS OF LIKELY RECOLONIZATION, AND PROVIDE TANGIBLE INFORMATION TO PLAN FUTURE BLACK BEAR MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS.

THE NEED FOR HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAMS IN THE STATE OF UTAH IS WIDELY COMPLEX AND SPANS LEGISLATIVE MANDATE, AGENCY MISSION AND A VARIETY OF PUBLIC NEED. THIS GRANT PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING FOR THE OPERATION AND MANAGEMENT OF THE UTAH HUNTER EDUCATION, BOWHUNTER EDUCATION, AND FURHARVESTER EDUCATION PROGRAMS. PROGRAM ADMINISTRATION INCLUDES MAINTENANCE OF STUDENT RECORDS, ISSUING OF COMPLETION CERTIFICATES, VOLUNTEER INSTRUCTOR TRAINING AND RECOGNITION, COURSE SCHEDULING, MATERIALS, CURRICULUM AND DELIVERY, ETC.THE HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAMS ASSIST THE DIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES IN FULFILLING ITS MISSION BY EDUCATION HUNTERS TO BE SAFE, RESPONSIBLE, KNOWLEDGEABLE, AND INVOLVED.

THE GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES WILL PURCHASE THE 386 ACRE JUPITER TRACTS, WHICH WILL BECOME PART OF THE TALLAPOOSA RIVER WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA. ACQUIRING THE JUPITER TRACT WOULD IMPROVE OUR ABILITY TO MANAGE THE EXISTING AREA, CONSERVE IMPORTANT WILDLIFE HABITAT AND INCREASE PUBLIC HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES BY SECURING PERMANENT OWNERSHIP OF THESE TRACTS.

THE GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, WILDLIFE RESOURCES DIVISION (WRD) WILL RENOVATE THE CAMPGROUNDS AT CLYBEL AND TUCKAHOE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS BY CONSTRUCTING BATH HOUSES, AND PROVIDING WATER, POWER AND SEWER HOOK-UPS FOR RECREATIONAL VEHICLES (CAMPERS AND MOTOR HOMES) AND TENT SITES. THE IMPROVEMENTS WILL INCREASE ACCESS TO WILDLIFE-ASSOCIATED RECREATION IN THE RESPECTIVE WMAS.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) HAS TRUSTEE RESPONSIBILITY FOR MANAGING THE STATE S DIVERSE WILDLIFE RESOURCES AS WELL AS THE HABITATS UPON WHICH THEY DEPEND. IN PART, THE WILDLIFE POLICY OF THE STATE IS TO PROVIDE BENEFICIAL USE AND ENJOYMENT OF WILDLIFE BY ALL CITIZENS  MAINTAIN DIVERSIFIED RECREATIONAL USES OF WILDLIFE, INCLUDING SPORT HUNTING  PROVIDE FOR ECONOMIC CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE CITIZENS OF THE STATE THROUGH REGULATED MANAGEMENT  AND MAINTAIN SUFFICIENT POPULATIONS OF ALL WILDLIFE SPECIES AND THE HABITAT NECESSARY TO ACHIEVE THE ABOVE-STATE OBJECTIVES (FISH AND GAME CODE SECTIONS 1801-1802). BIGHORN SHEEP, MOUNTAIN LION, MULE DEER, AND BLACK BEAR ARE HIGH-PROFILE LARGE MAMMAL SPECIES OCCURRING WITHIN CDFW S SOUTH COAST REGION (SCR). CONSERVATION OF THESE SPECIES IS CARRIED OUT BY THE CDFW JOINTLY THROUGH STATEWIDE AND REGIONAL WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS. CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES UNDERTAKEN BY THE CDFW INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO DESIGNING AND IMPLEMENTING POPULATION ASSESSMENT AND MONITORING SURVEYS  DESIGNING AND IMPLEMENTING RESEARCH PROJECTS  DESIGNING, COORDINATING, AND IMPLEMENTING HABITAT ENHANCEMENT PROJECTS  AND DISSEMINATING INFORMATION ON SPECIES OCCURRENCE, DISTRIBUTION, AND ABUNDANCE TO THE PUBLIC, STATE AND FEDERAL RESOURCE AND LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES, AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS.

MANY SPECIES RELY ON THE ABILITY TO MOVE THROUGHOUT THE LANDSCAPE TO FULFILL THEIR DAILY AND SEASONAL NEEDS FORACCESS TO FOOD, SHELTER, AND OPPORTUNITIES TO REPRODUCE. THESE MOVEMENTS REQUIRE WILDLIFE TO NAVIGATEINCREASINGLY HUMAN-DOMINATED LANDSCAPES AND CAN BRING WILDLIFE INTO CONFLICT WITH PEOPLE. ONE OF THE AREAS OFHIGHEST CONFLICT IS ALONG ROADWAYS, WHERE COLLISIONS WITH WILDLIFE OFTEN CAUSE INJURY OR MORTALITY TO ANIMALS ANDPOSE A SIGNIFICANT SAFETY RISK FOR MOTORISTS. US HIGHWAY 20 BETWEEN BEND AND SUTTLE LAKE, OREGON, HAS ONE OF THEHIGHEST RATES OF COLLISIONS WITH DEER AND ELK IN THE STATE. AS TRAFFIC VOLUMES AND VEHICLE SPEEDS INCREASE INTHIS REGION DUE TO GROWING RESIDENTIAL AND RECREATIONAL PRESSURE, MITIGATION IS NEEDED TO IMPROVE WILDLIFECONNECTIVITY ACROSS ROADWAYS, REDUCE WILDLIFE-VEHICLE COLLISIONS, AND IMPROVE MOTORIST SAFETY. THE OVERALLPROJECT GOAL IS TO DEVELOP A PLAN IDENTIFYING SUITABLE SITES ALONG THIS CORRIDOR FOR INSTALLATION OF WILDLIFECROSSING STRUCTURES TO FACILITATE SAFE PASSAGE OF WILDLIFE ACROSS THE HIGHWAY, EVALUATE DESIGN ALTERNATIVES, ANDTO SELECT PREFERRED CONCEPTUAL DESIGNS FOR STRUCTURES AT EACH SITE. THIS PLAN WILL HELP INFORM AND INFLUENCEFUTURE ROADWAY AND TRAFFIC MANAGEMENT IN THIS CORRIDOR, IDENTIFY ANY ADDITIONAL NEEDS TO MAKE WILDLIFE CROSSINGSTRUCTURES FEASIBLE (E.G., RECREATION MANAGEMENT, CONSERVATION EASEMENTS, FENCING MODIFICATIONS, ETC.) ANDPROVIDE THE NECESSARY DESIGN INFORMATION FOR THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION TO ENGINEER AND CONSTRUCTSTRUCTURES THAT WILL EFFECTIVELY IMPROVE WILDLIFE CONNECTIVITY AND REDUCE WILDLIFE-VEHICLE COLLISIONS.

THE NORTH CAROLINA WILDLIFE RESOURCES COMMISSION MANAGES FIVE PUBLIC SHOOTING RANGES THROUGHOUT THE STATE WHERE ENTHUSIASTS CAN PRACTICE AND PERFECT THEIR HUNTING AND SHOOTING SKILLS AND ABILITIES : FLINTLOCK VALLEY SHOOTING RANGE IN MONTGOMERY COUNTY, WAYNE E. SMITH COLD MOUNTAIN SHOOTING RANGE IN HAYWOOD COUNTY, JOHN LENTZ SHOOTING RANGE IN RICHMOND COUNTY, CASWELL SHOOTING RANGE IN CASWELL COUNTY AND HOLLY SHELTER SHOOTING RANGE IN PENDER COUNTY. ADDITIONALLY, NCWRC PARTNERS WITH THE US FORESTRY SERVICE AND PENDER COUNTY IN THE IMPROVEMENTS AND UPGRADES OF THESE FACILITIES FOOTHILLS SHOOTING COMPLEX, MOSS KNOB SHOOTING RANGE, PANTHER TOP SHOOTING RANGE, DIRTY JOHN SHOOTING RANGE AND ATOAH SHOOTING RANGE. THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO CONTINUALLY IMPROVE AND MAINTAIN THESE FACILITIES FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE PUBLIC.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) ESTABLISHED THE SAN FELIPE VALLEY WILDLIFE AREA COMPLEX (SFVWAC) IN NORTHEASTERN SAN DIEGO COUNTY IN 1995 TO CONSERVE AND ENHANCE KEY HABITAT FOR SOUTHERN MULE DEER. KEY HABITATS ON SFVWA INCLUDE RIPARIAN WOODLAND, OAK WOODLAND, MIXED HARDWOOD-CONIFER FOREST, AND NATIVE GRASSLAND. A SECONDARY PURPOSE FOR ESTABLISHING SFVWA WAS TO ALLOW COMPATIBLE WILDLIFE DEPENDENT PUBLIC USE WHILE PROVIDING ACCESS TO APPROXIMATELY 19,800 ACRES OF ADJACENT FEDERAL BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT (BLM) LANDS. EXPANSION OF THE SFVWA IS ON-GOING WITH PREVIOUS LAND ACQUISITIONS RESULTING IN TWO SEPARATE MANAGEMENT UNITS TOTALING 17,794 ACRES. THESE INCLUDE THE 14,449-ACRE SFVWA UNIT AND THE 3,244-ACRE OAK GROVE (OG) UNIT. COLLECTIVELY THESE UNITS ARE REFERRED TO AS THE SAN FELIPE VALLEY WILDLIFE AREA COMPLEX (SFVWAC). IN 2003, CDFW BEGAN ACQUIRING LANDS KNOWN AS THE HOLLENBECK CANYON WILDLIFE AREA (HCWA) TO PROTECT, CONSERVE AND ENHANCE THE UPLAND AND RIPARIAN HABITATS PRESENT ON THE AREA AND THE SPECIES ASSOCIATED WITH THE VARIOUS HABITATS FOUND ON THE AREA. HCWA CURRENTLY CONSISTS OF APPROXIMATELY 6,927 ACRES WITH KEY HABITATS INCLUDING RIPARIAN WOODLAND, COASTAL SAGE SCRUB, MIXED CHAPARRAL, AND NATIVE GRASSLAND. SECONDARILY, HCWA WAS ACQUIRED TO PROVIDE FOR COMPATIBLE, WILDLIFE DEPENDENT RECREATION, INCLUDING HUNTING, WILDLIFE OBSERVATION, AND A VARIETY OF NATURE STUDY USES. SINCE THE AREA WAS ACQUIRED, THE CDFW AND ITS PARTNERS HAVE RESTORED RIPARIAN AND GRASSLAND AREAS TO BENEFIT UPLAND GAME SPECIES, RAPTORS, SONGBIRDS, AND LARGE MAMMALS. SINCE ESTABLISHMENT OF THE SFVWAC AND HWAC, THE CDFW AND ITS PARTNERS HAVE RESTORED WATER SOURCES, REMOVED WILDLIFE HAZARDS, IMPROVED EXISTING INFRASTRUCTURE, AND ENHANCED NATIVE HABITATS TO BENEFIT MULE DEER AND OTHER GAME AND NON-GAME SPECIES.

MANAGERS HAVE THE CHALLENGE OF MAINTAINING HEALTHY STOCKS OF ELK, THEIR HABITAT, AND PROVIDING A RECREATIONALRESOURCE WHILE LIMITING CONFLICTS ON PRIVATE LAND. THIS PROJECT WILL COLLECT COMPREHENSIVE DATA ON:(1) ACCURATE,UNBIASED POPULATION PARAMETER DATA FOR POPULATION MODELS, ESPECIALLY ANNUAL COW AND CALF SURVIVAL RATES (ANDCAUSE SPECIFIC MORTALITY ESTIMATES), (2) THE HABITAT LANDSCAPE FEATURES USED PREFERRED BY ELK IN WESTERN OREGON(BASED ON AVAILABILITY), (3) ELK SEASONAL DISTRIBUTION PATTERNS AND MOVEMENTS, (4) THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN COWELK BODY CONDITION, FORAGE RESOURCE AVAILABILITY AND THE RESULTING CALF SURVIVAL RECRUITMENT AND (5) THEDEVELOPMENT OF HABITAT-BASED SURVEY METHODS TO DOCUMENT ELK POPULATION TRENDS. LACK OF IMMEDIATE ACTION INOBTAINING NEEDED DATA ON ROOSEVELT ELK WILL AFFECT ODFWS ABILITY TO MAKE SOUND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS, WHICH COULD LEAD TO LOSS OF HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES, LOSS OF REVENUE TO THE STATE, DECLINES IN ELK POPULATIONS, AND A REDUCEDABILITY OF THE ODFW TO MEET STATUTORY GOALS AND OBLIGATIONS.

THE BLACK HAWK PROPERTY IS OWNED BY THE BLACK HAWK DUCK AND GOOSE CLUB AND IS AN OASIS OF CONTIGUOUS, UNDEVELOPED LAND WITHIN THE HEART OF SALT LAKE COUNTY. THIS AREA IS CONSIDERED A CRITICAL COMPONENT TO THE GREAT SALT LAKES DESIGNATION AS A WESTERN HEMISPHERIC SHOREBIRD RESERVE NETWORK SITE. IN ADDITION, THIS PROPERTY ALONG WITH SEVERAL OTHER WETLAND AREAS AROUND THE GREAT SALT LAKE HAVE BEEN DECLARED BY THE NATIONAL AUDUBON SOCIETY AND THE AMERICAN BIRD CONSERVANCY AS A GLOBALLY IMPORTANT BIRD AREA (IBA).THIS PROPERTY PROVIDES CRITICAL WETLAND HABITAT ALONG THE GREAT SALT LAKE FOR THESE AND MANY OTHER MIGRATORY BIRDSPECIES. WHILE THE PROPERTY IS INCREDIBLY VALUABLE TO BIRDS, IT IS ALSO POTENTIAL HABITAT FOR MONARCH BUTTERFLY,A CANDIDATE SPECIES FOR LISTING UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. ADDITIONALLY, AS HABITAT FOR MANY WATERFOWL ANDUPLAND GAME SPECIES THIS PROPERTY ALSO PROVIDES VALUABLE POTENTIAL HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE PUBLIC. THECURRENT OWNERSHIP HAS RESTRICTED THIS HUNTING OPPORTUNITY TO ITS CLUB MEMBERS  HOWEVER, UNDER UDWR OWNERSHIP THISOPPORTUNITY WOULD BE EXPANDED TO ALL OF THE PUBLIC.BRINGING THIS BLACK HAWK PROPERTY INTO PUBLIC OWNERSHIP WOULD PERMANENTLY PROTECT KEY HABITAT AND PUBLIC GREENSPACE WITHIN THE INCREASING DEVELOPMENT OF SALT LAKE COUNTY. THIS ACQUISITION WILL PROVIDE UDWR AND PARTNERS WITHTHE OPPORTUNITY TO SECURE AN UNDEVELOPED PUBLIC LAND TREASURE THAT TODAY SUPPLIES IRREPLACEABLE ECOLOGICAL,RECREATIONAL, AND AESTHETIC VALUES ASSOCIATED WITH URBAN WILDLIFE AND WATERFOWL. BY SECURING FEE TITLE OF THEPROPERTY AND ASSOCIATED WATER RIGHTS AND WATER SHARES, THE WILDLIFE VALUES OF THE PROPERTY, IN PARTICULARWATERFOWL HABITAT, WILL BE PROTECTED.ACQUISITION OF THE BLACK HAWK PROPERTY WILL PROTECT THIS CRUCIAL WETLAND HABITAT FROM THE THREATS OF DEVELOPMENTAND OPEN UP SIGNIFICANT WATERFOWL HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES TO THE PUBLIC. THE ACQUISITION WILL CREATE A NEWWATERFOWL MANAGEMENT AREA (WMA) THAT WILL BE MANAGED FOR ACCESS, GRAZING, NOXIOUS WEED CONTROL, HUNTING, ANDHABITAT TREATMENTS ACCORDING TO AN ESTABLISHED HABITAT MANAGEMENT PLAN SPECIFIC TO THE PROPERTY.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR THE COORDINATION OF WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM GRANTS TO NEW HAMPSHIRE FISH AND GAME DEPARTMENT, AND THE ADMINISTRATION OF THESE FEDERAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS IN COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL REGULATIONS. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE STAFF, PROCEDURES, AND MATERIALS NECESSARY TO ENSURE THAT NEW HAMPSHIRE FISH AND GAME DEPARTMENT MEETS ITS RESPONSIBILITIES FOR PARTICIPATION IN THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAMS, INCLUDING WORK PLANNING, RECORD KEEPING, REPORTING, SUPERVISION OF FIELD STAFF, AND COORDINATION OF FEDERAL AID ACTIVITIES WITH OTHER STATE AND AGENCY PROGRAMS. EFFECTIVE ADMINISTRATION OF THESE FEDERAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS RESULTS IN AN EXPECTED OUTCOME OF PROPER AND EFFICIENT USE OF AVAILABLE PROGRAM FUNDING AND MAXIMIZES POTENTIAL BENEFITS TO WILDLIFE RESOURCES AND USER GROUPS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE NH FISH AND GAME PROGRAMS, WHICH BENEFIT FROM OUR ABILITY TO PROPERLY MANAGE THE GRANTS. THERE ARE NO SUB-RECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

THE NEW JERSEY FISH AND WILDLIFE MANAGES 122 STATE-OWNED WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS COMPRISING OVER 360,000 ACRES. THESE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS PROVIDE IMPORTANT RESOURCES FOR THE EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT OF HABITAT AND FISH AND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS. WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS ALSO PROVIDE THE PUBLIC WITH IMPORTANT ACCESS AND AMENITIES FOR ENGAGING IN WILDLIFE ASSOCIATED RECREATION. THIS PROJECT WILL CONDUCT HABITAT DEVELOPMENT AND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES THAT BENEFIT FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES AND THE HABITAT ON WHICH THEY DEPEND AND OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE ACTIVITIES TO ENSURE THE PUBLIC HAS SAFE AND ADEQUATE ACCESS TO WILDLIFE ASSOCIATED RECREATION.

THE OBJECTIVE IS TO REDUCE HUNTING AND FIREARMS RELATED ACCIDENTS, PROTECT HUMAN LIFE, ENCOURAGE RESPONSIBLE ETHICAL BEHAVIOR WHILE IN THE FIELD, AND TO EDUCATE THE NEW HUNTER IN THE BASIC PRINCIPLES OF SAFETY, WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AND OTHER RELATED TOPICS. THE HUNTER SAFETY GRANT IS A PITTMAN ROBERTSON QUALIFYING GRANT PROGRAM. ADMINISTRATION OF THE HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM IS THE RESPONSIBILITY OF THE SUPERINTENDENT OF THE NATURAL RESOURCES POLICE. UNDER THE NATURAL RESOURCES POLICE, THE SAFETY EDUCATION UNIT WAS CREATED TO OVERSEE THE STATEWIDE HUNTER EDUCATION AND BOATING SAFETY CLASSES. HUNTER EDUCATION COURSES ARE TAUGHT BY A CADRE OF APPROXIMATELY 1000 VOLUNTEER INSTRUCTORS AND THROUGH ON LINE AND HOME STUDY COURSES. EACH TRADITIONAL COURSE CONSISTS OF A MINIMUM OF TEN HOURS OF FORMAL INSTRUCTION. APPROXIMATELY 200 TRADITIONAL CLASSES AS WELL AS THE INDEPENDENT STUDY OPTIONS ARE OFFERED STATEWIDE AND OVER 7000 STUDENTS ARE INSTRUCTED ANNUALLY.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONSTRUCT WILDLIFE-VIEWING FACILITIES THROUGHOUT DELAWARE. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE DESIGN, ENGINEERING, AND CONSTRUCTION OF WILDLIFE-VIEWING STRUCTURES. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE PROVIDING ENHANCED ACCESSIBLE PUBLIC ACCESS FOR WILDLIFE-VIEWING ACTIVITIES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE MEMBERS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC INTERESTED IN PARTICIPATING IN WILDLIFE-VIEWING ACTIVITIES AND ENCOURAGING THOSE WHO MAY NOT BE AWARE OF OPPORTUNITIES TO VIEW WILDLIFE TO PARTICIPATE IN THIS OUTDOOR RECREATION. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES INVOLVED WITH THIS GRANT.

EARLY SUCCESSIONAL HABITAT IS IMPORTANT FOR A NUMBER OF SPECIES, INCLUDING: PHEASANTS, QUAIL, GROUSE, DEER, TURKEYS, RABBITS AND MANY MORE SPECIES. EARLY SUCCESSIONAL HABITAT IS THE VEGETATION THAT OCCURS ON A SITE IMMEDIATELY OR WITHIN THE NEXT GROWING SEASON AFTER THAT SITE HAS BEEN DISTURBED. DISTURBANCE CAN BE CAUSED BY FIRE, GRAZING, HAYING, FLOODING, DISKING, TILLING OR ANY OTHER ACTION THAT MIGHT REMOVE EXISTING VEGETATION AND CAUSE SEEDS IN THE SEED BANK TO GERMINATE. EARLY SUCCESSIONAL PLANTS THAT GERMINATE ARE GENERALLY HERBACEOUS ANNUALS AND PERENNIALS THAT QUICKLY OCCUPY DISTURBED SITES. EARLY SUCCESSIONAL HABITAT IS IMPORTANT BECAUSE OF THE FOOD, STRUCTURE AND DIVERSITY PROVIDED BY ITS COMPONENTS. THE PRIMARY NEED OF THIS GRANT IS TO PROVIDE FOR THE DEVELOPMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF EARLY SUCCESSIONAL VEGETATION ON MANY OF THE 280 WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS ACROSS NEBRASKA.
COLORADO PARKS AND WILDLIFE WILL REPLACE THE EXISTING PARKING LOT AT THE CRAIG WAREHOUSE FACILITY WITH A NEW AGGREGATE BASE COURSE AND ASPHALT SURFACE.
