THIS GRANT WILL FUND TWO PROJECTS FOCUSED ON PROACTIVE CONSERVATION OF BIRD AND MAMMAL SGCN THROUGH BOTH SPECIES SPECIFIC AND LANDSCAPE-SCALE APPROACHES. FIRST, THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES SPECIES RECOVERY, THROUGH DATA COLLECTIONAND ANALYSIS, MANAGEMENT AND PARTICIPATION IN MULTI-PARTNER SPECIES WORKING GROUPS AND TECHNICAL TEAMS, DIRECTCONSERVATION ACTION IMPLEMENTATION, AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE IN PLANNING AND PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION. FURTHER,THIS GRANT WILL FUND MANAGEMENT OF WDFWS FALCONRY PROGRAM, WHICH MAINTAINS THIS HISTORIC SPORT WHILE MANAGINGIMPACTS TO WILD RAPTOR POPULATIONS. SECOND, THIS PROJECT WILL INTEGRATE LANDSCAPE LEVEL-INFORMATION INTO SPECIESRECOVERY NEEDS, AND VICE VERSA, ACROSS BOTH PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS BY INFLUENCING DECISIONS THROUGH KEYOPPORTUNITIES AND PARTNERSHIP AND DELIVERING INCENTIVES AND OPPORTUNITIES TO LANDOWNERS.

PRONGHORN ARE WIDELY DISTRIBUTED ACROSS SOUTHEASTERN OREGON AND ARE HIGHLY VALUED FOR BOTH HUNTING ANDRECREATIONAL VIEWING OPPORTUNITIES. PRONGHORN HABITAT HAS BEEN IMPACTED BY MANY FACTORS INCLUDING CHANGING LAND USE PRACTICES, MINERAL EXTRACTION, ENERGY DEVELOPMENT, EFFECTS OF INVASIVE ANIMALS AND PLANTS, LARGE-SCALEWILDFIRES, AS WELL AS FENCES AND OTHER BARRIERS TO MOVEMENT. MANY BIG GAME SPECIES INCLUDING PRONGHORN CAN MOVELONG DISTANCES (  100 MILES) BETWEEN SEASONAL RANGES TO TAKE ADVANTAGE OF SEASONALLY AVAILABLE HIGH-QUALITY FOODSOR TO ESCAPE HARSH WINTER CONDITIONS. INCREASING DEVELOPMENT FOR HIGHWAYS, URBAN EXPANSION, AND MINERALEXTRACTION ACTIVITIES HAS POTENTIAL TO SEVERELY DISRUPT MIGRATION CORRIDORS FOR THESE ANIMALS. THEREFORE,DELINEATING SEASONAL RANGES AND MIGRATORY PATHWAYS IS IMPORTANT FOR PRONGHORN MANAGEMENT AND TO HELP OFFSETNEGATIVE EFFECTS OF OTHER ACTIVITIES ON PUBLIC LANDS. NUTRITIONAL VALUE OF MANY OF THE NATIVE PLANTS HAS BEENLOST WITH CHANGES IN ECOSYSTEMS. INCREASINGLY DOMINANT INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES HAVE LOWER NUTRITIONAL VALUE AND DONOT SUPPORT PRONGHORN POPULATIONS AT THE SAME LEVEL AS NATIVE SHRUB COMMUNITIES IN THE GREAT BASIN. FAT RESERVESAT THE START OF THE WINTER SEASON (E.G. CARRIED OVER FROM SUMMER RANGE) ARE IMPORTANT FOR WINTER SURVIVAL AND FORFEMALES TO CARRY DEVELOPING YOUNG TO FULL TERM. THEREFORE, KNOWLEDGE OF NUTRITIONAL RESOURCES ON SEASONAL RANGESIS IMPORTANT FOR PRONGHORN MANAGEMENT. THIS COLLABORATIVE EFFORT BETWEEN OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFEAND UNIVERSITY OF NEVADA RENO IS DESIGNED TO EVALUATE MOVEMENTS, NUTRITIONAL ECOLOGY, AND IMPACTS OF LARGE SCALECHANGES TO THE LANDSCAPE ON PRONGHORN DEMOGRAPHICS IN OREGON.

THIS GRANT WILL BE A SUBAWARD TO THE CITY OF ALTUS. THE CITY OF ALTUS, IN COOPERATION WITH ODWC, WILL CONDUCT THE PLANNING ACTIVITIES NEEDED TO CONSTRUCT A WORLD CLASS SHOOTING SPORTS COMPLEX THAT WILL INCREASE SHOOTING OPPORTUNITIES FOR NEW AND EXISTING HUNTERS, AND BOTH RECREATIONAL AND COMPETITIVE SHOOTERS FOR THE COMMUNITIES OF SOUTHWEST OKLAHOMA AND BEYOND. FUNDS WILL BE USED FOR PLANNING AND TO ASSESS THE FEASIBILITY OF THE PROJECT: CONTINUED PUBLIC REVIEW   INPUT  ENVIRONMENTAL CONSULTATION TO INCLUDE CULTURAL RESOURCES, DRAFT ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT, ESA INTRA-SERVICE SECTION 7 OR BIOLOGICAL ASSESSMENT IF NECESSARY, DRAFT FINDINGS OF NO SIGNIFICANT IMPACT (FONSI), AND DRAFT ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP PLAN (LEAD MANAGEMENT PLAN)  ENGINEERING PLANS TO INCLUDE SITE DESIGN, CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS, AND CONSTRUCTION BUDGET ESTIMATES  DRAFT LONG-TERM MOA INCLUDING HOURS OF OPERATION, FEES, AND USEFUL LIFE.
TWRA WILL BUILD A SHOOTING RANGE HEADQUARTERS BUILDING TO PROVIDE NECESSARY INFRASTRUCTURE FOR THE SHOOTING RANGE TO INCLUDE OFFICES, PRO SHOP, STORAGE, CLASSROOMS, AND RESTROOMS.

GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (GADNR) URBAN WILDLIFE PROGRAM RESPONDS TO NUMEROUS CALLS FROM METRO ATLANTA RESIDENTS ABOUT WHITE-TAILED DEER BECOMING ENTANGLED IN RESIDENTIAL FENCES. THESE EMERGENCIES PRESENT CONCERNS FOR THE WELFARE OF DEER AND THE SAFETY OF RESIDENTS AND RESPONDING PERSONNEL. ALTHOUGH FENCES GREATER THAN 10 FEET IN HEIGHT ARE KNOWN TO PREVENT DEER CROSSINGS, LITTLE RESEARCH HAS BEEN DONE TO EXAMINE DEER INTERACTIONS WITH COMMON FENCE DESIGNS IN SUBURBAN AREAS. UNDERSTANDING WHERE DEER-FENCE CONFLICTS OCCUR IN METRO ATLANTA AND THE DESIGN FEATURES OF FENCES WHICH ARE PROBLEMATIC WOULD OFFER OPPORTUNITIES TO ENGINEER IMPROVED FENCES AND TO MODIFY EXISTING FENCES TO REDUCE DEER ENTANGLEMENTS. THIS STUDY WILL UTILIZE INFORMATION FROM PREVIOUS DEER-FENCE CONFLICTS AND NEWLY NEW DATA ABOUT JUMPING BEHAVIOR OF CAPTIVE DEER TO GUIDE FENCE MODIFICATIONS. ADDITIONAL TESTING WITH CAPTIVE DEER JUMPING MODIFIED FENCING WILL BE CONDUCTED. FINALLY, RESIDENTS WILL BE SURVEYED TO DETERMINE PREFERENCES FOR FENCE MODIFICATIONS DESIGNED TO REDUCE CONFLICTS WITH DEER RELATIVE TO AESTHETICS, COSTS, PRACTICALITY, AND LIKELIHOOD OF REDUCING CONFLICTS WITH DEER. ULTIMATELY, GADNR WILL BE EQUIPPED WITH INFORMATION TO PROVIDE RESIDENTS, MUNICIPALITIES, AND HOMEOWNERS ASSOCIATIONS WISHING TO REDUCE ISSUES RELATED TO DEER INTERACTING WITH RESIDENTIAL FENCES.

ANNUALLY SEVERAL HUNDRED THOUSAND ANGLERS, HUNTERS AND RECREATIONAL SHOOTERS FISH, HUNT, BOAT AND SHOOT IN ARIZONA. IT IS ESSENTIAL TO CONSERVE, MANAGE, AND ENHANCE THE QUALITY AND AVAILABILITY OF SPORT FISH AND WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITS IN ORDER TO PROVIDE QUALITY SPORT FISHING AND HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES AND TO DISSEMINATE INFORMATION ABOUT ARIZONA S SPORT FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES AND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. THE ARIZONA COMPREHENSIVE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM GRANT ACTIVITIES ARE CONDUCTED STATEWIDE AND TIER TO AGFD S STRATEGIC AND OPERATIONAL PLANS AND ARE EVALUATED ANNUALLY TO ENSURE THE GRANT IS PERFORMING AS ANTICIPATED.THE GRANT FUNDS THE OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF FIVE SPORT FISH HATCHERIES AND THE STOCKING OF 380,000 POUNDS OR SPORT FISH (PRIMARILY TROUT, LARGEMOUTH BASS AND CATFISH) IN MORE THAN 100 OF ARIZONA S STREAMS AND LAKES AND AN ADDITIONAL 56 LAKES THAT ARE MANAGED TO PROVIDE DIVERSE WARM AND COLD WATER FISHING OPPORTUNITIES. SPORT FISH HABITAT RESTORATION, FISHERIES DISEASE SURVEILLANCE AND WATER QUALITY MONITORING ACTIVITIES SUPPORT MANAGEMENT EFFORTS TO PROVIDE DIVERSE WARM AND COLD WATER SPORT FISHING RECREATION DEMANDS ESTIMATED AT 6.5 MILLION ANGLER DAYS ANNUALLY. IN ADDITION, BOATER ACCESS IS EVALUATED AND OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE CONDUCTED TO ENSURE REASONABLE AND QUALITY ACCESS IS AVAILABLE TO BOATING RECREATIONISTS.CONSERVATION EFFORTS ARE CONDUCTED ON WILDLIFE HABITAT AND WATER TO ENHANCE THE CAPACITY OF HABITAT TO SUPPORT WILDLIFE AND ENHANCE RESILIENCE TO STRESSORS. STRATEGIES EMPLOYED INCLUDE:EXTENSIVE WILDLIFE DISEASE SURVEILLANCE.GAME AND NONGAME SPECIES POPULATION ENHANCEMENTS.PARTNERING WITH PRIVATE AND PUBLIC LANDOWNERS TO CONSERVE, PROTECT AND MONITOR LANDSMAINTAINING AND ENHANCING RELATIONSHIPS WITH LAND MANAGERS AND CONSERVATION PARTNERS TO IMPROVE WILDLIFE HABITAT AT A VARIETY OF SCALES THROUGHOUT ARIZONA (SUBRECIPIENTS INCLUDE TURKEY FEDERATION, TROUT UNLIMITED, MULE DEER FOUNDATION, SOUTHERN WINGS AND NATIONAL AUDUBON SOCIETY AMONG OTHERS).SUSTAINING WILDLIFE HABITATS ON PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS BY RESTORING HABITATS USING VARIOUS MANAGEMENT TOOLS (E.G. GRASSLAND RESTORATION, FOREST THINNING BURNING, FENCING FENCE MODIFICATIONS, RIPARIAN RESTORATION, WATER DEVELOPMENTS) AND COLLABORATIVE CONSERVATION APPROACHES (E.G. CONSERVATION EASEMENTS, HABITAT ACQUISITION, LAND USE AGREEMENTS, WATER RIGHT USE PURCHASES TRANSFERS) TO PROTECT HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE AND WILDLIFE RELATED RECREATION.COLLECTING, MANAGING AND PROVIDING WILDLIFE INFORMATION, DATA AND SCIENCE NEEDED TO INFORM AND DEVELOP THE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT CAPABILITIES.CONDUCTING WILDLIFE AREA OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE AND STREAM AND GRASSLAND HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS AND WATER DEVELOPMENTS TO IMPROVE HABITAT FOR THE BENEFIT OF WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH POPULATIONS.OUTREACH IS NEEDED TO INFORM THE PUBLIC ABOUT THE ACTIVITIES THAT SUPPORT AND ARE SUPPORTED BY WSFR AND TO EDUCATE PEOPLE ABOUT THE BENEFITS OF GRANT FUNDED PROGRAMS IN ORDER TO BUILD PUBLIC BACKING AND CONTINUED PARTICIPATION. GRANT FUNDED OUTREACH AND COMMUNICATION EFFORTS INCLUDE SOCIAL MEDIA STRATEGIES AS PART OF AGFD S CONSERVE AND PROTECT CAMPAIGN.THE GRANT FUNDED SHOOTING SPORTS PROGRAM MAINTAINS, DEVELOPS, OR SUPPORTS PUBLIC SHOOTING RANGES WITHIN REASONABLE PROXIMITY OF URBAN CENTERS TO MEET THE INCREASING DEMAND FOR RECREATIONAL SHOOTING OPPORTUNITIES. THE PROGRAM PROVIDES INTRODUCTORY THROUGH ADVANCED SHOOTING OPPORTUNITIES AT COMMISSIONED-OWNED RANGES, INCLUDING THE WORLD CLASS BEN AVERY SHOOTING FACILITY, WITH THE INTENT OF INCREASING THE PERCENTAGE OF ARIZONANS PARTICIPATING IN RECREATIONAL SHOOTING. THE PROGRAM ALSO PROVIDES TECHNICAL, DEVELOPMENT AND CONSTRUCTION ASSISTANCE TO SHOOTING RANGE OPERATORS AT FACILITIES STATEWIDE AND ALSO WORKS WITH PARTNERS TO PROVIDE RESPONSIBLE DISPERSED RECREATIONAL SHOOTING ON PUBLIC LANDS

SOUTH DAKOTA GFP CREATED THE SHOOTING RANGE DEVELOPMENT GRANT PROGRAM IN 1971 TO ENCOURAGE THE NEW DEVELOPMENT AND IMPROVEMENT OF SHOOTING RANGES. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS GRANT IS TO DEVELOP A SINGLE VAULT TOILET (SVT) AT ONE SHOOTING RANGE AND TO OPERATE AND MAINTAIN EIGHTEEN SHOOTING RANGE FACILITIES. THE EXPECTED RESULTS AND BENEFITS ARE TO PROVIDE A SAFE PLACE FOR HUNTER EDUCATION AND THE PUBLIC TO DEVELOP AND PRACTICE SHOOTING SKILLS.

TO ASSIST GA DNR URBAN WILDLIFE PROGRAM IN THEIR PROACTIVE APPROACH TO DEVELOP AND DISTRIBUTE EDUCATION AND OUTREACH PROGRAMMING RELATED TO URBAN WILDLIFE, WE PROPOSE A STUDY OF COYOTE BEHAVIOR AND HUMAN-WILDLIFE AND HUMAN-PET CONFLICT. THIS EFFORT WILL EVALUATE COYOTE BEHAVIOR USING VIDEO COLLARS DEPLOYED ON URBAN COYOTES. THIS APPROACH WILL (1) ASSESS THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THIS DATA COLLECTION APPROACH FOR ASSESSING PREDATOR-PREY INTERACTIONS ACROSS GEORGIA, (2) ADDRESS QUESTIONS RELATED TO THE PREVALENCE OF COYOTE DEPREDATIONS ON DOMESTIC PETS AND LIVESTOCK IN AN URBAN SETTING.

THIS ANNUAL GRANT FUNDS THE CPW HUNTER EDUCATION AND HUNTER OUTREACH PROGRAMS IN COLORADO. THE PURPOSE OF THE HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM IS TO CONDUCT HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAMS TO TRAIN INDIVIDUALS TO BE SAFE, LEGAL AND RESPONSIBLE HUNTERS.THE PURPOSE OF THE HUNTER OUTREACH PROGRAM IS TO RECRUIT AND RETAIN CURRENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS OF HUNTERS IN COLORADO BY DEVELOPING A SYSTEMS OF PROGRAMS TO ENHANCE HUNTER SKILLS AND OPPORTUNITIES THROUGHOUT THE STATE.

THIS WILDLIFE RESTORATION GRANT PROVIDES FOR DATA COLLECTION TO SUPPORT THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION S EFFORTS TO MANAGE PRAIRIE-CHICKEN, PHEASANT, QUAIL AND BEAR. THIS GRANT IS DIVIDED INTO FIVE (5) INDIVIDUAL PROJECTS. THE FIRST PROJECT FOCUSING ON LESSER AND GREATER PRAIRIE CHICKENS, ALLOWS FOR 2 SURVEY INVESTIGATIONS AS WELL AS HABITAT AND VEGETATION ANALYSIS AS NEEDED. IT ALSO ALLOWS FOR TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE WITH OTHER ORGANIZATIONS. THE SECOND PROJECT FOCUSES ON RING-NECKED PHEASANT AND ALLOWS FOR 2 SURVEY INVESTIGATIONS. IT ALSO ALLOWS FOR TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE WITH OTHER ORGANIZATIONS. THE THIRD PROJECT FOCUSES ON NORTHERN BOBWHITE AND SCALED QUAIL AND ALLOWS FOR 1 SURVEY INVESTIGATION. IT ALSO ALLOWS FOR TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE WITH OTHER ORGANIZATIONS. THE FOURTH PROJECT FOCUSES ON BLACK BEAR AND ALLOWS FOR 1 SURVEY INVESTIGATION AS WELL AS UTILIZATION ANALYSIS. THE FIFTH AND FINAL PROJECT FOCUSES ON QUAIL AND OTHER GRASSLAND BIRD SPECIES AND ALLOWS FOR 2 SURVEY INVESTIGATIONS AS WELL AS HABITAT AND VEGETATION ANALYSIS AS NEEDED. IT ALSO ALLOWS FOR TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE WITH OTHER ORGANIZATIONS. ANNUALLY SURVEYING THE POPULATIONS OF THESE ANIMALS ALLOWS THE ODWC TO MONITOR LONG TERM POPULATION TRENDS UNDER CURRENT REGULATIONS. RESULTS OF THE ABOVE DESCRIBED SURVEYS AND DATA COLLECTED WILL BE USED TO FORMULATE MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION STRATEGIES IN OKLAHOMA. DATA OBTAINED WILL ALSO BE USEFUL IN DISSEMINATING ACCURATE INFORMATION POPULATIONS OF THESE ANIMALS IN OKLAHOMA TO ENTITIES REQUESTING SUCH INFORMATION. EACH PROJECT ALSO INCLUDES CONDUCTING RELATED PROJECT ADMINISTRATION, COORDINATION AND PLANNING, PROCUREMENT, PERSONNEL MANAGEMENT, SUPERVISORY AND SAFETY TRAINING, PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT (TO INCLUDE CONTINUING EDUCATION AND WORKSHOPS AND SYMPOSIA AS WELL AS THROUGH CLOSE COORDINATION WITH MULTI-AGENCY REGIONAL EFFORTS), MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR OF EQUIPMENT, AND ALL OTHER ASSOCIATED ELIGIBLE ACTIVITIES. THIS GRANT WILL CONTINUE WORK PREVIOUSLY CONDUCTED UNDER UPLAND GAME INVESTIGATIONS GRANT F21AF02272   W-82-R-54.

TO INCREASE THE RANGE OF LESSER PRAIRIE-CHICKEN (TYMPANUCHUS PALLIDICINCTUS) IT IS IMPORTANT TO CONDUCT ACTIVITIES WHICH SUPPORT THE REGULATORY, RESEARCH, AND MANAGEMENT NEEDS OF LESSER PRAIRIE-CHICKEN BY COLLECTING AND ANALYZING BIOLOGICAL AND HARVEST INFORMATION ON LESSER PRAIRIE-CHICKEN FOR MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.

THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE, UMPQUA WATERSHED DISTRICT WILDLIFE STAFF STRIVES TO PROTECT ANDENHANCE WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS FOR USE AND ENJOYMENT BY PRESENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS WITHIN BOTH COOS ANDDOUGLAS COUNTIES. WE HAVE ACHIEVED THIS BY WORKING WITH MULTIPLE STAKEHOLDERS, BOTH PUBLIC AND PRIVATE, TOIMPROVE UPON CURRENT HABITAT CONDITIONS IN ORDER TO PROVIDE THE HIGHEST QUALITY OF HABITAT FOR WILDLIFEPOPULATIONS WITHIN OUR DISTRICT. OUR OBJECTIVES AS WE SEEK TO MEET THE NEEDS OF WILDLIFE IN OUR DISTRICT INCLUDE:1. PROTECT, MAINTAIN, AND ENHANCE WILDLIFE HABITATS ON VARIOUS LAND OWNERSHIPS WITHIN OUR DISTRICT.2. ENCOURAGE OTHER AGENCIES AND LANDOWNERS TO ENHANCE WILDLIFE HABITATS ON THEIR MANAGED LANDS.3. MAINTAIN THE FACILITIES, STRUCTURES, AND EQUIPMENT NECESSARY FOR THE ADMINISTRATION OF OUR DISTRICTSWILDLIFE HABITAT PROGRAM.4. ADMINISTRATION OF HABITAT PROGRAM ACTIVITIES AND ASSIST WITH ADMINISTRATION OF DISTRICT WILDLIFE ACTIVITIES.5. PURCHASE A COMPACT TRACKED LOADER WITH A DRUM MULCHING ATTACHMENT.6. PURCHASE A TRACTOR, IMPLEMENTS, AND TRAILER.7. PURCHASE THE CONSTRUCTION OF A VOLUNTEER HOST PAD.THE UMPQUA WATERSHED DISTRICT WILDLIFE STAFF HAS A SOLID AND GROWING RELATIONSHIP WITH LAND MANAGERS, BOTH PUBLICAND PRIVATE, WITHIN OUR DISTRICT. OPPORTUNITIES FOR WILDLIFE HABITAT ENHANCEMENT ARE IDENTIFIED AND PURSUEDTHROUGH OUR PROJECT PARTNERSHIPS.

POOR ACCESS TO PLACES TO HUNT AND TARGET SHOOT REMAINS ONE OF THE TOP BARRIERS IDENTIFIED BY NEW AND EXISTING PARTICIPANTS IN HUNTING AND TARGET SHOOTING RELATED ACTIVITIES. WHILE MOTIVATIONS TO PARTICIPATE IN THESE ACTIVITIES CONTINUE TO TREND TOWARDS SPENDING TIME WITH FRIENDS AND FAMILY, FOR FOOD MEAT AND FOR RECREATION OR TO BE CLOSE TO NATURE.ACQUISITION OF THIS PROPERTY WILL PROVIDE A DEDICATED AREA TO CONDUCT PROGRAMS SUCH AS FIELD TO FORK, LEARN TO HUNT TRAP SHOOT WORKSHOPS, BECOMING AN OUTDOORS WOMAN WORKSHOPS AND OTHER MENTORED EXPERIENCES. HAVING ACCESS TO THIS AREA WILL ALLOW THE DEPARTMENT TO TARGET DIVERSE AUDIENCES AND PROVIDE THEM WITH A SAFE, CONTROLLED ENVIRONMENT FOR PARTICIPATION IN DEPARTMENT SPONSORED ACTIVITIES AND GAIN THE KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS AND SOCIAL SUPPORT NECESSARY TO CONTINUE PARTICIPATION WELL INTO THE FUTURE.

ONCE PREVALENT THROUGHOUT THE AMERICAN SOUTHWEST, THE MEXICAN WOLF WAS NEARLY EXTINCT BY THE1970S. IN 1976, THIS SPECIES WAS LISTED AS ENDANGERED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT OF 1973.IN NOVEMBER OF 2019, THE NEW MEXICO DEPARTMENT OF GAME AND FISH (DEPARTMENT) AGREED TO BEONE OF SEVERAL LEAD AGENCIES TO ASSIST IN THE RECOVERY OF THESE ANIMALS. AS SUCH, THE DEPARTMENTHAS ALLOCATED STAFF TO PARTICIPATE ON A TECHNICAL COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE AND ASSESS THECONSERVATION STATUS, DEVELOP OPERATIONAL RECOMMENDATIONS, COORDINATE AND IMPLEMENT ACTIVITIESASSOCIATED WITH THE MANAGEMENT OF WOLVES IN NEW MEXICO PER PROTOCOL AND POLICY.

THIS GRANT IS CRUCIAL IN MEETING DEPARTMENT MISSION AND GOALS AND TO INSURE COMPLIANCE WITH STATE AND FEDERAL MANDATES. THROUGH THE COMMISSION, THE DEPARTMENT HAS THE RESPONSIBILITY, MANDATED BY STATUTE, TO PROTECT NEW MEXICO S GAME WHILE PROVIDING AND MAINTAINING AN ADEQUATE SUPPLY FOR RECREATIONAL USE. THIS INCLUDES DEVELOPING RECOMMENDATIONS FOR HUNTER OPPORTUNITY, ENGAGING LANDOWNERS IN BIG GAME MANAGEMENT, CONDUCTING POPULATION SURVEYS, AND RESTORING POPULATIONS WHEN FEASIBLE.

THE PRIMARY FUNCTION OF THIS GRANT IS TO MANAGE AND MONITOR WILDLIFE POPULATIONS USING SCIENTIFICALLY-PROVEN PRINCIPLES, DELIVER TECHNICAL GUIDANCE TO CONSTITUENTS THROUGHOUT THE STATE, PROTECT AND ENHANCE HABITATS, AND PROVIDE SAFE AND ENJOYABLE OUTDOOR RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES TO CONSTITUENTS THROUGHOUT THE STATE. THIS PROPOSED ACTION CONSISTS OF FOUR PROJECTS DESIGNED TO CARRY OUT THE OBJECTIVES OF THE GRANT AND ONE PROJECT FOR COORDINATION AND ADMINISTRATION OF THE GRANT.

PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE THE PUBLIC ACCESS TO LAND FOR HUNTING AND OTHER OUTDOOR ORIENTED RECREATION BY MAINTAINING AND OPERATING INFRASTRUCTURE ON WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS.OBJECTIVES:OBJECTIVE 1: PROJECT A: DIRECTLY OPERATE AND MAINTAIN 132 WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS BY JUNE 30, 2024.OBJECTIVE 2: PROJECT B: DIRECTLY MANAGE AND ENHANCE HABITAT ON 62 AGENCY OWNED WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS BY JUNE 30, 2024.OBJECTIVE 3: PURCHASE EQUIPMENT TO DIRECTLY MAINTAIN, OPERATE AND MANAGE 132 WMAS FOR WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AND PUBLIC ACCESS BY JUNE 30, 2024.EXPECTED OUTCOMES:PROJECT A: WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA MAINTENANCE AND OPERATIONSTHE WMA SYSTEM PROVIDES PUBLIC HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES AND A RELATIVELY CONSISTENT HUNTER SUCCESS RATE BY CONTROLLING THE ANNUAL HARVEST OF GAME SPECIES THROUGH ADAPTIVE REGULATIONS ON BAG LIMITS, SEASON DATES AND HARVEST METHODS. THE UTILIZATION OF THESE AREAS BY THE PUBLIC FOR OTHER WILDLIFE-ORIENTED RECREATION WILL BE MAINTAINED AT LEVELS CONSISTENT WITH THE DEMAND FOR SUCH USES AND WHICH ARE COMPATIBLE WITH THE PRIMARY USES OF HUNTING AND FISHING.PROJECT B: WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA HABITAT MANAGEMENTBY CONTINUING THE HABITAT PROGRAM, THE WMA SYSTEM WILL PROVIDE ENHANCED HABITAT FOR NATIVE AND MIGRATORY SPECIES AND IMPROVED OUTDOOR RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. THE HABITAT PROGRAM WILL HELP MAINTAIN A RELATIVELY CONSISTENT HUNTER SUCCESS RATE BY SUPPORTING WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AT SUSTAINABLE LEVELS.PROJECT C: WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT EQUIPMENT ACQUISITIONEQUIPMENT ACQUIRED UNDER THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE THE EFFICIENCY AND EFFECTIVENESS OF WMA MANAGEMENT AND THE PERFORMANCE OF RESEARCH, MONITORING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE. CONSEQUENTLY, THE INCREASED CAPACITY TO PERFORM THESE FUNCTIONS WILL HELP IMPROVE HABITAT CONDITIONS AND PUBLIC HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES AS WELL AS OTHER OUTDOOR RECREATION.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: GENERAL PUBLICSUB-RECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE

THIS GRANT FUNDS THE ACQUISITION OF LAND FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE AREAS, WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS, WETLANDCONSERVATION AREAS, GAMEBIRD AREAS AND OTHER, SIMILAR AREAS THROUGHOUT INDIANA. THESE LANDS AREMANAGED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, DIVISION OF FISH   WILDLIFE TO SUPPORT WILDLIFE HABITAT,WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND PUBLIC, WILDLIFE-BASED RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES.

PROVIDING A SAFE AND ENJOYABLE PLACE FOR HUNTERS AND RECREATIONAL SHOOTERS TO PRACTICE AND HONE THEIRSKILLS IS AN INTEGRAL PART OF ANY RECREATIONAL SHOOTING AND HUNTING SAFETY PROGRAM. THIS GRANT IS NEEDED TOPROVIDE FOR SAFE OPERATION, MAINTENANCE, AND DEVELOPMENT OF TWELVE SHOOTING RANGES AND ELEVEN ARCHERYRANGES ON DIVISION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE PROPERTY. THESE FISH AND WILDLIFE AREA (FWA) SHOOTING RANGES HAVEBEEN IMPROVED TO PROVIDE RANGE BACKSTOPS AND BERMS WITH HEIGHTS AND SLOPES RECOMMENDED BY NATIONALRIFLE ASSOCIATION (NRA) SHOOTING RANGE STANDARDS. NRA STANDARDS ARE USED WHEN IMPROVEMENTS,ENHANCEMENTS, AND RANGE OPERATION CONSIDERATIONS ARE EVALUATED.
W-37-D-07 WILDLIFE RESTORATION ACTIVITIES ON NATURAL AREAS

TO PROVIDE FISH AND WILDLIFE DATA AND RECOMMENDATIONS TO, AND COORDINATION WITH, APPROPRIATE FEDERAL AND STATE LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES, REGIONAL OR LOCAL PLANNING GROUPS, AND OTHER DECISIONS MAKERS IN ALL LAND AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANS USING SCIENCE AND DATA-DRIVE EXPERTISE, AND TO EXPAND OUR KNOWLEDGE AND EXPERTISE THROUGH COLLABORATIVE, FOCUSED RESEARCH. NDOW RECOGNIZES THE IMPORTANCE OF COMMUNICATING WITH AGENCY PARTNERS, THE PUBLIC, AND OTHER INTERESTED PARTIES ON WILDLIFE RESOURCES AND POTENTIAL IMPACTS TO THOSE RESOURCES AS A RESULT OF DIFFERING ACTIVITIES ACROSS THE LANDSCAPE. NDOW REGULARLY PROVIDES FEEDBACK AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO AGENCY PARTNERS, INTERESTED MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC AND OTHER INTERESTED PARTIES THROUGH PROVIDING EXPERT ADVICE ON FISH AND WILDLIFE ASSESSMENTS, RESEARCH TECHNIQUES, AND OR SPECIES HABITAT MANAGEMENT, PRIMARILY THROUGH THE NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY ACT PROCESS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND AND AVOID, MINIMIZE, OR MITIGATE POTENTIAL IMPACTS. ADDITIONALLY, NDOW PROVIDES FISH AND WILDLIFE DATA THROUGH FORMAL DATA REQUESTS, AND PROVIDES DETAILED ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEWS OF RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANS, RECOMMENDATIONS, AND COORDINATION TO ENSURE THAT FISH AND WILDLIFE CONSIDERATIONS ARE INCLUDED IN ALL LAND AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANS IN CONCERT WITH THE PUBLIC LANDS MULTIPLE USE CONCEPT AND THE STATE OF NEVADA WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN. A KEY COMPONENT OF THE TECHNICAL GUIDANCE PROGRAM IS ALSO TO PROVIDE SUPPORT TO NDOW REGIONAL BIOLOGISTS ASSISTING IN THE PLANNING PROCESS WITH FEDERAL LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES. ALL REVIEWS, DATA REQUESTS, AND COORDINATION ARE TRACKED BY PROJECT OR PLAN TYPE, AND NDOW USES THIS INFORMATION FOR REPORTING PURPOSES THROUGHOUT THE FISCAL YEAR.

VERMONT HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM CLASSES ARE OFFERED THROUGHOUT THE STATE IN VARIOUS SETTINGS INCLUDING SCHOOLS, FISH AND GAME CLUBS, PUBLIC BUILDINGS, AND DEPARTMENT FACILITIES, INCLUDING THE TWO GREEN MOUNTAIN CONSERVATION CAMPS (BUCK LAKE AND EDWARD F. KEHOE). THE DEPARTMENT CURRENTLY PROVIDES THREE DIFFERENT VERSIONS OF THE COURSE FOR INTERESTED PARTICIPANTS. THESE INCLUDE THE TRADITIONAL, COMPLETELY IN-PERSON COURSE, THE HOMESTUDY COURSE THAT REQUIRES A FIELD DAY COMPONENT, AND A COMPLETELY ONLINE VERSION. CLASS SCHEDULES CONTINUE TO BE AVAILABLE ON THE DEPARTMENTS WEBSITE. COURSE INFORMATION IS UPDATED AS SOON AS THE INFORMATION IS RECEIVED. THIS PROCESS CONTINUES TO BE IMPROVED AND STREAMLINED AS THE CERTIFIED INSTRUCTORS GET MORE FAMILIAR WITH THE EVENT MANAGER SOFTWARE.  THIS GRANT ALSO INCLUDE MAINTENANCE OF FOUR RECREATIONAL SHOOTING RANGES.

TO HAVE SAFE, AVAILABLE AND ENVIRONMENTALLY SOUND PUBLIC SHOOTING RANGES FOR SPORTSMEN AND WOMEN TO LEARN, PRACTICE AND IMPROVE SHOOTING SKILLS TO BE ETHICAL, SAFE AND KNOWLEDGEABLE HUNTERS. EXISTING SHOOT RANGE GROUNDS AND FACILITIES WILL BE OPERATED, IMPROVED AND MAINTAINED TO MEET THIS NEED. RANGE FACILITIES ARE USED TO CONDUCT HUNTER, BOWHUNTER AND OUTDOOR SKILLS COURSES, AND PROVIDE STUDENT AMENITIES SUCH AS BATHROOMS, CLASSROOMS, AND INSTRUCTOR FACILITIES ARE NEEDED AT RANGES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO ADDRESS ONGOING WILDLIFE HABITAT DEGRADATION BY IMPROVING, MAINTAINING, ANDRESTORING WILDLIFE HABITAT THROUGHOUT THE JOHN DAY WATERSHED. WILDLIFE HABITAT QUALITY IN OREGON HAS BEENDEGRADED AND FRAGMENTED AS A RESULT OF DEVELOPMENT, AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES, TIMBER HARVEST, AND ACTIVITIESASSOCIATED WITH INCREASES IN THE HUMAN POPULATION (OREGON CONSERVATION STRATEGY 2016). THE JOHN DAY WATERSHEDDISTRICT LANDS ARE MADE UP OF MULTIPLE PARCELS OF LAND OWNED AND OR MANAGED BY VARIOUS ENTITIES AND VARY IN SIZE,LOCATION AND TOPOGRAPHY.ODFW MANAGEMENT IS REQUIRED TO PROTECT, ENHANCE AND RESTORE HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE AND FISH SPECIES IN THEDISTRICT, INCLUDING FIVE WILDLIFE AREAS TOTALING 17,091 ACRES. LANDS ADMINISTERED BY ODFW WITHIN THE COLUMBIABASIN WA PROVIDES ESSENTIAL HABITATS FOR 129 BIRD SPECIES, 32 KNOWN MAMMAL SPECIES, 16 SPECIES OF AMPHIBIANS AND REPTILES AS WELL AS 14 SPECIES OF FISH. ADDITIONALLY, BRIDGE CREEK WA SUPPORTS 116 BIRD SPECIES, 48 MAMMALSPECIES INCLUDING MORE THAN 2,500 ROCKY MOUNTAIN ELK FOR UP TO 5 MONTHS, 9 SPECIES OF AMPHIBIAN AND REPTILE ASWELL AS 15 SPECIES OF FISH INCLUDING TWO LISTED SPECIES.THE JOHN DAY WATERSHED WILDLIFE HABITAT PROGRAM PROVIDES AN ESTIMATED 2,000 HUNTER DAYS, 300 ANGLER-DAYS, AND1,300 DAYS OF OTHER FORMS OF WILDLIFE-ORIENTED RECREATION ANNUALLY. TECHNICAL ADVICE IS REQUIRED TO HELPCOORDINATE CONSERVATION EFFORTS AMONG NUMEROUS LANDOWNERS INCLUDING LOCAL, STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES. ODFWMANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES ARE CRITICAL TO MAINTAIN HABITAT QUALITY THROUGHOUT THE WATERSHED, COORDINATE CONSERVATIONEFFORTS, ALLEVIATE DAMAGE DEPREDATION ON PRIVATE LANDS, AND PROVIDE CONTINUED WILDLIFE ORIENTED RECREATIONALOPPORTUNITIES.THIS GRANT FUNDS THE ANNUAL OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF THE JOHN DAY WATERSHED WILDLIFE HABITAT PROGRAM.

OBJECTIVES OF THIS GRANT INCLUDE COORDINATION OF THE ANNUAL IMPLEMENTATION OF STATIONARY ACOUSTIC SURVEYS WITHTHE NORTH AMERICAN BAT MONITORING PROGRAM (NABAT) MONITORING PROTOCOL ACROSS OREGON, CONDUCT AUDIBLE BATS SURVEYS IN HABITAT APPROPRIATE LOCATIONS CONCURRENT TO STATIONARY ACOUSTIC MONITORING, TO MANAGE AND ANALYZE COLLECTED DATA, MANAGE AND STORE ODFW ACOUSTIC DETECTORS, PROVIDE TRAININGS FOR AGENCY BIOLOGISTS AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO PARTNERS IN SUPPORT OF BAT CONSERVATION RESEARCH AND MONITORING. PRODUCTS RESULTING FROM THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT EVIDENCE-BASED DECISION MAKING BY THE DEPARTMENT FOR MANAGEMENT ACTIONS THAT WILL AFFECT BATPOPULATIONS.THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO SUPPORT AN ONGOING PARTNERSHIP WITH THE NORTHWESTERN BAT HUB TO IMPLEMENTCOORDINATED RESEARCH AND MONITORING OF BAT POPULATIONS ACROSS OREGON AND PARTNER STATES. DATA COLLECTED UNDERTHIS GRANT WILL BE USED TO INFORM CONSERVATION ACTIONS AND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.

ODFW NEEDS TO DEVELOP APPROPRIATE LANDSCAPE-SCALE SURVEY METHODS AND COLLECT POPULATION DATA FOR OREGONCONSERVATION STRATEGY SPECIES AND OTHER FOREST MESOCARNIVORES. FOREST CARNIVORES IN THE OREGON CASCADE MOUNTAINS, SPECIFICALLY PACIFIC MARTEN, PERFORM VITALLY IMPORTANT ROLES IN THE ECOSYSTEM. FOREST CARNIVORES ALSO PROVIDE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES (HUNTING, TRAPPING, AND WILDLIFE VIEWING) THAT ARE IMPORTANT COMPONENTS OF OREGONCULTURE AND ECONOMY. TO APPROPRIATELY MANAGE THESE IMPORTANT SPECIES, POPULATION MONITORING, AND KNOWLEDGE OFTHEIR DEMOGRAPHICS IS REQUIRED. UNFORTUNATELY, POPULATION MANAGEMENT OF FOREST MESOCARNIVORES HAS BEEN (ANDCONTINUES TO BE) BASED ON LIMITED DEMOGRAPHIC DATA AND POTENTIALLY BIASED SURVEYS THAT ARE BOTH TIME CONSUMINGAND SPECIFIC TO A SPECIES. THE USE OF TRAIL CAMERAS (CAMERA TRAPPING) IN A DESIGNED STUDY FORMAT MAY ALLEVIATESOME DRAWBACKS THAT OREGON CURRENTLY EXPERIENCES IN FOREST MESOCARNIVORE SURVEYS. CAMERA TRAPPING ALLOWS YEAR-ROUND MONITORING AND CAN BE DEPLOYED IN LANDSCAPES TOO LARGE FOR TRADITIONAL SURVEYS. WITHIN A SINGLE STUDYDESIGN, CAMERA TRAPPING ALSO ALLOWS SIMULTANEOUS MONITORING OF DEMOGRAPHIC METRICS (PRESENCE, OCCUPANCY, RESOURCE SELECTION, RECRUITMENT, SEX AND AGE RATIOS, AND DENSITY) FOR MULTIPLE WILDLIFE SPECIES INCLUDING FORESTMESOCARNIVORES, LARGE CARNIVORES AND UNGULATES THAT OCCUPY THE SAME AREA. WE WILL UTILIZE STATISTICAL SURVEYTECHNIQUES INCLUDING SPACE-TO-EVENT (STE) AND TIME-TO-EVENT (TTE)TO GENERATE DENSITY AND ABUNDANCE ESTIMATES OFSEVERAL SPECIES. ODFW WILL DETERMINE THE FEASIBILITY OF UTILIZING CAMERA TRAPPING AND THESE ANALYTICAL TECHNIQUESFOR COLLECTING WILDLIFE POPULATION DEMOGRAPHICS. IMPORTANT RESULTS OF OUR STUDY INCLUDE DETERMINING THE STATISTICAL POWER OF DEMOGRAPHIC ESTIMATES AND DETERMINING THE COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH CAMERA MONITORING SURVEYS.

THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION PROGRAM WAS INITIATED IN 1937 UNDER THE PITTMAN-ROBERTSON ACT TO PROVIDE FEDERAL FUNDINGTO STATES FOR THE BENEFIT OF A DIVERSE ARRAY OF WILDLIFE AND ASSOCIATED HABITATS. THIS GRANT FUNDS THE ANNUALOPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF THE FERN RIDGE WILDLIFE AREA (FRWA).FRWA IS MANAGED BY THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (ODFW), UNDER A 25 YEAR LICENSE AGREEMENT WITH THEUS ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS (USACE). THE LICENSE AGREEMENT IS IN PLACE TO AUTHORIZE ODFW TO MANAGE PROPERTYWITHIN THE FERN RIDGE LAKE PROJECT FOR WILDLIFE HABITAT MANAGEMENT. THE WILDLIFE AREAS PURPOSE IS TO DEVELOP,CONSERVE, AND MANAGE ALL WILDLIFE RESOURCES ON 5,929 ACRES OF LAND AND WATER WITHIN THE GREATER USACE UPPERWILLAMETTE VALLEY - FERN RIDGE LAKE PROJECT, AND ADJACENT PROPERTIES.ODFW STAFF ADMINISTER HABITAT MANAGEMENT AND PUBLIC USE PROGRAMS ON THE WILDLIFE AREA. A TEAM OF DEDICATEDVOLUNTEERS IS ALSO ANTICIPATED TO CONTRIBUTE APPROXIMATELY 1,700 HOURS OF LABOR ASSISTANCE ON THE WILDLIFE AREADURING THE YEAR.THIS PROJECT DEVELOPS, ENHANCES, AND MAINTAINS WILDLIFE HABITATS AND PROVIDE PUBLIC RECREATION OPPORTUNITIES INTHE SOUTH WILLAMETTE VALLEY OF WESTERN OREGON. FRWA SUPPORTS 2.25 MILLION WATERFOWL USE DAYS ANNUALLY AND  359DOCUMENTED SPECIES OF BIRDS, MAMMALS, AMPHIBIANS AND REPTILES. FRWA ALSO PROVIDES OPPORTUNITIES FOR 4,000 HUNTERS ANNUALLY AND AN ESTIMATED 800,000 PEOPLE VISIT FERN RIDGE LAKE ANNUALLY.

THE STATEWIDE TECHNICAL GUIDANCE PROJECT PROVIDES DIRECT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO PRIVATE PROPERTY OWNERS, OTHERODFW STAFF, AND STAFF OF OTHER LOCAL, STATE, AND FEDERAL AGENCIES TO PROMOTE PROGRAMS AND PROJECTS THAT AREEFFECTIVE IN MAINTAINING, ENHANCING, OR RESTORING FUNCTIONAL WILDLIFE HABITATS. STAFF FUNDED THROUGH THIS PROJECT DEVELOP ODFW POLICY POSITIONS, AND COORDINATE PARTICIPATION IN LOCAL, STATE, AND FEDERAL LAND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH ENERGY, FORESTRY, LAND USE, MINING, WETLAND AND WATERWAY DEVELOPMENT INCLUDING IN-WATEREXPLOSIVE PERMITS, AND TWO STATE LANDOWNER INCENTIVE PROGRAMS.

THIS GRANT FUNDS ADMINISTRATION OF THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION (WR) PROGRAM AT ODFW. THE WR PROGRAM WAS INITIATEDUNDER THE PITTMAN-ROBERTSON ACT (1937) TO PROVIDE FEDERAL FUNDING TO STATES FOR THE BENEFIT OF A DIVERSE ARRAY OFWILDLIFE AND ASSOCIATED HABITATS. IN OREGON, THE PROGRAM SUPPORTS THE OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF 16 MAJORWILDLIFE AREAS ACROSS THE STATE. TWO ADDITIONAL WILDLIFE AREAS PRIMARILY FUNDED BY STATE HUNTING LICENSE DOLLARSARE ALSO MANAGED BY THIS PROGRAM AND TOGETHER THE 18 AREAS ENCOMPASS APPROXIMATELY 200,000 ACRES WHERE OVER 2 MILLION RECREATIONAL USE-DAYS ARE RECORDED ANNUALLY. THE PROGRAM ALSO SUPPORTS SEVEN REGIONAL HABITAT PROGRAMSDESIGNED TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO PUBLIC LAND MANAGERS AND PRIVATE LANDOWNERS TO ENHANCE AND PROTECTWILDLIFE HABITATS ON PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS ACROSS THE STATE. OTHER FUNDED PROJECTS INCLUDE ELK AND MULE DEERECOLOGY STUDIES, GAME MANAGEMENT, THE WILDLIFE HEALTH AND POPULATION LABORATORY, AND HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAMS.

THE TECHNICAL GUIDANCE GRANT SERVES A HABITAT FUNCTION AS WELL AS A DAMAGE MANAGEMENT FUNCTION:1. TO PROVIDE PUBLIC, PRIVATE AND CORPORATE LANDOWNERS WITH SOUND WILDLIFE HABITAT MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS THAT FIT THEIR GOALS AND ABILITIES TO THE EXTENT POSSIBLE. INCENTIVES TO LANDOWNERS WILL BE USED WHENEVER POSSIBLE TO OFFSET COSTS AND TO ENSURE FOLLOW UP CONTACT.2. TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL GUIDANCE TO AGENCIES, ORGANIZATIONS AND INDIVIDUALS FOR THE RESOLUTION OF HUMAN-WILDLIFE CONFLICTS WITH THE GOAL OF MAINTAINING WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AT BIOLOGICALLY AND SOCIALLY ACCEPTABLE LEVELS.

THE WILDLIFE HEALTH PROGRAM AND LABORATORY WAS IMPLEMENTED IN 2004 TO PROVIDE AGENCY EXPERTISE AND VETERINARY SERVICES FOR WILDLIFE DISEASES FOR ALL WILDLIFE IN OREGON. VETERINARY AND LAB STAFF COORDINATES AGENCY RESPONSE TO DISEASE ISSUES AND OUTBREAKS FOR ALL SPECIES AND ADDRESSES WILDLIFE HEALTH ISSUES WITHIN THE DEPARTMENT, WITH INTERAGENCY COOPERATORS, REGIONALLY AND NATIONALLY AS APPROPRIATE. THE POPULATION LAB PROVIDES POPULATION LEVEL INFORMATION TO HEADQUARTERS STAFF, MANAGERS AND FIELD STAFF FOR STATEWIDE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS INVOLVING HARVEST AND WILDLIFE POPULATION LEVEL STATISTICS. FUNDING FROM THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT THE STATEWIDE LABORATORY, FIELD ACTIVITIES AND STAFF COSTS FOR BOTH OF THESE INTEGRATED PROGRAMS.THE WILDLIFE HEALTH AND POPULATION LABORATORY PROGRAM PRIMARY MISSION IS TO SERVE AS SUPPORT ALL AGENCY FIELDSTAFF, PROGRAMS AND ADMINISTRATORS THROUGH:1. PREVENTION OF EMERGING WILDLIFE DISEASES BY PROVIDING DISEASE SURVEILLANCE, MONITORING, DISEASE ERADICATION ORCONTROL TO PROTECT OREGONS WILDLIFE RESOURCE FROM EMERGING DISEASE THREATS.2. INCORPORATING ANIMAL WELFARE STANDARDS INTO RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS THROUGH INTRA-AGENCY CONSULTS,ANIMAL CARE AND USE COMMITTEE SERVICE, AND VETERINARY SUPPORT ON RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT PROJECTS AS REQUESTED.3. PROVIDING EDUCATION AND TRAINING (ANIMAL HANDLING, DISEASE PROTOCOLS, ANIMAL CAPTURE, DRUG AND IMMOBILIZATION,ETC.) TO AGENCY STAFF, LABORATORY STAFF AND COOPERATORS AND OTHER INSTITUTIONS AND AGENCIES4. PROVIDING EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATION, SUPPORT, AND SERVICE BETWEEN HEALTH STAFF AND ALL FIELD AND ADMINISTRATIONSTAFF AS WELL AS COLLABORATIVE LIAISON BETWEEN ODFW AND INTERAGENCY COOPERATORS, STAKEHOLDERS AND THE PUBLIC OFOREGON CONCERNING WILDLIFE HEALTH ISSUES5. DETERMINING SEX AND AGE STRUCTURE OF BEAR, COUGAR, BOBCAT, RIVER OTTER, MARTEN, DEER AND ELK POPULATIONSTHROUGHOUT OREGON. DETERMINE REPRODUCTIVE STATUS AND LITTER SIZE OF FEMALE BEAR, COUGAR AND MARTEN IN OREGONSTATEWIDE OR BY COUNTY.6. COORDINATING RADIO TRANSMITTER FREQUENCIES FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE TELEMETRY STUDIES AGENCY BIOLOGISTS ANDOTHER COOPERATORS STATEWIDE.
IL - FEDERAL ASSISTANCE ADMINISTRATION AND COORDINATION, FW-05-C-66

THE PURPOSE OF THE STATEWIDE WILDLIFE SURVEYS, PLANNING, INVESTIGATIONS AND PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT GRANT (W-99-R) IS TO ANNUALLY COLLECT DATA ON WATERFOWL, UPLAND AND FOREST GAME BIRDS, FURBEARERS AND GAME MAMMALS TO DETERMINE POPULATION TRENDS, HARVEST AND DEMOGRAPHICS. CONDUCTING THESE INVESTIGATIONS WILL GATHER THE DATA NECESSARY TO EFFECTIVELY MANAGE THE WILDLIFE RESOURCES OF ILLINOIS FROM A COMPREHENSIVE APPROACH. THERE ARE NO ANTICIPATED SUB-GRANTEES OF THIS PROJECT.

ILLINOIS CONTAINS CRITICAL HABITATS FOR BREEDING, SPRING- AND AUTUMN-MIGRATING, AND WINTERING WATERFOWL AND OTHER WETLAND-ASSOCIATED BIRDS SUCH AS SECRETIVE MARSH BIRDS, SHOREBIRDS, WADING BIRDS, AND PELAGIC WATERBIRDS. NEARLY 30 SPECIES OF RESIDENT AND MIGRATORY DUCKS, GEESE, AND SWANS COMMON TO THIS REGION ARE ECOLOGICALLY IMPORTANT COMPONENTS OF WETLAND ECOSYSTEMS AND ECONOMICALLY IMPORTANT TO ILLINOIS FOR HUNTING AND VIEWING OPPORTUNITIES THE PROJECT WILL WORK TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE CURRENT STATE OF WATERFOWL IN ILLINOIS, HOW DISEASE IMPACTS WATERFOWL, AND HOW HABITAT AVAILABILITY IMPACTS WATERFOWL. BENEFITS OF THIS PROJECT ARE AN INCREASED UNDERSTANDING OF WATERFOWL IN THE STATE OF ILLINOIS AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF BETTER MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES. UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS URBANA CHAMPAIGN IS AN EXPECTED SUBRECIPIENT.

THIS PROJECT WILL WORK TO BETTER UNDERSTAND WHY GEESE HAVE CHANGED DISTRIBUTIONS AND HOW LANDOWNERS CAN MANAGE THEIR PROPERTY TO BETTER EXPLOIT THEIR PREFERENCES, WE PROPOSE TO STUDY THE ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS THAT INFLUENCE THE DISTRIBUTIONS AND HABITAT USE OF CANADA, GREATER WHITE-FRONTED, AND LESSER SNOW GEESE IN ILLINOIS. THIS STUDY WILL HELP EXPLAIN WHY WINTERING GEESE HAVE CHANGED THEIR DISTRIBUTION AND IDENTIFY BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO MANAGE HABITAT FOR THE EXPLOITATION OF EACH OF THESE 3 SPECIES. SOUTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY CARBONDALE IS AN EXPECTED SUBGRANTEE OF THIS PROJECT.

HUNTING IS AN IMPORTANT PART OF UTAHS ECONOMIC, POLITICAL AND SOCIAL WELFARE. HUNTING WAS RECENTLY PROTECTED INUTAHS CONSTITUTION AS AN INDIVIDUAL RIGHT AND THE PREFERRED MEANS OF WILDLIFE CONTROL AND MANAGEMENT. BEYONDACHIEVING INTERNAL GOALS, THE SIMPLIFIED GUIDEBOOKS, MARKETING CAMPAIGN AND HUNTER AND SHOOTER INTRODUCTORYEVENTS WILL HELP US FULFILL OUR MISSION OF SERVING THE PEOPLE OF UTAH AS TRUSTEES AND GUARDIANS OF THE STATE SPROTECTED WILDLIFE. ENGAGING NEW AND EXISTING HUNTERS, AND REACTIVATING LAPSED HUNTERS, IS ESSENTIAL TO MANAGINGUTAHS PROTECTED SPECIES. THIS GRANT IS FOCUSED ON SIMPLIFYING HUNTING REGULATIONS AND ENSURING THAT THE UTAHDIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES IS EDUCATING THE PUBLIC ABOUT HUNTING AND SHOOTING OPPORTUNITIES IN THE STATE.

THE SWIFT FOX HAS BEEN A SPECIES OF CONSERVATION CONCERN THROUGHOUT ITS RANGE FOR OVER 30 YEARS. IN 2022, AN INTERAGENCY COMMITTEE REPRESENTED BY TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT, THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, US FOREST SERVICE, AND US DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE NRCS DRAFTED A TEXAS-LEVEL PLAN FOR CONSERVATION OF THE SWIFT FOX (VULPES VELOX). THE PLAN IDENTIFIED A LIST OF RESEARCH PRIORITIES TO BETTER UNDERSTAND HOW TO INCREASE THE SURVIVAL AND POPULATION EXPANSION OF THE SPECIES. WE WILL ATTEMPT TO ADDRESS THESE RESEARCH PRIORITIES IN DALLAM COUNTY, TEXAS, THE ONLY COUNTY IN THE STATE KNOWN TO CURRENTLY HAVE A FUNCTIONAL SWIFT FOX POPULATION. OUR RESEARCH WILL FOCUS ON FOUR OBJECTIVES  1) EVALUATING THE EFFICACY OF DIFFERENT METHODS TO INCREASE SWIFT FOX SURVIVAL, INCLUDING A) LIVESTOCK GUARDIAN DOGS AND B) ARTIFICIAL BURROWS,  2) ASSESS FOX RESPONSE TO APPLIED HABITAT MANAGEMENT CONDUCTED VIA GRAZING AND PRESCRIBED BURNING  3) ESTIMATE THE PREVALENCE OF DISEASE (E.G., CANINE DISTEMPER, PARVO VIRUS) AMONG FOXES AND ATTEMPT TO DETERMINE DISEASE INFLUENCE ON PUP SURVIVAL  AND 4) ASSESS THE ATTITUDES AND KNOWLEDGE OF LANDOWNERS, HUNTERS, AND RECREATIONISTS REGARDING SWIFT FOX AND CONSERVATION ACTIONS. THE MULTIDISCIPLINARY NATURE OF THIS STUDY NECESSITATES PARTICIPATION OF RESEARCHERS WITH DIFFERENT AREAS OF EXPERTISE FROM DIFFERENT INSTITUTIONS, MANAGERS FROM STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES, AND LANDOWNERS IN THE STUDY

THE IDR S WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (IDRWP) IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS OF DATA REGARDING THE CONDITION OF WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND HABITATS, MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF MAMMALS, PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO OTHER AGENCIES REGARDING RESOURCE ISSUES, AND PUBLIC OUTREACH IN THESE LANDSCAPES. THE ACTIVITIES ARE CONDUCTED TO CARRY OUT THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE S (CDFW) TRUSTEE RESPONSIBILITIES FOR RESOURCES AND REQUIRE EXTENSIVE COMMUNICATION AND COORDINATION WITH OTHER AGENCIES, CDFW HEADQUARTERS PROGRAMS, REGIONAL CDFW STAFF, AND THE PUBLIC. CLIMATE CHANGE IS EXPECTED TO AFFECT SPECIES THE MOST IN EXTREME ENVIRONMENTS, SUCH AS THE ALPINE AND THE DESERT. MANY OF THESE EXTREME ENVIRONMENTS ARE FOUND IN HIGH ELEVATIONS ( 10,000 FEET) OF THE SIERRA NEVADA AND THE LOW ELEVATIONS ( 3,000 FEET) OF THE PENINSULAR RANGES, BOTH OF WHICH ARE IN THE CDFW S INLAND DESERTS REGION (IDR). CDFW IS THE LEAD AGENCY IMPLEMENTING EFFORTS TO CONSERVE SIERRA NEVADA BIGHORN SHEEP AND PENINULAR BIGHORN SHEEP. THE CDFW IS ALSO RESPONSIBLE FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF POPULATIONS OF DESERT BIGHORN SHEEP (DBHS) AND OTHER GAME SPECIES THROUGHOUT SOUTHEASTERN CALIFORNIA. IN 1994 A STATEWIDE POPULATION INVENTORY ESTIMATED THE POPULATION AT APPROXIMATELY 3,629 BIGHORN SHEEP (TORRES ET. AL. 1994). IN 2003, A STATEWIDE POPULATION INVENTORY YIELDED AN ESTIMATE OF 4,473 BIGHORN SHEEP SUGGESTING A POPULATION INCREASE OVER THE TEN YEAR PERIOD (EPPS ET. AL. 2005). THE MOST RECENT INVENTORY CONTINUED THE INCREASING TREND, YIELDING AN ESTIMATED TOTAL POPULATION OF 5,206 (ABELLA ET AL. 2011). THE COLLECTION OF ADEQUATE POPULATION INFORMATION IS NECESSARY TO CONTINUE TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS FOR BIGHORN SHEEP CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT. TO COLLECT SUCH DATA A VARIETY OF TECHNIQUES INCLUDING AERIAL AND GROUND BASED SURVEYS AND REMOTE DATA COLLECTION (CAMERA DATA COLLECTED AT WATERHOLES) WILL BE CONDUCTED. IN MAY, 2013 CDFW FIRST DETECTED EVIDENCE OF A PNEUMONIA OUTBREAK IN A POPULATION OF DBHS. THE DISEASE HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED IN SEVERAL MORE POPULATIONS SINCE. SUCH OUTBREAKS ARE NOT THOROUGHLY UNDERSTOOD AS WILDLIFE AGENCIES TEND TO DISCOVER THEM WHEN MANY INDIVIDUALS HAVE ALREADY BEEN AFFECTED AND SIGNIFICANT MORTALITY HAS OCCURRED. MONITORING THE DISTRIBUTION OF DISEASE AND SURVIVAL OF BIGHORN HERDS DURING THE CURRENT OUTBREAK CAN GUIDE FUTURE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS HERE AND IN OTHER STATES. THE RECENT OUTBREAK IN THE MOJAVE DESERT THREATENS SOME CORE DBHS POPULATIONS IN CALIFORNIA. THE AFFECTED POPULATIONS ARE LOCATED IN CURRENT HUNT ZONES AND TRADITIONAL SOURCE HERDS FOR TRANSLOCATION STOCK. IN ADDITION, THEY ARE CENTRAL TO THE OVERALL METAPOPULATION OF DESERT BIGHORN AND ANY FURTHER SPREAD OF DISEASE WOULD IMPACT A SUBSTANTIAL PROPORTION OF DESERT BIGHORN IN CALIFORNIA.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO MANAGE AND ADEQUATELY PROVIDE SUPPORT BY DEVELOPING A PROCESS WITH ASSIGNED RESOURCES FOR THE PURPOSE OF ENSURING THAT ALL FEDERAL PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS ARE ADHERED TO, AND THAT PROGRAM FUNDS ARE UTILIZED IN THE MANNER DESCRIBED IN FEDERAL AND STATE LAWS, REGULATIONS, AND POLICIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS STUDY IS TO PROMOTE POPULATION GROWTH OF OSPREY IN ILLINOIS BY IMPLEMENTING HACKING TECHNIQUES. THIS STUDY WILL HELP RESTORE LOCAL BREEDING POPULATIONS OF OSPREY IN CENTRAL ILLINOIS AND ALSO ASSESS THE ADEQUACY AND EFFECTIVENESS OF HACKING TECHNIQUES TO RECOVER OSPREY POPULATIONS AT MULTIPLE SCALES. UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS AT SPRINGFIELD IS AN EXPECTED SUBGRANTEE OF THIS PROJECT.

THIS PROJECT WILL SEEK TO LEARN MORE ABOUT THE IMPACT OF SHARPSHOOTING ON DEER USE OF MANAGED SITES, LEARN MORE ABOUT THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN DOE RESOURCE SELECTION AND FAWN SURVIVAL, AND LEARN MORE ABOUT THE IMPACT OF MOUNTAIN BIKING ON DEER BEHAVIOR. THE EXPECTED RESULTS ARE A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF HOW THESE ELEMENTS EFFECT DEER. SOUTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY CARBONDALE IS AN EXPECTED SUBRECIPIENT OF THIS AWARD.

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO ASSESS THE CONTRIBUTION OF SUBLETHAL TREMATODE INFECTIONS ON LESSER SCAUP HEN MIGRATION AND BREEDING SUCCESS TO INFORM FUTURE MANAGEMENT OF LESSER SCAUP POPULATIONS. OUR RESEARCH IS DESIGNED TO INFORM CONSERVATION-PLANNING EFFORTS AND ANSWER BASIC AND APPLIED QUESTIONS OF THE ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER AND GREAT LAKES REGION JOINT VENTURE, UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, AND OTHER CONSERVATION PARTNERS. THIS INVESTIGATION WILL ASSIST IDNR IN UNDERSTANDING THE IMPACTS OF INFECTION AND INFORM FUTURE HUNTING AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT. NORTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY IS AN EXPECTED SUBGRANTEE OF THIS PROJECT.

THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO DEVELOP A SCIENCE-BASED HUNTER R3 PROGRAM THAT PROVIDES ADULTS (18 YEARS OF AGE) WITH AN OPPORTUNITY TO LEARN ABOUT HUNTING, CLEANING, AND PREPARING GAME BY HOLDING WORKSHOPS AROUND THE STATE THAT FOCUS ON HOW ANDWHERE TO HUNT, HOW TO CLEAN GAME AND EQUIPMENT POST-HUNT, ILLINOIS LAWS AND REGULATIONS, AND THE ROLE OF HUNTING IN WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT HUNTING FOSTERS INTEREST IN THE NATURAL WORLD, AND WILDLIFE SPECIFICALLY. THIS INTEREST TRANSFERS TO OTHER ACTIVITIES (BACKYARD BIRD FEEDING, CONSERVATION). HUNTERS ALSO PROVIDE ESSENTIAL CONTRIBUTIONS TO RURAL ECONOMIES AND SUPPORTING JOBS IN SEVERAL INDUSTRIAL SECTORS. UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS URBANA CHAMPAIGN IS AN EXPECTED SUBGRANTEE OF THIS GRANT.

UTAH S NATURAL LANDSCAPE IS CHANGING. URBAN SPRAWL, COMMERCIAL DEVELOPMENT, NATURAL RESOURCE EXPLORATION AND EXTRACTION, EXPANDING FORMS OF OUTDOOR RECREATION, CLIMATE SHIFTS, RECURRING CATASTROPHIC WILDFIRE, GENERATIONAL LAND OWNERSHIP DIFFERENCES, AND CHANGES IN HUNTING VALUES ARE ALL CONTRIBUTING FACTORS TO A DECREASE IN THE QUALITY AND QUANTITY OF PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE HUNTING AREAS AND HEALTHY WILDLIFE HABITATS. UTAH S WALK-IN ACCESS PROGRAM IS A COOPERATIVE DEVELOPMENT OF LAND ACCESS LEASES BETWEEN PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND THE UTAH DIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES. THROUGH FORMAL WRITTEN AGREEMENTS, THE LANDOWNER IS COMPENSATED WITH A STANDARDIZED ANNUAL PAYMENT IN EXCHANGE FOR OPENING THEIR LAND FOR FREE PUBLIC ACCESS TO HUNT OR TRAP. THESE LEASES OPEN APPROXIMATELY 65,000 ACRES OF PRIVATE LAND THAT WOULD NOT OTHERWISE BE ACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC. PARTICIPATING LANDS ARE ENCOURAGED TO MAKE HABITAT IMPROVEMENTS AND CONTINUE TO BE PRODUCTIVE FOR FUTURE WILDLIFE. PUBLIC USERS ARE ENCOURAGED TO RESPECT AND CARE FOR THE PRIVATE LAND TO ENSURE THAT THE PRIVILEGE OF ACCESS REMAINS.

SPORT FISH RESTORATION: PROJECTS WILL ADDRESS FISHING, FISH HABITAT, AND FISH POPULATION MANAGEMENT IN WATERS ACROSS TENNESSEE. WILDLIFE RESTORATION: PROJECTS WILL ADDRESS HUNTING, WILDLIFE HABITAT, AND WILDLIFE POPULATION MANAGEMENT ACROSS TENNESSEE. HUNTER EDUCATION: PROJECTS WILL ADDRESS TEACHING HUNTER EDUCATION AND OPERATING SHOOTING RANGES ACROSS TENNESSEE AND RECRUITING PARTICIPANTS TO HUNTING AND THE SHOOTING SPORTS. BOAT ACCESS: PROJECTS WILL SEEK TO DEVELOP, RENOVATE, MAINTAIN, OR IMPROVE PUBLIC BOAT ACCESS SITES.
STATEWIDE WILDLIFE DISEASE MANAGEMENT W108M8

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO DEVELOP, ADMINISTER AND FACILITATE PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT IN PROGRAMS THAT PROMOTE THE SAFE RESPONSIBLE USE OF SPORTING ARMS AND OTHER HUNTING EQUIPMENT, THE RESPONSIBLE AND ETHICAL USE OF OUR WILDLIFE RESOURCES, AND THE BENEFITS OF MODERN WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT.  AN AVERAGE ANNUAL THROUGHPUT OF 12,000 STUDENTS WILL RECEIVE SKILLS-BASED TRAINING DESIGNED TO MAKE THEM SAFE AND RESPONSIBLE HUNTERS IN ADDITION TO IMPROVING THEIR PARTICIPATION IN THE SHOOTING SPORTS. BENEFITS INCLUDE MAINTAINING THE NUMBER OF HUNTING RELATED INCIDENTS AND AN INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF THOSE PARTICIPATING IN HUNTING AND THE SHOOTING SPORTS. THERE WILL ALSO BE ADDED ECONOMIC BENEFITS AND POSITIVE ACROSS-THE-BOARD IMPACTS TO LOCAL, REGIONAL AND STATE, ECONOMIES. THE END RESULT WILL BE AN ENHANCED AWARENESS OF HUNTING AND SHOOTING SPORTS, GREATER ENTHUSIASM TO PARTICIPATE SAFELY IN HUNTING ACTIVITIES, RESULTING IN IMPROVED SALES OF EQUIPMENT SUPPLIES AND THE USE OF AMENITIES ASSOCIATED WITH OUTDOOR HUNTING RELATED ACTIVITIES.

IN 1975, THE STATE PURCHASED 794 ACRES FROM JOSEPH T. BUDD JR., A PROMINENT BUSINESSMAN IN THE PROFITABLE SHADE TOBACCO INDUSTRY OF GADSDEN COUNTY AND MANUFACTURER OF  FLORIDA QUEEN  CIGARS. OTHER LAND USES ONCE INCLUDED TIMBERING AND CATTLE GRAZING. JOE BUDD WAS ESTABLISHED AFTER AN ADDITIONAL 4,000 ACRES WERE PURCHASED FROM THE FLORIDA POWER CORPORATION. IN 1981, 2,000 ACRES WERE ACQUIRED, AND IN 1987, THE 927-ACRE LITTLE RIVER TRACT WAS PURCHASED. IN 1992, OVER 3,000 ACRES WERE ADDED THROUGH PRESERVATION 20000 FUNDS. A 20-ACRE STOCKED POND WAS CREATED AND ADDITIONAL ACREAGE ADDED TO JOE BUDD THROUGH DIRECT ACQUISITION BY FWC AND THROUGH COOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT AGREEMENTS WITH OTHER STATE AGENCIES. THERE IS A YOUTH CONSERVATION CENTER AND AN ARCHERYRANGE AT THE STOCKED POND, BUT NO SHOTGUN AND RIFLE SHOOTING SPORTS FACILITIES AND CLASSROOM.  THE ADDITION OF THIS SMALL-BORE RIFLE RANGE, COMPACT SPORTING CLAYS COURSE, CLASSROOM, AND RESTROOM WILL ALLOW FWC TO OFFER HUNTER EDUCATION AND SHOOTING SPORTS TRAINING AT THE JOE BUDD YOUTH CONSERVATION CENTER.

THIS GRANT COVERS ADMINISTRATIVE, OPERATIONAL AND RENTAL COSTS ASSOCIATED COLORADO PARKS AND WILDLIFE S STATE TRUST LANDS ACCESS PROGRAM, INCLUDING THE NEW WALK-IN ACCESS PROGRAM. THE PROGRAM OPENS APPROXIMATELY 770,000 ACRES ACROSS COLORADO TO PUBLIC HUNTING, ANGLING, CAMPING AND WILDLIFE VIEWING.

THIS GRANT BUILDS UPON THE WILDLIFE DIVISION S KEYSTONE  A PRIVATE LANDS HABITAT MANAGEMENT PROGRAM THAT FUNCTIONS TO MEET THE AGENCY MISSION OF CONSERVING AND ENHANCING KANSAS S NATURAL HERITAGE, WILDLIFE, AND WILDLIFE HABITATS  ASSURING FUTURE GENERATIONS THE BENEFITS OF THE STATE S DIVERSE, LIVING RESOURCES BY FOCUSING EFFORTS ON CONSERVING PRIVATE LANDS WILDLIFE HABITAT IN KANSAS.

SOUTH DAKOTA GFP CREATED THE SHOOTING RANGE DEVELOPMENT GRANT PROGRAM IN 1971 TO ENCOURAGE THE NEW DEVELOPMENT AND IMPROVEMENT OF SHOOTING RANGES BY OFFERING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO THIRD PARTY COOPERATORS. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS GRANT IS TO HELP MAINTAIN FIVE SHOOTING RANGES. THE EXPECTED RESULTS AND BENEFITS ARE TO PROVIDE A SAFE PLACE FOR HUNTER EDUCATION AND THE PUBLIC TO DEVELOP AND PRACTICE SHOOTING SKILLS. BY PROVIDING THE FUNDING FOR THESE PROGRAMS IT PROVIDES THE NECESSARY SUPPORT FOR R3 EFFORTS IN SOUTH DAKOTA AND WILL HELP DEVELOP AND USE PARTNERSHIPS TO HALT AND REVERSE THE DECLINING TREND IN HUNTING PARTICIPATION.

THE WHITE-WINGED DOVE IS ONE OF THE MOST HARVESTED GAMEBIRDS IN NORTH AMERICA, BUT A SCIENCE-BASED FRAMEWORK AT LARGE SPATIAL SCALES IS NEEDED TO SUSTAINABLY MANAGE THIS HARVEST. FOR YEARS TEXAS HAS CONDUCTED WHITE-WINGED DOVE MONITORING PROGRAMS, BUT ONLY RECENTLY HAVE METHODS BEEN DEVELOPED THAT ALLOW FOR FULL USE OF THESE DATA. WE PROPOSE TO LEVERAGE EXISTING DATA USING AN INTEGRATED POPULATION MODEL THAT WILL INFORM SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT OF WHITE-WINGED DOVE HARVEST AMIDST ONGOING CHANGES IN LAND COVER AND EXURBAN EXPANSION IN TEXAS.

THIS GRANT IS A SUBAWARD TO THE OKLAHOMA YOUTH HUNTING PROGRAM THROUGH THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION. THE GOAL OF THE OKLAHOMA YOUTH HUNTING PROGRAM IS TO RECRUIT HUNTERS THROUGH A MULTI-DAY HUNTING TRIP. THE HUNTS INVOLVE THE WHOLE FAMILY INCLUDING PARENTS AND SIBLINGS IF POSSIBLE. THIS AND THE MULTI-DAY APPROACH WHERE HUNTING SKILLS ARE TAUGHT HELPS TO IMPROVE THE RECRUITMENT RESULTS OF NEW HUNTERS. HUNTERS ARE TRAINED IN SIGHTING IN, MARKSMANSHIP, HUNTER SAFETY, SCOUTING AND BLIND SET UP, FIELD DRESSING AND OTHER IMPORTANT HUNTER SKILLS. A UNIQUE TACTIC THAT OYHP USES IS TO RECRUIT THEIR HUNTERS AS MENTOR HUNTERS. THIS FURTHER ENGAGES THE RECRUITED HUNTER AND HELPS TO RETAIN THEM AS A HUNTER. A LARGER NUMBER OF HUNTERS WILL PROVIDE ADDITIONAL FUNDING TO PROTECT WILDLIFE HABITAT AND COMPLETE THE MISSION OF THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION.

THIS PROPOSAL CONSISTS OF ONE COMPREHENSIVE PROJECT FOR EACH OF THE FIVE GAME SPECIES PROGRAMS CURRENTLY ADMINISTERED BY THE IOWA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (DNR): WHITE-TAILED DEER, FOREST WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT, FURBEARER MANAGEMENT, UPLAND WILDLIFE, AND MIGRATORY BIRDS. THE MAJORITY OF WORK DESCRIBED IN THIS PROPOSAL IS A CONTINUATION OF PRIOR GRANT EFFORTS.THE WILDLIFE BUREAU OF THE IOWA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES HAS STATUTORY AUTHORITY FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF ALL FISH AND WILDLIFE IN THE STATE. THIS RESPONSIBILITY AUTHORIZES THE IOWA DNR TO ORGANIZE AND PURSUE A PROGRAM OF RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT. THE WILDLIFE RESEARCH SECTION OF THE IOWA DNR HAS DEVELOPED A PROGRAM TO COORDINATE AND INFORM MANAGEMENT OF WILDLIFE IN IOWA. THESE PROGRAMS MAINLY INVOLVE THE COORDINATION AND EVALUATION OF SURVEYS TO DETERMINE POPULATION TRENDS AND MONITOR ANNUAL HARVEST, AS WELL AS CONDUCT RESEARCH TO INFORM POPULATION MODELING AS WELL AS HABITAT RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT. SURVEYS ARE THE PRIMARY METHOD BY WHICH THE IOWA DNR OBTAINS INFORMATION ON POPULATION TRENDS OF THESE SPECIES, THUS INFORMING ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS ON AN ANNUAL BASIS TO MAINTAIN, FOR EXAMPLE, A STABLE WHITE-TAILED DEER POPULATION WITHIN ESTABLISHED POPULATION GOALS. RESEARCH TO EVALUATE ESTABLISHED SURVEYS ENSURES THE IOWA DNR IS OBTAINING THE MOST RELIABLE INFORMATION TO MAKE DECISIONS.SOME OF THESE SPECIES HAVE HAD A RESTORATION PROGRAM IN IOWA, E.G. THE RIVER OTTER AND THE GREATER PRAIRIE CHICKEN, AMONG OTHERS. SINCE RESTORATION THESE SPECIES HAVE BEEN MANAGED IN CONSIDERATION OF THE SOCIAL CARRYING CAPACITY OF THE PEOPLE OF IOWA. MULTIPLE SURVEYS ARE CONDUCTED ALLOWING THE DEPARTMENT THE ABILITY TO MANAGE DYNAMIC POPULATIONS. WITHOUT THESE SURVEYS COORDINATED MANAGEMENT WOULD BE DIFFICULT IF NOT IMPOSSIBLE.EFFECTIVE AND ADAPTIVE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS REQUIRE CONSISTENT AND DETAILED INFORMATION FROM WHICH TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS. PERHAPS EQUALLY IMPORTANT, IT IS EXTREMELY BENEFICIAL TO SHARE TECHNICAL INFORMATION WITH THE PUBLIC, THE MEDIA, AND OTHER BIOLOGISTS.
THE PRIMARY FUNCTION OF THIS GRANT IS TO PROVIDE HEALTHY POPULATIONS OF WILDLIFE THROUGH POPULATION MONITORING, HABITAT DEVELOPMENT, AND TECHNICAL GUIDANCE TO CONSTITUENTS STATEWIDE.

JEWELL MEADOWS WILDLIFE AREA IS LOCATED IN THE NORTH OREGON COAST RANGE, APPROXIMATELY 25 MILES SE OF ASTORIAOREGON, AND MANAGED BY THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE.JEWELL MEADOWS WILDLIFE AREA CONSISTS OF 1439 ACRES OWNED BY OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE. THE PRIMARY PURPOSE IS TO PROTECT AND ENHANCE HABITAT TO BENEFIT NATIVE WILDLIFE SPECIES, REDUCE WILDLIFE DAMAGE TO ADJACENT PROPERTIES, AND TO PROVIDE THE PUBLIC AN OPPORTUNITY TO OBSERVE WILDLIFE IN A NATURAL SETTING.1. PROVIDE HABITAT FOR ROOSEVELT ELK, BLACK-TAILED DEER, AND OTHER WILDLIFE.2. MANAGE ELK POPULATIONS ON THE AREA TO BE COMPATIBLE WITH SURROUNDING LAND USE PRACTICES.3. PROVIDE QUALITY WILDLIFE ORIENTED RECREATIONAL AND EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES.

IN RESPONSE TO WOLVES DISPERSING INTO OREGON FROM THE NORTHERN ROCKY MOUNTAIN GRAY WOLF RECOVERY AREA, THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (ODFW) DEVELOPED THE OREGON WOLF CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT PLAN (ODFW 2005  HEREAFTER WOLF PLAN) WHICH WAS UPDATED IN 2019. THE WOLF PLAN IDENTIFIES POPULATION AND DISTRIBUTION OBJECTIVES THAT AFFECT HOW WOLVES ARE MANAGED IN EASTERN AND WESTERN OREGON. THE GRAY WOLF (CANIS LUPUS) IS NO LONGER LISTED AS ENDANGERED UNDER THE OREGON STATE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. THE WOLF PLAN CALLS FOR POPULATION MONITORING, RESEARCH, DEPREDATION RESPONSE, PUBLIC OUTREACH, AND EDUCATION TO ENHANCE CONSERVATION. THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT IMPLEMENTATION OF THE WOLF PLAN. THE GRAY WOLF IS LISTED AS FEDERALLY ENDANGERED IN  OF THE STATE.

THE STATEWIDE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT GRANT INCLUDES THE FOUR PROJECTS. WILDLIFE HEALTH PROGRAMRESPONSIBILITIES AND ACTIVITIES INCLUDE THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF A WILDLIFE HEALTH PROGRAM (WHP) THAT COLLABORATES WITH LOCAL, STATE AND FEDERAL PARTNERS TO ASSESS AND ELIMINATE THE IMPACTS OF WILDLIFE DISEASES ON WILDLIFE POPULATIONS, LIVESTOCK AND HUMANS. THE WHP INVESTIGATES AND MONITORS ISSUES AFFECTING WILDLIFE HEALTH AND DISEASE OCCURRENCES ACROSS THE STATE. GRANT FUNDS ARE USED FOR PROGRAM STAFFING AND PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION.SURVEY AND INVENTORYSUPPORTS WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AND WILDLIFE-RELATED RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES THROUGH STAFF AND PROJECT FUNDING. THE GRANT FUNDS WILDLIFE MONITORING OF POPULATIONS THROUGH CAPTURE, RADIO-MARKING, AND GPS TELEMETRY MONITORING TO ASSESS SURVIVAL AND DISTRIBUTION  AERIAL AND GROUND-BASED SURVEYS TO ASSESS POPULATION COMPOSITION, SIZE, AND TREND  AND ESTIMATION AND MONITORING OF HARVEST. IT FUNDS THE TRANSLOCATION OF WILDLIFE SPECIES TO RESTORE OR AUGMENT POPULATIONS AND TO PROVIDE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. ADDITIONALLY, IT FUNDS STAFF PARTICIPATION IN TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, STAKEHOLDER INVOLVEMENT, AND MANAGEMENT PLANNING.HABITAT PROGRAM MANAGEMENTSUPPORTS WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AND WILDLIFE-RELATED RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES THROUGH STAFF AND PROJECT FUNDING. THE HABITAT PROGRAM FUNDS WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA (WMA) SUPPORT FACILITIES CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE  HABITAT DEVELOPMENT AND RESTORATION PROJECTS, AND ASSOCIATED MONITORING  WILDLIFE, HABITAT, AND PUBLIC USE MONITORING. THE HABITAT PROGRAM PROVIDES FUNDS FOR INCENTIVE PROGRAMS TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS FOR HUNTER ACCESS. THE HABITAT PROGRAM FUNDS STAFF PARTICIPATION IN ENVIRONMENTAL AND TECHNICAL REVIEW AND INPUT, AS WELL AS TASKS ASSOCIATED WITH PUBLIC OUTREACH, AND STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT.WILDLIFE RESEARCHCONDUCTS RESEARCH PROJECTS THAT WILL INFORM AND IMPROVE THE MANAGEMENT OF MULE DEER, ELK, WHITE-TAILED DEER, MOOSE, PRONGHORN, BIGHORN SHEEP, MOUNTAIN GOATS, BLACK BEARS, MOUNTAIN LIONS, GRAY WOLVES, COLUMBIAN SHARP-TAILED GROUSE, GREATER SAGE-GROUSE, AND IMPROVE HABITAT FOR ALL SPECIES IN THE STATE. PROJECT FUNDS ARE USED FOR RESEARCH PROGRAM STAFF AND PROJECTS IMPLEMENTATION.

THE MISSISSIPPI DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE, FISHERIES, AND PARKS (MDWFP) ADMINISTERS THE MISSISSIPPI HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM TO TEACH HUNTERS THE SKILLS, KNOWLEDGE, AND ATTITUDES NECESSARY TO BE SAFE AND RESPONSIBLE HUNTERS. THIS GRANT WILL FUND TRADITIONAL HUNTER EDUCATION, R3 PROGRAMS (SHOOTING SPORTS AND ARCHERY) AND EVENTS, AND THE THREE STATE-OWNED PUBLIC SHOOTING RANGES.
THIS GRANT SUPPORTS GEORGIA S HUNTER EDUCATION AND SHOOTING RANGE OPERATIONS   MAINTENANCE PROGRAMS.

THE STATEWIDE HABITAT PROGRAM IN THE DESCHUTES WATERSHED DISTRICT COMPRISES TWO SUB-BASINS OF THE COLUMBIA RIVER BASIN: THE DESCHUTES SUB-BASIN, WHICH INCLUDES 6.8 MILLION ACRES OF WILDLIFE HABITAT, AND THE HOOD RIVER SUBBASIN, WHICH INCLUDES 341,000 ACRES OF WILDLIFE HABITAT. THERE ARE 25 PRIMARY WILDLIFE HABITAT TYPES IN THE SUBBASINS ALONG WITH 400  SPECIES OF TERRESTRIAL AND AQUATIC WILDLIFE. IN ADDITION, THERE ARE 18 FEDERALLY LISTEDFISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES AND 35 SPECIES OF CONCERN INCLUDING PLANTS (9) AND INVERTEBRATES (4). ADDITIONALLY,THIS PROJECT INCLUDES THE ENTIRE MANAGEMENT OF THREE STATE WILDLIFE AREAS: 2,230-ACRE PRINEVILLE RESERVOIR, 140-ACRE CRATES POINT (INCLUDING TAYLOR LAKE), AND 22-ACRE RUFUS PONDS AS WELL AS 20 ACRES IN THE SPRING CREEK AREAOF THE METOLIUS WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT UNIT AND FOUR PARCELS (TOTALING 20 ACRES) ALONG THE LITTLE DESCHUTES RIVER.HUMAN POPULATION EXPANSION, HUMAN DEVELOPMENT, AND AN UPSURGE IN THE VARIETY OF RECREATIONAL PURSUITS HAVE ALLIMPACTED FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITATS. THESE ACTIVITIES HAVE INCREASED HABITAT FRAGMENTATION, WILDLIFE DISTURBANCE,LANDSCAPE-LEVEL WILDFIRES, AND THE SPREAD OF EXOTIC SPECIES. THE RESULT HAS BEEN A DECLINE IN WILDLIFE HABITATEFFECTIVENESS. WITHOUT ACTIVE STRATEGIC PLANNING TO ADDRESS THESE THREATS, WILDLIFE HABITAT CONNECTIVITY WILLCONTINUE TO DETERIORATE. THIS HABITAT PROGRAM S PURPOSE IS TO PROTECT, MAINTAIN, AND ENHANCE WILDLIFE HABITAT TOMEET OREGONS WILDLIFE POLICY BY: 1) MANIPULATING HABITAT, 2) ACQUIRING LAND, 3) DEVELOPING HABITAT MANAGEMENTAND RESTORATION TECHNIQUES, 4) PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO STATE, FEDERAL, TRIBAL, AND LOCAL AGENCIES ANDINDIVIDUALS  AND, 5) PROVIDING FUNDING THROUGH GRANTS FOR HABITAT PROTECTION, RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT.

THIS PROJECT WILL EXPAND CAPACITY AND COMMUNITY USE OF THE WRANGELL OUTDOOR SHOOTING RANGE BY DESIGNING AND CONSTRUCTING AN EIGHT-STATION SKEET RANGE. THIS EXPANSION WILL SET THE STAGE FOR FUTURE TRAP SHOOTING SPORT FOR PUBLIC USE AND SUPPORT HUNTER SAFETY AND EDUCATION.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO HELP EDUCATE OKLAHOMANS ABOUT SAFE AND ETHICAL HUNTING, SHOOTING AND TRAPPING. THIS GRANT WILL USE HUNTER EDUCATION CLASSES, SHOOTING SPORTS TRAINING, TRAPPER TRAINING, EMAILS, MAGAZINE ARTICLES, TV SHOW SEGMENTS AND OTHER OUTREACH AND EDUCATION OPPORTUNITIES TO PROVIDE INFORMATION AND EDUCATION TO NEW, POTENTIAL, EXISTING AND FORMER HUNTERS, SHOOTERS AND TRAPPERS. THIS WILL RESULT IN A MORE ACTIVE, EDUCATED, SAFE AND ETHICAL GENERATION OF HUNTERS, SHOOTERS AND TRAPPERS IN OKLAHOMA. THIS WILL BENEFIT ALL OKLAHOMANS BY PROVIDING A SAFER AND MORE WILDLIFE AWARE POPULACE.

THIS GRANT ANNUALLY FUNDS ALL STATEWIDE WILDLIFE DISEASE WORK IN COLORADO. THE PURPOSE IS TO DELIVER A COORDINATED AND SYSTEMATIC APPROACH FOR MONITORING, INVESTIGATING, AND REPORTING ON HEALTH PROBLEMS IN FREE-RANGING WILDLIFE THROUGHOUT COLORADO.

IN ORDER FOR GRANT COMPLIANCE TO BE EFFECTIVELY MONITORED AND REPORTED, THE DEPARTMENT HAS DESIGNATED A FEDERALAID COORDINATOR POSITION TO HELP SUPPORT AND ASSIST IN THESE PROCESSES AND SYSTEMS. THE FEDERAL AID COORDINATORPOSITION ASSISTS THE DEPARTMENT GRANT MANAGERS, ADMINISTRATIVE LEADERSHIP AND STAFF IN ORDER FOR THEM TO MEETTHEIR PROGRAM AND GRANT OBJECTIVES, THEIR BUDGET MANDATES AS WELL AS HELP THEM FIND AND ANALYZE DIFFERENT SOURCESFOR STATE MATCH.

TO PROVIDE EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT, COORDINATION, AND TECHNICAL SUPPORT FOR THE UTAH DIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES (UDWR) FEDERAL AID PROGRAMS. WHICH INCLUDES THE CONTRACTUAL ANNUAL PAYMENTS FOR IN-LIEU-OF-TAXES TO UTAH COUNTIES FOR WILDLIFE RESTORATION ACT AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION ACT FEDERAL AID LANDS, AS WELL AS WILDLIFE LANDS OBTAINED UNDER SECTION 8 OF THE COLORADO RIVER STORAGE PROJECT ACT, WHICH LANDS WERE ACQUIRED FROM PRIVATE OWNERSHIP ONLY.THE COORDINATION WILL INSURE UTAH S ELIGIBILITY FOR CONTINUED FEDERAL AID FUNDING THROUGH COMPLIANCE WITH APPLICABLE LAWS AND REGULATIONS. IT WILL ALSO ENSURE ADEQUATE PLANNING AND EXECUTION OF UTAH S FEDERAL AID GRANTS FOR EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES AND FOR THE SOCIO-ECONOMIC BENEFIT TO SPORTS PERSON AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.THE PAYMENT OF IN-LIEU-OF-TAXES AMOUNTS TO COUNTIES WILL COMPLY WITH UTAH LAW AND MAINTAIN FAVORABLE SUPPORT FOR UDWR S FEDERAL AID LAND ACQUISITION AND OWNERSHIP PROGRAM.

THE PURPOSE OF THE FEDERAL AID COORDINATION GRANT IS TO PROVIDE THE STAFF AND PROCEDURES TO ENSURE THAT THE STATE MEETS ITS RESPONSIBILITIES FOR PARTICIPATION IN THE FEDERAL AID PROGRAM, INCLUDING WORK PLANNING, RECORD KEEPING, REPORTING, SUPERVISION OF FIELD STAFF, AND COORDINATION OF FEDERAL AID ACTIVITIES WITH OTHER STATE AND AGENCY PROGRAMS.
THIS GRANT FUNDS A MAJORITY OF THE ANNUAL CPW SMALL GAME CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING THE WALK IN ACCESS PROGRAM AND HUNTING SURVEYS.
THIS GRANT PROJECT FUNDS ALL ANNUAL DEER POPULATION MANAGEMENT WORK IN COLORADO.

IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME (IDFG) NEEDS TO PROVIDE HUNTER AND TRAPPER EDUCATION PROGRAMS TO DEVELOP SAFE, ETHICAL AND RESPONSIBLE IDAHO HUNTERS AND TRAPPERS THROUGH THE HUNTER, BOWHUNTER AND TRAPPER EDUCATION COURSES. A SKILLED AND EDUCATED HUNTING POPULATION MAINTAINS THE SAFETY AND INTEGRITY OF THE SPORT FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS.

THE WEST VIRGINIA DIVISION OF NATURAL RESOURCES, WILDLIFE RESOURCES SECTION IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF OUR STATE S WILDLIFE RESOURCES AND FOR PROVIDING WILDLIFE ASSOCIATED RECREATION FOR THE CITIZENS OF OUR STATE. ELK BECAME EXTIRPATED IN WEST VIRGINIA IN THE LATE 1800 S WITH THE LAST RECORDED SIGHTING FROM THE HEADWATERS OF THE CHEAT RIVER IN POCAHONTAS COUNTY IN 1873. ELK WERE REINTRODUCED INTO LOGAN COUNTY IN DECEMBER 2016 FROM LAND BETWEEN THE LAKES IN KENTUCKY, AND FROM ARIZONA IN FEBRUARY 2018. IN ADDITION, ADDITIONAL STOCKING OF ANIMALS OCCURRED FROM LAND BETWEEN THE LAKES. DATA IS NEEDED TO DETERMINE THE PERCENTAGE OF CALVES SIRED IN WEST VIRGINIA, AND TO DETERMINE IF THE WEST VIRGINIA POPULATION IS BREEDING WITH THE ELK POPULATIONS IN EITHER KENTUCKY AND OR VIRGINIA.

THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION PROGRAM WAS INITIATED IN 1937 UNDER THE PITTMAN-ROBERTSON ACT TO PROVIDE FEDERAL FUNDINGTO STATES FOR THE BENEFIT OF A DIVERSE ARRAY OF WILDLIFE AND ASSOCIATED HABITATS. THIS GRANT FUNDS THE ANNUALOPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF THE E.E. WILSON WILDLIFE AREA (EEW).THE E.E. WILSON WILDLIFE AREA CAME INTO EXISTENCE IN 1950 WHEN THE U.S. GOVERNMENT GAVE QUITCLAIM TITLE TO THE PROPERTY TO THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE. THE WILDLIFE AREA COVERS APPROXIMATELY 1,788 ACRES, IS LOCATED ON HIGHWAY 99W ABOUT 10 MILES NORTH OF CORVALLIS AND IS SITUATED ON THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY FLOOR. BORDERED TO THE NORTH BY PRIVATE FARMLANDS, THE URBAN COMMUNITY OF ADAIR VILLAGE TO THE SOUTH, HIGHWAY 99W TO THE WEST AND THE UNDEVELOPED CITY OF ADAIR AND UNITED STATES FOREST SERVICE (USFS) PROPERTIES TO THE EAST, EEW ALSO INCLUDES THE ISOLATED 55-ACRE BAKER TRACT, THE 50-ACRE COFFIN BUTTE TRACT AND 40 ACRES SURROUNDING THE SOUTH WILLAMETTE WATERSHED DISTRICT OFFICE. THIS PROJECT WILL MAINTAIN OR IMPROVE FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT ON THE 1,788 ACRE STATE WILDLIFE AREA. IT WILL MAINTAIN UNIQUE HABITATS AND BIODIVERSITY IN A REGION THAT IS BECOMING INCREASINGLY IMPACTED BY RISING HUMAN POPULATION. IT WILL PROVIDE A WIDE RANGE OF WILDLIFE ORIENTED RECREATIONAL AND EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE ENJOYMENT OF VISITORS. THIS IN TURN CONTRIBUTES TO THE LOCAL, STATE AND FEDERAL ECONOMY AS PEOPLE SPEND MONEY IN VARIOUS WAYS WHILE ENJOYING THE EE WILSON WILDLIFE AREA.

THIS PROJECT WILL WORK TO ACCURATELY ASSESS THE STATUS OF CERTAIN FURBEARING SPECIES IN ILLINOIS. EXPECTED BENEFITS ARE RIGOROUS ESTIMATES OF DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE FOR THE TERRESTRIAL FURBEARER COMMUNITY, AN UNDERSTANDING OF CURRENT POPULATION INDICES AND TRENDS, AND PROVIDE THE PUBLIC WITH UP TO DATE INFORMATION REGARDING FURBEARERS. UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS URBANA CHAMPAIGN IS AN EXPECTED SUBRECIPIENT OF THIS AWARD.

PURPOSE: TO INSTITUTE A SYSTEM OF WILDLIFE DISEASE RESEARCH, MONITORING, AND RESPONSE THAT INCREASES OUR KNOWLEDGE OF WILDLIFE DISEASES AND POPULATION-LEVEL EFFECTS TO ENABLE THE COMMISSION TO PREVENT OR MANAGE THOSE ISSUES IN A SAFE AND EFFECTIVE MANNER.OBJECTIVES INCLUDE:OBJECTIVE 1: CONDUCT WILDLIFE DISEASE MONITORING AND SURVEILLANCE FOR AT LEAST 6 SPECIES BY JUNE 30, 2024OBJECTIVE 2: MANAGE AGENCY RESPONSE FOR CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE (CWD) IN WHITE-TAILED DEER AND ELK THROUGH JUNE 30, 2024OBJECTIVE 3: CONDUCT AT LEAST 5 WILDLIFE TECHNICAL SUPPORT OR TRAINING ACTIVITIES BY JUNE 30, 2024OBJECTIVE 4: EDUCATE 10,000 INDIVIDUALS ABOUT WILDLIFE HEALTH ISSUES THROUGH JUNE 30, 2024OBJECTIVE 5: IMPLEMENT NEW DATABASES FOR CWD AND WILDLIFE DISEASE RECORD KEEPING IN THE STATE BY JUNE 30, 2024EXPECTED OUTCOMES: IMPROVE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AND REGULATION DEVELOPMENT USING BEST AVAILABLE SCIENCE, INCREASE AGENCY STAFF AND PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE REGARDING WILDLIFE HEALTH, MAINTAIN OR INCREASE HUNTER PARTICIPATION BY ADDRESSING WILDLIFE-HEALTH RELATED CONCERNS, INCREASE COMMUNICATION WITH THE PUBLIC REGARDING WILDLIFE HEALTH AND CONSERVATION, MEET PUBLIC EXPECTATIONS FOR ANIMAL WELFARE AND PUBLIC HEALTH THROUGH EFFECTIVE WILDLIFE HEALTH MANAGEMENTINTENDED BENEFICIARIES: GENERAL PUBLIC, WILDLIFE REHABILITATORS, CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS, ARKANSAS GAME AND FISH COMMISSION

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE INFORMATION THAT CAN AID IN EFFECTIVE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES FOR CONSERVATION PRIORITY BIRDS IN ILLINOIS. THE PROJECT SEEKS TO PROVIDE INFORMATION ON THE STATUS AND DISTRIBUTION OF PRIORITY SPECIES, HOW HABITAT USE OF THESE SPECIES INFLUENCES POTENTIAL MANAGEMENT APPROACHES, AND THE INFLUENCE OF SPECIFIC MANAGEMENT ACTIONS ON PRIORITY SPECIES. THESE RESULTS CAN BE USED TO TARGET FUTURE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES FOR THESE DECLINING SPECIES. UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS URBANA CHAMPAIGN IS AN EXPECTED SUBRECIPIENT,

THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO ASSIST NATURAL RESOURCE AGENCIES WITH ADDRESSING WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT ISSUES IN A TIME- AND COST-EFFECTIVE MANNER. THIS INCLUDES INCREASING PUBLIC AWARENESS AND UNDERSTANDING OF HUMAN-WILDLIFE ISSUES, AS WELL AS HABITAT DEVELOPMENT AND PROTECTION. BENEFITS INCLUDE INCREASE PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING OF WILDLIFE, MAINTENANCE AND DEVELOPMENT OF ONLINE PUBLIC RESOURCES, AND GREATER HUNTER EDUCATION. LEWIS AND CLARK COMMUNITY COLLEGE IS AN EXPECTED SUBGRANTEE OF THIS GRANT.

PURPOSE AND OBJECTIVES: TO PROVIDE THE PUBLIC WITH SAFE AND RESPONSIBLE OPPORTUNITIES FOR FIREARM AND ARCHERY ACTIVITIES.OBJECTIVE 1: OPERATE AND MAINTAIN FOUR AGENCY-OWNED FIREARM RANGES BY JUNE 30, 2024.OBJECTIVE 2: OPERATE AND MAINTAIN 13 FIELD ARCHERY ONLY RANGES AND 7 COMBINATION FIELD ARCHERY 3D ARCHERY RANGES BY JUNE 30, 2024.RESULTS OR BENEFITS EXPECTED: INCREASE IN HUNTER SHOOTER PROFICIENCY WITH FIREARMS AND ARCHERY EQUIPMENT, RETENTION OF CURRENT HUNTERS AND SHOOTERS, REACTIVATION OF FORMER HUNTERS AND SHOOTERS, INCREASED PUBLIC INTEREST IN SHOOTING SPORTS ACTIVITIES, INCREASE IN WOMEN AND MINORITY GROUPS IN SHOOTING SPORTS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: GENERAL PUBLIC, HUNTERS, RECREATIONAL SHOOTERSSUB-RECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE
THIS GRANT PROJECT FUNDS MUCH OF THE ANNUAL CPW PREDATOR POPULATION MANAGEMENT AND RESEARCH WORK.
THIS ANNUAL GRANT PROJECT FUNDS ALL CPW ELK POPULATION MANAGEMENT AND RESEARCH WORK ACROSS THE STATE OF COLORADO.

THE VOLUME AND COMPLEXITY OF STATE WORK UNDER USFWS FEDERAL AID REQUIRES COORDINATION, ADMINISTRATION AND SUPERVISION TO ENSURE ACTIVITIES ARE PROPERLY DOCUMENTED AND PRODUCTIVE OF RESULTS. THIS GRANT SUPPORTS THE ADMINISTRATION OF ALL OF THE AGENCY S USFWS GRANT WORK.

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO MONITOR THE ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF DOUBLE-CRESTED CORMORANTS (NANNOPTERUM AURITUM)AND OTHER PISCIVOROUS WATERBIRDS (E.G. CASPIAN TERN HYDROPROGNE CASPIA AND AMERICAN WHITE PELICAN PELECANUSERYTHRORHYNCHOS) WITHIN OREGON, AND ASSESS THEIR DIETS. WE WILL COLLECT INFORMATION TO EVALUATE TRENDS ANDLIMITING FACTORS FOR DOUBLE-CRESTED CORMORANTS AND OTHER PISCIVOROUS WATERBIRDS. WE WILL ALSO ASSESS THESIGNIFICANCE OF RECENT CHANGES IN THE STATEWIDE DOUBLE-CORMORANT POPULATION FOLLOWING IMPLEMENTATION OF A MAJORDOUBLE-CRESTED CORMORANT MANAGEMENT PLAN IN THE COLUMBIA RIVER ESTUARY.THIS PROJECT ALSO SEEKS TO FILL LONGSTANDING KNOWLEDGE GAPS CONCERNING THE ABUNDANCE, DISTRIBUTION, ANDPOPULATION DYNAMICS OF A VARIETY OF AVIAN SPECIES ALONG THE OREGON COAST. THIS INFORMATION IS ESPECIALLYNECESSARY CONSIDERING RECENT OBSERVED AND ANTICIPATED CHANGES IN OCEAN CONDITIONS THAT MAY DIRECTLY AFFECT AVIANSPECIES THROUGH CHANGES IN FOOD AVAILABILITY. SURVEY DATA WILL BE COLLECTED FOR A VARIETY OF AVIAN SPECIES,ENABLING A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF AVIAN USE OF ESTUARY HABITATS FOR FUTURE CONSERVATION PLANNING.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE STUDYING THE HABITAT USE AND NESTING SUCCESS OF WILD TURKEY HENS IN RELATION TO FOREST MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES. THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE KNOWLEDGE OF WILD TURKEY, EFFICACY OF MANAGEMENT ACTIONS, AND HABITAT PREFERENCES. UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS URBANA CHAMPAIGN IS AN EXPECTED SUBRECIPIENT.

PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO MAINTAIN HEALTHY WILDLIFE POPULATIONS BY PROVIDING TECHNICAL GUIDANCE TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS REGARDING BEST WILDLIFE AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT PRACTICES.OBJECTIVE 1: PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO APPROXIMATELY 600 PRIVATE LAND OWNERS BY JUNE 30, 2024.OBJECTIVE 2: DEVELOP 200 MANAGEMENT PLANS IN COLLABORATION WITH PRIVATE LAND OWNERS AND OTHER CONSERVATION PARTNERS BY JUNE 30, 2024.OBJECTIVE 3: DIRECTLY ASSIST LANDOWNERS IN MANAGING OR ENHANCING 1,500 ACRES OF WILDLIFE HABITAT BY JUNE 30, 2024.EXPECTED OUTCOMES:WILDLIFE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ON PRIVATE LAND IS ESSENTIAL TO THE LONG-TERM WELFARE OF WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS. BY PROVIDING TECHNICAL GUIDANCE, PRIVATE LANDOWNERS CAN IMPLEMENT MANAGEMENT PRACTICES THAT ACHIEVE THEIR LAND USE GOALS IN WAYS THAT BENEFIT WILDLIFE TO INCLUDE BENEFITING SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION CONCERN FROM THE ARKANSAS WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (AWAP) ALONG WITH FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: PRIVATE LAND OWNERS, ARKANSAS GAME AND FISH COMMISSIONSUB-RECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: A SUB-AWARD WILL BE GIVEN TO QUAIL FOREVER TO ASSIST WITH PRESCRIBED BURN ACTIVITIES.

PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO OBTAIN SCIENTIFIC AND OTHER DATA (E.G. ABUNDANCE, CHARACTERISTICS, POPULATION SIZE, STATUS, CONDITION,DISTRIBUTION, HABITAT AND CONDITION, ETC.) NECESSARY FOR THE EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT OF NATIVE AND MIGRATORY SPECIES AND HABITATS WITHIN WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS (WMA S) AND STATEWIDE (PUBLIC AND PRIVATE) LAND.OBJECTIVES:OBJECTIVE 1: CONDUCT AT LEAST 25 INVESTIGATIONS CONSISTING OF RESEARCH,SURVEYS AND OR MONITORING ACTIVITIES BY JUNE 30, 2024EXPECTED OUTCOMES:BY CONTINUING RESEARCH, MONITORING AND SURVEYS OF WILDLIFE POPULATIONS, THE AGFC WILL BE ABLE TO BETTER UNDERSTAND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND DEVELOP RECOMMENDATIONS ON SPECIES MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES THAT EFFECTIVELY CONSERVE GAME AND NON-GAME WILDLIFE SPECIES.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: ARKANSAS GAME AND FISH COMMISSION, GENERAL PUBLICSUB-RECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE

THE NATIONAL BOBWHITE AND GRASSLAND INITIATIVE (NBGI) IS A RANGE-WIDE GRASSLAND HABITAT PLAN FOR RECOVERING BOBWHITES TO TARGET DENSITIES SET BY STATE WILDLIFE AGENCIES. CONCURRENTLY, AT LEAST 18 SPECIES OF OTHER GRASSLAND BIRDS THAT SHARE HABITATS WITHBOBWHITES ALSO ARE DECLINING, AND THEY ARE CONSIDERED PRIORITIES FOR CONSERVATION ATTENTION.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS:-TO COORDINATE AND MANAGE THE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA SYSTEM TO ENHANCE AND PROTECT WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITAT AS WELL AS PROVIDE OUTDOOR RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES.-TO AID AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL GUIDANCE TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND PUBLIC LAND MANAGERS IN MISSISSIPPI.THE DEPARTMENT WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL GUIDANCE (I.E., EXPERT ADVICE) REGARDING WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AND PUBLIC USE TO GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES AND PRIVATE LANDOWNERS. THIS ADVICE IS FORMED THROUGH ADEQUATE DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS AND IS INTENDED TO IMPROVE ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS AFFECTING WILDLIFE, PROTECT AND OR CREATE WILDLIFE HABITAT, AND PROVIDE FOR RESPONSIBLE MANAGEMENT OF WILDLIFE POPULATIONS, AREAS, AND HABITATS FOR INCREASED PRODUCTION FOR PUBLIC BENEFITS.- TO ACTIVELY MONITOR THE RECOVERY AND EXPANSION OF THE BLACK BEAR POPULATION TO ALLOW FOR THE EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT OF THE SPECIES IN THE STATE, AND TO MAINTAIN THE VIABILITY OF THE SPECIES AS A POTENTIAL RENEWABLE WILDLIFE RESOURCE.- TO ENSURE THAT GRANT FUNDED PROJECTS ARE ACCOMPLISHED IN AN EFFECTIVE, TIMELY, AND EFFICIENT MANNER AS WELL AS MAINTAIN ELIGIBILITY FOR PARTICIPATION IN FEDERAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS.

THE GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES WILL PURCHASE THE 42  ACRE CORLEY TRACT, WHICH WILL BECOME PART OF THE 25,707-ACRE PAULDING FOREST WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA (WMA). ACQUIRING THE CORLEY TRACT WILL IMPROVE OUR ABILITY TO MANAGE THE EXISTING WMA, IMPROVE ACCESS TO THE PROPERTY, CONSERVE WILDLIFE HABITAT AND INCREASE PUBLIC HUNTING OPPORTUNITY BY ADDING THIS PROPERTY TO THE WMA.
THESE FUNDS WILL BE USED FOR SCDNR S HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM FOR FY23-24

THIS GRANT IS FOR RESEARCH BASED PROJECTS COMPLETED BY THE MDWFP AND COOPERATING UNIVERSITIES. THESE PROJECTS PROVIDE DATA THAT IS BENEFICIAL FOR IMPROVING MANAGEMENT AND HABITAT IMPROVEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS AND PRACTICES AND SETTING SEASON AND BAG LIMITS FOR GAME ANIMALS IN THE STATE.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO STUDY FURBEARERS AND NON-GAME WILDLIFE IN ILLINOIS TO PROVIDE INFORMATION TO SUPPORT WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT. THIS STUDY WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION THAT BIOLOGISTS CAN USE TO MANAGE AND MONITOR FURBEARER AND NON-GAME WILDLIFE POPULATIONS IN ILLINOIS. SOUTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY CARBONDALE IS AN EXPECTED SUBRECIPIENT.

THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE MAINTENANCE AND OPERATION OF 39 STATE-OWNED AND OPERATED PROPERTIES LOCATED THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF NEW MEXICO. THESE PROPERTIES ENCOMPASS A MORE THAN 255,000 ACRES STATEWIDE AND ARE OWNED OR COOPERATIVELY MANAGED BY THE NEW MEXICO STATE GAME COMMISSION (SEE APPENDIX A: MAP OF STATEWIDE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS (WMAS) AND LISTINGS OF WMAS). THESE PROPERTIES PROVIDE A WIDE RANGE OF WILDLIFE HABITATS, HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND WILDLIFE-ASSOCIATED RECREATION. IF THESE PROPERTIES ARE NOT PROPERLY MAINTAINED AND OPERATED, WILDLIFE HABITAT AND USE OF THESE PROPERTIES WOULD BE REDUCED. THISWOULD RESULT IN POOR HUNTING SATISFACTION AND PUBLIC SATISFACTION WOULD DRASTICALLY DECREASE LEADING TO LOSS OF INCOME TO STATE WILDLIFE AGENCIES. WITHOUT THIS INCOME, AGENCIES WOULD BE UNABLE TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE CONSERVATION OF HABITATS FOR WILDLIFE THEREBY NEGATIVELY IMPACTING WILDLIFE POPULATIONS FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS.IMPROVEMENT, MAINTENANCE, AND OPERATION ACTIVITIES INCLUDED IN THIS GRANT ARE CONSIDERED ROUTINE OR RE-OCCURRING ACTIVITIES. THE ACTIVITIES LISTED IN THIS GRANT ARE IMPROVEMENT, MAINTENANCE, AND OPERATION ACTIVITIES, AND ARE EVALUATED IN THE REQUIRED COMPLIANCE DOCUMENTS: PROGRAMMATIC ESA SECTION 7 BIOLOGICAL EVALUATION (APPENDIX C), NEPA CATEGORICAL EXCLUSION, AND PROGRAMMATIC AGREEMENT FOR NHPA SECTION 106 (APPENDIX D), AND THE NM PREHISTORIC AND HISTORIC SITES PRESERVATION ACT 18-8 NMSA 1978. IF A PROJECT IS OUTSIDE THE SCOPE OF THE INCLUDED COMPLIANCE, ADDITIONAL COMPLIANCE DOCUMENTATION WILL BE PROVIDED FOR REVIEW ANDAPPROVAL  OR THE PROJECT WILL BE CONDUCTED UNDER A SEPARATE GRANT AND COMPLIANCE.

CARNIVORES AND FURBEARERS ARE IMPORTANT BIOLOGICAL, RECREATIONAL, AND ECONOMIC RESOURCES IN NEW MEXICO, AND THE NEW MEXICO DEPARTMENT OF GAME AND FISH IS RESPONSIBLE FOR SUSTAINING POPULATIONS OF THESE SPECIES FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE PUBLIC. IN ORDER TO ENSURE THE PERSISTENCE OF CARNIVORE POPULATIONS IT IS IMPORTANT TO CONDUCTRESEARCH AND MONITORING, COORDINATE WITH GOVERNMENTAL AND PRIVATE ENTITIES, AND CONTINUOUSLY MONITOR POPULATION AND HARVEST TRENDS. THESE ACTIVITIES PROVIDE SOUND BIOLOGICAL INFORMATION THAT INFORMS THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF APPROPRIATE REGULATIONS AND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. THIS GRANT WILL HELP TO DEVELOP RESEARCH, IMPLEMENT MONITORING, AND DEVELOP GUIDELINES AND STRATEGY TO IMPROVE CARNIVORE AND FURBEARER MANAGEMENT IN NEW MEXICO TO ENSURE SUSTAINED POPULATIONS OF CARNIVORE SPECIES FOR THEIR RECREATIONAL, EDUCATIONAL, SCIENTIFIC,AND INTRINSIC VALUE.

THE GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES WILL PURCHASE THE 875  ACRE FEATHER FIELD FARMS TRACT, WHICH WILL BECOME PART OF THE 8,635-ACRE LAKE SEMINOLE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA (WMA). ACQUIRING THE FEATHER FIELD FARMS TRACT WILL IMPROVE OUR ABILITY TO MANAGE THE EXISTING WMA, IMPROVE ACCESS TO THE PROPERTY AND CONSERVE WILDLIFE HABITAT AND INCREASE PUBLIC HUNTING OPPORTUNITY ADDING THIS PROPERTY TO THE WMA.

THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION PROGRAM WAS INITIATED IN 1937 UNDER THE PITTMAN-ROBERTSON ACT (1937) TO PROVIDE FEDERALFUNDING TO STATES FOR THE BENEFIT OF A DIVERSE ARRAY OF WILDLIFE AND ASSOCIATED HABITATS. THIS GRANT FUNDS THEANNUAL OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF THE RIVERSIDE WILDLIFE AREA, THE ROGERS WILDLIFE AREA, THE SNAKE RIVERISLANDS, BURNS POND WILDLIFE AREA, CHICKAHOMINY WILDLIFE AREA, FISH LAKE WILDLIFE AREA, AND YELLOWJACKET LAKEWILDLIFE AREA. THIS GRANT ALSO FUNDS ASSISTANCE AND TECHNICAL GUIDANCE TO PUBLIC LAND MANAGERS AND PRIVATELANDOWNERS IN MALHEUR AND HARNEY COUNTIES WITH REGARDS TO WILDLIFE HABITAT RESTORATION.PROTECT, ENHANCE, RESTORE, AND PROMOTE WILDLIFE HABITATS AND THE MALHEUR WATERSHED UTILIZING SOUND STEWARDSHIPPRACTICES, WHILE PROVIDING WILDLIFE ORIENTATED RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE PUBLIC.

OUR PROJECT DIRECTLY BENEFITS MULTIPLE HABITAT AND SPECIES IDENTIFIED IN THE 2016 OREGON CONSERVATION STRATEGY(OCS) AS PRIORITIES WITH THE COLUMBIA PLATEAU ECOREGION. THE LOWER DESCHUTES AS A WHOLE IS IDENTIFIED AS ACONSERVATION OPPORTUNITY AREA. AREA MANAGEMENT FOCUSES ON THE PRIORITIES OUTLINED WITHIN THE OCS, SUCH ASRESTORATION OF SAGE AND RIPARIAN HABITATS, EARLY DETECTION AND SUPPRESSION OF INVASIVE WEEDS, AND MAINTAINING IN CHANNEL WATERSHED FUNCTION.THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT AND ENHANCE THE HABITATS, CONTROL INVASIVE SPECIES, PROVIDE FISHING ANDHUNTING ACCESS, AND OPERATE AND MAINTAIN THE LOWER DESCHUTES WA.

THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE WENAHA WILDLIFE AREA BEGAN IN 1953 WITH THE ACQUISITION OF FIVE PARCELS OF LAND CONSISTING OF 4,400 ACRES. THE DEPARTMENT CONTINUED TO PURCHASE ADDITIONAL LANDS, ACQUIRING 1,670 ACRES IN 1954 AND ANOTHER 760 ACRES IN 1955. FROM 1961 TO THE PRESENT, THE DEPARTMENT HAS PURCHASED OR RECEIVED ANOTHER 4,219 ACRES. THE WILDLIFE AREA CURRENTLY CONSISTS OF 12,419 ACRES. IN ADDITION, MANAGEMENT AGREEMENTS WITH THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT (BLM) WERE WRITTEN FOR 1,329 ACRES WITHIN OR ADJACENT TO THE WILDLIFE AREA.THE WENAHA WILDLIFE AREA ESTABLISHED IN RESPONSE TO CONTINUING COMPLAINTS FROM LANDOWNERS CONCERNED WITH ELKDAMAGE ON PRIVATE LANDS DURING WINTER MONTHS. OVER 18,000 ACRES NEAR THE INITIAL WILDLIFE AREA PURCHASE HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED AS CRITICAL BIG GAME WINTER RANGE. A SMALL RESIDENT POPULATION OF ELK AND DEER SUMMER IN THE WENAHA BASIN  HOWEVER, THE PROBLEM STEMMED PRIMARILY FROM ELK, WHICH SUMMERED IN OREGON AND WASHINGTON AND THEN MIGRATED DOWN THE WENAHA RIVER DRAINAGE INTO THE TROY AREA IN EARLY WINTER MONTHS. ELK REMAINED ON PRIVATE LANDS UNTIL APRIL WHEN THEY RETURN THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE WENAHA WILDLIFE AREA BEGAN IN 1953 WITH THE ACQUISITION OF FIVE PARCELS OF LAND CONSISTING OF 4,400 ACRES. THE DEPARTMENT CONTINUED TO PURCHASE ADDITIONAL LANDS, ACQUIRING 1,670 ACRES IN 1954 AND ANOTHER 760 ACRES IN 1955. FROM 1961 TO THE PRESENT, THE DEPARTMENT HAS PURCHASED OR RECEIVED ANOTHER 4,219 ACRES. THE WILDLIFE AREA CURRENTLY CONSISTS OF 12,419 ACRES. IN ADDITION, MANAGEMENT AGREEMENTS WITH THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT (BLM) WERE WRITTEN FOR 1,329 ACRES WITHIN OR ADJACENT TO THE WILDLIFE AREA.
