A SMALL RESIDENT POPULATION OF ELK AND DEER SUMMER IN THE WENAHA BASIN  HOWEVER, THE PROBLEM STEMMED PRIMARILY FROM ELK, WHICH SUMMERED IN OREGON AND WASHINGTON AND THEN MIGRATED DOWN THE WENAHA RIVER DRAINAGE INTO THE TROY AREA IN EARLY WINTER MONTHS. ELK REMAINED ON PRIVATE LANDS UNTIL APRIL WHEN THEY RETURNED TO SUMMER RANGE IN THE WENAHA BASIN, ON LANDS ADMINISTERED BY THE U.S. FOREST SERVICE IN BOTH OREGON AND WASHINGTON. THERE IS A NEED TO ALLEVIATE DAMAGE TO PRIVATE LANDS BY WINTERING ELK AND PROVIDE HIGH QUALITY WILDLIFE HABITAT NEAR TROY IN NORTHEAST OREGON. THE WWA IS MANAGED PRIMARILY FOR PROVIDING NATURAL AND SUPPLEMENTAL FORAGE FOR ROCKY MOUNTAIN ELK, MULE AND WHITE-TAILED DEER, AND ROCKY MOUNTAIN BIGHORN SHEEP AS WELL AS MINIMIZE BIG GAME DAMAGE TO ADJACENT PRIVATE AGRICULTURAL CROPS. THE WILDLIFE AREA ALSO IS MANAGED TO ENHANCE HABITAT FOR INDIGENOUS FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES IN ADDITION, TO PROVIDE WILDLIFE ORIENTED RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE PUBLIC. THE NATURAL RESOURCES ON THE WWA NEED TO BE MANAGED IN SUCH A MANNER AS TO PROTECT, MAINTAIN, ENHANCE, AND RESTORE FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT TO SUPPORT OPTIMUM POPULATION LEVELS OF ALL SPECIES FOR THE ENJOYMENT OF PRESENT AND FUTURE CITIZENS. TO PROTECT THESE NATURAL RESOURCES, MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS AND STRATEGIES UTILIZED ON THE WWA WILL MEET OR EXCEED HABITAT PROTECTION POLICIES AND STANDARDS SET BY THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE.THE GOAL OF THE WENAHA WILDLIFE AREA IS TO MANAGE LANDS IN ORDER TO MEET ONE OR MORE OF THE FOLLOWING NEEDS: (1)TO PROTECT OR ENHANCE WILDLIFE SPECIES  (2) PROTECT OR ENHANCE EXISTING HABITAT CONDITIONS OR RESTORE LOST HABITATS  AND (3) PROVIDE QUALITY WILDLIFE-ORIENTED RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. PROPERLY MANAGE THE LAND, AND ENSURING THEIR AVAILABILITY FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS, AND PROVIDES BENEFITS FOR ALL CITIZENS. TO PROTECT THESE NATURAL RESOURCES, MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS AND STRATEGIES UTILIZED ON THE WENAHA WILDLIFE AREA WILL MEET OR EXCEED HABITAT PROTECTION POLICIES AND STANDARDS SET BY THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE.

THERE IS AN URGENT NEED TO PROTECT AND ENHANCE WILDLIFE HABITAT IN NORTHEAST OREGON PARTICULARLY BIG GAME WINTERRANGE AND CONSERVATION STRATEGY HABITATS. SUMMER FORAGE FOR DEER AND ELK IS ABUNDANT THROUGHOUT THE EASTERNOREGON BUT POPULATIONS OF THESE SPECIES ARE LIMITED BY AVAILABLE WINTER RANGE.OPERATION OF MINAM RIVER WILDLIFE AREA AND OTHER ODFW PROPERTIES PROTECTS BIG GAME WINTER RANGE AND CONSERVATION STRATEGY HABITATS FOR WIDE VARIETY OF INDIGENOUS WILDLIFE. WITHOUT THIS PROJECT CRITICAL WILDLIFE HABITAT INUNION AND WALLOWA COUNTIES RISKS FURTHER DIVISION AND DEVELOPMENT PERPETUATING THE DECLINE AND EROSION OFFUNCTION AND VALUETHIS GRANT FUNDS THE ANNUAL OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF THE MINAM RIVER WILDLIFE AREA AND AND FIVE OTHERSMALLER ODFW PROPERTIES (ENTERPRISE - 47 ACRES, LITTLE SHEEP - 516 ACRES, LOSTINE - 1001 ACRES, SPRING CREEK - 9ACRES, WALLOWA - 22 ACRES)IN WALLOWA COUNTY. THIS PROJECT WILL PROTECT AND ENHANCE 6,645 ACRES OF CRITICALHABITAT FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE WHILE FACILITATING PUBLIC ACCESS FOR HUNTERS, ANGLERS, WILDLIFE VIEWING, BACKPACKING AND PHOTOGRAPHY. RECENTLY EXPANDED IN 2021, THE MINAM RIVER WILDLIFE AREA: PHASE 1 PROTECTS MORE THAN 5000 ACRES OF TRADITIONAL BIG GAME WINTER RANGE IN UNION AND WALLOWA COUNTIES FROM HUMAN DEVELOPMENT, MAINTAINS AHISTORIC MIGRATION CORRIDOR AND PROVIDES CRITICAL HABITAT FOR WINTERING ELK AND DEER.

THIS GRANT FUNDS THE WORK OF COLORADO PARKS AND WILDLIFE S GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SERVICES SECTION. THE GIS UNIT PROVIDES VALUABLE MAPPING SERVICES TO NEARLY EVERY CPW UNIT, INCLUDING MAPS ON WILDLIFE HABITATS, POPULATIONS, NATURAL RESOURCES, TRAILS, FACILITIES AND PROJECT LOCATIONS. THE UNIT IS ALSO CRITICAL IN LAND USE PLANNING WORK AND ANALYSIS.

MANAGE POPULATIONS OF RESIDENT SMALL GAME (I.E., QUAIL, SQUIRREL, PHEASANT, DUSKY GROUSE) AND WILD TURKEY . COORDINATE ACTIVITIES WITH PRIVATE, STATE, AND FEDERAL CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS TO ASSURE INTEGRATION WITH OTHER DEPARTMENT PROGRAMS AND COMPLIANCE WITH STATE AND FEDERAL MANDATES. ACTIVITIES THAT SUPPORT REGULATORY, RESEARCH, AND MANAGEMENT ISSUES ON THESE SPECIES REQUIRE CONTINUOUS PARTICIPATION IN MONITORING POPULATION AND HARVEST TRENDS, ACCUMULATION AND DISTRIBUTION OF NEW RESULTS AND INFORMATION, AND DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF APPROPRIATE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE S (CDFW) NORTH CENTRAL REGION (NCR) HAS THREE STAFFED WILDLIFE AREAS THAT ARE GEOGRAPHICALLY CENTRALIZED: GRAY LODGE WILDLIFE AREA (GLWA), SPENCEVILLE WILDLIFE AREA (SWA), AND UPPER BUTTE BASIN WILDLIFE AREA (UBBWA) COMPRISING OVER 42,133 ACRES OF MANAGED WILDLIFE HABITAT. OPERATIONAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE OVERSIGHT OF THESE AREAS IS PROVIDED BY STAFF STATIONED AT GLWA AND UBBWA. THESE LANDS WERE ORIGINALLY PURCHASED BY THE WILDLIFE CONSERVATION BOARD (WCB) BETWEEN 1931 AND 1988. WHILE THE PURPOSE OF THE ACQUISITIONS HAS VARIED THROUGH THE YEARS, THE GOALS HAVE REMAINED THE SAME: CONSERVATION, RESTORATION, AND ENHANCEMENT OF HABITATS FOR WILDLIFE, WHILE PROVIDING FOR COMPATIBLE PUBLIC RECREATION SUCH AS HUNTING, FISHING, WILDLIFE VIEWING, NATURE STUDY, ETC. SUBSEQUENT ADDITIONS TO THE AREAS HAVE FOCUSED ON IMPLEMENTATION OF THE CENTRAL VALLEY HABITAT JOINT VENTURE AND PROTECTION OF SENSITIVE SPECIES AND THE HABITATS THEY DEPEND ON. WCB, ON BEHALF OF THE STATE, HAS ASSIGNED OVERALL MANAGEMENT OF THESE LANDS TO CDFW. CDFW HAS RESTORED, ENHANCED, DEVELOPED, AND MAINTAINED WETLAND, RIPARIAN, AND UPLAND HABITATS FOR MIGRATORY WATERFOWL, SHOREBIRDS, UPLAND GAME BIRDS, DEER, AND OTHER WILDLIFE SPECIES ASSOCIATED WITH THESE HABITATS. THESE LANDS WERE ASSIGNED TO CDFW TO RESTORE, ENHANCE, DEVELOP, MAINTAIN WILDLIFE HABITATS AND WHILE PROVIDING FOR COMPATIBLE PUBLIC USES.

NORTH CENTRAL REGION S (NCR) WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (WMP) PERSONNEL ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR COLLECTINGBIOLOGICAL DATA RELATED TO TERRESTRIAL WILDLIFE RESOURCES, DEVELOPING SCIENCE-BASED RECOMMENDATIONS FOR BIRD ANDMAMMAL HUNTING REGULATIONS, AND PROVIDING TECHNICAL GUIDANCE AND EXPERTISE TO OTHER CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISHAND WILDLIFE (CDFW) PROGRAMS, OTHER AGENCIES, STAKEHOLDERS, PARTNERS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC. THIS GRANT WILLALLOW FOR THE MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF BIG AND UPLAND GAME (COLLECTIVELY REFERRED TO AS GAME SPECIES) ANDTHEIR HABITATS IN SEVENTEEN NORTHERN CALIFORNIA COUNTIES.

TO INVESTIGATE AND ASSESS THE CONSERVATION STATUS OF NONGAME MAMMALS TO ENSURE THE CONTINUING RECOVERY, LISTING, DELISTING, ETC. OF NONGAME MAMMALS LISTED UNDER THE NEW MEXICO WILDLIFE CONSERVATION ACT (WCA), THE STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN, OR AS FEDERALLY ENDANGERED OR THREATENED BY THE FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE) UNDER THE U.S. ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA).

THE DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) OWNS AND OR MANAGES APPROXIMATELY 74 PROPERTIES IN THE FIVE-COUNTY SOUTH COAST REGION (R5). IN SANTA BARBARA, VENTURA, LOS ANGELES, AND ORANGE COUNTIES THERE ARE TEN PROPERTIES COMPRISING 10,379 ACRES, AND IN SAN DIEGO COUNTY, THERE ARE 64 PROPERTIES COMPRISING 54,921 ACRES. THIS PROJECT IS TO MANAGE EIGHT OF THE TEN PROPERTIES IN SANTA BARBARA, VENTURA, ORANGE, AND LOS ANGELES COUNTIES, AND ELEVEN OF THE 64 PROPERTIES IN SAN DIEGO COUNTY. THE LANDS OWNED AND MANAGED BY CDFW INCLUDE ECOLOGICAL RESERVES, WILDLIFE AREAS, PRIVATELY OWNED LANDS WITH CONSERVATION EASEMENTS, AND OTHER PUBLIC ACCESS FACILITIES. THESE PROPERTIES WERE ACQUIRED BY THE CDFW TO CONSERVE IMPORTANT SPECIES AND HABITATS. THE NINETEEN LANDS TO BE MANAGED UNDER THIS GRANT ARE SEVENTEEN ECOLOGICAL RESERVES AND TWO CURRENTLY UNDESIGNATED PROPERTIESPLANNED TO BECOME ECOLOGICAL RESERVES. THESE NINETEEN PROPERTIES ARE MANAGED BY CDFW AS AN IMPORTANT OVERALL ELEMENT OF WILDLIFE AND HABITAT CONSERVATION. THEY PROVIDE A UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY TO CONSERVE, RESTORE, AND PROTECT DECLINING SENSITIVE SPECIES AND THEIR ASSOCIATED HABITATS. THESE PROPERTIES OFFER SENSIBLE AND COMPATIBLE WILDLIFE DEPENDENT RECREATIONAL AND EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE PUBLIC AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR RESEARCH AND SCIENTIFIC STUDY. THE VALUES TO ENDEMIC AND SENSITIVE SPECIES, GAME SPECIES (DEER, WATERFOWL, UPLAND GAME) AND, IN GENERAL, ALL WILDLIFE IS HIGH AT THESE LOCATIONS. WILDLIFE DEPENDENT USES OCCUR NOW AND WILL BE CONTINUED. BMER, FOR EXAMPLE, IS ONE OF THE LARGEST REMAINING BLOCKS OF MARITIME CHAPARRAL AND BMER PROVIDES LONG-TERM PROTECTION FOR THE VALUABLE BIOLOGICAL RESOURCES FOUND THERE. CDFW AND ITS LOCAL PARTNERS HAVE IDENTIFIED SPECIES AND HABITAT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES, CONDUCTED PRIORITY MANAGEMENT ACTIONS, AND IMPLEMENTED COLLABORATIVE MONITORING AND RESEARCH PROJECTS TO IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING AND INFORM MANAGEMENT ACTIONS.
STATEWIDE PROJECT AIMED TOWARDS INCREASING PUBLIC HUNTING ACCESS TO PRIVATE LANDS IN KANSAS BY LEASING THE HUNTING RIGHTS FROM COOPERATING PRIVATE LANDOWNERS.

THE DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) HAS FIVE WILDLIFE AREAS (WAS) THAT ARE FEDERALLY FUNDED BY THE PITTMAN ROBERTSON ACT (PR) IN THE CENTRAL REGION OF CALIFORNIA. CDFW ACQUIRED LOS BANOS WILDLIFE AREA (LBWA) IN 1929, MENDOTA WILDLIFE AREA (MWA) IN 1955, COTTONWOOD CREEK WILDLIFE AREA (CCWA) IN 1979 AND NORTH GRASSLANDS WILDLIFE AREA (NGWA) IN 1990. THE VOLTA WILDLIFE AREA (VWA) IS OWNED BY THE U.S. BUREAU OF RECLAMATION AND IS MANAGED BY CDFW THROUGH A LEASE AGREEMENT INITIATED IN 1952. THREE OF THE WILDLIFE AREAS (LBWA, VWA, AND CCWA) ARE MANAGED OUT OF ONE OFFICE AND COLLECTIVELY FORM THE LOS BANOS WILDLIFE AREA COMPLEX (LBWAC). THE LANDS ARE MANAGED TO PROTECT, PRESERVE AND ENHANCE THE INTERIOR WETLANDS PRESENT ON THE AREA, AND THE SPECIES ASSOCIATED WITH THOSE VARIOUS HABITATS.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) MANAGES APPROXIMATELY 110 WILDLIFE AREAS ENCOMPASSING OVER 710,000 ACRES THROUGHOUT THE STATE. SEVERAL OF THESE AREAS RELY ON THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION PROGRAM TO SUPPORT MANAGEMENT OF WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS, AND TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR PUBLIC USE AND ENJOYMENT OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES.

THIS MAJORITY OF THIS GRANT IS A SUBAWARD TO OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY, WHO WILL SUBAWARD A PORTION TO TEXAS A M UNIVERSITY-KINGSVILLE. THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION (ODWC) WILL USE A SMALL PORTION OF THE FUNDING TO SUPPORT THE UNIVERSITIES WITH STAFF TIME. RECENT APPARENT POPULATION DECLINES ACROSS MULE DEER (ODOCOILEUS HEMIONUS) RANGE IN THE AMERICAN WEST ARE OF INTEREST TO BIOLOGISTS AND MANAGERS. MULE DEER IN OKLAHOMA ARE NEAR THE SOUTHEASTERN EXTENT OF THE SPECIES  RANGE  THUS, THEIR DISTRIBUTION IS LIMITED AND DENSITIES ARE PRESUMABLY LOW. MULE DEER POPULATIONS IN OKLAHOMA ARE RESTRICTED CURRENTLY TO AREAS THAT ARE TYPICALLY CHARACTERIZED BY EXTREME WEATHER EVENTS, HIGH VARIABILITY IN RESOURCE AVAILABILITY, AND AN INCREASING INFLUENCE OF ANTHROPOGENIC ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH AGRICULTURAL OPERATIONS AND ENERGY INFRASTRUCTURE. IN OKLAHOMA, DATA ARE LIMITED TO ANNUAL HARVEST NUMBERS, AND MULE DEER ARE HUNTED AND MANAGED UNDER WHITE-TAILED DEER (O. VIRGINIANUS) REGULATIONS. TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE DISTRIBUTION, ABUNDANCE, AND POPULATION ECOLOGY OF MULE DEER AND TO INFORM HARVEST MANAGEMENT IN WESTERN OKLAHOMA, WE ARE PROPOSING A COMPREHENSIVE RESEARCH PROJECT FROM A TEAM OF RESEARCHERS AT OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY AND TEXAS A M UNIVERSITY-KINGSVILLE WITH EXPERTISE RELATED TO THIS RESEARCH NEED. WE WILL ASSESS METHODS FOR INVESTIGATING AND MONITORING MULE DEER DISTRIBUTION AND SPATIAL VARIATION IN ABUNDANCE. WE WILL ESTIMATE SURVIVAL AND FACTORS INFLUENCING MORTALITY IN ADULT FEMALES AND FAWNS, AND WE WILL OBTAIN ESTIMATES OF FECUNDITY AND RECRUITMENT. WE WILL INVESTIGATE MOVEMENTS AND HABITAT SELECTION IN THE CONTEXT OF THE POTENTIAL EFFECTS OF ANTHROPOGENIC PRESSURES (INCLUDING AGRICULTURE AND ENERGY INFRASTRUCTURE) AND ENVIRONMENTAL VARIABILITY. ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL LEVERAGE MULE DEER DATA IN THE TEXAS PANHANDLE TO EVALUATE MOVEMENT ECOLOGY AND POPULATION DYNAMICS AT AN INTERSTATE SCALE. THIS RESEARCH WILL ASSIST ODWC IN MANAGING MULE DEER BY PROVIDING DATA TO SUPPORT DECISION-MAKING ON MONITORING, HARVEST, AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT.

THE NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE (NDOW) REPAIRS AND MAINTAINS APPROXIMATELY 1,725 EXISTING WATER DEVELOPMENTS STATEWIDE. NDOW LOCATES, CLEARS, INSTALLS, AND MAINTAINS ARTIFICIAL WATER DEVELOPMENTS AND NATURAL SPRING DEVELOPMENTS WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF VOLUNTEER SPORTSMEN ORGANIZATIONS. ARTIFICIAL AND NATURAL WATER DEVELOPMENTS ENHANCE NEVADA S WILDLIFE HABITAT WHERE WATER IS THE LIMITING FACTOR TO ESTABLISHING AND SUSTAINING WILDLIFE POPULATIONS. ARTIFICIAL AND NATURAL WATER DEVELOPMENTS ARE ESSENTIAL TO WILDLIFE POPULATIONS, ESPECIALLY DURINGPERIODS OF DROUGHT. ARTIFICIAL WATER DEVELOPMENTS ARE NEEDED TO EXPAND AND SUSTAIN GAME AND NON-GAME WILDLIFESPECIES WHEN NATURAL WATER SOURCES ARE INSUFFICIENT, DEGRADED, OR LOST AND NO LONGER PROVIDE AN ADEQUATE WATERSOURCE FOR WILDLIFE. NATURAL WATER DEVELOPMENTS INCLUDE PROTECTION AND RESTORATION OF NATURAL SPRINGS, SEEPS, ANDOTHER WATER SOURCES. THESE DEVELOPMENTS ENSURE NATURAL WATER SOURCES ARE AVAILABLE TO SUSTAIN WILDLIFEPOPULATIONS AND PROVIDE CRUCIAL HABITAT TYPES FOR MANY SPECIES. THIS PROJECT WILL BUILD, REBUILD, OR COMPLETEMAJOR MAINTENANCE ON TEN ARTIFICIAL WATER DEVELOPMENTS AND FIVE NATURAL SPRING PROTECTION PROJECTS DURING THEGRANT PERIOD. ADDITIONALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL CONDUCT AERIAL AND GROUND INSPECTIONS, AND COMPLETE MINORMAINTENANCE WHERE NEEDED, ON 435 ARTIFICIAL WATER DEVELOPMENTS OR NATURAL SPRING PROJECTION PROJECTS. AS A RESULTOF THIS WORK, EXISTING WILDLIFE POPULATIONS WILL CONTINUE TO BENEFIT FROM DEPENDABLE WATER SOURCES.

THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF NEVADA S HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM IS TO EDUCATE NEW HUNTERS IN FIREARMS SAFETY, ETHICS, REGULATIONS, AND GAME CARE WHICH WILL MAKE THEM SAFER AND MORE RESPONSIBLE WHEN GOING AFIELD. IN ADDITION TO PROVIDING THE ACCOMPANYING SUPPORT AND TRAINING TO MAINTAIN A CADRE OF 200-300 DIVERSE, TRAINED, KNOWLEDGEABLE, MOTIVATED VOLUNTEER HUNTER EDUCATION INSTRUCTORS STATEWIDE. THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF NDOW S PITTMAN-ROBERTSON MODERNIZATION PROGRAM IS TO PROMOTE SAFE HUNTING AND RECREATIONAL SHOOTING. ENHANCED HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAMMING INCLUDES NDOW S ARCHERY EDUCATION PROGRAMS, NATIONAL ARCHERY IN THE SCHOOLS PROGRAM (NASP) AND VARIOUS SPECIES SPECIFIC AND HUNTING TECHNIQUES WORKSHOPS. PROGRAMMING IS DESIGNED TO EDUCATE BOTH NEW AND EXISTING HUNTERS SHOOTERS ON ADDITIONAL HUNTING AND SHOOTING OPPORTUNITIES TO BECOME PROFICIENT IN VARIOUS SHOOTING SPORTS, HUNTING TECHNIQUES AND SKILLS. THE STATE CONTINUES TO HAVE A NEED FOR MORE QUALITY, CLEAN, FAMILY FRIENDLY PUBLIC SHOOTING RANGES. WITH THE EXPANSION AND FACILITY IMPROVEMENTS OF EXISTING PUBLIC RANGES AND THE POSSIBILITY OF OPENING NEW PUBLIC RANGES WE HOPE TO SEE AN INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF LIVE FIRE OPPORTUNITIES IN OUR HUNTER EDUCATION CLASSES AND INCREASED PARTICIPATION IN SHOOTING SPORTS AND TARGET SHOOTING IN GENERAL. THE FEDERAL FUNDING FOR THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED AS A SUPPLEMENT FOR PUBLIC SHOOTING RANGE RELATED IMPROVEMENTS THAT WILL BENEFIT THE HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM. IT WILL ALSO INCREASE SHOOTING OPPORTUNITIES FOR HUNTERS AND SHOOTERS IN GENERAL.

SINCE THE ENACTMENT OF THE NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY ACT IN 1969, STATE GAME AND FISH AGENCIES ACROSSTHE NATION ARE LEGALLY REQUIRED TO CONDUCT ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEWS ON DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS THAT HAVE A FEDERALNEXUS (I.E. A PROJECT THAT IS FUNDED WITH FEDERAL MONEY OR OCCURS ON FEDERAL LAND). THE REVIEWS ARE REQUIRED INORDER TO RECEIVE A PERMIT FROM A REGULATORY AGENCY OR FUNDING FOR POSSIBLE CONSTRUCTION. THE NORTH DAKOTA GAMEAND FISH DEPARTMENT S COORDINATION AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAM IS CARRIED OUT BY A SMALL WORK UNIT (I.E.CONSERVATION SECTION) WITHIN THE AGENCY THAT CONDUCTS THE MAJORITY OF THE WORK ASSOCIATED WITH ENVIRONMENTALREVIEW. THE CONSERVATION SECTION HAS 3 FULL TIME STAFF BIOLOGISTS WHO CARRY OUT THE DAY-TO-DAY ACTIVITIESASSOCIATED WITH THIS PROGRAM. EACH YEAR, THE CONSERVATION SECTION RECEIVES ROUGHLY 500-600 PROJECTS ORSOLICITATIONS OF THIS NATURE. BASED ON INFORMATION PROVIDED BY PROJECT PROPONENTS, STAFF CONDUCT A DESK TOPLEVEL REVIEW OF THE PROPOSED PROJECTS FOR POTENTIAL IMPACTS TO FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES IN THE IMMEDIATEVICINITY OF WHERE THE PROJECT. IF ADDITIONAL INFORMATION IS REQUIRED, STAFF MAY INTERACT WITH THE PROJECTPROPONENTS OR STATE, FEDERAL AND LOCAL RESOURCE EXPERTS. REVIEWS FOR THE VAST MAJORITY OF PROJECTS ARE CONDUCTEDWITHIN 2-4 WEEKS OF RECEIVING A SOLICITATION, WITH MOST PROJECTS HAVING MINIMAL IMPACTS. THE PROJECT PROPONENTSARE ROUTINELY PROVIDED A BRIEF SYNOPSIS OF THE PROJECTS MINIMAL IMPACT DETERMINATION VIA FORMAL LETTER, EMAIL ORFAX. IN INSTANCES WHERE IT IS DETERMINED THAT A PROJECT WILL IMPART LARGER OR MORE SUBSTANTIAL IMPACTS, STAFFWILL WORK WITH PROJECT PROPONENTS TO LESSEN OR MINIMIZE AFFECTS BY SUGGESTING ALTERNATIVE CONSTRUCTION MEASURES,TECHNIQUES, TIME FRAMES OR OFFSETS. THIS MAY REQUIRE ON SITE VISITS, IN PERSON MEETINGS, PHONE CALLS OR MEETINGSWITH OTHER NATURAL RESOURCE AGENCIES.

THIS PROJECT FUNDS ALL ANNUAL LAND USE PLANNING ACTIVITIES INCLUDING PROVIDING COMMENTS, ADVICE, INFORMATION AND RECOMMENDATIONS ON HABITAT ISSUES TO LAND USE PLANNERS AND LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES, DEVELOPERS AND CITIZENS TO PROTECT AND PRESERVE WILDLIFE HABITAT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO MANAGE STATEWIDE WILDLIFE POPULATIONS TO DESIRED LEVELS IN ACCORDANCE WITH ECOLOGICAL AND SOCIAL TOLERANCES THROUGH WILDLIFE PROGRAM ADMINISTRATION, PLANNING, IMPLEMENTATION, AND EVALUATION  ASSISTING LANDOWNERS TO ENHANCE ACCESS AND HABITAT ON THEIR LANDS  AND OPERATION, MAINTENANCE AND EVALUATION ON WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS AND WILDLIFE HABITAT PROTECTION AREAS AND EASEMENTS.

THIS GRANT WILL ALLOW THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE (ODWC) TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR OKLAHOMA RESIDENTS AND VISITORS INTERESTED IN PARTICIPATING IN OUTDOOR ACTIVITIES OR ENJOYING OKLAHOMA S NATURAL RESOURCES ON LAND NOT OWNED FEE-TITLE BY ODWC AND PROVIDE GUIDANCE AND INCENTIVES FOR OKLAHOMA LANDOWNERS TO ALLOW ACCESS TO THEIR PROPERTIES FOR HUNTING, ANGLING, AND OTHER WILDLIFE DEPENDENT RECREATION AND INCENTIVIZE HABITAT MANAGEMENT FOR THE BENEFIT OF OKLAHOMA WILDLIFE. THE OKLAHOMA LAND ACCESS PROGRAM IS A VITAL TOOL FOR THE ODWC TO CONTINUE TO PROVIDE HUNTING, TRAPPING, FISHING AND WILDLIFE VIEWING OPPORTUNITIES TO PEOPLE CURRENTLY INVOLVED OR THOSE INTERESTED IN BECOMING INVOLVED. IN VARIOUS HUNTER SURVEYS, ACCESS OR CROWDING HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS A SIGNIFICANT DETRACTANT OR DETERRENT TO PARTICIPATION. ADDITIONALLY, LANDOWNERS HAVE IDENTIFIED THE INCENTIVES PROVIDED WITHIN AGREEMENTS WITH STATE ACCESS PROGRAMS AS A MAJOR FACTOR IN DECIDING TO OPEN THEIR LAND TO PUBLIC ACCESS. THIS GRANT WILL BENEFIT OUTDOORS PERSONS BY INCREASING AND IMPROVING THEIR OPPORTUNITIES TO FOLLOW THEIR OUTDOOR PURSUITS. THIS GRANT WILL BENEFIT OKLAHOMA LANDOWNERS BY PROVIDING ECONOMIC INCENTIVES, FEEDBACK OR INPUT ON HABITAT MANAGEMENT FROM WILDLIFE PROFESSIONALS, LIMITED LIABILITY PROTECTIONS, AND GENERALLY INCREASED LAW ENFORCEMENT ACCESSIBILITY. THIS GRANT WILL BENEFIT ODWC BY PROVIDING ADDITIONAL OPPORTUNITIES TO REACH NEW CONSTITUENTS, BOTH IN TRADITIONAL USER GROUPS THROUGH R3 EFFORTS AND IN A NEW USER GROUP OF LANDOWNERS THAT MAY NOT OTHERWISE CONSIDER WILDLIFE OR OUTDOOR ISSUES. AND THIS GRANT WILL BENEFIT OKLAHOMA WILDLIFE BY HELPING SHIFT LANDOWNER MINDSETS TO VIEW WILDLIFE AND WILDLIFE HABITAT AS A POSITIVE, AND THUS MAINTAIN OR INCREASE THE TYPES OF WILDLIFE-FRIENDLY PRACTICES THAT A LANDOWNER MAY CONDUCT. OBJECTIVES INCLUDE 1) USE LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR PUBLIC HUNTING, FISHING AND OTHER WILDLIFE-ASSOCIATED RECREATION AND 2) USE LANDOWNER AGREEMENTS TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR PUBLIC STREAM ACCESS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE TO BUILD THE ILLINOIS DNR OWNED MANAGED AND LEASED PROPERTY DATABASE. THESE ENHANCEMENTS AND UPDATES WILL PROVIDE IDNR WITH THE MOST ACCURATE INFORMATION THAT STAFF CAN USE FOR MANAGING HUNTING, TRAPPING, AND OTHER RELATED RECREATION  FOR EDUCATION  AND FOR ENHANCEMENT AND MANAGEMENT OF BIRDS, MAMMALS, AND OTHER CRITICAL SPECIES ON IDNR PROPERTIES ACROSS ILLINOIS. UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS URBANA CHAMPAIGN IS AN EXPECTED SUBGRANTEE OF THIS PROJECT.

MIGRATORY GAME BIRDS (I.E., WATERFOWL, DOVE, SANDHILL CRANE   ANTIGONE CANADENSIS , AND BAND-TAILED PIGEON  PATAGIOENAS FASCIATA ) ARE IMPORTANT BIOLOGICAL, RECREATIONAL, AND ECONOMIC RESOURCES IN NEW MEXICO AS WELL AS THROUGHOUT NORTH AMERICA. IT IS IMPORTANT THAT ANY ACTIVITY (E.G., HUNTING, HABITAT MANIPULATION, VIEWING, ETC.) ASSOCIATED WITH THESE SPECIES USE SOUND BIOLOGICAL INFORMATION TO INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS IN ORDER TO MINIMIZE ANY POTENTIAL ASSOCIATED DETRIMENTAL EFFECTS. BECAUSE OF THEIR MIGRATORY NATURE, COORDINATION OF ACTIVITIES WITH PRIVATE, STATE, AND FEDERAL CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS IS NECESSARY. TO MANAGE MIGRATORY GAME BIRD RESOURCES AND THEIR ASSOCIATED HABITATS SUCH THAT VIABLE POPULATION LEVELS ARE MAINTAINED FORTHEIR RECREATIONAL, EDUCATIONAL, SCIENTIFIC, AND INTRINSIC VALUE.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) MANAGES APPROXIMATELY 150,000 ACRES OF WILDLIFE AREAS ANDECOLOGICAL RESERVES WITHIN THE BAY DELTA REGION (BDR). APPROXIMATELY 90,000 ACRES ARE DESIGNATED AS UNSTAFFEDLANDS. THESE LANDS PROVIDE HABITAT TO ELK, DEER, QUAIL, RABBITS, BEAR, DOVES, BAND-TAIL PIGEONS, TURKEYS, NONGAMESPECIES, AND SPECIAL STATUS SPECIES. THEY ARE MANAGED TO CONSERVE THEIR INHERENT ECOLOGICAL VALUES AND TOPROVIDE HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE PUBLIC FOR GAME SPECIES.

THIS GRANT IS APPLICABLE TO THE ODFW SOUTH WILLAMETTE WATERSHED DISTRICT (SWWD) WHICH COMPRISES ALL OR PORTIONSOF LANE, LINN, BENTON, MARION, POLK, LINCOLN AND YAMHILL COUNTIES. THE DISTRICT IS COMPRISED OF MULTIPLELANDSCAPES, VARYING IN SIZE AND TOPOGRAPHY THAT ARE OWNED AND MANAGED BY BOTH PRIVATE AND PUBLIC INTERESTS. ODFW TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE IS PROVIDED BY THE GRANT TO PROTECT, ENHANCE AND OR RESTORE HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE ONAPPROXIMATELY 2,500 ACRES OF LAND HOLDINGS. EE WILSON (1,800 AC), JUNCTION CITY POND (25 AC), COURTNEY CREEK WA(75 AC), MILLERS RIVERSIDE WA (411 AC) AND TAMI WAGNER WILDLIFE AREAS (141 AC) ARE PARTIALLY MANAGED UNDER THISPROGRAM BY THE ODFW. THE SWWD HABITAT PROGRAM IS ADMINISTERED BY STAFF STATIONED AT THE DISTRICT OFFICE (ADAIRVILLAGE) AND RESPONSIBLE FOR THE PROJECTS IMPLEMENTATION.THE FOCUS OF THIS GRANT IS TO SUPPORT ACTIVITIES ON SEVEN ODFW OWNED WILDLIFE AREAS. ADDITIONALLY WE WILLCONTINUE TO SUPPORT SEVERAL SMALL ODFW OWNED PARCELS THAT ARE EITHER UNMANAGED OR UNMANNED. AS TIME AND WORKLOADS ALLOW WE WILL DEVELOP PROJECTS ON PRIVATE LANDS THAT ARE ENROLLED IN ODFWS ACCESS AND HABITAT PROGRAM (A H).  THE FOCUS OF THESE PROJECTS WILL BE TO ENHANCE DEER AND ELK POPULATIONS IN AREAS ACCESSIBLE BY HUNTERS AND OR IN AREAS WHERE THE POPULATIONS OF TARGET SPECIES ARE BELOW POPULATION OBJECTIVE. OPPORTUNISTICALLY, WE WILL SUPPORT FWS ON PRIVATE LAND MANAGEMENT AND RESTORATION PROJECTS IN THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY. PROJECTS CONTRIBUTE TO THE LONG-TERM PROTECTION AND RECOVERY OF WETLAND, WET PRAIRIE, UPLAND AND WOODLAND HABITATS ACROSS THE WEST REGION. RENOVATION OF THESE IMPORTANT HABITATS CONTRIBUTES TO THE SUSTAINABILITY OF MANY DIVERSE SENSITIVE, GAME AND NONGAME WILDLIFE SPECIES FOUND WITHIN THE ECO-REGION.

THE KEN DENMAN WILDLIFE AREA (DWA) WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1954 WHEN 1,760 ACRES OF THE FORMER CAMP WHITE MILITARYRESERVATION WAS CONVEYED TO THE OREGON GAME COMMISSION FROM THE UNITED STATES GENERAL SERVICES ADMINISTRATION.THIS CONVEYANCE OCCURRED VIA A RESTRICTIVE DEED SPECIFYING THAT THE LAND BE USED FOR THE PURPOSE OF WILDLIFECONSERVATION. OTHER LAND ACQUISITIONS SINCE THAT TIME HAVE INCREASED THE SIZE OF THE WILDLIFE AREA TO 1,858ACRES.THERE IS A NEED TO PROVIDE, PROTECT AND MAINTAIN WILDLIFE HABITAT IN THE HEAVILY DEVELOPED ROGUE VALLEY IN SWOREGON. THE DWA CONTAINS MANY DIFFERENT TYPES OF HABITATS SUPPORTING A GREAT DIVERSITY OF PLANT AND ANIMALSPECIES. IMPORTANT HABITATS INCLUDE VERNAL POOLS, PRAIRIE GRASSLANDS, OAK WOODLAND SAVANNAHS, RIPARIAN HABITATAND WETLANDS.A MAJOR FUNCTION OF THE WILDLIFE AREAS MANAGEMENT IS TO PROVIDE WATERFOWL, UPLAND BIRD AND DEER HUNTINGOPPORTUNITIES. FISHING, HIKING, BIRDING AND HUNTING-DOG TRAINING ARE SOME OF THE OTHER RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIESAVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC. THE AREA IS ALSO AN IMPORTANT RESOURCE FOR OUTDOOR EDUCATION.AS NEIGHBORING LAND CONTINUES TO BE DEVELOPED, THE WILDLIFE HABITAT AND OPEN SPACE PROVIDED ON THE DWA HAVEBECOME AN INCREASINGLY IMPORTANT AND VALUABLE PUBLIC RESOURCE.

THE ROGUE WATERSHED HABITAT PROGRAM IS MANAGED FROM THE ROGUE WATERSHED DISTRICT OFFICE IN CENTRAL POINT BY ONE WILDLIFE HABITAT BIOLOGIST. THE BIOLOGIST ALSO ACTS AS THE SW REGION A H COORDINATOR AND OVERSEES APPROXIMATELY 5 A H PROJECTS INCLUDING 2 COOPERATIVE TRAVEL MANAGEMENT AREAS. THE ROGUE WATERSHED INCLUDES JACKSON, JOSEPHINE, AND CURRY COUNTIES. THE ROGUE WATERSHED DISTRICT IS COMPOSED OF LAND OWNED AND OR MANAGED BY VARIOUS ENTITIES, WHICH VARY IN SIZE, LOCATION AND TOPOGRAPHY. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ENHANCE WILDLIFE HABITAT BY ASSISTING OTHER GOVERNMENT AGENCIES AND PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IN DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING HABITAT IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS. THIS WORK IS DONE IN COLLABORATION WITH SPORTING ORGANIZATIONS AND EDUCATIONAL GROUPS. HABITAT IMPROVEMENTS FALL BROADLY INTO TWO CATEGORIES  RESTORATION OF NATURAL HABITATS, AND IMPROVEMENT OF MAN-MADE HABITATS. IN THE ROGUE WATERSHED, PRIMARY CAUSES OF DEGRADATION OF NATURAL HABITATS ARE FIRE SUPPRESSION, HUMAN DEVELOPMENT, AND INTRODUCTION OF NON-NATIVE PLANTS, WHICH ARE IDENTIFIED AS KEY CONSERVATION ISSUES IN THE OREGON CONSERVATION STRATEGY (OREGONS STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN). FIRE IS A NATURAL PART OF THIS ECOSYSTEM, AND FIRE SUPPRESSION HAS LED TO SHRUB COMMUNITIES BECOMING DECADENT, OAK WOODLANDS BEING INVADED BY CONIFERS, LOSS OF NATURAL OPENINGS AND MEADOWS, REDUCTION OF NATIVE PLANT SPECIES, AND LESS EARLY SERAL STAGE VEGETATION.

THERE IS A NEED TO IMPROVE, MAINTAIN AND RESTORE WILDLIFE HABITAT IN KLAMATH AND LAKE COUNTIES. WILDLIFE HABITATQUALITY IN OREGON HAS BEEN DEGRADED AND FRAGMENTED AS A RESULT OF DEVELOPMENT, AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES, TIMBERHARVEST, AND ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH INCREASES IN THE HUMAN POPULATION (OREGON CONSERVATION STRATEGY 2016).THE KLAMATH WATERSHED DISTRICT LANDS ARE MADE UP OF MULTIPLE PARCELS OF LAND OWNED AND OR MANAGED BY VARIOUSENTITIES, AND VARY IN SIZE, LOCATION AND TOPOGRAPHY. ODFW MANAGEMENT ACTIVITY IS REQUIRED TO PROTECT, ENHANCE ANDRESTORE HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE SPECIES IN THE DISTRICT. IN 2008, HUNTERS AND NON-CONSUMPTIVE WILDLIFE USERS SPENTOVER  24 MILLION PURSUING WILDLIFE ON LANDS ADMINISTERED UNDER THIS PROGRAM. TECHNICAL ADVICE IS REQUIRED TO HELPCOORDINATE CONSERVATION EFFORTS ACROSS MANY LANDOWNERS, LOCAL, STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES. IF NOTHING WAS DONEHABITAT QUALITY WOULD CONTINUE TO DEGRADE, CONSERVATION EFFORTS WOULD BE FRAGMENTED AND WILDLIFE RELATEDRECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES WOULD BE DIMINISHED.THE STATEWIDE HABITAT PROGRAM IS ONE OF FOUR PRINCIPLE PROGRAMS WITHIN THE WILDLIFE DIVISION OF THE AGENCY.PROGRAM OBJECTIVES ARE TO PROTECT, MAINTAIN, AND ENHANCE WILDLIFE HABITAT TO MEET OREGONS WILDLIFE POLICY BY: 1)MANIPULATING HABITAT, 2) ACQUIRING LAND, 3) DEVELOPING HABITAT MANAGEMENT AND RESTORATION TECHNIQUES, 4)PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO STATE, FEDERAL, TRIBAL, AND LOCAL AGENCIES AND INDIVIDUALS. THE PURPOSE OF THISGRANT IS TO IMPLEMENT THE OBJECTIVES OF THE STATEWIDE PROGRAM WITHIN THE KLAMATH WATERSHED DISTRICT. SPECIFICACTIVITIES INCLUDE PROVIDING WILDLIFE WATER IN XERIC HABITATS, CONTROLLING INVASIVE SPECIES, ASPEN GROVE FENCING,AND OTHER ACTIVITIES TO MAINTAIN HABITAT QUALITY AND WORKING WITH LANDOWNERS AND LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES TOPROTECT OR ENHANCE WILDLIFE HABITAT QUALITY.THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO PROTECT OR ENHANCE HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE WITHIN THE KLAMATH WATERSHED DISTRICT.MAINTAIN AND ENHANCE WILDLIFE HABITATS IN THE KLAMATH WATERSHED ON STATE, FEDERAL AND PRIVATE LANDS BY ASSISTINGOTHER GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND INVOLVING SPORTING ORGANIZATIONS AND EDUCATIONAL GROUPS INHABITAT IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS.REVIEWING AND COMMENTING ON LAND USE ACTIVITIES AND MONITOR WILDLIFE POPULATIONS.

THE MK NATURE CENTER IS LOCATED IN BOISE, ID, AND PROVIDES WILDLIFE VIEWING AND OUTREACH OPPORTUNITIES FOR SCHOOLS, COMMUNITY GROUPS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC IN BOTH NATURAL OUTDOOR AND INDOOR DISPLAY-ORIENTED SETTINGS. PROGRAMMING FOCUSES ON WILDLIFE AND THEIR ADAPTATIONS  WILDLIFE HABITAT AND MANAGEMENT  AND WILDLIFE-RELATED RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES.

THE GRANT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE ADMINISTRATION AND COORDINATION OF WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION(WSFR) FUNDED PROJECTS IN IDAHO. GRANTS INCLUDE STATEWIDE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT, WHICH INCLUDESPROJECT STATEMENTS FOR STATEWIDE WILDLIFE RESEARCH, STATEWIDE WILDLIFE SURVEYS AND INVENTORIES,STATEWIDE HABITAT MANAGEMENT, STATEWIDE WILDLIFE HEALTH PROGRAM  STATEWIDE FISH AND WILDLIFETECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, STATEWIDE HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAMS, MK NATURE CENTER, LARGE TRACTS PUBLICACCESS, IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF LANDS PUBLIC ACCESS, AND HABITAT PROGRAM INFRASTRUCTURE.

HAWAIIS GAME MANAGEMENT PROGRAM PROVIDES OPPORTUNITIES FOR RECREATIONAL HUNTING OF 15 SPP. OF GAME BIRDS AND SIX SPP. OF GAME MAMMALS. HOWEVER, GAME SPECIES CURRENTLY HUNTED IN HAWAII ARE NOT NATIVE, AND GAME MAMMAL SPECIES IN PARTICULAR MAY HAVE NEGATIVE IMPACTS ON SENSITIVE NATIVE SPECIES AND ECOSYSTEMS. FEDERAL LAW PRECLUDES THE USE OF FEDERAL FUNDS IN A MANNER THAT JEOPARDIZES THE CONTINUED EXISTENCE OF LISTED, PROPOSED, OR CANDIDATE THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES. BECAUSE A LARGE PERCENTAGE OF HAWAII S GAME PROGRAM IS FUNDED BY THE FEDERAL WILDLIFE RESTORATION PROGRAM (PITTMAN ROBERTSON OR PR PROGRAM), GAME MANAGEMENT DECISIONS MADE FOR THIS PROGRAM GREATLY INFLUENCE MANAGEMENT POLICY FOR PUBLIC HUNTING AREAS IN GENERAL. MAINTAINING A RECREATIONAL PUBLIC HUNTING PROGRAM THAT DOES NOT THREATEN THE PERSISTENCE OF NATIVE SPECIES AND ECOSYSTEMS IN HAWAII IS A COMPLEX ENDEAVOR. PUBLIC HUNTING CAN PROVIDE A USEFUL TOOL IN CONTROLLING GAME MAMMALS ON PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS WHERE CONTROL IS NEEDED, AND FUNDS ARE SCARCE. THE HAWAII DIVISION OF FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE (DOFAW) PUBLIC HUNTING PROGRAM SUPPORTS AND FACILITATES HUNTING ON PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS BY PROVIDING A STRUCTURED PROGRAM THAT PROMOTES AND ENCOURAGES PARTICIPATION. THE PROGRAM AIMS TO DIRECT HUNTING TOWARD LESS ECOLOGICALLY SENSITIVE AREAS, WHILE AT THE SAME PROVIDING STRUCTURED HUNTER ACCESS TO MORE REMOTE PRISTINE SITES WHERE RECREATIONAL HUNTING CAN HELP TO CONTROL GAME MAMMAL POPULATIONS. HAWAII S GAME MANAGEMENT PROGRAM WILL FUND PROJECTS FOR MONITORING HUNTER ACTIVITIES AND GAME SPECIES POPULATION STATUS, LAND LEASES TO PROVIDE ADDITIONAL AREAS FOR PUBLIC HUNTING, GAME HABITAT IMPROVEMENT, GAME POPULATION MANAGEMENT IN SUITABLE HABITATS THROUGH CONTROL OF ALIEN PREDATORS, FACILITY AND INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT, AND PROJECTS THAT WILL AID IN DATA GATHERING AND ANALYSIS. THESE AND OTHER ACTIVITIES ARE ALL AIMED AT MAXIMIZING HUNTER RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES AND STAFF EFFICIENCY, WITHIN BUDGETARY CONSTRAINTS, IN CONJUNCTION WITH OTHER DOFAW MANDATES, AND IN COMPLIANCE WITH RELEVANT STATE AND FEDERAL LAWS AND REGULATIONS. PROJECT STATEMENTS AND A  SCHEDULE OF FUNDED PROJECTS  WHICH PROVIDE SPECIFICS ON PLANNED MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES AND EXPENDITURES ARE PROVIDED IN THE FOLLOWING SECTIONS

THE WEST VIRGINIA DIVISION OF NATURA  RESOURCES WILDLIFE RESOURCES SECTION IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE MANAGEMENT. AND CONSERVATION OF OUR STATE S WILDLIFE  RESOURCES AND FOR PROVIDING WILDLIFE ASSOCIATED RECREATION FOR THE CITIZENS OF OUR STATE. RIVER OTTER POPULATIONS HAVE REBOUNDED FROM A LOW  IN THE 1970 S TO A THRIVING POPU ATION TODAY SUPPORTING A HARVEST OF 80-100 ANIMALS STATEWIDE. NUMEROUS TRAPPERS AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC HAVE MADE REQUESTS TO HAVE THE TRAPPING SEASON LIBERALIZED. HOWEVER, THE WRS HAS BEEN RELUCTANT TO SUPPORT THESE PROPOSALS WITHOUT THE PROPER DATA TO ENSURE THE PROPER MANAGEMENT OF THE SPECIES.

PROVIDE REQUIRED HUNTER EDUCATION TRAININGS AS WELL AS RECRUIT NEW HUNTERS THROUGH THE DELIVERY OF EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS THAT INCREASE WILDLIFE CONSERVATION MANAGEMENT AWARENESS AND SHOOTING SPORTS INVOLVEMENT.2. BASED ON PRIOR YEAR HARVEST DATA, 200,000  DEER,10,000  TURKEY, 75  ELK, AND 400  BEARS HARVEST REPORTS ARE ANTICIPATED.OBJECTIVES:OBJECTIVE 1: RECORD 200,000 DEER HARVESTS BY JUNE 30, 2024OBJECTIVE 2: RECORD 10,000 TURKEY HARVESTS BY JUNE 30, 2024OBJECTIVE 3: RECORD 75 ELK HARVESTS BY JUNE 30, 2024OBJECTIVE 4: RECORD 400 BEAR HARVESTS BY JUNE 30, 2024EXPECTED OUTCOMES:COLLECTING DEER, BEAR, ELK, AND TURKEY HARVEST DATA BY USING THE GAME CHECK SYSTEM WILL PROVIDE MORE TIMELY AND ACCURATE INFORMATION. THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES ISSUES ASSOCIATED WITH MULE DEER POPULATION DYNAMICS AND COMPETITION WITH ELK. MULE DEERHAVE HIGH RECREATIONAL, AESTHETIC, ECOLOGICAL, AND ECONOMIC VALUES IN OREGON AND THE WESTERN UNITED STATES.EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT OF MULE DEER REQUIRES AN UNDERSTANDING OF BASIC POPULATION METRICS SUCH AS SURVIVAL ANDRECRUITMENT OF FAWNS INTO ADULT AGE CLASSES AND FACTORS THAT INFLUENCE THOSE METRICS. THIS RESEARCH PROJECT WILLESTIMATE MULE DEER POPULATION METRICS INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, PREGNANCY RATES, FAWN SURVIVAL, AND DOESURVIVAL. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS RESEARCH ARE TO DETERMINE: 1) THE EFFECTS OF COMPETITION WITH ELK AND 2) WINTERNUTRITION ON MULE DEER POPULATION DYNAMICS.THIS RESEARCH WILL OCCUR IN TWO PHASES. DURING PHASE I (2013-2019), WE COLLECTED BASELINE POPULATION DATA (E.G.,BODY CONDITION, PREGNANCY, AND SURVIVAL) ON MULE DEER. WE WILL ENTER OUR TENTH YEAR OF COLLARING MULE DEERDURING WINTER 2023-2024. DURING PHASE II (WHICH BEGAN IN 2020), WE REDUCED THE ELK POPULATION IN THE STARKEYEXPERIMENTAL FOREST AND RANGE BY  85  TO DETERMINE IF MULE DEER RESPOND POSITIVELY TO REDUCTIONS IN ELK DENSITY.WE REDUCED THE ELK POPULATION DURING WINTER OF 2019 2020 BY APPROXIMATELY 50  AND ACHIEVED AN  85  REDUCTIONDURING THE WINTER OF 2020 2021. FOLLOWING ADDITIONAL DATA COLLECTION DURING YEARS WITH LOW ELK DENSITIES, WEWILL COMPARE PREGNANCY RATES, FAWN SURVIVAL, AND DOE SURVIVAL BEFORE AND AFTER A REDUCTION IN ELK POPULATIONS.ANY INCREASE IN MULE DEER POPULATION PERFORMANCE FOLLOWING REDUCTIONS IN ELK POPULATIONS, WILL PROVIDE COMPELLINGEVIDENCE THAT MULE DEER POPULATION GROWTH IS LIMITED BY COMPETITION WITH ELK.OUR RESEARCH IS ALSO DESIGNED TO DETERMINE THE EFFECTS OF WINTER NUTRITION ON MULE DEER POPULATION DYNAMICS.MULE DEER THAT VOLUNTARILY ENTER THE WINTER HANDLING FACILITIES AT THE STARKEY EXPERIMENTAL FOREST AND RANGE AREPROVIDED SUPPLEMENTAL FEED DURING WINTER. DEER THAT OVERWINTER IN MAIN STUDY AREA WILL NOT RECEIVE SUPPLEMENTALFEED. WE WILL COMPARE PREGNANCY RATES, FAWN SURVIVAL, AND ADULT SURVIVAL OF THESE TWO GROUPS TO DETERMINE IFWINTER FORAGE AND NUTRITION IS LIMITING MULE DEER POPULATION DYNAMICS. IF THIS LIMITATION IS OBSERVED, IT WILLSUGGEST WINTER FORAGE CONDITIONS ARE NOT SUFFICIENT TO MEET THE ENERGETIC DEMANDS OF MULE DEER.

THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION PROGRAM WAS INITIATED IN 1937 UNDER THE PITTMAN-ROBERTSON ACT TO PROVIDE FEDERAL FUNDINGTO STATES FOR THE BENEFIT OF A DIVERSE ARRAY OF WILDLIFE AND ASSOCIATED HABITATS. THIS GRANT FUNDS THE ANNUALOPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF THE LADD MARSH WILDLIFE AREA (LMWA).THE LADD MARSH WILDLIFE AREA IS LOCATED IN THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE GRANDE RONDE VALLEY, ABOUT 7 MILES SOUTHOF LA GRANDE, OREGON. IT LIES AT ABOUT 2800 FEET AND IS JUST OVER 6,000 ACRES IN SIZE. THE AREA HARBORS SOME OFTHE FEW REMAINING AREAS OF UNDISTURBED, NATIVE VALLEY FLOOR VEGETATION AND CONSTITUTES THE LARGEST REMAININGWETLAND IN NORTHEAST OREGON.LADD MARSH WILDLIFE AREA IS COMPRISED OF A VARIETY OF BOTH UPLAND AND WETLAND HABITATS INCLUDING CONIFER FOREST,UPLAND SHRUB, GRASSLAND, WET MEADOW AND SEASONAL EMERGENT WETLAND. THIS HABITAT DIVERSITY CONTRIBUTES TO THEWIDE ARRAY OF PLANT AND ANIMAL SPECIES FOUND ON THE AREA.THE OBJECTIVES FOR THE AREA ARE TO PROTECT, ENHANCE AND MANAGE WILDLIFE HABITATS TO BENEFIT FISH AND WILDLIFESPECIES AND TO PROVIDE A VARIETY OF WILDLIFE ORIENTED RECREATIONAL AND EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES TO THE PUBLIC.THE AREA SUPPORTS WILDLIFE ORIENTED RECREATION AND EDUCATION INCLUDING HUNTING, VIEWING, HIKING, AND PHOTOGRAPHY.
CPW ENERGY LIAISONS IN EACH OF THE FOUR REGIONS IN COLORADO WILL WORK WITH ENERGY COMPANIES TO LIMIT NEGATIVE IMPACTS TO COLORADO WILDLIFE RESOURCES.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) MANAGES POPULATIONS OF WILDLIFE THROUGHOUT THE STATE ACROSSA DIVERSE RANGE OF HABITATS, ENGAGES THE PUBLIC THROUGH OUTREACH, AND PROVIDES TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND EXPERTISEREGARDING RESOURCE ISSUES. MANAGEMENT OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES INCLUDES ASSESSMENT OF WILDLIFE POPULATIONS ANDHABITATS, AND CONSERVATION OF GAME AND NONGAME BIRDS AND MAMMALS. THE INLAND DESERT REGION S WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (IDRWP) IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS OF DATA REGARDING THE CONDITION OF WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND HABITATS, MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF GAME BIRDS AND MAMMALS, PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO OTHER AGENCIES REGARDING RESOURCE ISSUES, AND PUBLIC OUTREACH IN THE FOLLOWING FIVE COUNTIES: IMPERIAL, INYO, MONO, RIVERSIDE, AND SAN BERNARDINO.THESE RESPONSIBILITIES REPRESENT ACTIVITIES THAT COMPLEMENT OTHER REGIONS AND HEADQUARTERS ACTIVITIES, BUT DO NOTDUPLICATE OTHER CDFW ACTIVITIES SUPPORTED BY EITHER STATE OR FEDERAL ASSISTANCE FUNDS UNDER THE WILDLIFERESTORATION PITTMAN-ROBERTSON ACT (WR). THE ACTIVITIES ARE CONDUCTED TO CARRY OUT THE CDFW S TRUSTEERESPONSIBILITIES FOR RESOURCES AND REQUIRE EXTENSIVE COMMUNICATION AND COORDINATION WITH OTHER AGENCIES, CDFWHEADQUARTERS PROGRAMS, REGIONAL CDFW STAFF, AND THE PUBLIC.IDRWP STAFF OF THE INLAND DESERTS REGION-SOUTH (IDRS) MANAGE MULE DEER IN THE MOUNTAINOUS D14 AND D19 ZONES,WHERE DEMOGRAPHIC DATA ARE DIFFICULT TO OBTAIN BECAUSE OF STEEP TOPOGRAPHY AND LIMITED ACCESSIBILITY BY ROAD.THIS GRANT FOCUSES ON DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF METHODS FOR ASSESSMENT AND MONITORING OF MULE DEERDEMOGRAPHY.THESE ACTIVITIES IN IDRS WILL COMPLEMENT WORK IN IDR-NORTH, OTHER REGIONS, AND HEADQUARTERS ACTIVITIES, BUT DONOT DUPLICATE OTHER CDFW ACTIVITIES SUPPORTED BY EITHER STATE OR FEDERAL ASSISTANCE FUNDS UNDER THE WILDLIFERESTORATION PITTMAN-ROBERTSON ACT. THE ACTIVITIES ENABLE IDRS TO CARRY OUT CDFW S RESPONSIBILITIES AS TRUSTEEFOR CALIFORNIA S WILDLIFE RESOURCES.

THIS GRANT FUNDS COLORADO PARKS AND WILDLIFE S RESEARCH ON GUNNISON AND GREATER SAGE-GROUSE. WORK COVERED UNDER THIS GRANT INCLUDES SPRINGTIME LEK COUNTS, HABITAT USAGE STUDIES, SUPPORT FOR LOCAL WORKING GROUPS, TECHNICAL AND EXPERT ASSISTANCE TO INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL CUSTOMERS, DATA ANALYSIS AND PREPARATION OF RESEARCH STUDY FINDINGS FOR PROFESSIONAL JOURNALS. GRANT FUNDED WORK IS CRUCIAL TO THE RECOVERY OF BOTH SAGE-GROUSE SPECIES.
IOWA FY24 FISH AND  WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM

THIS PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONDUCT INVESTIGATIONS ON WILDLIFE POPULATION, HABITAT, DISEASE, AND HUMAN DIMENSIONS DATA. THIS PROVIDES THE BASIS FOR KDWP S WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS AND THE COORDINATION, ADMINISTRATION, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND EDUCATION SUPPORT ASSOCIATED WITH THESE PROGRAMS.

WILDLIFE SURVEYS AND INVENTORIES ARE ESSENTIAL ACTIVITIES FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF THE STATES NATURAL RESOURCES BYTHE NEBRASKA GAME   PARKS COMMISSION. NEBRASKA IS BLESSED WITH ABUNDANT WILDLIFE, FROM VERY POPULAR GAME SPECIES TO CONTINENTALLY IMPORTANT POPULATIONS OF MIGRANT BIRDS TO NATIONALLY IMPORTANT THREATENED AND ENDANGEREDSPECIES. THE STARTING POINT FOR MANAGING THIS PRECIOUS HERITAGE IS AN INFORMED PERSPECTIVE ON THE ABUNDANCE,DISTRIBUTION, AND POPULATION TRENDS FOR EVERY SPECIES CONCERNED. IN SOME CASES, WE HAVE CONDUCTED SURVEYS FORMANY YEARS WITHOUT SUBSTANTIAL CHANGES, WHILE IN OTHERS WE ARE IMPLEMENTING NEW SURVEYS TO EITHER (1) BROADEN OURSCOPE AND BRING IN SPECIES NOT PREVIOUSLY CONSIDERED OR (2) DEEPEN OUR KNOWLEDGE OF SPECIES MONITORED IN THEPAST. BECAUSE OF THE STATES SIZE, THE WIDE-SPREAD DISTRIBUTION OF DIVERSE WILDLIFE THROUGHOUT IT, AND THEPREDOMINANTLY PRIVATE OWNERSHIP OF WILDLIFE HABITAT (LESS THAN 3  OF THE STATE IS IN PUBLIC OWNERSHIP), OURSURVEY AND MONITORING ACTIVITIES EMPHASIZE TECHNIQUES THAT CAN BE EFFICIENTLY EMPLOYED OVER A LARGE AREA, WITHPUBLIC COOPERATION WHENEVER BENEFICIAL, AND DESIGNED TO PROVIDE USEFUL INFORMATION ON SEVERAL WILDLIFE SPECIESSIMULTANEOUSLY WHEN POSSIBLE.

THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT DEVELOPMENT OF TOOLS TO MONITOR THE POPULATION OUTCOMES OF MANAGEMENT ACTIONS AS FWP CONTINUES TO MOVE TOWARD ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT FRAMEWORKS MEANT TO IMPROVE HUNTING OPPORTUNITY THROUGH INTEGRATED MANAGEMENT OF HABITATS, PREDATORS AND HUNTING SEASONS.

BY DEVELOPING AN ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT FRAMEWORK FOR BIGHORN SHEEP AND MOUNTAIN GOATS CONSISTING OF PREDICTIVE MODELS, TARGETED MONITORING, AND A MECHANISM FOR IMPROVING PREDICTIVE MODELS, THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A FORMAL APPROACH TO ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT, ALLOWING THE CURRENT POOL OF PLANNED MANAGEMENT ACTIONS ACROSS MONTANA TO GUIDE STUDY DESIGN FOR INTEGRATED LEARNING AND REFINEMENT OF MANAGEMENT INTO THE FUTURE.

THE LOSS OF WETLANDS ASSOCIATED WITH THE GULF COAST OF TEXAS HAS BEEN WELL-DOCUMENTED. FOR MANY DECADES, RICE AGRICULTURE HAS PROVEN TO BE A SURROGATE FOR MANY BREEDING, STAGING, AND WINTERING MIGRATORY BIRDS IN TEXAS. HOWEVER, RECENT DECLINES IN RICEAGRICULTURE IN TEXAS, COMBINED WITH THE LOSS OF HISTORICAL WETLANDS, HAVE CREATED A DEFICIENCY OF FRESHWATER WETLANDS ALONG THE GULF COAST OF TEXAS, ESPECIALLY IN THE MIDCOAST REGION. TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT (TPWD), ALONG WITH PARTNERS, WILL WORK TO ESTABLISH FLOODED AGRICULTURAL FIELDS, PRIMARILY RECENT OR FALLOWED AGRICULTURAL FIELDS, DURING THE LAST SUMMER THROUGH EARLY SPRING PERIOD TO PROVIDE SHALLOW WATER FOR MIGRATORY, STAGING, AND WINTERING MIGRATORY BIRDS, MOSTLY SHOREBIRDS AND WATERFOWL. THE NEWPARTNERSHIP WILL WORK WITH VOLUNTARY LANDOWNERS OR PUBLIC LANDS WHEN AVAILABLE IN THE IDENTIFIED COUNTIES THAT WILL FLOOD THEIR AGRICULTURAL FIELDS WITH EXISTING WATER DELIVERIES (THROUGH WATER RECLAMATION AUTHORITIES OR EXISTING IRRIGATION WELLS). IN ADDITION, THESEAREAS WILL NOT BE HUNTED TO MINIMIZE DISTURBANCE AND MINIMIZE INDIVIDUAL ENERGY BUDGETS OF MIGRATORY BIRDS. PREVIOUS EXERCISE WITH THE GULF COAST JOINT VENTURE HAS IDENTIFIED MANY AREAS IN THE MIDCOAST REGION WHICH LACK LARGE AREAS OF FRESHWATER THAT ARE NOTDISTURBED DURING THE WATERFOWL HUNTING SEASON. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO ASSIST IN REVERSING THE DECLINE IN BODY CONDITION OF WATERFOWL, WINTERING WATERFOWL ABUNDANCE, AND INCREASE NON-COASTAL WETLANDS THAT MAY BE USED BY MIGRATING OR WINTERING WADING AND SHOREBIRDS.
NORTH DAKOTA DEPARTMENT OF GAME AND FISH PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE ACCESS TO, MANAGE, OPERATE AND MAINTAIN 184,591.88 ACRES OF WILDLIFE HABITAT ON 224 WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS.

COLLARED PECCARY ( PECARI TAJACU), ALSO KNOWN AS JAVELINA, OCCUR THROUGHOUT SOUTHERN AND WESTERN TEXAS AND IN THE ROLLING PLAINS (TAYLOR AND SYNATSKE 2008  APPENDIX A), AND ARE CLASSIFIED AS A GAME ANIMAL BY TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT (TPWD).HOWEVER, COLLARED PECCARY RECEIVE LESS MANAGEMENT ATTENTION THAN OTHER GAME SPECIES, AND IN MANY INSTANCES, DATA, INFORMATION, AND METHODS ARE LIMITED. CURRENT DATA SHOW DECLINING TRENDS IN POPULATION NUMBERS, AND IT IS PROPOSED THAT MANY FACTORS COULD BECAUSING THESE DECLINES SUCH AS FREQUENT AND WIDESPREAD DROUGHT, INCREASES IN WILD PIG (SUS SCROFA) POPULATIONS, OVERHARVEST, IMPROPER RANGELAND MANAGEMENT, OR THE REDUCTION OF WOODY VEGETATION (TAYLOR AND SYNATSKE 2008, TPWD RFP 2022).UNDERSTANDING A SPECIES  LIFE HISTORY, ECOLOGY, AND BEHAVIOR ARE CRITICAL TO MANAGING THEIR POPULATIONS AND HABITAT, AND FOR MITIGATING ISSUES RELATED TO POPULATION DECLINE. OUR PROPOSED WORK HAS FOUR FOCAL POINTS AIMED AT IMPROVING KNOWLEDGE OF COLLARED PECCARY FORMANAGEMENT PURPOSES AND INCREASING PUBLIC INTEREST  BOTH OF WHICH CAN INCENTIVIZE FUTURE CONSERVATION EFFORTS. FIRST, WE WILL DEVELOP AND EVALUATE CAMERA, ROADSIDE, AND HELICOPTER SURVEY METHODS TO ESTIMATE COLLARED PECCARY ABUNDANCE IN THE WESTERN SOUTH TEXAS PLAINS. THESE SURVEY METHODS WILL RELY ON GPS TAGGED INDIVIDUALS TO DEVELOP, EVALUATE, AND VALIDATE EACH MODEL USING DISTANCE SAMPLING, MARK-RESIGHT, OCCUPANCY, AND SPACE-TO-EVENT METHODS (MOELLER ET AL. 2018). SECOND, WE WILL USE POPULATION ABUNDANCE ESTIMATES FROM SURVEYS ALONG WITH HARVEST NUMBERS, SURVIVAL, REPRODUCTION, HEALTH, AND HABITAT AVAILABILITY TO MODEL COLLARED PECCARY POPULATION DYNAMICS AND GROWTH. THESE DATA WILL ALSO BE USED TO INVESTIGATE THE EFFECTS OF ENVIRONMENTAL CHARACTERISTICS AND CHANGING LANDSCAPES ON POPULATION DEMOGRAPHICS. WE WILL DEVELOP A WEB-BASED DATA MANAGEMENT AND ANALYSIS SYSTEM TO ASSIST BIOLOGISTS WITH SURVEYS, STORING DATA, AND FITTING POPULATION MODELS FOR COLLARED PECCARY. THIRD, WE WILL DEVELOP A SUITE OF SPECIES DISTRIBUTION MODELS FOR COLLARED PECCARIES USING HELICOPTER SURVEY DETECTIONS, CAMERA DETECTIONS AND OCCUPANCY ANALYSES, AND GPS TAGS AND RESOURCE SELECTION MODELS. LAST, WE WILL DEVELOP EDUCATIONAL MEDIA TO ELICIT PUBLIC INTEREST IN COLLARED PECCARY MANAGEMENT. THESE EFFORTS WILL IDENTIFY FACTORS RELATED TO THE DISTRIBUTION, SURVIVAL, REPRODUCTION, AND ABUNDANCE OFCOLLARED PECCARY, CREATE USER FRIENDLY TOOLS (E.G., MAPS AND WEB-BASED POPULATION MODELS), AND ALLOW BIOLOGISTS, LANDOWNERS AND TPWD TO PRIORITIZE MANAGEMENT IN A SPATIALLY EXPLICIT CONTEXT.

DEVELOPING STRATEGIC CONSERVATION PLANS REQUIRES UNDERSTANDING WHEN AND WHERE POPULATIONS ARE LIMITED ACROSS THE ANNUAL CYCLE. FOR SMALL BODIED MIGRATORY ANIMALS, COLLECTING DATA ON MIGRATORY PATHWAYS, SEASONAL DEMOGRAPHIC VITAL RATES, AND HOW POPULATIONS ARE GEOGRAPHICALLY LINKED, HAS PRESENTED A LONG-STANDING CHALLENGE. HOWEVER, RECENT ADVANCES IN THE USE OF AUTOMATED RADIO TELEMETRY ARE NOW PROVIDING HIGH RESOLUTION SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL DATA THAT ENABLE US TO TRACK SMALL BODIED MIGRATORY ANIMALS, FILL KEY KNOWLEDGE GAPS, AND CREATE STRATEGIC CONSERVATION PLANS. MOTUS IS A GROWING COLLABORATIVE NETWORK OF AUTOMATED TELEMETRY STATIONS THAT FACILITATES THE STUDY OF MOVEMENT FOR DIVERSITY OF TAXA. ALTHOUGH THE MOTUS NETWORK IS WELL ESTABLISHED IN THE EASTERN PORTION OF THE UNITED STATES, ITS DEVELOPMENT IN THE WESTERN US IS STILL IN A NASCENT PHASE. AS SUCH, THERE IS A NEED TO EXPAND THE MOTUS INFRASTRUCTURE ESPECIALLY IN BIOMES OF CRITICAL CONSERVATION IMPORTANCE LIKE THE CENTRAL GREAT PLAINS AND CHIHUAHUAN DESERT. HERE, WE OUTLINE A COLLABORATIVE PROJECT THAT EXPANDS THE GEOGRAPHIC SCOPE OF THE MOTUS NETWORK ACROSS TEXAS. SPECIFICALLY, WE REQUEST SUPPORT FOR A PROJECT THAT WILL BUILD 13 NEW MOTUS STATIONS AND LEVERAGE THE NETWORK BY DEPLOYING 225 TAGS ON BATS OF CONSERVATION CONCERN. THIS PROJECT IS EXPECTED TO HAVE BROAD TAXONOMIC RELEVANCE. FOR BIRDS, THIS WORK WILL FILL KEY KNOWLEDGE GAPS ON THE STOP-OVER, MIGRATORY PATHWAYS, SEASONAL HABITAT USE, AND POPULATION CONNECTIVITY FOR DECLINING GRASSLAND BIRDS (BAIRDS SPARROW, SPRAGUES PIPIT, CHESTNUT-COLLARED AND THICK-BILLED LONGSPUR). FOR BATS, THIS WORK WILL FILL KNOWLEDGE GAPS IN REGIONAL AND POPULATION-LEVEL MOVEMENT, DISEASE DYNAMICS (PSEUDOGYMNOASCUS DESTRUCTANS (PD) THAT CAUSES WHITE NOSE SYNDROME) AND MIGRATORY PATHWAYS FOR PRIORITY CONSERVATION SPECIES (CAVE MYOTIS AND MEXICAN LONG-NOSED BATS), AS WELL AS BAT SPECIES OF INCREASING CONCERN, SUCH AS HOARY BATS, DUE TO DRAMATIC POPULATION DECLINES.

CREATING AND MAINTAINING ACCESS IS THE MOST IMPORTANT FACTOR ASSOCIATED WITH PARTICIPATION AND IS A CRITICAL NEED OVER WHICH AGENCIES CAN HAVE AN IMPORTANT INFLUENCE (RESPONSIVE MANAGEMENT NSSF, 2008). RESEARCH SHOWS THAT ACCESS PLAYS A KEY ROLE IN PARTICIPATION AND IS ONE OF THE LEADING REASONS FOR DISSATISFACTION AND DESERTION AMONG HUNTERS AND ANGLERS. STATE-SPONSORED HUNTING AND FISHING ACCESS PROGRAMS ARE CONSIDERED SOME OF THE MOST EFFECTIVE PROGRAMS RESOURCES FOR FACILITATING ACCESS (RESPONSIVE MANAGEMENT NSSF, 2011), AND CAN ALSO MAINTAIN AND OR INCREASE LANDOWNER PARTICIPATION.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO RECRUIT AND RETAIN SAFE, RESPONSIBLE HUNTERS AND RECREATIONAL SHOOTERS BY PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES TO PARTICIPATE IN SHOOTING ACTIVITIES THAT ENCOURAGE FUTURE HUNTER PARTICIPATION AND CONTRIBUTIONS TO CONSERVATION.OBJECTIVE 1) TRAIN 25 YOUTH SHOOTING SPORTS COACHES BY JUNE 30, 2024. OBJECTIVE 2) INTRODUCE 300 NEW YOUTH TO SHOOTING SPORTS BY JUNE 30, 2024.OBJECTIVE 3) RETAIN 4,600 YOUTH PARTICIPANTS IN SHOOTING SPORTS BY PROVIDING SUPPLIES AND PROGRAMMING BY JUNE 30, 2024.OBJECTIVE 4) SPONSOR 10 EVENTS TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR YOUTH HUNTERS AND RECREATIONAL SHOOTERS TO PRACTICE FIREARM SAFETY AND DEMONSTRATE PROFICIENCY BY JUNE 30, 2024.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: INCREASE IN HUNTER EDUCATION PARTICIPANTS, INCREASE IN PARTICIPATION IN HUNTING AND TARGET SHOOTING,  INCREASE IN USE OF PUBLIC SHOOTING RANGES, REDUCTION IN WOUNDED GAME, INCREASE IN PUBLIC SUPPORT FOR WILDLIFE RESTORATION EFFORTS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: YOUTH HUNTERS AND RECREATIONAL SHOOTERS IN ARKANSAS AND THE GENERAL PUBLICSUB-RECIPIENTS: NONE

THERE IS A NEED TO HAVE SAFE, AVAILABLE AND ENVIRONMENTALLY SOUND PUBLIC SHOOTING RANGES FOR SPORTSMEN AND WOMEN TO LEARN, PRACTICE AND IMPROVE SHOOTING SKILLS TO BE ETHICAL, SAFE AND KNOWLEDGEABLE HUNTERS. EXISTING SHOOT RANGE GROUNDS AND FACILITIES WILL BE OPERATED, IMPROVED AND MAINTAINED TO MEET THIS NEED. RANGE FACILITIES ARE USED TO CONDUCT HUNTER, BOWHUNTER AND OUTDOOR SKILLS COURSES, AND PROVIDE STUDENT AMENITIES SUCH AS BATHROOMS, CLASSROOMS, AND INSTRUCTOR FACILITIES ARE NEEDED AT RANGES.

HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS BENEFIT A WIDE RANGE OF WILDLIFE SPECIES SUCH AS MULE DEER, ELK, PRONGHORN, WILD TURKEY, WATERFOWL, WITH ADDITIONAL BENEFITS FOR OTHER GAME AND NON-GAME SPECIES. THESE OPPORTUNITIES NEED TO BE ACTIVELY DEVELOPED IN ORDER FORIMPLEMENTATION TO OCCUR AT A MEANINGFUL SCOPE, SCALE, AND PACE. NEW MEXICO DEPARTMENT OF GAME AND FISH (DEPARTMENT) WILL COLLABORATE AND COORDINATE WITH OTHER AGENCIES AND ORGANIZATIONS, TO PLAN, DEVELOP, AND DESIGN HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIVITIES TOACTIVELY SHEPHERD PROJECT IDEAS INTO BECOMING HABITAT IMPROVEMENTS ON A LANDSCAPE SCALE.

A PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITY OF THE SOUTH DAKOTA DEPARTMENT OF GAME, FISH AND PARKS IS TO MANAGE ALL WILDLIFE SPECIESIN THE STATE TOWARD THE HIGHEST LEVEL POSSIBLE, CONSISTENT WITH LAND CARRYING CAPACITY AND COMPATIBILITY WITHSOCIAL TOLERANCES. A PREREQUISITE TO EFFECTIVE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT IS KNOWLEDGE OF POPULATION AND HABITATCHARACTERISTICS. SINCE WILDLIFE POPULATIONS ARE DYNAMIC DUE TO LAND-USE CHANGES, NATURAL CONDITIONS, MANAGEMENTEFFORTS, DISEASES, ETC., ANNUAL POPULATION AND HABITAT MONITORING IS REQUIRED FOR DETERMINING YEAR-TO-YEARFLUCTUATION AND LONG-TERM TRENDS, AND FOR EVALUATING CHANGES. OBTAINING NECESSARY INFORMATION ON THE DIFFERENTPOPULATION AND HABITAT PARAMETERS ALSO REQUIRES DIFFERENT TYPES OF SURVEYS BE CONDUCTED AT APPROPRIATE TIMES OFTHE YEAR. IN ADDITION, SURVEYS NEED TO BE CONDUCTED TO EVALUATE RESULTS OF SPECIFIC MANAGEMENT PRACTICES SUCH ASHUNTING SEASONS AND HABITAT MANIPULATION, WITH DIRECTION TOWARD INCREASED EFFECTIVENESS AND EFFICIENCY.

TROPICAL DRY AND MIXED MESIC FORESTS IN HAWAI I FACE MANY THREATS SUCH AS THE PRESENCE OF INVASIVE WEEDS AND WILDFIRE HAZARDS. THE ESTABLISHMENT OF INVASIVE FOUNTAIN GRASS AND OTHER FIRE TOLERANT NON-NATIVE GRASSES HAS LED TO THE CREATION OF A GRASS-FIRE CYCLE IN THESE AREAS. THE DIVISION OF FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE (DOFAW) MANAGES LANDS IN THE PU U WA AWA A FOREST RESERVE AND THE PU U ANAHULU GAME MANAGEMENT AREA, IN NORTH KONA, ON THE ISLAND OF HAWAI I (PROJECT AREA: REFERRED TO AS NPUU, MEANING THE HILLS). GAME MAMMAL HUNTING HAS BEEN AN IMPORTANT ACTIVITY IN THE PROJECT AREA FOR MORE THAN A CENTURY. ACCESS TO HUNTING AREAS WITHIN THE PROJECT AREA IS VIA FOUR-WHEEL DRIVE ROADS WHICH ACT AS FUEL BREAKS IN THIS HIGHLY FIRE PRONE ENVIRONMENT. THE FOUR-WHEEL DRIVE ROADS NEED TO BE ACTIVELY MAINTAINED TO PREVENT OVERGROWTH BY INVASIVE WEEDS, PRIMARILY FOUNTAIN GRASS AND TREE TOBACCO. HUNTERS ARE THE LARGEST PUBLIC GROUP ACCESSING THE FORESTS IN THESE AREAS, AND THREATS TO THE NATIVE ECOSYSTEMS FROM THE INTRODUCTION OF INVASIVE SPECIES OR WILDFIRE RESULTING FROM VEHICLES AND PEOPLE IS GREAT. WEED CONTROL ALONG THESE ROADS THEREFORE ALLOWS THEM TO MAINTAIN THEIR FUNCTION AS FIRE BREAKS, THUS REDUCING RISKS OF HABITAT DAMAGE CAUSED BY FIRES.IN ADDITION TO BEING A VALUABLE HUNTING AREA, THE PROJECT AREA IS ALSO HOME TO 15 ENDANGERED PLANT SPECIES, 7 THREATENED AND ENDANGERED BIRD SPECIES, AND ONE ENDANGERED MOTH SPECIES. THE DIVISION OF FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE HAS BEEN DEVELOPING CONSERVATION MEASURES THAT WILL PROTECT THESE ENDANGERED SPECIES WHILE ALSO ALLOWING HUNTER ACCESS AND OPPORTUNITIES. FENCED EXCLOSURES AS WELL AS PROPAGATION AND OUTPLANTING OF NATIVE PLANT SPECIES WILL HELP AVOID AND MINIMIZE IMPACTS FROM GAME MAMMALS AS WELL IMPROVE GAME BIRD HABITAT. A HEALTHY FOREST IS IMPORTANT FOR MAINTAINING NATIVE BIODIVERSITY AS WELL AS FOR MAINTAINING ECOSYSTEM SERVICES SUCH AS WATER RECHARGE IN THE AQUIFER, FOREST PRODUCTS, GAME MAMMALS FOR HUNTING, AND AMPLE NATIVE SPECIES FOR CULTURAL GATHERING.  NATIVE PLANT COMMUNITY RESTORATION WILL ENHANCE HABITAT FOR BOTH NATIVE, NON-GAME AND GAME BIRD SPECIES, ALLOWING FOR INCREASED OPPORTUNITY FOR RECREATIONAL BIRDING AND GAME BIRD HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES, AS WELL AS INCREASED OVERALL FOREST HEALTH, AND CONSERVATION OF NATIVE BIODIVERSITY.

PUBLIC DEMANDS FOR WILDLIFE-RELATED RECREATION ARE INCREASING WHILE MOST WILDLIFE POPULATIONS ARE BECOMING LESSSTABLE DUE TO CHANGING QUANTITY AND OR QUALITY OF HABITAT, PRIMARILY ON PRIVATELY OWNED LAND WHICH CONSTITUTESFOR MOST OF THE LAND IN THE STATE. ADDITIONALLY, THE POTENTIAL FOR WILDLIFE PRODUCTION IS NOT BEING REACHED ONTHE MUCH SMALLER ACREAGES OF PUBLIC LANDS. SINCE MOST PUBLIC LAND IS ADMINISTERED AND MANAGED BY OTHER STATE ANDFEDERAL AGENCIES, COORDINATION AND CONSULTATION WITH THESE AGENCIES ON APPROPRIATE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES WHICH CAN PERPETUATE OR INCREASE WILDLIFE POPULATIONS, WITHOUT NECESSARILY REDUCING OTHER BENEFITS OF THE LAND, NEED TO BERESEARCHED AND DETERMINED SO THAT THEY CAN BE USED ON STATE GAME PRODUCTION AREAS AND EFFECTIVELY COMMUNICATED TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND OTHER STATE AND FEDERAL LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES.ADDITIONALLY, RESEARCH STUDIES ARE NEEDED TO DEVELOP BETTER METHODS FOR DETERMINING STATUS OF WILDLIFEPOPULATIONS, AND TIME AND EXTENT OF MORTALITY AND MOVEMENT, SO THAT MANAGEMENT EFFORTS CAN BE EVALUATED. RESEARCH IS ALSO NEEDED TO INVESTIGATE RESTORATION OF WILDLIFE SPECIES, AS WELL AS STABILIZE OR INCREASE POPULATIONS, WILLPROVIDE INCREASED INSURANCE OF SPECIES WELFARE, AND OPPORTUNITY FOR PUBLIC ENJOYMENT OF WILDLIFE.RESEARCH FINDINGS WILL ASSIST MANAGEMENT PERSONNEL TO MORE FULLY UNDERSTAND THE ECOLOGY OF THE WILDLIFE SPECIESBEING MANAGED. METHODS TO IMPROVE WILDLIFE HABITATS AND INCREASE SPECIES DIVERSITY AND ABUNDANCE WILL ALSO BEACCOMPLISHED THROUGH RESEARCH EFFORTS. IMPLEMENTATION OF NEW AND IMPROVED TECHNIQUES WILL AID MANAGEMENT TOBETTER MONITOR WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND, THEREFORE, BETTER ABLE TO MAKE SOUND MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONDUCT POPULATION MONITORING AND HARVEST MANAGEMENT OF WILDLIFE SPECIES THAT ARE HUNTED AND TRAPPED IN THE STATE. THE OVERALL GOAL IS TO MAXIMIZE SUSTAINABLE HUNTING AND TRAPPING OPPORTUNITIES, WHILE MINIMIZING HUMAN-WILDLIFE CONFLICTS. THIS WORK IS ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH A SERIES OF SURVEYS, CENSUSES, AND INVENTORIES TO MONITOR THE POPULATION STATUS AND HEALTH AND THE HARVEST OF THESE IMPORTANT RESOURCES. RESEARCH STUDIES PROVIDE NEW INFORMATION TO HELP BETTER UNDERSTAND THE BIOLOGY AND ECOLOGY OF THE SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS. THE INFORMATION AND KNOWLEDGE GAINED FROM THESE ACTIVITIES ARE USED TO GUIDE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS, TO MAKE HUNTING AND TRAPPING SEASON RECOMMENDATIONS TO THE DIRECTOR AND THE GOVERNOR, AND TO PROVIDE INFORMATION TO THE PUBLIC AND OTHER AGENCIES AND ORGANIZATIONS.

THE NORTH DAKOTA GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT (DEPARTMENT) WILL USE FUNDING FROM THIS PROJECT TO ADMINISTER PORTIONSOF THE PRIVATE LAND OPEN TO SPORTMEN (PLOTS) PROGRAM. THE PLOTS PROGRAM IS A VOLUNTARY HABITAT AND ACCESSPROGRAM THAT PROVIDES YEAR-ROUND, PUBLIC WALK-IN HUNTING ACCESS ON ENROLLED ACRES. IN ADDITION TO LANDOWNERPAYMENTS, THIS PROJECT ALSO INCLUDES EXPENSES INCURRED BY THE DEPARTMENT FOR GRASS SEED, TITLE WORK AND RECORDINGFEES AS WELL AS STAFF SALARY, FRINGE AND EXPENSES. LOCATIONS OF THE ENROLLED TRACTS ARE PUBLISHED ANNUALLY IN THEPLOTS GUIDE AND DISSEMINATED TO VENDORS ACROSS THE STATE.

THE GOAL OF THE NATIVE SPECIES DIVERSITY PROGRAM (NONGAME GRANT) IS TO MANAGE, PRESERVE AND PROTECT HAWAII S NATIVE AVIFAUNA. A MAJOR FOCUS OF THE PROGRAM IS ON MANAGEMENT AND RECOVERY OF ENDANGERED SPECIES, INCLUDING PROJECTS TO MONITOR, MANAGE HABITAT, AND RECOVER POPULATIONS THROUGHOUT THE ISLANDS IN KEY WILDLIFE SANCTUARIES AND FOREST RESERVES AND CONTROL OF PREDATORS AFFECTING ENDANGERED SPECIES. OTHER NONGAME PROJECTS INCLUDE INCREASED SURVEILLANCE OF NON-NATIVE PESTS, CONSTRUCTION OF FACILITIES AND INFRASTRUCTURE TO PROMOTE MANAGEMENT OR RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES TO ENJOY NONGAME RESOURCES, AND MAINTENANCE OF THOSE FACILITIES. THE HAWAII NATIVE SPECIES DIVERSITY PROGRAM CONSISTS OF 38 DIFFERENT PROJECTS OR JOBS ORGANIZED BY ISLAND.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO PURCHASE 6.21 ACRES ADJACENT TO THE OVERTON WMA TO  (1) RESTORE AND MANAGE WILDLIFE FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE PUBLIC, PARTICULARLY FOR MIGRATORY WATERFOWL, GAMBEL S QUAIL, MOURNING DOVE, COTTONTAIL RABBITS AND RIO GRANDE TURKEY, (2) FACILITATE THE OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF THE OVERTON WMA, AND (3) PROVIDE PUBLIC ACCESS FOR WILDLIFE-ORIENTED RECREATION ACTIVITIES. THE PURCHASE OF ADDITIONAL PROPERTY IS VITAL TO NDOW S MISSION OF MANAGING, PROTECTING AND RESTORING HABITAT IN THE STATE. THE WETLAND HABITAT PROVIDED ON THIS PROPERTY SERVES AS A CRITICAL DESTINATION AND OR STOPOVER POINT FOR WATERFOWL THAT MIGRATE THROUGH THIS OTHERWISE ARID TRANSITION ZONE BETWEEN THE SOUTHERN GREAT BASIN AND THE MOJAVE DESERT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE SAFE, CONSERVATION-MINDED HUNTING EXPERIENCES IN ARKANSAS.OBJECTIVES DELIVERABLES:OBJECTIVE 1) TRAIN 100 NEW HUNTER EDUCATION VOLUNTEER INSTRUCTORS BY JUNE 30, 2024.OBJECTIVE 2) PROVIDE CONTINUED TRAINING TO 100 ACTIVE INSTRUCTORS BY JUNE 30, 2024.OBJECTIVE 3) CONDUCT 400 INSTRUCTOR-LED TRAINING EVENTS BY JUNE 30, 2024.OBJECTIVE 4) CERTIFY 13,000 STUDENTS IN HUNTER EDUCATION BY JUNE 30, 2024.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: FEWER HUNTING INCIDENTS, A REDUCTION IN THE NUMBER OF WOUNDED GAME, INCREASE IN HUNTER SUCCESSESAND SATISFACTION, FEWER HUNTING REGULATION VIOLATIONS, INCREASE IN PARTICIPATION IN HUNTING, SHOOTING AND OTHER RELATED SKILLS,PUBLIC AWARENESS OF THE ROLE OF HUNTING IN CONSERVATION EFFORTS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: CITIZENS OF ARKANSAS THAT ARE REQUIRED TO TAKE HUNTER EDUCATIONSUB-RECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE

RECREATIONAL SHOOTING AND ARCHERY SPORTS CONTINUES TO GROW IN THE UNITED STATES. OUR GOAL IS TO DEVELOP A ROBUST SPORTS COMPLEX THAT CAN ACCOMMODATE EVERYONE FROM THE NOVICE, INTERMEDIATE TO PROFESSIONAL ATHLETES WHO WILL FIND A WIDE RANGE OF SAFE AND FUN OPPORTUNITIES TO ENJOY AND IMPROVE THEIR SKILLS. IN ADDITION TO ON-SITE SHOOTER, ARCHERY AND HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAMS, OUR PROPOSED COMPLEX WOULD ALSO SERVE AS A VENUE FOR LOCAL, STATE, REGIONAL AND NATIONAL COMPETITION EVENTS. BY DEVELOPING A VENUE THAT CAN ALSO ACCOMMODATE GROUPS AND CLUBS, WE WOULD ALSO BE ABLE TO HOST OUR OWN FUNDRAISING EVENTS TO BENEFIT OUR EXPANSION, SUSTAINABILITY AND CONSERVATION EFFORTS FOR DOE MOUNTAIN AS WELL AS PARTNER WITH OTHER ORGANIZATIONS TO BENEFIT AREA CHARITIES.
THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE THE COORDINATION AND ADMINISTRATION OF THE WSFR PROGRAMS.

THE KANSAS HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM IS DESIGNED TO PRODUCE SAFE, KNOWLEDGEABLE, RESPONSIBLE AND INVOLVED HUNTERS WHO WILL SUPPORT WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES THAT PRODUCE HEALTHY POPULATIONS OF WILDLIFE FOR THE ENJOYMENT OF THE PEOPLE OF KANSAS. BY PLACING BETTER TRAINED AND DEDICATED INSTRUCTORS INTO THE CLASSROOM, KANSAS HUNTER EDUCATION STUDENTS WILL BE PROVIDED A HIGHER QUALITY EDUCATION WITH MORE UNIFORMITY OF INSTRUCTION ACROSS THE STATE. LEGAL AND REGULATED HUNTING CONTINUES TO HAVE BROAD SUPPORT FROM THE PUBLIC. THROUGH OPEN DISCUSSIONS OF HUNTER ETHICS AND FAIR CHASE HUNTING METHODS WE CAN MAINTAIN THIS BROAD SUPPORT AND IMPROVE THE IMAGE OF HUNTERS AND HUNTING IN THE STATE. HUNTING AS AN ACTIVITY IS SAFE AND CONTINUES TO BE SAFER EACH YEAR, IT IS EXPECTED THAT HUNTER EDUCATION TRAINING WILL HELP TO FURTHER REDUCE THE STATE S ALREADY LOW HUNTING INCIDENT RATE. BECAUSE EVERY HUNTING INCIDENT INVOLVES AN INDIVIDUAL PERSON, IT IS VITAL THAT WE CONTINUE TO WORK TO DECREASE THE NUMBER OF HUNTING-RELATED INCIDENTS THAT OCCUR EACH YEAR IN THE STATE, THUS CONTINUING TO MAKE THE ACTIVITY EVEN SAFER FOR ALL CITIZENS AND PREVENTING ADDITIONAL LOSSES FROM BEING INFLICTED ON FAMILIES.

THIS GRANT SUPPORTS THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION S EFFORTS TO MANAGE TURKEYS AND BIG GAME. THE OBJECTIVES OF THE TURKEY POPULATION AND HARVEST MONITORING PROJECT ARE: 1) CONDUCT 1 ANNUAL INVESTIGATION REGARDING TURKEY HARVEST DATA (CHECK STATION DATA) AND 2 ANNUAL INVESTIGATIONS FOR TURKEY POPULATION DATA (PRE-BREEDING TURKEY FLOCK SURVEY TO ASSESS ABUNDANCE AND BROOD SURVEY OPERATION TO ASSESS REPRODUCTION)  2) PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO ORGANIZATIONS. THE OBJECTIVES OF THE BIG GAME POPULATION, HARVEST AND DISEASE MONITORING PROJECT ARE: 1) CONDUCT 1 ANNUAL INVESTIGATION REGARDING BIG GAME HARVEST (COLLECT, ANALYZE, AND REPORT HABITAT, USAGE, AND HARVEST DATA FOR AT LEAST FOUR BIG GAME SPECIES), CONDUCT 2 ANNUAL INVESTIGATIONS FOR BIG GAME POPULATION DATA (SPOTLIGHT COUNTS AND AERIAL SURVEYS) AND CONDUCT 3 ANNUAL BIG GAME DISEASE STUDIES (HEARD HEALTH ASSESSMENT VIA 40 SAMPLES PER SAMPLED REGION, MORBIDITY MORTALITY OR OPPORTUNISTIC STUDIES, AND CWD SURVEILLANCE), 2) PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO TECHNICAL COMMITTEES, 3) FACILITY OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE, AND 4) PROVIDE OUTREACH REGARDING THE ROLE OF HUNTING VIA THE HUNTERS AGAINST HUNGER PROGRAM WHILE ALSO ASSISTING IN HERD MANAGEMENT BY ENCOURAGING DOE HARVEST. GRANT ACTIVITIES WILL OCCUR STATEWIDE.

THIS GRANT PROVIDES FUNDING TO SUPPORT THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION (ODWC) IN EVALUATING, ESTIMATING, AND MONITORING FURBEARER POPULATIONS IN OKLAHOMA. ADDITIONALLY THIS GRANT COMPLIES WITH FEDERAL REGULATIONS REGARDING MOVEMENT OF PELTS OF REGULATED SPECIES, MONITOR MOUNTAIN LION MOVEMENTS AND POPULATIONS, AND TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE RELATED TO FURBEARER MANAGEMENT. THIS GRANT WILL BENEFIT THE RESOURCE BY MONITORING THE OVERALL HEALTH OF FURBEARER POPULATIONS. IT WILL ALSO BENEFIT THE HUNTER BY ENSURING THE PROPER MANAGEMENT PRACTICES ARE BEING UTILIZED. OBJECTIVES INCLUDE 1) CONDUCTING RESEARCH, SURVEYS, COLLECTING DATA, AND ANALYSIS, 2) PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS, 3) PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO ORGANIZATIONS.

THIS WILDLIFE RESTORATION GRANT SUPPORTS THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION S EFFORTS TO MANAGE MIGRATORY BIRDS. THIS GRANT IS DIVIDED INTO THREE (3) OBJECTIVES. THE FIRST OBJECTIVE FOCUSES ON CONDUCTING TWELVE (12) MIGRATORY BIRD SURVEYS THE SECOND OBJECTIVE ALLOWS FOR THE PARTICIPATION ON FOUR (4) TECHNICAL COMMITTEES, SUPPORTING THE CENTRAL FLYWAY. THE THIRD OBJECTIVE ALLOWS FOR THE ROUTINE OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF SUPPORT FACILITIES. ANNUALLY SURVEYING THE POPULATIONS OF THESE ANIMALS ALLOWS THE ODWC TO MONITOR LONG TERM POPULATION TRENDS UNDER CURRENT REGULATIONS. RESULTS OF THE ABOVE DESCRIBED SURVEYS AND DATA COLLECTED WILL BE USED TO FORMULATE MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION STRATEGIES IN OKLAHOMA. DATA OBTAINED WILL ALSO BE USEFUL IN DISSEMINATING ACCURATE INFORMATION POPULATIONS OF THESE ANIMALS IN OKLAHOMA TO ENTITIES REQUESTING SUCH INFORMATION. THESE PROJECTS ALSO INCLUDE RELATED PROJECT ADMINISTRATION, COORDINATION AND PLANNING, PROCUREMENT, PERSONNEL MANAGEMENT, SUPERVISORY AND SAFETY TRAINING, PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT (TO INCLUDE CONTINUING EDUCATION AND WORKSHOPS AND SYMPOSIA AS WELL AS THROUGH CLOSE COORDINATION WITH MULTI-AGENCY REGIONAL EFFORT), MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR OF EQUIPMENT, AND ALL OTHER ASSOCIATED ELIGIBLE ACTIVITIES. THIS PROJECT BUILDS UPON THE PREVIOUS ODWC WILDLIFE RESTORATION MIGRATORY BIRD STUDIES GRANT F21AF01635   W-32-R-65.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO DEVELOP PRODUCTS THAT CAN BE USED FOR STATEWIDE MARTEN MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT, INCLUDING 1) A STATEWIDE HABITAT MODEL, 2) A STATEWIDE ASSESSMENT OF THE DISTRIBUTION OF BOTH MARTEN SPECIES, AND 3) DEVELOPMENT OF AN OCCUPANCY MONITORING METHODOLOGY AND FRAMEWORK WITH STATEWIDE IMPLICATIONS. WHEN THE PROJECT IS COMPLETED, MONTANA FISH, WILDLIFE AND PARKS WILL HAVE THE NECESSARY TOOLS TO DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT MANAGEMENT ACTIONS FOR MARTEN, INCLUDING TRANSLOCATION EFFORTS AND OCCUPANCY MONITORING TO INFORM HARVEST MANAGEMENT.
TO PROVIDE POPULATION, HARVEST, AND HUMAN DIMENSION SURVEY DATA TO INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.

THIS PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY INDIVIDUAL, HERD BAND-LEVEL, AND ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS THAT INFLUENCE THE PROBABILITY OF WILD AND DOMESTIC SHEEP CONTACT. THIS INFORMATION WILL BE USED TO EXPAND THE DEVELOPMENT OF TOOLS THAT MAINTAIN EFFECTIVE SEPARATION TO PREVENT DISEASE TRANSMISSION. INFORMATION FROM THIS STUDY MAY ALSO BE USED TO EVALUATE NEW OPPORTUNITIES TO EXPAND WILD SHEEP DISTRIBUTION IN MONTANA WHILE REDUCING THE RISK OF CONTACT WITH DOMESTIC SHEEP.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS 3-YEAR PROJECT IS TO: 1) CHARACTERIZE THE DEMOGRAPHIC, ECONOMIC, CULTURAL, AND ECOLOGICAL CONTEXT  2) QUANTIFY PARTICIPATION (NUMBER OF PEOPLE) IN BIRD AND EGG HARVEST IN RURAL ALASKA  3) COMPILE HARVEST DATA TO PORTRAY ALASKA-WIDE SUBSISTENCE HARVEST OF BIRDS AND EGGS  AND 4) ESTIMATE ECONOMIC VALUE OF BIRD AND EGG HARVEST IN RURAL ALASKA. RESULTS WILL CONTRIBUTE BY MAKING INFORMATION NEEDED FOR BIRD HARVEST MANAGEMENT EASILY ACCESSIBLE TO ALL STAKEHOLDERS.

THE GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES WILL PURCHASE THE 104  ACRE WEAVER TRUST TRACT, WHICH WILL BECOME PART OF THE 5,200-ACRE SPREWELL BLUFF WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA (WMA) WEST TRACT. ACQUIRING THE WEAVER TRUST TRACT WILL IMPROVE OUR ABILITY TO MANAGE THE EXISTING WMA, IMPROVE ACCESS TO THE PROPERTY AND CONSERVE WILDLIFE HABITAT AND INCREASE PUBLIC HUNTING OPPORTUNITY ADDING THIS PROPERTY TO THE WMA.

PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE BY WORKING DIRECTLY WITH FEDERAL, STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT AGENCIES AS WELL AS PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND COMMERCIAL RESIDENTIAL DEVELOPERS. THE AIM IS TO ACHIEVE A REDUCTION IN WILDLIFE AND FISHERIES HABITAT LOSS.

BOTH GRASSLANDS AND RIPARIAN AREAS ASSOCIATED WITH THE LOWER PECOS RIVER AND RIO GRANDE AND THEIR TRIBUTARIES ARE IDENTIFIED AS PRIORITY HABITATS IN THE CHIHUAHUAN DESERT. TRANS-PECOS GRASSLANDS AND RIPARIAN CONSERVATION INITIATIVE PARTNERS WILL CONDUCT NEEDED INVASIVE BRUSH REMOVAL, RESTRICTIVE FENCE REPLACEMENT, AND RIPARIAN RESTORATION WORK IN TARGETED, KEY GRASSLANDS AND RIPARIAN AREAS WITHIN THIS GEOGRAPHY. THIS HABITAT INITIATIVE WILL ASSIST LANDOWNERS THROUGH A COST-SHARE PROGRAM TO IMPROVE LONG-TERM GRASSLAND AND RIPARIAN HEALTH. LANDOWNERS WILL PAY APPROXIMATELY 30  OF THE COST, WHILE TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT (TPWD) PITTMAN-ROBERTSON (PR) FUNDS WILL COVER THE REMAINING 70  OF ALL COSTS. EFFECTS OF BRUSH TREATMENTS AND RIPARIAN WORK WILL BE MONITORED BY BORDERLANDS RESEARCH INSTITUTE (BRI) AND RIO GRANDE JOINT VENTURE (RGJV) STAFF.

PROJECT W-21 MONITORS GAME BIRD SPECIES IN PUERTO RICO AND ESTIMATES THEIR POPULATIONS AND HARVEST ANNUALLY. CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF GAME BIRD SPECIES IS REQUIRED TO SET ADEQUATE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES (I.E. ANNUAL BAG LIMITS, SELECTION OF SPECIES ALLOWED TO HUNT, SEASON DATES, ETC.) IN ORDER TO MAINTAIN THE SUSTAINABILITY OF THESE RESOURCES AND ENHANCE THE PERCEIVED BENEFIT BY THE USERS.

HUNTING IS A SIGNIFICANT CULTURAL, ECONOMIC, AND HISTORICAL ELEMENT OF THE NORTH CAROLINA LIFESTYLE. HOWEVER, NORTH CAROLINA HAS UNDERGONE SOCIOECONOMIC CHANGES THAT IMPACT THE TRADITIONAL ROLE AND IMPORTANCE OF HUNTING. AS A RESULT, TODAY S PUBLIC HAS BECOME INCREASINGLY CONCERNED ABOUT HUNTER SAFETY AND BEHAVIOR, DEMANDING GREATER ACCOUNTABILITY BY HUNTERS. HUNTERS IN NORTH CAROLINA NEED TO BE GIVEN OPPORTUNITIES TO ACQUIRE KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS AND ATTITUDES NECESSARY TO DEMONSTRATE SAFE AND RESPONSIBLE CONDUCT. THE NORTH CAROLINA HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE THE NECESSARY COMPONENTS TO FOSTER THIS DEVELOPMENT.

THIS GRANT PROVIDES FUNDING TO SUPPORT THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE (ODWC) IN PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND OTHER PRIVATE AND PUBLIC ENTITIES INTERESTED IN CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF WILDLIFE AND HABITAT ON LAND NOT DIRECTLY MANAGED BY ODWC, AND COMMENT ON STATEWIDE DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS AFFECTING FISH, WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS. THIS GRANT WILL BENEFIT THE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES OF OKLAHOMA BY ENSURING THAT AGENCY STAFF HAS THE OPPORTUNITY TO HELP ENCOURAGE LANDOWNERS AND OTHER PRIVATE OR PUBLIC ENTITIES TO INCORPORATE FISH AND WILDLIFE-FRIENDLY PRACTICES ON THEIR LANDS. THIS GRANT WILL ALSO BENEFIT RECREATIONAL ANGLERS AND HUNTERS BY ENHANCED FISH AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES ON PRIVATE AND PUBLIC LANDS. THIS GRANT WILL ALSO BENEFIT THE ENERGY INDUSTRY BY ENSURING THAT DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS MINIMIZE OR MITIGATE FOR POTENTIAL IMPACTS TO WILDLIFE, FISH, AND HABITAT RESOURCES. ANGLERS AND HUNTERS WILL ALSO BENEFIT FROM ENHANCED FISH AND WILDLIFE PRACTICES ON PRIVATE LANDS. THE ODWC WILL ALSO BENEFIT THROUGH MEETING AND LEARNING FROM PROFESSIONAL PEERS AND TECHNICAL EXPERTS. OBJECTIVES INCLUDE 1) PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS, 2) PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO ORGANIZATIONS, 3) PARTICIPATE ON TECHNICAL COMMITTEES, 4) REVIEW OF PROPOSED PROJECTS PLANS, 5) PARTICIPATE IN OR SPONSOR OUTREACH EVENTS, 6) PRODUCE DIGITAL AND PRINT PRODUCTS.

THE OVERALL GOAL OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS TO UNDERSTAND THE THREATS WILDLIFE FACE IN THE AGRICULTURAL LANDSCAPE OF ILLINOIS, EVALUATE VARIOUS PROGRAMS AND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES THAT MAY BENEFIT WILDLIFE, AND TO ULTIMATELY INFORM MANAGEMENT AND POLICY. BENEFITS OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE INCREASED DATA FOR MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AND A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF GRASSLAND MANAGEMENT. UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS URBANA CHAMPAIGN IS AN EXPECTED SUBGRANTEE OF THIS PROJECT.

THIS GRANT AND SUBSEQUENT AMENDMENTS OBLIGATE WYOMING S WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION APPORTIONMENTS FORIMPLEMENTATION AND OPERATION OF IT S COMPREHENSIVE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM AS DEFINED IN 50 CFR 80.2 AND 50 CFR 80.81.

THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION (ODWC) HAS CONDUCTED HUNTER SURVEYS SINCE 1986 TO ESTIMATE THE NUMBER OF HUNTERS AND GAME HARVEST STATEWIDE AND REGIONALLY. THE SURVEYS ARE CONDUCTED BY MAIL AND PHONE AND ARE SENT TO A SAMPLE OF RESIDENT AND NONRESIDENT HUNTING LICENSE HOLDERS DURING FEBRUARY AND MARCH OF EACH YEAR. ESTIMATES ARE CALCULATED OF THE PERCENTAGE OF LICENSE HOLDERS THAT WERE ACTIVE IN THE PREVIOUS YEAR. HUNTER AND GAME HARVEST ESTIMATES AND STATISTICS ARE CALCULATED STATEWIDE. DEER (ODOCOILEUS VIRGINIANUS AND O. HEMIONUS) SEASON IS TYPICALLY THE MOST POPULAR WITH HUNTERS. STATEWIDE HARVEST ESTIMATES ARE CALCULATED FOR PHEASANT (PHASIANUS COLCHICUS), RACCOON (PROCYON LOTOR), BEAVER (CASTOR CANADENSIS), FOX SQUIRREL (SCIURUS NIGER), RED FOX (VULPES FULVA), QUAIL (COLINUS VIRGINIANUS AND CALLIPEPLA S. QUAMATA), GRAY FOX (UROCYON CINEREOARGENTEUS), JACKRABBIT (LEPUS CALIFORNICUS), COYOTE (CANIS LATRANS) SWAMP RABBIT (S. AQUATICUS), FALL TURKEY (MELEAGRIS GALLOPAVO SILVESTRIS AND M. G. INTERMEDIA), BOBCAT (LYNX RUFUS), RIVER OTTER (LUTRA CANADENSIS), GRAY SQUIRREL (S. CAROLINENSIS), WOODCOCK (SCOLOPAX MINOR), CROW (CORVUS BRACHYRHYNCHOS), DOVE (ZENAIDA MACROURA), COTTONTAIL (SYLVILAGUS FLORIDANUS), AND SPRING TURKEY (MELEAGRIS GALLOPAVO SILVESTRIS AND M. G. INTERMEDIA). IN ADDITION TO HARVEST ESTIMATES, A SERIES OF HUMAN DIMENSIONS QUESTIONS ARE ASKED TO LEARN ABOUT A VARIETY OF TOPICS THAT WILL ASSIST WILDLIFE MANAGERS IN SETTING SEASON DATES AND HARVEST LIMITS. WE ALSO GAIN OPINION FEEDBACK ON REGULATIONS AND CAN BETTER UNDERSTAND MOTIVATIONS AND BARRIERS TO AN ACTIVITY WITH THESE QUESTIONS. THESE CHANGE EACH YEAR BASED ON WHAT BIOLOGISTS FEEL THEY WOULD LIKE TO KNOW FROM THE PUBLIC.

THIS GRANT SUPPORTS THE OVERALL COORDINATION AND ADMINISTRATION OF WILDLIFE RESTORATION PROGRAM GRANTS BY THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION (ODWC). IN THE LAST TWO YEARS, OKLAHOMA HAS BEEN APPORTIONED OVER  25M EACH YEAR UNDER THE PITTMAN-ROBERTSON WILDLIFE RESTORATION ACT. THESE FUNDS ARE ADMINISTERED BY THE WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM OF THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND USED BY THE STATE THROUGH APPROVED GRANT AGREEMENTS FOR ELIGIBLE PROJECTS. APPROVED PROJECTS MUST HAVE AS THEIR OBJECTIVE THE RESTORATION, CONSERVATION, MANAGEMENT, OR ENHANCEMENT OF WILD BIRDS, WILD MAMMALS, OR PROVIDE FOR PUBLIC USE AND BENEFIT FROM THESE RESOURCES. THE USE OF THESE FUNDS THROUGH NUMEROUS AND VARIED GRANT AGREEMENTS REQUIRES CONSIDERABLE COORDINATION AND ADMINISTRATION, FROM THE APPLICATION PROCESS THROUGH POST-CLOSEOUT. TO MAINTAIN ELIGIBILITY FOR THE PROGRAMS, THE DEPARTMENT MUST ESTABLISH AND MAINTAIN MANAGEMENT CONTROL SYSTEMS ADEQUATE TO MEET REQUIREMENTS FOR PARTICIPATION IN THESE FEDERAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS, AND MUST COMPLY WITH APPLICABLE FEDERAL LAWS AND REGULATIONS. THE BENEFIT OF THE GRANT EFFORTS WILL BE STATEWIDE, BUT THE MAJORITY OF ACTIVITIES WILL BE CARRIED OUT IN AN OFFICE SETTING, AT ODWC HEADQUARTERS IN OKLAHOMA CITY. IT IS ESTIMATED THAT 150 AWARDS WILL BE COORDINATED DURING TWO YEARS OF PERFORMANCE (STATE FY24 AND FY25).

THE IMPORTANCE OF HUNTER RECREATION RELATED TO WHITE-WINGED DOVES IS CONSIDERABLE. WHILE MOURNING DOVE POPULATION MANAGEMENT HAS RECEIVED CONSIDERABLE MANAGEMENT ATTENTION RECENTLY PROGRAMS ESTIMATING POPULATION DEMOGRAPHIC PARAMETERS TO ASSIST MANAGERS WITH HARVEST DECISIONS FOR WHITE-WINGED DOVES WERE ONLY RECENTLY DEVELOPED (COLLIER ET AL. 2012A, B). CURRENTLY, TEXAS REPRESENTS THE PRIMARY CONTINENTAL UNITED STATES RANGE OF THE EASTERN, MEXICAN HIGHLAND, UPPER BIG BEND, AND WESTERN BREEDING POPULATIONS OF WHITE-WINGED DOVES (ZENAIDA ASIATICA) (GEORGE ET AL. 1994). IN TEXAS, WHITE-WINGED DOVES CURRENTLY BREED IN  200 COUNTIES VERSUS  10 IN 1980 AND ONLY 16  OF THE WHITE-WINGED DOVE BREEDING POPULATION IN TEXAS OCCURS IN THE TRADITIONAL BREEDING SITES IN THE LOWER RIO GRANDE VALLEY. OUTSIDE THE HISTORIC RANGE, WHITE-WINGED DOVES ARE PREDOMINATELY SELECTING FOR URBAN ENVIRONMENTS (COLLIER ET AL. 2013) AND PRELIMINARY EVIDENCE FROM TEXAS SUGGESTS MOST WHITE-WINGED DOVES BREED IN THE RESIDENTIAL CORE OF CITIES WHICH HAS UNKNOWN IMPACTS ON REPRODUCTION, SURVIVAL, AND HARVEST.
THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO ACQUIRE ADDITIONAL ACREAGE FOR THE DEMONSTRATION OF CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES FOR INDIGENOUS WILDLIFE SPECIES OF THE EDWARDS PLATEAU ECOSYSTEM OF TEXAS.

USING CONTEMPORARY POPULATION GENETIC APPROACHES, WE WILL ASSESS THE RELATIVE CONTRIBUTION OF VARIOUS EASTERN WILD TURKEY (MELEAGRIS GALLOPAVO SILVESTRIS) SUPER-STOCKING SOURCES ON THE CURRENT WILD TURKEY POPULATION IN EASTERN TEXAS. IN ADDITION, BASED ON RELEASE HISTORIES, WE WILL TEST FOR HYBRIDIZATION BETWEEN RIO GRANDE WILD TURKEY (MELEAGRIS GALLOPAVO INTERMEDIA) AND EASTERN WILD TURKEY, INCLUDING FOR HYBRID VIGOR AMONG THE EXISTING WILD TURKEY POPULATION ACROSS THE POST OAK ECOREGION. THE GOAL OF OUR PROJECT IS TO DETERMINE IF ANY SUPER-STOCKING SOURCE CONTRIBUTED MORE TO THE SUCCESS OF EASTERN WILD TURKEY POPULATIONS THAN OTHERS IN THE POST OAK ECOREGION. IF SO, A BEST PRACTICE IN FUTURE TRANSLOCATION EFFORTS WOULD BE TO SOURCE INDIVIDUALS FROM THOSE REGIONS SHOWING THE GREATEST SUCCESS IN TEXAS. ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL USE CONTEMPORARY LANDSCAPE GENETIC ANALYSES TO UNDERSTAND GENE FLOW AMONG EASTERN WILD TURKEY IN TEXAS. AFTER DETERMINING GENE FLOW, WE WILL ESTIMATE LEVELS OF FUNCTIONAL DISPERSAL AMONG WILD TURKEY SAMPLE LOCATIONS TO GAIN INSIGHTS INTO HOW CURRENT LAND MANAGEMENT FOR TURKEYS IS INFLUENCING DISPERSAL AND SURVIVAL OF THE SPECIES IN EASTERN TEXAS. COLLECTIVELY, THESE DATA WILL PROVIDE NEEDED INSIGHTS INTO WILD TURKEY  LANDSCAPE DYNAMICS ACROSS EAST TEXAS. THESE METHODS WILL ALLOW US TO EVALUATE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN LANDSCAPE  SUPER-STOCK SOURCE GENETIC DIVERSITY AND HOW THEY INTERACT TO AFFECT LOCAL POPULATION SUCCESS. THIS INFORMATION WILL ALLOW TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT TO BETTER PLAN LANDMANAGEMENT, IDENTIFY RELEASE SITE HABITAT, AND SELECT SUCCESSFUL SOURCE POPULATIONS FOR SUSTAINING AND IMPROVING WILD TURKEY POPULATIONS ACROSS THE REGION.
