FOLLOWING A LARGE FIRE IN THE REGION OF WHITE PEAK, NEW MEXICO IN THE SUMMER OF 2022, SEVERAL PUBLIC ACCESS POINTS WERE SEVERELY IMPACTED BY EROSION THEREBY LIMITING HUNTER ACCESS TO TENS OF THOUSANDS OF ACRES IN NORTHEASTERN NEW MEXICO. ONE SUCH PUBLIC ACCESS AREA NEAR WHITE PEAK, ROAD 199, WAS ALMOST COMPLETELY DESTROYED BY MONSOONAL RAINS. ROAD 199 IS THE ONLY ACCESS POINT FOR RECREATIONAL USERS TO ACCESS PUBLIC LANDS IN THE VICINITY OF WHITE PEAK.

THE TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT (TPWD) HAS LONG RECOGNIZED A NEED FOR ADDITIONAL WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS (WMA) IN THE CROSS TIMBERS AND PRAIRIES ECOREGION WHERE STAFF CAN DEVELOP AND MANAGE HABITATS AND POPULATIONS OF INDIGENOUS AND MIGRATORY WILDLIFE SPECIES, CONDUCT WILDLIFE RELATED RESEARCH INVESTIGATIONS, PROVIDE DEMONSTRATION AND OUTREACH OPPORTUNITIES FOR PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, AND PROVIDE FOR ADDITIONAL WILDLIFE DEPENDENT RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. APPROXIMATELY 2,190 ACRES OF THE COLONEL BURNS RANCH, A PRIVATELY OWNED PROPERTY LOCATED IN NORTHEASTERN BROWN COUNTY, TEXAS AND ADJACENT TO THE MCGILLIVRAY AND LEONA MCKIE MUSE WMA IS CURRENTLY BEING OFFERED FOR SALE TO TPWD.

THE ENTERPRISE FIELD OFFICE HAS ALWAYS LACKED AN ENCLOSED SHOP SPACE FOR ODFW AND THEIR EQUIPMENT. THIS HASRESULTED IN VALUABLE EQUIPMENT BEING STORED OUTSIDE AND, IN THE ELEMENTS, WHICH HAS SHORTED THE LIFE OF ATVS,BOATS, SNOW MACHINES, AND OTHER EQUIPMENT. THE CURRENT SITUATION ALSO MAKES THIS EQUIPMENT MORE PRONE TO THEFTAND DAMAGE SINCE THE COMPOUND IS NOT GATED AND FENCED ON ALL SIDES. IN ADDITION, THERE IS NO DEDICATED SPACE FORMANDATORY ANIMAL CHECK-INS AND PROCESSING  THEREFORE, THESE CHECK-INS OCCUR EITHER OUTSIDE OR IN THE MAIN OFFICEBUILDING. DURING INCLEMENT WEATHER WHEN ANIMAL SAMPLING PROCESSING OCCURS IN THE MAIN OFFICE BUILDING LEADS TODISTRACTING AND UNSANITARY CONDITIONS IN STAFF WORKSPACES. HAVING THIS DEDICATED ENCLOSED SHOP WILL PROTECTVALUABLE EQUIPMENT, OFFER STORAGE AND MAINTENANCE AREAS, AND ALLOW SPACE FOR ANIMAL CHECK-IN AND PROCESSING.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO MANAGE NEW YORK S WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA SYSTEM, WHICH COMPRISES NEARLY 250,000 ACRES OF WILD LAND, TO MANAGE WILDLIFE HABITAT AND TO PROVIDE PUBLIC ACCESS AND OPPORTUNITY FOR WILDLIFE-DEPENDENT RECREATION INCLUDING WILDLIFE OBSERVATION, HUNTING, TRAPPING, AND PHOTOGRAPHY. THE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION WILL ACCOMPLISH THESE GOALS BY DEVELOPING WMA HABITAT AND ACCESS PLANS  MANAGING INVASIVE SPECIES  SELECTIVELY CUTTING TREES, SHRUBS, AND GRASSES TO MAINTAIN DESIRED HABITATS  MANAGING WATER LEVELS IN IMPOUNDMENTS AND WETLANDS  CONDUCTING PRESCRIBED BURNS TO IMPROVE HABITATS  AND MAINTAINING PUBLIC ACCESS POINTS AND AMENITIES INCLUDING PARKING LOTS, ROADS, TRAILS, BOARDWALKS, BOAT LAUNCHES, AND OBSERVATION BLINDS AND TOWERS. THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THESE ACTIVITIES INCLUDE CONSERVATION OF WILDLIFE, BIODIVERSITY, AND HABITAT AS WELL AS SAFE AND CONVENIENT PUBLIC ACCESS, INCLUDING RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES. SECONDARY BENEFITS INCLUDE THE PROTECTION OF AIR, SOIL, AND WATER QUALITY  CARBON SEQUESTRATION AND STORAGE  AND PERMANENT PROTECTION OF OPEN SPACE FROM DEVELOPMENT. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THESE ACTIVITIES ARE ALL NEW YORKERS AND VISITORS. THERE ARE NO SUB-RECIPIENTS OF THIS GRANT.
THIS GRANT WILL FUND ADMINISTRATION AND COORDINATION OF WR GRANTS IN NORTH CAROLINA.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFES (CDFW) INLAND DESERTS REGION (IDR) LANDS NORTH PROGRAM IS RESPONSIBLE FOR MANAGING APPROXIMATELY 100,000 ACRES OF ECOLOGICAL RESERVES AND WILDLIFE AREAS. THE AREAS INCLUDE DIVERSE HABITATS FROM DESERT SCRUB TO GREAT BASIN SCRUB TO MONTANE MEADOWS WHICH SUPPORT A WIDE ARRAY OF FISH, WILDLIFE, AND PLANT SPECIES. THESE LANDS ALSO PROVIDE WILDLIFE VIEWING, FISHING, AND HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO SUPPORT ECOLOGICALLY SOUND, SCIENCE-BASED WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE DATA COLLECTION, RESEARCH AND MONITORING ON THE HEALTH, ABUNDANCE, DISTRIBUTION, AND HARVEST OF WILDLIFE IN CONNECTICUT. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE MAINTAINING HEALTHY AND SUSTAINABLE POPULATIONS OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES WITHIN BIOLOGICAL AND CULTURAL LIMITS, WHICH SUPPORTS THE BUREAU OF NATURAL RESOURCES  MISSION OF CONSERVATION. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PUBLIC WHO USE AND APPRECIATE THESE NATURAL RESOURCES.

TO ACQUIRE BY FEE SIMPLE ACQUISITION AN APPROXIMATELY 790-ACRE PRIVATE INHOLDING WITHIN THE YELLOWBANK WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA IN BRECKINRIDGE COUNTY, KENTUCKY, UTILIZING WILDLIFE RESTORATION FUNDS.NON-FEDERAL MATCH SHALL BE PROVIDED THROUGH THE APPRAISED VALUE OF AN EXISTING 100  STATE-PURCHASED, NON-FEDERAL PARCEL KNOWN AS GABBARDS BRANCH WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA. THE MATCH VALUE OF THE PARCEL HAS BEEN DETERMINED BY STATE CERTIFIED APPRAISERS AND REVIEWED BY A CERTIFIED REVIEW APPRAISER. YELLOW BOOK GUIDELINES WERE UTILIZED. THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) GRANT CONDITIONS WILL BE ADDED TO ANY RELEVANT DEEDS.
FUNDS FROM THIS GRANT AWARD WILL BE USED TO CONTINUE MAINTENANCE ACTIVITIES OF HUNTER FACILITIES AND OBTAIN DATA ON GOAT PIG HUNTING AND HUNTER EFFORT AND SUCCESS ON MONA ISLAND, PUERTO RICO .
FUNDS FROM THIS GRANT AWARD WILL BE USED TO COORDINATE AND MONITOR WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION GRANTS AND GRANT PROJECTS IN PUERTO RICO

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) WILL CONTINUE A BIG GAME AND CARNIVORE GENETICS ASSESSMENT PROJECT TO HELP MONITOR BIG GAME AND CARNIVORE POPULATIONS, ANALYZE SPECIES TAXONOMIC STATUS, IDENTIFY MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION UNITS BASED ON NEUTRAL AND ADAPTIVE GENETIC VARIATION, AND DEVELOP AN ARCHIVE OF REFERENCE GENETIC SAMPLES TO FACILITATE FUTURE RESEARCH. THIS PROJECT WILL GREATLY ASSIST CDFW S WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES AND PRIORITIES. THIS NARRATIVE OUTLINES THE ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED DURING THE 2023 2024 YEAR (I.E., YEAR 8) OF A LARGER MULTI-YEAR PROJECT, PHASED IN EACH SUCCESSIVE YEAR WITH ANNUAL 12-MONTH OBJECTIVES DELIVERABLES. IT WILL SUPPORT THE CDFW WILDLIFE BRANCH S NEEDS FOR LARGE MAMMAL AND CARNIVORE FOCUSED GENETIC RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT, WITH THE FULL IMPLEMENTATION OVER YEARS TO INCLUDE A GREATER DIVERSITY OF SPECIES, AS THE NEED AND FUNDING ARE AVAILABLE.

THE NATIONAL BOBWHITE AND GRASSLANDS INITIATIVE (NBGI) IS A COOPERATIVE CONSERVATION INITIATIVE COMPRISED OF 25 STATES ACROSS THE RANGE OF THE NORTHERN BOBWHITE. THE GOALS OF THE NBGI ARE TO INCREASE AND IMPROVE HABITAT FOR NORTHERN BOBWHITE AND ASSOCIATED GRASSLAND SHUBLAND SPECIES THROUGH COORDINATED IMPLEMENTATION, OUTREACH, AND MONITORING ACROSS THE ENTIRETY OF THE BOBWHITES RANGE. COORDINATED EFFORTS AMONG STATES INCREASES FINANCIAL EFFICIENCIES, AVOIDS DUPLICATION OF EFFORT, RESULT IN TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT AND SHARING, AND ULTIMATELY RESULT IN GREATER HABITAT AND POPULATION INCREASES. RESULTS AND PRODUCTS OF THE NBGI AND ASSOCIATED STATES WILL ACCRUE ADDITIONAL SOCIETAL BENEFITS INCLUDING IMPROVED AND INCREASED OUTDOOR RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES, HABITAT RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT FOR MULTIPLE SPECIES INCLUDING POLLINATORS, CONSERVATION OF SOIL, AND IMPROVEMENTS IN WATER AND AIR QUALITY.

THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS PORTIONS OF THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) WILDLIFE DIVERSITY PROGRAM S (WDP) EFFORTS TO MONITOR, CONSERVE AND RESTORE NONGAME BIRDS AND MAMMALS IN CALIFORNIA, INCLUDING NUMEROUS LISTED AND SPECIAL STATUS SPECIES. WDP SCIENTIFIC STAFF ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE MANAGEMENT, CONSERVATION, AND RECOVERY OF NATIVE NONGAME BIRDS, MAMMALS, AMPHIBIANS, AND REPTILES. THIS PROJECT WILL FUND STAFF TO CONDUCT SURVEYS FOR SHOREBIRDS AND FOREST CARNIVORES, PARTICIPATE IN NUMEROUS WORKING GROUPS, ADVISORY COMMITTEES, STAKEHOLDER GROUPS, AND SCIENCE TEAMS, PARTICIPATE IN THE PACIFIC FLYWAY COUNCIL, PREPARE SPECIES CONSERVATION STRATEGIES AND MANAGEMENT ACTIONS, AND COLLATE AND PRIORITIZE INFORMATION AND MANAGEMENT NEEDS FOR SEMI-FOSSORIAL SMALL MAMMALS. FOCAL SPECIES ADDRESSED BY PROJECT INCLUDE THE STATE AND OR FEDERALLY LISTED MAMMALS SIERRA NEVADA RED FOX, WOLVERINE, AND MOHAVE GROUND SQUIRREL  THE STATE AND OR FEDERALLY LISTED BIRDS SNOWY PLOVER, LEAST TERN, BELL S VIREO, BANK SWALLOW, WILLOW FLYCATCHER, RIDGWAY S RAIL, AND YELLOW-BILLED CUCKOO  NUMEROUS MAMMAL SPECIES OF SPECIAL CONCERN  AND NUMEROUS NONGAME SHOREBIRDS. THE OVERARCHING PROJECT GOAL IS TO MONITOR AND CONSERVE THESE AND ADDITIONAL SPECIES TO ENSURE THE LONG-TERM VIABILITY OF THEIR POPULATIONS. CDFW WILL ALSO ASSESS THE STATUS OF OTHER CARNIVORES THAT CO-OCCUR WITH CARNIVORE SPECIES OF CONSERVATION CONCERN (E.G., SIERRA NEVADA RED FOX, WOLVERINE) IN MONTANE AND SUBALPINE HABITATS, WITH THE GOAL OF MONITORING AND MAINTAINING THE CARNIVORE COMMUNITY IN THESE HABITATS. IN CALIFORNIA, 181 ANIMAL SPECIES ARE LISTED AS THREATENED OR ENDANGERED PURSUANT TO THE CALIFORNIA ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (CESA) AND OR THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. ADDITIONALLY, 213 ANIMAL SPECIES HAVE BEEN DESIGNATED SPECIES OF SPECIAL CONCERN. CDFW STAFF IMPLEMENT DIVERSE CONSERVATION ACTIONS TO PROTECT THESE SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS, AS WELL AS NUMEROUS ADDITIONAL NONGAME SPECIES. ADDITIONAL SURVEYS AND DATA ANALYSIS ARE NEEDED FOR MANY OF THESE SPECIES, AND ONGOING RECOVERY AND MANAGEMENT EFFORTS (OFTEN INVOLVING STAFF FROM OTHER AGENCIES, UNIVERSITIES, AND GROUPS) ARE IN PLACE FOR MANY SPECIES. THIS PROJECT WILL FUND CDFW STAFF TO CONTINUE TO GATHER DATA ON IMPERILED SPECIES AND TO WORK TO CONSERVE A VARIETY OF SPECIAL STATUS AND NONGAME BIRDS AND MAMMALS.

THIS GRANT FUNDS THE ACQUISITION OF LAND FOR WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS THROUGHOUT MINNESOTA. THESE LANDS ARE MANAGED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES TO SUPPORT WILDLIFE HABITAT, WILDLIFE POPULATIONS, PUBLIC HUNTING AND TRAPPING AND OTHER COMPATIBLE OUTDOOR RECREATION.

THE WEST VIRGINIA DIVISION OF NATURAL RESOURCES, WILDLIFE RESOURCES SECTION IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF OUR STATE-S WILDLIFE RESOURCES AND FOR PROVIDING WILDLIFE-ASSOCIATED RECREATION FOR THE CITIZENS OF OUR STATE. PERCEIVED DECLINES IN WI D TURKEY POPULATIONS HAVE SPARKED AN INCREASED INTEREST FROM WILDLIFE BIOLOGISTS, HUNTERS AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC IN THE FAST TWO DECADES. CONCERNS ABOUT HUNTING SEASON STRUCTURE, NESTING AND BROOD HABITAT, HEN AND POULT SURVIVAL, AND HUNTER SATISFACTION HAVE ALL BEEN DISCUSSED BY BIOLOGISTS AS CONTRIBUTING FACTORS TO DECLINES IN TURKEY HARVEST. THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO STUDY HUNTER OPINIONS AND POPULATION DYNAMICS OF WILD TURKEY AND IN WEST VIRGINIA. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS GRANT ARE TO: 1. EVALUATE WILD TURKEY REPRODUCTION AND RECRUITMENT IN WEST VIRGINIA  2. EVALUATE WILD TURKEY SPATIAL ECOLOGY IN WEST VIRGINIA  3. EVALUATE WILD TURKEY POPULATION DYNAMICS AND SEASONAL SURVIVAL IN WEST VIRGINIA  AND 4. EVALUATE THE HUMAN DIMENSIONS OF WILD TURKEY MANAGEMENT IN WEST VIRGINIA.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) WILL CONTINUE TO STRATEGICALLY EVALUATE, PRIORITIZE, ANDIMPLEMENT RESEARCH PROJECTS THROUGH THE HUMAN DIMENSIONS OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION (HD) UNIT. THE HD UNIT WORKS TO UNDERSTAND HOW STAKEHOLDERS (CDFW STAFF, KEY STAKEHOLDERS, THE PUBLIC) PERCEIVE WILDLIFE CONSERVATION ISSUESUSING ROBUST AND DEFENSIBLE SOCIAL SCIENCE METHODOLOGIES (E.G. SURVEY INSTRUMENTS, FOCUS GROUPS, INTERVIEWS,CONTENT ANALYSES, EXPERIMENTS). THE HD UNIT APPLIES THIS RESEARCH TO ADDRESS PRIORITY AND CONTENTIOUS WILDLIFECONSERVATION ISSUES AND TO DETERMINE HOW CDFW CAN MOST EFFECTIVELY INCREASE MEANINGFUL PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT,INVESTMENT, AND BROAD SUPPORT FOR CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES.CALIFORNIA HAS TREMENDOUS DIVERSITY IN BOTH ITS WILDLIFE AND HUMAN POPULATIONS. THE DYNAMIC ENVIRONMENTAL,CULTURAL, AND SOCIAL CONDITIONS PRESENT MANY CHALLENGES IN EFFECTIVELY AND RESPONSIBLY MANAGING THE STATESWILDLIFE POPULATIONS. IT IS CRITICAL THAT CDFW INTUITIVELY ENGAGE IN SOCIAL SCIENCE IN CONJUNCTION WITHBIOLOGICAL AND ECOLOGICAL RESEARCH DUE TO CALIFORNIAS GEOGRAPHIC SIZE, SPECIES DIVERSITY AND DENSITY, AND OFTENCOMPLEX WILDLIFE ISSUES. UNDERSTANDING PUBLIC VALUES AND PERCEPTION OF THE STATES WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT ANDCONSERVATION APPROACH CAN HELP GUIDE FUTURE IMPLEMENTATION, DEVELOPMENT, AND OUTREACH STRATEGIES OR PLANS. THE HD UNIT WILL CONTINUE TO RESEARCH AND EVALUATE SOCIAL AND CULTURAL ATTITUDES, BEHAVIORS, AND VALUES REGARDINGWILDLIFE RESOURCES AND CONSERVATION BY THE PUBLIC IN CALIFORNIA. THE HD UNITS FUNCTION AND ROLE CONDUCTING THISRESEARCH IS CONSISTENT WITH THE CDFW DIRECTORS SCIENCE INSTITUTE (SCIENTIFIC INITIATIVE TO INCREASE SCIENTIFICCAPACITY), THE GOVERNORS BIODIVERSITY INITIATIVE, AND STATE LEGISLATION (AB 2402).THE HD UNIT WILL SUPPORT CDFW IN ACHIEVING ITS MISSION THROUGH INFORMED DECISION-MAKING THAT CONSIDERS THEDIVERSITY OF PUBLIC INPUT FOR DEVELOPING WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES. THE HD UNIT WILLCONTINUE TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT STRATEGIES TO UNDERSTAND THE PERSPECTIVES OF CALIFORNIAS DIVERSECONSTITUENCIES AND STAKEHOLDERS, TO HELP IDENTIFY PRIORITY CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ISSUES (E.G. PREDATORMANAGEMENT  WILDLIFE INCIDENT REPORTING  HUMAN-WILDLIFE INTERACTIONS AND CONFLICT MITIGATION  HUNTER RECRUITMENT,RETENTION, AND REACTIVATION (R3)  NEW EMERGING WILDLIFE ISSUES BEING DISCUSSED BY THE PUBLIC OR STAKEHOLDERCOMMUNITY, AND DETERMINE HOW TO MOST EFFECTIVELY ADDRESS THESE ISSUES. THESE ISSUES MAY BE EXACERBATED BYEXTERNAL EVENTS, BOTH ENVIRONMENTAL (E.G. DROUGHT, FIRE, CLIMATE CHANGE), ECONOMIC (E.G. EXURBAN DEVELOPMENT),AND OTHER USES THAT PUT PRESSURE ON WILD POPULATIONS AND ECOSYSTEMS.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) IS COMPRISED OF SIX INLAND REGIONS AND ONE MARINE REGION. THE CENTRAL REGION WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (CRWMP) IS RESPONSIBLE FOR WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT ISSUES WITHIN THE 12 COUNTY REGION. THE PROJECT AREA WITHIN THE REGION INCLUDES THE COUNTIES OF STANISLAUS, TUOLUMNE, MERCED, MARIPOSA, MADERA, FRESNO, KINGS, TULARE, KERN, SAN BENITO, MONTEREY, AND SAN LUIS OBISPO. WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE THE COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS OF DATA REGARDING THE CONDITION OF WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND HABITATS, MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF GAME BIRDS AND MAMMALS, PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO OTHER AGENCIES REGARDING RESOURCE ISSUES, PUBLIC OUTREACH, AND PUBLIC USE. THESE RESPONSIBILITIES REQUIRE EXTENSIVE COMMUNICATION AND COORDINATION WITH OTHER AGENCIES, CDFW STAFF, AND THE PUBLIC.

PROJECT ABSTRACT ESTABLISHED IN 1941, THE WILDLIFE HEALTH LABORATORY (WHL, FORMERLY THE WILDLIFE INVESTIGATIONS LABORATORY) WITHIN THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) IS MANDATED TO PROVIDE SERVICE AND EXPERTISE TO RESPOND TO ANY WILDLIFE MORBIDITY AND MORTALITY EVENT IN CALIFORNIA. THIS RESPONSIBILITY REQUIRES THE NEED FOR EXTENSIVE COMMUNICATION, COORDINATION, AND TRAINING WITH OTHER AGENCIES, CDFW REGIONAL AND LAW ENFORCEMENT STAFF, AND THE PUBLIC. THIS IS PARTICULARLY IMPORTANT FOR SUPPORTING STAFF IN CDFW WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT, HABITAT CONSERVATION, AND LANDS (E.G., WATERFOWL BOTULISM   AVIAN CHOLERA, UNGULATE HEMORRHAGIC DISEASE EVENTS, PESTICIDE USAGE IN ILLEGAL CANNABIS GROWS).THE WHL S MISSION IS TO INVESTIGATE, MONITOR, AND MANAGE WILDLIFE POPULATION HEALTH ISSUES IN CALIFORNIA. AS THE DEFINITION OF HEALTH HAS BROADENED SO HAS WHL S DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES. IN ADDITION TO PROVIDING LEADERSHIP, TRAINING, AND DIRECTION FOR STATEWIDE RESPONSE TO WILDLIFE DISEASE AND MORTALITY EVENTS, WILDLIFE CAPTURE, AND ANIMAL WELFARE, WHL HAS LEADERSHIP ROLES IN SCIENTIFIC DEVELOPMENT THAT INCLUDES COLLABORATIVE SUPPORT OF PROJECT DEVELOPMENT, STUDY DESIGN, ANALYSIS, AND REPORTING. THROUGH THESE AND OTHER ROLES, THE WHL SUPPORTS AND LEADS PROJECTS THAT TOUCH ON MOST ASPECTS OF TERRESTRIAL WILDLIFE IN CALIFORNIA. THE WHL OVERSEES THE COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS OF BIOLOGICAL SAMPLES FROM WILDLIFE FOR DISEASE SURVEILLANCE AND MORTALITY MORBIDITY INVESTIGATIONS. VETERINARIANS AND BIOLOGISTS AT WHL CONDUCT NECROPSIES  DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT WILDLIFE DISEASE SURVEILLANCE, MONITORING, AND MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS  AND TRAIN CDFW STAFF AND PARTNERS IN DISEASE INVESTIGATIONS AND SAMPLING AS NECESSARY TO MONITOR THE HEALTH AND CONDITION OF WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND TO AID MANAGERS IN EVALUATING POTENTIAL EFFECTS THAT MAY INFLUENCE HARVEST REGULATIONS. DISEASE SURVEILLANCE PROGRAMS MANAGED BY THE WHL FOR CALIFORNIA S SPECIES INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO, CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE (CWD), TREPONEME-ASSOCIATED HOOF DISEASE (TAHD), AND MYCOPLASMA OVIPNEUMONIAE. EPIDEMIOLOGIC DATA FROM THESE EFFORTS PROVIDE VALUABLE INFORMATION NEEDED FOR EFFECTIVE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AS ANIMALS ARE AFFECTED BY DROUGHT CONDITIONS AND CLIMATE CHANGE, WILDFIRE, AND EMERGING INFECTIOUS DISEASES, INCLUDING SARS-COV-2 AND RABBIT HEMORRHAGIC DISEASE (RHDV2), THAT ARE INCREASING IN OR THREATENING WILDLIFE POPULATIONS. IN ADDITION TO DISEASE SURVEILLANCE AND MANAGEMENT, THE WHL SUPPORTS SPECIES MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS AT CDFW BY PROVIDING EXPERTISE AND TRAINING IN THE SAFE CAPTURE AND HANDLING OF WILDLIFE, DATA COLLECTION, STUDY DESIGN, GENETICS, AND INVESTIGATIONS FOR PESTICIDES AND CONTAMINANTS. THE WHL IS MANAGING MORE AND MORE SPECIES-RELATED SAMPLES AND DATA COLLECTED THROUGH ANIMAL CAPTURES AND DISEASE INVESTIGATIONS. INCREASINGLY, THE WHL IS PROVIDING LEADERSHIP, TRAINING, AND EXPERTISE FOR HUMAN WILDLIFE CONFLICTS ASSOCIATED WITH GAME SPECIES SUCH AS MOUNTAIN LIONS, BLACK BEARS, COYOTES, DEER, AND ELK.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) UPLAND GAME UNIT IS TASKED WITH MANAGING HABITAT AND POPULATIONS OF RESIDENT AND MIGRATORY UPLAND GAME BIRDS AND VARIOUS SMALL MAMMAL SPECIES IN THE STATE. THESE SPECIES PROVIDE EXTENSIVE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITY THROUGHOUT THE STATE, WHETHER IT BE NON-CONSUMPTIVE USE (E.G., BIRD WATCHING) OR CONSUMPTIVE USE (I.E., HUNTING). TO HUNT UPLAND BIRDS, HUNTERS ARE REQUIRED TO PURCHASE A CALIFORNIA UPLAND GAME BIRD VALIDATION, THE SALES OF WHICH ARE IN TURN USED TO FUND GRANTS FOR PROJECTS THAT BENEFIT UPLAND GAME BIRD SPECIES AND ARE USED AS MATCH FOR THIS GRANT APPLICATION. GENERAL MANAGEMENT GUIDANCE, AS DIRECTED BY THE FISH AND GAME COMMISSION, IS PROVIDED THROUGH MANAGEMENT PLANS WITH THE GOAL OF INFORMING RESTORATION, MAINTENANCE, AND ENHANCEMENT OF UPLAND GAME BIRD POPULATIONS AND THEIR HABITATS COMMENSURATE WITH THE OPTIMUM MANAGEMENT OPPORTUNITIES ON BOTH PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS. MANAGEMENT GUIDANCE OF MOST RESIDENT UPLAND BIRDS FALLS SOLELY UPON THIS UNIT WHILE MANAGEMENT OF THE IMPERILED GREATER SAGE-GROUSE AND MIGRATORY UPLAND BIRDS (I.E., DOVES, PIGEONS, AND SNIPE), OCCUR THROUGH COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS. FOR RESIDENT UPLAND BIRDS, THE UNIT HAS A FUNDAMENTAL NEED TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT MONITORING STRATEGIES FOR UPLAND BIRD SPECIES. THESE MONITORING STRATEGIES WILL INCORPORATE THE LATEST SCIENTIFIC APPROACHES WITH THE GOAL OF BEING LONG-TERM ANNUAL MONITORING FOR UPLAND BIRD SPECIES. THE UNIT CURRENTLY USES THE BREEDING BIRD SURVEY AND INTERNAL CROW COUNTS FOR PHEASANTS TO ESTIMATE ABUNDANCE.THE UPLAND GAME BIRD ACCOUNT (UGBA) WAS CREATED AS A DEDICATED ACCOUNT UNDER THE FISH AND GAME PRESERVATION FUND TO PROVIDE A SOURCE OF FUNDING TO BENEFIT UPLAND GAME POPULATIONS, HABITATS, AND HUNTERS. IT IS MANAGED BY THE UPLAND GAME UNIT IN CONJUNCTION WITH AN EXTERNAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE WHICH PROVIDES INPUT AND OVERSIGHT. THIS ACCOUNT PRODUCES ROUGHLY  1.5 MILLION DOLLARS OF SPENDING AUTHORITY ANNUALLY, WHICH IS THEN DISTRIBUTED TO THIS UNIT, GAME PROGRAMS WITHIN THE SIX CDFW REGIONS AND CDFW ADMINISTRATION. PART OF THE ALLOCATION PROVIDED TO THE UPLAND GAME UNIT IS USED FOR MATCH FUNDING FOR THIS GRANT APPLICATION BUT ALSO AS A COMPETITIVE EXTERNAL GRANT TO FUND PROJECTS THAT BENEFIT UPLAND GAME BIRDS AND HUNTERS. THESE GRANTS NOT ONLY PROVIDE MONEY BUT ALSO A PROCESS FOR ANNUAL INVOLVEMENT OF STAKEHOLDERS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO REPAIR THE BERM AND EYEBROW AT THE WILDCAT HILLS SHOOTING RANGE. THE WILDCATHILLS SHOOTING SPORTS COMPLEX, BUILT IN 2017 (ORIGINAL GRANT F14AF00504 - W-87-E-9), MAINTAINS A 20 FOOT BERM ONTHE SMALLBORE RANGE WITH AN EYEBROW THAT WAS DESIGNED AND BUILT INCORRECTLY UNDER THE ORIGINAL GRANT. THE ISSUESPLAGUING THE BERM HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AND A PLAN IS IN PLACE TO FIX THEM FOR USE BY FUTURE GENERATIONS. THESEISSUES INCLUDE IMPROPER WATER DRAINAGE AWAY FROM THE BERM RESULTING IN DAMAGE TO THE BERM ALONG WITH IMPROPERDESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION OF THE WOOD METAL EYEBROW LOCATED AT THE TOP OF THE BERM. IF LEFT UNFIXED, THE RANGEWILL NOT BE USABLE DUE TO SAFETY CONCERNS.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) ACQUIRES LANDS AND FACILITIES WITH A FOCUS ON CONSERVING BIODIVERSITY, PROTECTING SENSITIVE SPECIES, AND COMPATIBLE PUBLIC RECREATION WHERE APPROPRIATE. CDFW IS CURRENTLY RESPONSIBLE FOR 749 PROPERTIES ON MORE THAN 1.1 MILLION ACRES STATEWIDE, INCLUDING WILDLIFE AREAS, ECOLOGICAL RESERVES, PRIVATE LANDS WITH CONSERVATION EASEMENTS, FISH HATCHERIES, FISHING ACCESSES, AND OTHER PUBLIC ACCESS FACILITIES. THESE LANDS AND FACILITIES ARE DIRECTLY MANAGED, OPERATED, OR OVERSEEN BY STAFF IN ONE OF CDFW-S SIX TERRESTRIAL REGIONS. REGIONAL STAFF ARE ALSO RESPONSIBLE FOR DEVELOPING ACQUISITION PROPOSALS, CONDUCTING BIOLOGICAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCE ASSESSMENTS, AND DEVELOPING LAND MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR WILDLIFE AREAS AND ECOLOGICAL RESERVES. STAFF IN CDFW-S HEADQUARTERS LANDS PROGRAM ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR STATEWIDE COORDINATION OF REGIONAL STAFF TO ENSURE THEIR EFFORTS ARE CONSISTENT WITH BEST PRACTICES AND WITH CDFW POLICIES AND PRIORITIES. COORDINATING REGIONAL STAFF WHO ARE ACQUIRING, MONITORING, AND MANAGING LANDS AND FACILITIES IS CRITICAL TO ENSURING A CONSISTENT APPROACH TO IMPLEMENTING CDFW POLICIES AND ACHIEVING GOALS FOR CONSERVING BIODIVERSITY, PROTECTING SENSITIVE SPECIES, AND PROVIDING COMPATIBLE PUBLIC RECREATION. INFORMATION ON CULTURAL AND BIOLOGICAL RESOURCES IS NEEDED TO INFORM LAND ACQUISITION EFFORTS, AND TO DEVELOP MANAGEMENT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES. REGIONAL STAFF MUST MONITOR BIOLOGICAL RESOURCES TO UNDERSTAND THE BENEFITS AND CONSEQUENCES OF MANAGEMENT ACTIONS, PUBLIC USE, AND TO ENSURE THAT THE SPECIES ORIGINALLY TARGETED FOR CONSERVATION REMAIN VIABLE. TO MEET THE NEED FOR COMPREHENSIVE PLANNING FOR THE MANAGEMENT AND USE OF CDFW LANDS FOR THEIR WILDLIFE AND PUBLIC USE VALUES, CDFW DIRECTS ENERGY AND RESOURCES TO PREPARE AND UPDATE MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR DESIGNATED LANDS AND NEW ACQUISITIONS CONSISTENT WITH CDFW POLICY. THE BASIC COMPONENTS OF DEVELOPING A MANAGEMENT PLAN ARE TO REVIEW RELEVANT ACQUISITION DOCUMENTATION AND SCIENTIFIC LITERATURE, COMPILE DATA ON BIOLOGICAL AND PHYSICAL RESOURCES ON THE PROPERTY, IDENTIFY HABITAT AND SPECIES GOALS AND OBJECTIVES, AND PLAN APPROPRIATE MANAGEMENT (AND PUBLIC ACCESS WHERE APPROPRIATE) ACTIVITIES TO SUPPORT THOSE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES. HEADQUARTERS STAFF SUPPORT REGIONAL STAFF BY PROVIDING TECHNICAL AND POLICY GUIDANCE AND REVIEW. REGIONAL STAFF AND MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC OFTEN HAVE QUESTIONS REGARDING STATEWIDE POLICIES AND REGULATIONS FOR WILDLIFE AREAS AND ECOLOGICAL RESERVES AND CONTACT HEADQUARTERS STAFF TO OBTAIN ANSWERS. STAFF ALSO PREPARE AND  OR REVIEW INFORMATION ABOUT CDFW LANDS PRESENTED ON CDFW-S WEBSITE. OCCASIONALLY, WE PREPARE PRESENTATIONS FOR OTHER PUBLIC VENUES. PROACTIVELY PROVIDING THIS INFORMATION ENHANCES THE PUBLIC-S UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION OF CDFW LANDS. OVER TIME CDFW POLICIES REGARDING PUBLIC USES ON A STATEWIDE OR SITE-SPECIFIC BASIS NEED TO BE RE-EXAMINED, BECAUSE OF THE POPULARITY OF NEWER FORMS OF RECREATION, CHANGES TO SURROUNDING LAND USES, THE IMPLEMENTATION OF COOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT OF ADJACENT NATURAL AREAS OWNED BY DIFFERENT ENTITIES, OR THE EMERGENCE OF UNFORESEEN CONSEQUENCES OF AN AUTHORIZED USE OVER TIME.

THE CENTRAL VALLEY OF CALIFORNIA IS ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT WINTERING AREAS FOR WATERFOWL IN NORTH AMERICA, SUPPORTING APPROXIMATELY 60  OF THE PACIFIC FLYWAY POPULATION. HISTORICALLY, THE CENTRAL VALLEY CONTAINED MORE THAN 4 MILLION ACRES OF WETLANDS AND PROVIDED HABITAT FOR AN ESTIMATED 20 TO 40 MILLION WATERFOWL ANNUALLY. TODAY, LESS THAN 5  OF HISTORIC WETLANDS REMAIN, AND OF THOSE, TWO-THIRDS ARE IN PRIVATE OWNERSHIP. CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE-S (CDFW)-S WETLAND CONSERVATION PROGRAM (WCP) WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1990 AS A MECHANISM FOR THE CDFW TO ACCOMPLISH THE WETLAND PROTECTION, RESTORATION, AND ENHANCEMENT OBJECTIVES OF THE CENTRAL VALLEY JOINT VENTURE (CVJV). CDFW STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP 2015) IDENTIFIES WETLAND RESTORATION AND PARTNERSHIPS WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AS A HIGH PRIORITY TO REVERSE PAST WETLAND DECLINES. THE WCP ADDRESSES THESE NEEDS BY WORKING WITH BOTH THE PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SECTORS TO PROTECT, RESTORE, ENHANCE, AND IMPROVE MANAGEMENT OF CALIFORNIA-S WETLANDS FOR WATERFOWL AND OTHER WETLAND-DEPENDENT SPECIES. FOR THE 2023-24 GRANT TERM, WE ANTICIPATE THAT THE WCP WILL HAVE MANAGEMENT AGREEMENTS ON 56,417 ACRES OF PRIVATE LANDS AND HELP WITH THE ENHANCEMENT AND MANAGEMENT OF 173,773 ACRES OF PUBLIC LANDS STATEWIDE. CDFW IDENTIFIES THE FOLLOWING SPECIFIC CONSERVATION NEEDS TO INCREASE ACREAGE AND QUALITY OF FRESHWATER WETLANDS: -CDFW SHOULD STRENGTHEN ITS CAPACITY TO IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION ACTIONS AND TO ASSIST LOCAL AGENCIES AND LANDOWNERS WITH PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION OF WILDLIFE AND HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION EFFORTS. -WHILE NUMEROUS PRIVATE LANDOWNERS ARE LEADERS IN CONSERVATION, THE CDFW, THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS), NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION SERVICE (NRCS), AND LOCAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION DISTRICTS NEED TO EXPAND EFFORTS TO IMPROVE CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION ON PRIVATE LANDS BY ASSISTING PRIVATE LANDOWNERS. -PUBLIC AGENCIES AND PRIVATE ORGANIZATIONS SHOULD CONSERVE AND RESTORE WATER-DEPENDENT HABITATS (INCLUDING WETLAND, RIPARIAN, AND ESTUARINE) THROUGHOUT THE  CENTRAL VALLEY  REGION. IF THESE NEEDS ARE NOT MET FEWER WETLAND ACRES WILL BE RESTORED IN CALIFORNIA, AND CURRENT WETLAND ACRES UNDER STATE CONTROL (CDFW LANDS AND PRIVATE LANDS UNDER CONTRACT WITH CDFW) WILL BE LOWER IN QUALITY, DRASTICALLY REDUCING THE BENEFITS TO WETLAND-DEPENDENT WILDLIFE SPECIES.

THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR WILDLIFE CONSERVATION IN PUERTO RICO PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE SUPPORT PUERTORICO DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES (PRDNER) TO PROVIDE LANDOWNERSWITH MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AND ADDRESS CONCERNS TO PROTECT AND ENHANCE WILDLIFE HABITATS ONTHEIR PROPERTIES.

PIKES PEAK GUN CLUB, LOCATED IN EL PASO COUNTY, COLORADO, WILL USE THIS PROJECT TO IMPROVE THEIR ACCESS ROAD TO ENSURE VISITORS CAN EASILY REACH THEIR FACILITY. THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE THEIR IMPROVEMENTS, AND ALLOW FURTHER USE OF THE RANGE FOR SHOOTERS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO COVER THE COST FOR LEASE AND TAX PAYMENTS ASSOCIATED WITH PROPERTIES EITHER OWNED OR MANAGED BY FWP WHICH ARE PRIMARILY ASSOCIATED WITH WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AND HABITAT PROTECTION.

CALIFORNIA IS OCCUPIED BY AN ESTIMATED 6,000 TULE ELK (CERVUS CANADENSIS NANNODES), 6,000 ROOSEVELT ELK (C. C. ROOSEVELTI), 2,000 ROCKY MOUNTAIN ELK (C. C. NELSONI), AND 4,000 PRONGHORN (ANTILOCAPRA AMERICANA) THAT PROVIDE NUMEROUS RECREATIONAL AND ECONOMIC BENEFITS TO CALIFORNIANS. ALTHOUGH TULE ELK WERE ON THE BRINK OF EXTINCTION AND ROOSEVELT ELK WERE NEARLY EXTIRPATED FROM CALIFORNIA, THEY HAVE MADE REMARKABLE RECOVERIES AS A RESULT OF HUMAN MEDIATION AND ALL THREE SUBSPECIES OF ELK IN CALIFORNIA ARE STABLE OR INCREASING IN BOTH ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION. SIMULTANEOUSLY, PRONGHORN ABUNDANCE IN NORTHEASTERN CALIFORNIA HAS DECREASED RELATIVE TO HISTORIC LEVELS, AND SOME SHIFT IN DISTRIBUTION HAS OCCURRED. ABUNDANCE OF REINTRODUCED PRONGHORN POPULATIONS HAS ALSO DECREASED. DURING THE 1980S AND 1990S SEVERAL HUNDRED PRONGHORN WERE REINTRODUCED INTO HISTORIC RANGE IN CENTRAL AND SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA, BUT TODAY ONLY A FEW SMALL, FRAGMENTED POPULATIONS CONTINUE TO PERSIST IN THESE AREAS. CAUSES OF DIVERGENT POPULATION TRAJECTORIES BETWEEN ELK AND PRONGHORN POPULATIONS THROUGHOUT CALIFORNIA REMAIN UNCLEAR BUT MAY BE RELATED TO DIFFERENCES IN LIFE HISTORIES, INCLUDING DIFFERENCES IN BODY SIZE, PHYSIOLOGY, PHENOLOGY, HABITAT USE, REPRODUCTIVE AND PREDATOR AVOIDANCE STRATEGIES, DIET NUTRITION, AND RESPONSE TO STRESSORS SUCH AS PROLONGED DROUGHT CONDITIONS. BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE FACTORS RELATED TO ELK AND PRONGHORN POPULATION TRENDS, INFORMATION ON ABUNDANCE, DEMOGRAPHIC RATES, DISTRIBUTIONS, MOVEMENTS, POPULATION AGE STRUCTURES, POPULATION GENETICS, DIET NUTRITION, AND HABITAT USE IS NEEDED. ADDITIONALLY, A NOVEL MANAGEMENT CONCERN AROSE FOR CALIFORNIA S ELK POPULATIONS IN APRIL 2020, WHEN TREPONEMEASSOCIATED HOOF DISEASE (TAHD) WAS DOCUMENTED IN ROOSEVELT ELK IN NORTHERN CALIFORNIA FOR THE FIRST TIME. TAHD APPEARS TO BE A CONTAGIOUS INFECTIOUS DISEASE IN ELK AND HAS THE POTENTIAL TO SPREAD TO ELK HERDS THROUGHOUT THE STATE. ETIOLOGY, ECOLOGY, AND DISTRIBUTION OF TAHD IN CALIFORNIA S ELK POPULATIONS IS POORLY UNDERSTOOD. FINALLY, CONNECTIVITY AMONG UNGULATE POPULATIONS AND BETWEEN SEASONAL RANGES OF MIGRATORY UNGULATES IS AN ISSUE OF EVER INCREASING IMPORTANCE, PARTICULARLY AS THE FOOTPRINT OF HUMAN ACTIVITY INCREASES ACROSS THE LANDSCAPE RESULTING IN INCREASED POPULATION FRAGMENTATION. SECRETARIAL ORDER (SO) 3362 ENCOURAGES FEDERAL AGENCIES TO PARTNER WITH STATE AGENCIES TO IDENTIFY AND MAP IMPORTANT MOVEMENT CORRIDORS FOR UNGULATES, INCLUDING ELK AND PRONGHORN, IN THE WESTERN UNITED STATES, SO THAT THESE CORRIDORS CAN BE PRIORITIZED FOR CONSERVATION.

MONTANA FISH, WILDLIFE   PARKS PROPOSES TO ACQUIRE THE SWEATHOUSE CREEK CONSERVATION EASEMENT, WHICH WOULD MAINTAIN APPROXIMATELY 549 ACRES OF LAND IN AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION IN PERPETUITY WHILE CONSERVING VALUABLE FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT IN THE FOOTHILLS OF THE BITTERROOT VALLEY IN WESTERN MONTANA.

THE WATERFOWL INVESTIGATIONS PITTMAN ROBERTSON PROJECT (PROJECT) WAS CREATED IN 1948. CALIFORNIA HOSTS THE DENSEST CONCENTRATIONS OF WINTERING WATERFOWL IN NORTH AMERICA AND SUPPORTS SUBSTANTIAL BREEDING POPULATIONS OF SOME WATERFOWL SPECIES. SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION ON WATERFOWL ABUNDANCE, TRENDS, RECRUITMENT, MORTALITY, AND DISTRIBUTION IS NEEDED TO CONSERVE THE WATERFOWL RESOURCE, INFORM HARVEST REGULATIONS AND RESTORATION AND PLANNING NEEDS AS WELL AS STIMULATES PRIVATE WETLAND HABITAT OWNERSHIP MANAGEMENT AND SUBSTANTIAL ECONOMIC ACTIVITY. THIS SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION IS COLLECTED BY CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) PROJECT STAFF THROUGH A SERIES OF PACIFIC FLYWAY COORDINATED AERIAL SURVEYS, TRAPPING, MARKING, AND HARVEST SURVEYS. THE DATA COLLECTED IS ANALYZED TO UNDERSTAND SPECIES POPULATION STATUS AND TO MAKE INFORMED MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. ANNUAL HARVEST RECOMMENDATIONS AND ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLIANCE ARE MADE TO BE CONSISTENT WITH POPULATION OBJECTIVES. HOWEVER, THE ADMINISTRATIVE PROCESS FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF DRAFT HARVEST RECOMMENDATIONS AND REGULATIONS WILL NOT BE CHARGED TO THE GRANT. IN ADDITION, PROJECT STAFF MANAGE THE DUCK STAMP DEDICATED ACCOUNT.

PROJECT ABSTRACT MOUNTAIN LIONS (PUMA CONCOLOUR) ARE THE LARGEST FELID IN CALIFORNIA AND HAVE RETAINED SPECIAL PROTECTIONS SINCE 1991. MOUNTAIN LIONS, ALSO KNOWN AS PUMAS AND COUGARS ARE FOUND THROUGHOUT CALIFORNIA IN A VARIETY OF HABITAT TYPES FROM REMOTE MOUNTAINOUS TERRAIN TO MOUNTAINOUS AREAS WITHIN SOME OF CALIFORNIA S LARGEST METROPOLITAN AREAS. THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) WILL CONTINUE THE MOUNTAIN LION CONSERVATION PROGRAM (MLCP) WHICH WAS ESTABLISHED IN PART WITH WSFR FUNDING IN 2014 TO COORDINATE MOUNTAIN LION (PUMA CONCOLOR) RESEARCH AND MONITORING ACTIVITIES AND TO INFORM BIG GAME MANAGEMENT OF PREY AND CO OCCURRING SPECIES, SPECIES MANAGEMENT PLANS, AND HABITAT CONSERVATION. RECENTLY OVER THE PAST FEW YEARS, CDFW COLLABORATED WITH EXTERNAL RESEARCH PARTNERS TO UNDERTAKE A RIGOROUS STATEWIDE APPROACH (DELLINGER ET AL. 2021) TO ANALYZE HISTORICAL AND CONTEMPORARY DATASETS TO ESTIMATE 1) STATEWIDE ABUNDANCE AND SURVIVAL  2) HABITAT USE PATTERNS  3) GENE FLOW  AND 4) WILDLIFE HEALTH AND DISEASE IMPACTS. THESE EFFORTS HAVE RESULTED IN SIGNIFICANT NEW FINDINGS REGARDING MOUNTAIN LION ECOLOGY THROUGHOUT CALIFORNIA AND IDENTIFIED NEW AREAS OF FURTHER RESEARCH ACROSS CALIFORNIA. CONSEQUENTLY, CURRENT RESEARCH EFFORTS WILL BE FOCUSED ON 1) HABITAT CONNECTIVITY AND ROAD ECOLOGY  2) HUMAN MOUNTAIN LION INTERACTIONS  3) CO OCCURRING SPECIES INTERACTIONS  AND 4) GENE FLOW AND GENETIC HEALTH.ROADS PRESENT A MAJOR BARRIER TO MOVEMENT, DISPERSAL, AND RESOURCE UTILIZATION FOR MOUNTAIN LIONS, AND VARIOUS CO OCCURRING SPECIES SUCH AS MULE DEER AND BLACK BEAR, ACROSS CALIFORNIA. THE HIGH DENSITY OF ROADS CONNECTING MAJOR METROPOLITAN AREAS AND WITHIN SUCH AREAS COUPLED WITH HUMAN DEVELOPMENT CREATES A MATRIX OF BARRIERS AND LIMITED CORRIDORS FOR MOUNTAIN LIONS TO USE TO ACCESS SUITABLE HABITATS. THESE BARRIERS IMPACT THE ABILITY OF MOUNTAIN LIONS TO DISPERSE FROM ONE AREA TO ANOTHER IN CERTAIN AREAS OF CALIFORNIA, IMPACTING GENE FLOW AND INCREASING INBREEDING POTENTIAL. MORE INFORMATION IS NEEDED TO UNDERSTAND WHERE MITIGATION MEASURES (E.G., ROADCROSSING STRUCTURES) CAN BE IMPLEMENTED TO IMPROVE HABITAT CONNECTIVITY AND GENE FLOW. HUMAN CAUSED MORTALITY IS ADDITIVE IN MOUNTAIN LIONS AND THUS NEGATIVELY IMPACTS MOUNTAIN LION POPULATION STABILITY AND THUS IT IS NECESSARY TO UNDERSTAND HOW TO MITIGATE HUMAN CAUSED MORTALITY. AS A TOP PREDATOR, MOUNTAIN LIONS ARE THE MAIN PREDATORS FOR LARGE UNGULATES SUCH AS MULE DEER (ODOCOILEUS HEMONIUS) AND ELK (CERVUS CANADENSIS) THE FEDERALLY AND STATE LISTED ENDANGERED CALIFORNIA BIGHORN SHEEP, AS WELL AS LIVESTOCK. THEY ALSO CO OCCUR WITH BLACK BEARS (URSUS AMERICANUS), COYOTES (CANIS LATRANS), AND THE FEDERALLY AND STATE LISTED ENDANGERED GRAY WOLVES (CANIS LUPUS). SOME CO OCCURRING SPECIES ARE KNOWN TO POTENTIALLY HAVE NEGATIVE IMPACTS ON MOUNTAIN LIONS IN OTHER PARTS OF THEIR SHARED GEOGRAPHIC RANGE. CONSEQUENTLY, THERE IS A NEED TO INVESTIGATE THE DYNAMICS BETWEEN MOUNTAIN LIONS, OTHER PREDATORS, AND UNGULATES TO BETTER INFORM BIG GAME MANAGEMENT AND SPECIES CONSERVATION EFFORTS IN CALIFORNIA.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS 5 YEAR PROJECT IS TO COLLECT AND ANALYZE BLACK BEAR DNA SAMPLES TO BETTER UNDERSTAND POPULATION DYNAMICS AND GENETIC RELATEDNESS OF BLACK BEARS UTILIZING THE ANCHORAGE BOWL AND GMU 14C.INFORMATION FROM THIS WORK WILL ALSO HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO GUIDE BOTH THE MUNICIPALITY OF ANCHORAGE (MOA) AND INDIVIDUAL COMMUNITY COUNCILS WITHIN MOA WHEN DECIDING HOW TO ADDRESS CONCERNS REGARDING HUMAN BEAR CONFLICTS IN SPECIFIC NEIGHBORHOODS.

IN 4 H, MUCH OF OUR WORK IN THIS AREA FOCUSED ON THE 4 H OUTDOOR RECREATION AND SHOOTING SPORTS PROJECT. THIS IS A PARTICULAR 4 H PROJECT WHICH YOUTH ARE ELIGIBLE TO ENROLL IN AT NO COST. AS WE SERVE APPROXIMATELY 5,000 CLASSROOMS ACROSS OUR 95 COUNTIES, 4 H AGENTS WILL HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO ENCOURAGE YOUTH TO ENROLL IN THIS PROJECT. LOCALLY, YOUTH WILL BE PROVIDED WITH RESOURCES AND VIRTUAL EXPERIENCES TO HELP GROW THEIR KNOWLEDGE OF THIS PROJECT AREA. THROUGH THE 4 H OUTDOOR RECREATION SHOOTING SPORTS, YOUTH WILL PARTICIPATE IN PHYSICALLY AND MENTALLY CHALLENGING ACTIVITIES. 4 H MEMBERS LEARN THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO DEAL WITH STRESSFUL SITUATIONS THAT MAY OCCUR IN THE OUTDOORS AS WELL AS IN ANY SETTING. THESE YOUTH WILL GAIN A GREATER SENSITIVITY, UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION FOR THEMSELVES AND THE OUTDOORS. THROUGH THIS PROGRAM, YOUTH WILL EXPERIENCE HANDS ON LEARNING AT OUR FOUR 4 H CENTERS, WHICH WILL PRIMARILY BE FOCUSED ON SHOOTING SPORTS AND HUNTER EDUCATION ACTIVITIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DESIGN AND CONSTRUCT AN IMPROVED PARKING AREA AND FORMAL TRAILHEAD AT THE WENDT ROAD ACCESS POINT TO THE MATANUSKA VALLEY STATE MOOSE RANGE NEAR PALMER, ALASKA. IMPROVED FACILITIES AT THE WENDT ROAD TRAILHEAD WILL SUPPORT A GROWING NUMBER OF HUNTERS AND OTHERS SEEKING PUBLIC ACCESS TO THE MVSMR NOT ONLY AT THIS ACCESS POINT BUT WILL ALSO HELP RELIEVE CONGESTION AT OTHER WESTERN MVSMR ACCESS POINTS AS WELL. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE SAFER ACCESS FOR ALL PUBLIC USERS, HELP MITIGATE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS TO THE AREA, PROVIDE MORE ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES FOR RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES, AND REDUCE EMERGENCY VEHICLE RESPONSE TIME.

IN ORDER TO HELP NEW HUNTERS AND ANGLERS IMPROVE THEIR SKILLS, THIS PROGRAM WILL OFFER CAMPS AND EVENTS FOCUSING ON DEVELOPMENT. RESPONSIBLE HUNTER CLUBS WILL BE ESTABLISHED THROUGHOUT THE STATE AND EVENTS WILL BE HELD DURING THE YEAR TO INCLUDE SHOOTING OPPORTUNITIES. NOVICE HUNTERS AND ANGLERS WILL RECEIVE TRAINING THROUGH ANGLING CAMPS AND HUNTING CAMPS. THE CURRICULUM WILL INCLUDE HUNTING, FIREARMS, ARCHERY, ANGLING SAFETY, CONSERVATION, CARE OF GAME ANIMALS, AND ETHICS. MOST PARTICIPANTS WILL BE REQUIRED TO TAKE A BASIC HUNTER EDUCATION COURSE. BY UTILIZING THESE TECHNIQUES, A NEW BASE OF HUNTERS AND ANGLERS MAY BE RECRUITED AND RETAINED.

A CENTURY AGO, 4 MILLION ACRES OF CENTRAL VALLEY WETLANDS SUPPORTED 20 TO 40 MILLION MIGRATING WATERFOWL ALONG THE PACIFIC FLYWAY. BY THE 1980S, 95  OF WETLANDS HAD BEEN DESTROYED, AND BIRD POPULATIONS PLUMMETED TO LESS THAN 15  OF THEIR HISTORIC NUMBERS. THROUGH COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS, CALIFORNIA HAS MADE SUBSTANTIAL PROGRESS IN EFFORTS TO IDENTIFY, ACQUIRE, RESTORE, AND ENHANCE WETLANDS. THE MIGRATORY BIRD TREATY ACT AND  NO NET LOSS  POLICY DRIVES THE EFFORT TO PRESERVE WETLAND HABITAT FOR MIGRATORY WATERFOWL AND RESIDENT SPECIES WITHIN THE PACIFIC FLYWAY. CALIFORNIA S FISH AND GAME COMMISSION POLICY SEEKS TO PROVIDE FOR THE PROTECTION, PRESERVATION, RESTORATION, ENHANCEMENT AND EXPANSION OF WETLAND HABITAT IN CALIFORNIA AND THAT THE QUANTITY AND QUALITY OF THE WATERS OF THIS STATE SHOULD BE APPORTIONED AND MAINTAINED RESPECTIVELY SO AS TO PRODUCE AND SUSTAIN MAXIMUM NUMBERS OF FISH AND WILDLIFE.THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) OPERATES WILDLIFE AREAS AND ECOLOGICAL RESERVES THAT SUPPORT WETLAND HABITAT FOR MIGRATORY AND RESIDENT WATERFOWL SPECIES. USES OF THESE LANDS ALSO INCLUDE RECREATIONAL HUNTING, FISHING, WILDLIFE VIEWING AND PHOTOGRAPHY, EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS, AND INTERPRETIVE TOURS. CDFW ALSO ADMINISTERS SEVERAL PRIVATE LANDS CONSERVATION PROGRAMS DESIGNED TO ASSIST LANDOWNERS WITH THE MANAGEMENT OF WETLANDS, RIPARIAN HABITATS, NATIVE GRASSLANDS AND WILDLIFE FRIENDLY FARMLANDS.EFFORTS IN PROVIDING NEW WETLAND HABITAT AND MAINTAINING EXISTING WETLAND HABITAT ARE INCREASINGLY HAMPERED BY THE LACK OF FIRM WATER RESOURCES AND INCREASED REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS IN THE DIVERSION AND USE OF WATER FOR WETLAND HABITAT. THE MOST RECENT CALIFORNIA DROUGHT EMERGENCY ENDING IN 2017 HAS RENEWED CALLS FOR HIGHER WATER USE EFFICIENCY FOR URBAN AND AGRICULTURAL USERS. ENERGETICS MODELING SHOWED THAT THE WATER RESOURCES NEEDED TO SUSTAIN SEASONAL WETLAND HABITAT WOULD HAVE BEEN CRITICALLY DEPLETED UNDER CERTAIN DROUGHT SCENARIOS. IMPACTS OF THE DROUGHT AND RESULTING NEW WATER REGULATIONS HAS MADE THE CDFW REALIZE ITS CURRENT PROGRAMS AND PLANS ARE INADEQUACIES IN THIS POST DROUGHT PARADIGM OF WATER RESOURCES MANAGEMENT.STATE WATER RIGHTS LAW, SB 88, ENACTED JANUARY 2016, CHANGED THE REPORTING REQUIREMENTS TO REQUIRE DIRECT MEASUREMENT AND INCREASE REPORTING FREQUENCY OF DIVERSIONS 10 ACRE FEET OR MORE. THE SUSTAINABLE GROUNDWATER MANAGEMENT ACT (SGMA), A STATE GROUNDWATER LAW ENACTED IN JANUARY 2015 REQUIRES THE FORMATION OF LOCAL GROUNDWATER BASIN AGENCIES TO REGULATE THE USE OF GROUNDWATER AND THROUGH PROHIBITIONS AND FEES. ON NOVEMBER 2014, THE CALIFORNIA PROPOSITION 1 WATER BOND AUTHORIZED  7.12 BILLION FOR WATER STORAGE INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECTS, OF WHICH SEVERAL ARE CURRENTLY BEING IMPLEMENTED AND ARE SLATED TO BENEFIT MANAGED WETLANDS. THE 1992 CENTRAL VALLEY PROJECT IMPROVEMENT ACT (CVPIA) REQUIRES THE CENTRAL VALLEY PROJECT TO PROTECT, RESTORE, AND ENHANCE FISH AND WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS IN THE CENTRAL VALLEY AND TRINITY RIVER BASINS, INCLUDING A MANDATE TO PROVIDE  FIRM WATER SUPPLIES OF A SUITABLE QUALITY AND QUANTITY TO MAINTAIN AND IMPROVE WETLAND HABITAT  FOR STATE, FEDERAL, AND PRIVATE WETLAND HABITAT AREAS.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) IS THE RESPONSIBLE AGENCY FOR CONSERVATION OF CALIFORNIA WILDLIFE SPECIES AND THE HABITATS UPON WHICH THEY DEPEND. THE BIG GAME UNIT IN THE GAME CONSERVATION PROGRAM OF THE WILDLIFE BRANCH IS RESPONSIBLE FOR COORDINATING STATEWIDE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES FOR MULE DEER (ODOCOILEUS HEMIONUS), ELK (CERVUS CANADENSIS), PRONGHORN (ANTILOCAPRA AMERICANA), BIGHORN SHEEP (OVIS CANADENSIS), AND BLACK BEAR (URSUS AMERICANUS). THESE ACTIVITIES INCLUDE THE DEVELOPMENT OF SPECIES CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT PLANS  RECOMMENDATION AND IMPLEMENTATION OF CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ACTIONS  OVERSIGHT OF CONTRACTED AND INTERNAL RESOURCE ASSESSMENT PROJECTS  COORDINATION OF MONITORING, RESEARCH AND HABITAT ENHANCEMENT PROJECTS  DEVELOPMENT OF HUNTING REGULATION RECOMMENDATIONS  PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND EXPERTISE REGARDING RESOURCE ISSUES  ENGAGING THE PUBLIC THROUGH OUTREACH AND PROVIDING LEADERSHIP AND COORDINATION FOR CONSERVATION EFFORTS ACROSS 6 CDFW REGIONAL JURISDICTIONS THROUGHOUT CALIFORNIA (I.E., NORTHERN REGION, NORTH CENTRAL REGION, BAY DELTA REGION, CENTRAL REGION, SOUTH COAST REGION, INLAND DESERTS REGION). WILDLIFE BRANCH ACTIVITIES COMPLEMENT THOSE IN CDFW REGIONS, AND DO NOT DUPLICATE OTHER CDFW ACTIVITIES SUPPORTED BY EITHER STATE OR FEDERAL ASSISTANCE FUNDS UNDER THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION PITTMAN ROBERTSON ACT (PR). FURTHERMORE, COORDINATION OF ELK AND PRONGHORN ACTIVITIES ARE COVERED UNDER A SEPARATE PR GRANT.CDFW IS RESPONSIBLE FOR ENSURING THAT HEALTHY, ECOLOGICALLY, AND SOCIALLY VIABLE POPULATIONS OF DEER, SHEEP, AND BEAR ARE CONSERVED THROUGHOUT CALIFORNIA WHILE PROVIDING FOR REGULATED HARVEST, OTHER HUMAN VALUES TOWARDS WILDLIFE, AND CO MANAGEMENT WITH CALIFORNIA TRIBES AND OTHER GROUPS. EFFECTIVE PURSUIT OF THESE OBJECTIVES REQUIRES SPECIES LEVEL COORDINATION BY A FULLY STAFFED BIG GAME UNIT THAT POSSESSES EXPERTISE AND LOGISTICAL CAPACITY IN SPECIES BIOLOGY, CONSERVATION PLANNING, LAND MANAGEMENT, REGULATORY DEVELOPMENT, PROJECT MANAGEMENT, RESOURCE ASSESSMENT AND MONITORING, DATA MANAGEMENT, POPULATION MODELING, COMMUNICATION, AND ADMINISTRATION.

REGIONAL AND STATEWIDE HEAVY EQUIPMENT AND VEHICLE PURCHASES ARE NECESSARY TO ACCOMPLISH WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS FUNDED BY THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION PROGRAM. THIS GRANT TO PURCHASE EQUIPMENT AND VEHICLES WILL ENABLE DIVISION OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION STAFF MANAGING WILDLIFE TO PERFORM TASKS ESSENTIAL TO THEIR IMPLEMENTATION.

THE WEST VIRGINIA DIVISION OF NATURAL RESOURCES, WILDLIFE RESOURCES SECTION IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF OUR STATE S WILDLIFE RESOURCES AND FOR PROVIDING WILDLIFE ASSOCIATED RECREATION FOR THE CITIZENS OF OUR STATE. DECLINES IN WOODCOCK POPULATIONS HAVE SPARKED AN INCREASED INTEREST FROM WILDLIFE BIOLOGISTS AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC IN THE LAST HALF CENTURY. MOST OF THE POPULATIONS OCCUR IN WEST VIRGINIA. ALTHOUGH MUCH RESEARCH HAS BEEN CONDUCTED IN NORTHERN LATITUDES, MORE DATA IS NEEDED ON THE SPECIES AT THE SOUTHERN EDGE OF ITS BREEDING DISTRIBUTION TO UNDERSTAND ITS IMPACT ON THE OVERALL POPULATION DYNAMICS.

THE SOUTH DAKOTA DEPARTMENT OF GAME, FISH AND  PARKS - WILDLIFE DIVISION OWNS OR LEASES, AND MANAGES, A VARIETY OF GPAS AND WAAS ACROSS THE STATE AS WILDLIFE HABITAT AND PUBLIC WATER ACCESS. THE 722 GPA AND WAA UNITS ARE COMPRISED OF 285,759 ACRES, OR 0.6  OF THE TOTAL LAND AREA IN SOUTH DAKOTA. THESE GPAS AND WAAS HAVE BEEN ACQUIRED THROUGH PURCHASE, DONATION, AND BY TEMPORARY OR LONG-TERM LEASES. IN SOUTH DAKOTA, PROPERTY TAXES ARE ASSESSED ON ALL REAL PROPERTY FOR COUNTY, TOWNSHIP AND PUBLIC SCHOOL PURPOSES. CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE (CWD) IS A DISORDER OF THE BRAIN AND NERVOUS SYSTEM THAT OCCURS IN WHITE TAILED DEER AND OTHER MEMBERS OF THE DEER FAMILY. CURRENTLY, CWD HAS BEEN DETECTED IN 30 U.S. STATES INCLUDING SEVERAL IN THE SOUTHEAST. CWD IS PASSED AMONG DEER THROUGH SALIVA, URINE, AND FECES, AND ALWAYS KILLS DEER THAT BECOME INFECTED. ALTHOUGH CWD HAS NOT BEEN DETECTED IN WHITE TAILED DEER IN GEORGIA, GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (GADNR) HAS BEEN WORKING FOR SEVERAL DECADES TO TEST FOR THE DISEASE AND COMMUNICATE TO MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC ABOUT EFFORTS TO STOP THE DISEASE FROM ENTERING THE STATE. THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THIS STUDY IS TO HELP GADNR TO PREVENT ENTRY OF CWD INTO GEORGIA THROUGH EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATION WITH HUNTERS. THE RESEARCH SPECIFICALLY SEEKS TO ASCERTAIN HUNTER PREFERENCES FOR INTERACTING WITH GADNR AND HOW THEY PREFER RECEIVING INFORMATION ABOUT CWD PREVENTION. IN ADDITION TO FINDING COMMUNICATION PREFERENCES FROM HUNTERS, THIS RESEARCH WILL SURVEY GEORGIA TAXIDERMIST AND MEAT PROCESSORS TO FIND OUT THE INCENTIVIZATION STRUCTURE NEEDED FOR THEM TO VOLUNTARILY ASSIST GADNR IN THE EFFICIENT MONITORING FOR CWD.

THIS GRANT PROPOSAL INCLUDES FOUR SEPARATE PROJECTS, EACH INTER RELATED TO THE OTHER AND OFTEN SERVING THE SAME CUSTOMERS, BUT EACH WITH A DIFFERENT AND SPECIFIC PURPOSE. THE FIRST IS THE STRATEGIC COMMUNICATIONS PROJECT, FOCUSING ON SOCIAL MEDIA EFFORTS AND STRATEGIC COMMUNICATION PLANS TO ESTABLISH OUR AGENCY AS THE GO TO RESOURCE FOR INFORMATION ABOUT HUNTING AND TRAPPING IN THE STATE OF PENNSYLVANIA. NEXT IS THE MARKETING OUTREACH PROJECT, NECESSARY TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF ACTIVE HUNTERS ANNUALLY AND TO DEVELOP VITAL AND SELF SUSTAINABLE HUNTING PARTICIPATION LEVELS WELL INTO THE FUTURE. NEXT IS THE DIGITAL COMMUNICATIONS PROJECT, DELIVERING DIGITAL CONTENT TO EDUCATE AND BUILD AWARENESS WITHIN THE CONSUMPTIVE AND NON CONSUMPTIVE USER BASE. THE FINAL PROJECT IS THE SHOOTING SPORTS OUTREACH PROJECT, TO FOCUS ON DEVELOPING VITAL AND FAR REACHING PARTICIPATION IN THE SHOOTING SPORTS WITH AN EMPHASIS ON SCHOOL AND COMMUNITY AUDIENCES. THIS DIVISION WILL ALSO DIRECT ALL RANGE CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS AND UPGRADES ACROSS THE COMMONWEALTH.

THE NORTHERN REGION OF THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) COMPRISES THE NINE NORTHERN MOST COUNTIES IN THE STATE. WITHIN THIS AREA, CDFW S NORTHERN REGION WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (NRWMP) IS RESPONSIBLE FOR ASSESSING THE CONDITION OF WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND HABITATS, MANAGING AND CONSERVING GAME BIRDS AND GAME MAMMALS, PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO OTHER AGENCIES, AND PROVIDING INFORMATION TO THE PUBLIC ABOUT GAME SPECIES.PROJECTS IMPLEMENTED BY NORTHERN REGION GRANT STAFF COMPLEMENT THOSE OF OTHER CDFW REGIONS AND HEADQUARTERS BUT ARE NOT DUPLICATED GEOGRAPHICALLY BY EITHER STATE OR FEDERAL ASSISTANCE FUNDS UNDER THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION  PITTMAN ROBERTSON ACT (WR). THEY ARE CONDUCTED TO IMPLEMENT THE CDFW S TRUSTEE RESPONSIBILITIES FOR RESOURCES AND REQUIRE EXTENSIVE COMMUNICATION AND COORDINATION WITH OTHER AGENCIES, CDFW HEADQUARTERS PROGRAMS, REGIONAL CDFW STAFF, AND THE PUBLIC. THE GRANT FUNDS REQUESTED WILL SUPPORT IMPORTANT PROJECTS CONSISTENT WITH THE WR AND CARRIED OUT BY 12 PROGRAM STAFF.

PRIOR TO THE ENACTMENT OF THE  TARGET PRACTICE AND MARKSMANSHIP TRAINING SUPPORT ACT,  A DECLINE IN THE AVAILABILITY OF PUBLIC TARGET RANGES ON NON FEDERAL LAND WAS IDENTIFIED. THIS DECLINE WAS ATTRIBUTED TO A VARIETY OF FACTORS, INCLUDING CONTINUED POPULATION GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT NEAR FORMER RANGES. WITHIN THE ACT, IT IS INDICATED THAT PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR TARGET PRACTICE AND MARKSMANSHIP TRAINING AT PUBLIC TARGET RANGES CAN HELP PROMOTE ENJOYMENT OF SHOOTING, RECREATIONAL, AND HUNTING ACTIVITIES  AND TO ENSURE SAFE AND CONVENIENT LOCATIONS FOR THESE ACTIVITIES. TO EXPAND THE REACH AND ACCESSIBILITY OF MISSISSIPPI S PUBLIC SHOOTING SPORTS FACILITIES ON STATE OWNED AND OR MANAGED LANDS, WE ARE PROPOSING THE ACQUISITION OF A MOBILE FIVE STAND UNIT.  FIVE STAND  IS A RECOGNIZED SHOOTING SPORT AND CONSISTS OF FIVE SHOOTING STATIONS AT WHICH SHOOTERS ARE PRESENTED WITH A VARIETY OF SHOTS FROM SIX TO EIGHTEEN STRATEGICALLY PLACED CLAY TARGET THROWERS. THE UNIT WILL CONSIST OF A MOBILE KIOSK AND LAPTOP COMPUTER FOR PROCESSING SHOOTERS, 5 SHOOTING PLATFORMS, 8 CLAY TARGET THROWERS ACTIVATED THROUGH AN ELECTRONIC TARGET RELEASE SYSTEM, AND A 40 FOOT GOOSENECK ENCLOSED TRAILER WITH BUILT IN GENERATOR AND HEATER THAT WILL TRANSPORT OTHER UNIT COMPONENTS. WE ARE ALSO REQUESTING 4 PALLETS OF CLAY TARGETS TO INITIALLY SUPPLY THE UNIT.

THE DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) ACQUIRED THE 1,704 ACRE NELSON RANCH AND THE 4,136 ACRE BIG SPRINGS RANCH (BSR) PARCELS TO PROTECT, PRESERVE, AND ENHANCE COLD WATER SPRINGS, RIPARIAN HABITAT, INTERIOR WETLANDS, AND TO PROVIDE HABITAT FOR WILD BIRDS AND MAMMALS, INCLUDING SOME SENSITIVE OR LISTED SPECIES. WILD PIGS ARE A SPECIES THAT POSE SERIOUS THREATS TO NATIVE WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS THROUGHOUT THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES. HARDWOOD FOREST COMMUNITIES, EXTENSIVE IN KENTUCKY, PROVIDE ONE IMPORTANT EXAMPLE OF WILDLIFE HABITAT AND FORAGE, WHICH PIGS REGULARLY UTILIZE AND DAMAGE. IN ADDITION TO ECOLOGICAL THREATS, PIGS ALSO SERVE AS COMMON VECTORS FOR A HOST OF DISEASES THAT ARE TRANSMISSIBLE TO WILDLIFE, LIVESTOCK, AND HUMANS. IN KENTUCKY, INCREASED MONITORING EFFORTS ARE NEEDED AS REPORTS OF UNCONFINED PIGS CONTINUE TO BE DOCUMENTED. EFFORTS TOWARDS MONITORING AND DISEASE TESTING TO BETTER ASSESS AND ASSIST POPULATION CONTROL MEASURES FOR THIS SPECIES NEED TO CONTINUE. MONITORING AND REMOVAL EFFORTS MUST BE INCREASED, HOWEVER, TO MINIMIZE POTENTIAL FOR CONTINUED RANGE EXPANSION AND ASSOCIATED WILDLIFE HABITAT DAMAGE IN KENTUCKY.
FUNDS UNDER THIS GRANT AWARD WILL BE USED TO PROVIDE MEETING SPACE AND AUDIO VISUAL SUPPORT FOR THE 51ST ANNUAL R4 WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM COORDINATORS  MEETING.

THE WALK IN AREA PROGRAM (WIA) HAS BEEN IN EXISTENCE SINCE 1988 AND HAS BEEN FUNDED IN PART THROUGH FEDERAL AID SINCE 1991. DOMESTIC SHEEP AND GOATS SERVE AS HOSTS FOR PATHOGENS THAT CAN SPILLOVER AND CAUSE PNEUMONIA EPIDEMICS IN BIGHORNSHEEP WHEN THE WILD AND DOMESTIC SPECIES COME INTO DIRECT CONTACT. FEDERAL AND STATE LAND AND WILDLIFEMANAGEMENT AGENCIES HAVE DEVELOPED STRATEGIES THAT ASSUME THAT THE RISK OF SPILLOVER INCREASES WITH BIGHORN SHEEPPOPULATION SIZE AND THAT THE DIRECTION OF MOVEMENTS IS INFLUENCED BY HABITAT. HOWEVER, CURRENT MODELS DESCRIBINGRISK OF CONTACT OR TRANSMISSION ARE VERY GENERAL AND ARE AIMED SPECIFICALLY AT FEDERAL LAND GRAZING ALLOTMENTS.RECENTLY, DATA AVAILABILITY ON BIGHORN SHEEP SPACE USE HAS INCREASED DUE TO THE WIDESPREAD USE OF GPS COLLARS.ANALYSIS OF WILDLIFE MOVEMENTS IN GENERAL, AND BIGHORN SHEEP MOVEMENTS SPECIFICALLY HAS ALSO ADVANCED. RECENTINCREASE IN NUMBER OF BIGHORNS IN A FEW HELLS CANYON POPULATIONS, AND NEW APPROACHES FOR MANAGEMENT OF BIGHORNRESPIRATORY DISEASE THAT COULD ALLOW MORE POPULATIONS TO GROW, RAISING QUESTIONS ABOUT HOW TO BETTER MANAGE RISKTO BIGHORN SHEEP POPULATIONS AS THEY GET CLOSER TO MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES. THIS STUDY WOULD OBTAIN NEW INFORMATIONTO BETTER DESCRIBE AND PREDICT BIGHORN SHEEP MOVEMENTS THAT COULD LEAD TO MORE RIGOROUS METHODS FOR MODELING RISKOF CONTACT WITH DOMESTIC SHEEP AND GOATS, AND SUBSEQUENTLY RISK OF PNEUMONIA EPIDEMICS IN BIGHORN SHEEP WITHINTHE HCI METAPOPULATION OF ROCKY MOUNTAIN BIGHORNS.

ONCE EXPOSED TO MYCOPLASMA OVIPNEUMONIA (MOVI), RESPIRATORY DISEASE MAY PERSIST IN WILD SHEEP POPULATIONS CAUSINGPOOR POPULATION PERFORMANCE THAT RETARDS POPULATION RECOVERY. SOME INDIVIDUALS MAY SURVIVE MOVI INDUCEDPNEUMONIA AND CAN BECOME PERSISTENT SHEDDERS OF THE VIRUS IN A POPULATION, PROLONGING THE IMPACT OF THE DISEASE.EVIDENCE SUGGESTS CAPTURE, TESTING, AND REMOVAL OF ANIMALS IDENTIFIED AS CHRONIC CARRIERS IS AN EFFECTIVE METHODFOR CLEARING POPULATIONS OF THE DISEASE. THIS STUDY WOULD CONTRIBUTE TO EFFORTS FOR AGGRESSIVELY AND ACTIVELYMANAGING INFECTED HERDS BY TESTING AND REMOVING CHRONICALLY POSITIVE ANIMALS FROM FOUR INFECTED HERDS IN EASTERNOREGON.

TO FUND THE SOUTH DAKOTA HUNTER SAFETY AND FIREARMS EDUCATION (HUNTSAFE) PROGRAM, THE SOUTH DAKOTA BOWHUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM, TRAPPER EDUCATION, AND THE SOUTH DAKOTA HUNTER DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM. THESE PROGRAMS SUPPORT THE TEACHING OF HUNTER SKILLS AND OPPORTUNITIES THROUGHOUT THE STATE AND CULTIVATE AN INFORMED CONSENT OF HUNTING BY THE GENERAL PUBLIC. THE TRACT IS ADJACENT TO THE SANDY MUSH GAME LAND ON ITS NORTHERN AND EASTERN BOUNDARIES AND WILL BE INCLUDED IN THE SANDY MUSH GAME LAND. THE SANDY MUSH GAME LAND MANAGEMENT PLAN IDENTIFIES THE SNELSON TRACT AS A TOP TIER PRIORITY ACQUISITION WHICH WILL PROVIDE PUBLIC ACCESS, HABITAT MANAGEMENT, AND WATERSHED PROTECTION. ACQUISITION OF THE PROPERTY IS ESPECIALLY IMPORTANT FOR ACCESS TO THE MADISON COUNTY SIDE OF SANDY MUSH GAME LAND. ACQUISITION OF THE SNELSON TRACT WILL PROTECT HABITAT FOR MULTIPLE SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED LIKELY TO OCCUR ON THE TRACT, INCLUDING RUFFED GROUSE, BARN OWL, YELLOW THROATED WARBLER, AND NORTHERN BOBWHITE.

THE PROJECT PROPOSAL IS ASSOCIATED WITH THE FEE SIMPLE TITLE ACQUISITION OF 39.1 ACRES IN ESCAMBIA COUNTY, ALABAMA. ESCAMBIA COUNTY IS IN SOUTH CENTRAL ALABAMA. THE PROPOSED ACQUISITION IS SURROUNDED BY LAND PREVIOUSLY PURCHASED BY THE ALABAMA FORESTRY COMMISSION AND THE ALABAMA FOREVER WILD PROGRAM USING FUNDS PROVIDED THROUGH THE US FOREST SERVICE FOREST LEGACY PROGRAM. THE PREVIOUSLY ACQUIRED PROPERTY IS BEING MANAGED BY ADCNR AS THE LITTLE RIVER STATE FOREST SPECIAL OPPORTUNITY AREA (SOA). THIS ADDITION WILL ADD TO THE EXISTING FOOTPRINT OF THE SOA AND PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR DOVE HUNTING.

THE DIVISION OF SUBSISTENCE WILL DEVELOP HARVEST ESTIMATES FOR DUCKS, GEESE, SWANS, AND SANDHILL CRANE INRURAL ALASKA  DEVELOP HARVEST ESTIMATES FOR PTARMIGAN AND GROUSE HARVEST IN RURAL ALASKA  AND ADDRESS ANIDENTIFIED DOCUMENTATION GAP RELATED TO SUBSISTENCE HARVEST OF MIGRATORY BIRDS. THIS INFORMATION ISNEEDED TO ESTIMATE THE CONTRIBUTION OF RURAL AND SUBSISTENCE HUNTING OF MIGRATORY BIRDS IN ALASKA TO TAKEIN THE WHOLE PACIFIC FLYWAY AND TO SUPPORT MANAGEMENT FUNCTIONS AND COLLABORATION AMONG STATE, FEDERAL,AND ALASKA NATIVE PARTNERS OF THE ALASKA MIGRATORY BIRD CO MANAGEMENT COUNCIL (AMBCC). HARVESTMANAGEMENT DATA WILL ADDRESS A GAP IN DOCUMENTATION OF THE HISTORY AND PROCESSES OF THE AMBCC, THUSSUPPORTING COLLABORATION AMONG PARTNERS.SUBSISTENCE WILL ALSO COMPILE EXISTING DATA FOR THE CEREMONIAL HARVEST OF GAME POPULATIONS STATEWIDE INORDER TO ASSESS DATA QUALITY AND GAPS AND GATHER QUALITATIVE DATA REGARDING POTLATCH PRACTICES. THESYNTHESIS OF THESE TWO DATASETS WILL INFORM THE DEVELOPMENT OF A ROBUST EDUCATIONAL AND OUTREACHPROGRAM TO IMPROVE CEREMONIAL HARVEST UTILIZATION AND REPORTING COMPLIANCE.RESULTS FROM INVESTIGATIONS 1 3 WILL CONTRIBUTE BY MAKING INFORMATION NEEDED FOR BIRD HARVESTMANAGEMENT EASILY ACCESSIBLE TO ALL STAKEHOLDERS.IN INVESTIGATION 4, CEREMONIAL HARVEST IS AN EXTREMELY IMPORTANT ASPECT OF SOME ALASKA NATIVE CULTURALPRACTICES, HONORING THE DECEASED AND THANKING THE LIVING FOR HELP GIVEN TO THE DECEASED S FAMILY. SHARINGCEREMONIAL WILD FOODS IS A CRITICAL COMPONENT OF THESE PRACTICES. THE IMPORTANCE OF THESE PRACTICES ISRECOGNIZED IN CURRENT LEGAL FINDINGS AND REGULATORY STRUCTURES, BUT REPORTING REMAINS POORLY DOCUMENTEDIN SOME AREAS DUE TO MYRIAD FACTORS, INCLUDING THE SENSITIVITY SURROUNDING TALKING ABOUT CEREMONIALHARVEST, A LACK OF UNDERSTANDING BY DECISIONMAKERS OF THE IMPORTANCE OF THESE PRACTICES, AND SOMETIMESJUST THE SOCIAL CIRCUMSTANCES SURROUNDING THE DEATH OF A FAMILY MEMBER AND THE OBLIGATIONS OF THE LIVINGTO HONORABLY  PUT AWAY  THEIR LOVED ONES. THE LIMITED REPORTING POSES CHALLENGES TO RESOURCE MANAGERSACCOUNTING FOR MORTALITY WITHIN A GIVEN WILD GAME POPULATION AND THEIR OVERALL ASSESSMENT OF WILD RESOURCEUSE.THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THIS LACK OF INFORMATION IN THREE WAYS  THROUGH DATA COMPILATION AND ASSESSMENT,EDUCATION AND OUTREACH, AND THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF A PLAN TO STANDARDIZE DATA ASSESSMENT. ATHOROUGH AND STATEWIDE CONSIDERATION OF CEREMONIAL HARVEST, INCLUDING THE COMPILATION OF EXISTING HARVESTDATA, WILL PROVIDE A GREATER UNDERSTANDING, BY BOTH THE DEPARTMENT AND BY COMMUNITIES ALIKE, OF THE LOCALAND REGULATORY REALITIES OF THIS IMPORTANT PRACTICE. ETHNOGRAPHIC RESEARCH WILL PROVIDE VALUABLE CONTEXTFOR, AND POTENTIAL EXPANSION OF, EXISTING HARVEST DATA AND WILL PROVIDE MORE THOROUGH DOCUMENTATION OFCUSTOMARY AND TRADITIONAL SUBSISTENCE USE THROUGH CEREMONIAL HARVEST. OUTREACH MEETINGS WILL ALSO FOCUSON EXPANDING COMMUNITY KNOWLEDGE OF THE EXISTING LEGAL STRUCTURES, HIGHLIGHTING THE IMPORTANCE OFHARVEST REPORTING TO SUCCESSFUL MANAGEMENT, AND WILL EXPLORE ANY IMPEDIMENTS IDENTIFIED BY LOCALSUBSISTENCE USERS TO ACCESSING OR FILING HARVEST PERMITS. THE DEVELOPMENT OF A PROPOSAL TO STANDARDIZEHOW DATA ARE RECORDED AND EVALUATED WILL MAKE THESE DATA MORE ACCESSIBLE AND UNDERSTANDABLE TOMANAGERS AND USERS.

THIS WORK ON THE MOUNT HAGGIN WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA WILL PREVENT LOSS OF SAGEBRUSH, GRASSLAND, ASPEN AND RIPARIAN HABITAT BY REMOVING COMPETING CONIFERS THAT COMPETE WITH FORB, GRASS, AND DECIDUOUS SHRUB AND TREE SPECIES. THIS WILL INCREASE YEAR ROUND FORAGE AND BROWSE AVAILABLE TO ELK, MULE DEER, MOOSE, PRONGHORN, RUFFED GROUSE AND NUMEROUS SPECIES OF SMALL MAMMALS AND SONGBIRDS.

THIS PROJECT WILL MONITOR FOR THE CONTINUED PRESENCE OF THE MEXICAN LONG NOSED BAT (LEPTONYCTERIS NIVALIS) IN THE BIG HATCHET ROOST IN HIDALGO COUNTY BY TESTING FOR ITS ENVIRONMENTAL DNA (EDNA) IN A POOLED FECAL SAMPLE COLLECTED ON A GROUND SHEET PLACED JUST INSIDE THE CAVE S ENTRANCE AND LEFT IN PLACE FOR SEVERAL MONTHS. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO MONITOR THE DISTRIBUTION OF THE MEXICAN LONG NOSED BAT, LESSER LONG NOSED BAT (L. YERBABUENAE), AND MEXICAN LONG TONGUED BAT (CHOERONYCTERIS MEXICANA) AND IDENTIFY THESE SPECIES  MIGRATORY CORRIDOR(S) BY DEPLOYING ARTIFICIAL NECTAR FEEDERS AT A MINIMUM OF 7 RESIDENTIAL SITES IN GRANT AND HIDALGO COUNTIES, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO SITES IN CLIFF, RODEO, AND SILVER CITY. THE FEEDERS WILL BE EQUIPPED WITH PIT TAG READERS TO DETECT AND RECORD THE PRESENCE OF ANY VISITING NECTAR BATS THAT WERE PREVIOUSLY PIT TAGGED. BATS WILL BE CAPTURED NEAR THE FEEDERS USING MIST NETS, AND SAMPLES OF POLLEN AND FECES WILL BE COLLECTED FROM THEIR FUR TO DETERMINE THE RELATIVE IMPORTANCE OF AGAVE SPP. IN NECTAR BAT DIETS AND DETERMINE IF OTHER NECTAR PLANTS ARE UTILIZED IN THE NORTHERNMOST EXTENT OF THE BATS  RANGES BY IDENTIFYING THE POLLEN GRAINS TO SPECIES. IN ADDITION, A TOTAL OF AT LEAST 164 EDNA SAMPLES WILL BE COLLECTED BY SWABBING AGAVE SPP. FLOWERS OVER 5 OCCASIONS AT APPROXIMATELY 12 SITES ON BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT LANDS AND A SIMILAR NUMBER OF SITES ON NEW MEXICO STATE LAND OFFICE LANDS IN OTERO COUNTY. THE EDNA WILL BE TESTED USING SPECIES SPECIFIC ASSAYS TO DETECT THE PRESENCE OF ANY OF THE THREE NECTAR BAT SPECIES IN A POTENTIAL MIGRATORY CORRIDOR IN SOUTHEASTERN NEW MEXICO.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE OUTREACH AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO RHODE ISLANDERS ON THE STATE S WILDLIFE RESOURCES, CONSERVATION PROGRAMS AND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, TO FOSTER AN UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION OF THESE RESOURCES, PUBLIC SUPPORT OF CONSERVATION EFFORTS AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL GUIDANCE REGARDING WILDLIFE TO THE PUBLIC, NON PROFIT, LOCAL, STATE, AND FEDERAL GOVERNMENTAL INSTITUTIONS. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES PLANNED FOR THIS GRANT.

NEBRASKA DEVELOPED THE NEBRASKA OUTDOOR EDUCATION CENTER, A LARGE INDOOR OUTDOOR HUNTING AND SHOOTING SPORTS EDUCATION COMPLEX AT BOOSALIS PARK LOCATED IN LINCOLN, NEBRASKA. THE EDUCATION CENTER HOUSES AN INDOOR FIREARM RANGE, ARCHERY RANGE, THREE CLASSROOMS, OFFICES, KITCHEN AREA AND PUBLIC RESTROOMS, AS WELL AS AN OUTDOOR TARGET ARCHERY RANGE, FIELD COURSE, YOUTH FIELD COURSE, SLINGSHOT RANGE, ATLATL AND TOMAHAWK RANGE AND OUTDOOR COOKING EDUCATION AREA. THIS FACILITY DIRECTLY SUPPORTS THE COMMISSION S SHOOTING RANGE PLAN, PROVIDING THOUSANDS OF HUNTERS AND SHOOTING SPORTS ENTHUSIASTS WITH A QUALITY SHOOTING RANGE FACILITY. IT ALSO SUPPORTS THE COMMISSION S 20 YEAR HUNTER ANGLER RECRUITMENT, DEVELOPMENT AND RETENTION PLAN BY PROVIDING HUNTING SKILLS EDUCATION PROGRAMMING ALONG WITH SHOOTING SPORTS SUPPORT FOR THOUSANDS ANNUALLY. THE FACILITY IS A FULL SCALE SHOOTING RANGE OPEN TO THE PUBLIC SIX DAYS PER WEEK THAT ALSO SERVES AS A HUNTING SKILLS OUTDOOR EDUCATION CENTER. SINCE OPENING, THE FACILITY HAS SERVICED OVER 250,000 PEOPLE AND THE ANNUAL NUMBER CONTINUES TO INCREASE. THIS GRANT SUPPORTS THE OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF THIS FACILITY IN EXCESS OF THE REVENUE IT GENERATES FROM USE FEES.

THE DODGE POND DEER HABITAT PROJECT IN RANGELEY, MAINE, WILL PROTECT 693 ACRES EAST OF DODGE POND AND WITHIN TWO MILES OF THE VILLAGE OF RANGELEY. CONSERVATION OF THIS LAND WILL PROTECT 39  OF A 1,173 ACRE MAPPED DEER WINTERING AREA IDENTIFIED AS A CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT PRIORITY BY STATE BIOLOGISTS FOR ITS ABILITY TO MEET THE HABITAT NEEDS FOR DEER THROUGHOUT THE YEAR. THE PROJECT WOULD CONSERVE APPROXIMATELY 452 ACRES OF WINTER HABITAT AND PROTECT KEY RIPARIAN CORRIDORS WITHIN A FORESTED AREA JUST 2 MILES FROM THE CENTER OF RANGELEY. CONSERVATION OF THIS AREA WILL ESTABLISH A SECURE HAVEN FOR DEER AT THE NORTHERN BOUNDARY OF THEIR RANGE, EVEN AS THAT BOUNDARY MOVES NORTH OVER TIME DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE, AND GUARANTEE PUBLIC ACCESS FOR HUNTERS, FISHERS, AND OTHER OUTDOOR RECREATIONISTS.

THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION PROGRAM WAS INITIATED IN 1937 UNDER THE PITTMAN ROBERTSON ACT (1937) TO PROVIDE FEDERALFUNDING TO STATES FOR THE BENEFIT OF A DIVERSE ARRAY OF WILDLIFE AND ASSOCIATED HABITATS. THIS GRANT WILL FUNDTHE CONSTRUCTION OF AN ADDITION TO AND RENOVATION OF THE EXISTING KLAMATH WATERSHED OFFICE AT THE KLAMATHWILDLIFE AREA. THIS WILL INCLUDE A TRAINING ROOM FOR HUNTER EDUCATION PURPOSES.THERE IS A NEED TO ADD ON TO THE EXISTING KLAMATH OFFICE WITH A NEW 2,350 SQ. FT. ADDITION. THE CURRENT OFFICE ISSTAFFED WITH 8 FULL TIME EMPLOYEES, THERE CAN ALSO BE SEVERAL SEASONALS, TEMPORARY S OR INTERNS DEPENDING ON THETIME OF YEAR. IT CURRENTLY HAS 4 OFFICES, TWO BATHROOMS, PUBLIC RECEPTION AREA AND A SMALL KITCHEN AREA. THENUMBER OF FULL TIME EMPLOYEES SEASONALS IS EXPECTED TO INCREASE BY 3 6 PEOPLE IN THE UPCOMING YEAR S. THEADDITION WOULD ADD MUCH NEEDED OFFICE SPACE, STORAGE, AND LARGE WORKROOM. ALSO ADDED WOULD BE A CLASSROOM FORHUNTER EDUCATION, A NEW SECURE PUBLIC ACCESS POINT AND RECEPTION AREA, AND TWO ADDITIONAL BATHROOMS. AN OPTIONALSOLAR PANEL ARRAY COULD ALSO BE CONSTRUCTED.

PROJECT ABSTRACTTHIS GRANT PROVIDES FUNDING TO CARRY OUT THE HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAMS FOR NEBRASKA. THE PURPOSE OF THE NEBRASKAHUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAMS ARE TO 1. PROVIDE CONVENIENT OPTIONS FOR ALL CITIZENS TO MEET THE NEBRASKA FIREARM HUNTER AND BOWHUNTER EDUCATIONMANDATE.2. REDUCE HUNTING RELATED ACCIDENTS, ESPECIALLY THOSE INVOLVING, FIREARMS, ARCHERY EQUIPMENT AND ELEVATED HUNTINGAND TREE STANDS.3. RAISE AWARENESS OF THE NEED TO HUNT IN A SAFE, RESPECTFUL, RESPONSIBLE AND ETHICAL MANNER.4. ENHANCE PUBLIC AWARENESS AND UNDERSTANDING OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT.5. PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR INDIVIDUALS TO FURTHER THEIR HUNTING KNOWLEDGE THROUGH ADVANCED SKILLS BASEDLEARNING.6. MAINTAIN AND OR ENHANCE EXISTING PUBLIC SHOOTING RANGES AND OR CONSTRUCT NEW SHOOTING FACILITIES AND ORESTABLISH PARTNERSHIPS WITH RANGE FACILITIES.7. ENCOURAGE LIFELONG LEARNING AND OUTDOOR PARTICIPATION AMONG NEW AND CURRENT HUNTERS AND TARGET SHOOTERS ANDENCOURAGE REACTIVATION OF LAPSED HUNTERS AND TARGET SHOOTERS.

THE WEST VIRGINIA DIVISION OF NATURAL RESOURCES (DNR) UTILIZES FUNDING THROUGH THE WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAMS (WSFR) TO CONDUCT FISH AND WILDLIFE RELATED ACTIVITIES. THESE ACTIVITIES ARE CONDUCTED BY STAFF FROM THE WILDLIFE RESOURCES SECTION (DNR WRS) AND THE LAW ENFORCEMENT SECTION (DNR LES). THE LAW ENFORCEMENT SECTION PROVIDES HUNTER EDUCATION ACTIVITIES. THERE IS A NEED TO ENSURE PROPER ADMINISTRATION OF THESE PROGRAMS, AS WELL AS PROVIDE APPROPRIATE INFORMATION EXCHANGE AND TRAINING AMONGST AGENCY STAFF AND ALL PARTNERS TO COMPLY WITH GRANT REGULATIONS AND POLICIES EFFICIENTLY AND RESPONSIBLY.THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO MANAGE ACTIVITIES FOR THE WSFR ADMINISTERED GRANT PROGRAM. EXECUTION OF THIS GRANT WILL ENSURE THAT THE DNR REMAINS ELIGIBLE FOR FUNDING UNDER THE WSFR ADMINISTERED GRANT PROGRAM AND THE DNR IS ACCOUNTABLE AND EFFICIENT IN MEETING FEDERAL REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS. LASTLY, EXECUTION OF THIS GRANT WILL BENEFIT THE DNR IN ACCOMPLISHING FISH AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION, RESTORATION, MANAGEMENT, AND RECREATIONAL GOALS USING FEDERAL FUNDS.

THIS PROJECT WILL WORK TO ANALYZE CURRENT DISTRIBUTION AND DENSITY OF SEMI AQUATIC MAMMALS, INCLUDING THE INVASIVE NUTRIA. AN ANALYSIS OF DETECTION METHODS FOR NUTRIA WILL ALSO BE CONDUCTED. EXPECTED RESULTS AND BENEFITS OF THIS PROJECT ARE A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF SEMI AQUATIC MAMMALS AND THE STATUS OF NUTRIA IN ILLINOIS. SOUTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY CARBONDALE IS AN EXPECTED SUBRECIPIENT OF THIS GRANT.
THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS THE COORDINATION OF INVASIVE SPECIES EARLY DETECTION, PREVENTION, AND MANAGEMENT IN NEBRASKA.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT PROPOSAL IS TO OBLIGATE FUNDS TO SUPPORT SDGFP S PRIVATE LANDS HABITAT PROGRAM FOR CALENDAR YEAR 2023. THIS PROGRAM PROVIDES COST SHARE INCENTIVES TO LANDOWNERS FOR COMPLETING HABITAT DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS ON PRIVATE FARMS AND RANCHES THROUGHOUT SOUTH DAKOTA USING WILDLIFE HABITAT BASED MANAGEMENT PRACTICES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE SUPPORT AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS TO LANDOWNERS IN NEBRASKA IN ORDER TO ASSIST THEM IN EFFECTIVELY MANAGING POPULATIONS OF NEBRASKA WILDLIFE GAME SPECIES ON THEIR LANDS.

THE PURPOSE OF THE GRANT IS TO PROVIDE OR SECURE HUNTING AND OR TRAPPING ACCESS ON PRIVATELY OWNED LAND, AND TO MANAGE HABITAT ON SITES ENROLLED IN THE OPEN FIELDS AND WATERS PROGRAM ALL FOR PUBLIC ENJOYMENT AND USE.

INVASIVE AOUDAD ARE CONSIDERED A THREAT TO THE SUCCESS OF DESERT BIGHORN SHEEP (DBS) RESTORATION AND MULE DEER POPULATIONS IN THE TRANS PECOS AND SOUTHERN NEW MEXICO, AND THREATEN SIMILAR EFFORTS IN OTHER WESTERN STATES AS THEIR RANGE EXPANDS. THE LIMITED AVAILABLE INFORMATION SUGGESTS AOUDAD ARE DIETARY GENERALISTS, AGGRESSIVE, RESILIENT, AND RAPID BREEDERS, POTENTIALLY CONFERRING COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGES OVER NATIVE SPECIES. HOWEVER, AOUDAD ERADICATION IN THEIR COLONIZED RANGE IS LIKELY LOGISTICALLY AND POLITICALLY UNFEASIBLE. POPULATIONS ARE LIKELY TOO WELL ESTABLISHED FOR REASONABLE REMOVAL EFFORTS TO PRODUCE LASTING EFFECTS, AND ERADICATION WOULD ELIMINATE A MAJOR REGIONAL ECONOMIC DRIVER. UNDER THESE CIRCUMSTANCES, OBJECTIVE INFORMATION AND QUALITY RESEARCH ARE CRITICAL TO DETERMINING FEASIBLE AND ACCEPTABLE MANAGEMENT TARGETS THAT ENSURE THE PERSISTENCE OF NATIVE SPECIES.

STREAMBANK EROSION AND RESERVOIR SEDIMENTATION ARE PRIMARY CONCERNS OF RESOURCE MANAGERS IN KANSAS AND THROUGHOUTMANY REGIONS OF THE UNITED STATES AND NEGATIVELY AFFECT FLOOD CONTROL, WATER SUPPLY, RECREATION, AND WILDLIFEHABITAT AVAILABILITY. FOR KDWP TO MEET OUR GOALS OF CONSERVING AND ENHANCING KANSAS  NATURAL HERITAGE, WILDLIFEAND THEIR HABITATS TO ASSURE FUTURE GENERATIONS THE BENEFITS OF THE STATE S DIVERSE, LIVING RESOURCES, A FOCUSEDEFFORT ON DIRECT WILDLIFE HABITAT IMPLEMENTATION IS NEEDED. WE WILL DO THIS BY PARTNERING WITH THE KANSASALLIANCE FOR WETLANDS AND STREAMS (KAWS) TO EMPLOY A WATERSHED HABITAT SPECIALIST. EROSION REDUCTION PROJECTSWILL BE GENERATED THROUGH EXISTING WATERSHED RESTORATION AND PROTECTION STRATEGIES, PRIORITIZED AND PRESENTED TOKDWP TO IMPLEMENT ONLY PRACTICES THAT ARE BENEFICIAL TO WILDLIFE.

THE GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES WILL PURCHASE THE 393 ACRE USHA REDDY TRUST TRACT, WHICH WILL BECOME PART OF THE 5,641 ACRE FLAT TUB WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA (WMA). ACQUIRING THE USHA REDDY TRUST TRACT WILL IMPROVE OUR ABILITY TO MANAGE THE EXISTING WMA, SOLVE CRITICAL ACCESS ISSUES TO THE PROPERTY AND CONSERVE WILDLIFE HABITAT AND INCREASE PUBLIC HUNTING OPPORTUNITY ADDING THIS PROPERTY TO THE WMA.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ACQUIRE 40 ACRES OF IMPORTANT WILDLIFE HABITAT ON THE WESTERN SIDE OF THE CREAMER S FIELD MIGRATORY WATERFOWL REFUGE FROM THE CONSERVATION FUND (TCF) TO PREVENT FUTURE DEVELOPMENT AND ENCROACHMENTS INTO THE CRFMWR. ACQUISITION OF THIS PARCEL WILL ALSO MAINTAIN CONTINUITY OF AN EXISTING TRAIL THAT DIAGONALLY CROSSES THROUGH THE PARCEL AND CONNECTS TO AN EXTENSIVE NETWORK OF TRAILS KNOWN AS THE ALASKA DOG MUSHERS ASSOCIATION JEFF STUDDERT MEMORIAL TRAIL SYSTEM. THIS PARCEL IS ADJACENT TO 530 ACRES THAT WERE PREVIOUSLY PURCHASED FROM THE CONSERVATION FUND FOR THE SAME PURPOSES.
THE PURPOSE IS TO TRAIN INDIVIDUALS TO BE SAFE, KNOWLEDGEABLE AND ETHICAL HUNTERS WHILE MAINTAINING STATE LAW REQUIREMENTS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT APPLICATION IS TO PROVIDE FUNDS FOR THE IDNR TO PURCHASE 153 ACRES OF PREDOMINANTLY DRY-MESIC UPLAND AND FLOODPLAIN FOREST FROM THE WILLING SELLER. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS LAND ACQUISITION ARE TO 1. INCREASE HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES  2. ADDVALUABLE FOREST HABITAT TO CACHE RIVER STATE NATURAL AREA THAT WOULD BENEFIT A NUMBER OF WILDLIFE SPECIES AND SGCN, WHILE INCREASING HABITAT INTERCONNECTIVITY. THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE PROTECTED FORESTED HABITAT, INCREASE HABITAT CONNECTEDNESS, PROTECT AND ENHANCE CRITICAL HABITAT, REDUCE EXOTIC AND INVASIVE SPECIES, AND FINALLY INCREASE HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT PROJECT IS TO RENOVATE THE EXISTING INFRASTRUCTURE FROM THE DLS GUN CLUB PROPERTY LOCATED IN SCOTT COUNTY AND REPLACE IT WITH PISTOL AND RIFLE RANGES. BOTH BAYS WOULD INCLUDE A COVERED FIRING LINE ON A CONCRETE WALKWAY WITH NEW PERMANENT BENCHES. OVERHEAD BAFFLES WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO THE DESIGN TO IMPROVE THE SAFETY OF THE RANGE AND ELIMINATE THE ABILITY TO SHOOT OVER THE BACKSTOP. FENCING AND RANGE BOUNDARY SIGNAGE WILL BE INSTALLED TO KEEP PEOPLE FROM ENTERING THE RANGE ANYWHERE EXCEPT THE DESIGNATED ENTRANCE. ADA ACCESSIBILITY REQUIREMENTS WILL BE MET WITH THE NEW CONSTRUCTION SO THAT THE RENOVATED RANGE IS ACCESSIBLE TO ALL. THIS PROJECT IS A MULTIPHASE PROJECT. PHASE 1 INCLUDES THE DEMOLITION OF SELECTED INFRASTRUCTURE ON THE DLS GUN CLUB PROPERTY. PHASE 2 INCLUDES THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE BACKSTOPS, LATERAL BERMS OR WALLS, COVERED FIRING LINE AND OVERHEAD BAFFLES, ELECTRICAL SERVICE AND LIGHTING, AND PERIMETER FENCING AND SIGNAGE. FUTURE PHASES INCLUDE CONSTRUCTION OF A REGISTRATION AND CLASSROOM BUILDING, A POTENTIAL SHOTGUN AND ARCHERY RANGE AREAS, AND UPDATING THE LARGE HEATED STORAGE BUILDING TO BECOME MORE OF A MULTIPURPOSE SPACE.IMPROVEMENTS MADE AS PART OF THIS RENOVATION PROJECT, WILL HELP TO MAINTAIN THE RANGE IN A SAFE OPERATING CONDITION. THIS WILL HELP TO PREVENT ANY POSSIBLE STRAY BULLETS FROM LEAVING THE RANGE. SAFETY, CUSTOMER SERVICE, AND ADA ACCESSIBILITY ENHANCEMENTS WILL ALL CONTRIBUTE TO INCREASED USAGE AND IMPROVED CUSTOMER SATISFACTION AT THE RANGE AS A RESULT OF THIS PROJECT.

OVERVIEW  THIS GRANT AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS  AND THE WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES  DEPARTMENT  WILL BE SUB-AWARDED OUT TO THE BRILL SPORTSMEN S CLUB  RICE LAKE, WI  FOR SHOOTING RANGE RENOVATIONS. THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE SAFETY AND ACCESSIBILITY BY ADDING A NEW BERM BETWEEN TWO SHOOTING LANES AND A COMPACTED GRAVEL PATH TO THESE FIRING LANES.BUDGET  - 75K FEDERAL SHARE  - 69K STATE MATCHACTION AREA  PRIVATELY OWNED RANGE OPEN FOR PUBLIC USE.GOALS AND OBJECTIVES  INCREASE SAFETY AND ACCESSIBILITY.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT PROJECT IS TO RENOVATE THE EXISTING IOWA DNR SPRING RUN SHOOTING RANGE LOCATED IN DICKINSON COUNTY. EXISTING BENCHES WILL BE REMOVED FROM THE RANGE AND REPLACED WITH A COVERED FIRING LINE ON A CONCRETE WALKWAY WITH NEW CONCRETE BENCHES. THE NEW COVERED FIRING LINE WILL INCORPORATE BAFFLES INTO THE DESIGN TO IMPROVE THE OVERALL SAFETY OF THE RANGE. THE EXISTING BACKSTOPS WILL BE RECONFIGURED INTO A 30 YARD BERM PRIMARILY FOR HANDGUN USE, AND A 200 YARD BERM FOR RIFLE SHOOTING. ADA ACCESSIBLE PARKING AND SIDEWALKS WILL BE INSTALLED TO MAKE THE RANGE ACCESSIBLE TO ALL. FENCING AND RANGE BOUNDARY SIGNAGE WILL BE INSTALLED TO KEEP PEOPLE FROM WALKING ONTO THE RANGE FROM THE NEARBY PUBLIC HUNTING AREA. ELECTRICAL SERVICE WILL ALSO BE INSTALLED SO THAT A SECURITY LIGHT CAN BE INSTALLED AND WOULD PROVIDE THE OPTION FOR INSTALLING SECURITY CAMERAS TO MONITOR THE RANGE.IMPROVEMENTS MADE AS PART OF THIS RENOVATION PROJECT WILL HELP TO MAINTAIN THE RANGE IN A SAFE OPERATING CONDITION. THIS WILL HELP TO PREVENT ANY POSSIBLE STRAY BULLETS FROM LEAVING THE RANGE. SAFETY, CUSTOMER SERVICE, AND ADA ACCESSIBILITY ENHANCEMENTS WILL ALL CONTRIBUTE TO INCREASED USAGE AND IMPROVED CUSTOMER SATISFACTION AT THE RANGE AS A RESULT OF THIS PROJECT.

HUNTING ACTIVITIES ARE DECREASING IN OUR NATIVE AREAS FOR VARIOUS REASONS. AS A RESULT, THOSE YOUTH WHO MAY BE FUTURE OUTDOORSMEN WOMEN ARE NOT RECEIVING THE EXPOSURE OR TRAINING NECESSARY TO LEARN HOW TO UNDERSTAND AND PARTICIPATE IN HUNTING EXPERIENCES. THE SOUTH DAKOTA YOUTH HUNTING ADVENTURES PROGRAM WILL UTILIZE TWO HUNTING MATCH SPECIALISTS (HMS) TO RECRUIT, TRAIN, AND RETAIN ELIGIBLE YOUTH MENTEES AND EXPERIENCED MENTORS SO THE MENTORS CAN TEACH THE NECESSARY SKILLS, KNOWLEDGE, AND ATTITUDES SO THE MENTEES CAN BECOME RESPONSIBLE HUNTERS.

NEW JERSEY FISH AND WILDLIFE, THE STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCY EMPOWERED BY STATUTE WITH MANAGEMENT AND PROTECTION OF THE STATE S FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES IS APPORTIONED, ON AVERAGE,  12,000,000 ANNUALLY FROM U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE S WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM  WSFR . THESE FUNDS ARE AWARDED TO NEW JERSEY FISH AND WILDLIFE  NJFW  THROUGH APPROVED GRANT AGREEMENTS TO SUPPORT ELIGIBLE WSFR PROJECTS AND ACTIVITIES. APPROVED PROJECTS MAY HAVE AS THEIR OBJECTIVE THE RESTORATION, CONSERVATION, MANAGEMENT, OR ENHANCEMENT OF WILD BIRDS, WILD MAMMALS, OR SPORT FISH, HABITAT MANAGEMENT, LAND ACQUISITION, HUNTER EDUCATION, GRANT COORDINATION, HUNTER AND ANGLER RECRUITMENT, RETENTION, OR REACTIVATION OR THE DEVELOPMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF PUBLIC ACCESS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE ASSOCIATED RECREATION. THE CONSERVATION RESERVE ENHANCEMENT PROGRAM (CREP) HAS BEEN IN EXISTENCE IN SOUTH DAKOTA SINCE 2010. THE MAIN OBJECTIVE OF THE PROGRAM IS TO PROVIDE UNLIMITED FREE PUBLIC HUNTING ACCESS TO PRIVATE LAND WITHIN THE JAMES RIVER WATERSHED THAT IS ENROLLED IN UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE S (USDA) CREP. THIS PROGRAM HAS INCREASED HUNTING OPPORTUNITY AND IMPROVED HUNTING QUALITY.ACCESS IS A VERY IMPORTANT PART OF ATTAINING HUNTER SATISFACTION. ACCESS IS ALREADY BEING PROVIDED ON DEPARTMENT OWNED AND LEASED PRIVATE LANDS THROUGH THE WALK IN AREA PROGRAM AND OTHER PUBLICLY OWNED LANDS. PUBLIC ACCESS TO PRIVATE LAND HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED AS A KEY COMPONENT OF PROVIDING A SATISFACTORY HUNTING EXPERIENCE. EASY ACCESS TO SUITABLE HUNTING GROUNDS FOR A SIGNIFICANT NUMBER OF HUNTERS IS AN IMPORTANT LIMITING FACTOR IN THE DECISION OF WHETHER TO HUNT. THIS LIMITATION IMPACTS LOCAL, STATE, NATIONAL, AND DEPARTMENT REVENUES, WHICH SUBSEQUENTLY IMPACTS HABITAT MANAGEMENT. THE CREP PROJECT TARGETS THE BEST HABITAT IN A KEY PORTION OF THE PHEASANT S RANGE AND PLAYS A CRITICAL PART IN PROVIDING FOR THE PUBLIC HUNTING ACCESS NEEDS IN SOUTH DAKOTA.

SOUTH DAKOTA GAME, FISH AND PARKS IS COLLABORATING WITH BEADLE COUNTY IWLA TO HELP PERFORM CYCLICAL MAINTENANCE BY HELPING WITH COSTS TO REMOVE UNWANTED TREES AND BRUSH FROM THE EXISTING EARTHEN BERMS AT THE BEADLE COUNTY IWLA AND TO RECYCLE THE LEAD FROM THOSE BERMS. AFTER REMOVING UNWANTED TREES AND BRUSH AND HAVING THE LEAD REMOVED FROM THE EARTHEN BERMS, GFP WILL HELP WITH COSTS TO MOVE THE EARTHEN BERMS TO CREATE SEPARATE SHOOTING BAYS AT VARIOUS DISTANCES AND MAKE SAFETY AND SECURITY UPGRADES TO THE SHOOTING RANGE. THE RE DESIGN OF THE RANGE WILL ENHANCE THE SAFETY AT THE SHOOTING RANGE AND WILL HELP MAKE THE SHOOTING RANGE MEET THE NEEDS OF VARIOUS HUNTER EDUCATION CLASSES AND RECREATIONAL SHOOTING DISCIPLINES.

WEST VIRGINIA CODE REQUIRES ALL PERSONS BORN ON OR AFTER JANUARY 1, 1975, TO SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETE AN APPROVED HUNTER ED COURSE BEFORE PURCHASING A HUNTING LICENSE  STUDIES HAVE INDICATED THAT THE AVAILABILITY OF THESE CLASSES INFLUENCES THE DECISION OF OUR YOUTH WHETHER TO HUNT OR NOT  ALSO, STATE DEMOGRAPHICS INDICATE APPROXIMATELY 60  OF OUR POPULATION PURCHASES A HUNTING AND OR FISHING LICENSE WITH HUNTERS STILL ON THE DECLINE NATIONALLY, WE MUST CONTINUE TO REMOVE THE BARRIERS OF HUNTER EDUCATION WITHOUT COMPROMISING THE QUALITY OF THE HUNTER ED COURSE  WE MAINTAIN THE IMPORTANCE OF OUR TRADITIONAL IN SEAT COURSES, BUT CONTINUE TO IMPROVE AND CREATE ALTERNATIVE COURSE DELIVERY METHODS  WE MUST CONTINUE TO RECRUIT THOSE WHO WOULD NOT NORMALLY TRY THE SPORT OF HUNTING  WE MUST RETAIN THOSE NEW HUNTERS THAT HAVE BEEN CERTIFIED  ENCOURAGE THOSE MIDDLE AGED HUNTERS, WHETHER MALE OR FEMALE, TO ALWAYS FIND TIME TO SPEND WITH FAMILY AND FRIENDS IN THE OUTDOORS  WE MUST NEVER FORGET TO REACTIVATE THOSE HUNTERS WHO HAVE TAKEN A BREAK FROM THE SPORT OF HUNTING  IT IS ESSENTIAL TO REACTIVATE THIS VALUABLE POPULATION SECTOR SO THAT THEY CAN EXTEND A HAND TO YOUNGSTERS  TAKING A YOUTH HUNTING WILL REINVIGORATE AND BRING BACK THE MEMORIES OF WHY THEY HUNTED SO LONG AGO  REACTIVATION OF OUR OLDER HUNTERS MAY BE AS IMPORTANT AS RECRUITING THE YOUNG SPORTSMEN IN THE PAST, WE HAVE BASED OUR STRATEGIES ON AN INCREASE IN THE AVAILABILITY OF TRADITIONAL CLASSES  WE NOW ACCEPT FIVE IHEA USA APPROVED WEB BASED HUNTER EDUCATION COURSES COMBINED WITH  FIELD DAY  PRACTICAL EXERCISE AS AN ALTERNATIVE DELIVERY METHOD FOR THE WV HUNTER EDUCATION COURSE  WE WOULD PREFER THE ON LINE STUDENT TO STILL HAVE A ONE ON ONE ENCOUNTER WITH THE INSTRUCTOR OR OFFICER GRADUATE A SAFER AND ETHICAL HUNTER BY CONTINUALLY REVISING THE CURRENT CURRICULUM TO STRONGLY STRESS SAFE GUN HANDLING AND TREE STAND SAFETY

THE MISSION OF THE VERMONT FISH AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT  DEPARTMENT  IS THE CONSERVATION OF ALL SPECIES OF FISH, WILDLIFE AND PLANTS AND THEIR HABITATS FOR THE PEOPLE OF VERMONT  TO ACCOMPLISH THIS MISSION, THE INTEGRITY, DIVERSITY AND VITALITY OF ALL NATURAL ECOLOGICAL SYSTEMS MUST BE PROTECTED  LAND AND HABITAT CONSERVATION, MANAGEMENT, ENHANCEMENT AND RESTORATION ARE A CRITICAL PART OF DEPARTMENT S APPROACH FOR ACHIEVING THIS BROAD MISSION  THE DEPARTMENT CURRENTLY OWNS AND MANAGES 101 WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS  WMAS  COMPRISED OF APPROXIMATELY 135,000 ACRES OF LAND  EACH YEAR, THE DEPARTMENT ACQUIRES LAND TO EXPAND EXISTING WMAS, AND MANAGES THOSE WMAS FOR THE BENEFIT OF FISH, WILDLIFE AND HEALTHY HABITATS  IN ADDITION, THE DEPARTMENT MANAGES WMAS TO SUPPORT PUBLIC ACCESS AND USE OF THOSE PROPERTIES FOR WILDLIFE BASED ACTIVITIES INCLUDING HUNTING, TRAPPING, FISHING, VIEWING, PHOTOGRAPHY, AMONG OTHERS THE DEPARTMENT MANAGES WMAS BASED ON THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES CONSERVE, MANAGE, ENHANCE AND RESTORE FISH, WILDLIFE, AND HABITAT ON ALL WMAS IN VERMONT, INCLUDING INSTALLATION AND MANAGEMENT OF INFRASTRUCTURE TO SUPPORT MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES INVENTORY AND ASSESS SPECIES, HABITAT, NATURAL COMMUNITY AND OTHER RESOURCE CONDITIONS ON WMAS AND EVALUATE THAT INFORMATION TO GUIDE AND DEVELOP MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS AND IMPLEMENTATION PROVIDE PUBLIC ACCESS TO WMAS FOR WILDLIFE BASED ACTIVITIES THAT ARE COMPATIBLE WITH WILDLIFE AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES 4  PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE PUBLIC TO LEARN ABOUT WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT ON WMAS
