FISH AND GAME DEPARTMENT HELD CONSERVATION EASEMENTS, TO SUSTAIN AND IMPROVE WILDLIFE HABITATS, AND PROVIDE INCREASED OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE PUBLIC TO ENJOY THESE PROPERTIES AND WILDLIFE RELATED ACTIVITIES  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE HABITAT INVENTORY, DEVELOPMENT OF PRESCRIPTIONS AND PLANS TO ENHANCE PRIORITY HABITATS, AND WILDLIFE HABITAT MANAGEMENT OPERATION AND SUPERVISION ON STATE LANDS  SUCH OPERATIONS MAY INCLUDE FOREST HARVESTING, MOWING, PRESCRIBED BURNING, HERBICIDING, PLANTING, AND OTHER MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES  TO STEWARD FISH AND GAME S WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS, WHICH CURRENTLY SIGNS ARE INSTALLED TO HELP THE PUBLIC IDENTIFY WHERE WMAS ARE LOCATED  IN ADDITION, 21,000 ACRES OF DEPARTMENT OWNED CONSERVATION EASEMENTS, ARE MONITORED ANNUALLY TO ENSURE THE HABITAT AND PUBLIC ACCESS VALUES THAT WERE PURCHASED ARE MAINTAINED IN PERPETUITY  EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPROVED HABITATS FOR WILDLIFE AND HEALTHIER WILDLIFE POPULATIONS  PROPERTY INFRASTRUCTURE WILL BE MAINTAINED TO FACILITATE HABITAT IMPROVEMENT OPERATIONS ON STATE LANDS AND TO PROVIDE SUITABLE PUBLIC ACCESS  AND CONSTITUENTS WILL BE BETTER INFORMED ABOUT HOW THEIR FINANCIAL CONTRIBUTIONS ARE USED IN MANAGEMENT OF STATE LANDS AND EASEMENTS  WILDLIFE HABITAT PROGRAM STAFF WILL ALSO DEVELOP A STRATEGIC PLAN AND A COMMUNICATIONS PLAN THAT WILL ESTABLISH THE DIRECTION OF THE PROGRAM, PRIORITIZE USE OF WILDLIFE RESTORATION AND MATCHING FUNDS, AND INFORM CONSTITUENTS ABOUT HOW THEIR FUNDING IS USED AND HOW THEY BENEFIT FROM THE PROGRAM S WORK  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE NH S PUBLIC THAT VALUES HEALTHY WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND THOSE WHO ENJOY ENGAGING IN HUNTING, TRAPPING, AND WILDLIFE WATCHING  THE STATE S WILDLIFE RESOURCES WILL ULTIMATELY BENEFIT  ANTICIPATED SUB RECIPIENTS PERFORMING WORK UNDER THIS AWARD INCLUDE THE CONSERVATION LAND STEWARDSHIP PROGRAM WITHIN THE NH DEPARTMENT OF ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES WHO MONITORS DEPARTMENT CONSERVATION EASEMENTS

THE PURPOSE OF THE FY 2023 PULATTAT MONITORING AND NATURAL HISTORY PROJECT IS TO MONITOR THE SIZE, DISTRIBUTION, AND THREATS TO THE PULATTAT POPULATION AND TO INFORM FUTURE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS TO RECOVER THE SPECIES  THE PROJECT WILL MONITOR PULATTAT ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION ON GUAM TO DETERMINE WHERE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS WILL BEST BENEFIT THE SPECIES  DETERMINE NEST SUCCESS AND THREATS TO PULATTAT SURVIVAL AND PROVIDE INFORMATION FOR PREDATOR CONTROL EFFORTS TO DECREASE THE EFFECT  THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO DEVELOP TELEMETRIC MONITORING PROTOCOL THAT WILL AID IN RECORDING NEW HABITATS USED BY PULATTAT AND FACTORS THAT MAY AFFECT MOVEMENT  THE ACTIVITIES IN THE PROJECT INCLUDE  1  POPULATION SURVEYS TO DETERMINE PULATTAT ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION ON GUAM  2 NEST MONITORING TO DETERMINE NEST SUCCESS AND THREATS THE PULATTAT POPULATION USING NEST CAMERAS  3  DEVELOPMENT AND DEPLOYMENT OF NESTING PLATFORMS TO INCREASE AND ENCOURAGE NESTING BEHAVIOR AND INCREASE PULATTAT PERSISTENCE IN A MANAGED AREA  AND 4  DEVELOP AND CONDUCT TELEMETRY MONITORING OF PULATTAT AROUND THREE LOCATIONS ON GUAM WHERE PULATTAT ARE FREQUENTLY OBSERVED TO UNDERSTAND MOVEMENT AND DISTRIBUTION ON GUAM

WASHINGTON STATE HAS 96 BIRD AND MAMMAL SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED  SGCN  AND 30 HABITATS OF GREATESTCONSERVATION NEED  HGCN  IDENTIFIED IN THE STATE S WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN  TO SUCCESSFULLY RECOVER THESE SPECIES,WE NEED 1  ACCURATE DATA ON CURRENT ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION AND PARTNERSHIPS, BOTH INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL, THATCAN EFFECTIVELY PRIORITIZE AND IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION ACTION, AND 2  CONSERVATION ACTION AT A LANDSCAPE SCALETHAT BENEFITS THESE SPECIES AND OTHERS IN THE HABITATS THAT THEY USE TO ACHIEVE THESE, FIRST, THIS PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO SPECIES CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY, THROUGH DATACOLLECTION AND ANALYSIS, MANAGEMENT AND PARTICIPATION IN MULTI PARTNER SPECIES WORKING GROUPS AND TECHNICALTEAMS, DIRECT CONSERVATION ACTION IMPLEMENTATION, AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO THE WDFW LANDS DIVISION IN ALLASPECTS OF PLANNING AND PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION ON WDFW WILDLIFE AREAS TO BENEFIT AND PROTECT SGCN AND THEHABITATS ON WHICH THEY DEPEND  SOME ACTIONS OR DATA COLLECTION WILL BE ACHIEVED THROUGH OUR SUPPORT OF PARTNERAGENCY AND ORGANIZATIONS  FURTHER, THIS GRANT WILL FUND MANAGEMENT OF WDFW S FALCONRY PROGRAM, WHICH MAINTAINSTHIS HISTORIC SPORT WHILE MANAGING IMPACTS TO WILD RAPTOR POPULATIONS SECOND, THIS PROJECT WILL ENHANCE THE AGENCY S INFLUENCE AND PRESENCE IN LANDSCAPE LEVEL CONSERVATION PLANNINGAND IMPLEMENTATION EFFORTS, THROUGH STAFF ENGAGEMENT, WHERE LOCAL AND SPECIES SPECIFIC KNOWLEDGE AND EXPERIENCEIS PARAMOUNT TO PROJECT AND PARTNERSHIP SUCCESS  WE EXPECT TO ACHIEVE 1  DELIBERATE INTERNAL COORDINATION TO BESTPOSITION THE AGENCY TO LEAD AND PARTICIPATE IN LANDSCAPE LEVEL CONSERVATION EFFORTS  2  ENHANCED DELIVERY OFLANDSCAPE CONSERVATION ACTIONS THROUGH PARTNERSHIPS, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND PROJECT REVIEW  FURTHER, THROUGHMANAGEMENT AND ADMINISTRATION OF THE AGENCY S PRIVATE LANDS CONSERVATION PROGRAM, WE WILL HAVE GREATER INFLUENCEON MANAGEMENT OF PRIVATE LANDS TO BENEFIT WILDLIFE

GRANT FUNDS WILL BE USED TO FURTHER THE FOLLOWING WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES   PROTECT, SUSTAIN, AND MANAGE HUNTED WILDLIFE   PROVIDE STABLE, REGULATED RECREATIONAL HUNTING OPPORTUNITY TO ALL CITIZENS   PROTECT AND ENHANCE WILDLIFE HABITAT   MINIMIZE ADVERSE IMPACTS TO RESIDENTS, OTHER WILDLIFE, AND THE ENVIRONMENT   ACHIEVE CONSERVATION OF SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED  SGCN  AND HABITATS OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED HGCN  ON PRIVATE LANDS, SPECIFICALLY THROUGH PARTICIPATION IN WORKING GROUPS, AND DELIVERY OF CONSERVATIONPROGRAMS TO LANDOWNERS THROUGH TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE   FACILITATE HUNTER ACCESS ON PRIVATE LANDS, WHILE MANAGING ISSUES AND COSTS   EDUCATE THE PUBLIC TO FOSTER APPROPRIATE USE AND RESPECTFUL BEHAVIOR TOWARD PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND THEIR LANDS THE IMPLEMENTATION OF STRATEGIES EMPLOYED TO IMPLEMENT THESE OBJECTIVES WILL BE CONDITIONED FIRST ON MEETING GAMEPOPULATION OBJECTIVES MUCH OF THE WORK CONDUCTED IN WASHINGTON STATE IS COORDINATED WITH, OR BASED ON COLLABORATIVE PRACTICES DEVELOPEDWITH OTHER STATES, ORGANIZATIONS, AND NATIONS

ODFW WILL MONITOR THE RECOVERY OF WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS IN 2 LARGE SCALE FIRES, THE ARCHIE CREEK FIRE INDIGO AND DIXON WMU  AND BEACHIE CREEK FIRE  SANTIAM WMU   THE PROJECT WILL PASSIVELY MONITOR MULTIPLE WILDLIFEMETRICS AT A LANDSCAPE LEVEL OVER TIME THIS PROJECT DIRECTLY ASSISTS WITH MEETING THE PRIORITIES OUTLINED IN THE 2021 STATE AGENCY CLIMATE CHANGEADAPTATION FRAMEWORK BY HELPING TO IDENTIFY THE HABITAT REQUIREMENTS AND THE IMPACTS OF WILDFIRE ON HABITATCONNECTIVITY FOR A VARIETY OF NATIVE WILDLIFE SPECIES  OVER TIME, CAMERA AND ACOUSTIC RECORDERS WILL LIKELY DOCUMENT THE RECOVERY  OR PRESENCE  OF SEVERAL SPECIES IN THE FIRE AREAS  AN IMPORTANT BENEFIT OF THIS MONITORINGIS THAT 39 SPECIES ARE EITHER AN IMPORTANT GAME SPECIES OR AN OREGON STRATEGY SPECIES THIS STUDY WILL ENABLE ODFW TO UNDERSTAND HOW WILDLIFE COMMUNITIES RESPOND TO CHANGING HABITAT CONDITIONS ANDECOLOGICAL SUCCESSION IN POST FIRE LANDSCAPES AND PROVIDE VALUABLE BASELINE DATA IN UNBURNED AREAS  WILDLIFE CONSERVATION, MANAGEMENT, AND HABITAT RESTORATION DECISIONS CAN BE BASED ON DATA PROVIDED BY THIS RESEARCH AND VALIDATED THROUGH STATISTICAL ANALYSES  THE RESULTS OF THIS STUDY HAVE IMPLICATIONS TO OTHER STATE WILDLIFEAGENCIES IN THEIR RESPONSE TO LARGE SCALE HABITAT DISTURBANCES, ESPECIALLY WILDFIRES  SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OFTHE PROJECT WILL ALLOW ODFW TO DEVELOP APPROPRIATE RECOMMENDATIONS AND POLICES FOR CONSERVATION, MANAGEMENT, ANDRESTORATION OF A LARGE ARRAY OF WILDLIFE AND HABITATS IMPACTED BY WILDFIRES IN WESTERN OREGON

THE ENDEMIC MARIANA SUBSPECIES OF THE PACIFIC SHEATH TAILED BATS  ERNBALLONURA SEMICAUDATA ROTENSIS  AND THEMARIANA SWIFTLET  AERODRAMUS BARTSCHI  ARE BOTH FEDERALLY LISTED ENDANGERED SPECIES WITH EXTREMELY LIMITEDGEOGRAPHIC RANGES  TO ENSURE THE RECOVERY AND PERSEVERANCE OF BOTH SPECIES, DIVISION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE  DFW WILL ASSESS THE FEASIBILITY AND LOGISTICS OF POSSIBLE REINTRODUCTION TO ROTA  AS PART OF THIS ASSESSMENT, WE WILLCOLLECT INFORMATION ABOUT THE CAVE CONDITIONS ON AGUIGUAN, SAIPAN, AND ROTA, MONITOR THE EXISTING POPULATIONS OFBATS AND SWIFTLETS ON AGUIGUAN, AND COLLECT GENETIC SAMPLES FROM SHEATH TAILED BATS   COMPARISON OF CAVE CONDITIONDATA FROM BOTH OCCUPIED AND UNOCCUPIED CAVES WILL ALLOW DFW TO EVALUATE CAVE SUITABILITY ON ROTA  COLLECTION OFGENETIC SAMPLES WILL PROVIDE A BASE LINE FOR LEVEL OF GENETIC DIVERSITY TO FOR REINTRODUCTION

THE REMOTE, UNPOPULATED OR SPARSELY POPULATED ISLANDS NORTH OF SAIPAN IN THE MARIANA ARCHIPELAGO, REFERRED TO AS THE  NORTHERN ISLANDS,  PLAY AN IMPORTANT ROLE AS A POTENTIAL REFUGE FOR SPECIES AT RISK OF DISAPPEARING FROM THE HUMAN DOMINATED LANDSCAPES OF SAIPAN, TINIAN, AND ROTA  THE DIVISION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE  DFW  AND ITS PARTNERS HAVE DEVELOPED A TRANSLOCATION PROGRAM TO MOVE AT RISK SPECIES FROM SAIPAN, TI NIAN AND ROTA TO THE NORTHERN ISLANDS TO CREATE REDUNDANT POPULATIONS SHOULD THE SPECIES DISAPPEAR FROM THEIR CURRENT RANGE DUE TO THE INTRODUCTION OF THE BROWN TREE SNAKE OR OTHER HUMAN CAUSED THREATS   THIS GRANT WILL FACILITATE WORK TO ASSESS THE STATUS OF HABITATS AND SPECIES POPULATIONS ON AGRIHAN, IN ORDER TO ASSESS WHETHER IT IS AN APPROPRIATE TARGET SITE FOR THE ENDANGERED SAIPAN REED WARBLER  ADDITIONALLY, IT WILL FUND THE ASSESSMENT OF REMOTE AUDIO RECORDING TO MONITOR ISLANDS WHERE WE HAVE PREVIOUSLY TRANSLOCATED SPECIES   REMOTE AUDIO MONITORING SHOULD IMPROVE OUR ABILITY TO ASSESS THE STATUS OF BIRD POPULATIONS IN THE NORTHERN IS LANDS AFTER TRANSLOCATION

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO FUND THE VERMONT DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE S WORK RELATED TO THE MONITORING, SPECIES MANAGEMENT, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, THE MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF KEY HABITATS, AND THE DISSEMINATION OF PROGRAM RESULTS RELATED TO OUR WELL ESTABLISHED FURBEARER PROGRAM  THE EVER EVOLVING NATURE OF THE ISSUES SURROUNDING THE STATE S FURBEARER RESOURCES, THE VARIOUS TECHNIQUES EMPLOYED TO MANAGE THESE SPECIES, OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THEIR LIFE HISTORIES AND HABITAT REQUIREMENTS, AND OF THE FURBEARER POPULATIONS THEMSELVES REQUIRES A PROGRAM THAT IS AT ONCE SPECIFIC AND COMPREHENSIVE AS WELL AS STEADFAST AND DYNAMIC OBJECTIVES  ENSURE THE HEALTH AND VIABILITY OF ALL NATIVE FURBEARER POPULATIONS   PURSUE A WELL INFORMED AND PRACTICAL REGULATORY FRAMEWORK FOR THE SUSTAINABLE HARVEST OF THESE SPECIES   ADVOCATE FOR THE CONTINUED DEVELOPMENT OF IMPROVED CAPTURE METHODS AND TECHNOLOGIES AND FACILITATE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THESE ADVANCEMENTS   ENSURE THE PUBLIC S SUPPORT FOR THE CONSERVATION OF THESE SPECIES BY WORKING TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE WHEN HUMAN WILDLIFE CONFLICTS ARISE   INVESTIGATE WAYS TO BETTER IDENTIFY, PROTECT, AND ENHANCE KEY FURBEARER HABITATS  AND  DISSEMINATE TO THE PUBLIC ACCURATE INFORMATION ABOUT THE ECONOMIC, CULTURAL, EDUCATIONAL, ECOLOGICAL, AND SCIENTIFIC VALUE OF FURBEARERS AND THEIR HABITATS

THE CARIBOU STREAM DEER WINTERING AREA PROPOSAL WILL CONSERVE 916 ACRES OF PRIORITY DEER WINTERING HABITAT IN THE TOWNS OF WOODLAND AND WASHBURN, IN AROOSTOOK COUNTY, THROUGH FEE ACQUISITION  IF FUNDING IS AWARDED, THE DEPARTMENT WILL CONSERVE AND MANAGE DEER HABITAT COMPREHENSIVELY TO MEET HABITAT NEEDS FOR DEER THROUGHOUT THE YEAR  THIS INCLUDES MANAGEMENT OF SUMMER RANGE TO ENHANCE HABITAT CONDITIONS AND MAXIMIZE THE HEALTH AND CONDITION OF DEER TO INCREASE SURVIVAL RATES THROUGH THE WINTER, AS WELL AS MANAGEMENT OF WINTER SHELTER TO PROVIDE FOR ADEQUATE EXTENT, CONNECTIVITY, AND CONDITION OF WINTER HABITATS THROUGH TIME  THE PROJECT WILL ALSO BENEFIT A VARIETY OF OTHER WILDLIFE, INCLUDING WILD EASTERN BROOK TROUT AND DOZENS OF STATE AND NATIONAL PRIORITY BIRD SPECIES  THE PROJECT PARCELS CONTAIN APPROXIMATELY 2 2 MILES OF INTACT RIPARIAN BUFFERS AND ARE RICH IN UNDISTURBED WETLANDS THAT ACCOUNT FOR NEARLY 1 5 OF THE PROJECT ACREAGE  RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES SUCH AS HUNTING, TRAPPING, FISHING, AND OTHER LOW IMPACT USES WILL BE ALLOWED

THE WEST VIRGINIA DIVISION OF NATURAL RESOURCES, WILDLIFE RESOURCES SECTION IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF OUR STATE S WILDLIFE RESOURCES AND FOR PROVIDING WILDLIFE ASSOCIATED RECREATION FOR THE CITIZENS OF OUR STATE  ELK BECOME EXTIRPATED IN WEST VIRGINIA IN THE LATE 1800S WITH THE LAST RECORD FROM THE HEADWATERS OF THE CHEAT RIVER IN POCAHONTAS COUNTY IN 1873  RENEWED INTEREST IN RESTORING ELK TO THE NATIVE FAUNA OF THE STATE HAS CREATED A NEED TO OBTAIN ANIMALS FROM A RELIABLE SOURCE, TRANSPORT THESE ANIMALS TO WEST VIRGINIA AND RELEASE THE ANIMALS INTO THE APPROPRIATE HABITAT  AN ELK OPERATIONAL PLAN WAS DEVELOPED TO GUIDE THE RESTORING OF THIS CERVID SPECIES IN WEST VIRGINIA  THIS PLAN WILL SERVE AS THE PLANNING DOCUMENT FOR THIS PROJECT  SINCE 2016, THE WILDLIFE RESOURCES SECTION HAS BEEN IMPLEMENTING THIS PLAN UNDER A WSFR FUNDED GENERAL GRANT, BUT WITH INCREASED ACTIVITY A MORE FOCUSED GRANT IS WARRANTED THIS GRANT SEEKS TO REINTRODUCE ELK INTO THE SOUTHERN REGION OF WEST VIRGINIA  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE BOTH MAINTAINING AND MONITORING THE EXISTING ELK POPULATION, IDENTIFYING POTENTIAL SOURCES OF ELK, REINTRODUCING ELK ONCE POTENTIAL SOURCES ARE ASCERTAINED AND PROVIDING PROFESSIONAL AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CONCERNING THE WEST VIRGINIA ELK REINTRODUCTION PROGRAM THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS GRANT ARE TO 1  MAINTAIN AND MONITOR ELK REINTRODUCTIONS IN ONE REGION OF WEST VIRGINIA 2  INVESTIGATE POTENTIAL SOURCE HERDS OF ELK 3  TRANSPORT ELK FROM APPROVED SOURCES TO WEST VIRGINIA 4  PROVIDE PROFESSIONAL AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOCUSING ON THE WEST VIRGINIA ELK REINTRODUCTION PROGRAM

RUFFED GROUSE POPULATION SIZE IN GEORGIA IS VERY LOW AND RESTRICTED TO HIGH ELEVATION MOUNTAIN RANGES  WITHOUT ANY MANAGEMENT CHANGES, GROUSE POPULATIONS MAY BE AT RISK OF DISAPPEARING FROM THE STATE  TO SOLVE OUR QUESTIONS, WE WILL BE CONDUCTING ROADSIDE COUNTS OF GROUSE, WHILE ALSO PLACING AUTOMATED RECORDERS IN CERTAIN AREAS TO DETECT GROUSE  ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL TRY TO BETTER UNDERSTAND HARVESTS OF GROUSE BY REACHING OUT TO SMALL GAME HUNTERS WITH SURVEYS  FINALLY, WE WILL CONDUCT GENETIC TESTING OF GROUSE TO UNDERSTAND HOW GROUSE MOVE ACROSS THE LANDSCAPE

THE CDFW NORTHERN REGION  NR  IS RESPONSIBLE FOR MANAGING ALL CDFW LANDS IN THE NORTHERN NINE COUNTIES OF CALIFORNIA  DEL NORTE, HUMBOLDT, LASSEN, MENDOCINO, MODOC, SHASTA, SISKIYOU, TEHAMA AND TRINITY COUNTIES   THE NR HAS EIGHT STAFFED WILDLIFE AREAS  AREAS   ASH CREEK WILDLIFE AREA  ACWA , BUTTE VALLEY WILDLIFE AREA  BVWA , HONEY LAKE WILDLIFE AREA  HLWA , HORSESHOE RANCH WILDLIFE AREA  HRWA , LAKE EARL WILDLIFE AREA  LEWA , SHASTA VALLEY WILDLIFE AREA  SVWA , AND WILLOW CREEK WILDLIFE AREA  WCWA  COMPRISING OVER 58,280 ACRES OF MANAGED WILDLIFE HABITAT MOST OF THESE LANDS WERE ORIGINALLY PURCHASED BY THE WCB BETWEEN 1941 AND 1991  FUNDING FROM WR WAS ALSO USED SPECIFICALLY TO ACQUIRE HLWA  WHILE THE PURPOSE OF THE ACQUISITIONS HAS VARIED THROUGH THE YEARS, THE GOALS HAVE REMAINED THE SAME  CONSERVATION, RESTORATION, AND ENHANCEMENT OF HABITATS FOR WILDLIFE, WHILE PROVIDING FOR COMPATIBLE PUBLIC RECREATION SUCH AS HUNTING, FISHING, WILDLIFE VIEWING, NATURE STUDY, ETC SUBSEQUENT ADDITIONS TO THE AREAS HAVE FOCUSED ON IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PACIFIC COAST AND INTERMOUNTAIN WEST JOINT VENTURES AND PROTECTION OF SENSITIVE SPECIES AND THE HABITATS THEY DEPEND ON  WCB, ON BEHALF OF THE STATE, HAS ASSIGNED OVERALL MANAGEMENT OF THESE LANDS TO THE CDFW

THE PROJECT IS THE ADMINISTRATION OF THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION PROGRAM FOR THE DIVISION OF AQUATIC AND  WILDLIFERESOURCES AND MAINTENANCE OF THE WR PROGRAM BUILDING, VEHICLE FLEET, AND BOAT  THERE ARE APPROXIMATELY 23 INDIVIDUAL WR PROJECTS THAT MONITOR NATIVE, NON NATIVE, AND MIGRANT SPECIES, CONTROL INVASIVE SPECIES, ANDRECOVER ENDANGERED SPECIES

THE COMMON WEALTH OF THE NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS  CNMI  DIVISION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE COORDINATION SECTION IS DEDICATED TO SUPPORTING ALL WILDLIFE RESTORATION AND SPORT FISH RESTEROATION  WSFR  FUNDED PROJECTS  WE WILL PROCESS ALL ADMINISTRATIVE TASKS SUCH AS EMPLOYEE CONTRACTS, OFF ISLAND RECRUITMENTS, PROCUREMENT ACTIONS, AND PROCESS MONTHLY PAYMENTS FOR GOODS AND SERVICES RECEIVED, AND ENSURE EQUAL DISTRIBUTION OF COSTS ACROSS ALL PROGRAMS AND PROJECTS BENEFITING FROM THESE GOODS AND SERVICES  ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL PERFORM QUALITY CONTROL CHECKS ON ALL GRANT DOCUMENTS AND RECONCILE EXPENDITURES TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH LOCAL AND FEDERAL REQUIREMENTS AND GRANT AWARD CONDITONS

THE WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE MANAGES EIGHTEEN PR FUNDED WILDLIFE AREAS ACROSS THE STATE TO PRESERVE, PROTECT AND PERPETUATE WILDLIFE AND THE HABITATS THAT WILDLIFE DEPEND ON, WHILE PROVIDING COMPATIBLE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES  GRANT DOLLARS PROVIDE A LARGE PORTION OF OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE FUNDS AND A LIMITED AMOUNT OF ENHANCEMENT FUNDS ON THESE LANDS  GRANT DOLLARS ALSO CONTRIBUTE TO WINTER FEEDING COSTS FOR BIG GAME AND UPLAND BIRDS, EQUIPMENT, WLA PLANNING AND OUTREACH EFFORTS, DEVELOPMENT OF A FACILITIES INVENTORY AND RECREATION STRATEGY, AND PAYMENT OF STATEWIDE LEASES AND ASSESSMENTS

THE MAIN THRUST OF THIS GRANT IS TO IMPLEMENT THE WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE  WDFW  HUNTEREDUCATION PROGRAM  SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF A HUNTER EDUCATION COURSE IS REQUIRED IN WASHINGTON FOR ALL FIRSTTIME HUNTERS BORN AFTER JANUARY 1, 1972  WDFW CERTIFIES BETWEEN 10,000 AND 13,000 STUDENTS EACH YEAR THROUGHAPPROXIMATELY 700 CLASSES OFFERED BY OVER 1,000 VOLUNTEER HUNTER EDUCATION INSTRUCTORS GRANT FUNDS WILL BE USED TO FUND HUNTER EDUCATION DIVISION STAFF, ACQUIRE NECESSARY SUPPLIES AND EQUIPMENT,MAINTAIN ONLINE STUDENT REGISTRATION AND RECORDS MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS  FOR BOTH CLASSROOM AND ONLINE COURSES , ASWELL AS THE ONLINE PORTION OF THE WEB BASED COURSE, AND RECRUIT, TRAIN, AND RETAIN VOLUNTEER HUNTER EDUCATIONINSTRUCTORS IN ADDITION TO IMPLEMENTING THE HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM, THE GRANT WILL ALSO BE USED TO CONDUCT 5 10 HUNTING CLINICS ON A VARIETY OF GAME SPECIES, IMPLEMENT THE NATIONAL ARCHERY IN THE SCHOOLS PROGRAM IN 10 ADDITIONALWASHINGTON SCHOOLS, PROVIDE ADVANCED HUNTER EDUCATION TO SOME WDFW STAFF, AND COMPLETE THE DEVELOPMENT AND BEGINIMPLANTATION OF A HUNTER RECRUITMENT, RETENTION, AND REACTIVATION PLAN

WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS USE DETAILED AVIAN DEMOGRAPHY DATA TO MEASURE HEALTH OF AVIAN POPULATIONS WHICH CAN BE USED AS AN INDICATION OF OVERALL ECOSYSTEM HEALTH  THIS IS PARTICULARLY ESSENTIAL FOR VULNERABLE ISLAND ECOSYSTEMS LIKE THOSE FOUND IN THE CNMI  THE CNMI DFW, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH INSTITUTE FOR BIRD POPULATIONS  IBP  PROPOSES TO ESTABLISH A TROPICAL MONITORING AVIAN PRODUCTIVITY AND SURVIVAL  TMAPS  BIRDBANDING PROGRAM ON ROTA  TMAPS IS AN AVIAN MONITORING PROGRAM THAT HAS BEEN WIDELY USED ACROSS THE TROPICS AND WAS CONDUCTED ON SAIPAN FROM 2008 2018  RESEARCHERS WILL SET UP BANDING STATIONS ACROSS THE ISLAND WHERE THEY WILL USE MIST NETS TO CAPTURE, BAND AND RELEASE FOREST BIRDS  MORPHOLOGICAL MEASUREMENTS LIKE AGE, SEX, BREEDING STATUS, WEIGHT, WING LENGTH, AND TAIL LENGTH ARE RECORDED FOR EACH BIRD  THIS MIST NETTING AND BANDING PROCESS IS REPLICATED ACROSS SEVERAL WEEKS AND SEASONS AT EACH SITE   WEATHER AND HABITAT DATA AT EACH STATION WILL ALSO BE RECORDED AND USED TO CHARACTERIZE HABITAT USE AND SEASONALITY OF BREEDING  THE DATA COLLECTED FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED TO HELP UNDERSTAND IMPORTANT DEMOGRAPHIC DETAILS OF FOREST BIRD POPULATIONS LIKE AVERAGE AGE OF THE POPULATION, SEX RATIO, AND SURVIVAL RATES  RESULTS FROM THIS STUDY WILL HELP GUIDE OUR MONITORING, CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT EFFORTS OF FOREST BIRD POPULATIONS ON ROTA, MANY OF WHICH ARE ONLY FOUND IN THE CNMI AND ARE ENDEMIC TO THE ISLAND

THE CNMI DIVISION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE WILL BE MANAGING 14 WILDLIFE RESTORATION PROJECTS IN FY 2023  MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES INCLUDES ENSURING WILDLIFE SECTION STAFF MEMBERS COMPLETE GRANT OBJECTIVES UNDER THESE 14 PROJECTS, REPORTS AND PROPOSALS ARE SUBMITTED IN A TIMELY MANNER, AND FULL STAFFING IS MAINTAINED AND TRAINED AS NEEDED  PHYSICAL AND LOGISTICAL SUPPORT, INCLUDING VEHICLES AND EQUIPMENTS, IS PROVIDED SO THAT ALL PROOJECTS CONTINUE TO RUN ON A DAILY BASIS  ADDITIONALLY, THIS PROGRAM PROVIDES OUTREACH TO THE PUBLIC TO KEEP THEM INFORMED REAGRADING ONGOING PROJECTS AND THEIR BENEFIT TO CNMI

THE IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME  IDFG  MANAGES 31 STATE OWNED WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS  WMA  ENCOMPASSING OVER 362,000 ACRES, AS WELL AS OTHER WILDLIFE HABITAT AREAS AND WILDLIFE RELATED RECREATION AREAS  IDFG MANAGESTHESE AREAS NOT ONLY TO CONSERVE THE STATE S WILDLIFE AND FISHERIES RESOURCES AND THEIR HABITAT, BUT ALSO TOPROVIDE THE PUBLIC WITH AN ARRAY OF OUTDOOR RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES  IDFG S 31 WMA S RANGE IN SIZE FROM 275 TO85,000 ACRES AND HAVE SPECIFIC PRIORITIES BASED UPON THE NEEDS OF WILDLIFE IN THE SURROUNDING AREA  IDFG BIOLOGISTS MANAGE THESE PROPERTIES TO IMPROVE FORAGE AND COVER VEGETATION, PLANT FOOD PLOTS, FIGHT NOXIOUS WEEDS,CREATE WETLANDS, PROTECT WATER QUALITY, SURVEY WILDLIFE, AND MANAGE PUBLIC ACCESS  THIS PROJECT ENCOMPASSESDIRECT HABITAT MANAGEMENT, INVASIVE WEED CONTROL, ANNUAL OPERATING AND MAINTENANCE, INCENTIVE PROGRAMS, PUBLIC OUTREACH AND  COMMUNICATION, RESEARCH, AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE COMPONENTS

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO INCREASE THE PUBLIC S UNDERSTANDING OF OPPORTUNITIES FOR FISHING, HUNTING, AND OUTDOOR RECREATION THROUGHOUT VERMONT, EXPAND THEIR KNOWLEDGE OF THE CONSERVATION MANAGEMENT OF THE STATE S WILDLIFE RESOURCES THAT HAS BEEN ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH THE WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAMS, AND FURTHER THEIR APPRECIATION OF HOW THIS REMARKABLE USER PAY USER BENEFIT FUNDING MECHANISM HAS LED TO THE RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE FOR THEIR BENEFIT  BY CONTINUING TO EXPAND THIS BROAD BASED OUTREACH PROGRAM, WE WILL   ENHANCE THE PUBLIC S OPPORTUNITY TO OBTAIN INFORMATION CONCERNING VERMONT S FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES,  INCREASE THE PUBLIC S UNDERSTANDING OF HOW THE DEPARTMENT S PROGRAMS MANAGE THE STATE S WILDLIFE RESOURCES,  INCREASE PUBLIC SUPPORT FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT PROTECTION,  EXPAND PUBLIC SUPPORT FOR THE CONTINUED RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT OF THE STATE S WILDLIFE SPECIES AND HABITATS,  ENCOURAGE INCREASED HANDS ON PARTICIPATION IN OUTDOOR BASED ACTIVITIES THAT FOSTER THE QUALITY OF LIFE AMONG THE STATE S RESIDENTS AND VISITORS,  FOSTER THE PUBLIC S APPRECIATION OF THE WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAMS AND SOURCES OF FUNDING THAT SUPPORT WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO CREATE ENHANCE UPLAND GAME BIRD HABITATS ON WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS AND OTHER PUBLIC LANDS UNDER THE MANAGEMENT OF THE WILDLIFE RESOURCES SECTION IN WEST VIRGINIA  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE SOUND FOREST AND GRASSLAND HABITAT MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES TO ACCOMPLISH HABITAT GOALS FOR UPLAND GAME BIRDS IN WEST VIRGINIA  IN ADDITION THE HABITAT WORK AFFORDED BY THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT WILDLIFE ASSOCIATED ENTHUSIASTS AND THE WILDLIFE RELATED HABITAT FOR NUMEROUS EARLY SUCCESSIONAL AND GRASSLAND WILDLIFE SPECIES THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS GRANT ARE TO 1  RESTORE ENHANCE FOREST HABITAT FOR RUFFED GROUSE2  RESTORE ENHANCE HABITAT FOR AMERICAN WOODCOCK3  UPDATE THE WV BOBWHITE QUAIL STRATEGIC AND OPERATIONAL PLANS 4  RESTORE ENHANCE GRASSLAND HABITAT FOR NORTHERN BOBWHITE QUAIL 5  CONTROL OF UNDESIRABLE NON NATIVE AND INVASIVE VEGETATION

DFW PROPOSES TO GIVE THE PEOPLE OF THE VIRGIN ISLANDS INCREASED INTERACTION WITH WILDLIFE RESOURCES, AS WELL AS ADVISE, COORDINATE AMONGST AGENCIES, AND PROTECT WILDLIFE RESOURCES THROUGH SKILLS DEVELOPMENT, RESOURCE AWARENESS, AND RESOURCE PRESERVATION  THE DIVISION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE COORDINATES ACTIVITIES DIRECTLY RELATED TO THE ADMINISTRATION OF FEDERAL ASSISTANCE TO THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION PROGRAM  THE VIRGIN ISLANDS OF THE UNITED STATES  USVI  HAVE BEEN EXPLORED AND MANAGED EXTENSIVELY SINCE PRE COLUMBIAN PEOPLE ARRIVED  THE ISLANDS ARE MADE UP OF OVER 65 SMALL ISLANDS, HUNTING IS A SIGNIFICANT CULTURAL, ECONOMIC, AND HISTORICAL ELEMENT OF THE ALABAMA LIFESTYLE  HOWEVER, ALABAMA HAS UNDERGONE SOCIOECONOMIC CHANGES THAT IMPACT THE TRADITIONAL ROLE AND IMPORTANCE OF HUNTING  AS A RESULT, TODAY S PUBLIC HAS BECOME INCREASINGLY CONCERNED ABOUT HUNTER SAFETY AND BEHAVIOR, DEMANDING GREATER ACCOUNTABILITY BY HUNTERS  HUNTERS IN ALABAMA NEED TO BE GIVEN OPPORTUNITIES TO ACQUIRE KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ATTITUDES NECESSARY TO DEMONSTRATE SAFE AND RESPONSIBLE CONDUCT  THE ALABAMA HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE THE NECESSARY COMPONENTS TO FOSTER THIS DEVELOPMENT  THE ALABAMA HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1973 AND HAS UNDERGONE SEVERAL COURSE CHANGES TO MAKE IT MORE COMPREHENSIVE IN NATURE  THESE CHANGES WERE MADE AS A RESULT OF CONCERNS REGARDING HUNTER BEHAVIOR AND THE INCREASING DIFFICULTY IN OBTAINING ACCESS TO HUNTING LAND  AT THE REQUEST OF THE DIVISION OF WILDLIFE AND FRESHWATER FISHERIES, LEGISLATION WAS PASSED IN 1991 REQUIRING ALL FIRST TIME HUNTING LICENSE BUYERS BORN ON OR AFTER AUGUST 1, 1977 TO SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETE AN APPROVED HUNTER EDUCATION COURSE  SINCE BECOMING MANDATORY FOR THOSE BORN ON OR AFTER AUGUST 1, 1977, THE HUNTING ACCIDENT RATE HAS CONTINUED TO DECLINE  THIS PROJECT IS BEING UNDERTAKEN TO FURTHER EDUCATE ALABAMIANS ABOUT THE IMPORTANCE OF SAFE, RESPONSIBLE HUNTING AND THE HUNTER S ROLE IN MODERN WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT  THE BASIC STUDENT HUNTER EDUCATION COURSES ARE DESIGNED FOR THE FIRST  TIME HUNTER AND TRAPPER  THERE IS A NEED TO BRIDGE THE GAP BETWEEN THE BASIC COURSE AND ACTUALLY PARTICIPATING IN HUNTING OR TRAPPING, AS WELL AS, INTRODUCING HUNTING AND TRAPPING TO NONTRADITIONAL AND UNDERSERVED AUDIENCES  THE CONSERVATION LEADERS FOR TOMORROW PROGRAM WILL ADDRESS THIS NEED

TO DETERMINE THE DIETARY NEEDS OF THE PACIFIC SHEATH TAILED BAT  ERNBALLONURA SEMICAUDATA ROTENSIS  AND THE MARIANA SWIFTLET  AERODRAMUS BARTSCHI , THE CNMI DIVISION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE WILL LOOK AT SEASONALITY OF INSECT POPULATIONS ON THE ISLANDS OF SAIPAN, ROTA AND AGUIGUAN THROUGH A SERIES OF INVERTEBRATE COLLECTION METHODS  FURTHERMORE, WILDLIFE STAFF WILL COLLECT NON INTRUSIVE FECAL SAMPLES FROM THE PACIFIC SHEATH TAILED BATS AND MARIANA SWIFTLETS ON THE ISLANDS OF SAIPAN AND AGUIGUAN THROUGH MINIMAL DISTURBANCE CAVE ENTRIES  THE FECAL SAMPLES WILL BE COMPARED TO INSECTS COLLECTED ON THE ISLANDS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE DIETARY NEEDS OF BOTH SPECIES AND DETERMINE THE AVAILABILITY OF PREY ITEMS ON EACH ISLAND  THIS INFORMATION WILL BE USED TO DETERMINE IF ROTA HAS THE RESOURCES NEEDED TO SUPPORT EACH SPECIES IN THE EVENT THAT THEY ARE REINTRODUCED TO ROTA IN THEF UTURE

THE DIVISION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE S GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEM  GIS  SERVES AS A DATA MANAGEMENT PROGRAM FOR PROCESSING, ORGANIZING, ANALYZING, AND LONG TERM ARCHIVING OF BIOLOGICAL DATA FOR WILDLIFE CONSERVATION PROJECTS  DFW BIOLOGISTS COLLECT AND ANALYZE DATA FROM PERMIT REVIEWS, RARE SPECIES SURVEYS, AND MONITORING PROJECTS IN ORDER TO ASSESS AND MANAGE SPECIES  POPULATIONS, MITIGATE HABITAT LOSS, AND GUIDE LAND DEVELOPMENT  IN TANDEM, THE GIS STAFF PROVIDE TECHNICAL SUPPORT FOR SUCH PROJECTS BY ENTERING DATA, DESIGNING SPATIAL COMPONENTS OF SURVEYS, MAPPING EFFORTS, AND PERFORMING SPATIAL ANALYSIS TO BETTER INFORM DECISIONS  AS A RESULT, IT IS ESSENTIAL TO PROVIDE CONTINUED MAINTENANCE OF GIS INFRASTRUCTURE AND TECHNICAL SUPPORT IN ORDER TO CONTINUE THE PROGRAM S CAPACITY AND PROVIDE THE BEST MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS FOR SPECIES FOUND WITHIN THE COMMONWEALTH OF THE NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS

THIS PROJECT WILL OCCUR IN A 1200SQKM AREA SITUATED ALONG THE CREST OF THE CASCADE MOUNTAINS IN OREGON THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF A TRAIL CAMERA TRAPPING STUDY DESIGN AND TOCOLLECT MESOCARNIVORE POPULATION DEMOGRAPHICS  ADDITIONALLY, STE AND TTE MODELS WILL BE EVALUATED TO DETERMINETHEIR APPLICABILITY TO PROVIDE POPULATION DENSITY ESTIMATES FOR MESOCARNIVORES  AND GAME SPECIES  IN AREASSIMILAR TO THE STUDY AREA  WE WILL RADIO MARK MARTEN TO OBTAIN DETAILED ECOLOGICAL INFORMATION, COMPARE THETELEMETRY DATA TO CAMERA GENERATED DEMOGRAPHICS AND TO INFORM STE AND TTE MODELS IF SUCCESSFUL, THE METHODS DEVELOPED WILL SERVE NOT ONLY ODFW, BUT OTHER MANAGEMENT AGENCIES TO EFFECTIVELY ANDEFFICIENTLY MONITOR SEVERAL SPECIES SIMULTANEOUSLY, WITH REDUCED COST

APPROPRIATE  THE POPULATION LAB PROVIDES POPULATION LEVEL INFORMATION TO HEADQUARTERS STAFF, MANAGERS AND FIELD STAFF FOR STATEWIDE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS INVOLVING HARVEST AND WILDLIFE POPULATION LEVEL STATISTICS  FUNDING FROM THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT THE STATEWIDE LABORATORY, FIELD ACTIVITIES AND STAFF COSTS FOR BOTH OF THESE INTEGRATED PROGRAMS THE WILDLIFE HEALTH AND POPULATION LABORATORY PROGRAM PRIMARY MISSION IS TO SERVE AS SUPPORT ALL AGENCY FIELD STAFF, PROGRAMS AND ADMINISTRATORS THROUGH  1  PREVENTION OF EMERGING WILDLIFE DISEASES BY PROVIDING DISEASE SURVEILLANCE, MONITORING, DISEASE CONSULTS, ANIMAL CARE AND USE COMMITTEE SERVICE, AND VETERINARY SUPPORT ON RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT PROJECTS AS REQUESTED  3  PROVIDING EDUCATION AND TRAINING  ANIMAL HANDLING, DISEASE PROTOCOLS, THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION PROGRAM WAS INITIATED IN 1937 UNDER THE PITTMAN ROBERTSON ACT TO PROVIDE FEDERAL FUNDINGTO STATES FOR THE BENEFIT OF A DIVERSE ARRAY OF WILDLIFE AND ASSOCIATED HABITATS  THIS GRANT FUNDS THE ANNUALOPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF THE LADD MARSH WILDLIFE AREA  LMWA  THE LADD MARSH WILDLIFE AREA IS LOCATED IN THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE GRANDE RONDE VALLEY, ABOUT 7 MILES SOUTHOF LA GRANDE, OREGON  IT LIES AT ABOUT 2800 FEET AND IS JUST OVER 6,000 ACRES IN SIZE  THE AREA HARBORS SOME OFTHE FEW REMAINING AREAS OF UNDISTURBED, NATIVE VALLEY FLOOR VEGETATION AND CONSTITUTES THE LARGEST REMAININGWETLAND IN NORTHEAST OREGON LADD MARSH WILDLIFE AREA IS COMPRISED OF A VARIETY OF BOTH UPLAND AND WETLAND HABITATS INCLUDING CONIFER FOREST,UPLAND SHRUB, GRASSLAND, WET MEADOW AND SEASONAL EMERGENT WETLAND  THIS HABITAT DIVERSITY CONTRIBUTES TO THEWIDE ARRAY OF PLANT AND ANIMAL SPECIES FOUND ON THE AREA THE OBJECTIVES FOR THE AREA ARE TO PROTECT, ENHANCE AND MANAGE WILDLIFE HABITATS TO BENEFIT FISH AND WILDLIFESPECIES AND TO PROVIDE A VARIETY OF WILDLIFE ORIENTED RECREATIONAL AND EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES TO THE PUBLIC THE AREA SUPPORTS WILDLIFE ORIENTED RECREATION AND EDUCATION INCLUDING HUNTING, VIEWING, HIKING, AND PHOTOGRAPHY

THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION PROGRAM WAS INITIATED IN 1937 UNDER THE PITTMAN ROBERTSON ACT TO PROVIDE FEDERAL FUNDINGTO STATES FOR THE BENEFIT OF A DIVERSE ARRAY OF WILDLIFE AND ASSOCIATED HABITATS  THIS GRANT FUNDS THE ANNUALOPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF THE KEN DENMAN WILDLIFE AREA  DWA  THE DWA WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1954 WHEN 1,760 ACRES OF THE FORMER CAMP WHITE MILITARY RESERVATION WAS CONVEYED TOTHE OREGON GAME COMMISSION FROM THE UNITED STATES GENERAL SERVICES ADMINISTRATION  THIS CONVEYANCE OCCURRED VIA ARESTRICTIVE DEED SPECIFYING THAT THE LAND BE USED FOR THE PURPOSE OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION  OTHER LANDACQUISITIONS SINCE THAT TIME HAVE INCREASED THE SIZE OF THE WILDLIFE AREA TO 1,858 ACRES THERE IS A NEED TO PROVIDE, PROTECT AND MAINTAIN WILDLIFE HABITAT IN THE HEAVILY DEVELOPED ROUGE VALLEY IN SWOREGON  THE WILDLIFE AREA CONTAINS MANY DIFFERENT TYPES OF HABITATS SUPPORTING A GREAT DIVERSITY OF PLANT ANDANIMAL SPECIES  IMPORTANT HABITATS INCLUDE VERNAL POOLS, PRAIRIE GRASSLANDS, OAK WOODLAND SAVANNAHS, RIPARIANHABITAT AND WETLANDS THE WILDLIFE AREA IS CURRENTLY MANAGED TO PROTECT, ENHANCE AND RESTORE ALL FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES AND THEIRHABITATS LOCATED ON THE WILDLIFE AREA, AND TO PROVIDE A WIDE VARIETY OF WILDLIFE ORIENTED RECREATIONAL ANDEDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES TO THE PUBLIC

THE STATE CONTINUES TO HAVE A NEED FOR MORE QUALITY, CLEAN, FAMILY FRIENDLY PUBLIC SHOOTING RANGES  WITH THE EXPANSION AND FACILITY IMPROVEMENTS OF EXISTING PUBLIC RANGES AND THE POSSIBILITY OF OPENING NEW PUBLIC RANGES WE HOPE TO SEE AN INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF LIVE FIRE OPPORTUNITIES IN OUR HUNTER EDUCATION CLASSES AND INCREASED PARTICIPATION IN SHOOTING SPORTS AND TARGET SHOOTING IN GENERAL  THE FEDERAL FUNDING FOR THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED AS A SUPPLEMENT FOR PUBLIC SHOOTING RANGE RELATED IMPROVEMENTS THAT WILL BENEFIT THE HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM  IT WILL ALSO INCREASE SHOOTING OPPORTUNITIES FOR HUNTERS AND SHOOTERS IN GENERAL

ALABAMA DIVISION OF WILDLIFE AND FRESHWATER FISHERIES  ADWFF  HAS A NEED TO ADDRESS THE DECLINE OF HUNTERS IN THESTATE AND PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES TO DEVELOP THE KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ATTITUDES TO ENSURE RESPONSIBLE HUNTING ANDENCOURAGE HUNTER PARTICIPATION  HUNTING IS A SIGNIFICANT CULTURAL, ECONOMIC, AND HISTORICAL ELEMENT OF THEALABAMA LIFESTYLE  HOWEVER, ALABAMA HAS UNDERGONE SOCIOECONOMIC CHANGES THAT IMPACT THE TRADITIONAL ROLE ANDIMPORTANCE OF HUNTING LEADING TO AN OVERALL DECLINE IN HUNTERS  THE DECLINE IN HUNTERS HAS BEEN WELL DOCUMENTEDIN LITERATURE AND ADWFF IS TAKING AN ACTIVE ROLE TO REVERSE THE DECLINE  ADWFF BELIEVES THAT EXPOSING A DIVERSEAUDIENCE TO HUNTING SKILLS AND TECHNIQUES, AND OR HUNTING EVENTS CAN ENCOURAGE HUNTING PARTICIPATION AND HELP TOREVERSE THE DECLINING TREND IN HUNTER NUMBERS  THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONDUCT HUNTER DEVELOPMENTEVENTS, R3 PROGRAMS, AND OUTREACH TO PROMOTE SAFE, RESPONSIBLE USE OF HUNTING EQUIPMENT AND SPORTING ARMS,KNOWLEDGEABLE USE OF OUR WILDLIFE RESOURCES, BASIC TRAPPING SKILLS, AND TO INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS OF AGENCYPROGRAMS AND ACCOMPLISHMENTS FUNDED THROUGH WSFR GRANTS AND LICENSE REVENUE TO ENCOURAGE FURTHER HUNTERPARTICIPATION  PROVIDING HUNTER DEVELOPMENT AND OUTREACH EVENTS FOR HUNTERS AND TRAPPERS WILL HELP BRIDGE THE GAPBETWEEN BASIC HUNTER EDUCATION COURSE WORK AND ACTUAL PARTICIPATION IN HUNTING OR TRAPPING, AS WELL AS, INTRODUCEHUNTING AND TRAPPING TO NON TRADITIONAL AND UNDERSERVED AUDIENCES TO FOSTER RECRUITMENT, REACTIVATION, ANDRETENTION OF HUNTERS  ADDITIONALLY, THESE EVENTS FURTHER EDUCATE ALABAMIANS ABOUT THE IMPORTANCE OF SAFE,RESPONSIBLE HUNTING, THE HUNTER S ROLE IN WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT, AND PROVIDE THE PUBLIC WITH KNOWLEDGE OF WSFRPROGRAMS

THE LEOLA MARSH WILDLIFE AREA   1800 ACRES  IS OWNED BY WI DNR AND MANAGED AS A GRASSLAND TO BENEFIT GRASSLAND DEPENDENT SPECIES  LEOLA MARSH IS HOME TO A POPULATION OF GREATER PRAIRIE CHICKENS  GRPC , A STATE THREATENED SPECIES  WITH PR FUNDING, WI DNR WILL ACQUIRE 520 ACRES OF LAND LOCATED WITHIN THE ACQUISITION BOUNDARIES OF THE LEOLA MARSH WILDLIFE AREA, INCREASING THE PROPERTY SIZE BY  27   THE PETRIKEN ACQUISITION WILL PROTECT HIGH QUALITY HABITAT FOR GRASSLAND BIRDS, PROVIDE DNR WITH OPPORTUNITIES FOR GRASSLAND HABITAT ENHANCEMENT, AND EXPAND PUBLIC HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES TOWN OF LEOLA, ADAMS COUNTY, T20N R7E S21

THE CNMI DIVISION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE  DFW  HAS MULTIPLE DATA SETS THAT NEED TO BE ANALYZED SO THAT WE CAN PROPERLY UTILIZE THE COLLECTED INFORMATION TO GUIDE OUR DECISION MAKING PROCESS REGARDING CONSERVATION ACTIONS  ADDITIONALLY, WE HAVE LONG TERM PROJECTS THAT NEED TO BE EVALUATED REGARDING EFFICIENCY OF DATA COLLECTION SO THAT STAFF TIME CAN BE SCHEDULED EFFECTIVELY  A BIOMETRICIAN WILL BE CONTRACT BY DFW TO ASSIST WITH DATA ANALYSIS AND PROJECT DESIGN NEEDS

ADULT SURVIVAL AND SITE FIDELITY ARE IMPORTANT LIFE HISTORY PARAMETERS THAT CAN AFFECT POPULATION GROWTH AND DECLINE  TO DETERMINE THE ANNUAL SURVIVAL AND SITE FIDELITY IN THE NIGHTINGALE REED WARBLER  ACROCEPHALUS HIWAE , A FEDERALLY ENDANGERED SONGBIRD OF THE NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS, THE CNMI DIVISION OF WILDLIFE CAPTURED AND UNIQUELY COLOR BANDED 38 NIGHTINGALE REED WARBLERS ON THE ISLAND OF SAIPAN IN 2021 AND 2022   DFW WILL REVISIT THE 38 SITES AND USE AUDIO RECORDING TO DETERMINE THE PRESENCE ABSENCE OF THE SPECIES  COLLECTED INFORMATION WILL BE USED TO UPDATE LIFE HISTORY INFORMATION  THIS GRANT WILL BENEFIT THE DIVISION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE BY PROVIDING BIOLOGICAL DATA AND INFORM EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES THAT BENEFIT THE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED NIGHTINGALE REED WARBLER

THE NOSA LUTA  ROTA WHITE EYE, ZOSTEROPS ROTENSIS  IS ENDEMIC TO THE ISLAND OF ROTA AND WAS FEDERALLY LISTED AS ENDANGERED IN 2004  THE CNMI DIVISION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE HAS REACHED SEVERAL MILESTONES FOR DELISTING THE SPECIES INCLUDING SETTING CRITICAL HABITAT BOUNDARIES, ESTABLISHING A BROWN TREE SNAKE PREVENTION PROGRAM, AND YEARLY POPULATION MONITORING WHICH HAS SHOWN A STEADY AND HEALTHY INCREASE SINCE 2004  OUR PROJECT AIMS TO CARRYOUT RESEARCH THAT DIRECTLY ADDRESSES THE REST OF THE USFWS RECOVERY PLAN S OBJECTIVES IN ORDER TO MOVE FORWARD WITH DELISTING THE SPECIES  WE WILL CONDUCT A NEST SUCCESS STUDY TO IDENTIFY THE PRIMARY THREATS TO NOSA LUTA, INCLUDING THE IMPACTS OF NON NATIVE RATS AND BLACK DRONGOS  WE WILL DEVELOP A MODEL FOR PREDICTING NESTING HABITAT, ENABLING TARGETED HABITAT CONSERVATION AND ENHANCEMENT ACTIONS  THE BEST METHODS FOR SAFELY TRAPPING AND BANDING NOSA LUTA IN ORDER TO ESTABLISH A SECONDARY POPULATION ON ONE OF THE NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS WILL BE EVALUATED DURING THIS STUDY   MOST IMPORTANTLY OUR STUDY IS FILLING KEY GAPS IN OUR KNOWLEDGE OF NOSA LUTA ECOLOGY THAT WILL PROGRESS US TOWARD ACHIEVING RECOVERY PLAN OBJECTIVES FOR THE DOWNLISTING OF THE SPECIES

THE COMMONWEALTH OF THE NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS  DIVISION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE REVIEWS ALL LAND USE AND DEVELOPMENT PROJECT PROPOSALS TO DETERMINE IF THEY HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO IMPACT FEDERALLY OR LOCALLY LISTED SPECIES  THE TECHNICAL GUIDANCE PROGRAM PROVIDES ASSISTANCE IN THE FORM OF PROJECT ACTIVITY ASSESSMENTS , ON SITE WILDLIFE AND CRITICAL HABITAT SURVEYS, AND CONSULTATION SERVICES WHICH ALLOWS DFW TO CONTINUE ITS EFFORTS IN THE CNMI TO AVOID OR MINIMIZE NATURAL AND HUMAN INDUCED IMPACTS ON WILDLIFE SPECIES

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO FUND OREGON S GAME MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, WHICH INCLUDES THE BIG GAME AND FURBEARER PROGRAMS, TO PROMOTE HEALTHY GAME POPULATIONS AND PUBLIC USE AS STATED IN OREGON REVISED STATUTE 496 012, IT IS THE POLICY OF THE STATE OF OREGON TO MANAGE WILDLIFE TOPREVENT SERIOUS DEPLETION OF ANY INDIGENOUS SPECIES AND TO PROVIDE THE OPTIMUM RECREATIONAL AND AESTHETICBENEFITS FOR PRESENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS OF THE CITIZENS OF THIS STATE  THE GAME PROGRAM IS THE PRIMARYPROGRAM FOR MANAGING POPULATIONS OF ANIMALS THAT ARE HUNTED AND TRAPPED TO MEET THE GOALS OF THE POLICY WHICHINCLUDE TO MAINTAIN ALL SPECIES OF WILDLIFE AT OPTIMUM LEVELS TO PERMIT AN ORDERLY AND EQUITABLE UTILIZATION OF AVAILABLE WILDLIFE TO REGULATE WILDLIFE POPULATIONS IN A MANNER THAT IS COMPATIBLE WITH PRIMARY USES OF THE LAND AND WATERS OF THESTATE TO PROVIDE OPTIMUM RECREATIONAL BENEFITS THERE IS A NEED TO MANAGE GAME SPECIES IN OREGON TO MAINTAIN HEALTHY POPULATIONS WHILE PROVIDING OPTIMUMRECREATIONAL AND AESTHETIC BENEFITS FOR PRESENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS THROUGH THIS GRANT, OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE WILL COORDINATE AND ADMINISTER THE GAME MANAGEMENT PROGRAM PROVIDE TECHNICAL GUIDANCE FOR BIG GAME AND FURBEARER MANAGEMENT TO 24 ORGANIZATIONS  FEDERAL, STATE, ANDTRIBAL LANDOWNERS, ORGANIZATIONS, STAFF BIOLOGISTS AND PERSONNEL  PARTICIPATE IN 13 TECHNICAL COMMITTEES COLLECT AND ANALYZE HARVEST  29 INVESTIGATIONS  AND SURVEY DATA  44 INVESTIGATIONS  TO HELP MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS

THE IDAHO FISH AND GAME STATEWIDE HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM PROVIDES OPPORTUNITIES FOR PEOPLE TO LEARN ABOUT IDAHO S MANY OUTDOOR ACTIVITIES AND TEACHES THE SKILLS NEEDED TO HUNT, BOWHUNT AND TRAP  CERTIFIED VOLUNTEER INSTRUCTORS TRAIN STUDENTS TO BE SAFE, ETHICAL AND RESPONSIBLE HUNTERS  HUNTER, TRAPPER AND BOWHUNTER COURSES ARE MANDATORY BEFORE PURCHASING A HUNTING AND TRAPPING LICENSE AND ARCHERY PERMIT  THE GRANT FUNDING SUPPORTS VOLUNTEER COORDINATOR PERSONNEL, STUDENT MANUALS, TEACHING MATERIALS AND COURSE SUPPLIES TO ADMINISTER THE COURSES

THE STATEWIDE HABITAT PROGRAM IN THE DESCHUTES WATERSHED DISTRICT COMPRISES TWO SUB BASINS OF THE COLUMBIA RIVERBASIN  THE DESCHUTES SUB BASIN, WHICH INCLUDES 6 8 MILLION ACRES OF WILDLIFE HABITAT, AND THE HOOD RIVER SUBBASIN,WHICH INCLUDES 341,000 ACRES OF WILDLIFE HABITAT  THERE ARE 25 PRIMARY WILDLIFE HABITAT TYPES IN THE SUBBASINSALONG WITH 400  SPECIES OF TERRESTRIAL AND AQUATIC WILDLIFE  IN ADDITION, THERE ARE 18 FEDERALLY LISTEDFISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES AND 35 SPECIES OF CONCERN INCLUDING PLANTS  9  AND INVERTEBRATES  4   ADDITIONALLY,THIS PROJECT INCLUDES THE ENTIRE MANAGEMENT OF THREE STATE WILDLIFE AREAS  2,230 ACRE PRINEVILLE RESERVOIR, 140 ACRE CRATES POINT  INCLUDING TAYLOR LAKE , AND 22 ACRE RUFUS PONDS AS WELL AS 20 ACRES IN THE SPRING CREEK AREAOF THE METOLIUS WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT UNIT AND FOUR PARCELS  TOTALING 20 ACRES  ALONG THE LITTLE DESCHUTES RIVER HUMAN POPULATION EXPANSION, HUMAN DEVELOPMENT, AND AN UPSURGE IN THE VARIETY OF RECREATIONAL PURSUITS HAVE ALLIMPACTED FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITATS  THESE ACTIVITIES HAVE INCREASED HABITAT FRAGMENTATION, WILDLIFE DISTURBANCE,LANDSCAPE LEVEL WILDFIRES, AND THE SPREAD OF EXOTIC SPECIES  THE RESULT HAS BEEN A DECLINE IN WILDLIFE HABITATEFFECTIVENESS  WITHOUT ACTIVE STRATEGIC PLANNING TO ADDRESS THESE THREATS, WILDLIFE HABITAT CONNECTIVITY WILLCONTINUE TO DETERIORATE  THIS HABITAT PROGRAM S PURPOSE IS TO PROTECT, MAINTAIN, AND ENHANCE WILDLIFE HABITAT TOMEET OREGON S WILDLIFE POLICY BY  1  MANIPULATING HABITAT, 2  ACQUIRING LAND, 3  DEVELOPING HABITAT MANAGEMENTAND RESTORATION TECHNIQUES, 4  PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO STATE, FEDERAL, TRIBAL, AND LOCAL AGENCIES ANDINDIVIDUALS  AND, 5  PROVIDING FUNDING THROUGH GRANTS FOR HABITAT PROTECTION, RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT

THE WHITE RIVER WILDLIFE AREA IS MANAGED PRIMARILY TO MINIMIZE OR ALLEVIATE CONFLICTS CAUSED BY ELK AND DEER TOPRIVATELY OWNED LANDS AND AGRICULTURAL CROPS  ALL MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES ON THE WRWA ARE UNDERTAKEN WITHIN THE CONTEXT OF THIS PRIMARY GOAL THE NATURAL RESOURCES IN THE WRWA NEED TO BE MANAGED IN SUCH A MANNER AS TO PROTECT, MAINTAIN, ENHANCE, ANDRESTORE FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT TO SUPPORT OPTIMUM POPULATION LEVELS OF ALL SPECIES FOR THE ENJOYMENT OF PRESENT AND FUTURE CITIZENS TO PROTECT THESE NATURAL RESOURCES, MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS AND STRATEGIES UTILIZED ON THE WRWA WILL MEET OR EXCEED HABITAT PROTECTION POLICIES AND STANDARDS SET BY THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE OVERALL PROJECT GOAL  DEVELOP ADDITIONAL WILDLIFE HABITAT, CONTINUE MAINTENANCE AND MANAGEMENT OF EXISTING HABITAT DEVELOPMENTS, MAINTENANCE, AND IMPROVEMENTS TO EQUIPMENT, FACILITIES AND INFRASTRUCTURE, WILDLIFE HABITATAND POPULATION MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT, AND PUBLIC USE PROGRAMS AS LISTED

THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION PROGRAM WAS INITIATED IN 1937 UNDER THE PITTMAN ROBERTSON ACT TO PROVIDE FEDERAL FUNDINGTO STATES FOR THE BENEFIT OF A DIVERSE ARRAY OF WILDLIFE AND ASSOCIATED HABITATS  THIS GRANT FUNDS THE ANNUALOPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF THE E E  WILSON WILDLIFE AREA  EEW  THE E E  WILSON WILDLIFE AREA CAME INTO EXISTENCE IN 1950 WHEN THE U S  GOVERNMENTGAVE QUITCLAIM TITLE TO THE PROPERTY TO THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE  THEWILDLIFE AREA COVERS APPROXIMATELY 1,788 ACRES, IS LOCATED ON HIGHWAY 99W ABOUT 10MILES NORTH OF CORVALLIS AND IS SITUATED ON THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY FLOOR  BORDERED TO THENORTH BY PRIVATE FARMLANDS, THE URBAN COMMUNITY OF ADAIR VILLAGE TO THE SOUTH, HIGHWAY99W TO THE WEST AND THE UNDEVELOPED CITY OF ADAIR AND UNITED STATES FOREST SERVICE USFS  PROPERTIES TO THE EAST, EEW ALSO INCLUDES THE ISOLATED 55 ACRE BAKER TRACT,THE 50 ACRE COFFIN BUTTE TRACT AND 40 ACRES SURROUNDING THE SOUTH WILLAMETTE WATERSHED DISTRICT OFFICE THIS PROJECT WILL MAINTAIN OR IMPROVE FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT ON THE 1,788 ACRE STATE WILDLIFE AREA  IT WILL MAINTAIN UNIQUE HABITATS AND BIODIVERSITY IN A REGION THAT IS BECOMING INCREASINGLY IMPACTED BY RISING HUMANPOPULATION  IT WILL PROVIDE A WIDE RANGE OF WILDLIFE ORIENTED RECREATIONAL AND EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR THEENJOYMENT OF VISITORS  THIS IN TURN CONTRIBUTES TO THE LOCAL, STATE AND FEDERAL ECONOMY AS PEOPLE SPEND MONEY INVARIOUS WAYS WHILE ENJOYING THE EE WILSON WILDLIFE AREA

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, COMMUNICATION, AND OUTREACH TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC, PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, AND OTHER ENTITIES REGARDING THE MANAGEMENT, CONSERVATION, AND AWARENESS OF WILDLIFE SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS AS WELL AS PROVIDE REVIEWS ON PROJECTS AND OR DEVELOPMENT PLANS  IMPACTS ON WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITAT  OVERALL, THERE IS A NEED FOR ALABAMA DIVISION OF WILDLIFE AND FRESHWATER FISHERIES  ADWFF  TO WORK COLLABORATIVELY WITH PUBLIC AND PRIVATE ENTITIES TO MANAGE AND CONSERVE THE DIVERSE WILDLIFE RESOURCES OF ALABAMA FOR THE BENEFIT OF HUNTERS AND WILDLIFE RECREATIONISTS  ALABAMA HAS FIVE  5  PHYSIOGRAPHIC REGIONS AND FIVE  5  DISTINCT RIVER BASINS OFFERING A WIDE DIVERSITY OF HABITATS AND WILDLIFE  THE HIGH SPECIES DIVERSITY AFFORDED TO ALABAMA RANKS THE STATE AS THE FIFTH MOST BIOLOGICALLY DIVERSE IN THE NATION  HOWEVER, OVER 93  OF ALABAMA S LAND BASE IS IN PRIVATE HOLDINGS, WITH LESS THAN 7  OF THE LAND AREA SPREAD ACROSS VARIOUS PUBLIC OWNERSHIPS  FEDERAL STATE COUNTY GOVERNMENT   THEREFORE, TO EFFECTIVELY CONSERVE AND MANAGE WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS, ADWFF MUST PUT EFFORTS TOWARDS ENGAGING PARTNERS, THE GENERAL PUBLIC, AND PRIVATE LANDOWNERS ON IMPLEMENTING MANAGEMENT AND OR CONSERVATION PRACTICES THAT BENEFIT WILDLIFE TO HAVE ANY SIGNIFICANT IMPACT AT A LANDSCAPE OR STATEWIDE SCALE  ADWFF RECEIVES MANY REQUESTS EACH YEAR FOR TECHNICAL GUIDANCE CONCERNING WILDLIFE SPECIES AND THEIR ASSOCIATED HABITAT  REQUESTS COME FROM OTHER GOVERNMENT AND NON GOVERNMENT AGENCIES INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, PROVIDING SPECIES MANAGEMENT INFORMATION, SPECIES STATUS UPDATES, REVIEW AND COMMENT ON PROJECT PLANS AND DOCUMENTS, AND ATTENDING COORDINATING MEETINGS OR SERVING ON COMMITTEES TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL GUIDANCE  IN ADDITION, PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, OPERATORS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC ALSO REQUEST INFORMATION CONCERNING IMPROVEMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS FOR WILDLIFE RESOURCES, PROTECTING AND OR CREATING WILDLIFE HABITAT, MANAGING WILDLIFE POPULATIONS, AND PREVENTION OR ALLEVIATION OF DAMAGE CAUSED BY BIRDS AND OR MAMMALS  PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO OTHER PUBLIC AND PRIVATE ENTITIES AFFORDS ADWFF AN OPPORTUNITY TO ENSURE BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES ARE IMPLEMENTED TO CONSERVE WILDLIFE RESOURCES FOR THE LONG TERM BENEFIT OF WILDLIFE AND WILDLIFE USERS

IN ORDER FOR GRANT COMPLIANCE TO BE EFFECTIVELY MONITORED AND REPORTED, THE DEPARTMENT HAS DESIGNATED A FEDERAL AID COORDINATOR POSITION TO HELP SUPPORT AND ASSIST IN THESE PROCESSES AND SYSTEMS  THE FEDERAL AID COORDINATOR POSITION ASSISTS THE DEPARTMENT GRANT MANAGERS, ADMINISTRATIVE LEADERSHIP AND STAFF IN ORDER FOR THEM TO MEET THEIR PROGRAM AND GRANT OBJECTIVES, THEIR BUDGET MANDATES AS WELL AS HELP THEM FIND AND ANALYZE DIFFERENT SOURCES FOR STATE MATCH

THIS GRANT WILL PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR HABITAT RESTORATION AND REHABILITATION PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION ACROSS THE STATE OF NEVADA  OVER THE LAST 30 YEARS NEVADA S HABITATS CHARACTERIZED AS MODERATE TO GOOD SHRUB AND GRASSLANDS HAVE DECREASED BY HALF WHILE AREAS CLASSIFIED AS BEING IN POOR CONDITION HAVE INCREASED FOUR FOLD  DUE TO THESE NEGATIVE LANDSCAPE CHANGES, THERE IS A NEED TO ASSESS, PLAN, COORDINATE, AND IMPLEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND REHABILITATION PROJECTS DESIGNED TO RESTORE HEALTHY, FUNCTIONING SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEMS THAT ARE SPECIES DIVERSE AND ECOLOGICALLY RESILIENT  NDOW BIOLOGISTS PLAN, CONSULT, AND IMPLEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION AND REHABILITATION PROJECTS ACROSS ALL LAND OWNERSHIPS THROUGHOUT NEVADA TO IMPROVE WILDLIFE HABITAT VALUES  SUBSEQUENTLY, WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND WILDLIFE DEPENDENT RECREATION AND VALUES BENEFIT

THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION PROGRAM WAS INITIATED IN 1937 UNDER THE PITTMAN ROBERTSON ACT  1937  TO PROVIDE FEDERALFUNDING TO STATES FOR THE BENEFIT OF A DIVERSE ARRAY OF WILDLIFE AND ASSOCIATED HABITATS  THIS GRANT FUNDS THEANNUAL OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF THE RIVERSIDE WILDLIFE AREA, THE ROGERS WILDLIFE AREA, THE SNAKE RIVERISLANDS, BURNS POND WILDLIFE AREA, CHICKAHOMINY WILDLIFE AREA, FISH LAKE WILDLIFE AREA, AND YELLOWJACKET LAKEWILDLIFE AREA  THIS GRANT ALSO FUNDS ASSISTANCE AND TECHNICAL GUIDANCE TO PUBLIC LAND MANAGERS AND PRIVATELANDOWNERS IN MALHEUR AND HARNEY COUNTIES WITH REGARDS TO WILDLIFE HABITAT RESTORATION PROTECT, ENHANCE, RESTORE, AND PROMOTE WILDLIFE HABITATS AND THE MALHEUR WATERSHED UTILIZING SOUND STEWARDSHIPPRACTICES, WHILE PROVIDING WILDLIFE ORIENTATED RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE PUBLIC

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO ADDRESS ONGOING WILDLIFE HABITAT DEGRADATION BY IMPROVING, MAINTAINING, ANDRESTORING WILDLIFE HABITAT THROUGHOUT THE JOHN DAY WATERSHED  WILDLIFE HABITAT QUALITY IN OREGON HAS BEENDEGRADED AND FRAGMENTED AS A RESULT OF DEVELOPMENT, AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES, TIMBER HARVEST, AND ACTIVITIESASSOCIATED WITH INCREASES IN THE HUMAN POPULATION  OREGON CONSERVATION STRATEGY 2016   THE JOHN DAY WATERSHEDDISTRICT LANDS ARE MADE UP OF MULTIPLE PARCELS OF LAND OWNED AND OR MANAGED BY VARIOUS ENTITIES AND VARY IN SIZE,LOCATION AND TOPOGRAPHY ODFW MANAGEMENT IS REQUIRED TO PROTECT, ENHANCE AND RESTORE HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE AND FISH SPECIES IN THEDISTRICT, INCLUDING FIVE WILDLIFE AREAS TOTALING 17,091 ACRES  LANDS ADMINISTERED BY ODFW WITHIN THE COLUMBIABASIN WA PROVIDES ESSENTIAL HABITATS FOR 129 BIRD SPECIES, 32 KNOWN MAMMAL SPECIES, 16 SPECIES OF AMPHIBIANS ANDREPTILES AS WELL AS 14 SPECIES OF FISH  ADDITIONALLY, BRIDGE CREEK WA SUPPORTS 116 BIRD SPECIES, 48 MAMMALSPECIES INCLUDING MORE THAN 2,500 ROCKY MOUNTAIN ELK FOR UP TO 5 MONTHS, 9 SPECIES OF AMPHIBIAN AND REPTILE ASWELL AS 15 SPECIES OF FISH INCLUDING TWO LISTED SPECIES THE JOHN DAY WATERSHED WILDLIFE HABITAT PROGRAM PROVIDES AN ESTIMATED 2,000 HUNTER DAYS, 300 ANGLER DAYS, AND1,300 DAYS OF OTHER FORMS OF WILDLIFE ORIENTED RECREATION ANNUALLY  TECHNICAL ADVICE IS REQUIRED TO HELPCOORDINATE CONSERVATION EFFORTS AMONG NUMEROUS LANDOWNERS INCLUDING LOCAL, STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES  ODFWMANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES ARE CRITICAL TO MAINTAIN HABITAT QUALITY THROUGHOUT THE WATERSHED, COORDINATE CONSERVATIONEFFORTS, ALLEVIATE DAMAGE DEPREDATION ON PRIVATE LANDS, AND PROVIDE CONTINUED WILDLIFE ORIENTED RECREATIONALOPPORTUNITIES THIS GRANT FUNDS THE ANNUAL OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF THE JOHN DAY WATERSHED WILDLIFE HABITAT PROGRAM

IN WEST VIRGINIA, RIVER OTTER POPULATIONS HAVE REBOUNDED FROM A LOW IN THE 1970 S TO A THRIVING POPULATION TODAY SUPPORTING A HARVEST OF 80 100 ANIMALS STATEWIDE  NUMEROUS TRAPPERS AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC HAVE MADE REQUESTS TO HAVE THE TRAPPING SEASON LIBERALIZED  HOWEVER, THE WEST VIRGINIA DIVISION OF NATURAL RESOURCES, WILDLIFE RESOURCES SECTION HAS BEEN RELUCTANT TO SUPPORT THESE PROPOSALS WITHOUT THE PROPER DATA TO ENSURE THE PROPER MANAGEMENT OF THE SPECIES THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO ASSESS THE GENETIC POPULATION STRUCTURE AND DIVERSITY OF OTTERS AND PERFORM A GENETIC ANALYSIS OF OTTER S DIET PROJECT OBJECTIVES OF THIS GRANT INCLUDE 1  CONDUCTING A DIET ANALYSIS OF THE STOMACH CONTENTS FROM OTTERS 2  CONDUCTING A GENETIC ASSESSMENT OF OTTER POPULATION STRUCTURE AND DIVERSITY 3  CONDUCTING A TOXICOLOGY SCREENING OF RIVER OTTERS EXECUTION OF THIS GRANT WILL ENHANCE THE KNOWLEDGE AND MANAGEMENT OF RIVER OTTER IN WEST VIRGINIA  IT WILL SUPPLY VALUABLE INFORMATION TO BIOLOGISTS SO THAT THEY MAY MAKE SOUND MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS TO ENSURE THE PROPER MANAGEMENT OF THE SPECIES

THE FY 22 23 CAPITAL CONSTRUCTION GRANT FOR THE TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT  TPWD  WILDLIFE DIVISION, WILL ALLOW TPWD TO COMPLY WITH STATE LAWS IN ITS FACILITIES  IT WILL PROVIDE A CONSERVATION FACILITY FOR THE ORIENTATION AND SUPPORT OF RESEARCHERS AND PUBLIC USERS  IT WILL PROVIDE FOR THE SAFETY AND SECURITY OF STATE OWNED AND OPERATED FACILITIES ON WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS

THE DOUBLE E WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA  WMA  ENCOMPASSES 5,828 DEEDED ACRES NEAR GILA, NM  THE PROPERTY INCLUDES LEASES OF 3,644 ACRES OF BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT  BLM  PROPERTY AND 2,493 ACRES OF STATE OF NEW MEXICO LAND OFFICE  SLO  PROPERTY  ROUGHLY 5 KM  3 MILES  OF BEAR CREEK, A TRIBUTARY OF THE GILA RIVER, RUNS THROUGH THE WMA  BEAR CREEK ON THE DOUBLE E IS CONSIDERED PERENNIAL, HOWEVER, AT DIFFERENT LOCATIONS THE CREEK RUNS SUBSURFACE  THEREFORE, DURING EXTREME DROUGHT YEARS, WATER AVAILABILITY IS UNRELIABLE FOR WILDLIFE SPECIES INCLUDING MULE DEER, ELK, BIGHORN SHEEP, AND WILD TURKEY PRIOR TO 2014, MUCH OF BEAR CREEK ON THE DOUBLE E PROPERTY WAS BULL DOZED TO ALLOW FOR VEHICLE ACCESS DISRUPTING THE CREEK AND THE SURROUNDING VEGETATION  AS A RESULT, BEAR CREEK NOW LACKS COMPLEXITY AND OLD GROWTH VEGETATION ALONG THE RIVER  UNDER DEPARTMENT MANAGEMENT, THE ROAD WEAVING IN AND OUT OF BEAR CREEK HAS BEEN ABANDONED AND THE VEGETATION HAS STARTED TO REGROW  HOWEVER, THERE ARE NOW MANY SINGLE AGE WILLOWS THAT ARE CAUSING BEAR CREEK TO INCISE, AND CAUSING THE CREEK TO GO UNDERGROUND MORE OFTEN REDUCING THE AMOUNT OF AVAILABLE SURFACE WATER THERE IS A NEED TO INSTALL BEAVER DAM ANALOGS  BDAS  AND POST ASSISTED LARGE WOODY DEBRIS STRUCTURES  PALS  TO ALLOW THE WATER TABLE TO RISE  A RISE IN THE WATER TABLE WILL BENEFIT LARGE GAME SPECIES SUCH AS DEER, ELK AND DESERT BIGHORN SHEEP BY INCREASING THE AMOUNT OF SURFACE WATER, EVEN IN EXTREME DROUGHT AS WELL AS INCREASING VEGETATION GROWTH FOR FORAGE AND HIDING COVER  AN INCREASE IN VEGETATION WILL ALSO INCREASE ROOSTING HABITAT FOR TURKEY

THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS TO INCREASE WETLANDS THAT PROVIDE FOOD, PROTECTION FROM PREDATORS, AND OTHER VITAL HABITAT FACTORS FOR MANY OF THE KANSAS WILDLIFE SPECIES AND, IN SOME CASES, INCLUDING ENDANGERED AND THREATENED SPECIES  THE WETLANDS INCREASE WILL HOPEFULLY DISPERSE SPORTSMAN PRESSURE THROUGH KANSAS AND EACH PROPERTY  THE ADDED BENEFITS OF THESE PROJECTS WILL REDUCE STAFFING NEEDS, SAVE MONEY IN PUMPING COSTS IN THE FUTURE, IMPROVE AND ENHANCE OVERALL WETLAND HABITAT CONDITIONS, AND HAVE WATER CONSERVATION BENEFITS  THESE PROJECTS ARE TO DEVELOP, RESTORE AND IMPROVE THE WATER DELIVERY AND MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS ON THESE PROPERTIES AND CONTINUE IMPACTING ALL WETLAND SPECIES  THE OUTCOMES OF EACH OF THE PROJECTS WILL INCREASE OUR STATE AND LOCAL WETLANDS AND WILL ENHANCE EFFICIENCY AND PROVIDE MIGRATORY BIRD HABITAT, EVEN WHEN MINIMUM DESIRABLE STREAM FLOWS AND RAINFALL EVENTS PREVENT AREA MANAGERS FROM INUNDATING WETLAND UNITS

PROJECT PURPOSE  TO INCREASE THE SAFETY OF STAFF AND BISON AS BOTH CORRAL SYSTEMS WERE BUILT OVER 50 YEARS AGO AND HAVE HAD MINIMAL UPGRADES SINCE 1996 WITH USED SUPPLIES THAT WERE OBTAINED WITH THE AREA  IN ORDER TO CONTINUE WITH OUR WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT IN THESE AREAS, NEW CORRALS MUST BE DEVELOPED TO ENSURE THE SAFETY OF OUR STAFF AND THE BISON ACTIVITIES PERFORMED  THE PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE THE CONSTRUCTION OF TWO NEW CORRAL SYSTEMS AND WILL INCLUDE ALL CORRAL MATERIALS, WATERLINES, WINDMILLS, FENCES, BISON CHUTES, AND REMOVAL OF THE OLD, UNSAFE SYSTEM DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  A PRIMARY EXPECTED OUTCOME IS TO DEVELOP A SAFE CORRAL SYSTEM FOR BOTH STAFF AND BISON WHEN WORKING THE ANIMALS  THE NEW DESIGN WILL DECREASE BISON S CONTACT AND SUPPLY THE AREA WITH A RELIABLE SYSTEM THAT IS SAFE TO STAFF  THE NEW SYSTEMS WILL ALSO SAVE FUNDS BY REDUCING THE STAFFING REQUIRED TO WORK THE BISON DURING ROUND UPS  THIS SITE SPECIFIC ENHANCEMENT WILL PROVIDE MORE MANAGEABLE RANGELANDS THAT ARE ESSENTIAL TO MANY UPLAND SPECIES AND GREAT ADDITIONAL ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE STATE OF KANSAS AND OUR SPORTSMEN INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  THE PRIMARY INTENDED BENEFICIARIES WILL BE THE WELFARE OF THE BISON DURING ROUND UPS  THE NEW SYSTEM WILL REDUCE THE NUMBER OF INJURIES TO ANIMALS DURING THE MANDATORY ROUND UPS, WHICH WILL INCREASE THE PRODUCTIVITY OF OUR RANGELANDS  THESE TWO NEW SYSTEMS WILL ALSO MINIMIZE BISON AND STAFF CONTACT, WHICH WILL RESULT IN A SAFER ENVIRONMENT

EARLY SUCCESSIONAL HABITAT IS IMPORTANT FOR A NUMBER OF SPECIES, INCLUDING  PHEASANTS, QUAIL, GROUSE, DEER, TURKEYS, RABBITS AND MANY MORE SPECIES  EARLY SUCCESSIONAL HABITAT IS THE VEGETATION THAT OCCURS ON A SITE IMMEDIATELY OR WITHIN THE NEXT GROWING SEASON AFTER THAT SITE HAS BEEN DISTURBED  DISTURBANCE CAN BE CAUSED BY FIRE, GRAZING, HAYING, FLOODING, DISKING, TILLING OR ANY OTHER ACTION THAT MIGHT REMOVE EXISTING VEGETATION AND CAUSE SEEDS IN THE SEED BANK TO GERMINATE  EARLY SUCCESSIONAL PLANTS THAT GERMINATE ARE GENERALLY HERBACEOUS ANNUALS AND PERENNIALS THAT QUICKLY OCCUPY DISTURBED SITES  EARLY SUCCESSIONAL HABITAT IS IMPORTANT BECAUSE OF THE FOOD, STRUCTURE AND DIVERSITY PROVIDED BY ITS  COMPONENTS  THE PRIMARY NEED OF THIS GRANT IS TO PROVIDE FOR THE DEVELOPMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF EARLY SUCCESSIONAL VEGETATION ON MANY OF THE 280 WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS ACROSS NEBRASKA

MONTANA FISH, WILDLIFE AND PARKS  FWP  WILDLIFE DIVISION S CORE RESPONSIBILITY IS TO MANAGE WILDLIFE POPULATIONS ACROSS THE LANDSCAPE OF MONTANA  THIS TASK CAN ONLY BE SUCCESSFULLY ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH EFFICIENT ADMINISTRATION AND COORDINATION, THE ESTABLISHMENT OF HUNTING AND TRAPPING SEASONS BASED ON CONTINUOUS EVALUATION OF POPULATION DATA, MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT OF SEASONS, EVALUATION OF THE HEALTH OF WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND THEIR ASSOCIATED HABITATS, MANAGING POPULATIONS AND HABITATS AS NECESSARY TO ENHANCE AND IMPROVE LONG TERM SUSTAINABILITY, OPERATING FWP WILDLIFE LANDS FOR WILDLIFE AND RECREATIONALIST AND BY WORKING WITH PUBLIC IN ORDER TO SECURE A LEVEL OF TOLERANCE FOR WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND ACCESS TO THOSE POPULATIONS AND TO PRESERVE OR ENHANCE HABITATS

THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF NEVADA S HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM IS TO EDUCATE NEW HUNTERS IN FIREARMS SAFETY, ETHICS, REGULATIONS, AND GAME CARE WHICH WILL MAKE THEM SAFER AND MORE RESPONSIBLE WHEN GOING AFIELD  IN ADDITION TO PROVIDING THE ACCOMPANYING SUPPORT AND TRAINING TO MAINTAIN A CADRE OF 200 300 DIVERSE, TRAINED, KNOWLEDGEABLE, MOTIVATED VOLUNTEER HUNTER EDUCATION INSTRUCTORS STATEWIDE THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF NDOW S PITTMAN ROBERTSON MODERNIZATION PROGRAM IS TO PROMOTE SAFE HUNTING AND RECREATIONAL SHOOTING ENHANCED HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAMMING INCLUDES NDOW S ARCHERY EDUCATION PROGRAMS, NATIONAL ARCHERY IN THE SCHOOLS PROGRAM  NASP  AND VARIOUS SPECIES SPECIFIC AND HUNTING TECHNIQUES WORKSHOPS  PROGRAMMING IS DESIGNED TO EDUCATE BOTH NEW AND EXISTING HUNTERS SHOOTERS ON ADDITIONAL HUNTING AND SHOOTING OPPORTUNITIES TO BECOME PROFICIENT IN VARIOUS SHOOTING SPORTS, HUNTING TECHNIQUES AND SKILLS

THE NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE  NDOW  REPAIRS AND MAINTAINS APPROXIMATELY 1,725 EXISTING WATER DEVELOPMENTS STATEWIDE  NDOW LOCATES, CLEARS, INSTALLS, AND MAINTAINS ARTIFICIAL WATER DEVELOPMENTS AND NATURAL SPRING DEVELOPMENTS WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF VOLUNTEER SPORTSMEN ORGANIZATIONS  ARTIFICIAL AND NATURAL WATER DEVELOPMENTS ENHANCE NEVADA S WILDLIFE HABITAT WHERE WATER IS THE LIMITING FACTOR TO ESTABLISHING AND SUSTAINING WILDLIFE POPULATIONS  ARTIFICIAL AND NATURAL WATER DEVELOPMENTS ARE ESSENTIAL TO WILDLIFE POPULATIONS, ESPECIALLY DURING PERIODS OF DROUGHT  ARTIFICIAL WATER DEVELOPMENTS ARE NEEDED TO EXPAND AND SUSTAIN GAME AND NON GAME WILDLIFE SPECIES WHEN NATURAL WATER SOURCES ARE INSUFFICIENT, DEGRADED, OR LOST AND NO LONGER PROVIDE AN ADEQUATE WATER SOURCE FOR WILDLIFE  NATURAL WATER DEVELOPMENTS INCLUDE PROTECTION AND RESTORATION OF NATURAL SPRINGS, SEEPS, AND OTHER WATER SOURCES  THESE DEVELOPMENTS ENSURE NATURAL WATER SOURCES ARE AVAILABLE TO SUSTAIN WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND PROVIDE CRUCIAL HABITAT TYPES FOR MANY SPECIES  THIS PROJECT WILL BUILD, REBUILD, OR COMPLETE MAJOR MAINTENANCE ON TEN ARTIFICIAL WATER DEVELOPMENTS AND FIVE NATURAL SPRING PROTECTION PROJECTS DURING THE GRANT PERIOD  ADDITIONALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL CONDUCT AERIAL AND GROUND INSPECTIONS, AND COMPLETE MINOR MAINTENANCE WHERE NEEDED, ON 435 ARTIFICIAL WATER DEVELOPMENTS OR NATURAL SPRING PROJECTION PROJECTS  AS A RESULT OF THIS WORK, EXISTING WILDLIFE POPULATIONS WILL CONTINUE TO BENEFIT FROM DEPENDABLE WATER SOURCES

HANDLING LARGE VOLUMES OF DATA REQUIRES DEDICATED PERSONNEL, HARDWARE AND SOFTWARE INFRASTRUCTURE, AND TIME  NDOW HAS BEEN CONTINUALLY DEVELOPING ITS GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEM  GIS  PROGRAM SINCE ITS INCEPTION AND MAINTAINS AN EXTENSIVE SYSTEM OF WILDLIFE SPECIES AND HABITAT DATA COLLECTION, MANAGEMENT, AND ANALYSIS TOOLS UTILIZED BY NDOW TO MAKE EFFECTIVE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS  MAINTAINING, DEVELOPING, AND EXPANDING THE WILDLIFE RESOURCES DATA SYSTEM IS ESSENTIAL TO PROVIDE THE CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURE NDOW NEEDS TO MAKE DATA DRIVEN DECISIONS GROUNDED IN SCIENCE AS NDOW CONTINUES TO ADVANCE IN BOTH TECHNOLOGICAL AND PROFESSIONAL CAPACITY, THE DEMANDS OF MANAGING EVER GROWING AMOUNTS OF WILDLIFE AND HABITAT INFORMATION WILL ONLY INCREASE OVER TIME  THIS PROJECT WILL ENSURE NDOW DEDICATES ADEQUATE FUNDING TO MEET THESE DEMANDS AND REMAIN EFFECTIVE IN ITS MISSION TO RESTORE WILDLIFE AND HABITAT IN NEVADA THE NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE  NDOW  GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEM  GIS  PROGRAM AIMS TO ENSURE THE FOLLOWING 1  NDOW REMAINS TECHNICALLY CAPABLE OF MAKING EFFECTIVE WILDLIFE AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT DECISIONS GROUNDED IN DATA DRIVEN SCIENCE THROUGH EFFECTIVE DATA MANAGEMENT 2  NDOW REMAINS TECHNICALLY CAPABLE OF MAKING EFFECTIVE WILDLIFE AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT DECISIONS THROUGH THE EFFECTIVE USE AND ANALYSIS OF WILDLIFE AND HABITAT DATA 3  NDOW IS ADEQUATELY REPRESENTED IN THE PROFESSIONAL COMMUNITY AND MAINTAINS THE HIGHEST LEVEL OF EXPERTISE AND EXPOSURE TO CURRENT WILDLIFE AND HABITAT DATA MANAGEMENT BEST PRACTICES AND SCIENCE  AND4  THE EFFECTIVE IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS PROJECT AND THE EFFICIENT USE OF THE FUNDS PROVIDED

THE HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM IS A PUBLIC EDUCATION EFFORT PROVIDING INSTRUCTION IN THE SAFE HANDLING OF FIREARMS AND OTHER OUTDOOR ACTIVITIES RELATED TO HUNTING AND FIREARM USE  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE INSTRUCTION IN BASIC HUNTER EDUCATION, TRAPPER EDUCATION, BOWHUNTER EDUCATION, AND OTHER DISCIPLINE SPECIFIC OR SPECIES SPECIFIC COURSES IN MASSACHUSETTS  THE RECRUITMENT, RETENTION, AND REACTIVATION PROGRAM WORKS TO EXPAND EXISTING PROGRAMS TO RECRUIT, RETAIN, AND RE ENGAGE RESIDENT HUNTERS, TRAPPERS AND SHOOTING SPORTS PARTICIPANTS  EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE INCREASED SAFETY FOR HUNTERS AND NON HUNTERS AND THE WISE MANAGEMENT, ETHICAL USE OF,AND A GREATER APPRECIATION FOR OUR WILDLIFE RESOURCES AS WELL AS CONTINUED ENGAGEMENT OF OUR HUNTING AND SHOOTING CONSTITUENCY  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE GENERAL PUBLIC OF MASSACHUSETTS  THERE ARE NO SUB RECIPIENTS

TO PROVIDE FISH AND WILDLIFE DATA AND RECOMMENDATIONS TO, AND COORDINATION WITH, APPROPRIATE FEDERAL AND STATE LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES, REGIONAL OR LOCAL PLANNING GROUPS, AND OTHER DECISIONS MAKERS IN ALL LAND AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANS USING SCIENCE AND DATA DRIVE EXPERTISE, AND TO EXPAND OUR KNOWLEDGE AND EXPERTISE THROUGH COLLABORATIVE, FOCUSED RESEARCH NDOW RECOGNIZES THE IMPORTANCE OF COMMUNICATING WITH AGENCY PARTNERS, THE PUBLIC, AND OTHER INTERESTED PARTIES ON WILDLIFE RESOURCES AND POTENTIAL IMPACTS TO THOSE RESOURCES AS A RESULT OF DIFFERING ACTIVITIES ACROSS THE LANDSCAPE  NDOW REGULARLY PROVIDES FEEDBACK AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO AGENCY PARTNERS, INTERESTED MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC AND OTHER INTERESTED PARTIES THROUGH PROVIDING EXPERT ADVICE ON FISH AND WILDLIFE ASSESSMENTS, RESEARCH TECHNIQUES, AND OR SPECIES HABITAT MANAGEMENT, PRIMARILY THROUGH THE NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY ACT PROCESS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND AND AVOID, MINIMIZE, OR MITIGATE POTENTIAL IMPACTS  ADDITIONALLY, NDOW PROVIDES FISH AND WILDLIFE DATA THROUGH FORMAL DATA REQUESTS, AND PROVIDES DETAILED ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEWS OF RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANS, RECOMMENDATIONS, AND COORDINATION TO ENSURE THAT FISH AND WILDLIFE CONSIDERATIONS ARE INCLUDED IN ALL LAND AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANS IN CONCERT WITH THE PUBLIC LANDS MULTIPLE USE CONCEPT AND THE STATE OF NEVADA WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN  A KEY COMPONENT OF THE TECHNICAL GUIDANCE PROGRAM IS ALSO TO PROVIDE SUPPORT TO NDOW REGIONAL BIOLOGISTS ASSISTING IN THE PLANNING PROCESS WITH FEDERAL LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES  ALL REVIEWS, DATA REQUESTS, AND COORDINATION ARE TRACKED BY PROJECT OR PLAN TYPE, AND NDOW USES THIS INFORMATION FOR REPORTING PURPOSES THROUGHOUT THE FISCAL YEAR

GRANT FUNDS WILL BE USED BY THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION FOR LAND ACQUISITION  THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO ACQUIRE LAND  SURFACE RIGHTS  FOR WILDLIFE HABITAT AND PUBLIC ACCESS FOR HUNTING AND OTHER WILDLIFE ORIENTED RECREATION IN OKLAHOMA  IN OKLAHOMA AND THE UNITED STATES, MOST OF THE LAND WHERE WILDLIFE CAN BE FOUND IS PRIVATELY OWNED  THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION HAS RECOGNIZED A NEED TO ACQUIRE LAND IN OKLAHOMA IN ORDER TO CONSERVE WILDLIFE HABITAT TO SUSTAIN HEALTHY POPULATIONS OF WILDLIFE AND TO PROVIDE PUBLIC ACCESS FOR HUNTING AND OTHER WILDLIFE ASSOCIATED RECREATION  ACQUISITION OF LAND IN OKLAHOMA WILL ENSURE PERMANENT CONSERVATION OF ADDITIONAL ACRES OF WILDLIFE HABITAT IN ORDER TO SUSTAINHEALTHY POPULATIONS OF WILDLIFE AND TO PROVIDE PUBLIC ACCESS FOR HUNTING AND OTHER WILDLIFE ASSOCIATED RECREATION

THE PROPOSED BIG SNOWY MOUNTAINS WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA  WMA  IS LOCATED IN THE FOOTHILLS OF THE BIG SNOWY MOUNTAINS, AN ISOLATED MOUNTAIN RANGE OF PUBLIC OWNERSHIP SURROUNDED BY PRIVATELY OWNED FOOTHILLS THAT IS TYPICAL OF ISLAND MOUNTAIN RANGES IN CENTRAL MONTANA  THERE IS A NEED TO SECURE THIS UNIQUE PROPERTY, AS SALE TO A PRIVATE OWNER WOULD LIKELY MEAN LOSING THE ABILITY TO PROVIDE PERMANENT PUBLIC ACCESS  MANY PROPERTIES ALONG THE BIG AND LITTLE SNOWY MOUNTAINS HAVE UNDERGONE OWNERSHIP CHANGES IN RECENT YEARS  THESE LAND OWNERSHIP CHANGES ARE OFTEN TO BUYERS PRIMARILY INTERESTED IN RECREATION RATHER THAN AGRICULTURAL VALUES, WHO OFTEN IMPOSE PUBLIC ACCESS RESTRICTIONS OR OUTRIGHT PROHIBITIONS  A GROWING INTEREST IN ACCESS TO OCCUPIED ELK HABITAT IN THIS HUNTING DISTRICT ALSO MAKES CONSERVATION OF THIS LAND A TIMELY AND IMPORTANT ACTION

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT PROPOSAL IS TO OBLIGATE FUNDS TO SOUTH DAKOTA GAME, FISH, AND PARKS  SDGFP  TO ENABLE THEM TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IN AN EFFORT TO AID THEM IN EFFECTIVELY MANAGING POPULATIONS OF CANADA GEESE, WHITE TAILED DEER, MULE DEER AND ELK WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT IS A COMPLEX AND ADAPTIVE PROCESS THAT MUST INCLUDE CONSIDERATION OF THE BIOLOGICAL, SOCIAL, ECONOMIC, AND POLITICAL FACTORS  IN GENERAL, ALL WILDLIFE MANAGERS MUST MAKE DECISIONS THAT RECOGNIZE THESE CONSIDERATIONS BECAUSE WILDLIFE IS A PUBLIC TRUST RESOURCE, BUT IN PARTICULAR, SDGFP IS EVEN FURTHER CHALLENGED TO EFFECTIVELY MANAGE WILDLIFE IN A STATE WHERE NEARLY 85  OF THE LAND MASS IS IN PRIVATE OWNERSHIP  SUCCESSFUL WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS MUST WORK COOPERATIVELY AND IN CONCERT WITH FARMERS AND RANCHERS TO BE EFFECTIVE BOOKHOUT 1996   WITHOUT THIS PARTNERSHIP, IT WOULD NOT BE POSSIBLE TO MEET THE AGENCY S RESPONSIBILITY OF SUSTAINABLY MANAGING SOUTH DAKOTA S WILDLIFE RESOURCES AS WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT SUCCEEDED WITH RESTORING AND CONSERVING WILDLIFE POPULATIONS ACROSS SOUTH DAKOTA, MANY OF THESE GROWING POPULATIONS BEGAN TO IMPACT PRIVATE LANDOWNERS  BECAUSE PRIVATE LANDOWNERS PLAY SUCH AN INTEGRAL ROLE IN WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT, SDGFP HAS PROVIDED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS WHEN HUMAN WILDLIFE CONFLICTS HAVE OCCURRED  SDGFP COOPERATIVELY WORKS WITH OVER 1,000 PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, FARMERS, AND RANCHERS TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND EFFECTIVE WILDLIFE POPULATION MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS ANNUALLY FOR CANADA GOOSE, WHITE TAILED DEER, MULE DEER, AND ELK

CURRENTLY, FLORIDA S WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA  WMA  SYSTEM CONSISTS OF OVER 150 TRACTS AND 6 MILLION ACRES  THERE ARE 83 WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS AND 4 55 MILLION ACRES ON THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION GRANT  FLORIDA S WMAS PROVIDE A VARIETY OF RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES, SUCH AS HUNTING, FISHING, AND WILDLIFE VIEWING  THESE NATURAL AREAS ALSO PROVIDE VALUE BY MAINTAINING ENDANGERED SPECIES, PRESERVING WETLANDS, AND PROVIDING A STABLE ECOSYSTEM  AS FLORIDA S LANDSCAPE BECOME SUBJECT TO MORE GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT, THE FUTURE OF MANY WILDLIFE SPECIES WILL REST WITH HOW GOOD WE ARE AS LAND MANAGERS AND STEWARDS OF THE RESOURCES  IT IS IMPERATIVE THAT SOUND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES ARE IMPLEMENTED ON THESE CONSERVATION LANDS TO PROTECT THE NATURAL RESOURCES AND BALANCE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES  PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE THE DEVELOPMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF WMAS IN FLORIDA  THIS GRANT WILL RESTORE, MAINTAIN, AND ENHANCE THE HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE AND ASSIST IN PROVIDING PUBIC ACCESS TO THE WMAS OF FLORIDA

TO PROVIDE EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT, COORDINATION, AND TECHNICAL SUPPORT FOR THE UTAH DIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES  UDWR  FEDERAL AID PROGRAMS  WHICH INCLUDES THE CONTRACTUAL ANNUAL PAYMENTS FOR IN LIEU OF TAXES TO UTAH COUNTIES FOR WILDLIFE RESTORATION ACT AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION ACT FEDERAL AID LANDS, AS WELL AS WILDLIFE LANDS OBTAINED UNDER SECTION 8 OF THE COLORADO RIVER STORAGE PROJECT ACT, WHICH LANDS WERE ACQUIRED FROM PRIVATE OWNERSHIP ONLY THE COORDINATION WILL INSURE UTAH S ELIGIBILITY FOR CONTINUED FEDERAL AID FUNDING THROUGH COMPLIANCE WITH APPLICABLE LAWS AND REGULATIONS  IT WILL ALSO ENSURE ADEQUATE PLANNING AND EXECUTION OF UTAH S FEDERAL AID GRANTS FOR EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES AND FOR THE SOCIO ECONOMIC BENEFIT TO SPORTS PERSON AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC THE PAYMENT OF IN LIEU OF TAXES AMOUNTS TO COUNTIES WILL COMPLY WITH UTAH LAW AND MAINTAIN FAVORABLE SUPPORT FOR UDWR S FEDERAL AID LAND ACQUISITION AND OWNERSHIP PROGRAM

UTAH S NATURAL LANDSCAPE IS CHANGING  URBAN SPRAWL, COMMERCIAL DEVELOPMENT, NATURAL RESOURCE EXPLORATION AND EXTRACTION, EXPANDING FORMS OF OUTDOOR RECREATION, CLIMATE SHIFTS, RECURRING CATASTROPHIC WILDFIRE, GENERATIONAL LAND OWNERSHIP DIFFERENCES, AND CHANGES IN HUNTING VALUES ARE ALL CONTRIBUTING FACTORS TO A DECREASE IN THE QUALITY AND QUANTITY OF PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE HUNTING AREAS AND HEALTHY WILDLIFE HABITATS  UTAH S WALK IN ACCESS PROGRAM IS A COOPERATIVE DEVELOPMENT OF LAND ACCESS LEASES BETWEEN PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND THE UTAH DIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES  THROUGH FORMAL WRITTEN AGREEMENTS, THE LANDOWNER IS COMPENSATED WITH A STANDARDIZED ANNUAL PAYMENT IN EXCHANGE FOR OPENING THEIR LAND FOR FREE PUBLIC ACCESS TO HUNT OR TRAP  THESE LEASES OPEN APPROXIMATELY 65,000 ACRES OF PRIVATE LAND THAT WOULD NOT OTHERWISE BE ACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC  PARTICIPATING LANDS ARE ENCOURAGED TO MAKE HABITAT IMPROVEMENTS AND CONTINUE TO BE PRODUCTIVE FOR FUTURE WILDLIFE  PUBLIC USERS ARE ENCOURAGED TO RESPECT AND CARE FOR THE PRIVATE LAND TO ENSURE THAT THE PRIVILEGE OF ACCESS REMAINS

THIS GRANT IS A SUB AWARD TO THE UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA  THE ACTION FOR THIS GRANT IS TO PROVIDE RESOURCES TO THE ODWC TO ASSIST IN GLADE MANAGEMENT ON BOTH PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS IN THE OZARK ECOREGION OF OKLAHOMA  GLADE COMMUNITIES OCCUR IN SEVERAL EASTERN STATES, AND BIOLOGISTS HAVE LONG RECOGNIZED THEM AS A UNIQUE AND BIOLOGICALLY SIGNIFICANT HABITAT TYPE IN THE EASTERN UNITED STATES  MANY STATES IN WHICH GLADES OCCUR  SUCH AS MISSOURI  HAVE CREATED GEOSPATIAL RESOURCES THAT CONTAIN MAPS OF GLADES LOCATIONS AND DATA REGARDING THEIR CONDITION AND INTEGRITY  ALTHOUGH GLADES OCCUR IN THE OZARKS AND OUACHITAS OF OKLAHOMA, NO COMPARABLE ASSESSMENTS EXIST FOR CONSERVATION AND WILDLIFE DECISION MAKERS IN OUR STATE  THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO REDRESS THIS SITUATION THROUGH FOUR OBJECTIVES  1  LOCATE AND MAP POTENTIAL GLADE HABITATS IN THE OKLAHOMA OZARKS USE EXISTING SPATIAL DATA LAYERS FOR SOILS, GEOLOGY, AND LAND COVER TO IDENTIFY POTENTIAL SITES, 2  VERIFY AND ASSESS GLADE CONDITION WITH FIELD WORK, 3  MAP HISTORIC EXTENT OF GLADE COMMUNITIES, AND 4  DEVELOP A GEOSPATIAL DATABASE OF GLADE SITES THAT CONTAINS ASSESSMENT OF HABITAT CONDITION  OUTCOMES WILL INCLUDE A SPATIAL DATABASE CONTAINING MAPS OF GLADE SITES, AN ASSESSMENT OF ECOLOGICAL INTEGRITY OF MAPPED GLADES, DATA RELATED TO THE HISTORIC EXTENT AND AREA OCCUPIED BY SPECIFIC GLADES, AND RECOMMENDATIONS FOR FUTURE RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH & WILDLIFES (CDFW) NORTH CENTRAL REGION (NCR) WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM(WMP) IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE GEOGRAPHIC REGION WHICH INCLUDES THE NORTHERN SACRAMENTO VALLEY AND THE CENTRAL SIERRA (APPENDIX A). THIS AREA SPANS SEVENTEEN COUNTIES AND CONTAINS A NETWORK OF MORE THAN 82,000 ACRES OF DEPARTMENT OWNED LAND (APPENDIX B). THE BREAKDOWN OF THESE LANDS IS AS FOLLOWS: TYPE C OR UNSTAFFED WILDLIFE AREAS (WA, 61,403 ACRES), ECOLOGICAL RESERVES (ER, 10,725 ACRES), AND NON-DESIGNATED LANDS (10,000 ACRES); HEREAFTER COLLECTIVELY REFERRED TO AS CONSERVED LANDS. A LIST OF PROPERTIES EXPECTED TO RECEIVE GRANT FUNDED WORK FROM THE NCR'S WMP IS INCLUDED IN TABLE 1. THESE LANDS WERE ORIGINALLY PURCHASED BY OR TRANSFERRED TO CDFW BY THE WILDLIFE CONSERVATION BOARD (WCB) AND OTHER AGENCIES. WHILE THE PRECISE PURPOSE OF THE ACQUISITIONS HAS VARIED THROUGH THE YEARS, MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES REMAIN THE SAME: CONSERVATION AND PRESERVATION OF HABITATS FOR WILDLIFE WHILE PROVIDING COMPATIBLE PUBLIC USE. THE CDFW MANAGES COMPATIBLE PUBLIC USE ACTIVITIES IN ACCORDANCE WITH THIS MISSION, WHICH MAY VARY FROM PROPERTY TO PROPERTY AND INCLUDE: HUNTING, FISHING, HIKING, WILDLIFE WATCHING, BICYCLING, HORSEBACK RIDING, NATURE STUDY, RESEARCH, AND OTHER SUITABLE FORMS OF OUTDOOR RECREATION.

THE IMPERIAL WILDLIFE AREA (IWA) AND JOB #2. SAN JACINTO WILDLIFE AREA (SJWA) ARE BOTH LOCATED IN SOUTHERNCALIFORNIA AND MANAGED BY THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) STAFF.THE IMPERIAL WILDLIFE AREA (IWA) IS A 7,929-ACRE FACILITY LOCATED IN THE IMPERIAL VALLEY IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIAAND MANAGED BY THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW). THE IWA IS A COMPLEX OF THREE DIFFERENTWILDLIFE AREAS: THE WISTER UNIT, FINNEY-RAMER UNIT AND THE HAZARD UNIT. THE HAZARD UNIT, WHILE OWNED BY THE CDFW,IS MANAGED BY THE SONY BONO NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE AND IS NOT PART OF THIS GRANT.IWA WAS FIRST ESTABLISHED IN 1954, FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF WATERFOWL HABITAT, HELP ALLEVIATE CROP DEPREDATIONS ANDTO PROVIDE PUBLIC HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES.THE SAN JACINTO WILDLIFE AREA (SJWA) IS COMPRISED OF TWO SEPARATE UNITS, THE DAVIS UNIT AND POTRERO CANYON UNIT,BOTH MANAGED BY CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW). THESE AREAS ARE JUST NORTH OF THE SMALLCOMMUNITY OF LAKEVIEW IN WESTERN RIVERSIDE COUNTY. WESTERN RIVERSIDE COUNTY, AS PART OF THE INLAND EMPIRE OFSOUTHERN CALIFORNIA IS PERHAPS THE MOST RAPIDLY URBANIZING AREA WITHIN THE STATE. SJWA IS WITHIN A TWO-HOUR DRIVEFROM MORE THAN 10 MILLION SOUTHERN CALIFORNIANS. THE WESTERN BOUNDARY OF THE 19,100-ACRE STATE WILDLIFE AREA ISCONTIGUOUS WITH THE 8,300-ACRE LAKE PERRIS STATE RECREATION AREA. THIS PROVIDES A COMBINED HABITAT AREA ANDMULTIPLE PUBLIC USE ATTRACTION.THE SJWA WAS ESTABLISHED AS PART OF THE MITIGATION PACKAGE DEVELOPED FOR WILDLIFE HABITAT LOSSES RESULTING FROMCONSTRUCTION OF THE STATE WATER PROJECT. INITIAL LAND ACQUISITIONS FOR SJWA WERE COMPLETED DURING THE PERIOD OF1981-82. SINCE THAT TIME, THE WILDLIFE CONSERVATION BOARD (WCB) HAS CONTINUED TO ACQUIRE ADDITIONAL PROPERTIES,INCLUDING THE ACQUISITION OF THE 9,100-ACRE POTRERO UNIT OCCURRING IN 2003.MUCH OF SJWA IS WITHIN THE FLOODPLAIN OF THE SAN JACINTO RIVER. MAJOR WILDLIFE ENHANCEMENT GOALS FOR SJWA INCLUDERESTORATION OF HISTORIC FRESHWATER WETLAND AND RIPARIAN HABITAT VALUES. THE DEVELOPMENT OF PERMANENT AND SEASONALWETLANDS CURRENTLY TOTALS APPROXIMATELY 950 MANAGED ACRES. IN 1990, WCB IN CONJUNCTION WITH EASTERN MUNICIPALWATER DISTRICT COMPLETED A 36-INCH DIAMETER PIPELINE TO DELIVER UP TO 4,500 ACRE-FEET/YEAR OF RECLAIMED WATER TOTHE AREA. THIS RELATIVELY INEXPENSIVE WATER SOURCE IS BEING UTILIZED FOR HABITAT RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT. THECDFW CURRENTLY PURCHASES WATER AT $54.00 PER ACRE FOOT. THE COST OF WATER IS EXPECTED TO INCREASE MORE THAN TWOFOLDIN THE NEAR FUTURE. MORE THAN EIGHT MILES OF THE HISTORIC SAN JACINTO RIVERBED, PREVIOUSLY IMPACTED BY FLOODCONTROL DIVERSIONS, HAVE BEEN RESTORED. THE AREA ALSO SUPPORTS A SIGNIFICANT AMOUNT OF HISTORICAL FARMLAND ANDRIVERSIDEAN COASTAL SAGE SCRUB. CONVERSION OF AGRICULTURAL HABITAT TO UPLAND HABITAT IS CURRENTLY UNDERWAY.

THIS PROJECT INCLUDES ACTIVITIES TO SCIENTIFICALLY MANAGE AND MONITOR WILDLIFE POPULATIONS OF GAME SPECIES. THESE INCLUDE BIG GAME, BEAR, WOLVES, SMALL GAME FURBEARERS, WATERFOWL AND OTHER MIGRATORY GAME BIRDS, WILD TURKEY, AND OTHER RESIDENT SMALL GAME BIRDS. BIG GAME SPECIES INCLUDE MOOSE, WHITE-TAILED DEER, AND ELK. THE PROJECT INCLUDES A VARIETY OF WORK DEPENDING UPON THE SPECIES. FOR EACH SPECIES IT MAY INCLUDE DEFINITION OF MANAGEMENT UNITS, DEVELOPMENT OF MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES, POPULATION SURVEYS, POPULATION MODELING AND MONITORING, STRATEGY DEVELOPMENT AND HARVEST MONITORING. THIS PROJECT ALSO INCLUDES THE MANAGEMENT OF DISEASE OUTBREAKS IN WILDLIFE POPULATIONS.
