PROJECT PURPOSE: CONSERVE AND ENHANCE KANSAS NATURAL HERITAGE, ITS WILDLIFE AND ITS HABITATS--TO ASSURE FUTURE GENERATIONS THE BENEFITS OF THE STATE'S DIVERSE, LIVING RESOURCES; PROVIDE THE PUBLIC WITH OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE USE AND APPRECIATION OF THE NATURAL RESOURCES OF KANSAS, CONSISTENT WITHTHE CONSERVATION OF THOSE RESOURCES; INFORM THE PUBLIC OF THE STATUS OF THE NATURAL RESOURCES OF KANSAS TO PROMOTE UNDERSTANDING AND GAIN ASSISTANCE IN ACHIEVING THIS MISSION. TO PROTECT, CONSERVE, AND ENHANCE KDWP PUBLIC LANDS USING SCIENCE BASED AND BUSINESS INTELLIGENCE INFORMATION, AND TO PROVIDE HUNTING, FISHING, AND COMPATIBLE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR CURRENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS. ACTIVITIES PERFORMED: PUBLIC LANDS DIVISION STAFF AND OTHER CONTRACTED NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS WILL WORK TO IMPROVE WILDLIFE HABITATS AND MAINTAIN STABLE WILDLIFE POPULATIONS OF GAME AND NON-GAME SPECIES FOR KANSAS RESIDENTS, HUNTERS AND OUTDOOR WILDLIFE ENTHUSIASTS. PROTECT THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS. PROVIDE FACILITIES THAT ARE SAFE AND SANITARY AND MEET THE MINIMUM NEEDS OF OUR USERS. OPTIMIZE PUBLIC ACCESS FOR HUNTERS AND OTHER COMPATIBLE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. CONSERVE, MANAGE, AND OPTIMIZE WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS. DEMONSTRATE LEADERSHIP IN LAND STEWARDSHIP. PROVIDE APPROPRIATE INFRASTRUCTURE TO SUPPORT HUNTING AND OTHER COMPATIBLE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: MEETING DEMAND FOR AREAS TO HUNT, MAINTAINING STABLE WILDLIFE POPULATIONS, AND PROVIDING AN ENJOYABLE OPPORTUNITY FOR OUR CONSTITUENTS. INCREASE DEMAND FOR DEER, TURKEY, PHEASANT, QUAIL AND WATERFOWL HUNTING WILL BE MET BY UTILIZING AGGRESSIVE HABITAT MANIPULATION PRACTICES, CONTINUING EFFECTIVE CONTROL METHODS FOR INVASIVE AND NOXIOUS PLANT SPECIES, AND MAXIMIZING PRODUCTIVE HABITATS ON MANAGED PROPERTY. INFRA-STRUCTURE (DAMS, DIKES, PUMPS, RESTROOMS, PARKING LOTS, ROADS, ETC.) WILL BE MAINTAINED TO SUPPORT THE INTEGRITY OF THE STRUCTURES AND FACILITIES AS WELL AS TO PROVIDE SAFE CONDITIONS FOR OUR USERS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: ALL WILDLIFE, GAME AND NON-GAME, POPULATIONS WILL BENEFIT FROM THE BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES AT KDWP WILDLIFE AREAS. GOOD STEWARDSHIP OF OUR EQUIPMENT, INFRASTRUCTURE, AND FACILITIES WILL PROLONG THEIR USEFUL LIFE, WHICH IN TURN, WILL CONTINUE TO HELP WITH BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES AND PROVIDE SAFE INFRASTRUCTURE AND FACILITIES. KDWP CONSTITUENTS WILL RECEIVE THE REWARDS OF IMPROVED WILDLIFE HABITATS AND STABLE WILDLIFE POPULATIONS.

THIS GRANT IS PRIMARILY A SUB-AWARD TO OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY. ODWC WILL PROVIDE MINIMAL FIELD ASSISTANCE AS NEEDED. THE ACTION FOR THIS GRANT IS TO ASSESS THE STATUS OF THE PRAIRIE GRAY FOX POPULATION IN OKLAHOMA (E.G., SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION AND RANGE BOUNDARY, POPULATION TREND, GENETIC DIVERSITY, AND EFFECTIVE POPULATION SIZE [NE]) AND IDENTIFY FACTORS INFLUENCING THE POPULATION (E.G., HABITAT ASSOCIATIONS AND INTERSPECIFIC INTERACTIONS) TO PROVIDE DATA CRITICAL TO INFORMING MANAGEMENT AND THE FEDERAL SPECIES STATUS REVIEW. NONINVASIVE CAMERA AND FECAL DNA SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED IN 37 EASTERN OKLAHOMA COUNTIES. LANDOWNER PERMISSIONS WILL BE OBTAINED PRIOR TO SAMPLING. COLLECTION OF HARVEST-BASED SAMPLES WILL BE CONDUCTED ACROSS THE STATE OF OKLAHOMA IN COORDINATION WITH ODWC, THE OKLAHOMA FUR BEARERS ALLIANCE, AND THE OSU EXTENSION PROGRAM. GENETIC LAB PROCEDURES WILL BE CONTRACTED WITH THE LABORATORY OF ECOLOGICAL, EVOLUTIONARY, AND CONSERVATION GENETICS (UNIVERSITY OF IDAHO).
THIS GRANT PROJECT ANNUALLY FUNDS GENERAL OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE, AS WELL AS SMALL-SCALE WEED CONTROL AT ALL STATE WILDLIFE AREAS IN COLORADO.

THIS GRANT IS A SUB-AWARD TO OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY. THE ACTION FOR THIS GRANT IS TO INVESTIGATE LANDOWNER KNOWLEDGE AND PERCEPTIONS OF MYCOTOXINS IN WILDLIFE FEEDS AND OPINIONS ON IMPLEMENTING BEST PRACTICES ON SUPPLEMENTAL FEED FOR WILDLIFE THAT HAS A HIGH POTENTIAL FOR MYCOTOXINS. SUPPLEMENTAL FEEDING, BROADLY DEFINED AS INTENTIONAL, ANTHROPOGENIC PROVISIONING OF FOOD FOR WILDLIFE, IS A COMMON PRACTICE AMONG PROFESSIONAL WILDLIFE MANAGERS AND BOTH CONSUMPTIVE AND NON-CONSUMPTIVE WILDLIFE ENTHUSIASTS. IT IS INTENDED FOR A WIDE VARIETY OF PURPOSES SUCH AS WILDLIFE VIEWING AND PHOTOGRAPHY, RECREATION/HUNTING, CONDUCTING RESEARCH, DELIVERING MEDICATIONS, AND RESTORING NATURAL DIET-LIMITED WILDLIFE POPULATIONS, AMONG OTHERS (MURRAY ET AL. 2016). ALTHOUGH IT IS KNOWN TO HAVE SOME BENEFICIAL EFFECTS ON WILDLIFE, PARTICULARLY FOR THOSE THAT MAY NOT HAVE ACCESS TO A RELIABLE FOOD SOURCE (MURRAY ET AL. 2016), WILDLIFE FEEDING CAN HAVE NEGATIVE CONSEQUENCES BOTH FOR TARGET AND NON-TARGET SPECIES ACCESSING THE FOOD RESOURCES. AMONG THESE CONSEQUENCES, GRAINS OFFERED TO WILDLIFE CAN HARBOR CONTAMINANTS THAT CAN LEAD TO SEVERE NEGATIVE EFFECTS ON WILDLIFE HEALTH (MURRAY ET AL. 2016). IN PARTICULAR, THESE FOODS MAY BE CONTAMINATED WITH MYCOTOXIN - A TOXIC METABOLIC BYPRODUCT FROM FUNGAL GROWTH. THIS PROJECT LEVERAGES PREVIOUS WORK DONE BY PIS AND AIMS TO FILL THE KNOWLEDGE GAP IN THREE UNIQUE WAYS. FIRST, WE WILL FURTHER ANALYZE AND PUBLISH THE PREVIOUSLY COLLECTED DATA ON AFLATOXIN IN SUPPLEMENTAL FEED (I.E., DALE 2014). SECOND, WE WILL INVESTIGATE LANDOWNER PERCEPTIONS TOWARDS AFLATOXIN AND QUANTIFY THEIR WILLINGNESS TO TAKE MITIGATION MEASURES. THIRD, WE WILL SEGMENT OKLAHOMA LANDOWNERS BASED ON THEIR MOTIVATION (OR LACK THEREOF) FOR IMPLEMENTING BEST PRACTICES THAT CAN REDUCE WILDLIFE EXPOSURE TO MYCOTOXINS IN SUPPLEMENTAL FEEDS. THE INFORMATION FROM OBJECTIVE 3 CAN BE USED TO TAILOR FUTURE COMMUNICATION EFFORTS WITH OKLAHOMA LANDOWNERS.

UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA AND TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT (TPWD) WILL WORK COLLABORATIVELY TOGETHER TO REVIEW THE CURRENT LICENSE TYPES AND SYSTEM, HARVEST SURVEYS, EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN, AND DELIVERY METHOD FOR HARVEST SURVEYS. IN ADDITION, UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA WILL ADVISE TPWD ON FUTURE EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN, STATISTICAL APPROACHES, AND DELIVERY METHODS FOR HARVEST SURVEYS, MANDATORY REPORTING, AND OTHER IDEAS TO IMPROVE HARVEST AND HUNTER ESTIMATES IN TEXAS.

THE COASTAL REFUGIA PROGRAM WAS INITIATED IN RESPONSE TO INCREASING WATERFOWL HUNTING PRESSURE AND DIMINISHING POPULATION NUMBERS OF CERTAIN MIGRATORY GAME BIRD SPECIES ON THE TEXAS COAST (MID-WINTER WATERFOWL SURVEY 1998-2022, TEXAS PARKS & WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT, AUSTIN, TEXAS, USA, UNPUBLISHED DATA). HUNTING PRESSURE IS WIDELY RECOGNIZED AS HAVING A SUBSTANTIAL INFLUENCE ON WATERFOWL HABITAT USE AND DISTRIBUTION (MADSEN AND FOX 1995, DOOLEY ET AL. 2010). SEVERAL STUDIES HAVE DEMONSTRATED THE IMPORTANCE OF REFUGIA (I.E., AREAS FREE FROM HUNTING PRESSURE) TO WATERFOWL DURING HUNTING SEASON (DINGES, ET AL. 2015, GIROUX AND BEDARD 1988, EVANS AND DAY 2002, MADSEN 1998). REFUGIA HAVE BEEN DEMONSTRATED TO INCREASE WATERFOWL ABUNDANCE AND DIVERSITY BEYOND THE IMMEDIATE REFUGES AND, THUS, HAVE BEEN IMPLICATED AS AN EFFICIENT MANAGEMENT TOOL TO IMPROVE CONSERVATION VALUE AND BIODIVERSITY OF WETLANDS (MADSEN 1998). TO DATE, THE EFFECTIVENESS OF REFUGIA HAS ONLY BEEN QUALIFIED VISUALLY AND LIMITED BY HUMAN OBSERVER TIME AND SPHERE OF VISUAL AND AUDITORY DETECTION. ALTHOUGH THESE TECHNIQUES (E.G., AERIAL SURVEYS, GROUND COUNTS) HAVE BEEN ADEQUATE TO DEMONSTRATE THE SIGNIFICANT EFFECTS OF HUNTING-FREE AREAS ON RELATIVELY LOCAL WATERFOWL COMMUNITY DIVERSITY AND ABUNDANCE, A NEED EXISTS TO APPLY MORE QUANTITATIVE METRICS TO THE DESIGN AND ALLOCATION OF REFUGIA ACROSS LARGER LANDSCAPES. THIS IS ESPECIALLY TRUE FOR POPULATIONS THAT ARE LIMITED BY WINTER RESOURCES (FOX AND MADSEN, 1997). WELL-DESIGNED LANDSCAPE-SCALE STUDIES DEMAND STANDARDIZED EQUIPMENT AND PROTOCOLS THAT GENERATE REPEATABLE AND RELIABLE DATA TO DRAW ECOLOGICALLY RELEVANT INFERENCES AND CONCLUSIONS (PEREIRA AND COOPER 2006). AUDIO RECORDING UNITS (ARUS) HAVE BEEN USED IN AN ECOLOGICAL CONTEXT SINCE THE 1970S AND HAVE SPECIFICALLY BEEN EMPLOYED IN AVIAN STUDIES WITH INCREASING FREQUENCY IN THE LAST SEVERAL YEARS (PREZ-GRANADOS, ET AL. 2018, CELIS-MURILLO ET AL. 2009, SHONFIELD AND BAYNE 2017, PREZGRANADOS AND TRABA 2021). ARUS OFFER DISTINCT ADVANTAGES RELATIVE TO HUMAN OBSERVERS IN AVIAN SURVEYS (TABLE 1) ESPECIALLY AS INVESTIGATIVE SCOPE EXPANDS INTO THE SCALE OF 'LANDSCAPE' (ALQUEZAR AND MACHADO 2015, VENIER ET AL. 2012). THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS STUDY ARE TO (1) ESTABLISH HIGH-QUALITY, LANDSCAPE-SCALE MONITORING PROTOCOLS FOR THE COASTAL REFUGIA PROGRAM ON THE TEXAS COAST, (2) QUANTIFY THE USE OF SITES OF REFUGIA SITES BY WATERFOWL AND WETLAND-RELIANT SPECIES, AND (3) PROVIDE PRACTICAL, SCIENTIFICALLY INFORMED RECOMMENDATIONS FOR WATERFOWL CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ON THE TEXAS COAST.
MISSOURI STATEWIDE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT W93D28

WETLAND HABITAT MANAGEMENT ON DIVISION-MANAGED WILDLIFE AREAS AND AGREEMENT LANDS IS CRITICAL TO MAINTAINING SUSTAINABLE WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND WILDLIFE RELATED RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. WITHOUT ROUTINE MANAGEMENT, WETLAND HABITAT WILL BE IMPACTED BY NATURAL SUCCESSION, INVASIVE SPECIES, AND OTHER THREATS WHICH DEGRADE HABITAT QUALITY. FURTHER, IT IS NOT PRACTICAL TO ASSUME THAT THE DIVISION CAN CONSERVE AND ENHANCE WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS WITHOUT THE ASSISTANCE OF LIKE-MINDED CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS AND AGENCIES.THIS ROUTINE OPERATIONS, MANAGEMENT, AND MAINTENANCE PROJECT INCLUDES OBJECTIVES DESIGNED TO SUPPORT WETLAND WILDLIFE HABITAT MANAGEMENT ON DIVISION-MANAGED OR AGREEMENT LANDS. THESE OBJECTIVES INCLUDE (1) PLANNING AND ADMINISTRATION, (2) WETLAND HABITAT MANAGEMENT, AND (3) PARTNERSHIP PROJECTS. ACTIVITIES ARE DEPENDENT ON WEATHER, STAFFING, BUDGET, AND OTHER AVAILABLE RESOURCES. PERSONNEL AND NON-PERSONNEL EXPENSES WERE DETERMINED BASED ON THE CONSOLIDATION OF NUMEROUS INDIVIDUAL PROJECTS IN EACH DISTRICT. PROJECT EVALUATION AND REPORTING ARE CONDUCTED THROUGH AN ANNUAL PERFORMANCE REPORT WITH CONTRIBUTIONS FROM THE WILDLIFE ADVISORY TEAM.DIVISION-LED OR PARTNER-LED WETLAND MANAGEMENT WILL MAINTAIN QUALITY WETLAND HABITAT FOR SUSTAINABLE WETLAND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND PROVIDE WILDLIFE RELATED RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. EXISTING PARTNERSHIPS WITH LIKE-MINDED CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS AND AGENCIES HAVE BEEN STRENGTHENED AND NEW ONES DEVELOPED RESULTING IN GREATER AMOUNTS OF WILDLIFE AND ITS HABITAT PROTECTED, RESTORED AND/OR ENHANCED.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) MANAGES POPULATIONS OF WILDLIFE THROUGHOUT THE STATE ACROSSA DIVERSE RANGE OF HABITATS, ENGAGES THE PUBLIC THROUGH OUTREACH, AND PROVIDES TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND EXPERTISEREGARDING RESOURCE ISSUES. MANAGEMENT OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES INCLUDES ASSESSMENT OF WILDLIFE POPULATIONS ANDHABITATS, AND CONSERVATION OF GAME AND NONGAME BIRDS AND MAMMALS. THE INLAND DESERT REGION'S WILDLIFE MANAGEMENTPROGRAM (IDRWP) IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS OF DATA REGARDING THE CONDITION OF WILDLIFEPOPULATIONS AND HABITATS, MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF GAME BIRDS AND MAMMALS, PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCETO OTHER AGENCIES REGARDING RESOURCE ISSUES, AND PUBLIC OUTREACH IN THE FOLLOWING FIVE COUNTIES: IMPERIAL, INYO,MONO, RIVERSIDE, AND SAN BERNARDINO.THESE RESPONSIBILITIES REPRESENT ACTIVITIES THAT COMPLEMENT OTHER REGIONS AND HEADQUARTERS ACTIVITIES, BUT DO NOTDUPLICATE OTHER CDFW ACTIVITIES SUPPORTED BY EITHER STATE OR FEDERAL ASSISTANCE FUNDS UNDER THE WILDLIFERESTORATION/PITTMAN-ROBERTSON ACT (WR). THE ACTIVITIES ARE CONDUCTED TO CARRY OUT THE CDFW'S TRUSTEERESPONSIBILITIES FOR RESOURCES AND REQUIRE EXTENSIVE COMMUNICATION AND COORDINATION WITH OTHER AGENCIES, CDFWHEADQUARTERS PROGRAMS, REGIONAL CDFW STAFF, AND THE PUBLIC.IDRWP STAFF OF THE INLAND DESERTS REGION-SOUTH (IDRS) MANAGE MULE DEER IN THE MOUNTAINOUS D14 AND D19 ZONES,WHERE DEMOGRAPHIC DATA ARE DIFFICULT TO OBTAIN BECAUSE OF STEEP TOPOGRAPHY AND LIMITED ACCESSIBILITY BY ROAD.THIS GRANT FOCUSES ON DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF METHODS FOR ASSESSMENT AND MONITORING OF MULE DEERDEMOGRAPHY.THESE ACTIVITIES IN IDRS WILL COMPLEMENT WORK IN IDR-NORTH, OTHER REGIONS, AND HEADQUARTERS ACTIVITIES, BUT DONOT DUPLICATE OTHER CDFW ACTIVITIES SUPPORTED BY EITHER STATE OR FEDERAL ASSISTANCE FUNDS UNDER THE WILDLIFERESTORATION/PITTMAN-ROBERTSON ACT. THE ACTIVITIES ENABLE IDRS TO CARRY OUT CDFW'S RESPONSIBILITIES AS TRUSTEEFOR CALIFORNIA'S WILDLIFE RESOURCES.

THIS GRANT FUNDS VERMONT FISH AND WILDLIFE'S RESEARCH, MANAGEMENT AND RESTORATION OF GAME SPECIES IN THE STATE AND IS FOCUSED ON PROJECTS RELATED TO DEER, BLACK BEAR, MIGRATORY BIRDS, MOOSE, SMALL MAMMALS, UPLAND GAME BIRDS AND BEARS, AND WILDLIFE DISEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE. EACH PROJECT OF A SELECT SPECIES OR SUITE OF SPECIES HAS SPECIFIC NEEDS, OBJECTIVES, APPROACHES, AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES THAT APPLY. DESPITE THIS, THE APPROACHES FOR EACH PROJECT REMAINS THE SAME: 1) POPULATION INVENTORY, MONITORING, AND MANAGEMENT; 2) HABITAT MONITORING AND CONSERVATION; AND 3) HUMAN DIMENSIONS AND DISSEMINATION OF RESULTS. THE GRANT WILL FUND THE RESEARCH AND OUTREACH WORK FOR EACH OF THE RESPECTIVE PROJECTS.

THIS GRANT FUNDS VERMONT FISH AND WILDLIFE'S NON-GAME BIRD RESEARCH AND OUTREACH PROGRAM. WITHIN THIS GRANT, PROJECT FUNDS WILL GO TOWARDS:- IMPLEMENTING EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES THAT WILL PLAY A SIGNIFICANT ROLE IN THE CONSERVATION OF VERMONT'S THREATENED AND ENDANGERED BIRD POPULATIONS.- IMPLEMENTING EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES THAT WILL PLAY A SIGNIFICANT ROLE IN THE CONSERVATION OF VERMONT'S SGCN POPULATIONS- IMPLEMENTING EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES THAT WILL PLAY A BENEFICIAL ROLE IN THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN VERMONT'S BIRDS OF SPECIAL CONSERVATION INTEREST AND THE MANY PUBLICS THAT READILY INTERACT WITH THEM.- CONTINUING TO ADVOCATE FOR HABITAT CONSERVATION FOR ALL NATIVE BIRD SPECIES.- CONTINUING TO IMPROVE DECISION-MAKING RESPONSE TO BIRD INJURIES, SICKNESS, AND ENTRAPMENTS THAT FULLY CONSIDER HUMAN SAFETY AND BIRD WELFARE PARAMETERS.- DISSEMINATING CURRENT AND ACCURATE BIRD-RELATED INFORMATION TO THE MANY EXTERNAL AND INTERNAL PUBLICS.

OVERVIEW: THIS GRANT AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) AND THE WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (DEPARTMENT) WILL BE SUB-AWARDED OUT TO FOUR SHOOTING RANGES. PROJECTS WILL INCLUDE CONSTRUCTION IMPROVEMENTS AND PURCHASES TO INCREASE SAFETY AND VIABILITY AND MAINTAIN CAPACITY FOR USERS OF THE CLUBS.BUDGET: ~$195K FEDERAL SHARE; ~$65K STATE MATCHACTION AREA: PRIVATELY OWNED RANGES OPEN FOR PUBLIC USE.GOALS AND OBJECTIVES: INCREASE SAFETY AND VIABILITY AND MAINTAIN CAPACITY FOR USERS OF THE CLUBS.

HE NEW MEXICO STATE GAME COMMISSION OWNS APPROXIMATELY 20,000 ACRES OF LAND IN SOUTHEASTERN NEW MEXICO, WHICH ARE MANAGED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF GAME AND FISH (DEPARTMENT) FOR THE BENEFIT AND CONSERVATION OF LESSER PRAIRIE CHICKENS (TYMPANUCHUS PALLIDICINCTUS). PRIOR TO ACQUISITION BY THE DEPARTMENT, THIS LAND WAS USED FOR SHEEP, GOAT, AND CATTLE RANCHING, OR WERE PREVIOUS FARMLANDS, AND WERE FENCED WITH NET-WIRE OR 7-STRAND BARBED-WIRED FENCES TO CONTAIN LIVESTOCK. THESE FENCES FRAGMENTED THE LANDSCAPE AND NEGATIVELY IMPACTED WILDLIFE MOVEMENTS ESPECIALLY THAT OF PRONGHORN. THERE IS A NEED TO IMPROVE HABITAT CONNECTIVITY AND HELP EXPAND THE RANGE OF GRASSLAND DEPENDENT WILDLIFE SPECIES SUCH AS PRONGHORN THROUGH THE REMOVAL AND MODIFICATION OF FENCES. ADDITIONALLY, THERE IS A NEED TO CONTINUE TO CONSERVE LESSER PRAIRIE CHICKEN HABITAT BY FENCING THE BOUNDARIES OF SEVERAL OF THESE WMAS IN ORDER TO EXCLUDE TRESPASS LIVESTOCK. THESE BOUNDARY FENCES WILL BE COMPOSED OF WILDLIFE FRIENDLY WIRES TO ALLOW THE CONTINUED MOVEMENT OF WILDLIFE. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE TO REMOVE, MODIFY, AND INSTALL WILDLIFE FRIENDLY FENCE ON WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS IN SOUTHEASTERN NEW MEXICO FOR THE CONTINUED CONSERVATION OF PRAIRIE CHICKEN HABITAT AS WELL AS TO RECONNECT GRASSLAND HABITATS.

THE TECHNICAL GUIDANCE GRANT SERVES A HABITAT FUNCTION AS WELL AS A DAMAGE MANAGEMENT FUNCTION:1. TO PROVIDE PUBLIC, PRIVATE AND CORPORATE LANDOWNERS WITH SOUND WILDLIFE HABITAT MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS THAT FIT THEIRGOALS AND ABILITIES TO THE EXTENT POSSIBLE. INCENTIVES TO LANDOWNERS WILL BE USED WHENEVER POSSIBLE TO OFFSET COSTS AND TO ENSUREFOLLOW UP CONTACT.2. TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL GUIDANCE TO AGENCIES, ORGANIZATIONS AND INDIVIDUALS FOR THE RESOLUTION OF HUMAN-WILDLIFE CONFLICTS WITHTHE GOAL OF MAINTAINING WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AT BIOLOGICALLY AND SOCIALLY ACCEPTABLE LEVELS.

OVERVIEW: THIS GRANT AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) AND THE WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (DEPARTMENT) WILL BE SUB-AWARDED OUT TO FOUR SHOOTING RANGES FOR PROJECTS THAT WILL INCREASE SAFETY AND ACCESSIBILITY AT THE RANGES.BUDGET: ~$72K FEDERAL SHARE; ~$25K STATE MATCHACTION AREA: PRIVATELY OWNED RANGES OPEN FOR PUBLIC USE.GOALS AND OBJECTIVES: INCREASE SAFETY AND ACCESSIBILITY.

THIS GRANT WILL PROVIDE COST ASSISTANCE TO ACQUIRE UP TO APPROXIMATELY 1,000 ACRES IN LAND FOR THE PURPOSE OF PROVIDING INCREASEDWILDLIFE RECREATION OPPORTUNITY FOR ALL OHIOANS. THIS WOULD INCLUDE THE ACQUISITION OF LARGE TRACTS OF LAND THAT SIGNIFICANTLY INCREASE THEAMOUNT OF LAND AVAILABLE FOR WILDLIFE RECREATION AS WELL AS THE ACQUISITION OF SMALLER TRACTS OR INHOLDINGS THAT IMPROVE PUBLIC ACCESS,PROVIDE CONTINUOUS ACREAGE OR ADDRESS MANAGEMENT ISSUES ON EXISTING WILDLIFE AREAS. TYPICALLY, ACQUISITIONS RANGE BETWEEN 50-200ACRES BUT WILL VARY DEPENDING ON AVAILABILITY AND FAIR MARKET VALUE OF THE LAND. THE STATEWIDE GRANT IS INTENDED TO ALLOW THE DIVISIONTO EFFICIENTLY ACQUIRE LANDS DURING THE GRANT PERIOD THAT ARE CONSISTENT WITH THE PURPOSES IDENTIFIED IN THE WILDLIFE RESTORATIONPROGRAM.

THE PURPOSE OF THE FEDERAL AID COORDINATION GRANT IS TO PROVIDE THE STAFF AND PROCEDURES TO ENSURE THAT THE STATE MEETS ITS RESPONSIBILITIES FOR PARTICIPATION IN THE FEDERAL AID PROGRAM, INCLUDING WORK PLANNING, RECORD KEEPING, REPORTING, SUPERVISION OF FIELD STAFF, AND COORDINATION OF FEDERAL AID ACTIVITIES WITH OTHER STATE AND AGENCY PROGRAMS.

FLORIDA'S WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS PROVIDE A VARIETY OF RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITES, SUCH AS HUNTING, FISHING, AND WILDLIFE VIEWING. THESE NATURAL AREAS ALSO PROVIDE VALUE BY MAINTAINING ENDANGERED SPECIES, PRESERVING WETLANDS, AND PROVIDING A STABLE ECOSYSTEM. THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION COORDINATION GRANT WILL PROVIDE OVERSIGHT OF THE WMA DEVELOPMENT AND MAINTENANCE PROGRAM TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND INFORMATION TO LANDOWNERS, LAND MANAGERS, FORESTERS, CONSERVATION AGENCIES AND ORGANIZATIONS, AND OTHER DECISION MAKERS SO THAT IMPORTANT WILDLIFE HABITATS ARE PROPERLY IDENTIFIED, MANAGED AND PROTECTED. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE ASSISTING PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDOWNERS WITH ENHANCING, RESTORING, OR PROTECTING IMPORTANT HABITATS ON THEIR PROPERTIES, ASSISTING WITH IDENTIFYING AND CONSERVING HIGH PRIORITY LANDS FOR WILDLIFE, PROVIDING TRAINING TO LANDOWNERS, NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS, AND LOCAL DECISION MAKERS ON WILDLIFE AND HABITAT CONSERVATION TECHNIQUES, AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE WITH RESOLVING HUMAN-WILDLIFE CONFLICTS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE MORE INFORMED DECISIONS BY PRIVATE, LOCAL, AND STATEWIDE LANDOWNERS AND MANAGERS WITH RESPECT TO WILDLIFE HABITATS, MORE WILDLIFE-FRIENDLY PRACTICES ON BOTH PRIVATE AND PUBLIC LANDS, AND MORE ACRES MANAGED OR CONSERVED FOR WILDLIFE. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE LANDOWNERS, THEIR AGENTS, AND LOCAL AND STATEWIDE DECISION MAKERS, WHO NEED AND WANT INFORMATION ABOUT WILDLIFE AND WHO WILL BE ENCOURAGED TO INCORPORATE IMPROVED HABITAT MANAGEMENT PRACTICES ON THEIR LANDS AND IN THEIR POLICIES. WILDLIFE, AND THE PUBLIC THAT ENJOYS THESE RESOURCES, WILL BENEFIT FROM MORE ACRES MANAGED OR CONSERVED FOR WILDLIFE STATEWIDE. THE UNIVERSITY OF NEW HAMPSHIRE COOPERATIVE EXTENSION IS A PLANNED SUBRECIPIENT UNDER THIS PROJECT CARRYING OUT MANY OF THESE ACTIVITIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR THE COORDINATION OF WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM GRANTS TO NEW HAMPSHIRE FISH AND GAME DEPARTMENT, AND THE ADMINISTRATION OF THESE FEDERAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS IN COMPLIANCE WITH FEDERAL REGULATIONS. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE STAFF, PROCEDURES, AND MATERIALS NECESSARY TO ENSURE THAT NEW HAMPSHIRE FISH AND GAME DEPARTMENT MEETS ITS RESPONSIBILITIES FOR PARTICIPATION IN THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAMS, INCLUDING WORK PLANNING, RECORD KEEPING, REPORTING, SUPERVISION OF FIELD STAFF, AND COORDINATION OF FEDERAL AID ACTIVITIES WITH OTHER STATE AND AGENCY PROGRAMS. EFFECTIVE ADMINISTRATION OF THESE FEDERAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS RESULTS IN AN EXPECTED OUTCOME OF PROPER AND EFFICIENT USE OF AVAILABLE PROGRAM FUNDING, AND MAXIMIZES POTENTIAL BENEFITS TO WILDLIFE RESOURCES AND USER GROUPS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE NH FISH AND GAME PROGRAMS, WHICH BENEFIT FROM OUR ABILITY TO PROPERLY MANAGE THE GRANTS. THERE ARE NO SUB-RECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

OVERVIEW: THIS GRANT AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) AND THE WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (DEPARTMENT) WILL BE SUB-AWARDED OUT TO THREE SHOOTING RANGES. THE RANGES WILL BE MAKING IMPROVEMENTS TO INCREASE HOURS OF OPERATION AND TEMPORAL SHOOTING AVAILABILITY AS WELL AS REPLACE TRAP MACHINES.BUDGET: ~$90K FEDERAL SHARE; ~$41K STATE MATCHACTION AREA: PRIVATELY OWNED RANGES OPEN FOR PUBLIC USE.GOALS AND OBJECTIVES: INCREASE TIME OPEN TO THE PUBLIC AND REPLACE TRAP MACHINES.

OVERVIEW: THIS GRANT AWARD WILL BE SUB-AWARDED TO ACCESS ABILITY WISCONSIN, INC FOR THEM TO CARRY OUT TWO PROJECTS THAT WILL INCREASE HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES FOR PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES AND RAISE AWARENESS OF THESE OPPORTUNITIES.BUDGET: ~$105K FEDERAL SHARE; ~$26K STATE MATCHACTION AREA: THIS GRANT INCLUDES ACTIVITIES INDOORS AND ON PUBLIC HUNTING LAND IN DOOR AND LINCOLN COUNTIES IN WISCONSIN.GOALS & OBJECTIVES:" PURCHASE ONE TRACKCHAIR AND SUPPORTING EQUIPMENT (TRAILER, SPARE TIRE, GUN HOLDERS, AND MISCELLANEOUSTOOLS)." PLACE AT AND TRAIN HOST SITE ON USE PROCEDURES OF ONE TRACKCHAIR." HIRE AT LEAST TWO HALF TIME LTE STAFF MEMBERS FOR HR3 WORK AND PURCHASE MATERIALS NECESSARY FOR LTE STAFF TO CARRYOUT CHAIR AWARENESS IN THE HUNTING COMMUNITY.OUTCOMES: INCREASE THE NUMBER OF HUNTERS WITHIN AN UNDERREPRESENTED COMMUNITY.
FY23 CMS GRANT FOR WILDLIFE RESTORATION

THE VEHICLES, HEAVY EQUIPMENT AND OTHER EQUIPMENT INCLUDED IN THIS GRANT ARE NECESSARY TO ACCOMPLISH THE OBJECTIVES FOR THE DIFFERENT GRANTS COMPRISING THE WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM AT THE PUERTO RICO DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES. THE TASKS IN THE OBJECTIVES INCLUDE WILDLIFE AND FISH SPECIES RESEARCH, SURVEY AND HABITAT DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS, FACILITIES AND AREAS MAINTENANCE AND OPERATIONS, OUTREACH AND COMMUNICATION, TRAINING AND EDUCATION, AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AMONG OTHERS. BECAUSE OF VARIOUS ADMINISTRATIVE HURDLES WITHIN DNER AND EXTERNAL GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, THE PURCHASING PROCESS OF SAID EQUIPMENT CAN BE LENGTHY TAKING UP TO THREE YEARS FROM THE ORDERING TO THE DELIVERY OF THE ITEMS TO THE PROJECT LEADERS. DELAYS IN PROCUREMENT CAUSE EXTENSIONS OF PROJECT GRANTS BEYOND PLANNED TIMELINES TO TAKE DELIVERY OF EQUIPMENT TIED TO THE GRANT. PR DNER NEEDS TO DECOUPLE EQUIPMENT PURCHASES FROM PROJECT GRANTS TO PROMOTE BETTER PROJECT GRANT CYCLING AND TIGHTER PERFORMANCE ACCOUNTABILITY. THIS GRANT WILL PROVIDE THE PROJECT LEADERS FOR THE VARIOUS GRANTS COMPRISING THE DNER WSFR PROGRAM THE LENGTH OF TIME AND VENUE NECESSARY FOR THE PURCHASING PROCESS OF VEHICLES, HEAVY EQUIPMENT, AND OTHER APPLICABLE EQUIPMENT TO BE COMPLETED IN ITS TOTALITY WITHOUT THE NECESSITY OF GRANT TIME EXTENSION.

WILD TURKEYS (MELEAGRIS GALLOPAVO) ARE AN IMPORTANT GAME SPECIES IN NEBRASKA. HOWEVER,MANAGERS AND HUNTERS HAVE REPORTED DECLINES IN THE NUMBER OF WILD TURKEYS ACROSS THESTATE, SIMILAR TO OTHER STATE OR REGIONAL DECLINES.PRECISE EXPLANATIONS ARE TYPICALLY LACKING, BUT MOST POPULATIONS APPEAR TO HAVE REPORTEDDECLINES IN PRODUCTIVITY (E.G., NEST SUCCESS AND BROOD SURVIVAL). TO REVERSE THISDECLINE, STATE WILDLIFE AGENCIES HAVE REDUCED WILD TURKEY BAG LIMITS AND PRIORITIZEDHABITAT MANAGEMENT EFFORTS TO INCREASE RECRUITMENT AND ADULT FEMALE SURVIVAL IN THEBREEDING SEASON. THESE EFFORTS HAVE SLOWED WILD TURKEY POPULATION DECLINES, BUTPOPULATIONS CONTINUE TO DECLINE IN CERTAIN AREAS, SUGGESTING THERE ARE OTHERSITE-SPECIFIC FACTORS AFFECTING POPULATION GROWTH RATES.THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE VALUABLE INFORMATION NEEDED TO UNDERSTAND THESE FACTORS.

THIS GRANT FUNDS COLORADO PARKS AND WILDLIFE'S RESEARCH ON GUNNISON AND GREATER SAGE-GROUSE. WORK COVERED UNDER THIS GRANT INCLUDES SPRINGTIME LEK COUNTS, HABITAT USAGE STUDIES, SUPPORT FOR LOCAL WORKING GROUPS, TECHNICAL AND EXPERT ASSISTANCE TO INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL CUSTOMERS, DATA ANALYSIS AND PREPARATION OF RESEARCH STUDY FINDINGS FOR PROFESSIONAL JOURNALS. GRANT FUNDED WORK IS CRUCIAL TO THE RECOVERY OF BOTH SAGE-GROUSE SPECIES.

THIS GRANT ANNUALLY FUNDS ALL STATEWIDE WILDLIFE DISEASE WORK IN COLORADO  THE PURPOSE IS TO DELIVER A COORDINATED AND SYSTEMATIC APPROACH FOR MONITORING, INVESTIGATING, AND REPORTING ON HEALTH PROBLEMS IN FREE RANGING WILDLIFE THROUGHOUT COLORADO

THIS APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL ASSISTANCE SECURES WILDLIFE RESTORATION (AKA PITTMAN-ROBERTSON) FUNDING OVER A FIVE-YEAR PERIOD (APRIL 1, 2022 - MARCH 31, 2027) TO SUPPORT NUMEROUS ACTIVITIES NEEDED TO HELP FULFILL THE BUREAU OF WILDLIFE'S MISSION. THE GRANT DESCRIBES A COMPREHENSIVE PROGRAM FOR THE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF THE FULL SUITE OF BIRDS AND MAMMALS THAT OCCUR IN NEW YORK STATE. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE COORDINATION, PLANNING, TECHNICAL GUIDANCE, OUTREACH, SURVEYS, RESEARCH AND ACTIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT TO MEET THE CONSERVATION NEEDS OF BOTH GAME AND "NON-GAME" (NON-HARVESTED) SPECIES. WE WILL CONDUCT AND ADMINISTER THESE ACTIVITIES AS A SINGLE GRANT (W-173-G) DIVIDED INTO TWO PROJECTS: GAME SPECIES MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF BIRD AND MAMMAL DIVERSITY. THE GAME MANAGEMENT PROJECT ADDRESSES POLICY, PLANNING, RESEARCH, SURVEY, AND MANAGEMENT FOR NEW YORK'S SUITE OF GAME SPECIES, ORGANIZED BY TAXONOMIC GROUPS: BIG GAME (WHITE-TAILED DEER, BLACK BEAR, MOOSE); FURBEARERS AND SMALL GAME MAMMALS (BEAVER, OTTER, MUSKRAT, BOBCAT, FISHER, MARTEN, COYOTE, RED AND GRAY FOX, RACCOON, SKUNK, RABBIT, HARE, SQUIRRELS); MIGRATORY GAME BIRDS (WATERFOWL, WOODCOCK, SNIPE, RAILS, DOVES, CROWS); AND UPLAND GAME BIRDS (WILD TURKEY, RUFFED GROUSE, PHEASANT, QUAIL). IT ALSO INCLUDES TECHNICAL GUIDANCE TO PREVENT OR ADDRESS CONFLICTS BETWEEN PEOPLE AND GAME BIRDS AND GAME MAMMALS AND MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT OF NON-NATIVE INVASIVE SPECIES THAT NEGATIVELY IMPACT NATIVE SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS. THE BIRD AND MAMMAL DIVERSITY PROJECT ADDRESSES POLICY, PLANNING, RESEARCH, SURVEY, AND MANAGEMENT FOR NEW YORK'S SUITE OF NON-GAME BIRDS AND MAMMALS, INCLUDING AT-RISK AND LISTED SPECIES. COMPLETION OF THESE PROJECTS WILL RESULT IN A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF BIRD AND MAMMAL POPULATIONS AND HELP GUIDE APPROPRIATE ACTIONS TO CONSERVE THESE RESOURCES. THEY WILL ALSO HELP TO PREVENT THE FUTURE LISTING OF SPECIES AS ENDANGERED OR THREATENED AND ACTIVE MANAGEMENT OF RARE OR THREATENED SPECIES AND SPECIES ASSEMBLAGES WILL AID THE RECOVERY OF POPULATIONS TO SUSTAINABLE LEVELS.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) MANAGES APPROXIMATELY 110 WILDLIFE AREAS ENCOMPASSING OVER710,000 ACRES THROUGHOUT THE STATE. SEVERAL OF THESE AREAS RELY ON THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION PROGRAM TO SUPPORTMANAGEMENT OF WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS, AND TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR PUBLIC USE AND ENJOYMENT OF WILDLIFERESOURCES.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) INLAND DESERTS REGION (IDR), COLORADO RIVER PROGRAM ISRESPONSIBLE FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF THE LOWER COLORADO RIVER (LCR), WHICH FORMS THE BORDER BETWEEN CALIFORNIA ANDARIZONA BEGINNING BELOW NEVADA AT LAKE MEAD AND CONTINUES FOR 276 MILES TO THE INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY WITH MEXICO(USBR, LCRMSCP.GOV). THE INLAND DESERTS REGION LANDS SOUTH (IDRLS) PROGRAM IS COMPRISED OF OVER 155,000 ACRES OFECOLOGICAL RESERVES (ER) AND WILDLIFE AREAS (WA) IN SAN BERNARDINO, RIVERSIDE, AND IMPERIAL COUNTIES. THISPROJECT WILL CONSERVE WILDLIFE BY MANAGING ACCESS, REVIEWING PROJECTS, MAINTAINING WILDLIFE HABITAT AND MANAGINGACCESS ON NINETEEN WILDLIFE AREAS AND ECOLOGICAL RESERVES. THE AREAS INCLUDE DIVERSE HABITATS FROM DESERT SCRUBTO COASTAL SAGE SCRUB TO MONTANE PEBBLE PLAIN HABITAT, WHICH SUPPORT A WIDE ARRAY OF FISH, WILDLIFE, AND PLANTSPECIES.THE WILDLIFE HABITAT AND MAINTENANCE, PALO VERDE ECOLOGICAL RESERVE, AND IDRLS PROJECTS WILL CONTINUE TO CONSERVEAND ENHANCE VARIOUS HABITATS ASSOCIATED WITH THE PALO VERDE ECOLOGICAL RESERVE (PVER) AND OTHER STATE-OWNEDLANDS, THAT SUPPORT A VARIETY OF WILDLIFE AND PLANT SPECIES. MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES ARE NECESSARY TO IMPLEMENTWILDLIFE RESTORATION PROJECTS FOR THE CONSERVATION, MANAGEMENT, AND ENHANCEMENT OF WILDLIFE SPECIES AND THEIRHABITATS. THESE LANDS ALSO PROVIDE PUBLIC USE ACCESS FOR HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES, WILDLIFE VIEWING, AND NATURESTUDY.

THIS GRANT IS PRIMARILY A SUB-AWARD TO OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY. ODWC WILL PROVIDE MINIMAL FIELD ASSISTANCE AS NEEDED. WE PROPOSE TO USE AN IPM APPROACH TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE DRIVERS OF BOBWHITE POPULATIONS, ESPECIALLY EXTREME WEATHER AND POTENTIAL HARVEST SCENARIOS, AND USE THIS INFORMATION TO DEVELOP POPULATION MODELING TOOLS TO BETTER INFORM ODWC MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES AND HARVEST REGULATIONS FOR BOBWHITE. ADDITIONALLY, ODWC IS INTERESTED IN UNDERSTANDING THE IMPACT OF HARVEST ON BOBWHITE POPULATIONS WITH A PARTICULAR FOCUS ON IMPACTS OF LATE SEASON HARVEST. WE PROPOSE TO COLLECT MORE DETAILED INFORMATION ON HUNTER EFFORT (E.G., TIMING AND INTENSITY OF HUNTER EFFORT, TEMPORAL AND SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION OF HUNTER EFFORT) BY COLLECTING HUNTER ACTIVITY DATA AND HARVEST THROUGH BAND RETURN DATA. OBJECTIVES 1-3 WILL RELY ON PREVIOUSLY COLLECTED DATA FROM PACKSADDLE AND BEAVER WMAS AND DATA COLLECTED FROM OTHER SOURCES SO THE GEOGRAPHIC LOCATION WILL BE OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY CAMPUS. DATA COLLECTION FOR OBJECTIVE 4 WILL INCLUDE PACKSADDLE WMA IN ELLIS COUNTY, BEAVER WMA IN BEAVER COUNTY, AND POTENTIALLY OTHER WESTERN WMAS.

THIS GRANT IS PRIMARILY A SUB-AWARD TO OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY. ODWC WILL PROVIDE MINIMAL FIELD ASSISTANCE AS NEEDED. THIS STUDY WILL BE CONDUCTED PRIMARILY WITHIN THE OZARK ECOREGION OF OKLAHOMA. THIS INCLUDES DELAWARE, OTTAWA, CHEROKEE, CRAIG, MAYES, AND ADAIR COUNTIES. THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE RESOURCES TO THE ODWC TO ASSIST IN GLADE MANAGEMENT ON BOTH PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS IN THE OZARK ECOREGION OF OKLAHOMA. THIS WORK WILL ASSESS BIODIVERSITY RESOURCES (PLANTS, INVERTEBRATES, HERPTILES, BIRDS, AND MAMMALS) AS A FUNCTION OF GLADE SIZE, DEGREE OF CEDAR ENCROACHMENT, AND CURRENT MANAGEMENT TO HELP GUIDE FUTURE MANAGEMENT OF THIS IMPORTANT RESOURCE. WE WILL ALSO PROVIDE THE ODWC WITH A MAPPING PRODUCT OF GLADE RESOURCES IN THE REGION TO HELP WITH TARGETED STAKEHOLDER OUTREACH.

THIS GRANT IS PRIMARILY A SUB-AWARD TO OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY. ODWC WILL PROVIDE MINIMAL FIELD ASSISTANCE AS NEEDED. NONINVASIVE FIELD SURVEYS AND HABITAT SAMPLING WILL BE CONDUCTED IN CHEROKEE, ADAIR, SEQUOYAH, LE FLORE, AND MCCURTAIN COUNTIES IN EASTERN OKLAHOMA. THE ACTION FOR THIS GRANT IS TO ASSESS FACTORS INFLUENCING CAMERA-BASED MONITORING OF PLAINS SPOTTED SKUNKS AND ELUCIDATE DISTRIBUTIONAL PATTERNS AND HABITAT ASSOCIATIONS OF PLAINS SPOTTED SKUNKS IN OKLAHOMA TO PROVIDE ODWC WITH CRITICAL DATA TO INFORM THE FEDERAL STATUS REVIEW AND IMPROVE CONSERVATION.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO MAINTAIN HEALTHY WILDLIFE POPULATIONS BY PROVIDING TECHNICAL GUIDANCE TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS REGARDING BEST WILDLIFE AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT PRACTICES.OBJECTIVE 1: PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO APPROXIMATELY 800 PRIVATE LAND OWNERS BY JUNE 30, 2023.OBJECTIVE 2: DEVELOP 200 MANAGEMENT PLANS IN COLLABORATION WITH PRIVATE LAND OWNERS AND OTHER CONSERVATION PARTNERS BY JUNE 30, 2023.OBJECTIVE 3:DIRECTLY ASSIST LANDOWNERS IN MANAGING OR ENHANCING 3,100 ACRES OF WILDLIFE HABITAT BY JUNE 30, 2023.RESULTS OR BENEFITS EXPECTED: WILDLIFE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ON PRIVATE LAND IS ESSENTIAL TO THE LONG-TERM WELFARE OF WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS. BY PROVIDING TECHNICAL GUIDANCE, PRIVATE LANDOWNERS CAN IMPLEMENT MANAGEMENT PRACTICES THAT ACHIEVE THEIR LAND USE GOALS IN WAYS THAT BENEFIT WILDLIFE TO INCLUDE BENEFITING SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION CONCERN FROM THE ARKANSAS WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (AWAP) ALONG WITH FEDERAL TRUST SPECIES.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: PRIVATE LAND OWNERS IN ARKANSASSUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: A PORTION OF THE FUNDS OBLIGATED TO THIS PROJECT WILL BE SUB-AWARDED TO QUAIL FOREVER

THIS GRANT HAS TWO PURPOSES.1. TO PROVIDE PUBLIC ACCESS TO LAND FOR HUNTING AND OTHER OUTDOOR RECREATION BY MAINTAINING AND OPERATING INFRASTRUCTURE ON WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS. 2. TO PROVIDE CONSERVATION OF WILDLIFE SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS FOR MAINTAINING VIABLE POPULATIONS AND PUBLIC ENJOYMENT AND USE.OBJECTIVE 1:DIRECTLY MAINTAIN AND OPERATE INFRASTRUCTURE ON 129 WMAS, AT WHICH MOST MAINTENANCE AND OPERATION ACTIVITIES WILL OCCUR ON 61 STATE-OWNED WMAS, TO ALLOW PUBLIC HUNTING AND OTHER OUTDOOR RECREATION BY JUNE 30, 2023.OBJECTIVE 2:DIRECTLY MANAGE AND ENHANCE HABITAT ON 129 WMAS, OF WHICH HABITAT WORK WILL BE CONDUCTED ON 61 COMMISSION-OWNED WMAS, TO ALLOW PUBLIC HUNTING AND OTHER RECREATION BY JUNE 30, 2023.RESULTS AND BENEFITS EXPECTED: THE WMA SYSTEM PROVIDES PUBLIC HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES AND A RELATIVELY CONSISTENT HUNTER SUCCESS RATE BY CONTROLLING THE ANNUAL HARVEST OF GAME SPECIES THROUGH ADAPTIVE REGULATIONS ON BAG LIMITS, SEASON DATES AND HARVEST METHODS. THE UTILIZATION OF THESE AREAS BY THE PUBLIC FOR OTHER WILDLIFE-ORIENTED RECREATION WILL BE MAINTAINED AT LEVELS CONSISTENT WITH THE DEMAND FOR SUCH USES AND WHICH ARE COMPATIBLE WITH THE PRIMARY USES OF HUNTING AND FISHING. BY CONTINUING THE HABITAT PROGRAM, THE WMA SYSTEM WILL PROVIDE ENHANCED HABITAT FOR NATIVE AND MIGRATORY SPECIES AND IMPROVED OUTDOOR RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. THE HABITAT PROGRAM WILL HELP MAINTAIN A RELATIVELY CONSISTENT HUNTER SUCCESS RATE BY SUPPORTING WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AT SUSTAINABLE LEVELS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: GENERAL PUBLIC

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO DEVELOP, ADMINISTER AND FACILITATE PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT IN PROGRAMS THAT PROMOTE THE SAFE RESPONSIBLE USE OF SPORTING ARMS AND OTHER HUNTING EQUIPMENT, THE RESPONSIBLE AND ETHICAL USE OF OUR WILDLIFE RESOURCES, AND THE BENEFITS OF MODERN WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT. AN AVERAGE ANNUAL THROUGHPUT OF 12,000 STUDENTS WILL RECEIVE SKILLS-BASED TRAINING DESIGNED TO MAKE THEM SAFE AND RESPONSIBLE HUNTERS IN ADDITION TO IMPROVING THEIR PARTICIPATION IN THE SHOOTING SPORTS. BENEFITS INCLUDE MAINTAINING THE NUMBER OF HUNTING RELATED INCIDENTS AND AN INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF THOSE PARTICIPATING IN HUNTING AND THE SHOOTING SPORTS. THERE WILL ALSO BE ADDED ECONOMIC BENEFITS AND POSITIVE ACROSS-THE-BOARD IMPACTS TO LOCAL, REGIONAL AND STATE, ECONOMIES. THE END RESULT WILL BE AN ENHANCED AWARENESS OF HUNTING AND SHOOTING SPORTS, GREATER ENTHUSIASM TO PARTICIPATE SAFELY IN HUNTING ACTIVITIES, RESULTING IN IMPROVED SALES OF EQUIPMENT/SUPPLIES AND THE USE OF AMENITIES ASSOCIATED WITH OUTDOOR HUNTING RELATED ACTIVITIES.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) WILL CONTINUE A BIG GAME AND CARNIVORE GENETICS ASSESSMENTPROJECT TO HELP MONITOR BIG GAME AND CARNIVORE POPULATIONS, ANALYZE SPECIES TAXONOMIC STATUS, IDENTIFY MANAGEMENTAND CONSERVATION UNITS BASED ON NEUTRAL AND ADAPTIVE GENETIC VARIATION, AND DEVELOP AN ARCHIVE OF REFERENCEGENETIC SAMPLES TO FACILITATE FUTURE RESEARCH. THIS PROJECT WILL GREATLY ASSIST CDFW'S WILDLIFE CONSERVATION ANDWILDLIFE MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES AND PRIORITIES.THIS NARRATIVE OUTLINES THE ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED DURING THE 2021/2022 YEAR (I.E., YEAR 6) OF A LARGERMULTI-YEAR PROJECT, PHASED IN EACH SUCCESSIVE YEAR WITH ANNUAL 12-MONTH OBJECTIVES/DELIVERABLES. IT WILL SUPPORTTHE CDFW WILDLIFE BRANCH'S NEEDS FOR LARGE MAMMAL AND CARNIVORE FOCUSED GENETIC RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT, WITH THEFULL IMPLEMENTATION OVER YEARS TO INCLUDE A GREATER DIVERSITY OF SPECIES, AS THE NEED AND FUNDING ARE AVAILABLE.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) IS COMPRISED OF SIX INLAND REGIONS AND ONE MARINE REGION.THE BAY DELTA REGION'S (BDR), WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (BDRWP) IS RESPONSIBLE FOR MANAGEMENT OF OVER 150,000ACRES OF LANDS WHICH HAVE BEEN ACQUIRED FOR THE PURPOSES OF CONSERVATION, RECOVERY, AND PUBLIC RECREATIONOPPORTUNITIES WHERE COMPATIBLE. THE LANDS INCLUDE DIVERSE HABITATS THAT RANGE FROM GRASSLANDS, FRESH WATERWETLANDS, BRACKISH AND SALINE WETLANDS, RIPARIAN HABITATS, OAK SAVANNAH, OAK WOODLAND, TO SERPENTINE GRASSLANDSAND CHAMISE CHAPARRAL. THESE LANDS SUPPORT A DIVERSE RANGE OF SPECIES WHICH INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO:BOBCAT, COYOTE, DEER, ELK, PIG, UPLAND GAME BIRDS, RABBITS, AND WATERFOWL AS WELL AS LISTED AND CANDIDATESPECIES. THESE LANDS DO NOT HAVE ANY ON SITE STAFF TO CARRY OUT MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES. AS A RESULT, THE BDRWP ISRESPONSIBLE FOR CARRYING OUT ALL THE NECESSARY MANAGEMENT ACTIONS TO MEET THE CONSERVATION OBJECTIVES. ACTIONSINCLUDE COORDINATION, COLLECTION, AND ANALYSIS OF DATA REGARDING THE CONDITION OF WILDLIFE POPULATIONS ANDHABITATS; MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF GAME AND NONGAME BIRDS AND MAMMALS; PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TOOTHER AGENCIES REGARDING RESOURCE ISSUES; ADMINISTERING SPECIAL PUBLIC HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES; AND PUBLICOUTREACH.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE'S (CDFW) NORTH CENTRAL REGION (NCR) HAS THREE STAFFED WILDLIFEAREAS THAT ARE GEOGRAPHICALLY CENTRALIZED: GRAY LODGE WILDLIFE AREA (GLWA), SPENCEVILLE WILDLIFE AREA (SWA), ANDUPPER BUTTE BASIN WILDLIFE AREA (UBBWA) COMPRISING OVER 42,133 ACRES OF MANAGED WILDLIFE HABITAT. OPERATIONAL ANDADMINISTRATIVE OVERSIGHT OF THESE AREAS IS PROVIDED BY STAFF STATIONED AT GLWA AND UBBWA.THESE LANDS WERE ORIGINALLY PURCHASED BY THE WILDLIFE CONSERVATION BOARD (WCB)BETWEEN 1931 AND 1988. WHILE THEPURPOSE OF THE ACQUISITIONS HAS VARIED THROUGH THE YEARS, THE GOALS HAVE REMAINED THE SAME: CONSERVATION,RESTORATION, AND ENHANCEMENT OF HABITATS FOR WILDLIFE, WHILE PROVIDING FOR COMPATIBLE PUBLIC RECREATION SUCH ASHUNTING, FISHING, WILDLIFE VIEWING, NATURE STUDY, ETC. SUBSEQUENT ADDITIONS TO THE AREAS HAVE FOCUSED ONIMPLEMENTATION OF THE CENTRAL VALLEY HABITAT JOINT VENTURE AND PROTECTION OF SENSITIVE SPECIES AND THE HABITATSTHEY DEPEND ON. WCB, ON BEHALF OF THE STATE, HAS ASSIGNED OVERALL MANAGEMENT OF THESE LANDS TO CDFW.GLWA WAS ORIGINALLY PURCHASED IN 1931 TO PREVENT DEPREDATION ON AGRICULTURAL CROPS AND PROVIDE WINTERING HABITATFOR MIGRATORY BIRDS. THESE LANDS ARE LOCATED IN BOTH BUTTE AND SUTTER COUNTIES. SINCE THE ORIGINAL ACQUISITIONS,GLWA HAS EXPANDED WITH ADDITIONAL LAND PURCHASES TO ITS PRESENT 9,200 ACRES, AND HAS INCREASED PUBLIC USEACTIVITIES SUCH AS HUNTING, WILDLIFE VIEWING, AND NATURE STUDY. WILDLIFE RESTORATION ACT (WR) FUNDS HAVE BEENUSED TO PURCHASE PORTIONS OF GLWA, AND FOR ITS OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE SINCE THE INCEPTION OF THE WR PROGRAM IN1937.UBBWA CONSISTS OF THREE INDIVIDUAL UNITS (LITTLE DRY CREEK, HOWARD SLOUGH, AND LLANO SECO) WHICH WERE ACQUIREDBETWEEN 1988 AND 2016. THESE LANDS ARE LOCATED IN BOTH BUTTE AND GLENN COUNTIES AND WERE IN AGRICULTURALPRODUCTION PRIOR TO PURCHASE BY THE WCB. THESE LANDS WERE ASSIGNED TO CDFW TO RESTORE, ENHANCE, DEVELOP, ANDMAINTAIN AS WILDLIFE HABITATS, WHILE PROVIDING FOR COMPATIBLE PUBLIC USES. SINCE THE ORIGINAL ACQUISITIONS, THEWILDLIFE AREA HAS EXPANDED WITH ADDITIONAL AGRICULTURAL LAND PURCHASES TO ITS PRESENT 9,408 ACRES AND HASINCREASED PUBLIC USE ACTIVITIES SUCH AS HUNTING, WILDLIFE VIEWING, AND NATURE STUDY.THE FIRST LAND ACQUISITION THAT FORMED WHAT IS NOW THE SWA OCCURRED IN 1963. SINCE THAT TIME THERE HAVE BEENSEVERAL PARCELS ADDED TO THE ORIGINAL PROPERTY, WHICH NOW TOTALS 11,887 ACRES. SWA IS LOCATED IN BOTH NEVADA ANDYUBA COUNTIES IN THE WESTERN FOOTHILLS OF THE SIERRA NEVADA MOUNTAIN RANGE. THESE PROPERTIES WERE ACQUIRED TOPRESERVE BLUE OAK WOODLAND AND GRASSLAND HABITATS AND PROVIDE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE PUBLIC.CDFW HAS RESTORED, ENHANCED, DEVELOPED, AND MAINTAINED WETLAND, RIPARIAN, AND UPLAND HABITATS FOR MIGRATORYWATERFOWL, SHOREBIRDS, UPLAND GAME BIRDS, DEER, AND OTHER WILDLIFE SPECIES ASSOCIATED WITH THESE HABITATS. THESELANDS WERE ASSIGNED TO CDFW TO RESTORE, ENHANCE, DEVELOP, MAINTAIN WILDLIFE HABITATS AND WHILE PROVIDING FORCOMPATIBLE PUBLIC USES.
MO HUNTER EDUCATION AND SHOOTING RANGE PROGRAMS (W95E22)

ANNUALLY SEVERAL HUNDRED THOUSAND ANGLERS, HUNTERS AND RECREATIONAL SHOOTERS FISH, HUNT, BOAT AND SHOOT IN ARIZONA. IT IS ESSENTIAL TO CONSERVE, MANAGE, AND ENHANCE THE QUALITY AND AVAILABILITY OF SPORT FISH AND WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITS IN ORDER TO PROVIDE QUALITY SPORT FISHING AND HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES AND TO DISSEMINATE INFORMATION ABOUT ARIZONA'S SPORT FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES AND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. THE ARIZONA COMPREHENSIVE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM GRANT ACTIVITIES ARE CONDUCTED STATEWIDE AND TIER TO AZGFD'S STRATEGIC AND OPERATIONAL PLANS AND ARE EVALUATED ANNUALLY TO ENSURE THE GRANT IS PERFORMING AS ANTICIPATED. THE GRANT FUNDS THE OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF FOUR SPORT FISH HATCHERIES AND THE STOCKING OF 380,000 POUNDS OR SPORT FISH (PRIMARILY TROUT, LARGEMOUTH BASS AND CATFISH) IN MORE THAN 118 OF ARIZONA'S STREAMS AND LAKES AND AN ADDITIONAL 56 LAKES THAT ARE MANAGED TO PROVIDE DIVERSE WARM AND COLD WATER FISHING OPPORTUNITIES. SPORT FISH HABITAT RESTORATION, FISHERIES DISEASE SURVEILLANCE AND WATER QUALITY MONITORING ACTIVITIES SUPPORT MANAGEMENT EFFORTS TO PROVIDE DIVERSE WARM AND COLD WATER SPORT FISHING RECREATION DEMANDS ESTIMATED AT 5.9 MILLION ANGLER DAYS ANNUALLY. IN ADDITION, BOATER ACCESS IS EVALUATED AND OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE CONDUCTED TO ENSURE REASONABLE AND QUALITY ACCESS IS AVAILABLE TO BOATING RECREATIONISTS. CONSERVATION EFFORTS ARE CONDUCTED ON WILDLIFE HABITAT AND WATER TO ENHANCE THE CAPACITY OF HABITAT TO SUPPORT WILDLIFE AND ENHANCE RESILIENCE TO STRESSORS. STRATEGIES EMPLOYED INCLUDE: EXTENSIVE WILDLIFE DISEASE SURVEILLANCE. GAME AND NONGAME SPECIES POPULATION ENHANCEMENTS. PARTNERING WITH PRIVATE AND PUBLIC LANDOWNERS TO CONSERVE, PROTECT AND MONITOR LANDS MAINTAINING AND ENHANCING RELATIONSHIPS WITH LAND MANAGERS AND CONSERVATION PARTNERS TO IMPROVE WILDLIFE HABITAT AT A VARIETY OF SCALES THROUGHOUT ARIZONA (SUBRECIPIENTS INCLUDE TURKEY FEDERATION, TROUT UNLIMITED, MULE DEER FOUNDATION, SOUTHERN WINGS AND NATIONAL AUDUBON SOCIETY). SUSTAINING WILDLIFE HABITATS ON PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS BY RESTORING HABITATS USING VARIOUS MANAGEMENT TOOLS (E.G. GRASSLAND RESTORATION, FOREST THINNING/BURNING, FENCING/FENCE MODIFICATIONS, RIPARIAN RESTORATION, WATER DEVELOPMENTS) AND COLLABORATIVE CONSERVATION APPROACHES (E.G. CONSERVATION EASEMENTS, HABITAT ACQUISITION, LAND USE AGREEMENTS, WATER RIGHT USE/PURCHASES/TRANSFERS) TO PROTECT HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE AND WILDLIFE RELATED RECREATION. COLLECTING, MANAGING AND PROVIDING WILDLIFE INFORMATION, DATA AND SCIENCE NEEDED TO INFORM AND DEVELOP THE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT CAPABILITIES. CONDUCTING WILDLIFE AREA OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE AND STREAM AND GRASSLAND HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS AND WATER DEVELOPMENTS TO IMPROVE HABITAT FOR THE BENEFIT OF WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH POPULATIONS. OUTREACH IS NEEDED TO INFORM THE PUBLIC ABOUT THE ACTIVITIES THAT SUPPORT AND ARE SUPPORTED BY WSFR AND TO EDUCATE PEOPLE ABOUT THE BENEFITS OF GRANT FUNDED PROGRAMS IN ORDER TO BUILD PUBLIC BACKING AND CONTINUED PARTICIPATION. GRANT FUNDED OUTREACH AND COMMUNICATION EFFORTS INCLUDE SOCIAL MEDIA STRATEGIES AS PART OF AZGFD'S CONSERVE AND PROTECT CAMPAIGN. THE GRANT FUNDED SHOOTING SPORTS PROGRAM MAINTAINS, DEVELOPS, OR SUPPORTS PUBLIC SHOOTING RANGES WITHIN REASONABLE PROXIMITY OF URBAN CENTERS TO MEET THE INCREASING DEMAND FOR RECREATIONAL SHOOTING OPPORTUNITIES. THE PROGRAM PROVIDES INTRODUCTORY THROUGH ADVANCED SHOOTING OPPORTUNITIES AT COMMISSIONED-OWNED RANGES, INCLUDING THE WORLD CLASS BEN AVERY SHOOTING FACILITY, WITH THE INTENT OF INCREASING THE PERCENTAGE OF ARIZONANS PARTICIPATING IN RECREATIONAL SHOOTING. THE PROGRAM ALSO PROVIDES TECHNICAL, DEVELOPMENT AND CONSTRUCTION ASSISTANCE TO SHOOTING RANGE OPERATORS AT FACILITIES STATEWIDE AND ALSO WORKS WITH PARTNERS TO PROVIDE RESPONSIBLE DISPERSED RECREATIONAL SHOOTING ON PUBLIC LANDS.
STATEWIDE WILDLIFE DISEASE MANAGEMENT (W108M7)

TROPICAL DRY AND MIXED MESIC FORESTS IN HAWAII FACE MANY THREATS SUCH AS THE PRESENCE OFINVASIVE WEEDS AND WILDFIRE HAZARDS. THE ESTABLISHMENT OF INVASIVE FOUNTAIN GRASS AND OTHER FIRETOLERANT NON-NATIVE GRASSES HAS LED TO THE CREATION OF A GRASS-FIRE CYCLE IN THESE AREAS. THEDIVISION OF FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE (DOFAW) MANAGES LANDS IN THE PUU WAAWAA FORESTRESERVE AND THE PUU ANAHULU GAME MANAGEMENT AREA, IN NORTH KONA, ON THE ISLAND OFHAWAII (PROJECT AREA: REFERRED TO AS "NAPUU", MEANING "THE HILLS"). GAME MAMMAL HUNTING HASBEEN AN IMPORTANT ACTIVITY IN THE PROJECT AREA FOR MORE THAN A CENTURY. ACCESS TO HUNTING AREASWITHIN THE PROJECT AREA IS VIA FOUR-WHEEL DRIVE ROADS WHICH ACT AS FUEL BREAKS IN THIS HIGHLY FIREPRONE ENVIRONMENT. THE FOUR-WHEEL DRIVE ROADS NEED TO BE ACTIVELY MAINTAINED TO PREVENTOVERGROWTH BY INVASIVE WEEDS, PRIMARILY FOUNTAIN GRASS AND TREE TOBACCO. HUNTERS ARE THE LARGESTPUBLIC GROUP ACCESSING THE FORESTS IN THESE AREAS, AND THREATS TO THE NATIVE ECOSYSTEMS FROM THEINTRODUCTION OF INVASIVE SPECIES OR WILDFIRE RESULTING FROM VEHICLES AND PEOPLE IS GREAT. WEEDCONTROL ALONG THESE ROADS THEREFORE ALLOWS THEM TO MAINTAIN THEIR FUNCTION AS FIRE BREAKS, THUSREDUCING RISKS OF HABITAT DAMAGE CAUSED BY FIRES.IN ADDITION TO BEING A VALUABLE HUNTING AREA, THE AREA IS ALSO HOME TO 15 ENDANGERED PLANTSPECIES, 7 THREATENED AND ENDANGERED BIRD SPECIES, AND ONE ENDANGERED MOTH SPECIES. THE DIVISIONOF FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE HAS BEEN DEVELOPING CONSERVATION MEASURES THAT WILL PROTECT THESEENDANGERED SPECIES WHILE ALSO ALLOWING HUNTER ACCESS AND OPPORTUNITIES. FENCED EXCLOSURES AS WELLAS PROPAGATION AND OUTPLANTING OF NATIVE PLANT SPECIES WILL HELP AVOID AND MINIMIZE IMPACTS FROMGAME MAMMALS AS WELL IMPROVE GAME BIRD HABITAT. A HEALTHY FOREST IS IMPORTANT FOR MAINTAININGNATIVE BIODIVERSITY AS WELL AS FOR MAINTAINING ECOSYSTEM SERVICES SUCH AS WATER RECHARGE IN THEAQUIFER, FOREST PRODUCTS, GAME MAMMALS FOR HUNTING, AND AMPLE NATIVE SPECIES FOR CULTURALGATHERING. NATIVE PLANT COMMUNITY RESTORATION WILL ENHANCE HABITAT FOR BOTH NATIVE, NON-GAME ANDGAME BIRD SPECIES, ALLOWING FOR INCREASED OPPORTUNITY FOR RECREATIONAL BIRDING AND GAME BIRDHUNTING OPPORTUNITIES, AS WELL AS INCREASED OVERALL FOREST HEALTH, AND CONSERVATION OF NATIVEBIODIVERSITY.

WILDLIFE POPULATIONS SERVE AS RESERVOIRS FOR DISEASE WHICH POSE A THREAT TO OTHER WILDLIFE POPULATIONS, ECOSYSTEM HEALTH, AND HUMAN SAFETY. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ESTABLISH A MECHANISM FOR WILDLIFE DISEASE SURVEILLANCE, DIAGNOSIS, AND RESPONSE THROUGHOUT SOUTH CAROLINA. PROMPT PROFESSIONAL DIAGNOSIS OF CAUSES OF MORBIDITY AND MORTALITY IN WILDLIFE WILL ALLOW SCDNR TO PROVIDE APPROPRIATE AND RAPID RESPONSE TO WILDLIFE DISEASE EVENTS, MINIMIZING EXPOSURE TO OTHER ANIMALS AND POPULATIONS, REDUCING HUMAN HEALTH RISKS, AND MINIMIZING SPREAD OF DISEASE.

THIS GRANT AND SUBSEQUENT AMENDMENTS OBLIGATE WYOMING'S WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION APPORTIONMENTS FOR IMPLEMENTATION AND OPERATION OF IT'S COMPREHENSIVE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM AS DEFINED IN 50 CFR 80.2 AND 50 CFR 80.81. THIS PERFORMANCE PERIOD FOR THIS AWARD IS STATE FISCAL YEAR 2023 - JULY 1, 2022 - JUNE 30, 2023.

MANY NOXIOUS WEED SPECIES, SUCH AS SPOTTED KNAPWEED, LEAFY SPURGE, AND CANADA THISTLE OUTCOMPETE NATIVE VEGETATION AND HAVE LITTLE TO NO FORAGE VALUE RESULTING IN DEGRADATION OF CRITICAL WILDLIFE HABITAT. THIS PROJECT WILL TREAT APPROXIMATELY 34,708 ACRES OF NOXIOUS WEEDS TO PROMOTE THE RESTORATION OF NATIVE VEGETATION TYPES TO POSITIVELY IMPACT AN ESTIMATED 434,000 ACRES OF PRIORITY WILDLIFE HABITAT.

THE GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES WILL PURCHASE THE 267 ACRE INDIGO TRACT AND THE 369 ACRE HAMMERSMITH TRACT, WHICH WILL BECOME PART OF THE 3,986-ACRE ALTAMA WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA (WMA). ACQUIRING THE INDIGO AND HAMMERSMITH TRACTS WOULD IMPROVE OUR ABILITY TO MANAGE THE EXISTING WMA, SOLVE CRITICAL ACCESS ISSUES TO THE PROPERTY AND CONSERVE WILDLIFE HABITAT AND INCREASE PUBLIC HUNTING OPPORTUNITY ADDING THESE PROPERTIES TO THE WMA.

THE GOAL FOR THE GAME PROGRAM IS TO MAINTAIN A RECREATIONAL PUBLIC HUNTING PROGRAM THAT DOES NOT THREATEN THE PERSISTENCE OF NATIVE SPECIES AND ECOSYSTEMS IN HAWAII IS A COMPLEX ENDEAVOR. PUBLIC HUNTING CAN PROVIDE A USEFUL TOOL IN CONTROLLING GAME MAMMALS ON PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS WHERE CONTROL IS NEEDED AND FUNDS ARE SCARCE. THE HAWAII DIVISION OF FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE (DOFAW) PUBLIC HUNTING PROGRAM SUPPORTS AND FACILITATES HUNTING ON PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS BY PROVIDING A STRUCTURED PROGRAM THAT PROMOTES AND ENCOURAGES PARTICIPATION. THE PROGRAM AIMS TO DIRECT HUNTING TOWARD LESS ECOLOGICALLY SENSITIVE AREAS, WHILE AT THE SAME PROVIDING STRUCTURED HUNTER ACCESS TO MORE REMOTE/PRISTINE SITES WHERE RECREATIONAL HUNTING CAN HELP TO CONTROL GAME MAMMAL POPULATIONS.GAME MANAGEMENT PROGRAM WILL FUND PROJECTS FOR MONITORING HUNTER ACTIVITIES AND GAME SPECIES POPULATION STATUS, LAND LEASES TO PROVIDE ADDITIONAL AREAS FOR PUBLIC HUNTING, GAME HABITAT IMPROVEMENT, GAME POPULATION MANAGEMENT IN SUITABLE HABITATS THROUGH CONTROL OF ALIEN PREDATORS, FACILITY AND INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT, AND PROJECTS THAT WILL AID IN DATA GATHERING AND ANALYSIS. THESE AND OTHER ACTIVITIES ARE ALL AIMED AT MAXIMIZING HUNTER RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES AND STAFF EFFICIENCY, WITHIN BUDGETARY CONSTRAINTS, IN CONJUNCTION WITH OTHER DOFAW MANDATES, AND IN COMPLIANCE WITH RELEVANT STATE AND FEDERAL LAWS AND REGULATIONS. PROJECT STATEMENTS AND A "SCHEDULE OF FUNDED PROJECTS" WHICH PROVIDE SPECIFICS ON PLANNED MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES AND EXPENDITURES ARE PROVIDED IN THE FOLLOWING SECTIONS.

DIVISON OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION REGION 3 WILDLIFE SURVEY & INVENTORY, RESEARCH, AND COORDINATION: INTERIOR ANDEASTERN ARCTIC ALASKA'S VERTEBRATE TERRESTRIAL WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND FACTORS INFLUENCING THEIR STATUS:THE INTERIOR AND EASTERN ARCTIC REGION OF ALASKA (REGION 3) WILDLIFE SURVEY AND INVENTORY, RESEARCH ANDCOORDINATION GRANT SUPPORTS WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AND WILDLIFE-RELATED RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES THROUGH STAFFAND PROJECT FUNDING. IT FUNDS THE STAFF AND DATA COLLECTION TO ENSURE THE CONSERVATION, PROTECTION, ANDMANAGEMENT OF WILDLIFE TO PROVIDE SUSTAINABLE POPULATIONS FOR HUNTING, TRAPPING, AND OTHER WILDLIFE-BASED USEROPPORTUNITIES. SURVEYS ASSESS WILDLIFE POPULATIONS, APPLIED RESEARCH INFORMS WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS, ANDCOORDINATION OF STAFF AND RESOURCES SUPPORTS MANAGEMENT AND RESEARCH PLANNING, AND PROVIDING INFORMATION ANDREQUIRED REGULATORY SERVICES TO THE PUBLIC.SEE ATTACHED.

THE WILDLIFE BUREAU IS RESPONSIBLE FOR WILDLIFE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ON PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS, AND THE MANAGEMENT, MAINTENANCE, AND OPERATION OF ALL PUBLIC FISH AND WILDLIFE AREAS. THESE AREAS, TERMED WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS INCLUDE WILDLIFE AREAS, FISHING ACCESS AREAS, SOME STATE PRESERVES, AND LARGE LAKE SITES THAT HAVE BEEN ACQUIRED SPECIFICALLY FOR THE PURPOSE OF PROVIDING HABITAT AND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES IN THE FORM OF HUNTING, FISHING, TRAPPING, AND WILDLIFE RELATED NON-CONSUMPTIVE ACTIVITIES.THROUGH THIS GRANT PROPOSAL, 415,423 ACRES OF PUBLIC LAND WILL BE DEVELOPED AND MANAGED AS FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT. THESE AREAS ARE ALL MANAGED BY THE WILDLIFE BUREAU AND AVAILABLE YEAR AROUND TO THE PUBLIC FOR RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. THESE AREAS INCLUDE FEE TITLE LANDS, LEASED LANDS MANAGED BY THE DNR THROUGH LONG TERM AGREEMENTS, AND DNR LANDS MANAGED BY OTHER AGENCIES THROUGH LONG TERM AGREEMENTS. EXAMPLES OF LEASED LANDS MANAGED BY DNR INCLUDE ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEER RESERVOIRS AND FISH & WILDLIFE SERVICE WATERFOWL PRODUCTION AREAS.IN ADDITION TO FUNDING UNIT PERSONNEL, THIS GRANT WILL ALSO COST-SHARE THE SALARIES OF TWO PERMANENT AND FOUR PART-TIME WILDLIFE DEPREDATION TECHNICIANS, FOUR PRIVATE LANDS BIOLOGISTS AND FOUR PRIVATE LANDS TECHNICIANS. ALL OF THESE PERSONNEL ARE DIRECTLY RESPONSIBLE FOR ADMINISTERING AND DELIVERING FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAMS AND ARE ELIGIBLE FOR ASSISTANCE THROUGH THIS GRANT.

THE CACKLING GOOSE (BRANTA HUTCHINSII) IS A SMALL, WHITE-CHEEKED GOOSE THAT WAS TAXONOMICALLY SEPARATED FROM THE SIMILAR BUT LARGER CANADA GOOSE IN 2004. FOUR SUBSPECIES COMPRISE THE CACKLING GOOSE, WHICH ARE SEPARATED BASED ON DISTINCT BREEDING DISTRIBUTIONS, AS WELL AS DIFFERENCES IN PLUMAGE COLOR AND BODY SIZE. THE B. H. HUTCHINSII SUBSPECIES DOMINATES THROUGHOUT MOST OF THE MIDCONTINENT REGION DURING THE NON-BREEDING PERIOD (MLODINOW ET AL. 2008), AND THE CACKLING GOOSE IS REPORTED TO BE PHILOPATRIC TO WINTERING AREAS AND STOPOVER SITES DURING MIGRATION (MOWBRAY ET AL. 2020). THERE HAS BEEN CHANGES IN THE WINTER DISTRIBUTION OF CACKLING GEESE OVER THE LAST SEVERAL DECADES. AT A LARGER SCALE, CACKLING GEESE HAVE MOVED THEIR WINTER DISTRIBUTION NORTHWARD. FOR EXAMPLE, IN THE PACIFIC FLYWAY WHERE THEY HISTORICALLY WINTERED IN THE CENTRAL VALLEY OF CALIFORNIA, NOW WINTER PRIMARILY IN THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY OF OREGON (JARVIS AND BROMLEY 1998). SIMILARLY, THEY ARE ALMOST NON-EXISTENT ALONG THE TEXAS COAST WHERE THEY WERE HIGHLY ABUNDANT AS RECENT AS THE LATE 1990S (TPWD, UNPUBLISHED DATA). AT A SMALLER SCALE, THE INCREASED USE OF URBAN LANDSCAPES HAS BEEN NOTICEABLE THROUGHOUT MUCH OF THE SPECIES' EXISTING RANGE. GIVEN THE IMPORTANCE OF THE CACKLING GOOSE AS A GAME SPECIES, THESE CHANGES IN DISTRIBUTION HAVE POTENTIAL IMPLICATIONS TO HARVEST MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES ON WINTERING AREAS. FURTHER, INVESTIGATIONS OF DISTRIBUTION, MIGRATORY CONNECTIVITY AMONG SUBSPECIES, AND INTERACTIONS BETWEEN BREEDING AND WINTERING BIOLOGY HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS PRIORITIES FOR RESEARCH FOR THE CACKLING GOOSE (MOWBRAY ET AL. 2020). THESE ARE ALL OBJECTIVES THAT CAN BE EFFECTIVELY ADDRESSED WITH A WELL-DESIGNED TRACKING STUDY. THE ADVANCEMENT OF TRACKING DEVICE TECHNOLOGY HAS ALLOWED EFFECTIVE TRACKING OF SMALLER SPECIES OF BIRDS THROUGHOUT THE ANNUAL CYCLE. FOR EXAMPLE, THE 22 G NECK COLLAR DEVICE WE PROPOSE TO USE IN THIS STUDY IS SOLAR RECHARGEABLE WITH A THEORETICAL LIFE OF 1 YEAR, IS ABLE TO HANDLE AGGRESSIVE DUTY CYCLES FOR LOCATION ACQUISITION WHEN IN GOOD CELL COVERAGE, AND IS ONLY ABOUT 1% OF THE BIRD'S BODY MASS. THESE FULLY AUTOMATED DEVICES ALLOW CONTINUAL REMOTE TRACKING WHILE THE BIRD IS WITHIN CELL NETWORK COVERAGE. WHEN THE BIRD IS OUTSIDE OF CELL COVERAGE, SUCH AS WHEN IN THEIR ARCTIC BREEDING AREAS, THE DEVICE STORES ALL DATA UNTIL IT RETURNS TO CELL NETWORK COVERAGE WHEN IT UPLOADS DATA TO A SERVER. THUS, THE ABILITY TO MONITOR MOVEMENTS THROUGHOUT THE ANNUAL CYCLE ALLOW US TO UNDERSTAND CRITICAL ASPECTS OF THEIR NON-BREEDING ECOLOGY THAT IS OF INTEREST TO RESOURCE MANAGERS. FURTHER, THIS TECHNOLOGY WILL ALLOW US TO ADDRESS MANY QUESTIONS BEYOND THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS STUDY.

TWRA'S COMPREHENSIVE GRANT WILL CONTAIN THE FOLLOWING SUBPROGRAMS, EACH WITH PROJECTS THAT ADDRESS THEOBJECTIVES, ISSUES, AND STRATEGIES OF THE AGENCY'S STRATEGIC PLAN.SPORT FISH RESTORATION: PROJECTS WILL ADDRESS FISHING, FISH HABITAT, AND FISH POPULATION MANAGEMENT IN WATERSACROSS TENNESSEE. WE WILL MANAGE THE STATE'S FISHERIES THROUGH RESEARCH AND COLLECTION OF DATA ON FISHPOPULATIONS, EVALUATION OF ANGLER SUCCESS, CREATION AND MANAGEMENT OF HABITAT IN RESERVOIRS, OPERATION OF FISHHATCHERIES AND AGENCY FISHING LAKES, STOCKING OF FISH, PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO POND OWNERS, MAINTAININGCLEAN WATER AND PRIME AQUATIC HABITAT, AND ADMINISTRATION OF SPORT FISH PROJECTS. WE WILL ADDRESS THE STRATEGICPLAN CHAPTERS TITLED STREAMS AND RIVERS, IMPOUNDMENTS, AND OUTDOOR RECREATION.WILDLIFE RESTORATION: PROJECTS WILL ADDRESS HUNTING, WILDLIFE HABITAT, AND WILDLIFE POPULATION MANAGEMENT ACROSSTENNESSEE. WE WILL MANAGE THE STATE'S WILD MAMMALS AND WILD BIRDS THROUGH HABITAT MANAGEMENT, COLLECTING DATA ONPOPULATION LEVELS, OPERATING AND MAINTAINING WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA AND REFUGES, MANAGING FORESTS ON AGENCYOWNEDLANDS, AND ADMINISTRATION OF WILDLIFE RESTORATION PROJECTS. WE WILL ADDRESS THE STRATEGIC PLAN CHAPTERSTITLED GRASSLANDS, FORESTLANDS, WETLANDS, KARST, URBAN, AND OUTDOOR RECREATION.HUNTER EDUCATION: PROJECTS WILL ADDRESS TEACHING HUNTER EDUCATION AND OPERATING SHOOTING RANGES ACROSS TENNESSEEAND RECRUITING PARTICIPANTS TO HUNTING AND THE SHOOTING SPORTS. WE WILL INCREASE THE PUBLIC'S KNOWLEDGE OF SAFEHUNTING PRACTICES THROUGH A SYSTEM OF REGISTERING, TEACHING, TESTING, AND CERTIFYING HUNTERS THAT HAVEPARTICIPATED IN A HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM. WE WILL PROVIDE THE PUBLIC WITH PLACES TO SHOOT THROUGH CONSTRUCTION,MAINTENANCE, AND OPERATION OF PUBLIC SHOOTING RANGES. THIS WILL ADDRESS STRATEGIES IN THE OUTDOOR RECREATION ANDLAW ENFORCEMENT CHAPTERS OF THE AGENCY'S STRATEGIC PLAN.BOAT ACCESS: PROJECTS WILL SEEK TO DEVELOP, RENOVATE, MAINTAIN, OR IMPROVE PUBLIC BOAT ACCESS SITES. THE SOUTHCENTRAL REGION OF ALASKA (REGION 2) WILDLIFE SURVEY AND INVENTORY PROGRAM GRANT SUPPORTS WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AND WILDLIFE-RELATED RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES THROUGH STAFF AND PROJECT FUNDING IN FIVE AREA OFFICES (ANCHORAGE, CORDOVA, HOMER, KODIAK, AND SOLDOTNA). THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO PROVIDE WILDLIFE SURVEY, INVENTORY, WILDLIFE DATA MANAGEMENT AND SUPPORT, AND COORDINATION INFORMATION AT THE REGIONAL, GAME MANAGEMENT UNIT (UNIT), SUBUNIT, AREA OFFICE, HERD, OR HUNT AREA LEVEL FOR MORE THAN 20 SPECIES. THESE WILDLIFE POPULATIONS IN REGION 2 ARE MANAGED ACCORDING TO SUSTAINED YIELD PRINCIPLES. IT FUNDS THE NECESSARY STAFF AND DATA COLLECTION TO ENSURE THE CONSERVATION, PROTECTION, AND MANAGEMENT OF WILDLIFE TO PROVIDE SUSTAINABLE POPULATIONS FOR HUNTING, TRAPPING, AND OTHER WILDLIFE-BASED USER OPPORTUNITIES. THE GRANT FUNDS MONITORING OF POPULATIONS THROUGH CAPTURE, RADIO-MARKING, AND GPS/TELEMETRY MONITORING TO ASSESS SURVIVAL AND DISTRIBUTION; AERIAL AND GROUND-BASED SURVEYS TO ASSESS POPULATION COMPOSITION, SIZE, AND TREND; AND ESTIMATION AND MONITORING OF HARVEST. IT ALSO FUNDS STAFF PARTICIPATION IN TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND MANAGEMENT PLANNING, INCLUDING BIOMETRIC SUPPORT. THIS GRANT ALSO INCLUDES OPERATING COSTS FOR FACILITIES, VEHICLES, TRAVEL, MOVING ALLOWANCES, OFFICE EQUIPMENT, AND TRAINING.

THE PROJECT WILL RESTORE AND INCREASE RESILIENCE OF WETLANDS AT THE J.D. MURPHREE WMA BY CLEANING OUT DITCHES ADJACENT TO APPROXIMATELY 59,500 LINEAR FEET OF LEVEES IN COMPARTMENTS 1, 2, 3 AND 4, THEN USE THIS MATERIAL TO RAISE THE ELEVATION OF THE LEVEES TO +3.5 FT NAVD88 AND RECONTOUR THE SIDES.

PURPOSE: TO INSTITUTE A SYSTEM OF WILDLIFE DISEASE RESEARCH, MONITORING, AND RESPONSE THAT INCREASES OUR KNOWLEDGE OF WILDLIFE DISEASES AND POPULATION-LEVEL EFFECTS TO ENABLE THE COMMISSION TO PREVENT OR MANAGE THOSE ISSUES IN A SAFE AND EFFECTIVE MANNER.OBJECTIVE 1: CONDUCT WILDLIFE DISEASE MONITORING AND SURVEILLANCE FOR AT LEAST 6 SPECIES BY JUNE 30, 2023OBJECTIVE 2: MANAGE AGENCY RESPONSE FOR CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE(CWD) IN WHITE-TAILED DEER AND ELK BY JUNE 30, 2023OBJECTIVE 3: CONDUCT AT LEAST 5 WILDLIFE TECHNICAL TRAINING ACTIVITIES BY JUNE 30, 2023OBJECTIVE 4: EDUCATE 10,000 INDIVIDUALS ABOUT WILDLIFE HEALTH ISSUES BY JUNE 30, 2023OBJECTIVE 5: CREATE ONE DATABASE TO STORE AND ANALYZE CWD SAMPLING DATA BY JUNE 30, 2023EXPECTED OUTCOMES:IMPROVE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AND REGULATION DEVELOPMENT USING BEST AVAILABLE SCIENCE; INCREASE AGENCY STAFF AND PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE REGARDING WILDLIFE HEALTH; MAINTAIN OR INCREASE HUNTER PARTICIPATION BY ADDRESSING WILDLIFE-HEALTH RELATED CONCERNS; INCREASE COMMUNICATION WITH THE PUBLIC REGARDING WILDLIFE HEALTH AND CONSERVATION; MEET PUBLIC EXPECTATIONS FOR ANIMAL WELFARE AND PUBLIC HEALTH THROUGH EFFECTIVE WILDLIFE HEALTH MANAGEMENTINTENDED BENEFICIARIES: GENERAL PUBLIC, WILDLIFE REHABILITATORS, CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS, ARKANSAS GAME AND FISH COMMISSION

PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO OBTAIN SCIENTIFIC AND OTHER DATA (E.G. ABUNDANCE, CHARACTERISTICS, POPULATION SIZE, STATUS, CONDITION, DISTRIBUTION, HABITAT AND CONDITION, ETC.) NECESSARY FOR THE EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT OF NATIVE AND MIGRATORY SPECIES AND HABITATS WITHIN WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS (WMA'S) AND STATEWIDE (PUBLIC AND PRIVATE) LAND.OBJECTIVE 1: CONDUCT AT LEAST 25 INVESTIGATIONS CONSISTING OF RESEARCH, SURVEYS AND/OR MONITORING ACTIVITIES BY JUNE 30, 2023EXPECTED OUTCOMES:BY CONTINUING RESEARCH, MONITORING AND SURVEYS OF WILDLIFE POPULATIONS, THE AGFC WILL BE ABLE TO BETTER UNDERSTAND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND DEVELOP RECOMMENDATIONS ON SPECIES MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES THAT EFFECTIVELY CONSERVE GAME AND NON-GAME WILDLIFE SPECIES.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: ARKANSAS GAME AND FISH COMMISSION, GENERAL PUBLICSUB-RECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO AID AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL GUIDANCE TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AS WELL AS ON PUBLIC LANDS IN MISSISSIPPI. THE DEPARTMENT WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL GUIDANCE (I.E., EXPERT ADVICE) REGARDING WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AND PUBLIC USE TO GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES AND PRIVATE LANDOWNERS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE HUNTER EDUCATION AND TRAINING TO RESIDENTS OF THE STATE OF ILLINOIS. SOME PROJECT GOALS ARE TO:1.PRODUCE SAFE, RESPONSIBLE AND KNOWLEDGEABLE HUNTERS.2.OFFER ADEQUATE TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES IN THE INSTRUCTION OF HUNTER EDUCATION AS PRESCRIBED BY THE STATE STATUTE TO THE CITIZENS OF ILLINOIS.3.OFFER TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES TO THE VOLUNTEER INSTRUCTOR CORE.4.ATTRACT AND PRODUCE MORE COMPETENT ARCHERY PARTICIPANTS THROUGH TRAINING COURSES IN THE USE OF ARCHERY EQUIPMENT AND SHOOTING TECHNIQUES.5.OFFER TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES IN SPECIES SPECIFIC CLINICS TO ENCOURAGE AND DEVELOP SAFE, RESPONSIBLE AND KNOWLEDGEABLE HUNTERS IN THE FIELD.6.PROMOTE HUNTER SAFETY THROUGH EDUCATION AS A MEANS TO HELP REDUCE THE HUNTING INCIDENT RATE.7.OFFER LIVE FIRE TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES, THROUGH THE SUPPLY OF AMMUNITION, TARGETS AND FIREARMS, TO THE DEGREE PRACTICAL.ADDITIONALLY, THE SECTION 10 FUNDS ARE USED TO COMPLETE THE FOLLOWING GOALS:1.PROVIDE A HIGHER LEVEL OF SHOTGUN SHOOTING INSTRUCTION THAN CURRENTLY FOUND IN THE BASIC HUNTER EDUCATION COURSE TO INCREASE THE COMPETENCY LEVEL OF CURRENT/NEW HUNTERS AND TO ATTRACT AND INTRODUCE NEW PARTICIPANTS IN THE SHOOTING SPORTS.2.OFFER TRAINING IN SHOOTING SPORTS TEACHING TO VOLUNTEERS.3.ENHANCE THE PUBLIC RANGE SYSTEM ON DEPARTMENT SITES.4.EXPAND HUNTING AND SHOOTING OPPORTUNITIES TO PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES.5.PUBLICIZE THE HUNTING/SHOOTING SPORTS AS A RECREATIONAL PURSUIT.EXPECTED BENEFITS ARE INCREASED INTEREST IN HUNTING, SHOOTING, AND ARCHERY AND DECREASED INCIDENTS OF HUNTER RELATED ACCIDENTS. THERE ARE NO EXPECTED SUB-GRANTEES ASSOCIATED WITH THIS PROJECT.

THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO DEVELOP A SCIENCE-BASED HUNTER R3 PROGRAM THAT PROVIDES ADULTS (18 YEARS OF AGE) WITH AN OPPORTUNITY TO LEARN ABOUT HUNTING, CLEANING, AND PREPARING GAME BY HOLDING WORKSHOPS AROUND THE STATE THAT FOCUS ON HOW AND WHERE TO HUNT, HOW TO CLEAN GAME AND EQUIPMENT POST-HUNT, ILLINOIS LAWS AND REGULATIONS, AND THE ROLE OF HUNTING IN WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT. HUNTING FOSTERS INTEREST IN THE NATURAL WORLD, AND WILDLIFE SPECIFICALLY. THIS INTEREST TRANSFERS TO OTHER ACTIVITIES (BACKYARD BIRD FEEDING, CONSERVATION). HUNTERS ALSO PROVIDE ESSENTIAL CONTRIBUTIONS TO RURAL ECONOMIES AND SUPPORTING JOBS IN SEVERAL INDUSTRIAL SECTORS. MOREOVER, HUNTERS ARE A STRONG SOURCE OF SUPPORT FOR SCIENTIFIC MANAGEMENT OF WILDLIFE. FOR THESE AND OTHER REASONS, IT IS BENEFICIAL TO INTRODUCE CITIZENS TO HUNTING. UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS AT URBANA CHAMPAIGN IS AN EXPECTED SUBRECIPIENT OF THIS GRANT.
THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ACQUIRE THE 657 ACRES OF THE PAUL TRACT, A FEE SIMPLE AQUISITION, AND ADD THIS PROPERTY TO THE OAK WOODS WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA.
