MULE DEER IN EASTERN OREGON HAVE EXPERIENCED LONG-TERM POPULATION DECLINES AND THESE DECLINES ARE NOT RESTRICTEDTO A SINGLE GEOGRAPHIC REGION. BASED ON CHRONICALLY LOW RECRUITMENT OF FAWNS INTO THE ADULT POPULATION,NUTRITION, PARTICULARLY ON SUMMER RANGE MAY BE A FACTOR CONTRIBUTING TO LOW RECRUITMENT AND POPULATION DECLINES. IN MANY UNGULATE SPECIES, ANNUAL VARIATION IN RECRUITMENT IS THE PRIMARY DETERMINANT OF POPULATION GROWTH GIVENADULT SURVIVAL TENDS TO BE RELATIVELY HIGH AND INVARIABLE. IN MULE DEER, RECRUITMENT IS THE PRODUCT OF THREEVITAL RATES: PREGNANCY, FETAL RATE, AND SURVIVAL OF OFFSPRING TO ONE YEAR. NUTRITIONAL CONDITION OF FEMALE MULEDEER SHOULD HAVE A STRONG EFFECT ON REPRODUCTIVE PERFORMANCE AND SURVIVAL OF OFFSPRING IF NUTRITIONAL RESOURCESARE LIMITED ON THE LANDSCAPE. THE QUANTITY AND QUALITY OF FORAGE ON SUMMER RANGE WILL AFFECT NUTRITIONALCONDITION OF FEMALES ENTERING WINTER, WHICH IN TURN WILL AFFECT OTHER VITAL RATES INCLUDING: 1) PREGNANCY RATES,2) FETAL RATES, 3) NEONATE BIRTH MASS AND GROWTH RATES, 4) JUVENILE SURVIVAL AND RECRUITMENT, AND 5) FINALLY ADULT SURVIVAL. AS THE SEVERITY OF NUTRITIONAL LIMITATION INCREASES, IT WOULD BE EXPECTED THAT VITAL RATESAFFECTING OFFSPRING WOULD DECLINE FIRST, AS THE MATERNAL FEMALE WILL USE NUTRITIONAL RESOURCES TO ENSURE SURVIVALTO THE NEXT YEAR WHEN CONDITIONS MAY BE BETTER (E.G., A BET-HEDGING STRATEGY OF REPRODUCTION). GIVEN THISREPRODUCTIVE STRATEGY, TO EFFECTIVELY STUDY POTENTIAL NUTRITIONAL LIMITATIONS IN A POPULATION IT IS IMPORTANT TOASSESS THOSE FACTORS WHICH ARE MOST LIKELY TO BE AFFECTED BY NUTRITIONAL LIMITATIONS (E.G., PREGNANCY RATES,FETAL RATES, AND FAWN SURVIVAL).THIS RESEARCH PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO ASSESS THE ROLE OF SUMMER NUTRITION ON MULE DEER POPULATION PERFORMANCE INEASTERN OREGON. TO CONDUCT THIS RESEARCH, WE WILL CAPTURE ADULT MULE DEER IN LATE FALL (DECEMBER) TO MEASURETHEIR BODY FAT AND ASSES THEIR PREGNANCY STATUS. WE WILL RECAPTURE DEER IN LATE WINTER (MARCH) TO AGAIN MEASUREBODY FAT, ASSESS PREGNANCY STATUS, AND NUMBER OF FETUSES. ADULT FEMALE MULE DEER WILL BE FITTED WITH A GPS COLLARAND PREGNANT FEMALES WILL BE FITTED A VAGINAL IMPLANT TRANSMITTER TO AID IN CAPTURE OF THEIR FAWNS THE FOLLOWINGSPRING. FAWNS WILL BE CAPTURED AFTER BIRTH AND FITTED WITH COLLARS TO MONITOR SURVIVAL THEIR SURVIVAL ANDDOCUMENT THE CAUSE OF MORTALITY. WE WILL ALSO CAPTURE 6-MONTH-OLD FAWNS ENTERING WINTER TO OBTAIN THEIR WEIGHT -DURING YEARS OF INCREASED NUTRITIONAL STRESS, FAWNS SHOULD HAVE REDUCED GROWTH RATES AND BE SMALLER ENTERINGWINTER. THESE FIELD APPROACHES WILL ALLOW US TO COMPLETE THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES:1. ASSESS NUTRITIONAL CONDITION OF ADULT FEMALES ENTERING AND LEAVING WINTER AND DETERMINE IF BODY FAT LEVELS ARESUFFICIENT TO SUPPORT POPULATION GROWTH.2. DETERMINE THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN MATERNAL CONDITION (I.E., BODY FAT) AND PREGNANCY RATES, FETAL RATES, ANDFAWN AND DOE SURVIVAL.3. DETERMINE THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN FAWN WEIGHTS ENTERING WINTER AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS.4. DETERMINE HOW HABITAT USE AND OTHER ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS (E.G., DROUGHT) AFFECT NUTRITIONAL CONDITION OFADULT FEMALE MULE DEER ENTERING WINTER.IDENTIFYING THE DEGREE OF NUTRITIONAL LIMITATIONS IN MULE DEER POPULATIONS IN OREGON IS CRITICAL FOR EFFECTIVEMANAGEMENT OF THE SPECIES. THIS WORK WILL IDENTIFY FACTORS LIMITING POPULATION GROWTH IN MULE DEER. THESE FINDINGS WILL ALLOW WILDLIFE AND LAND MANAGERS TO DEVELOP STRATEGIES TO IMPROVE NUTRITIONAL CONDITIONS FOR MULEDEER. INCREASING MULE DEER POPULATIONS WILL ALLOWED FOR INCREASED RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITY AND ECONOMIC BENEFITSIN OREGON.

YELLOW RAILS (COTURNICOPS NOVEBORACENSIS) ARE AN OREGON CONSERVATION STRATEGY SPECIES BECAUSE OF THEIRSPECIALIZED HABITAT NEEDS WITHIN SHALLOW WETLAND SYSTEMS IN THE EAST CASCADE ECOREGION. IN PARTICULAR, THE COREOF THE WESTERN YELLOW RAIL POPULATION RESIDES IN KLAMATH MARSH NWR AND ITS PERSISTENCE IS RELIANT ON PERENNIALWETLAND CONDITIONS. THERE IS AN EXISTING DATA GAP REGARDING YELLOW RAIL ECOLOGY AND DISTRIBUTION OUTSIDE OF THEKLAMATH MARSH AND A FEW SURROUNDING WETLANDS. IMPORTANTLY, YELLOW RAIL DEPEND ON WETLAND HABITATS ASSOCIATED WITHFLOODED RIPARIAN AND PERENNIAL WET MEADOW SYSTEMS. HOWEVER, AN INVENTORY OF POTENTIAL BREEDING HABITATS WITHIN SOUTH-CENTRAL OREGON HAS NOT BEEN CONDUCTED. YELLOW RAIL SHARE THIS HABITAT WITH OTHER WETLAND DEPENDENT OREGONCONSERVATION STRATEGY SPECIES INCLUDING THE OREGON SPOTTED FROG (RANA PRETIOSA) AND SANDHILL CRANE (GRUSCANADENSIS) AND IN SOME PLACES, INCLUDING KLAMATH MARSH AND THE WOOD RIVER VALLEY, OVERLAP WITH REDBAND TROUT(ONCORHYNCHUS MYKISS), AND SEVERAL SPECIES OF ENDEMIC LAMPREY (PETROMYZONTIFORMES). THESE WETLAND SYSTEMS ALSOPROVIDE ESSENTIAL ECOSYSTEM SERVICES THAT DRIVE WATERSHED NUTRIENT AND WATER BUDGETS. THE POPULATION TREND OF YELLOW RAIL AND OTHER WETLAND DEPENDENT SPECIES IS A CRITICAL METRIC FOR THE OVERALL HEALTH AND WELL-BEING OF THELARGER WATERSHED.WITH INCREASED DROUGHT AND THE ASSOCIATED DEGRADATION OF WATERSHED WATER BUDGETS, GAINING A BETTER UNDERSTANDINGOF THE DISTRIBUTION OF YELLOW RAIL IN OREGON AND THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST IS CRITICAL IF THIS DISJUNCT POPULATION ISTO SURVIVE ONGOING HABITAT CHANGES. IN THE UPPER KLAMATH BASIN, 85-90% OF THEIR ORIGINAL PERENNIAL SHORT EMERGENTWETLAND HABITAT WAS LOST BY THE 1980S. WITHOUT A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF HOW HYDROLOGY AFFECTS YELLOW RAILS,FUTURE MANAGEMENT OF THE SPECIES AND THEIR HABITAT IS UNCERTAIN. THUS, DEVELOPING GIS MODELS THAT PREDICT SHALLOWWETLAND HABITAT AND ITS SPATIO-TEMPORAL VARIATION IS PARAMOUNT IN UNDERSTANDING POTENTIAL LOCATIONS OF YELLOWRAIL HABITAT. THE COMPUTING POWER OF GOOGLEEARTH ENGINE HAS TRANSFORMED HOW LANDSCAPE ECOLOGISTS MODEL HABITATAND PROVIDES GREAT PROMISE IN DEVELOPING PREDICTIVE MODELS OF SHALLOW WETLAND HABITAT. THERE IS A NEED TOESTABLISH A MORE DEFINITIVE DISTRIBUTION MAP TO SERVE AS A FOUNDATION OR REFERENCE POINT FOR FUTURE CONSERVATIONEFFORTS. THUS, EXPANDING SURVEY EFFORT AND MONITORING OF YELLOW RAIL OCCUPANCY AND ABUNDANCE IN KNOWN ANDPOTENTIAL HABITAT IS NEEDED.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS STUDY IS TO ESTIMATE BLACK-TAILED DEER DENSITY BY HABITAT TYPE, DOCUMENT BLACK-TAILED DEERSURVIVAL RATES AND CAUSES OF MORTALITY, AND TO COLLECT AND INTEGRATE DATA ON WESTERN OREGON BLACK-TAILED DOE BODYCONDITION, HABITAT SELECTION, AVAILABLE FORAGE RESOURCES, AND FAWN SURVIVAL.PREVIOUS RESEARCH RESULTS OF HAVE INDICATED SIGNIFICANT DISPARITY BETWEEN SPOTLIGHT AND FECAL DNA DERIVED SEX ANDAGE RATIOS. WE PROPOSE TO DIRECTLY COMPARE METHODS (SPOTLIGHT, FECAL DNA, CAMERA) ON THE SAME STUDY SITE. SEXRATIOS OBTAINED IN THE STUDY SITES WILL BE COMPARED USING SPACE-TO-EVENT (CAMERA DATA), SPATIAL CAPTURE-RECAPTUREESTIMATES (FECAL DNA) AND SPOTLIGHT VALUES. AGE RATIOS WILL BE COMPARED BETWEEN CAMERA DATA AND SPOTLIGHTVALUES. ULTIMATELY, DEER DENSITY ESTIMATES FROM SPACE-TO-EVENT (CAMERA) AND SPATIAL CAPTURE-RECAPTURE (FECAL DNA)WILL BE COMPARED. POTENTIALLY, CAMERAS CAN PROVIDE A COST-EFFECTIVE AND NONINVASIVE METHOD FOR ENUMERATING ANDMONITORING BLACK-TAILED DEER, SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCING FUTURE COSTS FOR ODFW.

THE MK NATURE CENTER IN BOISE IS AN IDEAL LOCATION FOR EFFORTS TO PROVIDE WILDLIFE-VIEWING OPPORTUNITIES AS WELLAS INCREASE PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING ABOUT WILDLIFE AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT. THESE EFFORTS INCREASE APPRECIATION FORIDAHO'S WILDLIFE, LEADING TO GREATER PUBLIC SUPPORT FOR AND UNDERSTANDING OF AGENCY MANAGEMENT WORK. ADDITIONALLY, VISITORS LEARN ABOUT AND BECOME INSPIRED TO PARTICIPATE IN IDAHO'S WEALTH OF WILDLIFE-RELATEDRECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES.WILDLIFE RESTORATION FUNDING ASSISTS THE NATURE CENTER IN PROVIDING WILDLIFE-RELATED OUTREACH OPPORTUNITIES TOITS URBAN VISITORS. THROUGH PUBLIC PROGRAMS, SCHOOL OUTREACH, AND INFORMAL EDUCATION EFFORTS, NATURE CENTERSTAFF AND VOLUNTEERS CAN ASSIST VISITORS IN LEARNING ABOUT IDAHO'S WILDLIFE AND HABITATS ALONG WITH WILDLIFERELATEDRECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. IN ADDITION, HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIVITIES ATTRACT NATIVE WILDLIFE SPECIESAND INCREASE WILDLIFE-VIEWING OPPORTUNITIES AT THE FACILITY. THESE OPPORTUNITIES HELP VISITORS LEARN ABOUTWILDLIFE; GAIN AN APPRECIATION AND UNDERSTANDING FOR THE VALUE OF WILDLIFE RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT; AND INSPIRETHEM TO BECOME INVOLVED IN WILDLIFE-RELATED RECREATION IN IDAHO.

THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE NON-INVASIVE SAMPLING OF 95 SITES USED TO ESTIMATE FISHER POPULATION DENSITY. INADDITION, THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW EVALUATION OF FISHER SPACE USE, ESTIMATION OF SURVIVAL RATES, AND ASSESSMENT OFCOMPETITION WITH GRAY FOXES. EACH OF THESE TYPES OF DATA ARE IMPORTANT REGARDING THE CURRENT POPULATION DYNAMICSAND POTENTIAL FUTURE EXPANSION OF FISHERS IN OREGON.ODFW IS PROPOSING TO COLLECT ADDITIONAL DATA ON FISHER TO INFORM MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT OF THIS OREGONSTRATEGY SPECIES. SPECIFICALLY, ATTACHING GPS-COLLARS TO FISHERS AND GRAY FOXES, ONE OF THE PRIMARY COMPETITORSOF FISHERS, WITHIN THE KLAMATH MOUNTAIN ECOREGION WILL BENEFIT ODFW'S ABILITY TO EFFECTIVELY CONSERVE FISHERSTHROUGH IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF 1) THE EFFICACY OF NON-INVASIVE GENETIC SAMPLING FOR FISHERS, 2) THE INFLUENCEOF HABITAT ON FISHER MOVEMENTS AND POTENTIAL BARRIERS TO CONNECTIVITY WITHIN THE KLAMATH MOUNTAIN ECOREGION, 3)FISHER SURVIVAL RATES AND CAUSES OF MORTALITY, AND 4) COMPETITION FOR RESOURCES WITH GRAY FOXES. THIS KNOWLEDGEWILL ALLOW ODFW TO BETTER ASSESS LIMITS TO FISHER POPULATION RECOVERY AND EXPANSION INTO PURPORTEDLY SUITABLEHABITAT IN SOUTHERN OREGON, THEREBY ADDRESSING MULTIPLE DATA GAPS LISTED FOR THIS SPECIES IN THE OREGONCONSERVATION STRATEGY.

IN OREGON, THE SIERRA NEVADA RED FOX (VULPES VULPES NECATOR) IS MANAGED AS BOTH A RECREATIONALLY HARVESTEDFURBEARER AND AS A STRATEGY SPECIES IN THE OREGON CONSERVATION STRATEGY (HTTPS://WWW.OREGONCONSERVATIONSTRATEGY.ORG/). HISTORICALLY, SIERRA NEVADA RED FOX WERE DISTRIBUTED THROUGHOUT ALPINE, SUBALPINE, AND MONTANEENVIRONMENTS OF CALIFORNIA AND OREGON. IN CALIFORNIA, THE SIERRA NEVADA DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENT WAS LISTED ASENDANGERED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT IN 202. RED FOX POPULATIONS IN OREGON ARE NOT FEDERALLY LISTED,THOUGH THEY HAVE EXPERIENCED A DECLINE OVER THE PAST CENTURY CHARACTERIZED BY SMALLER POPULATIONS AND A MOREFRAGMENTED DISTRIBUTION.ALTHOUGH RESEARCH OVER THE PAST SEVERAL YEARS HAS BEGUN TO DOCUMENT RED FOX DISTRIBUTION AND HABITAT SUITABILITYIN OREGON, KEY INFORMATION ON CONTEMPORARY RED FOX OCCUPANCY, ABUNDANCE, DISTRIBUTION, POPULATION STATUS ANDCONNECTIVITY IS URGENTLY NEEDED TO HELP INFORM DECISION MAKING PROCESSES. HERE, WE PROPOSE A CAMERA-BASED STUDYOF SIERRA NEVADA RED FOX DISTRIBUTION IN THREE REGIONS OF OREGON WITH HISTORICAL SNRF RANGE AND SUITABLE HABITATCONDITIONS, BUT LACKING CONTEMPORARY SURVEY EFFORTS. THESE INCLUDE AREAS OF THE CASCADES TO THE SOUTH AND NORTHOF CRATER LAKE, AND IN THE REGION BETWEEN THE CENTRAL CASCADES AND MOUNT HOOD. SUITABILITY MODELS SUGGEST A HIGHPOTENTIAL FOR RED FOX IN THESE REGIONS, BUT WITH SCANT DOCUMENTATION OF FOX PRESENCE.COLLECTING DATA ON AN ELUSIVE, SPARSELY DISTRIBUTED, AND WIDELY-RANGING SPECIES PRESENTS A DIFFICULT CHALLENGEFOR WILDLIFE MANAGERS AND SCIENTISTS. HERE, WE PROPOSE A PASSIVE, TRAIL-BASED, CAMERA DESIGN THAT HAS PROVENHIGHLY EFFECTIVE AT SURVEYING LOW DENSITY MONTANE CARNIVORES AT LARGE SCALES IN WASHINGTON AND MONTANA (E.G.,CANADA LYNX). CAMERA DATA WILL BE USED IN AN OCCUPANCY MODELING APPROACH TO ESTIMATE RED FOX PRESENCE (CORRECTEDFOR DETECTABILITY) AND DISTRIBUTION. OCCUPANCY MODELS WILL BE USED TO EXAMINE HOTSPOTS OF PRESENCE (COREHABITAT), AND TO EVALUATE KEY ENVIRONMENTAL DRIVERS OF FOX DISTRIBUTION PATTERNS (E.G., RECREATION, COMPETITION,CLIMATE, TOPOGRAPHY, HABITAT). THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THIS WORK WILL BE TO GENERATE A MORE COMPLETEUNDERSTANDING OF RED FOX DISTRIBUTION AND DRIVERS OF THAT DISTRIBUTION, AND TO ASSESS THE UTILITY OF THIS CAMERABASEDMETHOD TO SERVE AS A COMPONENT OF A LARGE-SCALE MONITORING FRAMEWORK (VIA ANALYSIS OF DETECTIONPROBABILITIES, COST, TOTAL AREA SURVEYED). THIS STUDY WILL PROVIDE KEY DATA ON THE CURRENT STATUS OF FOXES INOREGON, WHICH WILL BE CRITICALLY IMPORTANT FOR WILDLIFE MANAGERS ENGAGED IN CONSERVATION PLANNING AND MANAGEMENTOF THIS SPECIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT TO ASSURE THAT FEDERAL AID PROJECT GOALS ARE ACCOMPLISHED IN AN EFFECTIVE, TIMELY, AND EFFICIENT MANNER AS WELL AS MAINTAIN ELIGIBILITY FOR PARTICIPATION IN FEDERAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS.

THE NEED FOR HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAMS IN THE STATE OF UTAH IS WIDELY COMPLEX AND SPANS LEGISLATIVE MANDATE, AGENCY MISSION AND A VARIETY OF PUBLIC NEED. THIS GRANT PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING FOR THE OPERATION AND MANAGEMENT OF THE UTAH HUNTER EDUCATION, BOWHUNTER EDUCATION, AND FURHARVESTER EDUCATION PROGRAMS. PROGRAM ADMINISTRATION INCLUDES MAINTENANCE OF STUDENT RECORDS, ISSUING OF COMPLETION CERTIFICATES, VOLUNTEER INSTRUCTOR TRAINING AND RECOGNITION, COURSE SCHEDULING, MATERIALS, CURRICULUM AND DELIVERY, ETC.THE HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAMS ASSIST THE DIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES IN FULFILLING ITS MISSION BY EDUCATION HUNTERS TO BE SAFE, RESPONSIBLE, KNOWLEDGEABLE, AND INVOLVED.
THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT THE SC HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM FOR FY 22-23

HUNTING IS A SIGNIFICANT CULTURAL, ECONOMIC, AND HISTORICAL ELEMENT OF THE NORTH CAROLINA LIFESTYLE. HOWEVER, NORTH CAROLINA HAS UNDERGONE SOCIOECONOMIC CHANGES THAT IMPACT THE TRADITIONAL ROLE AND IMPORTANCE OF HUNTING. AS A RESULT, TODAY'S PUBLIC HAS BECOME INCREASINGLY CONCERNED ABOUT HUNTER SAFETY AND BEHAVIOR, DEMANDING GREATER ACCOUNTABILITY BY HUNTERS. HUNTERS IN NORTH CAROLINA NEED TO BE GIVEN OPPORTUNITIES TO ACQUIRE KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS AND ATTITUDES NECESSARY TO DEMONSTRATE SAFE AND RESPONSIBLE CONDUCT. THE NORTH CAROLINA HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE THE NECESSARY COMPONENTS TO FOSTER THIS DEVELOPMENT.

THIS GRANT WILL ACTIVELY MONITOR THE RECOVERY AND POPULATION EXPANSION OF THE BLACK BEAR TO ALLOW FOR THE EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT OF THE SPECIES IN THE STATE TO MAINTAIN THE VIABILITY OF THE SPECIES AS A POTENTIAL RENEWABLE WILDLIFE RESOURCE.

THE NORTHEAST CORRIDOR (NEC) NATURAL RESERVE AND THE BOQUERN STATE FOREST (BSF) ARE NATURAL PROTECTED AREAS (NPA) MANAGED BY THE PUERTO RICO DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES. BOTH NPAS SHARE COMMON HABITATS AND THREATS THROUGH BOTH NATURAL AND ANTHROPOGENIC ACTIONS. WITH THIS PROJECT, WE ARE SEEKING FUNDS TO: (1) CONDUCT A STUDY TO ASSESS THE CURRENT HYDROLOGICAL CONDITIONS AT THE NEC AND THE BSF, (2) DEVELOP STRATEGIES TO RESTORE WETLAND FOREST CONDITIONS, THROUGH EFFORTS INCLUDING HYDROLOGICAL CONNECTIVITY, INVASIVE SPECIES REMOVAL, AND REFORESTATION AT BOTH SITES. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE THE NECESSARY INFORMATION TO DEVELOP RESTORATION STRATEGIES, WHICH WILL CONSIST OF A PHASE 2. THUS, FUTURE FUNDING WILL BE NEEDED TO IMPLEMENT THE SECOND PHASE.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO OBTAIN WILDLIFE POPULATION, HABITAT, DISEASE, AND HUMAN DIMENSIONS DATA THAT WILL PROVIDE THE BASIS OF KDWP'S WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS THROUGH JUNE 30, 2023, AND PROVIDE THE COORDINATION, ADMINISTRATION, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND EDUCATION SUPPORT ASSOCIATED WITH THESE PROGRAMS. DELIVERABLES ARE GENERALLY IN THE FORM OF DATA THAT INFORM DECISIONS ON SPECIES AND HUNTER MANAGEMENT AND ARE SUMMARIZED IN SURVEY REPORT THAT IS PRODUCED ON AN ANNUAL BASIS AND ARE INCLUDED IN THE ANNUAL REPORT FOR THIS PROJECT. BENEFICIARIES LIKELY WILL INCLUDE CONSUMPTIVE AND NON-CONSUMPTIVE USERS OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES IN THE STATE OF KANSAS.

MANAGING MAMMALIAN PREDATORS IS CHALLENGING. SOME SPECIES ARE CONSIDERED OVER-ABUNDANT AND MAY HAVE DETRIMENTAL IMPACTS, WHILE OTHER SPECIES APPEAR TO BE EXPERIENCING DRAMATIC POPULATION DECLINES. HISTORICALLY, FUR TRAPPING RECORDS WERE CONSIDERED ADEQUATE FOR MONITORING TRENDS IN THESE SPECIES. HOWEVER, DEPRESSED FUR PRICES HAVE REDUCED INTEREST IN TRAPPING AND REDUCED THE RELIABILITY OF FUR HARVEST DATA TO TRACK POPULATION TRENDS. THIS PROJECT WILL ATTEMPT TO DEVELOP MONITORING METHODS TO MONITOR POPULATION TRENDS IN 11 SPECIES OF MAMMALS.
THIS PROJECT WILL FUND MUCH OF THE NECESSARY PREDATORY MAMMAL CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES IN COLORADO.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS ONE-YEAR PROJECT IS TO MONITOR MOOSE NUTRITIONAL CONDITION AFTER LANDSCAPE-SCALE WILDFIRES ON THE KENAI PENINSULA. THIS MONITORING SHOULD PROVIDE INSIGHTS INTO HABITAT QUALITY AS WELL AS INSIGHTS INTO HOW LARGE-SCALE HABITAT ENHANCEMENT PROJECTS CAN POSITIVELY INFLUENCE MOOSE POPULATIONS.WILL CONTINUE TO CONTRIBUTE TO 14 YEARS OF DATA ON MOOSE MOVEMENTS IN THE EARLY SERAL HABITATS OF THE FUNNY RIVER FIRE AND SWAN LAKE FIRE, IN COMPARISON WITH LATE SERAL HABITATS ON THE NORTHERN KENAI LOWLANDS. GIVEN THE LAST OPPORTUNITY TO DO A RESEARCH PROJECT OF THIS MAGNITUDE IN RESPONSE TO A LANDSCAPE SCALE WILDFIRE ON THE KENAI PENINSULA WAS IN 1969, THE RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE ESSENTIAL TO UNDERSTANDING MOOSE RESPONSE TO LANDSCAPE SCALE FIRE IN THIS AREA.EXPANDED RESEARCH ON SELECTED POPULATIONS SUPPORTS IMPROVED MANAGEMENT OF WILDLIFE OVER TIME WITH RESPECT TO HABITAT QUALITY. RESULTS FROM THIS WORK ARE INTENDED TO SUBSTANTIATE INCREASED USE OF PRESCRIBED FIRE OR MECHANICAL TREATMENT RELATIVE TO MOOSE POPULATIONS ON THE KENAI PENINSULA. COMPLEMENTARY BENEFITS SUCH AS COMMUNITY WILDFIRE PROTECTION CONNECTS FOREST AND FIRE MANAGEMENT TO COMMUNITY VALUES FOR SAFETY AND HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES.CONTINUING RESEARCH ON THE KENAI PENINSULA MOOSE POPULATION SUPPORTS MANAGEMENT DECISIONS FOR HARVEST BAG LIMITS WHILE EXPANDING THE BODY OF KNOWLEDGE RELATING HABITAT QUALITY TO BODY CONDITION, MOVEMENT PATTERNS, ANTLER SIZE, AND HERD RECRUITMENT.

PURPOSE AND OBJECTIVES: TO PROVIDE THE PUBLIC WITH SAFE AND RESPONSIBLE OPPORTUNITIES FOR FIREARM AND ARCHERY ACTIVITIES.OBJECTIVE 1: OPERATE AND MAINTAIN FOUR AGENCY-OWNED FIREARM RANGES BY JUNE 30, 2023.OBJECTIVE 2: OPERATE AND MAINTAIN TWELVE AGENCY-OWNED ARCHERY RANGES BY JUNE 30, 2023.RESULTS OR BENEFITS EXPECTED: INCREASE IN HUNTER/SHOOTER PROFICIENCY WITH FIREARMS AND ARCHERY EQUIPMENT, RETENTION OF CURRENT HUNTERS AND SHOOTERS, REACTIVATION OF FORMER HUNTERS AND SHOOTERS, INCREASED PUBLIC INTEREST IN SHOOTING SPORTS ACTIVITIES, INCREASE IN WOMEN AND MINORITY GROUPS IN SHOOTING SPORTS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: GENERAL PUBLIC, HUNTERS, RECREATIONAL SHOOTERSSUB-RECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE

THIS GRANT IS A SUB-AWARD FROM WDNR TO BARRON COUNTY FOR INSTALLATION OF SOUND BARRIERS AT THE OWNE-ANDERSON SHOOTING RANGE. BARRON COUNTY'S OWEN-ANDERSON RANGE IS A HEAVILY USED RANGE, BUT THE NOISE CARRIES TO THE NEIGHBORING PROPERTIES. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO REDUCE NOISE FROM THE RANGE, THEREBY ALLOWING THE COUNTY TO INCREASE OPERATING HOURS AND MAINTAIN A POSITIVE RELATIONSHIP WITH NEIGHBORING LANDOWNERS.

PROACTIVE RESEARCH CAN INFORM CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY PLANNING FOR MARINE MAMMALS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO 1) PLAN AND MANAGE THE MARINE MAMMAL PROGRAM, 2) PERFORM ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEWS ON PROPOSALS/PERMITS, 3) CONDUCT DIRECT RESEARCH ON POLAR BEARS AND COOK INLET BELUGAS, BOTH HIGH PRIORITY SPECIES (FIVE RESEARCH PROJECTS), AND 4) PROVIDE INFORMATION AND EXPERTISE TO STATE, NATIONAL, AND INTERNATIONAL ENTITIES FOR USE IN MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.

IN THE SPATIAL ANALYSIS PORTION OF THE PROGRAM, THE GIS ANALYST COORDINATES IMAGERY, WILDLIFE COLLAR LOCATIONS, AND OTHER DATA LAYERS FOR MAPPING PROJECTS, DATA ANALYSIS AND MODELING FOR WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AND RESEARCH, AND FIELD DATA COLLECTION SUPPORT THROUGH TOOL DEVELOPMENT AND APPLICATIONS. THIS WORK CONTRIBUTES TO WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT FOR HARVEST AND CONSERVATION FOR BOTH GAME AND NON-GAME SPECIES. ADDITIONALLY, IT SUPPORTS COMMUNICATIONS AND RESEARCH ON THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES.UNDER THE WILDLIFE HABITAT ENHANCEMENT SCOPE OF WORK, TEAM MEMBERS EVALUATE PROJECT PROPOSALS FOR FEASIBILITY, COORDINATE AND CONDUCT MONITORING BEFORE AND AFTER TREATMENTS, PLAN PROJECTS THROUGH INTERAGENCY PARTNERSHIPS, AND IMPLEMENT PROJECTS WITH AN INTERAGENCY GROUP. PROGRAM STAFF PARTICIPATE AT THE INTERAGENCY LEVEL STATEWIDE TO ENHANCE THE APPLICATION AND USE OF WILDLAND AND PRESCRIBED FIRE ALONG WITH MECHANICAL TREATMENTS FOR WILDLIFE HABITAT ENHANCEMENT. WHESAP STAFF ADVANCE SKILLS IN DATA ANALYSIS AND MODELING, GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS (GIS), FIRE MANAGEMENT OPERATIONS IN WILDLIFE, ECOLOGY, AND APPLICATIONS IN VEGETATION MANAGEMENT. BY PARTICIPATING IN ACTIVITIES OF THE FIRE MANAGEMENT, FORESTRY, WILDLIFE, AND FIRE SCIENCE COMMUNITIES, ADF&G CAN EFFECTIVELY CONTRIBUTE TOWARD AND SERVE IN COMPLIANCE WITH WILDLAND AND PRESCRIBED FIRE MANAGEMENT POLICIES, FOREST PRACTICES, AND DECISIONS THAT BENEFIT THE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES OF ALASKA.

CALIFORNIA IS HOME TO AN ESTIMATED 5,700 TULE ELK (CERVUS CANADENSIS NANNODES), 5,700 ROOSEVELT ELK (C. C.ROOSEVELTI), 1,500 ROCKY MOUNTAIN ELK (C. C. NELSONI), AND 4,000 PRONGHORN (ANTILOCAPRA AMERICANA) THAT PROVIDENUMEROUS RECREATIONAL AND ECONOMIC BENEFITS TO CALIFORNIANS. ALTHOUGH TULE ELK WERE ON THE BRINK OF EXTINCTIONAND ROOSEVELT ELK WERE NEARLY EXTIRPATED FROM CALIFORNIA, THEY HAVE MADE REMARKABLE RECOVERIES AND ALL THREESPECIES OF ELK IN CALIFORNIA ARE STABLE OR INCREASING IN NUMBER AND DISTRIBUTION. SIMULTANEOUSLY, PRONGHORNPOPULATIONS IN CALIFORNIA ARE DECREASING IN NUMBER AND POTENTIALLY IN DISTRIBUTION. CAUSES OF DIVERGENTPOPULATION TRAJECTORIES BETWEEN ELK AND PRONGHORN POPULATIONS IN NORTHERN CALIFORNIA REMAIN UNCLEAR BUT MAY BERELATED TO DIFFERENCES IN LIFE HISTORIES OF ELK AND PRONGHORN, INCLUDING DIFFERENCES IN BODY SIZE, PHYSIOLOGY,REPRODUCTIVE INVESTMENT, HABITAT USE, PREDATOR AVOIDANCE, AND OTHER BEHAVIORS. BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THEFACTORS UNDERPINNING ELK AND PRONGHORN POPULATION TRAJECTORIES, INFORMATION ON ABUNDANCE, DEMOGRAPHIC RATES,DISTRIBUTIONS, MOVEMENTS, POPULATION AGE STRUCTURES, AND HABITAT USE IS NEEDED.ADDITIONALLY, A NOVEL MANAGEMENT CONCERN AROSE FOR CALIFORNIA'S ELK POPULATIONS IN APRIL 2020, WHEN TREPONEMEASSOCIATEDHOOF DISEASE (TAHD) WAS DOCUMENTED IN ROOSEVELT ELK IN NORTHERN CALIFORNIA FOR THE FIRST TIME. TAHDAPPEARS TO BE A CONTAGIOUS INFECTIOUS DISEASE IN ELK AND HAS THE POTENTIAL TO SPREAD TO ELK HERDS THROUGHOUT THESTATE. ETIOLOGY, ECOLOGY, AND DISTRIBUTION OF TAHD IN CALIFORNIA'S ELK POPULATIONS IS POORLY UNDERSTOOD.FINALLY, CONNECTIVITY AMONG UNGULATE POPULATIONS AND BETWEEN SEASONAL RANGES OF MIGRATORY UNGULATES IS AN ISSUEOF EVER-INCREASING IMPORTANCE, PARTICULARLY AS THE FOOTPRINT OF HUMAN ACTIVITY INCREASES ACROSS THE LANDSCAPE.SECRETARIAL ORDER 3362 ENCOURAGES FEDERAL AGENCIES TO PARTNER WITH STATE AGENCIES TO IDENTIFY AND MAP IMPORTANTMOVEMENT CORRIDORS FOR UNGULATES, INCLUDING ELK AND PRONGHORN, IN THE WESTERN UNITED STATES, SO THAT THESECORRIDORS CAN BE PRIORITIZED FOR CONSERVATION.

OAK WOODLANDS ARE A KEY HABITAT FOR WILD TURKEYS IN EASTERN NEBRASKA, PROVIDING VITAL ROOSTING, FORAGING ANDNESTING SITES. NEBRASKA'S MOST EXPANSIVE OAK WOODLANDS OCCUR IN THE VALLEYS OF THE MISSOURI RIVER AND THE LOWERREACHES OF ITS LARGER TRIBUTARIES. AN ESTIMATED 20,000 TO 30,000 ACRES OF HIGHER-QUALITY OAK WOODLANDS REMAIN INTHIS REGION. UNFORTUNATELY, NEBRASKA'S OAK WOODLANDS ARE THREATENED BY LACK OF FIRE AND THE SUBSEQUENTPROLIFERATION OF SHADE-TOLERANT SHRUBS AND TREES, LACK OF OAK REGENERATION, AND INVASION BY EXOTIC PLANTS. ONLYTHROUGH ACTIVE MANAGEMENT CAN WE RESTORE THE ECOLOGICAL INTEGRITY OF OUR OAK WOODLANDS AND ENHANCE WILD TURKEYPOPULATIONS.

THIS TRAINING SHOULD IMPROVE THE SAFETY BEHAVIORS AND ATTITUDES OF NEWMEXICOS HUNTERS. THE DEPARTMENT IS ADDITIONALLY AUTHORIZED TO ADMINISTER THE MENTORED YOUTH HUNTING PROGRAM MY PROGRAM. THEMY PROGRAM PROVIDES A STRUCTURED MECHANISM TO ENABLE YOUTH 8 TO 17 YEARS OF AGE WHO ARE FIRST TIME HUNTERS, THE OPPORTUNITY TOEXPERIENCE HUNTING IN A SAFE, CONTROLLED, ENVIRONMENT WITH A LICENSED ADULT MENTOR WITHOUT FIRST HAVING PASSED A STATE CERTIFIEDHUNTER EDUCATION COURSE.
CPW ENERGY LIAISONS IN EACH OF THE FOUR REGIONS IN COLORADO WILL WORK WITH ENERGY COMPANIES TO ASSURE THAT THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL NOT IMPACT COLORADO WILDLIFE RESOURCES.
TO PROVIDE OUTREACH AND EDUCATION TO THE PUBLIC REGARDING HUNTING, TRAPPING, AND USE OF OUR WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS FOR HUNTING AND TRAPPING PURPOSES.

CARNIVORES AND FURBEARERS ARE IMPORTANT BIOLOGICAL, RECREATIONAL, AND ECONOMIC RESOURCES IN NEW MEXICO, AND THE NEW MEXICO DEPARTMENT OF GAME AND FISH IS RESPONSIBLE FOR SUSTAINING POPULATIONS OF THESE SPECIES FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE PUBLIC. IN ORDER TO ENSURE THE PERSISTENCE OF CARNIVORE POPULATIONS IT IS IMPORTANT TO CONDUCT RESEARCH AND MONITORING, COORDINATE WITH GOVERNMENTAL AND PRIVATE ENTITIES, AND CONTINUOUSLY MONITOR POPULATION AND HARVEST TRENDS. THESE ACTIVITIES PROVIDE SOUND BIOLOGICAL INFORMATION THAT INFORMS THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF APPROPRIATE REGULATIONS AND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES.

THIS PROPOSAL CONSISTS OF ONE COMPREHENSIVE PROJECT FOR EACH OF THE FIVE GAME SPECIES PROGRAMS CURRENTLY ADMINISTERED BY THE IOWA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (DNR): WHITE-TAILED DEER, FOREST WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT, FURBEARER MANAGEMENT, UPLAND WILDLIFE, AND MIGRATORY BIRDS. THE MAJORITY OF WORK DESCRIBED IN THIS PROPOSAL IS A CONTINUATION OF PRIOR GRANT EFFORTS.THE WILDLIFE BUREAU OF THE IOWA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES HAS STATUTORY AUTHORITY FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF ALL FISH AND WILDLIFE IN THE STATE. THIS RESPONSIBILITY AUTHORIZES THE IOWA DNR TO ORGANIZE AND PURSUE A PROGRAM OF RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT. THE WILDLIFE RESEARCH SECTION OF THE IOWA DNR HAS DEVELOPED A PROGRAM TO COORDINATE AND INFORM MANAGEMENT OF WILDLIFE IN IOWA. THESE PROGRAMS MAINLY INVOLVE THE COORDINATION AND EVALUATION OF SURVEYS TO DETERMINE POPULATION TRENDS AND MONITOR ANNUAL HARVEST, AS WELL AS CONDUCT RESEARCH TO INFORM POPULATION MODELING AS WELL AS HABITAT RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT. SURVEYS ARE THE PRIMARY METHOD BY WHICH THE IOWA DNR OBTAINS INFORMATION ON POPULATION TRENDS OF THESE SPECIES, THUS INFORMING ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS ON AN ANNUAL BASIS TO MAINTAIN, FOR EXAMPLE, A STABLE WHITE-TAILED DEER POPULATION WITHIN ESTABLISHED POPULATION GOALS. RESEARCH TO EVALUATE ESTABLISHED SURVEYS ENSURES THE IOWA DNR IS OBTAINING THE MOST RELIABLE INFORMATION TO MAKE DECISIONS.SOME OF THESE SPECIES HAVE HAD A RESTORATION PROGRAM IN IOWA, E.G. THE RIVER OTTER AND THE GREATER PRAIRIE CHICKEN, AMONG OTHERS. SINCE RESTORATION THESE SPECIES HAVE BEEN MANAGED IN CONSIDERATION OF THE SOCIAL CARRYING CAPACITY OF THE PEOPLE OF IOWA. MULTIPLE SURVEYS ARE CONDUCTED ALLOWING THE DEPARTMENT THE ABILITY TO MANAGE DYNAMIC POPULATIONS. WITHOUT THESE SURVEYS COORDINATED MANAGEMENT WOULD BE DIFFICULT IF NOT IMPOSSIBLE.EFFECTIVE AND ADAPTIVE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS REQUIRE CONSISTENT AND DETAILED INFORMATION FROM WHICH TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS. PERHAPS EQUALLY IMPORTANT, IT IS EXTREMELY BENEFICIAL TO SHARE TECHNICAL INFORMATION WITH THE PUBLIC, THE MEDIA, AND OTHER BIOLOGISTS.

PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE SAFE, CONSERVATION-MINDED HUNTING EXPERIENCES IN ARKANSAS.OBJECTIVES/DELIVERABLES:OBJECTIVE 1) TRAIN 100 NEW HUNTER EDUCATION VOLUNTEER INSTRUCTORS BY JUNE 30, 2023.OBJECTIVE 2) CONDUCT 400 INSTRUCTOR-LED TRAINING EVENTS BY JUNE 30, 2023.OBJECTIVE 3) CERTIFY 13,000 STUDENTS IN HUNTER EDUCATION BY JUNE 30, 2023.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: FEWER HUNTING INCIDENTS, A REDUCTION IN THE NUMBER OF WOUNDED GAME, INCREASE IN HUNTER SUCCESSES AND SATISFACTION, FEWER HUNTING REGULATION VIOLATIONS, INCREASE IN PARTICIPATION IN HUNTING, SHOOTING AND OTHER RELATED SKILLS, PUBLIC AWARENESS OF THE ROLE OF HUNTING IN CONSERVATION EFFORTS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: CITIZENS OF ARKANSAS THAT ARE REQUIRED TO TAKE HUNTER EDUCATIONSUB-RECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO CONSTRUCT A STORAGE BUILDING ON THE ABERDEEN GAME, FISH & PARKS (GFP) OFFICE COMPLEX IN ABERDEEN, SD. THIS STORAGE BUILDING IS NEEDED TO SUPPLY HABITAT MANAGEMENT, LAW ENFORCEMENT, AND WILDLIFE DAMAGE SECTIONS EACH STORAGE TO STORE WILDLIFE EQUIPMENT, INCREASE SECURITY, AND PREVENT WEATHER AND WATER DAMAGE OF EQUIPMENT AND GOODS. THE STORAGE SPACE SPLIT OF THE BUILDING WILL BE 60% HABITAT MANAGEMENT, AND 40% LAW ENFORCEMENT AND WILDLIFE DAMAGE MANAGEMENT. FEDERAL DOLLARS WILL ONLY BE USED FOR THE SPACE TO BE USED FOR HABITAT MANAGEMENT EQUIPMENT STORED IN THIS STORAGE FACILITY.

RIO GRANDE WILD TURKEYS (MELEAGRIS GALLOPAVO INTERMEDIA) HAVE EXPERIENCED CONSIDERABLE POPULATION VARIATION ACROSS PORTIONS OF TEXAS SINCE THE 1970S (BEASOM AND WILSON 1992, COLLIER ET AL. 2007). IN PARTICULAR, WILD TURKEY POPULATIONS IN THE ROLLING PLAINS OF TEXAS HAVE REMAINED DEPRESSED FOLLOWING THE INTERMEDIATE DROUGHT LASTING FROM 2010 TO 2014. WITHIN THE SEMI-ARID RANGELANDS OF THE WESTERN UNITED STATES, WILD TURKEY DISTRIBUTION IS STRICTLY DEPENDENT ON THE AVAILABILITY OF ROOSTING HABITAT. THUS, LOSS OR ALTERATION OF ROOSTING HABITAT IS OF INCREASING CONCERN DURING THE LAST DECADE DUE TO ITS POTENTIAL IMPACTS ON RIO GRANDE WILD TURKEYS IN THE ROLLING PLAINS (BEASOM AND WILSON 1992, SWEARINGIN ET AL. 2010A, WALKER ET AL. 2010). OUR PROPOSED WORK HAS THREE MAJOR AREAS FOCUSED ON ADDRESSING THE LOSS OF RIPARIAN CORRIDOR ROOSTING HABITATS IN THE ROLLING PLAINS. FIRST, WE WILL CLASSIFY LAND USE/LAND COVER (LULC) TO LINK WITH ROOST SITE LOCATION DATA OBTAINED FROM THREE AREAS OF THE ROLLING PLAINS FROM 2003-2006 (DATA PROVIDED BY TPWD PC) AND FROM ONE AREA IN THE ROLLING PLAINS FROM 2017-2018 TO MODEL AND VALIDATE ROOST SITE HABITAT ACROSS THE REGION. NEXT, WE WILL PREDICT AREAS OF POTENTIAL ROOSTING HABITAT FROM 2000 TO 2022 AND DETERMINE IF ROOSTING CONDITIONS ARE STABLE, INCREASING, DECREASING OR TRANSITIONING ACROSS THE ROLLING PLAINS. LAST, USING THE LULC DATA CLASSIFIED FOR ROOSTING HABITAT, WE WILL ASSESS HOW LULC HAS CHANGED FROM 2000 TO 2022 IN THE ROLLING PLAINS, AND WHAT IMPACTS LULC CHANGE HAS HAD ON AVAILABILITY OF ROOST CONDITIONS REQUIRED FOR WILD TURKEYS. LEVERAGING SPATIO-TEMPORAL TECHNIQUES TO DETERMINE WHEN, WHERE AND HOW HABITAT AND HABITAT FEATURES ARE CHANGING WILL HELP TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT MANAGE WILD TURKEY POPULATIONS BY IDENTIFYING AND PRIORITIZING AREAS IN NEED OF CONSERVATION INTERVENTION.

THE GA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, WILDLIFE RESOURCES DIVISION WILL ACQUIRE A CONSERVATION EASEMENT ON A 3,880ACRE TRACT ADJACENT TO THE CANOOCHEE SANDHILLS WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA. THIS ACQUISITION WILL EXPAND PUBLIC ACCESS FOR HUNTING AND OTHER WILDLIFE-ORIENTED RECREATION AND ALLOW FOR THE RESTORATION, CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF A VARIETY OF HABITAT TYPES INCLUDING BOTTOMLAND HARDWOOD FOREST, FORESTED DEPRESSIONAL WETLANDS, EARLY SUCCESSIONAL HABITATS, LONGLEAF PINE FOREST AND MIXED PINE FORESTS.

PURPOSE AND OBJECTIVE: TO MAINTAIN THE WMA SYSTEM AND PROVIDE ADDITIONAL PUBLIC HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES BY LEASING 289,457 ACRES UNTIL JUNE 30, 2023.EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THE LEASING OF PRIVATELY OWNED LAND ALLOWS THE COMMISSION TO PROVIDE THE PUBLIC WITH ADDITIONAL HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES. THESE LEASED LANDS OFFER THE PUBLIC A VARIETY OF HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES. LEASING LAND ALSO ALLOWS THE COMMISSION TO PROVIDE HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES IN AREAS OF THE STATE WHERE PUBLIC LANDS ARE LIMITED; THEREBY INCREASING HUNTING ACTIVITY IN THOSE AREAS AND BETTER MANAGING WILDLIFE POPULATIONS. LEASING LAND WITHIN OR ADJACENT TO COMMISSION-OWNED OR COOPERATIVELY MANAGED WMA'S WILL PROVIDE BETTER ACCESS TO THE AREA AND IMPROVE MANAGEMENT BY PROVIDING MORE CONTROL OVER THE LOCAL LANDSCAPE.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: GENERAL PUBLIC, ARKANSAS GAME AND FISH COMMISSIONSUB-RECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE
THIS ANNUAL GRANT PROJECT FUNDS ALL CPW ELK POPULATION MANAGEMENT AND RESEARCH WORK ACROSS THE STATE OF COLORADO.
THIS CPW GRANT PROJECT FUNDS ALL ANNUAL DEER POPULATION MANAGEMENT AND RESEARCH WORK IN COLORADO.
THIS GRANT FUNDS A MAJORITY OF THE ANNUAL CPW SMALL GAME CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING THE WALK IN ACCESS PROGRAM AND HUNTING SURVEYS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE INFORMATION THAT CAN AID IN EFFECTIVE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES FOR CONSERVATION PRIORITY BIRDS IN ILLINOIS. WE SEEK TO PROVIDE INFORMATION ON THE STATUS AND DISTRIBUTION OF PRIORITY SPECIES, HOW HABITAT USE OF THESE SPECIES INFLUENCES POTENTIAL MANAGEMENT APPROACHES, AND THE INFLUENCE OF SPECIFIC MANAGEMENT ACTIONS ON PRIORITY SPECIES .THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE DATA ON THE DISTRIBUTION, ABUNDANCE, AND DEMOGRAPHY OF SEVERAL AVIAN SPECIES OF CONSERVATION CONCERN, AS WELL AS INFORMATION ON HABITAT ATTRIBUTES ASSOCIATED WITH SUCCESSFUL POPULATIONS, AND RESPONSES TO SPECIFIC MANAGEMENT INTERVENTIONS. THESE RESULTS CAN BE USED TO TARGET FUTURE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES FOR THESE DECLINING SPECIES. UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS URBANA CHAMPAIGN IS AN EXPECTED SUB GRANTEE OF THIS PROJECT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS STUDY IS TO PROMOTE POPULATION GROWTH OF OSPREY IN ILLINOIS BY IMPLEMENTING HACKING TECHNIQUES. THIS STUDY WILL HELP RESTORE LOCAL BREEDING POPULATIONS OF OSPREY IN CENTRAL ILLINOIS AND ALSO ASSESS THE ADEQUACY AND EFFECTIVENESS OF HACKING TECHNIQUES TO RECOVER OSPREY POPULATIONS AT MULTIPLE SCALES. THE RESULTS FROM THIS STUDY ALSO CAN INFORM OSPREY RECOVERY NEEDS IN OTHER STATES, NATIONALLY, AND INTERNATIONALLY. UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS AT SPRINGFIELD IS AN EXPECTED SUBRECIPIENT OF THIS GRANT.

OVERALL, WE HAVE THREE MAIN RESEARCH OBJECTIVES:1. WE WILL MAINTAIN AN INTERDISCIPLINARY APPROACH TO DISEASE DIAGNOSTICS OF SICK, DEAD, OR DYING ILLINOIS WILDLIFE. 2. WE WILL SUSTAIN THE DIAGNOSTIC TESTING FOR THE SURVEILLANCE AND MANAGEMENT OF CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE (CWD).. 3. CWD RISK EVALUATION -SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL DISTRIBUTION OF CWD AND RELATED GENETIC FACTORS, EFFECTS OF CWD MANAGEMENT.WE EXPECT THAT THESE EFFORTS WILL FACILITATE IDENTIFICATION OF DISEASE OUTBREAKS, ALLOW CWD TO BE ADEQUATELY MONITORED IN IL, AND PROVIDE INFORMATION REGARDING THE EFFICIENCY OF CURRENT CWD MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES. UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS AT URBANA CHAMPAIGN IS AN EXPECTED SUBRECIPIENT OF THIS GRANT.

PURPOSE: TO OPERATE THE GAME CHECK SYSTEM FOR THE 2022 - 2023 DEER, TURKEY, ELK, AND BEAR SEASONS. HUNTERS ARE REQUIRED TO USE THE SYSTEM TO REPORT THEIR DEER, TURKEY, ELK, AND BEAR HARVESTS. BASED ON PRIOR YEAR HARVEST DATA, 200,000+ DEER, 10,000+ TURKEY, 75+ ELK, AND 400+ BEARS HARVEST REPORTS ARE ANTICIPATED.OBJECTIVES:OBJECTIVE 1: RECORD 200,000 DEER HARVESTS BY JUNE 30, 2023OBJECTIVE 2: RECORD 10,000 TURKEY HARVESTS BY JUNE 30, 2023OBJECTIVE 3: RECORD 75 ELK HARVESTS BY JUNE 30, 2023OBJECTIVE 4: RECORD 400 BEAR HARVESTS BY JUNE 30, 2023EXPECTED OUTCOMES:COLLECTING DEER, BEAR, ELK, AND TURKEY HARVEST DATA BY USING THE GAME CHECK SYSTEM WILL PROVIDE MORE TIMELY AND ACCURATE INFORMATION. COMMISSION BIOLOGISTS WILL USE THIS INFORMATION TO UNDERSTAND SPECIES POPULATION TRENDS AND HARVESTS AND TO GUIDE REGULATORY RECOMMENDATIONS ON SPECIES MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES. THIS INFORMATION WILL ALSO BE USED TO BETTER INFORM THE PUBLIC AND IMPROVE THEIR PARTICIPATION AT FUTURE PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT MEETINGS ON REGULATION AND SEASON PROPOSALS. COMMISSION STAFF AND THE PUBLIC WILL BE ABLE TO VIEW ACTUAL HARVEST DATA AS IT IS BEING REPORTED BY HUNTERS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: GENERAL PUBLIC, HUNTERS, ARKANSAS GAME AND FISH COMMISSIONSUB-RECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE

THIS GRANT IS CRUCIAL IN MEETING DEPARTMENT MISSION AND GOALS AND TO INSURE COMPLIANCE WITH STATE AND FEDERAL MANDATES. THROUGH THE COMMISSION, THE DEPARTMENT HAS THE RESPONSIBILITY, MANDATED BY STATUTE, TO PROTECT NEW MEXICO'S GAME WHILE PROVIDING AND MAINTAINING AN ADEQUATE SUPPLY FOR RECREATIONAL USE. THIS INCLUDES DEVELOPING RECOMMENDATIONS FOR HUNTER OPPORTUNITY, ENGAGING LANDOWNERS IN BIG GAME MANAGEMENT, CONDUCTING POPULATION SURVEYS, AND RESTORING POPULATIONS WHEN FEASIBLE.

THIS PROJECT WILL BE SUBAWARDED TO PROVIDE FUNDING FOR THE OKLAHOMA YOUTH HUNTING PROGRAM. FUNDING WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT INTRODUCTORY HUNTING TRIPS TO OKLAHOMA YOUTH HUNTERS AGES 12-17 AND THEIR FAMILIES. WHILE ONLY THE YOUTH HUNTER WILL HARVEST AN ANIMAL, THEIR FAMILY MEMBERS WILL BE PRESENT IN ORDER TO LEARN ABOUT AND EXPERIENCE A HUNTING TRIP. ALL YOUTH HUNTING PROGRAM EVENTS WILL INCLUDE AN EDUCATIONAL DAY WHERE THE YOUTH HUNTERS WILL LEARN SAFE GUN HANDLING, FENCE CROSSING, SAFE FIREARM CARRIES, FIELD DRESSING AND BUTCHERING AND HUNTER RESPONSIBILITY. 50 YOUTH HUNTERS AND THEIR FAMILIES WILL BE TRAINED EACH YEAR. IT IS EXPECTED THAT THIS WILL PROVIDE THESE FAMILIES WITH THE KNOWLEDGE THAT THEY NEED IN ORDER TO BE RECRUITED AS HUNTERS. THIS WILL BENEFIT ALL HUNTERS BY RECRUITING NEW HUNTERS AND PROVIDING MORE FUNDING FOR WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES.

OUR OVERALL PURPOSE IS TO INVESTIGATE THE ECOLOGY OF NONBREEDING DUCKS IN THE WABASH RIVER REGION OF ILLINOIS TO PROVIDE INFORMATION THAT GUIDES CONSERVATION EFFORTS AND FURTHERS UNDERSTANDING OF WATERFOWL-HABITAT RELATIONSHIPS. OUR EFFORTS TO INVESTIGATE FOOD RESOURCES FOR MIGRATING WATERFOWL IN THE WABASH RIVER REGION WILL PROVIDE CRITICAL INFORMATION TO UNDERSTAND THE IMPORTANCE OF THIS AREA TO STAGING WATERFOWL. DATA COLLECTED WILL BE USEFUL FOR GUIDING CONSERVATION PLANNING AND ALLOCATION OF RESOURCES FOR WETLAND ACQUISITION, RESTORATION, OR ENHANCEMENT IN THIS IMPORTANT ECOREGION. UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS URBANA CHAMPAIGN IS AN EXPECTED SUBGRANTEE FOR THIS PROJECT.

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO MONITOR THE ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF DOUBLE-CRESTED CORMORANTS (NANNOPTERUM AURITUM)AND OTHER PISCIVOROUS WATERBIRDS (E.G. CASPIAN TERN HYDROPROGNE CASPIA AND AMERICAN WHITE PELICAN PELECANUSERYTHRORHYNCHOS) WITHIN OREGON, AND ASSESS THEIR DIETS. WE WILL COLLECT INFORMATION TO EVALUATE TRENDS ANDLIMITING FACTORS FOR DOUBLE-CRESTED CORMORANTS AND OTHER PISCIVOROUS WATERBIRDS. WE WILL ALSO ASSESS THESIGNIFICANCE OF RECENT CHANGES IN THE STATEWIDE DOUBLE-CORMORANT POPULATION FOLLOWING IMPLEMENTATION OF A MAJORDOUBLE-CRESTED CORMORANT MANAGEMENT PLAN IN THE COLUMBIA RIVER ESTUARY.THIS PROJECT ALSO SEEKS TO FILL LONGSTANDING KNOWLEDGE GAPS CONCERNING THE ABUNDANCE, DISTRIBUTION, ANDPOPULATION DYNAMICS OF A VARIETY OF AVIAN SPECIES ALONG THE OREGON COAST. THIS INFORMATION IS ESPECIALLYNECESSARY CONSIDERING RECENT OBSERVED AND ANTICIPATED CHANGES IN OCEAN CONDITIONS THAT MAY DIRECTLY AFFECT AVIANSPECIES THROUGH CHANGES IN FOOD AVAILABILITY. SURVEY DATA WILL BE COLLECTED FOR A VARIETY OF AVIAN SPECIES,ENABLING A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF AVIAN USE OF ESTUARY HABITATS FOR FUTURE CONSERVATION PLANNING.

THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO PROVIDE DATA ON RINGTAIL ECOLOGY, AND CURRENT RINGTAIL DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE INA SOUTHERN OREGON STUDY AREA WHILE DEVELOPING A PROVEN SURVEY PROTOCOL.THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (ODFW) TO DEVELOP A POPULATION ESTIMATE, SUITABLEHABITAT DISTRIBUTION MAP AND A SURVEY TECHNIQUE FOR MANAGEMENT OF RINGTAIL POPULATIONS IN SOUTHERN OREGON. DATANEEDED FOR MANAGEMENT OF RINGTAIL POPULATIONS IN SOUTHERN OREGON WILL BE GREATLY ENHANCED BY THE RESULTS OF THISSTUDY. THE RESULTS OF THIS STUDY ALSO HAVE MANAGEMENT IMPLICATIONS TO OTHER STATE WILDLIFE AGENCIES THAT HAVERINGTAIL POPULATIONS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO EVALUATE COMPONENTS OF DEER POPULATIONS THAT USE DESIGNATED WINTER RANGE INSOUTHERN OREGON. SPECIFIC STUDY COMPONENTS ARE DEER MOVEMENTS AND USE OF MIGRATION CORRIDORS, WINTER RANGE USE,POPULATION DENSITY, SURVIVAL, CAUSES OF MORTALITY AND CONTRIBUTIONS TO HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES WITHIN THE WMUS.SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE: (1)DOCUMENT BLACK-TAILED DEER POPULATION DYNAMICS IN A DESIGNATED WINTERRANGE STUDY AREA OF SOUTHERN OREGON. (2)DOCUMENT HOME RANGE SIZE, WINTER RANGE USE, MIGRATION PATTERNS, ANDMIGRATION HABITAT CORRIDORS OF BLACK-TAILED DEER ASSOCIATED WITH DESIGNATED WINTER RANGES OF SOUTHERN OREGON.THIS DATA IS NEEDED FOR MANAGEMENT OF BLACK-TAILED DEER POPULATIONS. MANAGEMENT DECISIONS CAN BE BASED ON DATAPROVIDED BY THIS RESEARCH AND VALIDATED THROUGH STATISTICAL ANALYSIS. THE RESULTS OF THIS STUDY HAVEIMPLICATIONS TO OTHER STATE WILDLIFE AGENCIES IN THEIR BLACK-TAILED DEER MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS. SUCCESSFULCOMPLETION OF THE PROJECT WILL ALLOW ODFW TO DEVELOP APPROPRIATE RECOMMENDATIONS AND POLICES FOR MANAGEMENT OFBLACK-TAILED DEER POPULATIONS IN WESTERN OREGON.

OUR PURPOSE IS TO STUDY BOBCAT ECOLOGY IN NORTH-CENTRAL ILLINOIS TO PROVIDE INFORMATION TO SUPPORT WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT. EXPECTED PROJECT OUTPUTS INCLUDE: (1) REPORTS TO THE IDNR WITH DETAILED INFORMATION ABOUT PROGRESS TOWARD COMPLETING/COMPLETION OF STUDY OBJECTIVES, AND (2) SUBMISSION OF SEVERAL MANUSCRIPTS TO APPROPRIATE PEER-REVIEWED JOURNALS. RESEARCH RESULTS AND MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS WILL BE COMMUNICATED TO THE IDNR VIA ADDITIONAL WRITTEN REPORTS, ORAL PRESENTATIONS, AND MEETINGS WITH IDNR STAFF. RESULTS FROM THESE STUDIES, ALONG WITH OTHER AVAILABLE INFORMATION, MAY GENERATE NEW PROGRAMS OR REFINEMENT OF EXISTING PROGRAMS. SOUTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY AT CARBONDALE IS AN EXPECTED SUB GRANTEE OF THIS PROJECT.

THIS PROJECT'S PURPOSE IS TO STUDY FURBEARERS AND NON-GAME WILDLIFE IN ILLINOIS TO PROVIDE INFORMATION TO SUPPORT WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT. THESE SPECIES INCLUDE BOBCATS, RIVER OTTERS, GRAY FOX, AND, RACCOON.IN GENERAL, THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION THAT BIOLOGISTS CAN USE TO MANAGE AND MONITOR FURBEARER AND NON-GAME WILDLIFE POPULATIONS IN ILLINOIS. STUDIES WILL PROVIDE IMPORTANT INFORMATION ON POPULATION DYNAMICS AND RESPONSE TO HARVEST, SPACE USE AND SURVIVAL RATES, PATHOGENS, OCCUPANCY, AND RESPONSE TO PREDATOR CONTROL.SOUTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY AT CARBONDALE IS AN EXPECTED SUBRECIPIENT OF THIS AWARD.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE'S (CDFW) INLAND DESERTS REGION (IDR) LANDS NORTH PROGRAM ISRESPONSIBLE FOR MANAGING APPROXIMATELY 100,000 ACRES OF ECOLOGICAL RESERVES AND WILDLIFE AREAS. THE AREAS INCLUDEDIVERSE HABITATS FROM DESERT SCRUB TO GREAT BASIN SCRUB TO MONTANE MEADOWS WHICH SUPPORT A WIDE ARRAY OF FISH,WILDLIFE, AND PLANT SPECIES. THESE LANDS ALSO PROVIDE WILDLIFE VIEWING, FISHING, AND HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES FORTHE GENERAL PUBLIC.

THE STATE CONTINUES TO HAVE A NEED FOR MORE QUALITY, CLEAN, FAMILY FRIENDLY PUBLIC SHOOTING RANGES. WITH THE EXPANSION AND FACILITY IMPROVEMENTS OF EXISTING PUBLIC RANGES AND THE POSSIBILITY OF OPENING NEW PUBLIC RANGES WE HOPE TO SEE AN INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF LIVE FIRE OPPORTUNITIES IN OUR HUNTER EDUCATION CLASSES AND INCREASED PARTICIPATION IN SHOOTING SPORTS AND TARGET SHOOTING IN GENERAL. THE FEDERAL FUNDING FOR THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED AS A SUPPLEMENT FOR PUBLIC SHOOTING RANGE RELATED IMPROVEMENTS THAT WILL BENEFIT THE HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM. IT WILL ALSO INCREASE SHOOTING OPPORTUNITIES FOR HUNTERS AND SHOOTERS IN GENERAL.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT PROPOSAL IS TO IMPROVE COMMUNICATION WITH AND INCREASE AWARENESS OF OUTDOOR OPPORTUNITIES FOR OKLAHOMANS IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE MISSIONS OF THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION (ODWC) AND THE NATIONAL WILD TURKEY FEDERATION (NWTF). SPECIFICALLY, THE PARTIES TO THIS AGREEMENT INTEND TO PROVIDE THE PUBLIC OF OKLAHOMA WITH OPPORTUNITIES TO USE AND APPRECIATE THE NATURAL RESOURCES OF OKLAHOMA. THIS AGREEMENT ADDRESSES AN INCREASED NEED FOR PARTNERSHIPS THAT FOCUS ON PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE PUBLIC OF OKLAHOMA TO POSITIVELY EXPERIENCE THE GREAT OUTDOORS. THE PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITY FOR THIS POSITION WILL BE TO DEVELOP A FOCUSED LEARN TO HUNT SYSTEM THROUGH A COMPREHENSIVE PLAN TO FOCUS ON RECRUITING, RETAINING, AND REACTIVATING (R3) HUNTERS THROUGH COORDINATED EFFORTS BETWEEN MULTIPLE DIVERSE GROUPS.

WILDLIFE SURVEYS AND INVENTORIES ARE ESSENTIAL ACTIVITIES FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF THE STATE'S NATURAL RESOURCES BYTHE NEBRASKA GAME & PARKS COMMISSION. NEBRASKA IS BLESSED WITH ABUNDANT WILDLIFE, FROM VERY POPULAR GAME SPECIESTO CONTINENTALLY IMPORTANT POPULATIONS OF MIGRANT BIRDS TO NATIONALLY IMPORTANT THREATENED AND ENDANGEREDSPECIES. THE STARTING POINT FOR MANAGING THIS PRECIOUS HERITAGE IS AN INFORMED PERSPECTIVE ON THE ABUNDANCE,DISTRIBUTION, AND POPULATION TRENDS FOR EVERY SPECIES CONCERNED. IN SOME CASES, WE HAVE CONDUCTED SURVEYS FORMANY YEARS WITHOUT SUBSTANTIAL CHANGES, WHILE IN OTHERS WE ARE IMPLEMENTING NEW SURVEYS TO EITHER (1) BROADEN OURSCOPE AND BRING IN SPECIES NOT PREVIOUSLY CONSIDERED OR (2) DEEPEN OUR KNOWLEDGE OF SPECIES MONITORED IN THEPAST. BECAUSE OF THE STATE'S SIZE, THE WIDE-SPREAD DISTRIBUTION OF DIVERSE WILDLIFE THROUGHOUT IT, AND THEPREDOMINANTLY PRIVATE OWNERSHIP OF WILDLIFE HABITAT (LESS THAN 3% OF THE STATE IS IN PUBLIC OWNERSHIP), OURSURVEY AND MONITORING ACTIVITIES EMPHASIZE TECHNIQUES THAT CAN BE EFFICIENTLY EMPLOYED OVER A LARGE AREA, WITHPUBLIC COOPERATION WHENEVER BENEFICIAL, AND DESIGNED TO PROVIDE USEFUL INFORMATION ON SEVERAL WILDLIFE SPECIESSIMULTANEOUSLY WHEN POSSIBLE.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE REQUIRED HUNTER EDUCATION COURSES AND SHOOTING SPORTS OPPORTUNITIES TO THE PUBLIC AS WELL AS ACCESS TO RANGE AND EDUCATIONAL FACILITY THROUGH OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF EXISTING RANGES AND DEVELOPMENT OF NEW RANGES. THIS PROGRAM IS EXPECTED TO RECRUIT NEW HUNTERS AND INCREASE WILDLIFE CONSERVATION MANAGEMENT AND AWARENESS.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) ESTABLISHED THE SAN FELIPE VALLEY WILDLIFE AREA COMPLEX(SFVWAC) IN NORTHEASTERN SAN DIEGO COUNTY IN 1995 TO CONSERVE AND ENHANCE KEY HABITAT FOR SOUTHERN MULE DEER. KEYHABITATS ON SFVWA INCLUDE RIPARIAN WOODLAND, OAK WOODLAND, MIXED HARDWOOD-CONIFER FOREST, AND NATIVE GRASSLAND. ASECONDARY PURPOSE FOR ESTABLISHING SFVWA WAS TO ALLOW COMPATIBLE WILDLIFE DEPENDENT PUBLIC USE WHILE PROVIDINGACCESS TO APPROXIMATELY 19,800 ACRES OF ADJACENT FEDERAL BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT (BLM) LANDS. EXPANSION OF THESFVWA IS ON-GOING WITH PREVIOUS LAND ACQUISITIONS RESULTING IN TWO SEPARATE MANAGEMENT UNITS TOTALING 17,794ACRES. THESE INCLUDE THE 14,449-ACRE SFVWA UNIT AND THE 3,244-ACRE OAK GROVE (OG) UNIT. COLLECTIVELY THESE UNITSARE REFERRED TO AS THE SAN FELIPE VALLEY WILDLIFE AREA COMPLEX (SFVWAC). IN 2003, CDFW BEGAN ACQUIRING LANDSKNOWN AS THE HOLLENBECK CANYON WILDLIFE AREA (HCWA) (ATTACHMENT A) TO PROTECT, CONSERVE AND ENHANCE THE UPLANDAND RIPARIAN HABITATS PRESENT ON THE AREA AND THE SPECIES ASSOCIATED WITH THE VARIOUS HABITATS FOUND ON THE AREA.HCWA CURRENTLY CONSISTS OF APPROXIMATELY 6,927 ACRES WITH KEY HABITATS INCLUDING RIPARIAN WOODLAND, COASTAL SAGESCRUB, MIXED CHAPARRAL, AND NATIVE GRASSLAND. SECONDARILY, HCWA WAS ACQUIRED TO PROVIDE FOR COMPATIBLE, WILDLIFEDEPENDENTRECREATION, INCLUDING HUNTING, WILDLIFE OBSERVATION, AND A VARIETY OF NATURE STUDY USES. SINCE THE AREAWAS ACQUIRED, THE CDFW AND ITS PARTNERS HAVE RESTORED RIPARIAN AND GRASSLAND AREAS TO BENEFIT UPLAND GAMESPECIES, RAPTORS, SONGBIRDS, AND LARGE MAMMALS. SINCE ESTABLISHMENT OF THE SFVWAC AND HWAC, THE CDFW AND ITSPARTNERS HAVE RESTORED WATER SOURCES, REMOVED WILDLIFE HAZARDS, IMPROVED EXISTING INFRASTRUCTURE, AND ENHANCEDNATIVE HABITATS TO BENEFIT MULE DEER AND OTHER GAME AND NON-GAME SPECIES.

THE LOUISIANA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND FISHERIES (LDWF) ASSUMES THE RESPONSIBILITY OF MANAGING LOUISIANA'S WILD BIRD AND MAMMAL POPULATIONS AND THEIR HABITAT TO PROVIDE WILDLIFE DEPENDED RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT:* COORDINATION-WILDLIFE RESTORATION FUNDED GRANTS* RESEARCH-SPECIES, HABITAT, AND POPULATION MANAGEMENT* TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE-PRIVATE LANDS* OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE-ON THE DEPARTMENTS FIFTY-SIX (56) WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS (WMA'S), REFUGES, AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AREAS, ENCOMPASSING ROUGHLY 1.40 MILLION ACRES

THE STATEWIDE TECHNICAL GUIDANCE PROJECT PROVIDES DIRECT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO PRIVATE PROPERTY OWNERS, OTHERODFW STAFF, AND STAFF OF OTHER LOCAL, STATE, AND FEDERAL AGENCIES TO PROMOTE PROGRAMS AND PROJECTS THAT AREEFFECTIVE IN MAINTAINING, ENHANCING, OR RESTORING FUNCTIONAL WILDLIFE HABITATS. STAFF FUNDED THROUGH THISPROJECT DEVELOP ODFW POLICY POSITIONS, AND COORDINATE PARTICIPATION IN LOCAL, STATE, AND FEDERAL LAND MANAGEMENTACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH ENERGY, FORESTRY, LAND USE, MINING, WETLAND AND WATERWAY DEVELOPMENT INCLUDING INWATEREXPLOSIVE PERMITS, AND TWO STATE LANDOWNER INCENTIVE PROGRAMS.

TO INVESTIGATE AND ASSESS THE CONSERVATION STATUS OF NONGAME MAMMALS TO ENSURE THE CONTINUING RECOVERY, LISTING, DELISTING, ETC. OF NONGAME MAMMALS LISTED UNDER THE NEW MEXICO WILDLIFE CONSERVATION ACT (WCA), THE STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN OR AS FEDERALLY ENDANGERED OR THREATENED BY THE FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE) UNDER THE U.S. ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA).

ONCE PREVALENT THROUGHOUT THE AMERICAN SOUTHWEST, THE MEXICAN GRAY WOLF WAS NEARLY EXTINCT BY THE 1970S. IN 1976, THIS SPECIES WAS LISTED AS ENDANGERED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT OF 1973. IN NOVEMBER OF 2019, THE NEW MEXICO DEPARTMENT OF GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT AGREED TO BE ONE OF SEVERAL LEAD AGENCIES TO ASSIST IN THE RECOVERY OF THESE ANIMALS. AS SUCH, THE DEPARTMENT HAS ALLOCATED STAFF TO PARTICIPATE ON A TECHNICAL COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE AND ASSESS THE CONSERVATION STATUS, DEVELOP OPERATIONAL RECOMMENDATIONS, COORDINATE AND IMPLEMENT ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THE MANAGEMENT OF WOLVES IN NEW MEXICO PER PROTOCOL AND POLICY.

BASIC HUNTER EDUCATION: THE HUNTER INFORMATION & TRAINING (HIT) PROGRAM DEVELOPS, MAINTAINS, ANDPROVIDES EFFECTIVE TRAINING TO PROMOTE FIREARMS SAFETY, KNOWLEDGE, AND ETHICS TO YOUTH AND ADULTS TOBECOME RESPONSIBLE HUNTERS AND SHOOTING SPORTS ENTHUSIASTS. THE FOLLOWING CERTIFICATION COURSES ARETAUGHT BY OVER 400 VOLUNTEER INSTRUCTORS STATEWIDE: HUNTER EDUCATION, BOWHUNTER EDUCATION, CROSSBOWEDUCATION, AND MUZZLELOADER EDUCATION. THESE COURSES ASSIST IN TEACHING THE SKILLS, KNOWLEDGE, ANDATTITUDES NECESSARY TO BE A SAFE, RESPONSIBLE HUNTER. THE HIT PROGRAM IS ALSO ACTIVELY INVOLVED IN OUTDOORRECREATION PROGRAMS DESIGNED TO RECRUIT AND RETAIN NEW HUNTERS INTO THE SHOOTING SPORTS AND PRESERVEOUR HUNTER HERITAGE.THE EXPECTED RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO:1. INCREASE THE SAFE HANDLING OF FIREARMS AND REDUCE HUNTING-RELATED FIREARMS INCIDENTS.2. RAISE AWARENESS OF THE NEED TO HUNT IN A SAFE, LEGAL, ETHICAL, AND RESPONSIBLE MANNER.3. ENHANCE PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT.4. ENCOURAGE LIFELONG LEARNING AND OUTDOOR PARTICIPATION AMONG HUNTERS AND SHOOTING SPORTS ENTHUSIASTS.ENHANCED HUNTER EDUCATION: HUNTERS AND SHOOTING SPORTS ENTHUSIASTS PLAY A HUGE ROLE IN WILDLIFECONSERVATION BY PROVIDING FUNDING FOR WILDLIFE RESTORATION AND HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAMS THROUGH THEPURCHASE OF LICENSES, FIREARMS, AMMUNITION, AND ARCHERY EQUIPMENT. THEREFORE, INCREASING HUNTER ANDSHOOTING SPORTS PARTICIPATION IS IMPORTANT TO THE HUNTER INFORMATION & TRAINING (HIT) PROGRAM. THEPURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO OFFER ENHANCED PROGRAMS FOR HUNTER EDUCATION, HUNTER DEVELOPMENT, ANDFIREARM AND ARCHERY SAFETY WHICH WILL INTRODUCE INDIVIDUALS TO AND RECRUIT THEM TO TAKE PART IN HUNTING,TARGET SHOOTING, AND ARCHERY. THESE ENHANCEMENT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO HIT PROGRAMALASKANS AFIELD CLINICS, THE NATIONAL ARCHERY IN THE SCHOOLS PROGRAM (NASP), THE BECOMING AN OUTDOORSWOMAN (BOW) PROGRAM, YOUTH CONSERVATION CAMPS, YOUTH SHOOTING LEAGUES, AND OUTREACH EVENTS.THESE ENHANCED PROGRAMS HAVE HAD A SIGNIFICANT IMPACT ON INTRODUCING NEW, YOUNG PEOPLE TO OUTDOORACTIVITIES. MANY OF THE ACTIVITIES PROVIDE SAFE FIREARMS INSTRUCTION, AND MANY PARTICIPANTS MOVE FROMSHOOTING TARGETS INTO HUNTING AS THEY LOOK FOR ADDITIONAL CHALLENGES AND ENJOYMENT OF THE OUTDOORS.THE EXPECTED RESULTS AND BENEFITS FROM THIS PROJECT INCLUDE:1. ENCOURAGE PEOPLE TO TAKE GREATER ADVANTAGE OF HUNTING AND SHOOTING OPPORTUNITIES.2. EMBOLDEN PEOPLE TO GET THEIR WHOLE FAMILIES INVOLVED IN HUNTING, AND PROVIDE THEM WITH GREATERKNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS TO MAKE THEM SAFER AND MORE RESPONSIBLE HUNTERS.

THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME (ADF&G) OPERATES, MAINTAINS, AND ENHANCES THREE PUBLIC TARGET RANGES. THETWO INDOOR RANGES ARE LOCATED IN FAIRBANKS (FAIRBANKS HUNTER EDUCATION INDOOR SHOOTING RANGE) AND JUNEAU (JUNEAUHUNTER EDUCATION SHOOTING COMPLEX). THE OUTDOOR RANGE IS LOCATED IN ANCHORAGE (RABBIT CREEK SHOOTING PARK). THETHREE RANGES PROVIDE SAFE AND USER-FRIENDLY FACILITIES FOR HUNTERS, TARGET SHOOTERS, AND SHOOTING SPORTSENTHUSIASTS. THE FACILITIES ALSO SERVE AS THE PRIMARY SUPPORT FACILITIES FOR ALL CERTIFICATION CLASSES ANDHUNTING/SHOOTING SPORTS PUBLIC EDUCATION OPPORTUNITIES IN THEIR SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES.THE EXPECTED RESULTS AND BENEFITS OF THIS PROJECT ARE:1. SAFE AND GEOGRAPHICALLY CONVENIENT RANGE FACILITIES FOR HUNTERS AND TARGET SHOOTERS.2. TRAINED STAFF WHO WILL ENSURE THE SAFETY OF RANGE USERS AND WHO WILL MAINTAIN THE FACILITIES.3. ENCOURAGE LIFELONG PARTICIPATION IN THE SHOOTING SPORTS.

REFUGES AND SANCTUARIES VIEWING, EDUCATION, AND MANAGEMENT SUPPORTS THE MISSION OF THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISHAND GAME - DIVISION OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION (DWC) TO PROVIDE LONG-TERM OPPORTUNITIES FOR PEOPLE TO USE AND ENJOYALASKA'S FISH, WILDLIFE, AND HABITAT RESOURCES.PROJECT 31.0 CREAMER'S/MINTO FLATS REFUGES 1) MANAGES BOTH REFUGES TO MEET LEGISLATIVE MANDATES AND PROTECTS ANDENHANCES WILDLIFE HABITATS AND POPULATIONS; 2) ALLOWS FOR PUBLIC USES SUCH AS HUNTING, TRAPPING, FISHING,WILDLIFE VIEWING, AND NATURE STUDY; 3) MANAGES BOTH REFUGES TO PROMOTE COMPATIBLE WILDLIFE-RELATED USES THROUGHEDUCATION AND OUTREACH; AND 4) SUPPORTS THE FARMING PROGRAM AT CFMWR, DIRECTLY PROVIDING HABITAT COMPONENTS FORMIGRATORY WATERFOWL AND OTHER WILDLIFE SPECIES.PROJECT 32.0 SANCTUARY AND REFUGE FIELD OPERATION IN REGIONS 1, 2, 4, AND 5 OPERATES THE DEPARTMENT'S VISITOR USEAND WILDLIFE MONITORING FIELD PROGRAMS AT MCNEIL RIVER, WALRUS ISLANDS AND STAN PRICE STATE GAME SANCTUARIES; ASWELL AS THE ANCHORAGE COASTAL WILDLIFE REFUGE AND OTHER REFUGE AREAS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS RECURRING 1-YEAR PROJECT IS TO: 1) MEASURE AND INTERPRET CHANGES IN THE STATUS AND USE OFALASKA'S HARVESTED WILDLIFE POPULATIONS IN REGION I AND TO PROVIDE THAT INFORMATION TO THE PUBLIC, 2) CONDUCTWORK FOCUSED ON MONITORING POPULATION ABUNDANCE AND TRENDS, HABITAT CONDITION, DISTRIBUTION, SEX AND AGECOMPOSITION, RECRUITMENT, PRODUCTIVITY, MORTALITY, AND HUNTING EFFORT AND HARVEST, 3) ENSURE REGION I STAFF HAVETHE FUNDING, FACILITIES AND TOOLS NEEDED TO ACCOMPLISH THE NECESSARY WORK, AND 4) SUPPORT THIS WORK THROUGHOVERSIGHT, MANAGEMENT, WILDLIFE INFORMATION AWARENESS AND DISSEMINATION, AND REPORTING OF THE DIVISION'S FEDERALAID WILDLIFE RESTORATION (WR)-FUNDED PROGRAMS EACH STATE FISCAL YEAR.THE OVERALL GOAL OF THESE EFFORTS IS TO GATHER AND DISSEMINATE INFORMATION AND ADMINISTER PROGRAMS NEEDED TO MANAGE ALASKA'S WILDLIFE RESOURCES FOR SUSTAINABLE HARVEST AND OTHER BENEFICIAL USES BY THE PUBLIC.

ALASKA'S WILDLIFE SPECIES HAVE CONSUMPTIVE AND NON-CONSUMPTIVE USES AND MUST BE SUSTAINABLY MANAGED WHEN THE DEMAND FOR HARVEST EXCEEDS THAN THE NUMBER OF ANIMALS AVAILABLE FOR HARVEST. SUCCESSFUL MANAGEMENT REQUIRES UP-TO-DATE INFORMATION ON ABUNDANCE, PRODUCTIVITY, RECRUITMENT, AND SURVIVAL OF EACH POPULATION. THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH & GAME (DEPARTMENT), DIVISION OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION (DWC) REGULARLY MONITORS WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND THE FACTORS AFFECTING STATUS FOR SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT. POPULATIONS ARE INFLUENCED BY FACTORS SUCH AS WINTER SEVERITY, PREDATION, DISEASE, HABITAT CHANGE, WEATHER CONDITIONS, DEVELOPMENT, AND HUMAN USE OF OUR NATURAL RESOURCES THAT ACT INDEPENDENTLY OR IN CONCERT. PLANNING, COORDINATION, AND OUTREACH ARE NEEDED TO BETTER INFORM PROGRAMMATIC DEVELOPMENT AND DECISIONS TO ACHIEVE DWC'S MISSION TO CONSERVE AND ENHANCE ALASKA'S WILDLIFE AND HABITATS AND PROVIDE FOR A WIDE RANGE OF PUBLIC USES AND BENEFITS.

THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH & GAME (DEPARTMENT), DIVISION OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION (DWC) REGULARLY MONITORS WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND THE FACTORS AFFECTING STATUS TO SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT. THE DIVISION OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION IS COMPRISED OF FIVE ADMINISTRATIVE REGIONS AND SEVERAL STATEWIDE PROGRAMS THAT ARE MOST EFFECTIVEWHEN THEY WORK TOGETHER TO MAINTAIN CONSISTENCY AND ADDRESS COMMON ISSUES. DWC IS REQUIRED TO IMPLEMENT FEDERALAID PROGRAMS IN ACCORDANCE THE APPLICABLE FEDERAL LAWS. DWC'S REGION 5 INCLUDES GAME MANAGEMENT UNITS 18, 22, 23AND 26A, WHICH ARE MANAGED BY STAFF IN THE NOME REGIONAL OFFICE AND AREA OFFICES IN BETHEL, NOME, KOTZEBUE ANDUTQIAGVIK (BARROW).THE WESTERN AND NORTHWEST ARCTIC REGION OF ALASKA (REGION 5) WILDLIFE SURVEY AND INVENTORY PROGRAM AND MANAGEMENT & RESEARCH COORDINATION GRANT SUPPORTS WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AND WILDLIFE-RELATED RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIESTHROUGH STAFF AND PROJECT FUNDING. IT FUNDS THE STAFF AND DATA COLLECTION TO ENSURE THE CONSERVATION, PROTECTION,AND MANAGEMENT OF WILDLIFE TO PROVIDE SUSTAINABLE POPULATIONS FOR HUNTING, TRAPPING, AND OTHER WILDLIFE-BASEDUSER OPPORTUNITIES. THE GRANT FUNDS MONITORING OF POPULATIONS THROUGH CAPTURE, RADIO-MARKING, AND GPS/TELEMETRYMONITORING TO ASSESS SURVIVAL AND DISTRIBUTION; AERIAL AND GROUND-BASED SURVEYS TO ASSESS POPULATION COMPOSITION,SIZE, AND TREND; AND ESTIMATION AND MONITORING OF HARVEST. IT PROVIDES RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITY, AND FUNDS STAFFPARTICIPATION IN TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND MANAGEMENT PLANNING. PLANNING AND COORDINATION ARE NEEDED TO BETTERINFORM PROGRAMMATIC DEVELOPMENT AND DECISIONS TO ACHIEVE DWC'S MISSION TO CONSERVE AND ENHANCE ALASKA'S WILDLIFEAND HABITATS AND PROVIDE FOR A WIDE RANGE OF PUBLIC USES AND BENEFITS. THIS INCLUDES ENSURING THAT AREA OFFICESAND FACILITIES ARE OPERATED AND MAINTAINED EFFICIENTLY AND EFFECTIVELY, INCLUDING PROPER MAINTENANCE OF LABS,VEHICLES, AND EQUIPMENT; PROVIDING BIOMETRIC AND COMPUTER SOFTWARE SUPPORT WHERE NEEDED TO ENSURE SOUND STUDIES,INTERPRETATION AND DISSEMINATION OF RESULTS, AND MANAGEMENT ACTIONS; AND PLANNING FOR MANAGEMENT AND RESEARCH.

CREATING AND MAINTAINING ACCESS IS THE MOST IMPORTANT FACTOR ASSOCIATED WITH PARTICIPATION AND IS A CRITICAL NEED OVER WHICH AGENCIES CAN HAVE AN IMPORTANT INFLUENCE (RESPONSIVE MANAGEMENT/NSSF, 2008). RESEARCH SHOWS THAT ACCESS PLAYS A KEY ROLE IN PARTICIPATION AND IS ONE OF THE LEADING REASONS FOR DISSATISFACTION AND DESERTION AMONG HUNTERS AND ANGLERS. STATE-SPONSORED HUNTING AND FISHING ACCESS PROGRAMS ARE CONSIDERED SOME OF THE MOST EFFECTIVE PROGRAMS/RESOURCES FOR FACILITATING ACCESS (RESPONSIVE MANAGEMENT/NSSF, 2011), AND CAN ALSO MAINTAIN AND/OR INCREASE LANDOWNER PARTICIPATION. THIS GRANT IS NEEDED TO IMPROVE HUNTING, FISHING AND TRAPPING ACCESS TO PRIVATE LANDS IN A MANNER THAT IS BENEFICIAL TO THE LANDOWNERS AND SPORTSMEN THROUGH EFFECTIVE ADMINISTRATION OF THE OPEN GATE PROGRAM.

THE NORTHERN REGION OF THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) COMPRISES THE NINE NORTHERN MOST COUNTIES IN THE STATE. WITHIN THIS AREA, CDFW'S NORTHERN REGION WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (NRWMP) IS RESPONSIBLE FOR ASSESSING THE CONDITION OF WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND HABITATS, MANAGING AND CONSERVING GAME BIRDS AND GAME MAMMALS, PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO OTHER AGENCIES, AND PROVIDING INFORMATION TO THE PUBLIC ABOUT GAME SPECIES.PROJECTS IMPLEMENTED BY NORTHERN REGION GRANT STAFF COMPLEMENT THOSE OF OTHER CDFW REGIONS AND HEADQUARTERS BUT ARE NOT DUPLICATED GEOGRAPHICALLY BY EITHER STATE OR FEDERAL ASSISTANCE FUNDS UNDER THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION/ PITTMAN-ROBERTSON ACT (WR). THEY ARE CONDUCTED TO IMPLEMENT THE CDFW'S TRUSTEE RESPONSIBILITIES FOR RESOURCES AND REQUIRE EXTENSIVE COMMUNICATION AND COORDINATION WITH OTHER AGENCIES, CDFW HEADQUARTERS PROGRAMS, REGIONAL CDFW STAFF, AND THE PUBLIC. THE GRANT FUNDS REQUESTED WILL SUPPORT IMPORTANT PROJECTS CONSISTENT WITH THE WR AND CARRIED OUT BY 11 PROGRAM STAFF.

THE IDR'S WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (IDRWP) IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS OF DATA REGARDINGTHE CONDITION OF WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND HABITATS, MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF MAMMALS, PROVIDING TECHNICALASSISTANCE TO OTHER AGENCIES REGARDING RESOURCE ISSUES, AND PUBLIC OUTREACH IN THESE LANDSCAPES. THE ACTIVITIESARE CONDUCTED TO CARRY OUT THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE'S (CDFW) TRUSTEE RESPONSIBILITIES FORRESOURCES AND REQUIRE EXTENSIVE COMMUNICATION AND COORDINATION WITH OTHER AGENCIES, CDFW HEADQUARTERS PROGRAMS,REGIONAL CDFW STAFF, AND THE PUBLIC.CLIMATE CHANGE IS EXPECTED TO AFFECT SPECIES THE MOST IN EXTREME ENVIRONMENTS, SUCH AS THE ALPINE AND THE DESERT.MANY OF THESE EXTREME ENVIRONMENTS ARE FOUND IN HIGH ELEVATIONS (>10,000 FEET) OF THE SIERRA NEVADA AND THE LOWELEVATIONS (<3,000 FEET) OF THE PENINSULAR RANGES, BOTH OF WHICH ARE IN THE CDFW'S INLAND DESERTS REGION (IDR).CDFW IS THE LEAD AGENCY IMPLEMENTING EFFORTS TO CONSERVE SIERRA NEVADA BIGHORN SHEEP AND PENINULAR BIGHORN SHEEP.THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) IS ALSO RESPONSIBLE FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF POPULATIONS OFDESERT BIGHORN SHEEP (DBHS) AND OTHER GAME SPECIES THROUGHOUT SOUTHEASTERN CALIFORNIA. IN 1994 A STATEWIDEPOPULATION INVENTORY ESTIMATED THE POPULATION AT APPROXIMATELY 3,629 BIGHORN SHEEP (TORRES ET. AL. 1994). IN2003, A STATEWIDE POPULATION INVENTORY YIELDED AN ESTIMATE OF 4,473 BIGHORN SHEEP SUGGESTING A POPULATIONINCREASE OVER THE TEN YEAR PERIOD (EPPS ET. AL. 2005). THE MOST RECENT INVENTORY CONTINUED THE INCREASING TREND,YIELDING AN ESTIMATED TOTAL POPULATION OF 5,206 (ABELLA ET AL. 2011). THE COLLECTION OF ADEQUATE POPULATIONINFORMATION IS NECESSARY TO CONTINUE TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS FOR BIGHORN SHEEP CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT.TO COLLECT SUCH DATA A VARIETY OF TECHNIQUES INCLUDING AERIAL AND GROUND BASED SURVEYS AND REMOTE DATA COLLECTION(CAMERA DATA COLLECTED AT WATERHOLES) WILL BE CONDUCTED.IN MAY, 2013 CDFW FIRST DETECTED EVIDENCE OF A PNEUMONIA OUTBREAK IN A POPULATION OF DBHS. THE DISEASE HAS BEENIDENTIFIED IN SEVERAL MORE POPULATIONS SINCE. SUCH OUTBREAKS ARE NOT THOROUGHLY UNDERSTOOD AS WILDLIFE AGENCIESTEND TO DISCOVER THEM WHEN MANY INDIVIDUALS HAVE ALREADY BEEN AFFECTED AND SIGNIFICANT MORTALITY HAS OCCURRED.MONITORING THE DISTRIBUTION OF DISEASE AND SURVIVAL OF BIGHORN HERDS DURING THE CURRENT OUTBREAK CAN GUIDE FUTUREMANAGEMENT ACTIONS HERE AND IN OTHER STATES. THE RECENT OUTBREAK IN THE MOJAVE DESERT THREATENS SOME CORE DBHSPOPULATIONS IN CALIFORNIA. THE AFFECTED POPULATIONS ARE LOCATED IN CURRENT HUNT ZONES AND TRADITIONAL SOURCEHERDS FOR TRANSLOCATION STOCK. IN ADDITION, THEY ARE CENTRAL TO THE OVERALL METAPOPULATION OF DESERT BIGHORN ANDANY FURTHER SPREAD OF DISEASE WOULD IMPACT A SUBSTANTIAL PROPORTION OF DESERT BIGHORN IN CALIFORNIA.

THE DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) OWNS AND MANAGES APPROXIMATELY 74 PROPERTIES IN THE FIVE-COUNTY SOUTHCOAST REGION (R5). IN SANTA BARBARA, VENTURA, LOS ANGELES, AND ORANGE COUNTIES THERE ARE TEN PROPERTIESCOMPRISING 10,379 ACRES, AND IN SAN DIEGO COUNTY, THERE ARE 64 PROPERTIES COMPRISING 54,921 ACRES. THIS PROJECTIS TO MANAGE EIGHT OF THE TEN PROPERTIES IN SANTA BARBARA, VENTURA, ORANGE, AND LOS ANGELES COUNTIES, AND ELEVENOF THE 64 PROPERTIES IN SAN DIEGO COUNTY. THE LANDS OWNED AND MANAGED BY CDFW INCLUDE ECOLOGICAL RESERVES (ER),WILDLIFE AREAS, PRIVATELY OWNED LANDS WITH CONSERVATION EASEMENTS, AND OTHER PUBLIC ACCESS FACILITIES. THESEPROPERTIES WERE ACQUIRED BY THE CDFW TO CONSERVE IMPORTANT SPECIES AND HABITATS. THE NINETEEN LANDS TO BE MANAGEDUNDER THIS GRANT ARE SEVENTEEN ER'S AND TWO CURRENTLY UNDESIGNATED PROPERTIES-PLANNED TO BECOME ER'S ASIDENTIFIED BELOW.JOB 1 IS TO MANAGE THE FOUR ER'S AND TWO UNDESIGNATED LANDS UNDER THIS GRANT THAT RANGE FROM COASTAL WETLANDS,RIPARIAN HABITAT, AND INLAND CANYONS. THE SIX LANDS TO BE MANAGED UNDER JOB 1 ARE: BURTON MESA (BMER) IN SANTABARBARA COUNTY; CIENEGA SPRINGS (CSER) IN VENTURA COUNTY; AND PEACE VALLEY, AN UNDESIGNATED LAND (FUTURE PEACEVALLEY ER (PVER)) IN LOS ANGELES COUNTY; AND COAL CANYON (CCER), LAGUNA LAUREL (LLER), AND TRABUCO CANYON, ANUNDESIGNATED PROPERTY (FUTURE TRABUCO CANYON ER (TCER) IN ORANGE COUNTY. THEY HAVE A VARIETY OF SPECIES ANDHABITATS INCLUDING COASTAL SAGE SCRUB, CHAPARRAL, RIPARIAN, OAK WOODLAND THAT CONTAIN GAME, NON-GAME, LISTED ANDCOMMON WILDLIFE. FOR EXAMPLE, BMER IN SANTA BARBARA SUPPORTS EL SEGUNDO BLUE BUTTERFLY AND ALL LANDS CONTAINCALIFORNIA QUAIL, DOVE AND RABBITS.JOB 2 IS TO MANAGE THE ELEVEN ER'S, ALL IN SAN DIEGO COUNTY, UNDER THIS GRANT THAT RANGE FROM COASTAL WETLANDS TOINLAND CANYONS. THEY HAVE A VARIETY OF SPECIES INCLUDING GAME, NON-GAME, LISTED AND COMMON WILDLIFE. FOR EXAMPLE,THE COASTAL WETLANDS ARE IN URBAN AREAS AND PROVIDE WINTERING AND MIGRATION HABITAT FOR WATERFOWL AND SHOREBIRDSIN THE PACIFIC FLYWAY. THE ELEVEN LANDS WE WILL MANAGE UNDER JOB 2 ARE AGUA HEDIONDA LAGOON (AHLER), BODEN CANYON(BCYNER), BUENA VISTA LAGOON (BVLER), CARLSBAD HIGHLANDS ER (CHER), MCGINTY MOUNTAIN (MMER), OTAY MOUNTAIN(OMER), RANCHO JAMUL (RJER), SAN DIEGUITO LAGOON (SDLER), SAN ELIJO LAGOON (SELER), SYCUAN PEAK (SPER) AND WALKERCANYON (WCER) ER'S.JOB 3 IS TO MANAGE TWO ECOLOGICAL RESERVES IN LOS ANGELES AND ORANGE COUNTIES THAT ARE PRIMARILY COASTAL WETLANDSAND COASTAL BLUFF HABITATS. THE TWO LANDS TO BE MANAGED UNDER JOB 3 ARE: BALLONA WETLANDS ER (BWER) IN LOSANGELES COUNTY AND BOLSA CHICA ER (BCER) IN ORANGE COUNTY, THEY HAVE A VARIETY OF SPECIES AND HABITATS INCLUDINGCOASTAL SAGE SCRUB, COASTAL SALT MARSH, AND GRASSLAND THAT CONTAIN GAME, NON-GAME, LISTED AND COMMON WILDLIFE.BWER ALSO SUPPORTS EL SEGUNDO BLUE BUTTERFLY.THESE NINETEEN PROPERTIES ARE MANAGED BY CDFW AS AN IMPORTANT OVERALL ELEMENT OF WILDLIFE AND HABITATCONSERVATION. THEY PROVIDE A UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY TO CONSERVE, RESTORE, AND PROTECT DECLINING SENSITIVE SPECIES ANDTHEIR ASSOCIATED HABITATS. THESE PROPERTIES OFFER SENSIBLE AND COMPATIBLE WILDLIFE DEPENDENT RECREATIONAL ANDEDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE PUBLIC AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR RESEARCH AND SCIENTIFIC STUDY. THE VALUES TOENDEMIC AND SENSITIVE SPECIES, GAME SPECIES (DEER, WATERFOWL, UPLAND GAME) AND, IN GENERAL, ALL WILDLIFE IS HIGHAT THESE LOCATIONS. WILDLIFE DEPENDENT USES OCCUR NOW AND WILL BE CONTINUED. BMER, FOR EXAMPLE, IS ONE OF THELARGEST REMAINING BLOCKS OF MARITIME CHAPARRAL AND BMER PROVIDES LONG-TERM PROTECTION FOR THE VALUABLE BIOLOGICALRESOURCES FOUND THERE. CDFW AND ITS LOCAL PARTNERS HAVE IDENTIFIED SPECIES AND HABITAT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES,CONDUCTED PRIORITY MANAGEMENT ACTIONS, AND IMPLEMENTED COLLABORATIVE MONITORING AND RESEARCH PROJECTS TO IMPROVEUNDERSTANDING AND INFORM MANAGEMENT ACTIONS.

THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS PORTIONS OF THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE'S (CDFW) WILDLIFE DIVERSITY PROGRAM (WDP) EFFORTS TO CONSERVE AND RESTORE RARE, THREATENED, AND ENDANGERED BIRDS AND MAMMALS IN CALIFORNIA. THE WDP IS COMPRISED OF SCIENTIFIC STAFF RESPONSIBLE FOR THE MANAGEMENT, CONSERVATION, AND RECOVERY OF NATIVE BIRDS, MAMMALS, AMPHIBIANS, AND REPTILES. ACTIVITIES PERFORMED BY THIS PROJECT INCLUDE SURVEYS FOR SHOREBIRDS AND FOREST CARNIVORES IN CALIFORNIA, INVOLVEMENT IN NUMEROUS WORKING GROUPS, ADVISORY COMMITTEES AND SCIENCE TEAMS, PARTICIPATION IN THE PACIFIC FLYWAY COUNCIL, PREPARING CESA-LISTED SPECIES CONSERVATION STRATEGIES AND MANAGEMENT ACTIONS. IN ADDITION, CDFW NEEDS TO ASSESS THE STATUS OF CERTAIN NONGAME PREDATORS IN THE MONTANE FORESTED ZONE FOR WHICH TAKE AUTHORIZATIONS ARE GRANTED (E.G., BOBCATS, COYOTES) TO ASSURE THAT TAKE LIMITS ARE SUFFICIENT TO MAINTAIN VIABLE POPULATIONS IN THE STATE. THE PROJECTS PROPOSED IN THIS GRANT ARE SPECIFICALLY ORIENTED TOWARD MEETING THESE CONSERVATION NEEDS.IN CALIFORNIA, THERE ARE 173 SPECIES OF ANIMALS LISTED AS THREATENED OR ENDANGERED UNDER CESA, ESA, OR BOTH; AND 213 SPECIES OF ANIMALS LISTED AS SPECIES OF SPECIAL CONCERN. THE CDFW WORKS TO PROTECT AND PRESERVE THESE SENSITIVE SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS. CONSERVATION ACTIONS FOR NATIVE WILDLIFE THREATENED WITH EXTINCTION, OF SPECIAL CONCERN OR OTHERWISE EXPERIENCING SIGNIFICANT DECLINE NEED TO BE CONSIDERED AND IMPLEMENTED. THE PROJECTS PROPOSED IN THIS GRANT ARE SPECIFICALLY ORIENTED TOWARD MEETING THESE CONSERVATION NEEDS.

THE DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) HAS FIVE WILDLIFE AREAS (WAS) THAT ARE FEDERALLY FUNDED BY THE PITTMANROBERTSON ACT (PR) IN THE CENTRAL REGION OF CALIFORNIA. CDFW ACQUIRED LOS BANOS WILDLIFE AREA (LBWA) IN 1929,MENDOTA WILDLIFE AREA (MWA) IN 1955, COTTONWOOD CREEK WILDLIFE AREA (CCWA) IN 1979 AND NORTH GRASSLANDS WILDLIFEAREA (NGWA) IN 1990. THE VOLTA WILDLIFE AREA (VWA) IS OWNED BY THE U.S. BUREAU OF RECLAMATION AND IS MANAGED BYCDFW THROUGH A LEASE AGREEMENT INITIATED IN 1952. THREE OF THE WILDLIFE AREAS (LBWA, VWA, AND CCWA) ARE MANAGEDOUT OF ONE OFFICE AND COLLECTIVELY FORM THE LOS BANOS WILDLIFE AREA COMPLEX (LBWAC).THE LANDS ARE MANAGED TO PROTECT, PRESERVE AND ENHANCE THE INTERIOR WETLANDS PRESENT ON THE AREA, AND THE SPECIESASSOCIATED WITH THOSE VARIOUS HABITATS. THE THREE JOBS WILL PROVIDE OBJECTIVES AND APPROACH TO MAINTAINING THEFIVE WAS.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) UPLAND GAME PROGRAM IS TASKED WITH MANAGING HABITAT AND POPULATIONS OF RESIDENT AND MIGRATORY UPLAND GAME BIRDS, SMALL MAMMALS, AND FURBEARING AND NONGAME MAMMALS IN CALIFORNIA. THESE SPECIES PROVIDE EXTENSIVE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITY THROUGHOUT THE STATE, WHICH INCLUDES HUNTING. TO HUNT UPLAND BIRDS, HUNTERS ARE REQUIRED TO PURCHASE A CALIFORNIA UPLAND GAME BIRD VALIDATION, THE SALES OF WHICH ARE IN TURN USED TO FUND GRANTS FOR PROJECTS THAT BENEFIT UPLAND GAME BIRD SPECIES. THESE STAMP FUNDS AS WELL AS NON-DEDICATED INTERNAL FUNDING ARE USED AS MATCH FOR THIS GRANT APPLICATION.SPECIES SUCH AS GREATER SAGE-GROUSE AND MIGRATORY UPLAND BIRDS (I.E., DOVES, PIGEONS, AND SNIPE) ARE MANAGED THROUGH COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS (I.E., WITH OVERSIGHT FROM FEDERAL PARTNER AGENCIES), WHILE SMALL GAME, NON-GAME AND FURBEARING MAMMALS FALL UPON THIS PROGRAM TO PROVIDE GUIDANCE. GREATER SAGE-GROUSE HAVE A COMPLEX STAKEHOLDER INVOLVEMENT AND REQUIRE NUMEROUS MEETINGS AND PUBLIC INTERFACE. THE GREATER SAGE-GROUSE WAS A CANDIDATE FOR LISTING UNDER THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA) IN 2010 ACROSS ITS ENTIRE RANGE; HOWEVER, THE FINAL RECOMMENDATION FROM THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) WAS NOT TO LIST THE SPECIES. FURTHER COMPLICATING MATTERS, THE BI-STATE POPULATION OF GREATER SAGE-GROUSE IS RECOGNIZED AS A DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENT (DPS) THROUGH GENETICS AND IS A SIGNIFICANT MANAGEMENT CONCERN DUE TO RELATIVELY LOW POPULATION SIZE AND THREATS TO ITS HABITAT. THE UPLAND GAME PROGRAM SERVES A VITAL ROLE IN THE COORDINATION OF GREATER SAGE-GROUSE MANAGEMENT IN CALIFORNIA TO ENSURE POPULATIONS RECOVER. THE UPLAND GAME PROGRAM REPRESENTS CDFW ON THE PACIFIC FLYWAY STUDY COMMITTEE FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF MIGRATORY UPLAND GAME BIRDS. PART OF THIS COMMITMENT IS TO COORDINATE AND OVERSEE BANDING AND SURVEY PROGRAMS USED TO MONITOR MOURNING DOVES, WHITE-WINGED DOVES AND BAND-TAILED PIGEON POPULATIONS, PROGRAMS THAT PROVIDE DATA TO SET HARVEST REGULATIONS. OTHER COMMITMENTS INCLUDE TASKS THAT MAY ARISE AS PART OF STUDY COMMITTEE MEETINGS OR PARTICIPATION IN UPDATING FLYWAY MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR RELATED SPECIES. THE PROGRAM IS TASKED WITH MANAGING HABITAT AND HUNTING OF SMALL GAME, FURBEARING AND NONGAME MAMMALS WHICH INCLUDES TREE SQUIRRELS, GROUNDS SQUIRRELS, RABBITS, HARE, BADGER, BEAVER, BOBCAT, COYOTE, GRAY FOX, MINK, MUSKRAT, OPOSSUM, RACCOON, SPOTTED SKUNK, STRIPPED SKUNK, AND WEASELS. THE PROGRAM RECEIVES AND RESPONDS TO NUMEROUS REQUESTS REGARDING THESE SPECIES EACH YEAR. IN SEPTEMBER OF 2019 ASSEMBLY BILL 1254 PROHIBITS THE HUNTING OF BOBCATS UNTIL AT LEAST 2025. THE PROGRAM IS INVOLVED IS PROVIDING TECHNICAL GUIDANCE TO THE NEWLY ESTABLISHED BOBCAT PROGRAM WHICH WAS ESTABLISHED FROM THIS BILL. THE MAIN GOAL OF THE BOBCAT PROGRAM IS TO GATHER INFORMATION TO INFORM TAKE OF BOBCATS WHETHER IT BE FOR DEPREDATION OR FOR HUNTING.

THIS GRANT SUPPORTS THE N.C. WILDLIFE RESOURCES COMMISSION'S ACTIVITIES TO MANAGE AND MAINTAIN WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND TO DEVELOP AND MANAGE WILDLIFE HABITATS IN NORTH CAROLINA. WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM (WSFR PROGRAM) GRANT FUNDS WILL SUPPORT COORDINATION AND ADMINISTRATION OF PROGRAMS AND PROJECTS; MANAGEMENT OF WILDLIFE HABITATS TO BENEFIT BIRDS AND MAMMALS; COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS OF DATA ON BIRD AND MAMMAL POPULATIONS; DEVELOPMENT OF MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR BIRDS AND MAMMALS; NATIVE SPECIES RESTORATION; AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO CITIZENS, LANDOWNERS AND GOVERNMENTAL ENTITIES.

KENTUCKY DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES WILL BID OUT THE CONSTRUCTION OF A NEW 6,500 GAL/DAY PRE-ENGINEERED, PRECAST CONCRETE, EXTENDED AERATION PACKAGE WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT (WWTP) AND THE REQUIRED ELECTRICAL IMPROVEMENTS AND CAMP ROBERT C. WEBB.RESIDENT CAMPERS, HUNTER EDUCATION WORKSHOP PARTICIPANTS, AND OTHER MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC ATTENDING R3 EVENTS WILL CONTINUE TO RECEIVE HUNTER EDUCATION INSTRUCTION AND HUNTER EDUCATION CERTIFICATION.WITHOUT ADEQUATE SEWAGE TREATMENT THE CAMP PROPERTY WILL NOT BE ABLE TO BE UTILIZED FOR CONSERVATION CAMP, HUNTER EDUCATION INSTRUCTION, AND R3 PROGRAMMING. THE CURRENT WWTP HAS ALREADY OUTLIVED ITS LIFE SPAN AND IS NOT FUNCTIONING PROPERLY.

CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE (CWD) IS A FATAL NEUROLOGICAL DISEASE OF CERVIDS PROPAGATED AS MALFORMED PRION PROTEINS THAT ARE SHED FROM INFECTED INDIVIDUALS IN BODY FLUIDS. THE DISEASE SPREADS VIA ANIMAL-TO-ANIMAL CONTACT, OR UPTAKE FROM INFECTIOUS PRIONS DEPOSITED IN THE ENVIRONMENT. CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE WAS DETECTED IN MULE DEER IN THE HUECO MOUNTAINS OF TRANS-PECOS TEXAS IN JULY 2012 (TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT AND TEXAS ANIMAL HEALTH COMMISSION 2012). IT IS PROBABLE THAT THE DISEASE WAS TRANSMITTED VIA NATURAL EXPANSION FROM AN ENDEMIC AREA IN SOUTHEASTERN NEW MEXICO. TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT (TPWD) AND TEXAS ANIMAL HEALTH COMMISSION (TAHC) IMMEDIATELY ENACTED A DISEASE-MANAGEMENT PLAN AIMED TO DETERMINE THE GEOGRAPHIC EXTENT AND PREVALENCE OF CWD, AND REDUCE RISKS OF THE DISEASE SPREADING OUT OF THE AFFECTED REGION. THE DISEASE HAS SINCE BEEN DETECTED IN FREE-RANGING MULE DEER, WHITE-TAILED DEER, AND ELK IN DALLAM AND HARTLEY COUNTIES, LOCATED IN THE NORTHWEST PANHANDLE. INFECTED INDIVIDUALS PROBABLY EXPANDED THE RANGE OF THE DISEASE VIA NATURAL MOVEMENTS FROM ENDEMIC AREAS IN NEIGHBORING STATES. TEXAS CERVIDS ARE NOT MIGRATORY, BUT MAY MAKE LARGE SEASONAL MOVEMENTS. IN FREE-RANGING POPULATIONS, NATURAL MOVEMENTS AND DISPERSAL ARE A PRIMARY INFLUENCE ON SPREAD OF CWD. ADULT MALES USUALLY HAVE THE HIGHEST RATES OF INFECTION, WHILE MOST DISPERSAL EVENTS INVOLVE YOUNG MALES. LANDSCAPE FEATURES AFFECT MOVEMENTS AND DISPERSAL OF CERVIDS, AND MAY CONCENTRATE, IMPEDE, OR FUNNEL ANIMAL MOVEMENTS. CERVID MOVEMENTS AND DISPERSAL IN THE TRANS-PECOS AND PANHANDLE REGIONS ARE NOT WELL UNDERSTOOD. EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT OR CONTAINMENT STRATEGIES REQUIRE INFORMATION ON ANIMAL MOVEMENTS AND HOW THEY ARE AFFECTED BY LANDSCAPE FEATURES. OUR STUDY WILL INVOLVE INDIVIDUAL-BASED LONGITUDINAL DATA, INCLUDING MOVEMENT AND LIVE CWD TESTING FROM EARLY LIFE TO ADULTHOOD. WE WILL ALSO IDENTIFY FACTORS DRIVING ANNUAL SURVIVAL RATES FOR EACH SPECIES ACROSS SEX, AGE, AND SITES. WE WILL USE DEMOGRAPHIC AND BEHAVIORAL DATA TO PARAMETERIZE SIMULATION MODELS TO EXPLORE HOW CERVID DENSITY AND DEMOGRAPHICS AS WELL LANDSCAPE PATTERNS INFLUENCE THE DISEASE DYNAMICS UNDER VARIOUS FUTURE SCENARIOS. OUR RESULTS WILL ENABLE ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT PLANS INCORPORATING MOVEMENT AND DEMOGRAPHIC FACTORS WITH THE SPREAD OF CWD.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO FEDERAL, STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT AGENCIES AS WELL AS PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND COMMERCIAL/RESIDENTIAL DEVELOPERS FOR THE PURPOSE OF PROTECTING, CONSERVING AND REPLENISHING THE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES OF THIS STATE.

SUPPORTING FWP'S BLOCK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (BMP) THROUGH THIS FEDERAL GRANT WILL INCREASERECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR HUNTERS AND WILL HELP FWP TO BETTER MANAGE WILDLIFE POPULATIONSACROSS THE STATE.AN EFFECTIVE BMP CAN PROVIDE PRIVATE LANDOWNERS WITH RELIEF FROM, AND PARTIAL COMPENSATION FOR,SOME OF THE IMPACTS ASSOCIATED WITH ALLOWING PUBLIC HUNTING ON PRIVATE PROPERTY. THROUGH THEIRPARTICIPATION IN THIS PROGRAM, LANDOWNERS MAY PROVIDE BETTER HARVEST OF GAME ON THEIR PROPERTYAND BE MORE TOLERANT OF WILDLIFE AND HUNTERS.

MANAGE POPULATIONS OF RESIDENT SMALL GAME (I.E., QUAIL, SQUIRREL, PHEASANT, DUSKY GROUSE) AND WILD TURKEY. COORDINATE ACTIVITIES WITH PRIVATE, STATE, AND FEDERAL CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS TO ASSURE INTEGRATION WITH OTHER DEPARTMENT PROGRAMS AND COMPLIANCE WITH STATE AND FEDERAL MANDATES. ACTIVITIES THAT SUPPORT REGULATORY, RESEARCH, AND MANAGEMENT ISSUES ON THESE SPECIES REQUIRE CONTINUOUS PARTICIPATION IN MONITORING POPULATION AND HARVEST TRENDS, ACCUMULATION AND DISTRIBUTION OF NEW RESULTS AND INFORMATION, AND DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF APPROPRIATE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES.
IOWA FY23 HUNTER EDUCATION

THIS PROJECT WILL MONITOR STATE ACRES FOR WILDLIFE ENHANCEMENT (SAFE) AND POLLINATOR FIELDS TO DETERMINE HOW THEY ARE BENEFITTING GRASSLAND BIRDS. THE GOAL IS TO DETERMINE IF SIMPLE MANAGEMENT APPROACHES (FALLOW FIELDS, COVER CROPS) CAN BE USED TO PROVIDE HIGH-QUALITY HABITAT FOR BIRDS. THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE A STUDY ON THE FACTORS LEADING TO THE DECLINE OF EASTERN MEADOWLARKS (THE MOST RAPIDLY DECLINING GRASSLAND BIRD IN ILLINOIS). EXPECTED RESULTS AND BENEFITS OF THIS PROJECT ARE INCREASED UNDERSTANDING OF HOW BIRDS RESPOND TO SAFE FIELDS AND GRASSLANDS, BETTER UNDERSTAND THE DECLINE IN EASTERN MEADOWLARKS, AND TO DETERMINE IF AGRICULTURAL FIELDS AND LOW-QUALITY HABITAT CAN BE CONVERTED TO FALLOW FIELDS WHICH MAY PROVIDE RELATIVELY HIGH-QUALITY HABITAT FOR BIRD POPULATIONS. UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS AT URBANA CHAMPAIGN IS AN EXPECTED SUBRECIPIENT OF THIS GRANT.

TO INCREASE THE RANGE OF LESSER PRAIRIE-CHICKEN (TYMPANUCHUS PALLIDICINCTUS) IT IS IMPORTANT TO CONDUCT ACTIVITIES WHICH SUPPORT THE REGULATORY, RESEARCH, AND MANAGEMENT NEEDS OF LESSER PRAIRIE-CHICKEN BY COLLECTING AND ANALYZING BIOLOGICAL AND HARVEST INFORMATION ON LESSER PRAIRIE-CHICKEN FOR MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.
NORTH DAKOTA GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT'S PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE ACCESS TO, MANAGE, OPERATE AND MAINTAIN 184,472.07 ACRES OF WILDLIFE HABITAT ON 224 WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS.

ANNUALLY THE COLORADO DIVISION OF PARKS AND WILDLIFE (CPW) OFFERS AN OPPORTUNITY THROUGH ITS SMALL SHOOTING RANGE GRANT PROGRAM FOR THIRD PARTY ENTITIES ACROSS COLORADO TO APPLY FOR FUNDING TO MAKE SMALL IMPROVEMENTS AT SHOOTING RANGES. THE SMALL SHOOTING RANGE GRANT PROGRAM SERVES AS A COOPERATIVE EFFORT BETWEEN CPW (GRANTOR) AND OTHER PUBLIC ENTITIES (GRANTEES) TO ENHANCE COLORADO'S SHOOTING RANGES TO ENCOURAGE INCREASED USE OF THESE FACILITIES. THIS YEAR CPW HAS SELECTED FIVE PROJECTS TO BE FUNDED WITH HUNTER EDUCATION (HE) FEDERAL GRANT FUNDS THAT COLLECTIVELY TOTAL APPROXIMATELY $20,717.94. THIS GRANT PROGRAM ALLOWS CPW TO MORE EFFECTIVELY UTILIZE ITS ANNUAL APPORTIONMENT OF HE SECTION 4 FUNDING.
THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE THE COORDINATION AND ADMINISTRATION OF THE WSFR PROGRAMS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS THE COORDINATION OF THE WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION GRANTPROGRAM IN THE KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND PARKS AND TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH THEDEPARTMENT'S PROGRAM ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS. ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE THE ADMINISTRATION OFAPPROXIMATELY FORTY-EIGHT GRANTS AND THE AUDITING OF ASSOCIATED EXPENSES. FUNDS FROM THIS GRANTALSO WILL BE USED FOR PREPARING AND SUBMITTING GRANTS AND REPORTS, AS WELL AS FOR SUBMITTING THEANNUAL LICENSE CERTIFICATION THAT IS REQUIRED FOR FEDERAL FUNDING. THE BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAMINCLUDE AGENCY PERSONNEL WHO IMPLEMENT WSFR GRANTS AND THE PUBLIC WHO ACCESS ACTIVITIES THATARE FUNDED BY THE GRANTS AND ENJOY RECREATION ON KDWP PROPERTIES. THIS PROGRAM ALSO BENEFITSTHE WILDLIFE OF KANSAS THROUGH HABITAT IMPROVEMENT AND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES.

THE ILLINOIS AND MISSISSIPPI RIVER VALLEYS ARE MAJOR MIGRATION AND WINTERING AREAS FOR NEARLY 30 SPECIES OF WATERFOWL IN THE MISSISSIPPI FLYWAY.
