THIS GRANT WILL CONTINUE OUR EXISTING STUDIES THAT ARE IN PROGRESS (AERIAL WATERFOWL AND SHOREBIRD INVENTORY, DIVING DUCK ECOLOGY, ECOLOGY OF CANADA GEESE, MOIST-SOIL WORKSHOPS, GREAT LAKES MALLARDS, SPRING AND FALL RAIL MIGRATION, RAIL DIET AND BODY CONDITION) IN FY23. IN ADDITION, WE WILL ASSESS THE PREVALENCE OF ANTIMICROBIAL RESISTANT BACTERIA IN CANADA GEESE IN RURAL AREAS, AREAS WITH LIVE STOCK, AND URBAN SETTINGS TO ASSESS THE RISK OF CANADA GEESE AS A VECTOR FOR SPREAD OF THOSE BACTERIA. WE WILL ASSESS THE STOPOVER DURATION OF AMERICAN GREEN-WINGED TEAL AND MALLARDS IN THE ILLINOIS RIVER VALLEY AND WILL ALSO CONDUCT PILOT EFFORTS TO DETERMINE THE BEST WAY TO QUANTIFY DIFFERENT KINDS OF DISTURBANCE AND THE IMPACT OF THAT DISTURBANCE ON BOTH SPECIES DURING THE HUNTING SEASON.OUR RESEARCH IS DESIGNED TO INFORM CONSERVATION-PLANNING EFFORTS AND ANSWER BASIC AND APPLIED QUESTIONS OF THE ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER AND GREAT LAKES REGION JOINT VENTURE, UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, AND OTHER CONSERVATION PARTNERS. UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS AT URBANA CHAMPAIGN IS AN EXPECTED SUBRECIPIENT OF THIS GRANT.

TO BETTER UNDERSTAND WHY GEESE HAVE CHANGED DISTRIBUTIONS AND HOW LANDOWNERS CAN MANAGE THEIR PROPERTY TO BETTER EXPLOIT THEIR PREFERENCES, WE PROPOSE TO STUDY THE ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS THAT INFLUENCE THE DISTRIBUTIONS AND HABITAT USE OF CANADA, GREATER WHITE-FRONTED, AND LESSER SNOW GEESE IN ILLINOIS. THIS STUDY WILL HELP EXPLAIN WHY WINTERING GEESE HAVE CHANGED THEIR DISTRIBUTION AND IDENTIFY BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO MANAGE HABITAT FOR THE EXPLOITATION OF EACH OF THESE 3 SPECIES. THIS STUDY'S RESULTS CAN BE USED BY PRIVATE AND PUBLIC RESOURCE MANAGERS TO IMPROVE HABITAT FOR THE RECREATIONAL EXPLOITATION OF THE THREE SPECIES OF GEESE THAT WINTER IN ILLINOIS. UNIVERSITY OF SOUTHERN ILLINOIS AT CARBONDALE IS AN EXPECTED SUB GRANTEE OF THIS PROJECT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP APPROACHES FOR THE RIGOROUS ESTIMATION OF POPULATION PARAMETERS FOR IMPORTANT SPECIES OF MANAGEMENT INTEREST THROUGH CLOSE CONSULTATION WITH IDNR STAFF. THE PROJECT WILL USE EXISTING DATA SOURCES AND REPORTING STRUCTURES TO ESTIMATE POPULATION TRENDS FOR SPECIES OF MANAGEMENT INTEREST AND WE WILL INTEGRATE THESE FINDINGS INTO A FORMAL DECISION-MAKING PROCESS THAT AIDS IN THEIR MANAGEMENT. WE WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION AND TOOLS NECESSARY TO EFFICIENTLY AND ACCURATELY ESTIMATE POPULATION SIZE AND STATUS OF SPECIES OF MANAGEMENT INTEREST AND USE THESE DATA TO OPTIMIZE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT IDNR AND THE STATE OF ILLINOIS AS IT WILL INCREASE EFFICIENCY OF DATA ANALYSIS, ACCURACY OF ESTIMATES AND POTENTIALLY REDUCE COSTS. UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS AT URBANA CHAMPAIGN IS AN EXPECTED SUBRECIPIENT FOR THIS PROJECT.

BIGHORN SHEEP (OVIS CANADENSIS) NUMBERS HAVE BEEN IN DECLINE ACROSS NORTH AMERICA SINCE THE LATE 1800'S DUE TOUNREGULATED HUNTING, HABITAT ENCROACHMENT, AND DISEASE. IN NEBRASKA, BIGHORN SHEEP WERE EXTIRPATED FROM THELANDSCAPE IN THE EARLY 1900'S. TRANSLOCATION EFFORTS WERE STARTED IN THE 1980'S TO REINTRODUCE BIGHORN SHEEP TOTHEIR NATIVE RANGE IN THE STATE. THESE EFFORTS HAVE ESTABLISHED 5 BIGHORN SHEEP POPULATIONS IN THE STATE. DESPITE THE SUCCESSFUL ESTABLISHMENT OF THESE POPULATIONS, DISEASE CONTINUES TO LIMIT POPULATION GROWTH AND POPULATION EXPANSION. THE BIGHORN SHEEP NUMBERS IN THE STATE HAVE BEEN GREATLY REDUCED FOR MULTIPLE REASONS, INCLUDING RESPIRATORY AND HEMORRHAGIC DISEASES. AT SUCH LOW NUMBERS, THE POPULATIONS ARE UNLIKELY TO RECOVER WITHOUTADDITIONAL TRANSLOCATIONS, MORTALITY INVESTIGATIONS AND MONITORING EFFORTS. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE SUPPORT TO THOSE EFFORTS.

THIS PROJECT PLANS TO MONITOR 60 SITES (30 FOREST SITES AND 30 GRASSLAND/SHRUBLAND SITES) ANNUALLY WITH CAMERA TRAPS ACROSS ILLINOIS. THE PROJECT WILL MATCH THE SAMPLING DESIGN OF THE STATEWIDE AND LONG- TERM MONITORING FOR OTHER TAXA PROVIDED BY THE CRITICAL TRENDS ASSESSMENT PROGRAM. ANNUAL MONITORING WILL THEN BE COMPARED TO OTHER DATA COLLECTED ANNUALLY BY THE IDNR (SPOTLIGHT SURVEYS, ROADKILL SURVEYS, ETC.) TO COMPARE EFFECTIVENESS OF ALL TECHNIQUES FOR MONITORING THE SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF FURBEARERS STATEWIDE. CAMERA TRAPS ARE AN EFFECTIVE WILDLIFE MONITORING TOOL THAT COLLECT ROBUST DATA CONTINUOUSLY OVER LONG TIME PERIODS. IMPLEMENTING CAMERA TRAP SURVEYS STATEWIDE WILL PROVIDE RIGOROUS ESTIMATES OF DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE FOR THE TERRESTRIAL FURBEARER COMMUNITY AND ALLOW FOR QUANTITATIVE COMPARISONS WITH OTHER METHODS. UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS AT URBANA CHAMPAIGN IS AN EXPECTED SUBRECIPIENT OF THIS GRANT.

THIS APPLICATION FOR FEDERAL ASSISTANCE SECURES WILDLIFE RESTORATION (AKA PITTMAN-ROBERTSON) FUNDING OVER A FIVE-YEAR PERIOD (APRIL 1, 2022 - MARCH 31, 2027) TO SUPPORT THE NEW YORK STATE HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM (HEP). WITH ROUGHLY 600,000 HUNTERS AND 13,000 TRAPPERS IN NEW YORK, THERE IS A CRITICAL NEED TO OFFER EDUCATION AND SAFETY CERTIFICATION COURSES TO NEW AND EXISTING HUNTERS AND TRAPPERS TO SUSTAIN THESE ACTIVITIES AS IMPORTANT WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT TOOLS AND MECHANISMS FOR CONNECTING PEOPLE TO NATURE AND FOSTERING ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP.THE HEP MISSION IS TO PROVIDE A HIGH-QUALITY EDUCATION PROGRAM THAT WILL TRAIN PERSONS OF ALL AGES TO BE SAFE, KNOWLEDGEABLE, RESPONSIBLE, AND ETHICAL HUNTERS, SHOOTERS, BOWHUNTERS, AND TRAPPERS. BY MAINTAINING AND IMPROVING THE PUBLIC AND LANDOWNER EXPECTATIONS AND CURRENT SAFETY RECORD OF HUNTING IN NEW YORK, THIS PROGRAM MUST BE CONTINUED AND UPGRADED, BOTH TO TRAIN NEW HUNTERS AND TO REACH EXISTING HUNTERS WITH NEW SAFETY MESSAGES. THE PROGRAM'S GOAL IS TO MAINTAIN AN ACTIVE ROSTER OF WELL-TRAINED VOLUNTEER INSTRUCTORS USING MULTIPLE DELIVERY METHODS TO FULLY MEET THE VARIED NEEDS OF NEW YORK'S DIVERSE ARRAY OF STUDENTS AND TEACH THEM TO BE SAFE, KNOWLEDGEABLE, AND RESPONSIBLE MEMBERS OF THE HUNTING AND TRAPPING COMMUNITY.SUCCESSFUL DELIVERY OF THE HEP WILL RESULT IN FEWER HUNTING- AND TRAPPING-RELATED SAFETY INCIDENTS, FEWER HUNTING AND TRAPPING LAW AND REGULATION VIOLATIONS, SUSTAINABLE USE OF GAME SPECIES, INCREASED PARTICIPATION IN HUNTING AND TRAPPING, AND INCREASED PUBLIC AWARENESS OF AND SUPPORT FOR WILDLIFE CONSERVATION, HUNTING, AND TRAPPING.
THIS PROJECT FUNDS ALL ANNUAL LAND USE PLANNING ACTIVITIES FOR CPW PROPERTIES.

THE VOLUME AND COMPLEXITY OF NEBRASKA GAME AND PARKS COMMISSION WORK UNDER US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE FEDERAL AID REQUIRES COORDINATION, ADMINISTRATION ANDSUPERVISION TO ENSURE ACTIVITIES ARE PROPERLY DOCUMENTED AND PRODUCTIVE OF RESULTS. THIS GRANT SUPPORTS THE ADMINISTRATION OF ALL OF THE AGENCY'S US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE GRANT WORK.

THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE FOR THE COORDINATED AND CONTINUED DEVELOPMENT, OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF NEARLY 185,520 ACRES OF LAND AND WATER MANAGED FOR FISHING, HUNTING, AND TRAPPING ACTIVITIES ON APPROXIMATELY 281 STATE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS IN NEBRASKA. ACTIVITIES WILL ALSO EXTEND TO COMPARABLESTATE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS THAT MAY BE GAINED THROUGH ACQUISITION OF AGREEMENTS WITHIN THE GRANT PERIOD. IMPROVED MIGRATORY WATERFOWL HABITAT CONDITIONS AND PUBLIC USE FACILITATION WILL RESULT IN THE ONGOING PUMPING ACTIVITIES SUPPORTED ON US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE WATERFOWL PRODUCTION AREAS WITHIN THE RAINWATER BASIN AREA OF THE STATE.THE PROPOSED WORK ITEMS WILL ASSIST IN KEEPING THE NUMBER AND QUALITY OF NEBRASKA'S PUBLIC FISHING, HUNTING AND TRAPPING OPPORTUNITIES AT A HIGH LEVEL. THE OVERALL OBJECTIVE OF THE PROJECT INCLUDES PROVIDING, PROTECTING, AND ENHANCING WILDLIFE AND FISH HABITATS ON STATESTATE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS AND PROVIDING PUBLIC USE OPPORTUNITIES ON THESE APPROXIMATELY 281 AREAS.

THE MONTEZUMA QUAIL (CYRTONYX MONTEZUMAE) IS A GROUND-DWELLING BIRD THAT INHABITS THE SEMIARID OAK-PINE SAVANNAS, GRASSLANDS, AND WOODLANDS OF MEXICO AND THE SOUTHERN UNITED STATES. THERE IS LITTLE PEER-REVIEWED RESEARCH ON MONTEZUMA QUAIL RELATIVE TO MOST OTHER AVIAN SPECIES IN NORTH AMERICA; THIS IS LARGELY DUE TO THE DIFFICULTY IN SAMPLING BIRDS THAT CANNOT BE EFFECTIVELY TRAPPED OR MONITORED USING CONVENTIONAL METHODS. TO BETTER INFORM CONSERVATION EFFORTS OF MONTEZUMA QUAIL IN TEXAS, WHERE THEIR POPULATIONS ARE THREATENED BY HABITAT CHANGES ASSOCIATED WITH HUMAN DEVELOPMENT AND CHANGES IN LAND USE, THIS PROJECT WILL STUDY THE GENOMICS OF THE SPECIES IN THE CORE OF THEIR MEXICAN RANGE. THESE DATA WILL BE USED TO INFORM ONGOING CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT EFFORTS IN TEXAS AND MAY PROVIDE A PATH TOWARDS GENETIC RESCUE IF POPULATIONS ARE FOUND TO BE EXHIBITING EVIDENCE OF GENETIC EROSION.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) HAS APPROXIMATELY 730 INDIVIDUAL MANAGEMENT UNITS ON MORE THAN 1.1 MILLION ACRES INCLUDING WILDLIFE AREAS, ECOLOGICAL RESERVES, PRIVATE LANDS WITH CONSERVATION EASEMENTS, FISH HATCHERIES AND FISHING ACCESS AND OTHER PUBLIC ACCESS FACILITIES. THE LANDS PROGRAM WITHIN CDFW IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF LAND MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR THE WILDLIFE AREAS AND ECOLOGICAL RESERVES AND PROVIDES GUIDANCE AND SUPPORT FOR RESOURCE ASSESSMENT ACTIVITIES THAT THE INFORM LAND MANAGEMENT PLANS. THE LANDS PROGRAM ALSO SUPPORTS THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF STATEWIDE POLICIES FOR CDFW LANDS AND PROVIDES GUIDANCE AND REVIEW FOR LAND ACQUISITION PROPOSALS.MOST OF THE CDFWS MANAGEMENT UNITS ARE UNSTAFFED AND INFORMATION ON THEIR BIOLOGICAL RESOURCES IS NEEDED TO INFORM MANAGEMENT ACTIONS THAT AFFECT THE HABITATS AND SPECIES FOUND ON CDFW LANDS. CDFW MUST ASSESS BIOLOGICAL RESOURCES TO UNDERSTAND CONSEQUENCES OF MANAGEMENT ACTIONS, PUBLIC USE, AND TO ENSURE THAT THE SPECIES ORIGINALLY TARGETED ARE STILL VIABLE. RESOURCE ASSESSMENT ACTIVITIES ARE PRIORITIZED TO BALANCE MANAGEMENT PLANNING NEEDS, THE PURPOSE OF PROPERTY ACQUISITION AND CURRENT BIOLOGICAL CONCERNS. STAFFED CDFW PROPERTIES ALSO BENEFIT FROM CENTRALIZED GUIDANCE AND COORDINATION FOR RESOURCE ASSESSMENT.IN COMBINATION WITH BIOLOGICAL RESOURCE ASSESSMENT, MANAGEMENT PLANNING FOR CDFW LANDS IS A HIGH PRIORITY. IN RESPONSE TO ISSUES RAISED BY A STATE AUDIT AND LEGISLATION, AND TO MEET THE NEED FOR COMPREHENSIVE PLANNING FOR THE MANAGEMENT AND USE OF CDFW LANDS FOR THEIR WILDLIFE AND PUBLIC USE VALUES, THE CDFW DIRECTS ENERGY AND RESOURCES TO PREPARE AND UPDATE MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR DESIGNATED LANDS AND NEW ACQUISITIONS, CONSISTENT WITH CDFW POLICY. THE BASIC COMPONENTS OF A MANAGEMENT PLAN ARE TO PLAN MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES, DETERMINE APPROPRIATE PUBLIC ACCESS, REVIEW RELEVANT SCIENTIFIC LITERATURE (INCLUDING APPROACHES USED BY OTHER LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES), COMPILE SURVEYS OF BIOLOGICAL AND PHYSICAL RESOURCES, AND DRAFT UNMET PERSONNEL AND EQUIPMENT NEEDS FOR EACH AREA. COORDINATION AND OVERSIGHT AT A STATEWIDE LEVEL ARE NEEDED TO ASSIST CDFW'S REGIONS IN FULFILLING THIS REQUIREMENT TO ENSURE ACCURACY AND CONSISTENCY.THE REVIEW OF LAND ACQUISITION DOCUMENTS FOR COMPLETENESS, CONSISTENCY, AND INTEGRATION OF STATEWIDE PRIORITIES IS ALSO CRITICAL TO THE LAND MANAGEMENT PLANNING EFFORT. LAND ACQUISITION EFFORTS FOCUS ON BIODIVERSITY PROTECTION, HABITAT PRESERVATION AND ALSO CONSIDER OPPORTUNITIES FOR COMPATIBLE RECREATION.MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC OFTEN HAVE QUESTIONS REGARDING STATEWIDE POLICIES OR RULES FOR WILDLIFE AREAS AND ECOLOGICAL RESERVES AND CONTACT STAFF TO OBTAIN ANSWERS. STAFF ALSO PREPARE AND/OR REVIEW INFORMATION ABOUT CDFW LANDS PRESENTED ON CDFWS WEBSITE. OCCASIONALLY, WE PREPARE PRESENTATIONS FOR OTHER PUBLIC VENUES. PROACTIVELY PROVIDING THIS INFORMATION ENHANCES THE PUBLIC'S UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION OF CDFW LANDS.OVER TIME CDFW POLICIES REGARDING PUBLIC USES ON A STATEWIDE OR SITE-SPECIFIC BASIS NEED TO BE RE-EXAMINED, BECAUSE OF THE POPULARITY OF NEWER FORMS OF RECREATION, CHANGES TO SURROUNDING LAND USES, THE IMPLEMENTATION OF COOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT OF ADJACENT NATURAL AREAS OWNED BY DIFFERENT ENTITIES, OR THE EMERGENCE OF UNFORESEEN CONSEQUENCES OF AN AUTHORIZED USE OVER TIME.

THE DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) ACQUIRED THE 1,704 ACRE NELSON RANCH AND THE 4,136 ACRE BIG SPRINGS RANCH (BSR) PARCELS TO PROTECT, PRESERVE, AND ENHANCE COLD WATER SPRINGS, RIPARIAN HABITAT, INTERIOR WETLANDS, AND TO PROVIDE HABITAT FOR WILD BIRDS AND MAMMALS, INCLUDING SOME SENSITIVE OR LISTED SPECIES. THE PROPERTIES ARE COLLECTIVELY REFERRED TO AS THE BIG SPRINGS RANCH PROPERTY (BSR), AND UPON DESIGNATION BY THE CALIFORNIA FISH AND GAME COMMISSION WILL BE REFERRED TO AS THE BIG SPRINGS RANCH WILDLIFE AREA.

PROVIDE MATCHING FUNDS TO THIRD PARTY COOPERATORS FOR EXISTING SHOOTING RANGE MAINTENANCE AND UPGRADES. ALSO, PROVIDE GRANTS TO THIRD PARTIES TO ERECT OR FABRICATE NEW STRUCTURES OR OTHER PHYSICAL ENHANCEMENTS TO SHOOTING RANGES. THESE EFFORTS WILL BE MORE SUBSTANTIAL IN NATURE, IN AN EFFORT TO DEVELOP GREAT PLACES FOR THE PUBLIC TO SHOOT SAFELY.

A CENTURY AGO, 4 MILLION ACRES OF CENTRAL VALLEY WETLANDS SUPPORTED 20 TO 40 MILLION MIGRATING WATERFOWL ALONG THE PACIFIC FLYWAY. BY THE 1980S, 95% OF WETLANDS HAD BEEN DESTROYED, AND BIRD POPULATIONS PLUMMETED TO LESS THAN 15% OF THEIR HISTORIC NUMBERS. THROUGH COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS, CALIFORNIA HAS MADE SUBSTANTIAL PROGRESS IN EFFORTS TO IDENTIFY, ACQUIRE, RESTORE, AND ENHANCE WETLANDS. THE MIGRATORY BIRD TREATY ACT AND 'NO NET LOSS' POLICY DRIVES THE EFFORT TO PRESERVE WETLAND HABITAT FOR MIGRATORY WATERFOWL AND RESIDENT SPECIES WITHIN THE PACIFIC FLYWAY. CALIFORNIA'S FISH AND GAME COMMISSION POLICY SEEKS TO PROVIDE FOR THE PROTECTION, PRESERVATION, RESTORATION, ENHANCEMENT, AND EXPANSION OF WETLAND HABITAT IN CALIFORNIA AND THAT THE QUANTITY AND QUALITY OF THE WATERS OF THIS STATE SHOULD BE APPORTIONED AND MAINTAINED RESPECTIVELY SO AS TO PRODUCE AND SUSTAIN MAXIMUM NUMBERS OF FISH AND WILDLIFE.THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) OPERATES WILDLIFE AREAS AND ECOLOGICAL RESERVES THAT SUPPORT WETLAND HABITAT FOR MIGRATORY AND RESIDENT WATERFOWL SPECIES. USES OF THESE LANDS ALSO INCLUDE RECREATIONAL HUNTING, FISHING, WILDLIFE VIEWING AND PHOTOGRAPHY, EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS, AND INTERPRETIVE TOURS. CDFW ALSO ADMINISTERS SEVERAL PRIVATE LANDS CONSERVATION PROGRAMS DESIGNED TO ASSIST LANDOWNERS WITH THE MANAGEMENT OF WETLANDS, RIPARIAN HABITATS, NATIVE GRASSLANDS AND WILDLIFE-FRIENDLY FARMLANDS.EFFORTS IN PROVIDING NEW WETLAND HABITAT AND MAINTAINING EXISTING WETLAND HABITAT ARE INCREASINGLY HAMPERED BY THE LACK OF FIRM WATER RESOURCES AND INCREASED REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS IN THE DIVERSION AND USE OF WATER FOR WETLAND HABITAT. THE MOST RECENT CALIFORNIA DROUGHT EMERGENCY ENDING IN 2017 HAS RENEWED CALLS FOR HIGHER WATER USE EFFICIENCY FOR URBAN AND AGRICULTURAL USERS. ENERGETICS MODELING SHOWED THAT THE WATER RESOURCES NEEDED TO SUSTAIN SEASONAL WETLAND HABITAT WOULD HAVE BEEN CRITICALLY DEPLETED UNDER CERTAIN DROUGHT SCENARIOS. IMPACTS OF THE DROUGHT AND RESULTING NEW WATER REGULATIONS HAS MADE THE CDFW REALIZE ITS CURRENT PROGRAMS AND PLANS ARE INADEQUACIES IN THIS POST-DROUGHT PARADIGM OF WATER RESOURCES MANAGEMENT.THE SUSTAINABLE GROUNDWATER MANAGEMENT ACT (SGMA), A NEW STATE GROUNDWATER LAW ENACTED IN JANUARY 2015 REQUIRES THE FORMATION OF LOCAL GROUNDWATER BASIN AGENCIES TO REGULATE THE USE OF GROUNDWATER AND THROUGH PROHIBITIONS AND FEES. ON NOVEMBER 2014, THE CALIFORNIA PROPOSITION 1 WATER BOND AUTHORIZED $7.12 BILLION FOR WATER INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECTS, OF WHICH SEVERAL ARE CURRENTLY IN CONSIDERATIONS AND HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO BENEFIT MANAGED WETLANDS. THE 1992 CENTRAL VALLEY PROJECT IMPROVEMENT ACT (CVPIA) REQUIRES THE CENTRAL VALLEY PROJECT TO PROTECT, RESTORE, AND ENHANCE FISH AND WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS IN THE CENTRAL VALLEY AND TRINITY RIVER BASINS, INCLUDING A MANDATE TO PROVIDE 'FIRM WATER SUPPLIES OF A SUITABLE QUALITY AND QUANTITY TO MAINTAIN AND IMPROVE WETLAND HABITAT' FOR STATE, FEDERAL, AND PRIVATE WETLAND HABITAT AREAS.

THE CENTRAL VALLEY OF CALIFORNIA IS ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT WINTERING AREAS FOR WATERFOWL IN NORTH AMERICA, SUPPORTING APPROXIMATELY 60% OF THE PACIFIC FLYWAY POPULATION. HISTORICALLY, THE CENTRAL VALLEY CONTAINED MORE THAN 4 MILLION ACRES OF WETLANDS AND PROVIDED HABITAT FOR AN ESTIMATED 20 TO 40 MILLION WATERFOWL ANNUALLY. TODAY, LESS THAN 5% OF HISTORIC WETLANDS REMAIN, AND OF THOSE, TWO-THIRDS ARE IN PRIVATE OWNERSHIP. CDFW'S WETLAND CONSERVATION PROGRAM (WCP) WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1990 AS A MECHANISM FOR THE CDFW TO ACCOMPLISH THE WETLAND PROTECTION, RESTORATION, AND ENHANCEMENT OBJECTIVES OF THE CENTRAL VALLEY JOINT VENTURE (CVJV).THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP 2015) IDENTIFIES WETLAND RESTORATION AND PARTNERSHIPS WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AS A HIGH PRIORITY TO REVERSE PAST WETLAND DECLINES. THE WCP ADDRESSES THESE NEEDS BY WORKING WITH BOTH THE PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SECTORS TO PROTECT, RESTORE, ENHANCE, AND IMPROVE MANAGEMENT OF CALIFORNIA'S WETLANDS FOR WATERFOWL AND OTHER WETLAND-DEPENDENT SPECIES. FOR THE 2022-23 GRANT TERM, WE ANTICIPATE THAT THE WCP WILL HAVE MANAGEMENT AGREEMENTS ON 83,984 ACRES OF PRIVATE LANDS AND HELP WITH THE ENHANCEMENT AND MANAGEMENT OF 173,773 ACRES OF PUBLIC LANDS STATEWIDE.

THE WATERFOWL INVESTIGATIONS PITTMAN-ROBERTSON PROJECT (PROJECT) WAS CREATED IN 1948. CALIFORNIA HOSTS THE DENSEST CONCENTRATIONS OF WINTERING WATERFOWL IN NORTH AMERICA AND SUPPORTS SUBSTANTIAL BREEDING POPULATIONS OF SOME WATERFOWL SPECIES. SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION ON WATERFOWL ABUNDANCE, TRENDS, RECRUITMENT, MORTALITY, AND DISTRIBUTION IS NEEDED TO CONSERVE THE WATERFOWL RESOURCE, INFORM HARVEST REGULATIONS AND RESTORATION AND PLANNING NEEDS AS WELL AS STIMULATES PRIVATE WETLAND HABITAT OWNERSHIP/MANAGEMENT AND SUBSTANTIAL ECONOMIC ACTIVITY. THIS SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION IS COLLECTED BY CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) PROJECT STAFF THROUGH A SERIES OF PACIFIC FLYWAY-COORDINATED AERIAL SURVEYS, TRAPPING, MARKING, AND HARVEST SURVEYS. THE DATA COLLECTED IS ANALYZED TO UNDERSTAND SPECIES/POPULATION STATUS AND TO MAKE INFORMED MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. ANNUAL HARVEST RECOMMENDATIONS AND ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLIANCE ARE MADE TO BE CONSISTENT WITH POPULATION OBJECTIVES. HOWEVER, THE ADMINISTRATIVE PROCESS FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF DRAFT HARVEST RECOMMENDATIONS AND REGULATIONS WILL NOT BE CHARGED TO THE GRANT. IN ADDITION, PROJECT STAFF MANAGE THE DUCK STAMP DEDICATED ACCOUNT.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) WILL CONTINUE TO STRATEGICALLY EVALUATE, PRIORITIZE, AND IMPLEMENT RESEARCH PROJECTS THROUGH THE HUMAN DIMENSIONS OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION (HD) UNIT. THE HD UNIT WORKS TO UNDERSTAND HOW STAKEHOLDERS (CDFW STAFF, KEY STAKEHOLDERS, THE PUBLIC) PERCEIVE WILDLIFE CONSERVATION ISSUES USING ROBUST AND DEFENSIBLE SOCIAL SCIENCE METHODOLOGIES (E.G. SURVEY INSTRUMENTS, FOCUS GROUPS, INTERVIEWS, CONTENT ANALYSES, EXPERIMENTS). THE HD UNIT APPLIES THIS RESEARCH TO ADDRESS PRIORITY AND CONTENTIOUS WILDLIFE CONSERVATION ISSUES AND TO DETERMINE HOW CDFW CAN MOST EFFECTIVELY INCREASE MEANINGFUL PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT, INVESTMENT, AND BROAD SUPPORT FOR CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES.CALIFORNIA HAS TREMENDOUS DIVERSITY IN BOTH ITS WILDLIFE AND HUMAN POPULATIONS. THE DYNAMIC ENVIRONMENTAL, CULTURAL, AND SOCIAL CONDITIONS PRESENT MANY CHALLENGES IN EFFECTIVELY AND RESPONSIBLY MANAGING THE STATE'S WILDLIFE POPULATIONS. IT IS CRITICAL THAT CDFW INTUITIVELY ENGAGE IN SOCIAL SCIENCE IN CONJUNCTION WITH BIOLOGICAL AND ECOLOGICAL RESEARCH DUE TO CALIFORNIA'S GEOGRAPHIC SIZE, SPECIES DIVERSITY AND DENSITY, AND OFTEN COMPLEX WILDLIFE ISSUES. UNDERSTANDING PUBLIC VALUES AND PERCEPTION OF THE STATE'S WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION APPROACH CAN HELP GUIDE FUTURE IMPLEMENTATION, DEVELOPMENT, AND OUTREACH STRATEGIES OR PLANS. THE HD UNIT WILL CONTINUE TO RESEARCH AND EVALUATE SOCIAL AND CULTURAL ATTITUDES, BEHAVIORS, AND VALUES REGARDING WILDLIFE RESOURCES AND CONSERVATION BY THE PUBLIC IN CALIFORNIA. THE HD UNIT'S FUNCTION AND ROLE CONDUCTING THIS RESEARCH IS CONSISTENT WITH THE CDFW DIRECTOR'S SCIENCE INSTITUTE (SCIENTIFIC INITIATIVE TO INCREASE SCIENTIFIC CAPACITY), THE GOVERNOR'S BIODIVERSITY INITIATIVE, AND STATE LEGISLATION (AB 2402).THE HD UNIT WILL SUPPORT CDFW IN ACHIEVING ITS MISSION THROUGH INFORMED DECISION-MAKING THAT CONSIDERS THE DIVERSITY OF PUBLIC INPUT FOR DEVELOPING WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES. THE HD UNIT WILL CONTINUE TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT STRATEGIES TO UNDERSTAND THE PERSPECTIVES OF CALIFORNIA'S DIVERSE CONSTITUENCIES AND STAKEHOLDERS, TO HELP IDENTIFY PRIORITY CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ISSUES (E.G. PREDATOR MANAGEMENT; WILDLIFE INCIDENT REPORTING; HUMAN-WILDLIFE INTERACTIONS AND CONFLICT MITIGATION; HUNTER RECRUITMENT, RETENTION, AND REACTIVATION (R3); NEW EMERGING WILDLIFE ISSUES BEING DISCUSSED BY THE PUBLIC OR STAKEHOLDER COMMUNITY, AND DETERMINE HOW TO MOST EFFECTIVELY ADDRESS THESE ISSUES. THESE ISSUES MAY BE EXACERBATED BY EXTERNAL EVENTS, BOTH ENVIRONMENTAL (E.G. DROUGHT, FIRE, CLIMATE CHANGE), ECONOMIC (E.G. EXURBAN DEVELOPMENT), AND OTHER USES THAT PUT PRESSURE ON WILD POPULATIONS AND ECOSYSTEMS.

ESTABLISHED IN 1941, THE WILDLIFE HEALTH LABORATORY (WHL, FORMERLY THE WILDLIFE INVESTIGATIONS LABORATORY) WITHIN THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) IS MANDATED TO PROVIDE SERVICE AND EXPERTISE TO RESPOND TO ANY WILDLIFE MORBIDITY AND MORTALITY EVENT IN CALIFORNIA. THIS RESPONSIBILITY REQUIRES THE NEED FOR EXTENSIVE COMMUNICATION, COORDINATION, AND TRAINING WITH OTHER AGENCIES, CDFW REGIONAL AND LAW ENFORCEMENT STAFF, AND THE PUBLIC. THIS IS PARTICULARLY IMPORTANT FOR SUPPORTING STAFF MANAGING CDFW LANDS (E.G., WATERFOWL BOTULISM & AVIAN CHOLERA, UNGULATE HEMORRHAGIC DISEASE EVENTS, PESTICIDE USAGE IN ILLEGAL CANNABIS GROWS).COLLECTING AND ANALYZING DIAGNOSTIC BIOLOGICAL SAMPLES FROM WILDLIFE, CONDUCTING NECROPSIES, AND EVALUATING/ IMPLEMENTING WILDLIFE DISEASE AND CONTAMINANT WORK IS NECESSARY TO MONITOR THE HEALTH AND CONDITION OF WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND TO AID MANAGERS IN EVALUATING THE POTENTIAL DEMOGRAPHIC EFFECTS THAT MAY INFLUENCE HARVEST REGULATIONS. THE DATA ARE NEEDED FOR EFFECTIVE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AS ANIMALS ARE AFFECTED BY DROUGHT CONDITIONS AND CLIMATE CHANGE, WILDFIRE, AND EMERGING INFECTIOUS DISEASES, INCLUDING COVID-19, THAT ARE INCREASING IN OR THREATENING WILDLIFE POPULATIONS.WHL SUPPORTS BOTH GAME AND NON-GAME SPECIES MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS IN THE INVESTIGATION AND MANAGEMENT OF INFECTIOUS AND NON-INFECTIOUS DISEASE IN WILDLIFE POPULATIONS. THIS INCLUDES HEALTH MONITORING OF WILDLIFE, ZOONOTIC DISEASES FOUND IN WILDLIFE, AND ADDRESSING THE CONCERNS OF PUBLIC AND PRIVATE ORGANIZATIONS, AS WELL AS GOVERNMENT AGENCIES IN REGARDS TO WILDLIFE AND ZOONOTIC DISEASES, WILDLIFE EXPOSURE TO CONTAMINANTS, INJURED AND NUISANCE WILDLIFE, AND PUBLIC SAFETY WILDLIFE SUCH AS MOUNTAIN LIONS, BLACK BEARS, COYOTES, LARGE EXOTIC CARNIVORES, DEER AND ELK.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS A CONTINUATION OF W-147-T WITH THE INCREASED EMPHASIS ON LEVERAGING CITIZEN/STAKEHOLDER PARTICIPATION IN WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT WHILE PROVIDING THEM WITH TECHNICAL INFORMATION. THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO ASSIST NATURAL RESOURCE AGENCIES WITH ADDRESSING WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT ISSUES IN A TIME- AND COST-EFFECTIVE MANNER. THIS INCLUDES INCREASING PUBLIC AWARENESS AND UNDERSTANDING OF HUMAN-WILDLIFE ISSUES, AS WELL AS HABITAT DEVELOPMENT AND PROTECTION. THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO IMPROVE EFFECTIVENESS WITH MANAGING WILDLIFE IN HUMAN-DOMINATED SETTINGS BY PROVIDING LANDOWNERS AND THE PUBLIC WITH SCIENCE BASED INFORMATION ON WILDLIFE ISSUES SUCH AS: MINIMIZING THREATS TO HUMAN HEALTH AND SAFETY RELATED TO DISEASE AND VEHICULAR COLLISIONS; PREVENTING AND MINIMIZING WILDLIFE DAMAGE SUCH AS AGRICULTURAL LOSSES, DAMAGE TO PHYSICAL STRUCTURES, AND THE LOSS OF NATURAL VEGETATION AND IMPORTANT ECOSYSTEM FUNCTIONS; AND UNDERSTANDING BASIC WILDLIFE HABITAT MANAGEMENT. LEWIS AND CLARK COMMUNITY COLLEGE IS AN EXPECTED SUBRECIPIENT OF THIS PROJECT.

OUR PURPOSE IS TO STUDY UPLAND GAME IN ILLINOIS TO PROVIDE INFORMATION TO SUPPORT WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT, ACCORDING TO THE FOLLOWING STUDY-LONG OBJECTIVES. STUDIES CONDUCTED UNDER THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION FOR PLANNING AND EVALUATION OF UPLAND WILDLIFE AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT PRACTICES IN ILLINOIS. FINAL RESULTS FROM THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE HABITAT AND POPULATION MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS TO INFORM MANAGERS AND IMPROVE BOBWHITE HABITAT STATEWIDE, THUS BENEFITTING RESOURCES. SOUTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY AT CARBONDALE IS AN EXPECTED SUBGRANTEE OF THIS PROJECT.

MIGRATORY GAME BIRDS (I.E., WATERFOWL, DOVE, SANDHILL CRANE [ANTIGONE CANADENSIS], AND BAND-TAILED PIGEON [PATAGIOENAS FASCIATA]) ARE IMPORTANT BIOLOGICAL, RECREATIONAL, AND ECONOMIC RESOURCES IN NEW MEXICO AS WELL AS THROUGHOUT NORTH AMERICA. IT IS IMPORTANT THAT ANY ACTIVITY (E.G., HUNTING, HABITAT MANIPULATION, VIEWING, ETC.) ASSOCIATED WITH THESE SPECIES USE SOUND BIOLOGICAL INFORMATION TO INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS IN ORDER TO MINIMIZE ANY POTENTIAL ASSOCIATED DETRIMENTAL EFFECTS. BECAUSE OF THEIR MIGRATORY NATURE, COORDINATION OF ACTIVITIES WITH PRIVATE, STATE, AND FEDERAL CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS IS NECESSARY. TO MANAGE MIGRATORY GAME BIRD RESOURCES AND THEIR ASSOCIATED HABITATS SUCH THAT VIABLE POPULATION LEVELS ARE MAINTAINED FOR THEIR RECREATIONAL, EDUCATIONAL, SCIENTIFIC, AND INTRINSIC VALUE.

TO IMPROVE THE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF MIGRATORY BIRD SPECIES AND THEIR HABITAT IN RHODE ISLAND. THESE PROJECTS WILL HELP UNDERSTAND THE CURRENT STATUS OF MANY MIGRATORY BIRD SPECIES IN RHODE ISLAND, IMPROVE HABITAT QUALITY FOR BREEDING BIRDS, AND FURTHER UNDERSTAND RHODE ISLAND'S ROLE IN THE ANNUAL CYCLE OF DECLINING MIGRATORY BIRD SPECIES. DATA COLLECTED AS PART OF THESE PROJECTS WILL BE REFERENCED AND ANALYZED TO ASSIST IN MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AND TO GUIDE FUTURE PROJECTS FOR HABITAT MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION GOALS.

THE AMERICAN BLACK BEAR IS NOT ONLY AN EXTREMELY VALUED GAME SPECIES TO THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA, IT IS ALSO A SPECIES OF INCREDIBLE INTEREST TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC. RECOGNIZING THAT, THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE'S (CDFW) AMERICAN BLACK BEAR (URSUS AMERICANUS) MANAGEMENT PROGRAM IS TO MAINTAIN A VIABLE AND HEALTHY BEAR POPULATION FOR THE BENEFIT AND ENJOYMENT OF ALL CALIFORNIANS. CDFW CURRENTLY OPERATES IN ACCORDANCE WITH A 1998 BLACK BEAR MANAGEMENT PLAN (BBMP) TO ATTAIN THIS GOAL. CDFW HAS MAINTAINED REGULATED SPORT HUNTING OF BLACK BEARS IN THE BEAR HUNT ZONE SINCE 1948. BEGINNING IN THE 1970S, RESEARCH WAS CONDUCTED TO DETERMINE THE EFFECTS OF HUNTING ON BEAR POPULATIONS AS WELL AS BEARS HABITAT UTILIZATION AND DISTRIBUTION STATEWIDE. EXISTING STATE STATUTE AND THE BBMP REQUIRE CDFW TO ANNUALLY ESTIMATE THE BLACK BEAR POPULATION ABUNDANCE AND REPORT THE STATUS TO THE CALIFORNIA FISH AND GAME COMMISSION. THE PRIMARY APPROACH HAS BEEN TO USE DEMOGRAPHIC INFORMATION FROM HARVESTED ANIMALS SUCH AS HUNTER HARVEST REPORTS, SEX, AND AGE FROM TEETH CEMENTUM WHICH IS SOMEWHAT LIMITED BECAUSE THIS DATA DOES NOT ADDRESS BEAR POPULATIONS OUTSIDE OF THE HUNT BOUNDARY.GIVEN THE PAUCITY OF DATA ON BEARS OUTSIDE OF THE HUNT BOUNDARY AND IN AN EFFORT TO UPDATE THE MANAGEMENT PLAN, NEW APPROACHES HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED TO FILL INFORMATION GAPS IN CALIFORNIA'S BLACK BEAR MONITORING EFFORTS THROUGH SURVEYS OUTSIDE OF THE HUNT BOUNDARY AND BEYOND INFORMATION REPORTED FROM HARVEST. THE TECHNIQUES AND APPROACHES INCLUDED HERE WILL BE EVALUATED FOR POTENTIAL STATEWIDE IMPLEMENTATION AND APPLICABILITY STATEWIDE TO ASSESS BLACK BEAR POPULATIONS.

THE ROGUE WATERSHED HABITAT PROGRAM IS MANAGED FROM THE ROGUE WATERSHED DISTRICT OFFICE IN CENTRAL POINT BY ONEWILDLIFE HABITAT BIOLOGIST. THE BIOLOGIST ALSO ACTS AS THE SW REGION A&H COORDINATOR AND OVERSEES APPROXIMATELY 5A&H PROJECTS INCLUDING 2 COOPERATIVE TRAVEL MANAGEMENT AREAS. THE ROGUE WATERSHED INCLUDES JACKSON, JOSEPHINE,AND CURRY COUNTIES. THE ROGUE WATERSHED DISTRICT IS COMPOSED OF LAND OWNED AND/OR MANAGED BY VARIOUS ENTITIES,WHICH VARY IN SIZE, LOCATION AND TOPOGRAPHY. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ENHANCE WILDLIFE HABITAT BY ASSISTINGOTHER GOVERNMENT AGENCIES AND PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IN DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING HABITAT IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS.THIS WORK IS DONE IN COLLABORATION WITH SPORTING ORGANIZATIONS AND EDUCATIONAL GROUPS. HABITAT IMPROVEMENTS FALLBROADLY INTO TWO CATEGORIES - RESTORATION OF NATURAL HABITATS, AND IMPROVEMENT OF MAN-MADE HABITATS. IN THE ROGUEWATERSHED, PRIMARY CAUSES OF DEGRADATION OF NATURAL HABITATS ARE FIRE SUPPRESSION, HUMAN DEVELOPMENT, ANDINTRODUCTION OF NON-NATIVE PLANTS, WHICH ARE IDENTIFIED AS KEY CONSERVATION ISSUES IN THE OREGON CONSERVATIONSTRATEGY (OREGON'S STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN). FIRE IS A NATURAL PART OF THIS ECOSYSTEM, AND FIRE SUPPRESSIONHAS LED TO SHRUB COMMUNITIES BECOMING DECADENT, OAK WOODLANDS BEING INVADED BY CONIFERS, LOSS OF NATURAL OPENINGSAND MEADOWS, REDUCTION OF NATIVE PLANT SPECIES, AND LESS EARLY SERAL STAGE VEGETATION.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) WILL CONTINUE THE MOUNTAIN LION (PUMA CONCOLOR) CONSERVATION PROGRAM WHICH WAS ESTABLISHED IN PART WITH WSFR FUNDING IN 2014 TO COORDINATE MOUNTAIN LION POPULATION RESEARCH AND MONITORING AND TO INFORM BIG GAME MANAGEMENT, SPECIES MANAGEMENT PLANS AND HABITAT CONSERVATION AND PROTECTION. GIVEN THAT PREVIOUS EFFORTS TO ESTIMATE 1) STATEWIDE ABUNDANCE, 2) HABITAT USE PATTERNS, 3) GENE FLOW, AND 4) HEALTH STATUS HAVE BEEN SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETED, THE MOUNTAIN LION PROGRAM WILL NOW FOCUS ON: 1) CONNECTIVITY AND GENE FLOW; 2) HUMAN-MOUNTAIN LION INTERACTIONS; 3) COMMUNITY ECOLOGY; AND 4) DEVELOPING POPULATION MONITORING TECHNIQUES. THE FOUR PROGRAM PRIORITIES ARE OUTLINED IN DELLINGER ET AL. 2021. THE ESTABLISHMENT OF THIS PROGRAM WAS IN DIRECT RESPONSE TO NUMEROUS STAKEHOLDER GROUPS WHO HAVE VOICED CONCERN OVER CALIFORNIA'S MOUNTAIN LION POPULATIONS. FOR EXAMPLE, DEER (ODOCOILEUS SPP.) HUNTERS HAVE EXPRESSED CONCERN THAT THE MOUNTAIN LION POPULATION IS INCREASING AND THUS NEGATIVELY IMPACTING DEER HERDS BY HIGH RATES OF PREDATION. CONVERSELY, CERTAIN NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (NGOS) HAVE SUGGESTED THAT THE COMBINATION OF MORTALITY FACTORS (E.G. HABITAT LOSS AND DEGRADATION, VEHICLE STRIKES, HABITAT FRAGMENTATION, DEPREDATION TAKE, DISEASE AND TOXICANTS ETC.) IS LIKELY CAUSING THE STATE'S MOUNTAIN LION POPULATION TO DECLINE IN NUMBERS AND GENETIC DIVERSITY TO A POINT THAT WOULD THREATEN THE POPULATION'S VIABILITY. CDFW THEN UNDERTOOK A RIGOROUS SCIENTIFIC APPROACH TO ESTIMATING MOUNTAIN LION POPULATION STATUS (I.E., ABUNDANCE, GENETICS, HABITAT USE, HEALTH, AND DISEASE PREVALENCE) STATEWIDE (DELLINGER ET AL. 2021). IN DOING SO CDFW IDENTIFIED AREAS OF FURTHER RESEARCH NEED WITH RELATION TO MOUNTAIN LIONS. THESE NEW PRIORITIES ARE: 1) CONNECTIVITY AND GENE FLOW; 2) HUMAN-MOUNTAIN LION INTERACTIONS; 3) COMMUNITY ECOLOGY; AND 4) DEVELOPING POPULATION MONITORING TECHNIQUES. HUMAN DEVELOPMENT HAS IMPACTED ABILITY OF SUBADULT MOUNTAIN LIONS TO DISPERSE FROM ONE AREA TO ANOTHER IN CERTAIN AREAS OF CALIFORNIA. THIS HAS LIMITED GENE FLOW AND INCREASED INBREEDING. MORE INFORMATION IS NEEDED TO UNDERSTAND WHERE MITIGATION MEASURES (E.G., ROAD-CROSSING STRUCTURES) CAN BE IMPLEMENTED TO IMPROVE HABITAT CONNECTIVITY AND GENE FLOW. HUMAN-CAUSED MORTALITY IS ADDITIVE IN MOUNTAIN LIONS AND THUS NEGATIVELY IMPACTS MOUNTAIN LION POPULATION STABILITY AND THUS IT IS NECESSARY TO UNDERSTAND HOW TO MITIGATE HUMAN-CAUSED MORTALITY. MOUNTAIN LIONS ARE THE MAIN PREDATORS FOR MANY ECONOMICALLY AND SOCIALLY IMPORTANT BIG GAME SPECIES IN CALIFORNIA, SOME OF WHICH ARE STATE AND FEDERALLY LISTED AS THREATENED OR ENDANGERED. FURTHER, MOUNTAIN LIONS COMPETE WITH CO-OCCURRING BIG GAME SPECIES (I.E., BLACK BEARS) AND STATE LISTED ENDANGERED SPECIES (I.E., GRAY WOLVES). THUS, UNDERSTANDING FACTORS THAT INFLUENCE PREDATION RATES ON UNGULATES AND CO-OCCURRENCE AMONGST LARGE CARNIVORES CAN INFORM MANAGEMENT OF BIG GAME AND THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES. LASTLY, THERE IS NEED TO DEVELOP LOW-COST, REPEATABLE, AND SCIENTIFICALLY ROBUST METHODS TO MONITOR LOW-DENSITY WILDLIFE SPECIES LIKE MOUNTAIN LIONS TO UNDERSTAND POPULATION TRENDS FOR INFORMING MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION DECISION-MAKING.

THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE, UMPQUA WATERSHED DISTRICT WILDLIFE STAFF STRIVES TO PROTECT AND ENHANCE WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS FOR USE AND ENJOYMENT BY PRESENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS WITHIN BOTH COOS AND DOUGLAS COUNTIES. WE HAVE ACHIEVED THIS BY WORKING WITH MULTIPLE STAKEHOLDERS, BOTH PUBLIC AND PRIVATE, TO IMPROVE UPON CURRENT HABITAT CONDITIONS IN ORDER TO PROVIDE THE HIGHEST QUALITY OF HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE POPULATIONS WITHIN OUR DISTRICT. OUR OBJECTIVES AS WE SEEK TO MEET THE NEEDS OF WILDLIFE IN OUR DISTRICT INCLUDE:1. PROVIDE, MAINTAIN AND ENHANCE WILDLIFE HABITATS ON VARIOUS LAND OWNERSHIPS WITHIN OUR DISTRICT.2. ENCOURAGE OTHER AGENCIES AND LANDOWNERS TO ENHANCE WILDLIFE HABITATS ON THEIR MANAGED LANDS.3. MAINTAIN THE FACILITIES, STRUCTURES AND EQUIPMENT NECESSARY FOR THE ADMINISTRATION OF OUR DISTRICTS WILDLIFE HABITAT PROGRAM.4. ADMINISTRATION OF HABITAT PROGRAM ACTIVITIES AND ASSIST WITH ADMINISTRATION OF DISTRICT WILDLIFE ACTIVITIES.THE UMPQUA WATERSHED DISTRICT WILDLIFE STAFF HAS A SOLID AND GROWING RELATIONSHIP WITH LAND MANAGERS, BOTH PUBLICAND PRIVATE, WITHIN OUR DISTRICT. OPPORTUNITIES FOR WILDLIFE HABITAT ENHANCEMENT ARE IDENTIFIED AND PURSUEDTHROUGH OUR PROJECT PARTNERSHIPS.

THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE WENAHA WILDLIFE AREA BEGAN IN 1953 WITH THE ACQUISITION OF FIVE PARCELS OF LAND CONSISTINGOF 4,400 ACRES. THE DEPARTMENT CONTINUED TO PURCHASE ADDITIONAL LANDS, ACQUIRING 1,670 ACRES IN 1954 AND ANOTHER760 ACRES IN 1955. FROM 1961 TO THE PRESENT, THE DEPARTMENT HAS PURCHASED OR RECEIVED ANOTHER 4,219 ACRES. THEWILDLIFE AREA CURRENTLY CONSISTS OF 12,419 ACRES. IN ADDITION, MANAGEMENT AGREEMENTS WITH THE BUREAU OF LANDMANAGEMENT (BLM) WERE WRITTEN FOR 1,329 ACRES WITHIN OR ADJACENT TO THE WILDLIFE AREA.THE WENAHA WILDLIFE AREA ESTABLISHED IN RESPONSE TO CONTINUING COMPLAINTS FROM LANDOWNERS CONCERNED WITH ELKDAMAGE ON PRIVATE LANDS DURING WINTER MONTHS. OVER 18,000 ACRES NEAR THE INITIAL WILDLIFE AREA PURCHASE HAS BEENIDENTIFIED AS CRITICAL BIG GAME WINTER RANGE. A SMALL RESIDENT POPULATION OF ELK AND DEER SUMMER IN THE WENAHABASIN; HOWEVER, THE PROBLEM STEMMED PRIMARILY FROM ELK, WHICH SUMMERED IN OREGON AND WASHINGTON AND THEN MIGRATEDDOWN THE WENAHA RIVER DRAINAGE INTO THE TROY AREA IN EARLY WINTER MONTHS. ELK REMAINED ON PRIVATE LANDS UNTILAPRIL WHEN THEY RETURNED TO SUMMER RANGE IN THE WENAHA BASIN, ON LANDS ADMINISTERED BY THE U.S. FOREST SERVICE INBOTH OREGON AND WASHINGTON.THERE IS A NEED TO ALLEVIATE DAMAGE TO PRIVATE LANDS BY WINTERING ELK AND PROVIDE HIGH QUALITY WILDLIFE HABITATNEAR TROY IN NORTHEAST OREGON. THE WWA IS MANAGED PRIMARILY FOR PROVIDING NATURAL AND SUPPLEMENTAL FORAGE FORROCKY MOUNTAIN ELK, MULE AND WHITE-TAILED DEER, AND ROCKY MOUNTAIN BIGHORN SHEEP AS WELL AS MINIMIZE BIG GAMEDAMAGE TO ADJACENT PRIVATE AGRICULTURAL CROPS. THE WILDLIFE AREA ALSO IS MANAGED TO ENHANCE HABITAT FORINDIGENOUS FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES IN ADDITION, TO PROVIDE WILDLIFE ORIENTED RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR THEPUBLIC. THE NATURAL RESOURCES ON THE WWA NEED TO BE MANAGED IN SUCH A MANNER AS TO PROTECT, MAINTAIN, ENHANCE,AND RESTORE FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT TO SUPPORT OPTIMUM POPULATION LEVELS OF ALL SPECIES FOR THE ENJOYMENT OFPRESENT AND FUTURE CITIZENS. TO PROTECT THESE NATURAL RESOURCES, MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS AND STRATEGIES UTILIZED ONTHE WWA WILL MEET OR EXCEED HABITAT PROTECTION POLICIES AND STANDARDS SET BY THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH ANDWILDLIFE.THE GOAL OF THE WENAHA WILDLIFE AREA IS TO MANAGE LANDS IN ORDER TO MEET ONE OR MORE OF THE FOLLOWING NEEDS: (1)TO PROTECT OR ENHANCE WILDLIFE SPECIES; (2) PROTECT OR ENHANCE EXISTING HABITAT CONDITIONS OR RESTORE LOSTHABITATS; AND (3) PROVIDE QUALITY WILDLIFE-ORIENTED RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. PROPERLY MANAGE THE LAND, ANDENSURING THEIR AVAILABILITY FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS, AND PROVIDES BENEFITS FOR ALL CITIZENS.TO PROTECT THESE NATURAL RESOURCES, MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS AND STRATEGIES UTILIZED ON THE WENAHA WILDLIFE AREA WILLMEET OR EXCEED HABITAT PROTECTION POLICIES AND STANDARDS SET BY THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE.

THE WILDLIFE RESTORATION PROGRAM WAS INITIATED IN 1937 UNDER THE PITTMAN-ROBERTSON ACT TO PROVIDE FEDERAL FUNDINGTO STATES FOR THE BENEFIT OF A DIVERSE ARRAY OF WILDLIFE AND ASSOCIATED HABITATS. THIS GRANT FUNDS THE ANNUALOPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF THE FERN RIDGE WILDLIFE AREA (FRWA).FRWA IS MANAGED BY THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (ODFW), UNDER A 25 YEAR LICENSE AGREEMENT WITH THEUS ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS (USACE). THE LICENSE AGREEMENT IS IN PLACE TO AUTHORIZE ODFW TO MANAGE PROPERTYWITHIN THE FERN RIDGE LAKE PROJECT FOR WILDLIFE HABITAT MANAGEMENT. THE WILDLIFE AREA'S PURPOSE IS TO DEVELOP,CONSERVE, AND MANAGE ALL WILDLIFE RESOURCES ON 5,831 ACRES OF LAND AND WATER WITHIN THE GREATER USACE UPPERWILLAMETTE VALLEY - FERN RIDGE LAKE PROJECT, AND ADJACENT PROPERTIES.ODFW STAFF ADMINISTER HABITAT MANAGEMENT AND PUBLIC USE PROGRAMS ON THE WILDLIFE AREA. A TEAM OF DEDICATEDVOLUNTEERS IS ALSO ANTICIPATED TO CONTRIBUTE APPROXIMATELY 1,500 HOURS OF LABOR ASSISTANCE ON THE WILDLIFE AREADURING THE YEAR.THIS PROJECT DEVELOPS, ENHANCES, AND MAINTAINS WILDLIFE HABITATS AND PROVIDE PUBLIC RECREATION OPPORTUNITIES INTHE SOUTH WILLAMETTE VALLEY OF WESTERN OREGON. FRWA SUPPORTS 2.25 MILLION WATERFOWL USE DAYS ANNUALLY AND >359DOCUMENTED SPECIES OF BIRDS, MAMMALS, AMPHIBIANS AND REPTILES. FRWA ALSO PROVIDES OPPORTUNITIES FOR 4,000+HUNTERS ANNUALLY AND AN ESTIMATED 800,000 PEOPLE VISIT FERN RIDGE LAKE ANNUALLY.

OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (ODFW) IS RESPONSIBLE FOR MANAGEMENT OF THE STATE'S BIG GAME POPULATIONS.IN ORDER TO MANAGE BIG GAME POPULATIONS, ODFW NEEDS HIGH-QUALITY INFORMATION TO UNDERSTAND HOW THOSE POPULATIONSARE FLUCTUATING FROM YEAR TO YEAR. THIS GRANT COVERS AERIAL INVENTORY FOR DEER, ELK, PRONGHORN, BIGHORN SHEEP,MOUNTAIN GOAT, AND MOOSE IN OREGON. MOST SURVEYS OCCUR IN THE FALL, WINTER, AND SPRING PRIMARILY ON BIOLOGICALWINTER RANGES WITHIN EACH WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT UNIT. GIVEN THE LARGE SIZE OF WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT UNITS (WMU) INOREGON AND DISPERSED NATURE OF BIG GAME, GROUND-BASED SAMPLING IS IMPRACTICAL. MONITORING OF BIG GAMEPOPULATIONS USING HELICOPTERS OR FIXED WING AIRCRAFT IS MORE EFFECTIVE AND CAN BE COMPLETED FROM WITHIN A FEWHOURS TO MULTIPLE DAYS PER UNIT. ODFW STRIVES TO ESTIMATE POPULATION STATUS USING ROBUST, STATISTICALLY DESIGNEDMETHODS. AERIAL SURVEYS ALLOW ODFW TO EFFECTIVELY DETERMINE THE STATUS AND TRENDS OF SEVERAL BIG GAME MAMMALSPECIES AND THEREFORE MORE EFFECTIVELY MANAGE THEIR POPULATIONS AND THE HUNTING OPPORTUNITY THEY PROVIDE. THESEDATA WILL BE USED TO MAKE MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS FOR GAME MAMMALS THAT ARE CONSISTENT WITH OREGON'S WILDLIFEMANAGEMENT POLICIES TO MAINTAIN AND INCREASE BIG GAME POPULATIONS AND INCREASE HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES.

THIS GRANT FUNDS THE ANNUAL OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF THE ELKHORN WILDLIFE AREA (EWA). ESTABLISHED IN 1971TO MITIGATE THE LOSS OF TRADITIONAL BIG GAME WINTER RANGE IN BAKER AND UNION COUNTIES THROUGH HABITAT MANAGEMENTAND SUPPLEMENTAL FEEDING, THE WILDLIFE AREA PROVIDES SUPPLEMENTAL OR SUBSISTENCE FEED FOR WINTERING ELK AND DEERTO REDUCE DAMAGE TO ADJACENT PRIVATE LANDS AND AGRICULTURAL CROPS.THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE ELKHORN WILDLIFE AREA BEGAN WITH THE ACQUISITION OF THE NORTH POWDER AND AUBURN SITES.THESE SITES WERE IDENTIFIED AS CRITICAL WINTER RANGE WHERE SUPPLEMENTAL FEEDING COULD POTENTIALLY STOP AND HOLDMIGRATING ELK AND DEER. THE EWA HAS SINCE GROWN TO 8,836 ACRES, OF WHICH 6,723 ACRES ARE UNDER ODFW OWNERSHIP,1,728 ACRES MANAGED BY COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WITH THE U.S. FOREST SERVICE (USFS) AND BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT(BLM), AND 5 ACRES OF PRIVATE LANDS ARE LEASED BY ODFW. THE WILDLIFE AREA HAS RECEIVED ANNUAL FUNDING UNDER THEFEDERAL AID IN WILDLIFE RESTORATION ACT SINCE 1971.THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO FUND CONTINUED OPERATION OF ELKHORN WILDLIFE AREA TO ALLEVIATE DAMAGE CONFLICTSBETWEEN AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION AND UNGULATE POPULATIONS IN THE BAKER VALLEY.OPERATION OF ELKHORN WILDLIFE AREA PROVIDES HABITATS FOR BIG GAME SPECIES AND OTHER INDIGENOUS WILDLIFE. THE DAMAGE CONFLICTS HAVE BEEN ALLEVIATED THROUGH FENCE REPAIRS, FORAGE IMPROVEMENTS AND SUPPLEMENTAL WINTER FEEDING OF 1,400 ELK AND 800 DEER ON THE WILDLIFE AREA. WITHOUT THE OPERATIONS OF ELKHORN WILDLIFE AREA WILDLIFEINFLICTED HARDSHIPS WOULD CONTINUE FOR AREA LAND OWNERS AND ULTIMATELY ELK AND DEER POPULATIONS WOULD BE REDUCEDTO SOCIALLY TOLERANT LEVELS

SUMMER LAKE WILDLIFE AREA WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1944, WITH PRIMARY OBJECTIVES OF PROTECTING AND IMPROVING WATERFOWLHABITAT AND PROVIDING A PUBLIC HUNTING AREA. THE WILDLIFE AREA IS LOCATED IN CENTRAL LAKE COUNTY ALONG STATEHIGHWAY 31, 100 MILES SOUTHEAST OF BEND AND 75 MILES NORTHWEST OF LAKEVIEW. THE WILDLIFE AREA IS 18,941 ACRES INSIZE AT PRESENT.SUMMER LAKE WILDLIFE AREA IS LOCATED IN THE NORTHERN GREAT BASIN AND HAS A SIGNIFICANT LAND BASE WELL SUITED TOSUPPORT INDIGENOUS FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES AND MIGRATORY WATERBIRDS. WETLANDS AND ASSOCIATED UPLANDS PROVIDEHABITAT FOR A DIVERSE ARRAY OF WILDLIFE SPECIES. HABITAT TYPES FOUND ON SLWA ARE OF QUALITY AND QUANTITY TO MAKEA SIGNIFICANT CONTRIBUTION TO WILDLIFE AND MIGRATORY WATERFOWL IN THIS PORTION OF THE STATE.SLWA IS A POPULAR DESTINATION FOR HUNTING, WILDLIFE VIEWING AND ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION DUE TO ITS GEOGRAPHICSETTING, THE ABUNDANCE OF WILDLIFE PRESENT AND SPECIES DIVERSITY.HABITAT MANAGEMENT AND PUBLIC USE PROGRAMS ON THE WILDLIFE AREA ARE ADMINISTERED BY ODFW STAFF.THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO PROTECT, MAINTAIN, ENHANCE, AND RESTORE WILDLIFE HABITAT TO SUPPORT OPTIMUMPOPULATION LEVELS OF ALL SPECIES FOR THE ENJOYMENT OF PRESENT AND FUTURE CITIZENS. ALL MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES ONSLWA ARE UNDERTAKEN WITHIN THE CONTEXT OF THIS PRIMARY PURPOSE.

JEWELL MEADOWS WILDLIFE AREA IS LOCATED IN THE NORTH OREGON COAST RANGE, APPROXIMATELY 25 MILES SE OF ASTORIAOREGON, AND MANAGED BY THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE.JEWELL MEADOWS WILDLIFE AREA CONSISTS OF 1114 ACRES OWNED BY OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE. THE PRIMARYPURPOSE IS TO PROTECT AND ENHANCE HABITAT TO BENEFIT NATIVE WILDLIFE SPECIES, REDUCE WILDLIFE DAMAGE TO ADJACENTPROPERTIES, AND TO PROVIDE THE PUBLIC AN OPPORTUNITY TO OBSERVE WILDLIFE IN A NATURAL SETTING.1. PROVIDE HABITAT FOR ROOSEVELT ELK, BLACK-TAILED DEER, AND OTHER WILDLIFE.2. MANAGE ELK POPULATIONS ON THE AREA TO BE COMPATIBLE WITH SURROUNDING LAND USE PRACTICES.3. PROVIDE QUALITY WILDLIFE ORIENTED RECREATIONAL AND EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO CONDUCT RESEARCH TO DEVELOP INFORMATION THAT MANAGERS CAN USE IN MAKING DECISIONSON HOW HABITATS OF ELK, MULE DEER, AND OTHER UNGULATES IN OREGON AND OTHER PORTIONS OF WESTERN NORTH AMERICA CANBE EFFECTIVELY MANAGED. DOCUMENTING RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN UNGULATES AND HABITAT CAN INFLUENCE LAND MANAGEMENTPRACTICES, TRAVEL MANAGEMENT PLANS, AND LONG-TERM FOREST OR HABITAT PLANNING. ADDITIONALLY, INVESTIGATIONS OFHABITAT USE CAN IDENTIFY CRITICAL LANDSCAPE FEATURES THAT ALLOW COVER AND ESCAPEMENT FROM HUNTING PRESSURE.FINALLY, HABITAT USE IS A CRITICAL FACTOR INFLUENCING POPULATION DYNAMICS OF UNGULATES AND DOCUMENTING HABITATUSE IS AN IMPORTANT FIRST STEP IN UNDERSTANDING UNGULATE POPULATION DYNAMICS.OUR CURRENT RESEARCH CONSISTS OF 9 DATA COLLECTION, ANALYSIS, MANUSCRIPT PUBLICATION, OR METHOD DEVELOPMENTTASKS: 1) COMPLETE A PUBLICATION ON HABITAT EFFECTIVENESS MODELS FOR ELK IN THE BLUE MOUNTAINS OF OREGON, 2)COMPLETE A PUBLICATION ON THE RESPONSE OF FEMALE MULE DEER TO HABITAT MANIPULATIONS, 3) COMPLETE A PUBLICATIONDESCRIBING MIGRATION CORRIDORS AND HABITAT USE OF PRONGHORN IN SUMMER AND WINTER, 4) CONDUCT ANALYSES TO ASSESSLONG-TERM SITE FIDELITY OF FEMALE MULE DEER, 5) CONDUCT ANALYSES TO ASSESS CHANGES IN ELK BODY FAT IN RELATION TOCLIMATE CHANGE, 6) COMPLETE A PUBLICATION DESCRIBING CHANGES IN UNGULATE FORAGE PHENOLOGY SINCE THE 1990'S, 7)MONITOR PLANT PHENOLOGY AT 9 PRE-ESTABLISHED PLOTS AND WITH A GRID OF 20 TRAIL CAMERAS, 8) SAMPLING MULE DEERFORAGE IN GRASSLANDS TO DETERMINE NUTRITIONAL QUALITY, AND 9) DEVELOP METHODS TO ASSESS UNGULATE DIETS.

THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES ISSUES ASSOCIATED WITH MULE DEER POPULATION DYNAMICS AND COMPETITION WITH ELK. MULE DEERHAVE HIGH RECREATIONAL, AESTHETIC, ECOLOGICAL, AND ECONOMIC VALUES IN OREGON AND THE WESTERN UNITED STATES.EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT OF MULE DEER REQUIRES AN UNDERSTANDING OF BASIC POPULATION METRICS SUCH AS SURVIVAL ANDRECRUITMENT OF FAWNS INTO ADULT AGE CLASSES AND FACTORS THAT INFLUENCE THOSE METRICS. THIS RESEARCH PROJECT WILLESTIMATE MULE DEER POPULATION METRICS INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, PREGNANCY RATES, FAWN SURVIVAL, AND DOESURVIVAL. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS RESEARCH ARE TO DETERMINE: 1) THE EFFECTS OF COMPETITION WITH ELK AND 2) WINTER NUTRITION ON MULE DEER POPULATION DYNAMICS.THIS RESEARCH WILL OCCUR IN TWO PHASES. DURING PHASE I (2013-2019), WE COLLECTED BASELINE POPULATION DATA (E.G.,BODY CONDITION, PREGNANCY, AND SURVIVAL) ON MULE DEER. WE WILL ENTER OUR NINTH YEAR OF COLLARING MULE DEERDURING WINTER 2022-2023. DURING PHASE II (WHICH BEGAN IN 2020), WE REDUCED THE ELK POPULATION IN THE STARKEYEXPERIMENTAL FOREST AND RANGE BY ~85% TO DETERMINE IF MULE DEER RESPOND POSITIVELY TO REDUCTIONS IN ELK DENSITY.WE REDUCED THE ELK POPULATION DURING WINTER OF 2019/2020 BY APPROXIMATELY 50% AND ACHIEVED AN ~85% REDUCTIONDURING THE WINTER OF 2020/2021. FOLLOWING ADDITIONAL DATA COLLECTION DURING YEARS WITH LOW ELK DENSITIES, WEWILL COMPARE PREGNANCY RATES, FAWN SURVIVAL, AND DOE SURVIVAL BEFORE AND AFTER A REDUCTION IN ELK POPULATIONS.ANY INCREASE IN MULE DEER POPULATION PERFORMANCE FOLLOWING REDUCTIONS IN ELK POPULATIONS, WILL PROVIDE COMPELLINGEVIDENCE THAT MULE DEER POPULATION GROWTH IS LIMITED BY COMPETITION WITH ELK.OUR RESEARCH IS ALSO DESIGNED TO DETERMINE THE EFFECTS OF WINTER NUTRITION ON MULE DEER POPULATION DYNAMICS.MULE DEER THAT VOLUNTARILY ENTER THE WINTER HANDLING FACILITIES AT THE STARKEY EXPERIMENTAL FOREST AND RANGE AREPROVIDED SUPPLEMENTAL FEED DURING WINTER. DEER THAT OVERWINTER IN MAIN STUDY AREA WILL NOT RECEIVE SUPPLEMENTALFEED. WE WILL COMPARE PREGNANCY RATES, FAWN SURVIVAL, AND ADULT SURVIVAL OF THESE TWO GROUPS TO DETERMINE IFWINTER FORAGE AND NUTRITION IS LIMITING MULE DEER POPULATION DYNAMICS. IF THIS LIMITATION IS OBSERVED, IT WILLSUGGEST WINTER FORAGE CONDITIONS ARE NOT SUFFICIENT TO MEET THE ENERGETIC DEMANDS OF MULE DEER.

THE OVERARCHING OBJECTIVE OF THIS RESEARCH PROJECT IS TO ASSESS COMPETITIVE INTERACTIONS AMONG CARNIVORES, THEIRABUNDANCE AND POPULATION DYNAMICS, AND THEIR ASSOCIATED EFFECTS ON PREY POPULATIONS. IT IS OFTEN IMPLIED THATCARNIVORES ARE IMPORTANT DETERMINANTS OF UNGULATE POPULATION DYNAMICS, BUT EMPIRICAL DATA SUPPORTING THIS CLAIMIS LIMITED. FURTHERMORE, THE COMPETITIVE INTERACTIONS BETWEEN CARNIVORES MAY INFLUENCE UNGULATE POPULATIONS ANDTHIS TOPIC IS NOT WELL STUDIED. THIS LACK OF KNOWLEDGE WAS THE IMPETUS FOR THIS RESEARCH AND WILL HELP IMPROVEMANAGEMENT OF BOTH PREDATORS AND THEIR PREY IN OREGON AND ELSEWHERE.WE WILL USE INFORMATION GAINED FROM THIS STUDY IN CONJUNCTION WITH OTHER ONGOING RESEARCH TO IDENTIFY FACTORSINFLUENCING DECLINING MULE DEER POPULATIONS. OUR PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO DETERMINE CARNIVOREDENSITIES, DIETS, AND COMPETITIVE INTERACTIONS AT THE STARKEY EXPERIMENTAL FOREST AND RANGE AND TO ESTIMATECARNIVORE DENSITIES AND ABUNDANCE AT TWO STUDY AREAS IN CENTRAL AND SOUTHERN OREGON. THROUGH THIS AND OTHERCOMPLEMENTARY RESEARCH, WE WILL DETERMINE THE ROLE OF PREDATION IN INFLUENCING POPULATION DYNAMICS AND HABITATUSE OF MULE DEER. WE WILL CONDUCT FIELDWORK DURING THE CURRENT PROJECT PERIOD TO DEVELOP AN EMPIRICAL DATA SETTO MEET PROJECT OBJECTIVES. INFORMATION GAINED FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE USEFUL IN IMPROVING MANAGEMENT OFCARNIVORES AND THEIR PREY IN OREGON AND OTHER PORTIONS OF WESTERN NORTH AMERICA. THIS RESEARCH WILL ALSO ASSESSTHE RESPONSE OF CARNIVORES TO A SUBSTANTIAL DECLINE IN AVAILABLE PREY BIOMASS (PRIMARILY ELK) AT THE STARKEYEXPERIMENTAL FOREST AND RANGE AS PART OF A CONTROLLED EXPERIMENT. CHANGES IN DIET, SPACE AND HABITAT USE, ANDDENSITY WILL BE MONITORED AS PART OF THE EXPERIMENTAL REDUCTION OF THE ELK HERD. DOCUMENTING CHANGES IN PREDATORRESPONSES TO PREY REDUCTIONS ARE IMPORTANT TO UNDERSTANDING HOW PREDATORS ARE LIKELY TO AFFECT THEIR PREYPOPULATIONS.WE ARE ALSO CONDUCTING WORK IN OTHER PORTIONS OF EASTERN OREGON IN THE BLUE MOUNTAINS AND SOUTHERN OREGON CASCADERANGE TO DOCUMENT ABUNDANCE AND DIET OF COUGARS, BLACK BEARS, AND COYOTES. THIS WORK WILL BE USED TO DETERMINESPATIAL DIFFERENCES IN ABUNDANCE AND HOW HABITAT MAY INFLUENCE DENSITY. THIS KNOWLEDGE WILL THEN BE USED TOIDENTIFY PRIMARY PREDATORS OF MULE DEER VIA PRESENCE IN SCAT AND ALSO PROVIDE ACCURATE INFORMATION ON DENSITIESTHAT COULD BE USED TO ALTER HARVEST RATES OF THE SPECIES. ADDITIONALLY, DATA COLLECTED AS PART OF THIS PROJECTWILL BE USED TO DETERMINE IF VARIATION IN PREDATOR ABUNDANCE EFFECTS MULE DEER SURVIVAL.

THERE IS A NEED TO IMPROVE, MAINTAIN AND RESTORE WILDLIFE HABITAT IN KLAMATH AND LAKE COUNTIES. WILDLIFE HABITATQUALITY IN OREGON HAS BEEN DEGRADED AND FRAGMENTED AS A RESULT OF DEVELOPMENT, AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES, TIMBERHARVEST, AND ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH INCREASES IN THE HUMAN POPULATION (OREGON CONSERVATION STRATEGY 2016).THE KLAMATH WATERSHED DISTRICT LANDS ARE MADE UP OF MULTIPLE PARCELS OF LAND OWNED AND/OR MANAGED BY VARIOUSENTITIES, AND VARY IN SIZE, LOCATION AND TOPOGRAPHY. ODFW MANAGEMENT ACTIVITY IS REQUIRED TO PROTECT, ENHANCE ANDRESTORE HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE SPECIES IN THE DISTRICT. IN 2008, HUNTERS AND NON-CONSUMPTIVE WILDLIFE USERS SPENTOVER $24 MILLION PURSUING WILDLIFE ON LANDS ADMINISTERED UNDER THIS PROGRAM. TECHNICAL ADVICE IS REQUIRED TO HELPCOORDINATE CONSERVATION EFFORTS ACROSS MANY LANDOWNERS, LOCAL, STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES. IF NOTHING WAS DONEHABITAT QUALITY WOULD CONTINUE TO DEGRADE, CONSERVATION EFFORTS WOULD BE FRAGMENTED AND WILDLIFE RELATEDRECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES WOULD BE DIMINISHED.THE STATEWIDE HABITAT PROGRAM IS ONE OF FOUR PRINCIPLE PROGRAMS WITHIN THE WILDLIFE DIVISION OF THE AGENCY.PROGRAM OBJECTIVES ARE TO PROTECT, MAINTAIN, AND ENHANCE WILDLIFE HABITAT TO MEET OREGON'S WILDLIFE POLICY BY: 1)MANIPULATING HABITAT, 2) ACQUIRING LAND, 3) DEVELOPING HABITAT MANAGEMENT AND RESTORATION TECHNIQUES, 4)PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO STATE, FEDERAL, TRIBAL, AND LOCAL AGENCIES AND INDIVIDUALS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO IMPLEMENT THE OBJECTIVES OF THE STATEWIDE PROGRAM WITHIN THE KLAMATH WATERSHED DISTRICT. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE PROVIDING WILDLIFE WATER IN XERIC HABITATS, CONTROLLING INVASIVE SPECIES, ASPEN GROVE FENCING,AND OTHER ACTIVITIES TO MAINTAIN HABITAT QUALITY AND WORKING WITH LANDOWNERS AND LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES TO PROTECT OR ENHANCE WILDLIFE HABITAT QUALITY.THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO PROTECT OR ENHANCE HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE WITHIN THE KLAMATH WATERSHED DISTRICT.MAINTAIN AND ENHANCE WILDLIFE HABITATS IN THE KLAMATH WATERSHED ON STATE, FEDERAL AND PRIVATE LANDS BY ASSISTINGOTHER GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND INVOLVING SPORTING ORGANIZATIONS AND EDUCATIONAL GROUPS INHABITAT IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS.REVIEWING AND COMMENTING ON LAND USE ACTIVITIES AND MONITOR WILDLIFE POPULATIONS.

ACQUIRE BY FEE TITLE APPROXIMATELY 494 ACRES OF LAND IN KINGMAN COUNTY, KANSAS. ADJACENT TO EXISTING STATE OWNED AND MANAGED BYRON WALKER WILDLIFE AREA. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPROVEMENT OF SOIL HEALTH AND HABITAT CONDITIONS, ENHANCEMENT OF GAME AND NON-GAME CARRYING CAPACITIES, INCREASED PUBLIC ACCESS, AND IMPROVEMENT OF UPLAND AND RIPARIAN PLANT SPECIES COMPOSITION. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE CONSTITUENTS WHO CAN DIRECTLY ACCESS AND ENJOY THE PROPERTY AND SURROUNDING LANDOWNERS WHO WILL BENEFIT FROM IMPROVED WATER QUALITY AND DECREASED SOIL EROSION. SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES AND BUSINESS OWNERS WILL BENEFIT FROM INCREASED AREA VISITATION.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONDUCT POPULATION MONITORING AND HARVEST MANAGEMENT OF WILDLIFE SPECIES THAT ARE HUNTED AND TRAPPED IN THE STATE. THE OVERALL GOAL IS TO MAXIMIZE SUSTAINABLE HUNTING AND TRAPPING OPPORTUNITIES, WHILE MINIMIZING HUMAN-WILDLIFE CONFLICTS. THIS WORK IS ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH A SERIES OF SURVEYS, CENSUSES, AND INVENTORIES TO MONITOR THE POPULATION STATUS AND HEALTH AND THE HARVEST OF THESE IMPORTANT RESOURCES. RESEARCH STUDIES PROVIDE NEW INFORMATION TO HELP BETTER UNDERSTAND THE BIOLOGY AND ECOLOGY OF THE SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS. THE INFORMATION AND KNOWLEDGE GAINED FROM THESE ACTIVITIES ARE USED TO GUIDE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS, TO MAKE HUNTING AND TRAPPING SEASON RECOMMENDATIONS TO THE DIRECTOR AND THE GOVERNOR, AND TO PROVIDE INFORMATION TO THE PUBLIC AND OTHER AGENCIES AND ORGANIZATIONS.
THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS FOR THE CONSERVATION OF PRAIRIE GROUSE AND THEIR ASSOCIATED HABITATS FOR MAINTAINING VIABLE POPULATIONS FOR PUBLIC ENJOYMENT AND USE IN NEBRASKA.

THE NORTH DAKOTA GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT WILL USE FUNDING FROM THIS PROJECT TO ADMINISTER PORTIONS OF THE PRIVATE LAND OPEN TO SPORTMEN PROGRAM. THE PRIVATE LAND OPEN TO SPORTMEN PROGRAM IS A VOLUNTARY HABITAT AND ACCESS PROGRAM THAT PROVIDES YEAR-ROUND, PUBLIC WALK-IN HUNTING ACCESS ON ENROLLED ACRES. IN ADDITION TO LANDOWNER PAYMENTS, THIS PROJECT ALSO INCLUDES EXPENSES INCURRED BY THE DEPARTMENT FOR GRASS SEED, TITLE WORK AND RECORDING FEES AS WELL AS STAFF SALARY, FRINGE AND EXPENSES. LOCATIONS OF THE ENROLLED TRACTS ARE PUBLISHED ANNUALLY IN THEPRIVATE LAND OPEN TO SPORTMEN GUIDE AND DISSEMINATED TO VENDORS ACROSS THE STATE.

THE 17,701-ACRE FERNANDEZ (UPPER) L-BAR RANCH PROPERTY RESTS ON THE NORTHEASTERN SLOPES OF MT. TAYLOR IN NORTHWESTERN NEW MEXICO AND SUPPORTS IMPORTANT YEARLONG AND SUMMER HABITAT AND MOVEMENT CORRIDORS FOR ROCKY MOUNTAIN ELK, MULE DEER, PRONGHORN, BLACK BEAR, WILD TURKEY, AND MANY OTHER SPECIES OF WILDLIFE. THE ACQUISITION OF THIS PROPERTY WILL CONSERVE THESE WILDLIFE HABITAT VALUES, WHILE INCREASING BIG GAME HUNTER OPPORTUNITY IN GAME MANAGEMENT UNIT 9.IMPORTANTLY, THIS PROPERTY CONNECTS THE MARQUEZ WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA TO THE SOUTH, WITH LANDS MANAGED BY THE CIBOLA NATIONAL FOREST AND BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT TO THE NORTH. TO CONSERVE BIG GAME HABITAT AND PROTECT MIGRATION CORRIDORS FOR ROCKY MOUNTAIN ELK, MULE DEER, AND OTHER WILDLIFE SPECIES, AS WELL AS PROVIDE SUBSTANTIAL WILDLIFE ASSOCIATED RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) IS COMPRISED OF SIX INLAND REGIONS AND ONE MARINE REGION. THE CENTRAL REGION WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (CRWMP) IS RESPONSIBLE FOR WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT ISSUES WITHIN THE 12 COUNTY REGION. THE PROJECT AREA WITHIN THE REGION INCLUDES THE COUNTIES OF STANISLAUS, TUOLUMNE, MERCED, MARIPOSA, MADERA, FRESNO, KINGS, TULARE, KERN, SAN BENITO, MONTEREY, AND SAN LUIS OBISPO. WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE THE COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS OF DATA REGARDING THE CONDITION OF WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND HABITATS, MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF GAME BIRDS AND MAMMALS, PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO OTHER AGENCIES REGARDING RESOURCE ISSUES, PUBLIC OUTREACH, AND PUBLIC USE. THESE RESPONSIBILITIES REQUIRE EXTENSIVE COMMUNICATION AND COORDINATION WITH OTHER AGENCIES, CDFW STAFF, AND THE PUBLIC.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) HAS TRUSTEE RESPONSIBILITY FOR MANAGING THE STATE'S DIVERSE WILDLIFE RESOURCES AS WELL AS THE HABITATS UPON WHICH THEY DEPEND. IN PART, THE WILDLIFE POLICY OF THE STATE IS TO PROVIDE BENEFICIAL USE AND ENJOYMENT OF WILDLIFE BY ALL CITIZENS; MAINTAIN DIVERSIFIED RECREATIONAL USES OF WILDLIFE, INCLUDING SPORT HUNTING; PROVIDE FOR ECONOMIC CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE CITIZENS OF THE STATE THROUGH REGULATED MANAGEMENT; AND MAINTAIN SUFFICIENT POPULATIONS OF ALL WILDLIFE SPECIES AND THE HABITAT NECESSARY TO ACHIEVE THE ABOVE-STATE OBJECTIVES (FISH AND GAME CODE SECTIONS 1801-1802). BIGHORN SHEEP, MOUNTAIN LION, AND MULE DEER ARE HIGH-PROFILE LARGE MAMMAL SPECIES OCCURRING WITHIN THE STATE. CONSERVATION OF THESE SPECIES IS CARRIED OUT BY THE CDFW JOINTLY THROUGH STATEWIDE AND REGIONAL WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS. CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES UNDERTAKEN BY THE CDFW INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO DESIGNING AND IMPLEMENTING POPULATION ASSESSMENT AND MONITORING SURVEYS; DESIGNING AND IMPLEMENTING RESEARCH PROJECTS; DESIGNING, COORDINATING, AND IMPLEMENTING HABITAT ENHANCEMENT PROJECTS; AND DISSEMINATING INFORMATION ON SPECIES OCCURRENCE, DISTRIBUTION, AND ABUNDANCE TO THE PUBLIC, STATE AND FEDERAL RESOURCE AND LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES, AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS.

A PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITY OF THE SOUTH DAKOTA DEPARTMENT OF GAME, FISH AND PARKS IS TO MANAGE ALL WILDLIFE SPECIESIN THE STATE TOWARD THE HIGHEST LEVEL POSSIBLE, CONSISTENT WITH LAND CARRYING CAPACITY AND COMPATIBILITY WITHSOCIAL TOLERANCES. A PREREQUISITE TO EFFECTIVE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT IS KNOWLEDGE OF POPULATION AND HABITATCHARACTERISTICS. SINCE WILDLIFE POPULATIONS ARE DYNAMIC DUE TO LAND-USE CHANGES, NATURAL CONDITIONS, MANAGEMENTEFFORTS, DISEASES, ETC., ANNUAL POPULATION AND HABITAT MONITORING IS REQUIRED FOR DETERMINING YEAR-TO-YEARFLUCTUATION AND LONG-TERM TRENDS, AND FOR EVALUATING CHANGES. OBTAINING NECESSARY INFORMATION ON THE DIFFERENTPOPULATION AND HABITAT PARAMETERS ALSO REQUIRES DIFFERENT TYPES OF SURVEYS BE CONDUCTED AT APPROPRIATE TIMES OFTHE YEAR. IN ADDITION, SURVEYS NEED TO BE CONDUCTED TO EVALUATE RESULTS OF SPECIFIC MANAGEMENT PRACTICES SUCH ASHUNTING SEASONS AND HABITAT MANIPULATION, WITH DIRECTION TOWARD INCREASED EFFECTIVENESS AND EFFICIENCY.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE STUDYING THE HABITAT USE AND NESTING SUCCESS OF WILD TURKEY HENS IN RELATION TO FOREST MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES.ULTIMATELY, THIS INFORMATION WILL LEAD TO IMPROVED MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS FOR PUBLIC AND PRIVATE FORESTS AND WOODLANDS THROUGHOUT ILLINOIS AND ELSEWHERE IN THE MIDWEST AND PROVIDE A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF WHETHER FOREST MANAGEMENT IS AFFECTING WILD TURKEY HABITAT USE, NESTING SUCCESS, AND ULTIMATELY POPULATIONS.UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS URBANA CHAMPAIGN IS AN EXPECTED SUBRECIPIENT OF THIS AWARD.

WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA'S ARE MANAGED TO PROVIDE BENEFITS TO RESOURCE USERS, NAMELY HUNTERS, TRAPPERS AND ANGLERS BUT ALSO GENERAL WILDLIFE ENTHUSIASTS. WELL-MANAGED FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES ARE IMPORTANT TOWILDLIFE SPECIES, AND TO PROMOTE BROAD-SCALE RESOURCE APPRECIATION, AND IMPROVED LOCAL ECONOMIES. THERE IS A NEED TO MANAGE, IMPROVE, AND MAINTAIN THE HABITAT RESOURCES ON THESE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA'S FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES, AND PUBLIC ACCESS TO THOSE RESOURCES MUST CONTINUE.

THE MALLARD (ANAS PLATYRHYNCHOS) IS THE MOST THE MOST ABUNDANT AND HARVESTED DUCK IN KANSAS. IT IS A FOCAL SPECIES FOR WETLAND MANAGEMENT, PARTICULARLY IN SOUTHEAST KANSAS. AS SUCH BETTER INFORMATION IS NEEDED ON WHEN THEY ARRIVE IN SOUTHEAST KANSAS, HOW LONG THEY STAY, AS WELL AS WHICH HABITATS THEY USE AND WHY THEY SELECT THOSE HABITATS. ONE HUNDRED ADULT FEMALE MALLARDS WILL BE CAPTURED AND FITTED TRACKING DEVICES TO RECORD ITS LOCATION AND ACTIVITY OVER 3 FIELD SEASONS, WITH EACH SEASON FIELD SEASON BEING OCTOBER THROUGH FEBRUARY. INFORMATION COLLECTED FROM THIS PROJECT WILL ASSIST PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LAND HABITAT MANAGEMENT, AID IN SEASON SETTING PROCESS, IMPROVE HUNTING AND BIRD WATCHING MANAGEMENT, ASSIST IN DIRECTING CONSERVATION PROGRAMS AS WELL AS ENERGY DEVELOPMENT.

THE KANSAS HUNTER EDUCATION PROGRAM IS DESIGNED TO PRODUCE SAFE, KNOWLEDGEABLE, RESPONSIBLE AND INVOLVED HUNTERS WHO WILL SUPPORT WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES THAT PRODUCE HEALTHY POPULATIONS OF WILDLIFE FOR THE ENJOYMENT OF THE PEOPLE OF KANSAS. BY PLACING BETTER TRAINED AND DEDICATED INSTRUCTORS INTO THE CLASSROOM, KANSAS HUNTER EDUCATION STUDENTS WILL BE PROVIDED A HIGHER QUALITY EDUCATION WITH MORE UNIFORMITY OF INSTRUCTION ACROSS THE STATE. LEGAL AND REGULATED HUNTING CONTINUES TO HAVE BROAD SUPPORT FROM THE PUBLIC. THROUGH OPEN DISCUSSIONS OF HUNTER ETHICS AND FAIR CHASE HUNTING METHODS WE CAN MAINTAIN THIS BROAD SUPPORT AND IMPROVE THE IMAGE OF HUNTERS AND HUNTING IN THE STATE. HUNTING AS AN ACTIVITY IS SAFE AND CONTINUES TO BE SAFER EACH YEAR, IT IS EXPECTED THAT HUNTER EDUCATION TRAINING WILL HELP TO FURTHER REDUCE THE STATE'S ALREADY LOW HUNTING INCIDENT RATE. BECAUSE EVERY HUNTING INCIDENT INVOLVES AN INDIVIDUAL PERSON, IT IS VITAL THAT WE CONTINUE TO WORK TO DECREASE THE NUMBER OF HUNTING-RELATED INCIDENTS THAT OCCUR EACH YEAR IN THE STATE, THUS CONTINUING TO MAKE THE ACTIVITY EVEN SAFER FOR ALL CITIZENS AND PREVENTING ADDITIONAL LOSSES FROM BEING INFLICTED ON FAMILIES.

THIS GRANT SUPPORTS THE EXPANSION OF AN EXISTING OUTDOOR ARCHERY RANGE LOCATED AT LONE PINE STATE PARK NEARKALISPELL, MT, AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF A NEW OUTDOOR ARCHERY RANGE ON THE WEST SIDE OF FLATHEAD LAKE AT BIG ARMSTATE PARK. THE EXPANSION AT LONE PINE WILL DOUBLE THE SIZE OF THE CURRENT RANGE AT THAT LOCATION, WHICH HAS SEENA SIGNIFICANT INCREASE IN VISITORS OVER THE PAST FEW YEARS. THE NEW PUBLIC ARCHERY RANGE AT BIG ARM WILL BE THEONLY ONE OF ITS KIND IN THE GREATER FLATHEAD LAKE REGION, AN AREA WITH EXCEPTIONALLY HIGH PUBLIC OUTDOORRECREATIONAL DEMAND.

ACROSS THE UNITED STATES, MANY GAME AND FISH AGENCIES ARE SEEING A CONSISTENT DECLINE IN THENUMBER OF LICENSES SOLD ANNUALLY FOR HUNTING-RELATED ACTIVITIES. FOR MONTANA, THIS TREND IS A CONCERNRELATIVE TO UPLAND GAME BIRD HUNTING, WHERE OUR LICENSE SALES FOR THIS ACTIVITY HAVE BEGUN TOSTAGNATE AND DECLINE OVER THE PAST 6 YEARS.DESPITE THE FACT THAT PUBLIC HUNTING ACCESS AVAILABILITY IN MONTANA REMAINS AT A HIGH LEVEL,OPPORTUNITIES SPECIFIC TO UPLAND BIRD HUNTING CAN OFTEN BE CHALLENGING, AS THE BEST LOCATIONS AREOFTEN FOUND ON PRIVATE, AGRICULTURAL LANDS WHICH MAY OFFER ONLY LIMITED (IF ANY) ACCESS TO THE PUBLIC.TO IMPROVE THIS SITUATION, THERE IS A NEED TO INCREASE THE OVERALL ACREAGE AVAILABLE TO THE GENERALPUBLIC WHERE BIRDS CAN SUCCESSFULLY BE HUNTED IN AN EFFORT TO STABILIZE AND POSSIBLY EXPAND UPLANDBIRD HUNTING INTEREST IN THE FUTURE.

THERE IS A NEED FOR ONGOING MAINTENANCE OF THESEPROPERTIES AS WELL AS THOSE IMPROVEMENTS WHICH CURRENTLY EXIST ON THEM TO ENSURE THAT THESE ASSETSAND IMPROVEMENTS CONTINUE TO SERVE THEIR INTENDED PURPOSE. WORK ITEMS REQUIRED TO MAINTAIN EACHSITE VARIES FROM SITE-TO-SITE; HOWEVER, THE MAJORITY OF WORK TO BE COVERED BY THE GRANT WILL INCLUDEWEED CONTROL AND ROAD, FENCE, PARKING AREA AND SIGN MAINTENANCE. THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO DEVELOP ANALYTICAL TOOLS TO SUPPORT AN ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM FOR ELK AND THE FACTORS THAT INFLUENCE ELK POPULATIONS AND DISTRIBUTION IN MONTANA. THESE TOOLS WILL ALLOW MANAGERS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND WHAT TYPES OF FACTORS INFLUENCE POPULATIONS AND DISTRIBUTIONS IN DIFFERENT ECOLOGICAL SYSTEMS AND DEVELOP MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS THAT INTEGRATE HABITAT MANAGEMENT, CARNIVORE HARVEST AND ELK HARVEST RECOMMENDATIONS TO ACHIEVE ELK POPULATION OBJECTIVES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT PROPOSAL IS TO PURCHASE A PROPERTY TO BE MANAGED AND DEVELOPED BY MONTANA FISH WILDLIFE AND PARKS. SCHEDULED DEVELOPMENT INCLUDES THE EXPANSION AND CREATION OF FURTHER SHOOTING AND ARCHERY RANGES FOR MONTANA'S SPORTSMEN AND WOMEN.
RECRUIT, RETAIN, AND REACTIVATE HUNTERS AND SHOOTERS TO ENSURE A SUSTAINED FUTURE FOR HUNTING AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION THROUGH GRANTS FOR OUTREACH EVENTS AND TARGETED ADVERTISING.

THIS PROJECT IS TO EDUCATE HUNTERS ON THE SKILLS AND ATTITUDES NECESSARY TO PRACTICE THE SPORT RESPONSIBLY BY PROVIDING TRAINING ON HUNTING AND SHOOTING EQUIPMENT SAFETY, HUNTER RESPONSIBILITIES AND KNOWLEDGE OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES. THE PROGRAM ALSO PRODUCES AND DISTRIBUTES INFORMATION REGARDING HUNTING AND SHOOTING SPORTS.

THIS PROJECT WILL COMPARE THE RELATIVE CONTRIBUTIONS OF MALE-MALE, MALE-FEMALE, AND FEMALE-FEMALE CONTACTS TO POTENTIAL DISEASE TRANSMISSION AMONG WHITE-TAILED DEER, LEARN MORE ABOUT THE BEHAVIOR OF COYOTES AND BOBCATS AND THEIR EFFECTS ON WHITE-TAILED DEER, AND LEARN ABOUT THE IMPACT OF MOUNTAIN BIKING ON DEER.RESULTS AND BENEFITS EXPECTED INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING:(1) UNDERSTANDING THE FULL PICTURE OF CONTACT PATTERNS AMONG DEER WILL AID MANAGERS IN DEVELOPING AND IMPROVING DISEASEMANAGEMENT STRATEGIES FOR THE ILLINOIS DEER POPULATION.(2) QUANTIFYING AND UNDERSTANDING THE EFFECTS OF RISING PREDATOR POPULATIONS ON DEER BEHAVIOR AND PRODUCTIVITY WILL IMPROVEMANAGERS' ABILITY TO PREDICT AND MANAGE FUTURE CHANGES IN DEER ABUNDANCE.(3) STARTING TO QUANTIFY THE POTENTIAL IMPACTS MOUNTAIN BIKING AND OTHER RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES HAVE ON DEER BEHAVIOR IN SOUTHERNILLINOIS.THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL PROVIDE VALUE TO THE RESIDENTS OF ILLINOIS BY IMPROVING MANAGERS' CAPABILITY TO UNDERSTAND AND MANAGE A POPULAR AND ECONOMICALLY IMPORTANT WILDLIFE SPECIES, BY PROVIDING NEW DATA AND MORE USEFUL TOOLS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND DEER BEHAVIOR AND HOW IT IMPACTS THEIR POPULATIONS AND DISEASES.SOUTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY AT CARBONDALE IS AN EXPECTED SUBRECIPIENT FOR THIS PROJECT.

THE DEPARTMENT HAS A STATUTORY OBLIGATION TO PRIORITIZE, MANAGE, AND CONSERVE 72 NONGAME AVIAN SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN, AS IDENTIFIED WITHIN THE 2019 STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN), IN ADDITION TO 12 STATE-ENDANGERED AND 20 STATE-THREATENED SPECIES (AS IDENTIFIED WITHIN THE 2020 BIENNIAL REVIEW). THE DEPARTMENT ALSO HAS AUTHORITY TO MANAGE OTHER NATIVE BIRD SPECIES, AND THEIR HABITATS, WHO SPEND PART OR ALL OF THEIR ANNUAL CYCLE IN NEW MEXICO. THE DEPARTMENT WILL COLLECT DATA AND EXERCISE STATEWIDE MANAGEMENT RESPONSIBILITY FOR NATIVE NONGAME BIRDS, INCLUDING SGCN AND/OR LISTED SPECIES, AND THEIR ASSOCIATED HABITATS IN NEW MEXICO SUCH THAT VIABLE POPULATION LEVELS ARE MAINTAINED FOR THEIR INTRINSIC, SCIENTIFIC, EDUCATIONAL AND RECREATIONAL VALUE.

NORTH CENTRAL REGION'S (NCR) WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (WMP) PERSONNEL ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR COLLECTING BIOLOGICAL DATA RELATED TO TERRESTRIAL WILDLIFE RESOURCES, DEVELOPING SCIENCE-BASED RECOMMENDATIONS FOR BIRD AND MAMMAL HUNTING REGULATIONS, AND PROVIDING TECHNICAL GUIDANCE AND EXPERTISE TO OTHER CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) PROGRAMS, OTHER AGENCIES, STAKEHOLDERS, PARTNERS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC. THIS GRANT WILL ALLOW FOR THE MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF BIG AND UPLAND GAME (COLLECTIVELY REFERRED TO AS GAME SPECIES) AND THEIR HABITATS IN SEVENTEEN NORTHERN CALIFORNIA COUNTIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO MAINTAIN FURBEARER, QUAIL, AND SMALL GAME POPULATIONS IN DELAWARE AT SUSTAINABLE AND SOCIALLY ACCEPTABLE LEVELS WHILE MAXIMIZING RECREATIONAL USE OF THE RESOURCES. ACTIVITIES SUPPORTED BY THIS PROJECT INCLUDE SURVEYS OF FURBEARERS, QUAIL AND SMALL GAME AS WELL AS TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO COMMITTEES, PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND ORGANIZATIONS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE SURVEY AND HARVEST INFORMATION AND ESTIMATES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE GENERAL PUBLIC. THERE ARE NO SUB-RECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

PROPER WATERFOWL MANAGEMENT IN MASSACHUSETTS AND THE ATLANTIC FLYWAY REQUIRES GATHERING INFORMATION ABOUT THE SPECIES INVOLVED. THIS IS ACHIEVED IN PART THROUGH BANDING AND OTHERWISE MARKING WATERFOWL TO TRACK MOVEMENTS, DETERMINE RECOVERY AND SURVIVAL RATES OF JUVENILE AND ADULT BIRDS AND CREATE A DATABASE FOR DEVELOPING APPROPRIATE MODELS USED IN WATERFOWL MANAGEMENT. POPULATION SURVEYS AND PERIODIC HUNTER SURVEYS ALLOW BIOLOGISTS TO ASSESS THE DESIRES OF STAKEHOLDERS WHILE ENSURING SUCH DECISIONS ARE BIOLOGICALLY SOUND. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PUBLIC WHO USE AND APPRECIATE THESE NATURAL RESOURCES. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

THE NEW MEXICO DEPARTMENT OF GAME AND FISH {DEPARTMENT) REVENUE BASE IS DERIVED FROM HUNTING AND FISHING LICENSE SALES, AND FEDERAL GRANT DOLLARS REIMBURSED FOR APPROPRIATE EXPENDITURES UNDER A SUITE OF WSFR PROGRAM GRANTS. WITHOUT FUNDING FROM THE WSFR PROGRAM THE DEPARTMENT WOULD NOT BE ABLE TO ADEQUATELY ADDRESS WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT ISSUES IN NEW MEXICO. IT IS EXTREMELY IMPORTANT THAT THE DEPARTMENT ADEQUATELY PROVIDE SUPPORT BY DEVELOPING A PROCESS WITH ASSIGNED RESOURCES FOR THE PURPOSE OF ENSURING THAT ALL FEDERAL PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS ARE ADHERED TO. AND THAT PROGRAM FUNDS ARE UTILIZED IN THE MANNER DESCRIBED IN FEDERAL AND STATE LAWS, REGULATIONS, AND POLICIES.

THE NEW "NATIONAL BOBWHITE QUAIL COORDINATED IMPLEMENTATION PROGRAM" IS UTILIZED BY AT LEAST 20 STATES TO ESTABLISH BOBWHITE FOCAL AREAS IN PRIORITY LANDSCAPE. NBCI'S BOBWHITE FOCAL AREA PROGRAM-THE COORDINATED IMPLEMENTATION PROGRAM, IS A SCIENCE-BASED INITIATIVE DESIGNED TO DEMONSTRATE CONCLUSIVELY THAT BOBWHITE POPULATIONS (AS WELL AS POPULATIONS OF OTHER SPECIES) CAN BE RECOVERED WHEN THE PROPER AMOUNT AND ARRANGEMENT OF HABITAT IS PROVIDED ON A LANDSCAPE SCALE.THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO ASSIST SOUTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES IN IMPLEMENTING BOBWHITE RECOVERY EFFORTS STATEWIDE THROUGH COLLABORATION WITH AND SUPPORT FROM THE NATIONAL BOBWHITE CONSERVATION INITIATIVE (NBCI). PROJECT OBJECTIVES FOR SC INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING: 1) DIRECTLY RESTORE, ENHANCE, CREATE OR MANAGE 1,500 ACRES BY JUN 30, 2022, 2) INFORM OR COMMUNICATE WITH 500 INDIVIDUALS BY JUN 30, 2022, 3) CREATE OR MANAGE 1 DATABASE BY JUN 30, 2022, AND 4)PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO 6 OTHER ORGANIZATIONS BY JUN 30, 2022.

OVER THE PAST FIVE YEARS, BIG GAME DRAW APPLICATIONS HAVE INCREASED AN AVERAGE OF 7% PER YEAR. WITH LIMITED BIG GAME TAGS FOR EVERY HUNTER WHO APPLIES, NEW AVENUES TO PURSUE RECRUITMENT, RETENTION AND REACTIVATION (R3) EFFORTS ARE NECESSARY TO CONTINUE TO INCREASE HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES AND THE RICH HUNTING HERITAGE IN NEW MEXICO. OPPORTUNITIES FOR SMALL GAME HUNTING, ESPECIALLY FOR UPLAND BIRDS AND WATERFOWL, ARE PLENTIFUL, AND LICENSE SALES ARE UNLIMITED. THEREFORE, A NEED EXISTS TO TRAIN NEW AND EXISTING HUNTERS TO BE SUCCESSFUL IN HUNTING SMALL GAME, TEACH SAFE SHOTGUN HANDLING AND MINIMIZE WOUNDING LOSSES OF WILDLIFE. TO THAT END, THE NEW MEXICO DEPARTMENT OF GAME AND FISH (DEPARTMENT) RECOGNIZES THE NEED TO INVEST IN SAFE AND PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE SHOTGUN SHOOTING RANGES IN THE STATE. WITHOUT THIS INVESTMENT, HUNTER PARTICIPATION MAY DECLINE DUE TO THE LACK OF AVAILABILITY FOR BIG GAME HUNTING AND A LACK OF KNOWLEDGE AND SKILL TO HUNT SMALL GAME PROVIDED BY WING SHOOTING PRACTICE. AS WELL, OPPORTUNITIES TO RECRUIT NEW HUNTERS WILL CONTINUE TO BE MISSED WITHOUT ACCESS TO A TRAINING FACILITY TO TEACH NEW HUNTERS SMALL GAME HUNTING SKILLS. OVERALL, THE POTENTIAL LOSS OF THESE HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES WILL ULTIMATELY LEAD TO THE LOSS OF LICENSE REVENUE AND OUR RICH HUNTING HERITAGE.

HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS BENEFIT A WIDE RANGE OF WILDLIFE SPECIES SUCH AS MULE DEER, ELK, PRONGHORN, WILD TURKEY, WATERFOWL, WITHADDITIONAL BENEFITS FOR OTHER GAME AND NON-GAME SPECIES. THESE OPPORTUNITIES NEED TO BE ACTIVELY DEVELOPED IN ORDER FORIMPLEMENTATION TO OCCUR AT A MEANINGFUL SCOPE, SCALE, AND PACE. TO COLLABORATE AND COORDINATE WITH AGENCIES IN THE PLANNING,DEVELOPMENT, AND DESIGN NECESSARY FOR SUCCESSFUL HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS THROUGHOUT NEW MEXICO. THESE EFFORTS SUPPORT ADVICEAND TRAINING TO PROJECTS THAT ARE INTENDED TO SUPPORT THE WILDLIFE RESOURCES OF NEW MEXICO VIA IMPROVEMENTS TO ECOSYSTEM HEALTHAND RESILIENCY, AND SITE-SPECIFIC HABITAT IMPROVEMENTS TO ADDRESS LIMITED HABITAT RESOURCES. DEPARTMENT STAFF WILL USHER THESEPROJECTS THROUGH THE PLANNING, DEVELOPMENT, DESIGN PHASES TO ENSURE THE PROJECTS BECOME SHOVEL READY FOR ONTHE-GROUND IMPLEMENTATION. THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE MAINTENANCE AND OPERATION OF 50 STATE-OWNED AND OPERATED PROPERTIES LOCATED THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF NEW MEXICO. THESE PROPERTIES ENCOMPASS A TOTAL AREA OF APPROXIMATELY 250,000 ACRES, AND THEY ARE EITHER OWNED OR COOPERATIVELY MANAGED BY THE NEW MEXICO STATE GAME COMMISSION. PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO RECRUIT AND RETAIN SAFE, RESPONSIBLE HUNTERS AND RECREATIONAL SHOOTERS BY PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES TO PARTICIPATE IN SHOOTING ACTIVITIES THAT ENCOURAGE FUTURE HUNTER PARTICIPATION AND CONTRIBUTIONS TO CONSERVATION.OBJECTIVES:1) TRAIN 125 YOUTH SHOOTING SPORTS COACHES BY JUNE 30, 2023.2) INTRODUCE 600 NEW YOUTH TO SHOOTING SPORTS BY JUNE 30, 2023.3) RETAIN 4,600 YOUTH PARTICIPANTS IN SHOOTING SPORTS BY PROVIDING SUPPLIES AND PROGRAMMING BY JUNE 30, 2023.4) SPONSOR 20 EVENTS TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR YOUTH HUNTERS AND RECREATIONAL SHOOTERS TO PRACTICE FIREARM SAFETY AND DEMONSTRATE PROFICIENCY BY JUNE 30, 2023.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: INCREASE IN HUNTER EDUCATION PARTICIPANTS, INCREASE IN PARTICIPATION IN HUNTING AND TARGET SHOOTING, INCREASE IN USE OF PUBLIC SHOOTING RANGES, REDUCTION IN WOUNDED GAME, INCREASE IN PUBLIC SUPPORT FOR WILDLIFE RESTORATION EFFORTSINTENDED BENEFICIARIES: YOUTH HUNTERS AND RECREATIONAL SHOOTERS IN ARKANSAS AND THE GENERAL PUBLICSUB-RECIPIENTS: NONE

LAND ACQUISITION TO AID IN THE CONSERVATION OF IMPORTANT WILDLIFE HABITAT AND THE CONSERVATION OF SEASONAL MOVEMENT CORRIDORS FOR ROCKY MOUNTAIN ELK (CERVUS CANADENSIS NELSONI), MULE DEER (ODOCOILEUS HEMIONUS), AND PRONGHORN (ANTILOCAPRA AMERICANA) NORTH OF MT.
